title: Between the World and Me
subtitle: Notes on the First 150 Years in America
long_summary:
In a profound work that pivots from the biggest questions about American history to the most intimate concerns of a father for his son, Ta-Nehisi Coates offers a powerful framework for understanding our nation's current crisis. Americans have built an empire on the idea of "race," a falsehood that damages us all but falls most heavily on the bodies of black women and men—bodies exploited through slavery and segregation, and today threatened, locked up, and murdered out of all proportion.

Between the World and Me is Coates's attempt to answer these questions in a letter to his adolescent son. He shares the story of his awakening to the truth about his place in the world through revelatory experiences, from Howard University to Civil War battlefields, from the South Side of Chicago to Paris, from his childhood home to the living rooms of mothers whose children's lives were taken as American plunder.

Beautifully woven from personal narrative, reimagined history, and emotionally charged reportage, this work illuminates the past, confronts our present, and offers a transcendent vision for moving forward.
short_summary: Coates writes to his teenage son about inhabiting a Black body in America, weaving personal narrative with historical analysis. A searing meditation on race that illuminates four centuries of American history through one father's urgent, necessary reckoning.
author_bios: Ta-Nehisi Coates is the author of The Beautiful Struggle, We Were Eight Years in Power, The Water Dancer, and Between the World and Me, which won the National Book Award in 2015. He is the recipient of a MacArthur Fellowship and lives in New York City with his wife and son.
quotes:
"I've been wondering who might fill the intellectual void that plagued me after James Baldwin died. Clearly it is Ta-Nehisi Coates. The language of Between the World and Me, like Coates's journey, is visceral, eloquent, and beautifully redemptive. And its examination of the hazards and hopes of black male life is as profound as it is revelatory. This is required reading."

—Toni Morrison

"Ta-Nehisi Coates is the James Baldwin of our era, and this is his cri de coeur. A brilliant thinker at the top of his powers, he has distilled four hundred years of history and his own anguish and wisdom into a prayer for his beloved son and an invocation to the conscience of his country."

—Isabel Wilkerson, author of Caste & The Warmth of Other Suns

"Brilliant . . . a riveting meditation on the state of race in America . . . [Coates] is firing on all cylinders, and it is something to behold: a mature writer entirely consumed by a momentous subject and working at the extreme of his considerable powers at the very moment national events most conform to his vision."

—The Washington Post

title: James
long_summary:
When Jim learns he's about to be sold to a man in New Orleans—separated from his wife and daughter forever—he flees to Jackson Island to formulate a plan. Meanwhile, Huck Finn has faked his own death to escape his violent father. Thus begins their dangerous journey by raft down the Mississippi River toward the elusive promise of the Free States.

While many elements from The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn remain—floods and storms, unexpected death and treasure along the river's banks, encounters with the Duke and Dauphin—Jim's agency, intelligence, and compassion emerge in radically new light. No longer a supporting character, Jim becomes the brilliant, complex protagonist driving this reimagined classic.

Brimming with Everett's electrifying humor and lacerating observations, James transforms American literature's most problematic friendship into something far more honest and profound.
short_summary: Everett reimagines Huckleberry Finn from Jim's perspective, transforming literature's most problematic friendship into something honest and profound. Both harrowing and ferociously funny, with Jim finally given the agency and intelligence he deserves.
author_bios: Percival Everett is Distinguished Professor of English at USC. His recent books include Dr. No (NBCC Award finalist and PEN/Jean Stein Book Award winner), The Trees (Booker Prize and PEN/Faulkner Award finalist), Telephone (Pulitzer Prize finalist), So Much Blue, Erasure, and I Am Not Sidney Poitier. He's received the NBCC Ivan Sandrof Life Achievement Award and Yale's Windham Campbell Prize. The film American Fiction, based on Erasure, won the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay. He lives in Los Angeles with writer Danzy Senna and their children.
quotes:
"Percival Everett is a giant of American letters, and James is a canon-shatteringly great book. Unforgiving and compassionate, beautiful and brutal, a tragedy and a farce, this brilliant novel rewrites literary history to let us hear the voices it has long suppressed."

—Hernan Diaz, author of Trust

"This is a brilliant, accessible, and very necessary companion to Huckleberry Finn."

—Dave Eggers, author of The Eyes and the Impossible

"James is funny and horrifying, brilliant and riveting. In telling the story of Jim instead of Huckleberry Finn, Percival Everett delivers a powerful, necessary corrective to both literature and history. I found myself cheering both the writer and his hero. Who should read this book? Every single person in the country."

—Ann Patchett

title: Sing, Unburied, Sing
long_summary:
Thirteen-year-old Jojo is trying to understand what it means to be a man. He studies his Black grandfather, Pop, but other figures complicate his understanding: his absent White father Michael, who's being released from prison; his White grandfather Big Joseph, who won't acknowledge his existence; and memories of his dead uncle Given, who died as a teenager.

Jojo's mother Leonie is an inconsistent presence in his and his toddler sister's lives. She's an imperfect mother in constant conflict with herself and those around her—Black, with a White partner, wanting to be better but unable to put her children above her own needs, especially her drug use. Simultaneously tormented and comforted by visions of her dead brother that only come when she's high, Leonie is embattled in ways that reflect the brutal reality of her circumstances.

When Michael is released from prison, Leonie packs her kids and a friend into her car and drives north to Parchman Farm, the State Penitentiary. There, another thirteen-year-old boy appears—the ghost of a dead inmate who carries the ugly history of the South with him. He too has something to teach Jojo about fathers and sons, legacies, violence, and love.
short_summary: Thirteen-year-old Jojo navigates a family road trip to pick up his father from Mississippi's notorious Parchman prison. Ward weaves together the living and the dead in prose that's both lyrical and unflinching.
author_bios: Jesmyn Ward received her MFA from the University of Michigan and has received the MacArthur Genius Grant, a Stegner Fellowship, the Strauss Living Prize, and the 2022 Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction. She won two National Book Awards for Fiction for Sing, Unburied, Sing and Salvage the Bones. She's also the author of Where the Line Bleeds and the memoir Men We Reaped, which won the Chicago Tribune Heartland Prize. She's a professor of creative writing at Tulane University and lives in Mississippi.
quotes:
"Ghosts, literal and literary, haunt nearly every page of Sing, Unburied, Sing — a novel whose boundaries between the living and the dead shift constantly, like smoke or sand. Set on the Gulf Coast of Mississippi (a place rich in oil rigs and atmosphere, if almost nothing else), the book's Southern gothic aura recalls the dense, head-spinning prose of William Faulkner or Flannery O'Connor. But the voice is entirely Ward's own, a voluptuous magical realism that takes root in the darkest corners of human behavior ... Ward, whose Salvage the Bones won a National Book Award, has emerged as one of the most searing and singularly gifted writers working today."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Sing, Unburied Sing is Ward's third novel and her most ambitious yet. Her lyrical prose takes on, alternately, the tones of a road novel and a ghost story ... Sing, which is longlisted for a 2017 National Book Award, establishes Ward as one of the most poetic writers in the conversation about America's unfinished business in the black South."

—The Atlantic

"The connection between the injustices of the past and the desperation of present are clearly drawn in Sing, Unburied, Sing, a book that charts the lines between the living and the dead, the loving and the broken. I am a huge fan of Jesmyn Ward's work, and this book proves that she is one of the most important writers in America today."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

title: Evicted
subtitle: Poverty and Profit in the American City
long_summary:
In Evicted, Princeton sociologist and MacArthur "Genius" Matthew Desmond follows eight families in Milwaukee as they struggle to keep a roof over their heads. Through intimate portraits of tenants and landlords, he reveals how eviction has become a business model—and how housing instability traps families in cycles of poverty.

Desmond spent months living in Milwaukee's poorest neighborhoods, documenting the daily reality of families facing impossible choices: pay rent or buy food, keep the heat on or avoid eviction. His reporting transforms abstract statistics into human stories, showing how the lack of affordable housing ripples through every aspect of life—from children's education to parents' ability to find work.

Hailed as "wrenching and revelatory" by The Nation and "vivid and unsettling" by the New York Review of Books, Evicted transforms our understanding of poverty and economic exploitation while providing fresh ideas for solving one of America's most devastating problems. Its unforgettable scenes of hope and loss remind us of the centrality of home, without which nothing else is possible.
short_summary: Following eight Milwaukee families through eviction court and precarious rentals, Desmond shows how housing instability isn't just a symptom of poverty—it's a cause. Riveting narrative meets agenda-setting research.
author_bios: Matthew Desmond is the Maurice P. During Professor of Sociology at Princeton University and founding director of the Eviction Lab. His book Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City won the Pulitzer Prize, National Book Critics Circle Award, and PEN/John Kenneth Galbraith Award. A MacArthur Fellow, he's also a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"After reading Evicted, you'll realize you cannot have a serious conversation about poverty without talking about housing. . . . The book is that good, and it's that unignorable."

—Jennifer Senior, New York Times

"This book gave me a better sense of what it is like to be very poor in this country than anything else I have read. . . . It is beautifully written, thought-provoking, and unforgettable."

—Bill Gates

"My God, what [Evicted] lays bare about American poverty. It is devastating and infuriating and a necessary read."

—Roxane Gay, author of Bad Feminist and Difficult Women

title: Homeland Elegies
long_summary:
A deeply personal work about identity and belonging in a nation coming apart at the seams, Homeland Elegies blends fact and fiction to tell an epic story of longing and dispossession in the world that 9/11 made. Part family drama, part social essay, part picaresque novel, at its heart it is the story of a father, a son, and the country they both call home.

Ayad Akhtar forges a new narrative voice to capture a country where debt has ruined countless lives and the gods of finance rule, where immigrants live in fear, and where the nation's unhealed wounds wreak havoc around the world. Through the lens of one family's story—from a heartland town in America to palatial suites in Central Europe to guerrilla lookouts in the mountains of Afghanistan—Akhtar attempts to make sense of it all, sparing no one, least of all himself, in the process.
short_summary: From the Pulitzer Prize-winning author comes a genre-bending work that follows an immigrant father and son searching for belonging in post-Trump America. Raw, ambitious, and unflinching in its examination of identity and home.
author_bios: Ayad Akhtar is a novelist and playwright whose work has been published and performed in over two dozen languages. He is the winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Drama, the Edith Wharton Citation of Merit for Fiction, and an Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
quotes:
"[A] moving and confrontational novel . . .  Homeland Elegies deals in ambiguities that were beyond the pale of public discourse in the years after 9/11. . . . He has an unerring sense for the sore spots, the bitter truths that have emerged from this history."

—Hari Kunzru, New York Times Book Review

"At the core of this flashing, kinetic coil of a story -- part 1001 Nights, part Reality TV -- is a passionate, wrenching portrayal of Americans exiled into 'otherness'."

—Jennifer Egan, author of Manhattan Beach and A Visit From the Goon Squad

"Homeland Elegies is the astonishing work of an absolutely brilliant writer. With exquisite prose and lacerating honesty, Ayad Akhtar reveals the intersections of art, finance, race, religion, academia, and empire, and in the process, shows us a troubled reflection of our country in the twenty-first century."

—Phil Klay, author of Redeployment

title: Say Nothing
subtitle: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland
long_summary:
Jean McConville's abduction was one of the most notorious episodes of the vicious conflict known as The Troubles. Everyone in the neighborhood knew the I.R.A. was responsible. But in a climate of fear and paranoia, no one would speak of it.

In 2003, five years after an accord brought an uneasy peace to Northern Ireland, a set of human bones was discovered on a beach. McConville's children knew it was their mother when they were told a blue safety pin was attached to the dress—with so many kids, she had always kept it handy for diapers or ripped clothes.

Patrick Radden Keefe's mesmerizing book uses the McConville case as a starting point for the tale of a society wracked by violent guerrilla war, whose consequences have never been reckoned with. The brutal violence seared not only people like the McConville children, but also I.R.A. members embittered by a peace that fell far short of a united Ireland, left wondering whether their killings were justified acts of war or simple murders.

From radical terrorists like Dolours Price, planting bombs in London while barely out of her teens, to the ferocious I.R.A. mastermind known as The Dark, to the spy games of the British Army and Gerry Adams, who negotiated peace but betrayed hardcore comrades by denying his I.R.A. past—Say Nothing conjures a world of passion, betrayal, vengeance, and anguish.
short_summary: Using one notorious killing as its foundation, Keefe excavates the brutal history of the Troubles and its lasting wounds. Masterful true crime that reads like a thriller while honoring the human cost.
author_bios: Patrick Radden Keefe is a staff writer at The New Yorker and author of New York Times bestsellers Rogues, Empire of Pain (winner of the Baillie Gifford Prize), and Say Nothing, which received a National Book Critics Circle Award and was named one of the Twenty Best Books of the 21st Century by The New York Times Book Review. He's received a Guggenheim Fellowship, the National Magazine Award, and the Orwell Prize, and served as executive producer on the award-winning FX series Say Nothing.
quotes:
"Meticulously reported, exquisitely written, and grippingly told, Say Nothing is a work of revelation. Keefe not only peels back, layer by layer, the truth behind one of the most important and mysterious crimes of a terrible conflict; he also excavates the history of the Troubles, and illuminates its repercussions to this day."

—David Grann, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Killers of the Flower Moon

"Patrick Radden Keefe's gripping account of the Troubles is equal parts true-crime, history, and tragedy. Keefe's incisive reporting reveals the hidden costs of the Troubles, illuminating both the terrible toll of the conflict, and how it continues to reverberate today. A must read."

—Gillian Flynn, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Gone Girl

"Resolutely humane. . .Say Nothing [has an] exacting and terrifying lucidity. . .meticulously reported. . .Keefe's narrative is an architectural feat, expertly constructed out of complex and contentious material, arranged and balanced just so. . .an absorbing drama."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

title: Building Stories
long_summary:
In an age of digital everything, sometimes we need something tangible to hold onto. This innovative graphic novel arrives as a beautiful keepsake box containing 14 distinct reading formats—books, booklets, magazines, newspapers, and pamphlets—that can be read in any order.

At its heart is a protagonist navigating the gap between the cramped quarters of lonely young adulthood and the possibility of love and commitment. Ware captures the crushing weight of missed opportunities and creative dreams deferred that haunts the literary middle class, whether you're alone by yourself or alone with someone else.

Collecting a decade of work from publications like The New Yorker, The New York Times, and McSweeney's, Building Stories includes dozens of never-before-published pages. The back cover features a pictographic guide to all 260 pages, complete with tongue-in-cheek suggestions for where to strategically abandon various components around your home. This groundbreaking work transforms reading into an active, non-linear experience that redefines what a graphic novel can be.
short_summary: An innovative graphic novel that arrives as 14 separate reading formats in a keepsake box, exploring loneliness and missed opportunities through Ware's masterful visual storytelling. Read in any order you choose.
author_bios: Chris Ware is widely acknowledged as the most gifted cartoonist of his generation. His Jimmy Corrigan: The Smartest Kid on Earth won the Guardian First Book Award and was listed as one of the 100 Best Books of the Decade by The Times (London). Building Stories was named a Top Ten Fiction Book by both The New York Times and Time magazine. He contributes to The New Yorker and has exhibited at the Whitney Biennial and Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.
quotes:
"Stunning . . . As usual, Mr. Ware's style is a model of compression in both word and picture. Less usual, for the genre as a whole, is the vividness with which he limns his heroine's intense, if fairly ordinary, inner life . . . The lack of clear structure, much less traditional linearity, turns reading into an unusually active process. This is a great, easily ownable work of art."

—The New York Times

"There's no writer alive whose work I love more than Chris Ware. The only problem is it takes him ten years to draw these things and then I read them in a day and have to wait another ten years for the next one."

—Zadie Smith, author of Swing Time & NW

"Ware provides one of the year's best arguments for the survival of print . . . the spectacular, breathtaking visual splendor make this one of the year's standout graphic novels."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Underground Railroad
long_summary:
Cora is a slave on a cotton plantation in Georgia. An outcast even among her fellow Africans, she faces the brutal realities of approaching womanhood. When Caesar, a recently arrived slave from Virginia, urges her to join him on the Underground Railroad, she seizes her chance at freedom.

In Colson Whitehead's ingenious conception, the Underground Railroad is no metaphor—engineers and conductors operate a secret network of actual tracks and tunnels beneath the Southern soil. Cora embarks on a harrowing journey from state to state, encountering strange yet familiar iterations of her world at each stop.

Whitehead brilliantly recreates the terrors of the antebellum era while weaving in the broader saga of our nation, from the brutal abduction of Africans to the unfulfilled promises of the present day. The Underground Railroad is both a gripping tale of one woman's will to escape bondage and a powerful meditation on the history we all share.
short_summary: Cora escapes slavery via Whitehead's literalized Underground Railroad—actual trains running beneath the antebellum South. Each state offers new horrors and revelations in this Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece.
author_bios: Colson Whitehead is the #1 New York Times bestselling author of twelve works of fiction and nonfiction, and two-time Pulitzer Prize winner for The Nickel Boys and The Underground Railroad, which also won the National Book Award. A MacArthur and Guggenheim fellow, he lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Terrific."

—Barack Obama

"A triumph."

—The Washington Post

"Potent. . . .  Devastating. . . . Essential."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

title: Bring Up the Bodies
long_summary:
Henry VIII has grown disenchanted with Anne Boleyn after seven years of battle to marry her. She has failed to give him a son, and her sharp intelligence and audacious will have alienated his old friends and England's noble families. When the discarded Katherine dies in exile, Anne stands starkly exposed—the focus of gossip and malice.

At a word from Henry, Thomas Cromwell is ready to bring her down. Over three terrifying weeks, Anne becomes ensnared in a web of conspiracy, while the demure Jane Seymour waits her turn for the poisoned wedding ring. But Anne and her powerful family will not yield without a ferocious struggle.

Mantel follows the dramatic trial of the queen and her suitors for adultery and treason. To defeat the Boleyns, Cromwell must ally with his natural enemies, the papist aristocracy. The question becomes: what price will he pay for Anne's head?
short_summary: Thomas Cromwell orchestrates Anne Boleyn's downfall in this masterful sequel to Wolf Hall. Mantel transforms familiar Tudor history into something fresh and terrifying, following three weeks of conspiracy that will end with an execution.
author_bios: Hilary Mantel was the author of Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies, both Booker Prize winners. The trilogy's final novel, The Mirror & the Light, debuted at #1 on the New York Times bestseller list. She wrote seventeen celebrated books, including the memoir Giving Up the Ghost, and won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction, Walter Scott Prize, Costa Book Award, and Hawthornden Prize. In 2014, she was appointed Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire. She died in 2022.
quotes:
"Two years ago something astonishingly fair happened in the world of prestigious prizes: the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction for 2009 both went to the right winner. The book was Hilary Mantel's Wolf Hall, and it would have dwarfed the competition any year…It was a hard act to follow. But the follow-up is equally sublime…That ironic ending will be no cliffhanger for anyone even remotely familiar with Henry VIII's trail of carnage. But in Bring Up the Bodies it works as one. The wonder of Ms. Mantel's retelling is that she makes these events fresh and terrifying all over again."

—The New York Times

"the finest works of historical fiction in contemporary literature."

—The Washington Post

"In Mantel's hands, Cromwell's cunning, morally complicated orchestration of that historic slice through the royal neck is as exciting as any thriller."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Behind the Beautiful Forevers
subtitle: Life, Death, and Hope in a Mumbai undercity
long_summary:
As India starts to prosper, the residents of Annawadi slum are electric with hope. Abdul, an enterprising teenager, sees "a fortune beyond counting" in the recyclable garbage that richer people throw away. Meanwhile Asha, a woman of formidable ambition, has identified a shadier route to the middle class. With a little luck, her beautiful daughter, Annawadi's "most-everything girl," might become its first female college graduate. Even the poorest children, like the young thief Kalu, feel themselves inching closer to their dreams.

But then Abdul is falsely accused in a shocking tragedy; terror and global recession rock the city; and suppressed tensions over religion, caste, sex, power, and economic envy turn brutal.

With intelligence, humor, and deep insight into what connects people to one another in an era of tumultuous change, Behind the Beautiful Forevers carries the reader headlong into one of the twenty-first century's hidden worlds—and into the hearts of families impossible to forget. Based on years of uncompromising reporting, this is narrative nonfiction at its finest.
short_summary: Families in a Mumbai slum chase dreams of prosperity as India transforms around them. Boo's immersive reporting reveals how global forces play out in individual lives with devastating clarity.
author_bios: Katherine Boo is a staff writer at The New Yorker and former reporter and editor for The Washington Post. Her reporting has been awarded a Pulitzer Prize, a MacArthur "Genius" grant, and a National Magazine Award for Feature Writing. For the last decade, she has divided her time between the United States and India. This is her first book.
quotes:
"[An] exquisitely accomplished first book. Novelists dream of defining characters this swiftly and beautifully, but Ms. Boo is not a novelist. She is one of those rare, deep-digging journalists who can make truth surpass fiction, a documentarian with a superb sense of human drama. She makes it very easy to forget that this book is the work of a reporter. . . . Comparison to Dickens is not unwarranted."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Riveting, fearlessly reported . . . [Behind the Beautiful Forevers] plays out like a swift, richly plotted novel. That's partly because Boo writes so damn well. But it's also because over the course of three years in India she got extraordinary access to the lives and minds of the Annawadi slum, a settlement nestled jarringly close to a shiny international airport and a row of luxury hotels."

—Entertainment Weekly

"It might surprise you how completely enjoyable this book is, as rich and beautifully written as a novel. In the hierarchy of long form reporting, Katherine Boo is right up there."

—David Sedaris

title: Trust
long_summary:
Even through the roar and effervescence of the 1920s, everyone in New York has heard of Benjamin and Helen Rask. He is a legendary Wall Street tycoon; she is the daughter of eccentric aristocrats. Together, they have risen to the very top of a world of seemingly endless wealth—all as a decade of excess and speculation draws to an end.

But at what cost have they acquired their immense fortune? This is the mystery at the center of Bonds, a successful 1937 novel that all of New York seems to have read. Yet there are other versions of this tale of privilege and deceit.

Hernan Diaz's Trust elegantly puts these competing narratives into conversation with one another—and in tension with the perspective of one woman bent on disentangling fact from fiction. The result is a novel that spans over a century and becomes more exhilarating with each new revelation.

At once an immersive story and a brilliant literary puzzle, TRUST engages the reader in a quest for the truth while confronting the deceptions that often live at the heart of personal relationships, the reality-warping force of capital, and the ease with which power can manipulate facts.
short_summary: Four nested narratives tell competing versions of a 1920s Wall Street tycoon and his wife's rise to power. Diaz crafts an ingenious literary puzzle that questions who controls stories and how money warps truth itself.
author_bios: Hernan Diaz is the Pulitzer Prize-winning and New York Times bestselling author of Trust. Translated into more than thirty languages, Trust also received the Kirkus Prize, was longlisted for the Booker Prize, and was named one of the 10 Best Books of the Year by The New York Times, The Washington Post, NPR, and Time magazine. His previous novel, In the Distance, was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. He has received a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Whiting Award, and the John Updike Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
quotes:
"Intricate, cunning and consistently surprising…Much of the novel's pleasure derives from its unpredictabiility...Add Henry James to Wharton, and Thomas Mann too...Exhilarating and intelligent novel."

—The New York Times

"The only certainty here is Diaz's brilliance and the value of his rewarding book…In execution it's an elegant, irresistible puzzle."

—The Washington Post

"Diaz understands, and deeply, how strange money is, as an omnipotent and imaginary substance that controls our lives. Trust glints with wonder and knowledge and mystery. Its plotlines are as etched and surreal as Art Deco geometry, while inside that architecture are people who feel appallingly real. This novel is very classical and very original: Balzac would be proud, but so would Borges."

—Rachel Kushner, New York Times bestselling author of The Mars Room

title: Thirteen Days in September
subtitle: Carter, Begin, and Sadat at Camp David
long_summary:
In September 1978, President Jimmy Carter brought together two unlikely partners at Camp David: Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Egyptian President Anwar Sadat. What followed were thirteen days of intense negotiations that would produce the first—and still enduring—peace treaty in the modern Middle East.

Lawrence Wright takes us inside each day of the historic conference, revealing the personal dynamics and political calculations that nearly derailed the talks multiple times. With his acclaimed journalistic skill, Wright illuminates the deep-rooted issues that have made Middle Eastern peace so elusive, while exploring the scriptural narratives that continue to frame the conflict.

Beyond the three main leaders, Wright draws vivid portraits of the colorful personalities working behind the scenes—including Moshe Dayan, Osama el-Baz, and Zbigniew Brzezinski—as well as the significant role played by Rosalynn Carter. What emerges is a riveting account of diplomatic persistence, showing how lifelong enemies found common ground and the profound difficulties that shaped both the process and its lasting consequences.

Thirteen Days in September offers both a timely revisiting of this diplomatic triumph and an insider's look at how peace is actually made.
short_summary: Wright delivers a riveting day-by-day account of the 1978 Camp David negotiations, when Carter brought together Begin and Sadat to forge the Middle East's first modern peace treaty.
author_bios: Lawrence Wright is a staff writer for The New Yorker, playwright, and screenwriter. He's the best-selling author of two novels, including Thirteen Days in September & The End of October, and eleven nonfiction books, including Going Clear, God Save Texas, and The Looming Tower, winner of the Pulitzer Prize. He lives in Austin, Texas.
quotes:
"It is brilliant penetrating scholarship. . . . Wright expertly captures every move of the three-way realpolitik chess match. By using each man's biography to illuminate the history of his respective nation, he not only chronicles Camp David but elucidates the issues that continue to plague the Middle East."

—Jeff Labrecque, Entertainment Weekly

"A unique moment in history superbly captured . . . a day-by-day account of the tense negotiations that shaped these historic talks . . . Yet another triumph for Wright."

—Kirkus

"Meticulously researched . . . almost nail-bitingly tense . . . an authoritative, fascinating, and relatively unbiased exploration of a pivotal period and a complicated subject."

—Publishers Weekly

title: A Visit from the Goon Squad
long_summary:
Bennie is an aging former punk rocker turned record executive. Sasha is the passionate, troubled young woman he employs. But this is just the beginning of Jennifer Egan's brilliant exploration of interconnected lives across decades.

With music pulsing through every page, Egan reveals the pasts and inner worlds of a host of characters whose paths intersect in unexpected ways. From 1970s punk scenes to a near-future where technology has transformed human connection, these stories weave together themes of time, memory, and the soundtrack that defines our lives.

This startling novel of self-destruction and redemption features characters you'll care deeply about as you watch them make mistakes, chase dreams, and act gloriously, infuriatingly human. Egan's virtuosic storytelling shifts perspectives and even narrative forms, creating a symphony of voices that captures how we're all connected by the music of our times.
short_summary: Interconnected stories spanning decades follow aging punk rocker Bennie and his troubled employee Sasha, plus a host of other characters whose lives intersect. Music pulses through this virtuosic exploration of time, memory, and human connection.
author_bios: Jennifer Egan is the author of six books of fiction: Manhattan Beach, winner of the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction; A Visit from the Goon Squad, which won the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award; The Keep; the story collection Emerald City; Look at Me, a National Book Award Finalist; and The Invisible Circus. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, and The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"A spiky, shape-shifting new book. . . . A display of Egan's extreme virtuosity."

—The New York Times

"Frequently dazzling. . . . Egan's expert flaying of human foibles has the compulsive allure of poking at a sore tooth: excruciating but exhilarating too."

—Entertainment Weekly

"If Egan is our reward for living through the self-conscious gimmicks and ironic claptrap of postmodernism, then it was all worthwhile. . . . [A] triumph of technical bravado and tender sympathy. . . . Turn up the music, skip the college reunion and curl up with The Goon Squad instead."

—The Washington Post

title: The Warmth of Other Suns
subtitle: The Epic Story of America's Great Migration
long_summary:
In this masterwork of narrative nonfiction, Pulitzer Prize–winning author Isabel Wilkerson presents a definitive account of one of the great untold stories of American history: the Great Migration of six million Black citizens who fled the South for the North and West from World War I to 1970.

Wilkerson tells this sweeping story through the lives of three unforgettable protagonists: Ida Mae Gladney, a sharecropper's wife who in 1937 fled Mississippi for Chicago; sharp and quick-tempered George Starling, who in 1945 left Florida for Harlem; and Robert Foster, a surgeon who departed Louisiana in 1953 hoping to make it in California.

Wilkerson brilliantly captures their treacherous cross-country journeys by car and train and their new lives in unfamiliar territory. Through the breadth of its narrative, the beauty of the writing, the depth of its research, and the fullness of the people portrayed, this book transforms an "unrecognized immigration" within our own land into a deeply human story of courage, loss, and hope.
short_summary: Through three deeply personal stories, Wilkerson transforms the Great Migration into intimate human drama. Six million journeys from South to North become unforgettable individual portraits of courage and reinvention.
author_bios: Isabel Wilkerson, winner of the Pulitzer Prize and the National Humanities Medal, is the author of the critically acclaimed New York Times bestseller The Warmth of Other Suns, which won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Nonfiction and was named to Time's 10 Best Nonfiction Books of the 2010s. She has taught at Princeton, Emory, and Boston Universities and has lectured at more than two hundred colleges and universities worldwide.
quotes:
"A landmark piece of nonfiction . . . [Isabel Wilkerson's] closeness with, and profound affection for, her subjects reflect her deep immersion in their stories and allow the reader to share that connection."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"[An] extraordinary and evocative work."

—The Washington Post

"[An] indelible and compulsively readable portrait of race, class, and politics in twentieth-century America. History is rarely distilled so finely."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: The Yellow House
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In 1961, Sarah M. Broom's mother Ivory Mae bought a shotgun house in the promising neighborhood of New Orleans East and built her world inside it. It was the height of the Space Race, and the neighborhood housed a major NASA plant—postwar optimism seemed assured. Widowed, Ivory Mae remarried Sarah's father Simon Broom, and their combined family would eventually number twelve children. But after Simon died six months after Sarah's birth, the Yellow House would become Ivory Mae's thirteenth and most unruly child.

Broom's ambitious memoir tells a hundred years of her family's relationship to home in a neglected area of one of America's most mythologized cities. This is the story of a mother's struggle against a house's entropy, and of a daughter who left home only to reckon with its pull—even after Hurricane Katrina wiped the Yellow House off the map. Located in the gap between the "Big Easy" of tourist guides and the New Orleans where Broom was raised, this transformative memoir explores place, class, race, and the seeping rot of inequality with startling clarity and power.
short_summary: A transformative memoir about family, place, and the inexorable pull of home, centered on a shotgun house in New Orleans East. Broom traces a hundred years of history through her family's relationship to a house that became both sanctuary and burden.
author_bios: Sarah M. Broom's work has appeared in the New Yorker, The New York Times Magazine, The Oxford American, and O, The Oprah Magazine. A native New Orleanian, she received her Masters in Journalism from UC Berkeley in 2004. She was awarded a Whiting Foundation Creative Nonfiction Grant in 2016, was a NYFA Fellowship finalist in 2011, and has received fellowships at Djerassi and MacDowell. She lives in New York state.
quotes:
"[A] forceful, rolling and many-chambered new memoir.... [Broom's] memoir isn't just a Katrina story — it has a lot more on its mind. But the storm and the way it scattered her large family across America give this book both its grease and its gravitas.... This book is dense with characters and stories. It's a big, simmering pot that comes to a boil at the right times.... This is a major book that I suspect will come to be considered among the essential memoirs of this vexing decade. There are a lot of complicated emotions coursing through its veins. It throws the image of an exceptional American city into dark relief."

—New York Times

"One of the year's best memoirs, The Yellow House finds an epic, fascinating, empathetic history of New Orleans within the life of one woman, her family, and the home they grew up in...The book is at once intimate and sprawling, spinning at times dozens of stories in what amounts to a vital reframing of a misrepresented community, and an urgent meditation on the American dream."

—David Canfield, Entertainment Weekly

"A heartfelt but unflinching recovery project . . . Broom's lyrical style celebrates her family bonds, but a righteous fury runs throughout the narrative at New Orleans' injustices, from the foundation on up. A tribute to the multitude of stories one small home can contain, even one bursting with loss."

—Kirkus

title: Washington Black
long_summary:
Eleven-year-old George Washington Black—called Wash—is a field slave on a Barbados sugar plantation when he's chosen as manservant to his master's eccentric brother. To his surprise, Christopher Wilde proves to be a naturalist, explorer, inventor, and abolitionist who introduces Wash to a world of flying machines and scientific wonder—a world where even a boy born in chains might embrace dignity and meaning.

But when a man is killed and a bounty is placed on Wash's head, they must flee together. Their escape becomes an epic journey that spans the Caribbean to the frozen Arctic, London to Morocco. What initially brings them together will ultimately tear them apart, propelling Wash ever farther across the globe in search of his true identity.

This is a story of self-invention and betrayal, of love and redemption, and of finding wholeness in a world that seeks to destroy it.
short_summary: When a young slave becomes manservant to his master's abolitionist brother, their unlikely bond leads to adventure and betrayal across continents. Epic historical fiction about freedom, identity, and what it means to be truly human.
author_bios: Esi Edugyan is the internationally bestselling author of Washington Black, which won the Scotiabank Giller Prize and was a finalist for the Man Booker Prize and Rogers Writers' Trust Fiction Prize. Her novel Half-Blood Blues also won the Scotiabank Giller Prize and was a Man Booker Prize finalist. She's held fellowships across the U.S. and Europe and lives in Victoria, British Columbia.
quotes:
"A thrilling page-turner . . . also a lyrical contemplation of captivity and freedom, and the scars that stay with us for life."

—Marsha Lederman, Globe & Mail

"Edugyan's magnificent third novel again demonstrates her range and gifts . . . Framing the story with rich evocations of the era's science and the world it studies, Edugyan mines the tensions between individual goodwill and systemic oppression, belonging and exclusion, wonder and terror, and human and natural order . . . Crafted in supple, nuanced prose, Edugyan's novel is both searing and beautiful."

—Publishers Weekly

"High adventure fraught with cliffhanger twists marks this runaway-slave narrative, which leaps, sails, and soars from Caribbean cane fields to the fringes of the frozen Arctic and across a whole ocean . . . One of the most unconventional escapes from slavery ever chronicled . . . Edugyan displays as much ingenuity and resourcefulness as her main characters in spinning this yarn, and the reader's expectations are upended almost as often as her hero's. A thoughtful, boldly imagined ripsnorter that broadens inventive possibilities for the antebellum novel."

—Kirkus

title: There There
long_summary:
Twelve Native Americans converge on the Big Oakland Powwow, each carrying their own story of survival and connection. Among them is Jacquie Red Feather, newly sober and trying to make it back to the family she left behind. Dene Oxendene is pulling his life together after his uncle's death, working at the powwow to honor his memory. Fourteen-year-old Orvil comes to perform traditional dance for the very first time.

They collide on one fateful day, and together this chorus of voices tells of the plight of urban Native Americans—grappling with complex and painful history, with an inheritance of beauty and spirituality, with communion and sacrifice and heroism. Fierce, funny, and suspenseful, Orange's debut explodes onto the page with urgency and force. There There is at once poignant and unflinching, utterly contemporary and impossible to put down.
short_summary: Twelve Native Americans from different walks of life converge on the Big Oakland Powwow in this explosive debut. Orange weaves their stories into a devastating portrait of urban Indigenous life—full of poetry, rage, and unflinching honesty.
author_bios: Tommy Orange is a graduate of the MFA program at the Institute of American Indian Arts. An enrolled member of the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma, he was born and raised in Oakland, California. His first book, There There, was a finalist for the 2019 Pulitzer Prize and received the 2019 American Book Award.
quotes:
"Bravura… There There has so much jangling energy and brings so much news from a distinct corner of American life that it's a revelation… its appearance marks the passing of a generational baton."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"There There drops on us like a thunderclap; the big, booming, explosive sound of 21st century literature finally announcing itself. Essential."

—Marlon James, author of A Brief History of Seven Killings

"Commanding...The propulsion of both the overall narrative and its players are breathtaking as Orange unpacks how decisions of the past mold the present, resulting in a haunting and gripping story."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Five Days at Memorial
subtitle: Life and Death in a Storm-Ravaged Hospital
long_summary:
When Hurricane Katrina struck New Orleans, Memorial Medical Center became a nightmare of rising floodwaters, failed power, and crushing heat. Physician and reporter Sheri Fink reconstructs five harrowing days when exhausted caregivers faced impossible choices about who to save first—and who to leave behind.

In the chaos of evacuation, certain patients were designated last for rescue. Months later, several doctors and nurses faced criminal allegations that they had deliberately hastened deaths by injecting patients with lethal doses of drugs.

The culmination of six years of meticulous reporting, Five Days at Memorial unravels the mystery of what really happened during those desperate hours. Fink draws readers into a hospital fighting for survival while exposing the hidden ethical dilemmas of end-of-life care and our dangerous unpreparedness for large-scale disasters.

With a voice both involving and fair, masterful and intimate, this remarkable investigation transforms our understanding of human nature in crisis and challenges us to do better when catastrophe strikes.
short_summary: Physician-journalist Sheri Fink's Pulitzer Prize-winning investigation into the patient deaths at Memorial Medical Center during Hurricane Katrina. A gripping blend of medical ethics, legal drama, and disaster reporting.
author_bios: Sheri Fink is the New York Times bestselling author of Five Days at Memorial and War Hospital. A correspondent at The New York Times, her reporting on the West Africa Ebola crisis earned a Pulitzer Prize for international reporting. Her story "The Deadly Choices at Memorial" received the Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting and a National Magazine Award. A former relief worker in disaster zones, Fink holds an M.D. and Ph.D. from Stanford University.
quotes:
"Dr. Fink more than delivers. She writes with a seasoned sense of how doctors and nurses improvise in emergencies, and about the ethical realms in which they work. The first half of this book, which is well paced, covers the five days of the title. Then the viewfinder shifts to an entwined legal and political story in which state authorities pursue a homicide investigation. That so many people, starkly divided over the question of whether crimes had been committed, come off as decent and appealing makes this book an absorbing read. Dr. Fink brings a shimmering intelligence to its many narrative cul-de-sacs, which consider medical, legal and ethical issues…. By reporting the depth of those gruesome hours in Memorial before the helicopters came, and giving weight to medical ethics as grounded in the law, Sheri Fink has written an unforgettable story. Five Days at Memorial is social reporting of the first rank."

—Jason Berry, New York Times

"[Fink] has shaped her research into an elegant narrative, Five Days at Memorial, with all the page-turning pull of a novel, no easy feat given the complexity of the story… riveting."

—Entertainment Weekly

"In this astonishing blend of Pulitzer Prize–winning journalism (Fink, who also has an M.D. and Ph.D., won the award for the investigative reporting on which this book is based) and breathtaking narration, she chronicles the chaotic evacuation of the hospital and the agonizing ethical, physical, and emotional quandaries facing Memorial nurses and doctors, including a nightmarish triage process that led to the controversial decision to inject critically ill patients with fatal doses of morphine in order to refocus attention on those with a chance of surviving."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Story of the Lost Child
long_summary:
The Story of the Lost Child concludes the dazzling saga of two women whose friendship has weathered decades of change, betrayal, and growth. Elena and Lila first met amid the shambles of postwar Italy—one brilliant and bookish, the other fiery and uncontainable.

By this final volume, life's great discoveries have been made and its losses suffered. Both women once fought to escape their Naples neighborhood. Elena married, moved to Florence, started a family, and published several well-received books. But now she has returned to Naples to be with the man she has always loved.

Lila never succeeded in freeing herself from the city. She has become a successful entrepreneur, but her success draws her into closer proximity with the nepotism, chauvinism, and criminal violence that infect her neighborhood. Yet somehow, this proximity to a world she has always rejected only brings her role as unacknowledged leader into sharper relief.

Through it all, the women's friendship remains the gravitational center of their lives—a bond that has shaped them both in ways they're only beginning to understand.
short_summary: Elena returns to Naples after decades away, drawn back to both the man she's always loved and her complicated friendship with Lila. The final volume of Ferrante's acclaimed quartet.
author_bios: Elena Ferrante is the author of The Days of Abandonment, Troubling Love, and The Lost Daughter, all adapted for film. Her works include Frantumaglia: A Writer's Journey, Incidental Inventions, and the children's book The Beach at Night. The Neapolitan quartet—My Brilliant Friend, The Story of a New Name, Those Who Leave and Those Who Stay, and The Story of the Lost Child—was published by Europa Editions between 2012 and 2015. My Brilliant Friend became an HBO series in 2018.
quotes:
"The conclusion of Ferrante's four-book saga defies the laws of diminishing returns, illuminating the twined psychologies of its central pair—intractable, indelible, inseparable—in one last blast of X-ray prose."

—The New York Times

"It's spectacular, but you will only realize how spectacular The Story of the Lost Child is if you do not cheat. You must read the three earlier (also superb) Neapolitan Novels or the perfect devastation wrought by the conclusion of this last novel will be lost on you."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"The Neapolitan novel cycle is an unconditional masterpiece."

—Jhumpa Lahiri

title: Going Clear
subtitle: Scientology, Hollywood, and the Prison of Belief
long_summary:
A penetrating investigation into the Church of Scientology by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Looming Tower. Based on more than two hundred interviews with current and former Scientologists and years of archival research, Wright uncovers the inner workings of one of America's most controversial religious movements.

At the book's center are two men who shaped Scientology: L. Ron Hubbard, the restless science-fiction writer who invented a new religion, and his successor David Miscavige, tasked with preserving the church after Hubbard's death. Wright explores Scientology's complex cosmology and specialized language, reveals how the church pursues celebrities like Tom Cruise and John Travolta, and introduces us to young idealists who join the Sea Org clergy with billion-year contracts.

Going Clear examines what fundamentally makes a religion a religion, and whether Scientology deserves constitutional protection. With exceptional journalistic skill, Wright delivers an evenhanded yet incisive narrative that reveals the essence of this enigmatic institution.
short_summary: Wright's meticulous investigation exposes the inner workings of Scientology, from L. Ron Hubbard's origins to celebrity recruitment and billion-year contracts. Fearless journalism meets stranger-than-fiction reality.
author_bios: Lawrence Wright is a staff writer for The New Yorker, playwright, and screenwriter. He's the best-selling author of two novels, including Thirteen Days in September & The End of October, and eleven nonfiction books, including Going Clear, God Save Texas, and The Looming Tower, winner of the Pulitzer Prize. He lives in Austin, Texas.
quotes:
"An eye-opening short biography of Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard and a long-form journalism presentation of the creature Hubbard birthed: a self-help system complete with bizarre cosmology, celebrity sex appeal, lawyers, consistent allegation of physical abuse, and expensive answers for spiritual consumers."

—Publishers Weekly

"A hotly compelling read. It's a minutiae-packed book full of wild stories."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Lawrence Wright brings a clear-eyed investigative fearlessness to Scientology—its history, theology, its hierarchy—and the result is . . . evidence that truth can be stranger even than science fiction."

—Lisa Miller, The Washington Post

title: All Fours
long_summary:
A semi-famous artist announces her plan to drive cross-country from LA to New York. Thirty minutes after leaving her husband and child at home, she spontaneously exits the freeway, checks into a nondescript motel, and immerses herself in an entirely different journey.

Miranda July's second novel confirms the brilliance of her singular approach to fiction. With July's wry voice, perfect comic timing, and unabashed curiosity about human intimacy, All Fours tells the story of one woman's quest for a new kind of freedom.

Part absurd entertainment, part tender reinvention of the sexual, romantic, and domestic life of a forty-five-year-old female artist, All Fours transcends expectation while excavating our beliefs about life lived as a woman. July hijacks the familiar and turns it into something thrillingly, profoundly alive.
short_summary: When a semi-famous artist abandons her cross-country road trip thirty minutes in, checking into a roadside motel instead, chaos and reinvention follow. July's brilliant second novel mines desire, identity, and midlife with characteristic wit and unflinching intimacy.
author_bios: Miranda July is a writer, filmmaker, and artist. The recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship and one of TIME magazine's "100 most influential people of 2025," she is the New York Times bestselling author of two novels, All Fours and The First Bad Man, and one story collection, No One Belongs Here More Than You. All Fours was named a finalist for the National Book Award, the Women's Prize, and the Carol Shields Prize for Fiction. She lives in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"All Fours has spurred a whisper network of women fantasizing about desire and freedom...It's the talk of every group text."

—The New York Times

"A giddy, bold, mind-blowing tour de force by one of our most important literary writers."

—George Saunders, Booker-Prize winning author of Lincoln in the Bardo

"Characteristically witty, startlingly intimate. . .This tender, strange treatise on getting out from the 'prefab structures' of a conventional life is quintessentially July."

—Kirkus

title: On Immunity
subtitle: An Inoculation
long_summary:
Upon becoming a new mother, Eula Biss confronts a chronic condition of fear—fear of the government, the medical establishment, and what lurks in her child's air, food, mattress, medicine, and vaccines. She discovers that you cannot immunize your child, or yourself, from the world.

In this bold investigation, Biss explores the metaphors and myths surrounding our conception of immunity and its implications for both the individual and the social body. As she hears mounting fears about vaccines, Biss researches what they mean for her own child, her immediate community, America, and the world, both historically and in the present moment.

She extends conversations with other mothers into meditations on Voltaire's Candide, Bram Stoker's Dracula, Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, Susan Sontag's AIDS and Its Metaphors, and beyond. On Immunity is a moving account of how we are all interconnected—our bodies and our fates.
short_summary: New motherhood sparks an investigation into vaccine fears and the mythology of immunity. Biss weaves personal anxiety with cultural criticism, revealing how our bodies and fates remain inescapably interconnected.
author_bios: Eula Biss is the author of four books, including the New York Times bestseller On Immunity: An Inoculation, named one of the 10 Best Books of 2014 by The New York Times Book Review, and Notes from No Man's Land: American Essays, winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award for criticism. Her work has appeared in Harper's Magazine, The New York Times, and The Believer, supported by NEA Literature, Howard Foundation, and Guggenheim fellowships.
quotes:
"On Immunity casts a spell...There's drama in watching this smart writer feel her way through this material. She's a poet, an essayist, and a class spy. She digs honestly into her own psyche and into those of 'people like me, ' and she reveals herself as believer and apostate, moth and flame."

—The New York Times

"Biss, while making an unimpeachable case for childhood vaccination, delves into the metaphors that accompany notions of purity and invasion and recounts the medical history of vaccine development. It's a touching personal story that seeks to understand why the antivax crowd exists and why it's such a well-meaning, if misguided, movement."

—Publishers Weekly

"Biss ably tracks the progress of immunization...Biss also administers a thoughtful, withering critique to more recent fears of vaccines--the toxins they carry, from mercury to formaldehyde, and accusations of their role in causing autism. The author keeps the debate lively and surprising...but arrives at a clear point of view: Vaccinate. Brightly informative, giving readers a sturdy platform from which to conduct their own research and take personal responsibility."

—Kirkus

title: The Passage of Power
subtitle: The Years of Lyndon Johnson
long_summary:
The Passage of Power follows Lyndon Johnson through the most frustrating and triumphant period of his career—1958 to 1964. This spans his transition from the extraordinary power he wielded as Senate Majority Leader to the humiliating powerlessness of serving as Vice President in an administration that disdained him, and finally to the presidency thrust upon him by an assassin's bullet.

By 1958, Johnson was maneuvering for the presidency, known as one of the most brilliant politicians of his time and the greatest Senate Leader in American history. But the 1960 nomination went to John F. Kennedy. Caro provides an unparalleled account of the machinations behind Kennedy's decision to offer Johnson the vice presidency, revealing Robert Kennedy's efforts to force Johnson off the ticket and exposing the savage animosity between the two men.

For the first time, Caro's breathtaking narrative shows us the Kennedy assassination through Johnson's eyes. We watch him inherit a staff loyal to his predecessor, a resistant Congress, and a nation in shock. Within weeks, grasping the presidency with supreme mastery, he propels essential legislation through Congress and creates the revolutionary War on Poverty. This was Johnson's finest hour, before Vietnam would overshadow his accomplishments.
short_summary: Caro's masterful fourth volume chronicles Johnson's transformation from powerless Vice President to commanding President following Kennedy's assassination. Epic in scope, intimate in detail, and essential for understanding American political power.
genres: Biography & Autobiography / Presidents & Heads Of State
author_bios: Robert A. Caro has twice won the Pulitzer Prize for Biography for his work on Robert Moses and Lyndon Johnson. He has three times won the National Book Critics Circle Award and has received virtually every major literary honor, including the National Book Award, the Gold Medal in Biography from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and the Francis Parkman Prize. In 2010, he received the National Humanities Medal from President Barack Obama.
quotes:
"By writing the best presidential biography the country has ever seen, Caro has forever changed the way we think, and read, American history . . . Although the amount of research Caro has done for these books is staggering, it's his immense talent as a writer that has made his biography of Johnson one of America's most amazing literary achievements . . . Caro's chronicle is as absorbing as a political thriller . . . There's not a wasted word, not a needless anecdote . . . Most impressively, Caro comes closer than any other historian could to explaining the famously complex LBJ . . . Caro's portrayal of the president is as scrupulously fair as it is passionate and deeply felt . . . The series is a masterpiece, unlike any other work of American history published in the past. It's true that there will never be another Lyndon B. Johnson, but there will never be another Robert A. Caro, either."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"A breathtakingly dramatic story about a pivotal moment in United States history [told] with consummate artistry and ardor . . . It showcases Mr. Caro's masterly gifts as a writer: his propulsive sense of narrative, his talent for enabling readers to see and feel history in the making and his ability to situate his subjects' actions within the context of their times . . . Caro manages to lend even much-chronicled events a punch of tactile immediacy . . . Johnson emerges as both a larger-than-life, Shakespearean personage—with epic ambition and epic flaws—and a more human-scale puzzle . . .  Mr. Caro uses his storytelling gifts to turn seemingly arcane legislative maneuvers into action-movie suspense, and he gives us unparalleled understanding of how Johnson used a crisis and his own political acumen to implement his agenda with stunning speed. Taken together the installments of Mr. Caro's monumental life of Johnson form a revealing prism by which to view the better part of a century in American life and politics."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"An addictive read, written in glorious prose that suggests the world's most diligent beat reporter channeling William Faulkner. Passage is an essential document of a turning point in American history. It's also an incisive portrait of one great, terrible, fascinating man suddenly given the chance to reinvent the country in his image."

—Darren Franich, Entertainment Weekly

title: Martyr!
long_summary:
Cyrus Shams carries an inheritance of violence and loss. His mother died when her plane was shot down over the Persian Gulf in a senseless accident. His father spent his American life killing chickens at a Midwest factory farm. Now Cyrus—drunk, addicted, and a poet—finds himself obsessed with martyrs as he examines the mysteries of his past.

His search leads him toward an uncle who rode through Iranian battlefields dressed as the angel of death, inspiring and comforting the dying. It also leads him toward his mother, through a painting discovered in a Brooklyn art gallery that suggests she may not have been who she seemed.

Kaveh Akbar's Martyr! is a paean to how we spend our lives seeking meaning—in faith, art, ourselves, and others.
short_summary: A newly sober son of Iranian immigrants embarks on a search for family secrets that leads him to a terminally ill painter in the Brooklyn Museum. Electrifying, funny, and wholly original.
author_bios: Kaveh Akbar's poems appear in The New Yorker, The New York Times, The Paris Review, The Best American Poetry, and elsewhere. He is the author of two poetry collections: Pilgrim Bell and Calling a Wolf a Wolf, plus the chapbook Portrait of the Alcoholic. He edited The Penguin Book of Spiritual Verse: 110 Poets on the Divine and lives in Iowa City.
quotes:
"Kaveh Akbar is a radiant soul, a poet so agile and largehearted it comes as no surprise that his first leap into fiction is elegant, dizzying, playful. MARTYR!  is the best novel you'll ever read about the joy of language, addiction, displacement, martyrdom, belonging, homesickness for people longed for but forever unknown, the way art as eruption of life gazes back into death, and the ecstasy that sometimes arrives—like grace—when we find ourselves teetering on the knife-edge of despair."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates and Furies, Arcadia & Florida

"An absolute jewel of a novel. A diamond. I haven't loved a book this much in years. Kaveh's writing is so thoroughly powerful and gorgeous you can feel it from where dreams come, and in all over your brain, and straight from the bottom of your heart. This book does everything. It is so entirely funny and sad and true and beautiful. Kaveh Akbar is one of my favorite writers. Ever."

—Tommy Orange, author of There There

"I disappeared into Martyr!—utterly consumed by it—and then it returned me to the world with wider eyes, a swollen heart, and sharpened nerve endings. This is a book that understands the strangeness and grief and ecstasy of being alive; that understands the strange envelope of a body, the proximate sublime on the bare chest of a beloved; the baffled wonderment of sobriety, the grief that spans every scale of the human project—and, more than anything, the impossible salvation of love persisting not despite but through these materials. Kaveh Akbar writes with the staggering entirety of his mind and heart, and Martyr! will stay in my soul for good—a fever dream, a reckoning, a heartbreak, a shattering and mending, a delight—its double-helix of dreams and conversation now part of my own DNA for good."

—Leslie Jamison, author of The Empathy Exams

title: The Candy House
long_summary:
The Candy House opens with Bix Bouton, a tech mogul desperate for his next breakthrough. When he stumbles into a conversation group of Columbia professors experimenting with "externalizing" memory, he discovers his golden ticket.

Within a decade, Bix's technology "Own Your Unconscious" has seduced multitudes, allowing people to access every memory they've ever had and trade memories with others. But in Egan's spectacular imagination, this brave new world creates two camps: "counters" who track and exploit desires, and "eluders" who understand the true price of taking a bite of the Candy House.

Egan introduces her characters through an astonishing array of narrative styles—omniscient narration, first person plural, dueling voices, epistolary chapters, and even a chapter of tweets. Each technique illuminates different facets of how technology reshapes human connection.

Intellectually dazzling yet deeply human, The Candy House explores our eternal longing for authenticity, family, privacy, and love in an age when even our most intimate memories can be commodified.
short_summary: Egan imagines a near future where technology allows people to access and trade memories. A dazzling exploration of authenticity and human connection told through an astonishing array of narrative styles.
author_bios: Jennifer Egan is the author of six books of fiction: Manhattan Beach, winner of the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction; A Visit from the Goon Squad, which won the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award; The Keep; the story collection Emerald City; Look at Me, a National Book Award Finalist; and The Invisible Circus. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, and The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"The novel — with its prismatic plotting and ever-shifting chorus of seekers, kooks, and visionaries — feels less like a house than a honeycomb full of fantastical rooms, each one alive and thrumming with bright, weird humanity."

—Leah Greenblatt, Entertainment Weekly

"This is minimalist maximalism. It's as if Egan compressed a big 19th-century triple-decker novel onto a flash drive… Egan goes all in on the power of storytelling and of fiction."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A brilliant demonstration of the unquantifiable pleasures of great fiction."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
long_summary:
Her name was Henrietta Lacks, but scientists know her as HeLa. She was a poor Southern tobacco farmer who worked the same land as her slave ancestors, yet her cells—taken without her knowledge—became one of the most important tools in medicine. The first "immortal" human cells grown in culture, they're still alive today, though she has been dead for more than sixty years.

HeLa cells were vital for developing the polio vaccine, uncovered secrets of cancer and viruses, and helped lead to advances like in vitro fertilization, cloning, and gene mapping. They've been bought and sold by the billions. Yet Henrietta Lacks remains virtually unknown, buried in an unmarked grave.

Her family didn't learn of her "immortality" until more than twenty years after her death, when scientists began using her husband and children in research without informed consent. Though the cells launched a multimillion-dollar industry, her family never saw any profits.

Over the decade it took to uncover this story, Rebecca Skloot became enmeshed in the lives of the Lacks family—especially Henrietta's daughter Deborah, consumed with questions about whether scientists had cloned her mother or killed her to harvest her cells. Intimate in feeling and astonishing in scope, this captures the beauty and drama of scientific discovery, as well as its human consequences.
short_summary: The extraordinary true story of Henrietta Lacks, whose cells became the foundation of modern medicine while her family remained unaware and uncompensated. Skloot weaves science, ethics, and deeply human drama into an unforgettable narrative.
author_bios: Rebecca Skloot is an award-winning science writer whose work has appeared in The New York Times Magazine, O, The Oprah Magazine, and Discover. She's coeditor of The Best American Science Writing 2011 and has worked as a correspondent for NPR's Radiolab and PBS's Nova ScienceNOW. Her debut, The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, became an instant New York Times bestseller and was chosen as a best book of 2010 by more than sixty outlets. She's founder and president of The Henrietta Lacks Foundation.
quotes:
"Skloot's vivid account begins with the life of Henrietta Lacks, who comes fully alive on the page. . . . Immortal Life reads like a novel."

—The Washington Post

"Gripping . . . by turns heartbreaking, funny and unsettling . . . raises troubling questions about the way Mrs. Lacks and her family were treated by researchers and about whether patients should control or have financial claims on tissue removed from their bodies."

—The New York Times

"A rich, resonant tale of modern science, the wonders it can perform and how easily it can exploit society's most vulnerable people."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Just Kids
subtitle: An Autobiography
long_summary:
It was the summer Coltrane died, the summer of love and riots, and the summer when a chance encounter in Brooklyn led two young people on a path of art, devotion, and initiation.

Patti Smith would evolve as a poet and performer, and Robert Mapplethorpe would direct his provocative vision toward photography. Bound in innocence and enthusiasm, they traversed the city from Coney Island to Forty-Second Street, eventually reaching the celebrated round table of Max's Kansas City, where the Andy Warhol contingent held court.

In 1969, the pair set up camp at the Hotel Chelsea and entered a community of the famous and infamous—the influential artists of the day and the colorful fringe. It was a time of heightened awareness, when poetry, rock and roll, art, and sexual politics were colliding and exploding. In this milieu, two kids made a pact to take care of each other. Scrappy, romantic, committed to create, and fueled by mutual dreams, they would sustain one another during the hungry years.

Just Kids begins as a love story and ends as an elegy—a portrait of two young artists' ascent and a salute to New York City's rich and poor, its hustlers and hellions.
short_summary: Smith's memoir chronicles her extraordinary friendship with photographer Robert Mapplethorpe during their bohemian years in 1970s New York. A tender portrait of young artists finding their voices amid the city's creative chaos.
author_bios: Patti Smith is the author of the National Book Award winner Just Kids, as well as Woolgathering, M Train, Year of the Monkey, and Collected Lyrics. Her seminal album Horses has been hailed as one of the top 100 albums of all time. In 2005, the French Ministry of Culture awarded Smith the title of Commandeur des Arts et des Lettres. Inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 2007, Smith is also the recipient of the ASCAP Founders Award, Sweden's Polar Music Prize, the PEN/Audible Literary Service Award, and the Legion d'honneur.
quotes:
"Tenderly evocative...it makes perfect sense for [Smith] to use a memoirist's sleight of hand...to recapture an eager, fervent and wondrously malleable young spirit. It also makes sense for her to cast off all verbal affectation and write in a strong, true voice unencumbered by the polarizing mannerisms of her poetry."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Just Kids concerns the early years of their passionate friendship, a time that coincided with the beginning of the end of Manhattan's last great bohemian age, when a couple with dreams of beatnik glory could live on day-old bread and cigarettes and paint fumes, all of which Smith evokes so precisely that one can smell the Nescafé boiling on a hot plate...More than a 1970s bohemian rhapsody, Just Kids is one of the best books ever written on becoming an artist— not the race for online celebrity and corporate sponsorship that often passes for artistic success these days, but the far more powerful, often difficult journey toward the ecstatic experience of capturing radiance of imagination on a page or stage or photographic paper. Jesus may have died for somebody's sins, but Patti Smith lives and writes and sings for all of us."

—The Washington Post

"The reckless, splendid circus of New York's royal bohemia in the 1960s and '70s—rock idols, cowboy poets, Warhol Superstars—surrounds Smith in her heady recounting of a halcyon era. But the heart of Just Kids, a captivating memoir, is the lifelong love affair (first romantic, later creative and platonic) between Smith and photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, before she became music's punk poet laureate and he one of the art world's most provocative and controversial figures. In her inimitable, lyrical style, Patti Smith recalls the pair's coming together as young, monumentally broke dreamers: ''just kids.'' What follows is both a poignant requiem (Mapplethorpe died of AIDS at age 43) and a radiant celebration of life."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: No One Is Talking About This
long_summary:
A woman catapulted to social media fame travels the world meeting her adoring fans, but she's overwhelmed by navigating what she calls "the portal." She grapples with an unshakable conviction that a vast chorus of voices now dictates her thoughts, posting her way deeper into the void as existential threats loom—climate change, economic precariousness, an unnamed dictator, an epidemic of loneliness.

An avalanche of images, details, and references accumulate to form a landscape that is post-sense, post-irony, post-everything. "Are we in hell?" the people of the portal ask themselves. "Are we all just going to keep doing this until we die?"

Suddenly, two texts from her mother pierce the fray: "Something has gone wrong," and "How soon can you get here?" As real life collides with the increasingly absurd antics of the portal, she confronts a world that seems to contain both abundant proof of goodness, empathy, and justice, and a deluge of evidence to the contrary.

Fragmentary and omniscient, incisive and sincere, this is at once a love letter to the endless scroll and a profound meditation on love, language, and human connection.
short_summary: When a social media celebrity's hyper-online existence collides with a devastating family crisis, she must navigate between the absurd digital void and raw human connection. Lockwood captures our fractured moment with startling precision.
author_bios: Patricia Lockwood is the bestselling author of the Booker Prize finalist and Dylan Thomas Prize-winning novel No One Is Talking About This, named one of the 10 Best Books of 2021 by The New York Times Book Review and one of The Atlantic's Great American Novels of the past 100 years. Her other books include the memoir Priestdaddy and two poetry collections. She is a contributing editor at the London Review of Books.
quotes:
"[Lockwood is] a master of startling concision when highlighting the absurdities we've grown too lazy to notice . . . It's a vertiginous experience, gorgeously rendered but utterly devastating. I rattled around the house for days afterwards, shattered but grateful for the reminder that the ephemeral world we've constructed online is a shadow compared to the pain and affection we're blessed to experience in real life."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"I really admire and love this book. Patricia Lockwood is a completely singular talent and this is her best, funniest, weirdest, most affecting work yet."

—Sally Rooney, author of Normal People and Conversations with Friends

"Reading Patricia Lockwood feels like looking through a kaleidoscope built by a mischievous sorcerer—the world is suddenly rearranged in fragments that are cosmic, wondrous, humiliating, and profane. No One Is Talking About This is a furiously original novel, alive and unstable; the book builds to a reminder of how devastation and connection produce each other, endlessly and surprisingly, both on the internet and in human places that our shared digital consciousness can never reach."

—Jia Tolentino, author of Trick Mirror

title: Educated
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Born to survivalists in the mountains of Idaho, Tara Westover was seventeen the first time she set foot in a classroom. Her family was so isolated from mainstream society that there was no one to ensure the children received an education, and no one to intervene when one of Tara's older brothers became violent.

When another brother got himself into college, Tara decided to try a new kind of life. Her quest for knowledge transformed her, taking her over oceans and across continents, to Harvard and to Cambridge University. Only then would she wonder if she'd traveled too far, if there was still a way home.
short_summary: An unforgettable memoir about a young woman who leaves her survivalist family to pursue education, eventually earning a PhD from Cambridge University. Heart-wrenching and transformative.
author_bios: Tara Westover is an American historian and memoirist. Her first book, Educated, debuted at #1 on the New York Times bestseller list and remained there for over two years. The memoir was a finalist for the Los Angeles Times Book Prize, PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, and National Book Critics Circle Award, and has been translated into more than forty-five languages. Time named Westover one of the 100 Most Influential People of 2019. She holds a PhD in intellectual history from Trinity College, Cambridge, and received the National Humanities Medal from President Biden in 2023.
quotes:
