"Heart-wrenching . . . a beautiful testament to the power of education to open eyes and change lives."

—Amy Chua, The New York Times

"A coming-of-age memoir reminiscent of The Glass Castle."

—O: The Oprah Magazine

"Westover's one-of-a-kind memoir is about the shaping of a mind. . . . In briskly paced prose, she evokes a childhood that completely defined her. Yet it was also, she gradually sensed, deforming her."

—The Atlantic

title: Deacon King Kong
long_summary:
In September 1969, a fumbling, cranky old church deacon known as Sportcoat shuffles into the courtyard of a south Brooklyn housing project, pulls a .38 from his pocket, and shoots the neighborhood drug dealer at point-blank range. In front of everybody.

The reasons for this desperate burst of violence—and the wild consequences that follow—lie at the heart of James McBride's funny, moving novel. McBride brings to vivid life everyone affected by the shooting: the victim, the African-American and Latinx residents who witnessed it, the white neighbors, local cops, members of the Five Ends Baptist Church where Sportcoat served as deacon, the neighborhood's Italian mobsters, and the enigmatic Sportcoat himself.

As the story deepens, the lives of these characters—caught in the tumultuous swirl of 1960s New York—overlap in unexpected ways. When truth finally emerges, McBride reveals that not all secrets are meant to stay hidden, that growth requires facing change without fear, and that love's seeds lie in hope and compassion.
short_summary: When an elderly church deacon shoots a drug dealer in broad daylight, a Brooklyn housing project erupts in chaos. McBride's raucous, big-hearted novel weaves together faith, community, and the messy business of forgiveness.
author_bios: James McBride is the author of the bestselling The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store, Oprah's Book Club selection Deacon King Kong, National Book Award-winning The Good Lord Bird, the classic The Color of Water, novels Song Yet Sung and Miracle at St. Anna, story collection Five-Carat Soul, and Kill 'Em and Leave. Recipient of a National Humanities Medal and accomplished musician, McBride is distinguished writer in residence at New York University.
quotes:
"A mystery story, a crime novel, an urban farce, a sociological portrait of late-1960s Brooklyn: McBride's novel contains multitudes… He conducts his antic symphony with deep feeling, never losing sight of the suffering and inequity within the merriment."

—The New York Times

"A story of comedy and compassion."

—Time

"A boisterous, imaginative, tender foray into late- 1960's Brooklyn."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Hamnet
long_summary:
England, 1580: The Black Death creeps across the land, an ever-present threat. The end of days feels near, but life always goes on.

A young Latin tutor—penniless and bullied by a violent father—falls in love with an extraordinary woman. Agnes is a wild creature who walks her family's land with a falcon on her glove, known throughout the countryside for her gifts as a healer. She understands plants and potions better than she does people.

Once she settles with her husband on Henley Street in Stratford-upon-Avon, Agnes becomes a fiercely protective mother and the steadfast center of their household. Her young husband's career on the London stage is just taking off when tragedy strikes—their beloved son succumbs to sudden fever, leaving the family shattered by an unimaginable loss that will reshape everything they thought they knew about love, art, and survival.
short_summary: O'Farrell imagines the marriage behind Shakespeare's most haunting tragedy. When plague takes their son, a healer and her playwright husband must navigate devastating grief in this luminous portrait of love and loss.
author_bios: Maggie O'Farrell was born in Northern Ireland in 1972. Her novels include Hamnet (winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award), After You'd Gone, The Vanishing Act of Esme Lennox, The Hand That First Held Mine (winner of the Costa Novel Award), and Instructions for a Heatwave. She has also written a memoir, I Am, I Am, I Am: Seventeen Brushes with Death. She lives in Edinburgh.
quotes:
"What could be more common, over centuries and continents, than the death of a child - and yet Maggie O'Farrell, with her flawless sentences and furious heart, somehow makes it new. This story of remarkable people bereft of their boy will leave you shaking with loss but also the love from which family is spun."

—Emma Donoghue, author of Room

"A tour de force. . . . Hamnet vividly captures the life-changing intensity of maternity in its myriad stages—from the pain of childbirth to the unassuagable grief of loss. Fierce emotions and lyrical prose are what we've come to expect of O'Farrell."

—NPR

"Miraculous... brilliant... A novel told with the urgency of a whispered prayer — or curse...  through the alchemy of her own vision, she has created a moving story about the way loss viciously recalibrates a marriage...  A richly drawn and intimate portrait of 16th-century English life set against the arrival of one devastating death."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: A Flower Traveled in My Blood
subtitle: The Incredible True Story of the Grandmothers Who Fought to Find a Stolen Generation of Children
long_summary:
In the early hours of March 24, 1976, tanks rumble through Buenos Aires as soldiers seize the presidential palace and topple Argentina's government. The country falls under military control, with army chief Jorge Rafael Videla at the helm. With quiet U.S. support and tacit approval from Argentines exhausted by constant bombings and violence, the junta launches the National Reorganization Process—a bland name masking their ruthless campaign to crush the political left and instill "Western, Christian" values.

One of the military's most diabolical acts is kidnapping hundreds of pregnant women. After giving birth in captivity, the mothers are "disappeared" and their babies secretly given to other families—many headed by police or military officers. For the mothers and mothers-in-law of these women, the grief is twofold: the disappearance of their daughters and the theft of their grandchildren.

A group of fierce grandmothers forms the Abuelas de Plaza de Mayo, dedicated to finding the stolen infants and seeking justice from a nation that betrayed them. At a time when speaking out could mean death, the Abuelas confront military officers and launch protests to reach international diplomats. They become detectives, adopting disguises to observe suspected grandchildren, and work alongside a renowned American scientist to pioneer groundbreaking genetic tests.

The product of extensive archival research and meticulous reporting, this is narrative nonfiction that reads like a novel and reveals new truths about memory, identity, and family.
short_summary: During Argentina's military dictatorship, hundreds of babies were stolen from disappeared mothers and given to other families. The extraordinary true story of the grandmothers who risked everything to find them.
author_bios: Haley Cohen Gilliland is a journalist and director of the Yale Journalism Initiative. She worked at The Economist for seven years, including four years in Buenos Aires as Argentina correspondent. Her long-form features have appeared in The New York Times, National Geographic, Bloomberg Businessweek, and Vanity Fair. She lives in New York state with her husband, two children, and dogs. A Flower Traveled in My Blood is her first book.
quotes:
"[A] deeply researched and cinematically told work of history."

—The Washington Post

"Gilliland's first book (of many, we should hope) tells the remarkable story of the Abuelas de Plaza de Mayo. . . . Grandmothers came together across social divides to fight for their families, sometimes discovering reserves of strength they didn't know they had. The Abuelas remain united in their struggle to this day and Gillibrand does a masterful job conveying their extraordinary story."

—NPR

"[Gilliland] conveys the complicated, heart-wrenching fullness of her characters' individual stories and shades their backdrop with compulsively readable history of geopolitical tension and the emerging DNA science that fueled the Abuelas' fight. Gilliland's work, exhaustively and compassionately researched, offers a crucial counterbalance to the dark legacy of Argentina's desaparecidos, injecting the light of a model resistance movement that lay the groundwork for future international human rights investigations. Her humility and respect for the fraught journeys her subjects made toward each other and for the vital questions their journeys raised—about power, identity, family, and collective memory and healing—ensure the text will resonate for generations the world over. A piercing, emotional tribute to the value of persistent resistance."

—Kirkus Reviews (starred review)

title: The Nickel Boys
long_summary:
When Elwood Curtis, a Black teenager in 1960s Tallahassee, is unfairly sentenced to the Nickel Academy, a juvenile reformatory, he discovers a grotesque chamber of horrors masquerading as rehabilitation. His only lifeline becomes his friendship with Turner, a fellow student whose street-smart cynicism clashes with Elwood's unwavering idealism.

Turner believes the world is fundamentally crooked and survival depends on keeping your head down and working the angles. Elwood, shaped by the moral clarity of the civil rights movement, refuses to abandon his principles even as the Academy's brutality escalates. As conditions become increasingly perilous, the tension between their worldviews forces a decision that will reverberate across decades.

Based on the real story of a reform school that operated for 111 years and destroyed thousands of young lives, The Nickel Boys showcases Whitehead at the height of his powers, delivering a devastating narrative that excavates another buried strand of American history.
short_summary: Two boys navigate the horrors of a Jim Crow-era reform school, their friendship tested by clashing worldviews. Whitehead excavates another buried American tragedy with devastating precision.
author_bios: Colson Whitehead is the #1 New York Times bestselling author of twelve works of fiction and nonfiction, and two-time Pulitzer Prize winner for The Nickel Boys and The Underground Railroad, which also won the National Book Award. A MacArthur and Guggenheim fellow, he lives in New York City.
quotes:
"A necessary read."

—President Barack Obama

"This is a powerful book by one of America's great writers. . . . Without sentimentality, in as intense and finely crafted a book as you'll ever read, Whitehead tells a story of American history that won't allow you to see the country in the same way again."

—Toronto Star

"Colson Whitehead continues to make a classic American genre his own. . . . The narration is disciplined and the sentences plain and sturdy, oars cutting into water. Every chapter hits its marks. . . . Whitehead comports himself with gravity and care, the steward of painful, suppressed histories; his choices on the page can feel as much ethical as aesthetic. The ordinary language, the clear pane of his prose, lets the stories speak for themselves. . . . Whitehead has written novels of horror and apocalypse; nothing touches the grimness of the real stories he conveys here"

—The New York Times

title: Book of Ages
subtitle: The Life and Opinions of Jane Franklin
long_summary:
Benjamin Franklin wrote more letters to his sister Jane than to anyone else, yet her story has remained largely untold. While he became the original American self-made man, she spent her life caring for twelve children, leaving behind very different traces in history.

Using a remarkable cache of little-studied documents, objects, and portraits only recently discovered, Jill Lepore brings Jane Franklin to vivid life. Like her famous brother, Jane was a passionate reader, gifted writer, and shrewd political commentator—but her brilliance was confined to the domestic sphere that defined women's lives in colonial America.

Lepore's biography offers a strikingly original perspective on Benjamin Franklin while illuminating an entire world usually lost to history. Through Jane's story, we gain both a wholly different account of America's founding and one of the great untold stories of American letters—a life unknown that enriches our understanding of everyday relationships, conversations, and experiences in early America.
short_summary: Jill Lepore resurrects the forgotten story of Benjamin Franklin's youngest sister Jane, a brilliant woman confined by her era. From newly discovered letters and documents, an intimate portrait emerges that reframes both siblings and early American life.
author_bios: Jill Lepore is the David Woods Kemper '41 Professor of American History at Harvard University and professor of law at Harvard Law School. She is also a staff writer at The New Yorker. Her many books include the international bestseller These Truths: A History of the United States & Book of Ages. She lives in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"Book of Ages is the name of Lepore's extraordinary new book about Jane Franklin, but to call it simply a biography would be like calling Ben's experiments with electricity mere kite flying….The end product is thrilling—an example of how a gifted scholar and writer can lift the obscure out of silence. In so doing, Lepore enriches our sense of everyday life and relationships and conversational styles in Colonial America….The brilliance of Lepore's book is that plain Jane's story becomes every bit as gripping—and, in its own way, important—as Big Ben's public triumphs."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"This is a brilliant and delightful book! By weaving together the tales of Benjamin Franklin and his beloved little sister, Jill Lepore creates a richly-textured tapestry of life in early America. Deeply researched and passionately written, it brings us inside a poignant relationship between two lovable people who seemed so different but were also so connected. I devoured this book and will treasure it."

—Walter Isaacson, author of Steve Jobs

"From scraps and whispers, Jill Lepore has resurrected Ben Franklin's youngest sister, the only relative who could truthfully say, "Every line from him was a pleasure." The subject is tailor-made for Lepore, as artful a writer as she is exact a scholar. She delivers two marvels at once: An authentic 18th century female voice, cheerful, inquisitive, and saucy, as well as an intimate portrait of Jane Franklin's revered brother himself."

—Stacy Schiff, author of Cleopatra

title: H Is for Hawk
long_summary:
After her father's sudden death, Helen Macdonald makes an impulsive decision: she will train a goshawk, one of nature's most ferocious and unpredictable raptors. What follows is an extraordinary journey of grief, wildness, and unexpected connection.

Fierce and feral, her goshawk Mabel becomes both mirror and companion to Helen's raw emotional state. As woman and bird learn to navigate their unlikely partnership, Macdonald weaves together memoir, nature writing, and literary meditation with stunning grace. The result is a genre-defying exploration of loss, healing, and what it means to be truly alive in the natural world.

This award-winning sensation has captivated millions of readers worldwide with its unique voice and transcendent storytelling, establishing Macdonald as one of our most compelling contemporary writers.
short_summary: After her father's death, Macdonald trains a fierce goshawk in this genre-defying memoir. A stunning meditation on grief, wildness, and the unexpected connections between human and raptor.
author_bios: Helen Macdonald is a writer, poet, illustrator and naturalist, and an affiliated research scholar at the Department of History and Philosophy of Science at the University of Cambridge. She is the author of the bestselling H Is for Hawk, the cultural history Falcon, and three poetry collections, including Shaler's Fish. A former Research Fellow at Jesus College, Cambridge, and professional falconer, she has assisted with raptor research and conservation projects across Eurasia and now writes for the New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"Beautiful and nearly feral...H Is for Hawk reminds us that excellent nature writing can lay bare some of the intimacies of the wild world as well."

—The New York Times

"One of the loveliest things you'll read this year . . . You'll never see a bird overhead the same way again."

—Entertainment Weekly

"An elegantly written amalgam of nature writing, personal memoir, literary portrait and an examination of bereavement. . . . It illuminates unexpected things in unexpected ways."

—The Washington Post

title: All the Light We Cannot See
long_summary:
Marie-Laure lives with her father in Paris near the Museum of Natural History, where he works as the master of its thousands of locks. When she goes blind at six, her father builds a perfect miniature of their neighborhood so she can memorize it by touch and navigate her way home.

When she is twelve, the Nazis occupy Paris, and father and daughter flee to the walled citadel of Saint-Malo, where Marie-Laure's reclusive great uncle lives in a tall house by the sea. With them they carry what might be the museum's most valuable and dangerous jewel.

In a mining town in Germany, the orphan Werner grows up with his younger sister, enchanted by a crude radio they find. Werner becomes an expert at building and fixing these crucial instruments—a talent that wins him a place at a brutal academy for Hitler Youth, then a special assignment to track the Resistance. More and more aware of the human cost of his intelligence, Werner travels through the heart of the war and, finally, into Saint-Malo, where his story and Marie-Laure's converge.
short_summary: A blind French girl and a German boy's paths collide in occupied France during World War II. Doerr weaves their stories with stunning precision and humanity.
author_bios: Anthony Doerr is the author of the New York Times bestselling Cloud Cuckoo Land, a National Book Award finalist, and All the Light We Cannot See, winner of the Pulitzer Prize, Carnegie Medal, and Alex Award. His other works include the story collections Memory Wall and The Shell Collector, the novel About Grace, and the memoir Four Seasons in Rome. He has won five O. Henry Prizes, the Rome Prize, the Young Lions Award, the National Magazine Award for fiction, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and the Story Prize. He lives in Boise, Idaho.
quotes:
"Hauntingly beautiful."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Enthrallingly told, beautifully written…Every piece of back story reveals information that charges the emerging narrative with significance, until at last the puzzle-box of the plot slides open to reveal the treasure hidden inside."

—Amanda Vaill, The Washington Post

"If a book's success can be measured by its ability to move readers and the number of memorable characters it has, Story Prize-winner Doerr's novel triumphs on both counts. He convinces readers...that war—despite its desperation, cruelty, and harrowing moral choices—cannot negate the pleasures of the world."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Freedom
long_summary:
Patty and Walter Berglund were the pioneers of old St. Paul—the gentrifiers, the hands-on parents, the avant-garde of the Whole Foods generation. But now, in the new millennium, they have become a mystery.

Why has their teenage son moved in with the aggressively Republican family next door? Why has Walter, once an environmental lawyer, taken a job working with Big Coal? Most startling of all, why has Patty, the perfect neighbor, turned into the local Fury?

In his first novel since The Corrections, Jonathan Franzen delivers an epic of contemporary love and marriage. Freedom comically and tragically captures the temptations and burdens of liberty: the thrills of teenage lust, the shaken compromises of middle age, the wages of suburban sprawl, the heavy weight of empire. Charting the mistakes and joys of the Berglunds as they struggle to learn how to live in an ever more confusing world, Franzen creates an indelible portrait of our time.
short_summary: The Berglunds were model liberal parents until everything fell apart. Franzen's sprawling family saga captures the contradictions of early 2000s America with devastating precision and dark humor.
author_bios: Jonathan Franzen is the author of five novels, including The Corrections, Freedom, and Purity, and five works of nonfiction, most recently Farther Away and The End of the End of the Earth, all published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux. He lives in Santa Cruz, California.
quotes:
"A masterpiece of American fiction."

—The New York Times

"One of the best . . . living American novelist[s]"

—Time

"Brilliant . . . An extraordinary stylist."

—The Washington Post

title: An Immense World
subtitle: How Animal Senses Reveal the Hidden Realms Around Us
long_summary:
The Earth teems with sights and textures, sounds and vibrations, smells and tastes, electric and magnetic fields. But every animal, including humans, lives within its own unique sensory bubble, perceiving only a tiny sliver of our immense world.

In An Immense World, Ed Yong coaxes us beyond our own sensory confines, allowing us to perceive the skeins of scent, waves of electromagnetism, and pulses of pressure that surround us. We encounter beetles drawn to fires, turtles that track Earth's magnetic fields, fish that fill rivers with electrical messages, and humans who wield sonar like bats.

We discover that a crocodile's scaly face is as sensitive as a lover's fingertips, that giant squid eyes evolved to see sparkling whales, that plants thrum with the inaudible songs of courting bugs. We learn what bees see in flowers, what songbirds hear in their tunes, and what dogs smell on the street.

Funny, rigorous, and suffused with the joy of discovery, An Immense World takes us on what Marcel Proust called "the only true voyage... not to visit strange lands, but to possess other eyes."
short_summary: Pulitzer Prize-winning science journalist Ed Yong takes us beyond human perception to experience the world through animal senses. From magnetic turtle navigation to electrical fish communication, this joyful exploration reveals the hidden sensory universe surrounding us.
author_bios: Ed Yong is a Pulitzer Prize–winning science writer on the staff of The Atlantic, where he also won the George Polk Award for science reporting. He has been named a Guggenheim Fellow for science writing. His first book, I Contain Multitudes, was a New York Times bestseller and won numerous awards. His work has appeared in The New Yorker, National Geographic, Wired, The New York Times, and Scientific American. He lives in Washington, D.C.
quotes:
"A thrilling tour of nonhuman perception . . . Nature's true wonders aren't limited to a remote wilderness or other sublime landscape. . . . There is as much grandeur in the soil of a backyard garden as there is in the canyons of Zion."

—The New York Times

"What would we do without Ed Yong? This book feels like a tremendous burst of oxygen, animating everything around us with life and color and texture and wonder at precisely the moment we all need it."

—Rebecca Skloot, author of The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks

"Equal parts science and poetry: Yong guides us through the magic of the animal kingdom in ways that have unlocked something inside of me I didn't know was there. I'll never look at our planet the same way again."

—Clint Smith, author of How the Word Is Passed

title: Mother Mary Comes to Me
long_summary:
Arundhati Roy's first memoir is a soaring, intimate account of how she became the person and writer she is today—shaped by circumstance, but above all by her complex relationship with the extraordinary woman she describes as "my shelter and my storm."

"Heart-smashed" by her mother Mary's death in September 2022, yet puzzled by the intensity of her response, Roy began to write. She needed to make sense of her feelings about the mother she ran from at eighteen—"not because I didn't love her, but in order to be able to continue to love her."

What emerges is an astonishing, sometimes disturbing, and surprisingly funny journey from Roy's childhood in Kerala, India, where her single mother founded a school, through the writing of her prizewinning novels and essays, to today. With the scale and depth of her fiction and the passion of her essays, this memoir is an ode to freedom, a tribute to thorny love and savage grace—unlike any other.
short_summary: Roy excavates her complicated relationship with her late mother in this raw, luminous memoir. Equal parts tribute and reckoning, it traces how a fierce single mother in Kerala shaped one of our most essential writers.
author_bios: Arundhati Roy is the author of The God of Small Things, which won the Booker Prize in 1997, and The Ministry of Utmost Happiness, longlisted for the Man Booker Prize in 2017. She has published several works of nonfiction including The End of Imagination, The Doctor and the Saint, My Seditious Heart, and Azadi. In 2023, she was awarded the European Essay Prize for lifetime achievement, and in 2024 the PEN Pinter Prize. She lives in Delhi.
quotes:
"[Roy] channels warmth, moral clarity and a sweeping bird's-eye view of modern India to tell her life story, which was shaped by poverty, violence, political upheaval and—most of all—the volatile single mother who raised her."

—The New York Times

"Tender...full of precise imagery and blistering emotional intelligence."

—The Washington Post

"Booker Prize–winning Indian novelist Arundhati Roy recounts a life of poverty and upheaval, defiance and triumph in an emotionally raw memoir, centered on her complicated relationship with her mother...Her candid memoir revives both an extraordinary woman and the tangled complexities of filial love. An intimate, stirring chronicle."

—Kirkus Reviews (starred review)

title: North Woods
long_summary:
When two young lovers flee a Puritan colony, their humble cabin in the woods becomes home to an extraordinary succession of characters across centuries. An English soldier abandons battlefield glory to devote himself to growing apples. Spinster twins navigate war and famine, envy and desire. A crime reporter unearths an ancient mass grave, only to discover the earth refuses to give up its secrets.

A lovelorn painter, a sinister con man, a stalking panther, a lusty beetle—as inhabitants confront the wonder and mystery around them, they realize the dark, raucous, beautiful past is very much alive.

This inventive novel from Pulitzer Prize finalist Daniel Mason brims with love and madness, humor and hope. Following the cycles of history, nature, and language itself, North Woods reveals the magical ways we're connected to our environment, to history, and to one another. It's an unforgettable exploration of secrets and destinies that asks: How do we live on, even after we're gone?
short_summary: One house in the New England woods becomes home to centuries of inhabitants—from Puritan lovers to con men to wild creatures. Mason weaves their stories into something magical and profound.
author_bios: Daniel Mason is the author of The Piano Tuner, A Far Country, The Winter Soldier, and A Registry of My Passage Upon the Earth, which was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. His work has been translated into twenty-eight languages and awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship, the Joyce Carol Oates Prize, a California Book Award, an O. Henry Prize, and a Fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts. He is an assistant professor in the Stanford University department of psychiatry.
quotes:
"North Woods is a monumental achievement of polyphony and humanity . . . I loved it."

—Maggie O'Farrell, New York Times bestselling author of Hamnet

"North Woods is the most original and spellbinding novel I've read in ages. Mason makes bramble, brush, and orchard come alive with the spirits of their unforgettable former inhabitants. Their lives . . . had me glued to my seat."

—Abraham Verghese, New York Times bestselling author of The Covenant of Water

"Each arc is beautifully, heartbreakingly conveyed, stitching together subtle connections across time. This astonishes."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Can't We Talk about Something More Pleasant?
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In her first memoir, beloved New Yorker cartoonist Roz Chast brings her signature wit to the universal experience of caring for aging parents. Told through four-color cartoons, family photos, documents, and narrative that balances laughs with tears, this graphic memoir offers both comfort and comic relief for anyone navigating the life-altering challenge of elderly parent care.

For years, Roz relied on denial, avoidance, and distraction when it came to her mother and father. But when Elizabeth Chast climbed a ladder to retrieve an old souvenir from the "crazy closet"—with predictable results—those coping mechanisms could no longer work.

While the particulars are uniquely Chast-ian—an anxious father slipping into dementia and a former assistant principal mother whose overbearing personality had long sidelined Roz—the themes are achingly universal. Adult children accepting parental roles, aging parents leaving home for institutional care, managing uncomfortable physical intimacies, and hiring strangers to provide the most personal care.

An extraordinary portrait of two lives at their end and an only child doing her best to cope, this memoir showcases the full range of Chast's talent as both cartoonist and storyteller.
short_summary: New Yorker cartoonist Roz Chast chronicles her parents' final years in this groundbreaking graphic memoir. By turns hilarious and heartbreaking, it captures the universal experience of caring for aging parents with unflinching honesty.
author_bios: Roz Chast's cartoons have appeared in the New Yorker since 1978, where she has published over one thousand. She's the author of graphic memoirs Going Into Town (New York City Book Award winner) and the #1 New York Times bestseller Can't We Talk About Something More Pleasant? (National Book Critics Circle Award and Kirkus Prize winner, National Book Award finalist), plus What I Hate: From A to Z and cartoon collections The Party, After You Left, and Theories of Everything. Harvey Hall of Fame Award recipient. Lives in Connecticut and New York.
quotes:
"By turns grim and absurd, deeply poignant and laugh-out-loud funny. Ms. Chast reminds us how deftly the graphic novel can capture ordinary crises in ordinary American lives."

—Michiko Kakutani, New York Times

"Revelatory… So many have faced (or will face) the situation that the author details, but no one could render it like she does. A top-notch graphic memoir that adds a whole new dimension to readers' appreciation of Chast and her work."

—Kirkus

"Never has the abyss of dread and grief been plumbed to such incandescently hilarious effect. The lines between laughter and hysteria, despair and rage, love and guilt, are quavery indeed, and no one draws them more honestly, more . . . unscrimpingly, than Roz Chast."

—Alison Bechdel, author of Fun Home

title: The Bee Sting
long_summary:
The Barnes family is falling apart. Dickie's car business is collapsing, but instead of facing reality, he's hiding in the woods building an apocalypse bunker with a sketchy handyman. His wife Imelda is secretly selling her jewelry on eBay. Their once-brilliant daughter Cass is drinking her way through her final exams, while twelve-year-old PJ plots his escape from home.

Where did it all go wrong? Was it a patch of ice, a favor to a stranger, a bee trapped under a wedding veil? Can a single moment of bad luck derail an entire life?

With his signature blend of dark humor and devastating insight, Murray weaves together past and present to explore how families survive when everything falls apart. As the Barnes family confronts their failures and misfortunes, they must ask themselves: if your story has already been written, is there still time to find a different ending?
short_summary: The Barnes family faces financial ruin and personal collapse in this darkly comic exploration of how single moments can derail entire lives. Murray crafts a tender, hilarious portrait of ordinary people struggling to stay afloat.
author_bios: Paul Murray was born in 1975 in Dublin. His debut An Evening of Long Goodbyes was short-listed for the Whitbread First Novel Award and Kerry Group Irish Fiction Award. Skippy Dies was long-listed for the Booker Prize and was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. The Mark and the Void won the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize and was named one of Time's Top 10 Fiction Books.
quotes:
"Murray's latest is a comedy of errors, emphasis on both the comedy and the errors. The novel follows the reversal of fortunes of the Barnes family, a decline sparked by the Irish financial crash, yes, but perhaps set in motion by fateful moments in the family's past."

—The New York Times

"Reads like an instant classic . . . Murray is a fantastically witty and empathetic writer, and he dazzles by somehow bringing the great sprawling randomness of life to glamorously choreographed climaxes. He is essentially interested in the moral conflicts of our lives, and he handles his characters and their failings with heartbreaking tenderness."

—The Washington Post

"No moment or episode is implausible . . . carried by Murray's fine, measured prose and uncanny plotting . . . Irresistible."

—Kirkus

title: Room
long_summary:
To five-year-old Jack, Room is the entire world. It's where he was born, where he and Ma eat and sleep and play and learn. At night, Ma shuts him safely in the wardrobe, where he's meant to be asleep when Old Nick visits.

Room is home to Jack, but to Ma it's the prison where she's been held for seven years. Through fierce love for her son, she's created a life for him in this eleven-by-eleven-foot space. But with Jack's curiosity building alongside her own desperation, she knows Room cannot contain either much longer.

This is a tale at once shocking and riveting—a story of unconquerable love in harrowing circumstances, and of the diamond-hard bond between a mother and her child.
short_summary: Five-year-old Jack believes the tiny room where he lives with Ma is the entire world. When they finally escape their prison, everything changes in this devastating exploration of resilience and maternal love.
author_bios: Emma Donoghue is the author of sixteen novels, including the award-winning national bestseller Room, the basis for the acclaimed film. Her latest novel is The Paris Express. She has written screenplays for Room and The Wonder and nine stage plays. Her next film (adapted with Philippa Lowthorpe from Helen Macdonald's memoir) is H Is for Hawk. Born in Dublin, she lives in Ontario with her family.
quotes:
"Emma Donoghue's writing is superb alchemy, changing innocence into horror and horror into tenderness. Room is a book to read in one sitting. When it's over you look up: the world looks the same but you are somehow different and that feeling lingers for days."

—Audrey Niffenegger, author of The Time Traveler's Wife and Her Fearful Symmetry

"Powerful.... Seen entirely through Jack's eyes and childlike perceptions, the developments in this novel--there are enough plot twists to provide a dramatic arc of breathtaking suspense--are astonishing.... Donoghue brilliantly portrays the psyche of a child raised in captivity...will keep readers rapt."

—Publishers Weekly

"one of the most affecting and subtly profound novels of the year"

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: There Is No Place for Us
subtitle: Working and Homeless in America
long_summary:
The working homeless. In a country where hard work and determination are supposed to lead to success, there's something scandalous about this phrase. But skyrocketing rents, low wages, and a lack of tenant rights have produced a startling phenomenon: People with full-time jobs cannot keep a roof over their heads, especially in America's booming cities, where rapid growth is leading to catastrophic displacement.

In this gripping and deeply reported book, Brian Goldstone plunges readers into the lives of five Atlanta families struggling to remain housed in a gentrifying, increasingly unequal city. Maurice and Natalia make a fresh start in the country's "Black Mecca" after being priced out of DC. Kara dreams of starting her own cleaning business while mopping floors at a public hospital. Britt scores a coveted housing voucher. Michelle is in school to become a social worker. Celeste toils at her warehouse job while undergoing treatment for ovarian cancer.

Through intimate, novelistic portraits, Goldstone reveals the human cost of this crisis, following parents and their kids as they sleep in cars or squalid extended-stay hotels, then head out to their jobs and schools the next morning. By turns heartbreaking and urgent, There Is No Place for Us illuminates the true magnitude of the new American homelessness—and shows that it won't be solved until housing is treated as a fundamental human right.
short_summary: Five Atlanta families with full-time jobs face homelessness in America's booming cities. Goldstone's intimate reporting exposes the hidden crisis of the working homeless with devastating clarity.
author_bios: Brian Goldstone is a journalist whose longform reporting and essays have appeared in The New York Times, Harper's Magazine, The New Republic, The California Sunday Magazine, and Jacobin. He has a PhD in anthropology from Duke University, was a Mellon Research Fellow at Columbia University, and a 2021 National Fellow at New America. He lives in Atlanta with his family.
quotes:
"Deeply reported and written with an empathy that brims from every page . . . [Goldstone] has pulled off a rare and stunning narrative feat."

—Jonathan Blitzer, author of Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here

"A crucial, masterful book that will change the national conversation about homelessness."

—Rachel Aviv, author of Strangers to Ourselves

"Goldstone stitches together a textured and extraordinarily detailed narrative of [five families'] multiyear struggle to keep a roof over their heads. The effect is reminiscent of Random Family. . . . There Is No Place for Us shifts the paradigm on homelessness."

—The Washington Post

title: I Heard Her Call My Name
subtitle: A Memoir of Transition
long_summary:
For a long time, Lucy Sante felt unsure of her place. Born in Belgium to conservative working-class Catholic parents, she found home only when she moved to New York City in the early 1970s and discovered her people among fellow bohemians. Some would die young from drugs and AIDS; others would become jarringly famous. Sante flirted with both fates while building an estimable career as a writer.

But she still felt like her life was a performance, presenting a facade even to herself.

Sante's memoir braids together two threads: the arc of her life and her recent transition to a place of inner and outer alignment. She brings loving irony to her unsteady first steps—there was much she needed to learn about being a woman after sixty years cloaked in a man's identity. A marvel of grace and empathy, I Heard Her Call My Name parses with great sensitivity the complexities of gender identity and the courage required to face who we really are.
short_summary: An iconic writer's lapidary memoir of pursuing artistic truth while evading the truth of her own gender identity. Sante chronicles her bohemian life in 1970s New York and her recent transition with grace, humor, and hard-won wisdom.
author_bios: Lucy Sante is the author of Low Life, Evidence, The Factory of Facts, Kill All Your Darlings, Folk Photography, The Other Paris, Maybe the People Would Be the Times, and Nineteen Reservoirs. Her awards include a Whiting Writers Award, an Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, a Grammy Award, an Infinity Award from the International Center of Photography, and Guggenheim and Cullman Center fellowships. She recently retired after twenty-four years teaching at Bard College.
quotes:
"Reading this book is a joy. Sante is funny and warm . . . I Heard Her Call My Name has much to say about the trans journey and will undoubtedly become a standard for those in need of guidance. But the book speaks to a wider audience, too: for anyone who needs to break out of their self-imposed 'prison of denial,' as Sante puts it, or to stop punishing themselves for wanting what they want."

—The Washington Post

"Miraculous . . . With piercing insight and a formidable command of language, Sante molds the material into a trenchant self-portrait that's equal parts humorous (she wryly gives her coming-out email the subject line 'A Bombshell') and hard-nosed. This is a major achievement."

—Publishers Weekly

"I've admired the utter clarity and authority of Lucy Sante's work for years, and I was deeply moved by how she tunneled through the specificity of her experiences to create this vivid, encompassing, and compassionate book."

—Catherine Lacey, author of Biography of X

title: Asymmetry
long_summary:
Told in three distinct sections, Asymmetry explores the imbalances that define our most complex human relationships: inequities in age, power, talent, wealth, fame, geography, and justice.

The first section, "Folly," follows Alice, a young American editor, and her relationship with the famous and much older writer Ezra Blazer. Set in New York during the early years of the Iraq War, it's both a tender account of unexpected romance and an aspiring novelist's coming-of-age.

"Madness" shifts perspective entirely, narrated by Amar, an Iraqi-American man detained by immigration officers at Heathrow while traveling to visit his brother in Kurdistan. He spends the last weekend of 2008 in a holding room, reflecting on his life and circumstances.

These seemingly disparate stories gain resonance as their perspectives interact and overlap, with an unexpected coda revealing new implications for their relationship. A stunning debut that poses arresting questions about the very nature of fiction itself.
short_summary: Two seemingly unconnected stories—a young editor's affair with a famous older writer, and an Iraqi-American man detained at Heathrow—reveal unexpected connections in this inventive exploration of power, privilege, and storytelling.
author_bios: Lisa Halliday grew up in Medfield, Massachusetts and currently lives in Milan, Italy. Her work has appeared in The Paris Review and she is the recipient of a 2017 Whiting Award for Fiction. Asymmetry is her first novel.
quotes:
"Exquisite...For us, the ride is in surrendering to falling down rabbit holes to unknown places. The moment "Asymmetry" reaches its perfect ending, it's all the reader can do to return to the beginning in awe, to discover how Halliday upturned the story again and again."

—The Washington Post

"A scorchingly intelligent first novel. . . a clever comedy of manners set in Manhattan as well as a slowly unspooling tragedy about an Iraqi-American family, which poses deep questions about free will, fate and freedom, the all-powerful accident of one's birth and how life is alchemized into fiction. . . . [Asymmetry] will make you a better reader, a more active noticer. It hones your senses."

—Parul Seghal, The New York Times

"Lisa Halliday's debut novel starts like a story you've heard, only to become a book unlike any you've read. The initial mystery is how its pieces fit together; the lasting one is how she pulled the whole thing off. Deft, funny, and humane, Asymmetry is a profoundly necessary political novel about the place for art in an unjust world."

—Chad Harbach, author of The Art Of Fielding

title: Somebody's Daughter
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
For as long as she could remember, Ashley has put her father on a pedestal. Despite having only vague memories of seeing him face-to-face, she believes he's the only person in the entire world who understands her. She thinks she understands him too—he's sensitive like her, an artist, maybe even afraid of the dark. She's certain that one day they'll be reunited and she'll finally feel complete.

There are just a few problems: he's in prison, and she doesn't know what he did to end up there.

Through poverty, puberty, and a fraught relationship with her mother, Ashley returns to her image of her father for hope and encouragement. She doesn't know how to deal with the incessant worries that keep her up at night, or how to handle the changes in her body that draw unwanted attention from men. In her search for unconditional love, Ashley begins dating a boy her mother hates. When the relationship turns sour, he assaults her.

Still reeling from the rape, which she keeps secret from her family, Ashley finally learns why her father is in prison. And that's where the story really begins.

Somebody's Daughter steps into the world of growing up a poor Black girl, exploring how isolating and complex such a childhood can be. As Ashley battles her body and her environment, she provides a poignant coming-of-age recollection about finding the threads between who you are and what you were born into.
short_summary: Growing up poor and Black, Ashley clings to an idealized image of her incarcerated father—until devastating revelations force her to reckon with family, trauma, and survival. Ford's debut memoir is unflinching and luminous.
author_bios: Ashley C. Ford lives in Brooklyn by way of Indiana. She hosts The Chronicles of Now podcast and co-hosts The HBO companion podcast Lovecraft Country Radio. Ford has written for The Guardian, ELLE, BuzzFeed, Slate, Teen Vogue, The New York Times, and various other publications. Her writing has been listed among Longform & Longread's Best of 2017. She's been named among Forbes Magazine's 30 Under 30 in Media (2017) and Variety's New Power of New York (2019). She lives in Brooklyn with her husband Kelly Stacy and their chocolate lab Astro Renegade Ford-Stacy.
quotes:
"Ford creates fully three-dimensional portraits of her mother, grandmother, and other key players, using a child's-eye view to show us their failings and the calculations, negotiations, and survival tactics she developed in response to them."

—Kirkus Reviews

"Shoulder to shoulder with Ann Patchett and the greatest writers of our age.... There's such weight in this book. Such wisdom in this book, and grace and passion and truth. [Ford] wrote it with every cell in [her] body. I will always be a fan, and a fan of everything [she] writes."

—Elizabeth Gilbert

"Ashley C. Ford's wrenchingly brilliant memoir is truly a classic in the making. Ford's writing is so richly observed and so suffused with love and yearning that I kept forgetting to breathe while reading it."

—John Green, #1 New York Times bestselling author

title: The Furrows
long_summary:
Cassandra Williams is twelve; her little brother Wayne is seven. One day, when they're alone together, there is an accident and Wayne is lost forever. His body is never recovered.

The missing boy cleaves the family with doubt. Their father leaves, starts another family elsewhere. But their mother can't give up hope and launches an organization dedicated to missing children.

As C grows older, she sees her brother everywhere: in bistros, airplane aisles, subway cars. Here is her brother's older face, the light in his eyes, the way he seems to recognize her, too. But it can't be, of course. Or can it?

Then one day, in another accident, C meets a man both mysterious and familiar—a man who is also searching for someone and for his own place in the world. His name is Wayne.

Serpell's remarkable novel captures the uncanny experience of grief, the way the past breaks over the present like waves. The Furrows is a bold exploration of memory and mourning that twists unexpectedly into a story of mistaken identity, double consciousness, and the wishful longing for reunion with those we've lost.
short_summary: When twelve-year-old Cassandra loses her brother in a tragic accident, grief fractures her family and reshapes her reality. Years later, she begins seeing Wayne everywhere—until she meets a mysterious man with the same name.
author_bios: Namwali Serpell was born in Lusaka and lives in New York. She received a 2020 Windham-Campbell Prize, the 2015 Caine Prize for African Writing, and a 2011 Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award. Her debut novel, The Old Drift, won the Anisfield-Wolf Book Award, the Arthur C. Clarke Award, and the Los Angeles Times' Art Seidenbaum Award for First Fiction. Her nonfiction book, Stranger Faces, was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. She is a professor of English at Harvard.
quotes:
"Stylistically refreshing and emotionally intense, cementing Serpell's place among the best writers going."

—Kirkus

"With warmth and dexterity, Serpell has crafted a narrative that underscores how loss can show us the depths of our love."

—Time

"A genuine tour de force."

—Jonathan Lethem

title: The Vegetarian
long_summary:
Before the nightmares began, Yeong-hye and her husband lived an ordinary, controlled life. But the dreams—invasive images of blood and brutality—torture her, driving Yeong-hye to purge her mind and renounce eating meat altogether.

It's a small act of independence, but it interrupts her marriage and sets into motion an increasingly grotesque chain of events at home. As her husband, her brother-in-law and sister each fight to reassert their control, Yeong-hye obsessively defends the choice that's become sacred to her.

Soon their attempts turn desperate, subjecting first her mind, and then her body, to ever more intrusive violations, sending Yeong-hye spiraling into a dangerous, bizarre estrangement from those closest to her—and from herself.

Celebrated by critics around the world, The Vegetarian is a darkly allegorical, Kafka-esque tale of power, obsession, and one woman's struggle to break free from the violence both without and within her.
short_summary: When Yeong-hye decides to stop eating meat, her quiet rebellion spirals into surreal, devastating consequences for her family. A hypnotic novel of repression, desire, and defiance.
author_bios: Han Kang was born in 1970 in South Korea. She is the author of The Vegetarian, winner of the International Booker Prize, as well as Human Acts, The White Book, Greek Lessons, and We Do Not Part. In 2024, she was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
quotes:
"Surreal . . . [A] mesmerizing mix of sex and violence ."

—Alexandra Alter, The New York Times

"Compelling . . . [A] seamless union of the visceral and the surreal."

—Los Angeles Review of Books

"A complex, terrifying look at how seemingly simple decisions can affect multiple lives . . . In a world where women's bodies are constantly under scrutiny, the protagonist's desire to disappear inside of herself feels scarily familiar."

—Vanity Fair

title: All That She Carried
subtitle: The Journey of Ashley's Sack, a Black Family Keepsake
long_summary:
In 1850s South Carolina, an enslaved woman named Rose faced an unthinkable crisis: the imminent sale of her nine-year-old daughter Ashley. With little time and fewer options, Rose packed a cotton sack with a handful of precious items—a desperate act of love before mother and daughter were torn apart forever.

Decades later, Ashley's granddaughter Ruth would embroider their family's story onto that same sack in spare, haunting words that preserved what official records never could. Historian Tiya Miles carefully traces these women's faint presence in archives, but when documentation fails, she turns to objects, art, and landscape to reconstruct their lives.

The result is a singular history of slavery and the precarious freedom that followed—a poignant testament to resilience passed down against impossible odds. Miles honors the creativity of people who preserved family bonds when systems refused to recognize their humanity, offering a visionary model for recovering stories that were never meant to survive.
short_summary: A historian uses a cotton sack passed through three generations to reconstruct the lives of enslaved women erased from official records. Miles transforms fragments into a profound meditation on survival and memory.
author_bios: Tiya Miles is the Michael Garvey Professor of History at Harvard University, a 2011 MacArthur Fellowship recipient, and author of five prize-winning works, including the National Book Award–winning, best-selling All That She Carried. Miles founded and directed ECO Girls and lives in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"A history told with brilliance and tenderness and fearlessness."

—Jill Lepore, author of Book of Ages & These Truths: A History of the United States

"A remarkable book."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"[A] brilliant and compassionate account."

—Kirkus

title: Life After Life
long_summary:
On a cold and snowy night in 1910, Ursula Todd is born to an English banker and his wife. She dies before she can draw her first breath. On that same cold and snowy night, Ursula Todd is born, lets out a lusty wail, and embarks upon a life that will be unusual, to say the least.

As she grows, she also dies—repeatedly, in a variety of ways—while the young century marches toward its second cataclysmic world war. Each death becomes a new beginning, each life a chance to alter the course of history.

Does Ursula's apparently infinite number of lives give her the power to save the world from its inevitable destiny? And if she can—will she? Darkly comic, startlingly poignant, and utterly original, this is Kate Atkinson at her absolute best.
short_summary: Ursula Todd dies at birth, then lives again—and again—through multiple lifetimes spanning two world wars. A darkly comic exploration of fate, choice, and second chances that defies every expectation.
author_bios: Kate Atkinson is one of the world's foremost novelists. She won the Whitbread Book of the Year with her debut Behind the Scenes at the Museum. Her critically acclaimed novels include the recent Shrines of Gaiety, and her Second World War trilogy: Life After Life, A God in Ruins (both Costa Novel Award winners), and Transcription. Her bestselling Jackson Brodie crime series became a BBC television series. She was awarded an MBE in 2011 and is a Fellow of The Royal Society of Literature.
quotes:
"There aren't enough breathless adjectives to describe Life After Life: Dazzling, witty, moving, joyful, mournful, profound. Wildly inventive, deeply felt. Hilarious. Humane."

—Gillian Flynn, author of Gone Girl

"Kate Atkinson's new novel is a box of delights. Ingenious in construction, indefatigably entertaining, it grips the reader's imagination on the first page and never lets go. If you wish to be moved and astonished, read it. And if you want to give a dazzling present, buy it for your friends."

—Hilary Mantel, author of Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies

"Masterful...Atkinson not only invites readers in, she also asks them to give up their preconceptions of what a novel should be, and instead accept what a novel can be... What impresses me about this flip book of nonstop scenarios - in wartime and peacetime - is not only how absorbing they are, but how brave Atkinson is to have written them. After all, there really isn't much recent precedent for a major, serious yet playfully experimental novel with a female character at its center. Good for her to have given us one; we needed it...She opened her novel outward, letting it breathe unrestricted, all the while creating a strong, inviting draft of something that feels remarkably like life."

—Meg Wolitzer, NPR

title: Arguably
subtitle: Essays by Christopher Hitchens
long_summary:
Christopher Hitchens invites readers into a democratic conversation marked by formidable knowledge, encyclopedic recall, and fearless intellectual honesty. Reading him feels like hearing someone think out loud, following logic wherever it leads—unafraid to expose fraud, denounce injustice, or excoriate hypocrisy.

His felicity with language is legendary, every sentence crackling with oxygen and wit. Legions of readers, admirers and detractors alike, approach his work with something approaching awe at his readiness to fight intellectual battles and mount the ramparts for reason.

This collection offers fresh perceptions of figures as varied as Charles Dickens, Karl Marx, Rebecca West, George Orwell, J.G. Ballard, and Philip Larkin, matched by pungent discussions drawn from a lifetime of traveling and reporting from Iran, China, and Pakistan.

Hitchens's directness, elegance, and lightly carried erudition set a standard for the essayist rarely matched in our time. What emerges is an intellectual self-portrait of a writer with exemplary steadiness of purpose and a profound love affair with the English language—a man anchored in a humane vision of humanity's longing for reason and justice.
short_summary: Hitchens at his most essential: four decades of pitch-perfect prose defending the principles of reason, tolerance, and skepticism that define civilization. First-rate criticism that illuminates what we confront when grappling with fundamental truths.
author_bios: Christopher Hitchens was a contributing editor to Vanity Fair, Slate, and the Atlantic, and author of numerous books, including works on Thomas Jefferson, Thomas Paine, and George Orwell. He also wrote the international bestsellers god Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything, Hitch-22: A Memoir, and Arguably. He died in December 2011.
quotes:
"Bright, witty… one of the most lucid and humane voices of our age."

—The Globe and Mail

"Anyone who occasionally opens one of our more serious periodicals has learned that the byline of Christopher Hitchens is an opportunity to be delighted or maddened-possibly both-but in any case not to be missed....His range is extraordinary, both in breadth and altitude. He is as self-confident on the politics of Lebanon as on the ontology of the Harry Potter books....I still find Hitchens one of the most stimulating thinkers and entertaining we have, even when-perhaps especially when-he provokes."

—Bill Keller, The New York Times

"One reads him [Hitchens] despite his reputation as someone who wants to drink, argue, and tear the ornaments off the tree, because he is, first and last, a writer, an always exciting, often exacting, furious polemicist. This fact, the most salient thing about him, often gets neglected in the public jousting. Arguably, Hitchens's new collection, forcefully proves this point. Consisting of three kinds of writing - literary journalism, political commentary, and cultural complaint - Arguably offers a panoramic if somewhat jaundiced view of the last decade or so of cultural and political history."

—The Boston Globe

title: Exit West
long_summary:
In a country teetering on the brink of civil war, two young people meet—sensual, fiercely independent Nadia and gentle, restrained Saeed. They embark on a furtive love affair, cloistered in premature intimacy by the unrest roiling their city.

When violence explodes, turning familiar streets into a patchwork of checkpoints and bomb blasts, they begin to hear whispers about doors—magical portals that can whisk people far away, if perilously and for a price. As the violence escalates, Nadia and Saeed decide they no longer have a choice. Leaving their homeland and old lives behind, they find a door and step through.

Exit West follows these remarkable characters as they emerge into an alien and uncertain future, struggling to hold on to each other, to their past, to the very sense of who they are. Profoundly intimate and powerfully inventive, it tells an unforgettable story of love, loyalty, and courage that speaks to our current moment while remaining timelessly human.
short_summary: Two young lovers flee their war-torn homeland through magical doors that transport refugees across the globe. Hamid weaves a love story through the refugee experience with crystalline prose and fairy-tale elements.
author_bios: Mohsin Hamid is the author of five novels, including Booker Prize finalists and New York Times bestsellers Exit West and The Reluctant Fundamentalist. His essays, collected as Discontent and Its Civilizations, have appeared in The New York Times, The Washington Post, and elsewhere. He divides his time between Lahore, New York, and London.
quotes:
"In spare, crystalline prose, Hamid conveys the experience of living in a city under siege with sharp, stabbing immediacy. He shows just how swiftly ordinary life — with all its banal rituals and routines — can morph into the defensive crouch of life in a war zone. … [and] how insidiously violence alters the calculus of daily life. … By mixing the real and the surreal, and using old fairy-tale magic, Hamid has created a fictional universe that captures the global perils percolating beneath today's headlines."

—Michiko Kakutani, New York Times

"No novel is really about the cliche called 'the human condition,' but good novels expose and interpret the particular condition of the humans in their charge, and this is what Hamid has achieved here. If in its physical and perilous immediacy Nadia and Saeed's condition is alien to the mass of us, Exit West makes a final, certain declaration of affinity: 'We are all migrants through time.'"

—Washington Post

"This is the best writing of Hamid's career… Readers will find themselves going back and savoring each paragraph several times before moving on. He's that good. . . . Breathtaking."

—NPR

title: The Invention of Nature
subtitle: Alexander von Humboldt's New World
long_summary:
Alexander von Humboldt (1769–1859) was an intrepid explorer and the most famous scientist of his age. In North America, his name still graces four counties, thirteen towns, a river, parks, bays, lakes, and mountains. His restless life was packed with adventure and discovery, whether he was climbing the world's highest volcanoes, racing through anthrax-infected Siberia, or translating his research into bestselling publications that transformed science and thinking.

Among Humboldt's most revolutionary ideas was a radical vision of nature as a complex, interconnected global force that doesn't exist for humankind's use alone. Andrea Wulf brings this remarkable figure back into focus, chronicling his daring expeditions and investigations of wild environments worldwide, his discoveries of similarities between climate zones on different continents, and his prescient prediction of human-induced climate change.

Wulf explores how Humboldt's writings inspired naturalists and poets like Darwin, Wordsworth, and Goethe, making a compelling case that his influence led John Muir to natural preservation and shaped Thoreau's Walden. Through brilliant research and compelling prose, Wulf reveals how Humboldt created our modern understanding of the natural world and champions renewed interest in this vital figure in environmental history.
short_summary: The forgotten story of Alexander von Humboldt, the visionary German naturalist whose revolutionary ideas about interconnected nature created modern environmentalism and inspired Darwin, Thoreau, and countless others.
author_bios: Andrea Wulf was born in India and moved to Germany as a child. She is the author of Founding Gardeners, Brother Gardeners, and the New York Times bestseller The Invention of Nature, published in twenty-seven languages and winner of fifteen international literary awards. She has written for The New York Times, The Guardian, the Los Angeles Times, The Wall Street Journal, and The Atlantic. A member of PEN America and fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, she lives in London.
quotes:
"Andrea Wulf is a writer of rare sensibilities and passionate fascinations. I always trust her to take me on unforgettable journeys through amazing histories of botanical exploration and scientific unfolding. Her work is wonderful, her language sublime, her intelligence unflagging."

—Elizabeth Gilbert, bestselling author of The Signature of All Things and Big Magic

"Wulf (Chasing Venus) makes an impassioned case for the reinstatement of the boundlessly energetic, perpetually curious, prolific polymath von Humboldt (1769–1859) as a key figure in the history of science. . . . Wulf's stories of wilderness adventure and academic exchange flow easily, and her affection for von Humboldt is contagious."

—Publishers Weekly

"Engrossing. . . . Humboldt was the Einstein of the 19th century but far more widely read, and Wulf successfully combines a biography with an intoxicating history of his times."

—Kirkus

title: Empire of Pain
subtitle: The Secret History of the Sackler Dynasty
long_summary:
The Sackler dynasty's history reads like a dark fairy tale—baroque personal lives, bitter estate disputes, boardroom fistfights, glittering art collections, and Machiavellian legal maneuvers. Their name adorns Harvard, the Met, Oxford, and the Louvre. They're one of the world's richest families, but the source of their fortune remained deliberately vague until a devastating truth emerged: the Sacklers built their empire on the painkiller that sparked America's opioid crisis.

Empire of Pain traces three generations of this singular family, moving from early twentieth-century Brooklyn to Greenwich mansions and Cap d'Antibes estates to Washington's corridors of power. It follows their early success with Valium to the far more potent OxyContin, marketed through ruthless tactics—co-opting doctors, influencing the FDA, systematically downplaying addiction risks.

Keefe chronicles the multiple investigations into the Sacklers and their company, revealing the scorched-earth legal strategies they deployed to evade accountability. This masterpiece of narrative reporting delivers a ferociously compelling portrait of America's second Gilded Age—a study of elite impunity and an unflinching investigation of the naked greed behind one of the world's great fortunes.
short_summary: Three generations of the Sackler family built a fortune on Valium and OxyContin while their name graced museum walls worldwide. Keefe's devastating investigation reveals how philanthropy masked the ruthless tactics behind America's opioid crisis.
author_bios: Patrick Radden Keefe is a staff writer at The New Yorker and author of New York Times bestsellers Rogues, Empire of Pain (winner of the Baillie Gifford Prize), and Say Nothing, which received a National Book Critics Circle Award and was named one of the Twenty Best Books of the 21st Century by The New York Times Book Review. He's received a Guggenheim Fellowship, the National Magazine Award, and the Orwell Prize, and served as executive producer on the award-winning FX series Say Nothing.
quotes:
"An engrossing (and frequently enraging) tale of striving, secrecy and self-delusion….Keefe nimbly guides us through the thicket of family intrigues and betrayals… Even when detailing the most sordid episodes, Keefe's narrative voice is calm and admirably restrained, allowing his prodigious reporting to speak for itself. His portrait of the family is all the more damning for its stark lucidity."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"A brutal, multigenerational treatment of the Sackler family… Keefe deepens the narrative by tracing the family's ambitions and ruthless methods back to the founding patriarch, Arthur Sackler…His life might be a model for the American dream, if it hadn't arguably laid the foundations for a still-unfolding national tragedy."

—Brian Mann, NPR

"A damning portrait of the Sacklers, the billionaire clan behind the OxyContin epidemic. If you are someone who engages in this kind of sneaky conduct, the last person you want reporting on you is Keefe….[He] has a knack for crafting lucid, readable descriptions of the sort of arcane business arrangements the Sacklers favored. He is also indefatigable….The Sackler infighting described in Empire of Pain will surely prompt many comparisons to the HBO series Succession."

—Laura Miller, Slate

title: A Manual for Cleaning Women
subtitle: Selected Stories
long_summary:
A Manual for Cleaning Women compiles the best work of legendary short-story writer Lucia Berlin. With the grit of Raymond Carver, the humor of Grace Paley, and a blend of wit and melancholy all her own, Berlin crafts miracles from the everyday.

She uncovers moments of grace in the Laundromats and halfway houses of the American Southwest, in the homes of the Bay Area upper class, among switchboard operators and struggling mothers, hitchhikers and bad Christians. Her stories are inspired by a life lived fully—from her childhood in Western mining towns to glamorous teenage years in Santiago, Chile, through three failed marriages, battles with alcoholism, and the various jobs she held to support her writing and four sons.

Readers will revel in this remarkable collection from a master of the form and wonder how they'd ever overlooked her in the first place.
short_summary: Hard-living women navigate Laundromats, halfway houses, and the margins of American life in these unforgettable stories. Berlin writes with devastating humor and grace about the everyday miracles found in struggle.
author_bios: Lucia Berlin (1936-2004) worked brilliantly but sporadically throughout the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s. Her stories draw from her childhood in Western mining towns, glamorous teenage years in Santiago, Chile, three failed marriages, lifelong struggles with alcoholism, and years in Berkeley, New Mexico, and Mexico City. Sober and writing steadily by the 1990s, she joined the University of Colorado Boulder as visiting writer in 1994, soon promoted to associate professor. She died in 2004 in Marina del Rey.
quotes:
"In A Manual for Cleaning Women we witness the emergence of an important American writer, one who was mostly overlooked in her time. Ms. Berlin's stories make you marvel at the contingencies of our existence. She is the real deal. Her stories swoop low over towns and moods and minds."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A posthumous collection of stories, almost uniformly narrated by hard-living women, that makes a case for the author as a major talent . . . The prevailing sensibility of this book, collecting 43 of the 76 stories Berlin published, is cleareyed and even comic in the face of life hitting the skids. The title story, for instance, balances wry commentary about housecleaning work ('never make friends with cats') and deadpan observation ('I clean their coke mirror with Windex') with a sad, thrumming back story."

—Kirkus

"[Lucia Berlin] may just be the best writer you've never heard of . . . Imagine a less urban Grace Paley, with a similar talent for turning the net of resentments and affections among family members into stories that carry more weight than their casual, conversational tone might initially suggest . . . Berlin's offbeat humor, get-on-with-it realism, and ability to layer details that echo across stories and decades give her book a tremendous staying power."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Men We Reaped
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In five years, Jesmyn Ward lost five young men in her life—to drugs, accidents, suicide, and the bad luck that follows people who live in poverty, particularly Black men. Dealing with these losses, one after another, made her ask: Why?

As she began to write about the experience of living through all the dying, she realized the devastating truth. Her brother and friends all died because of who they were and where they were from—because they lived with a history of racism and economic struggle that fostered drug addiction and the dissolution of family and relationships.

Ward grew up in poverty in rural Mississippi. She writes powerfully about the pressures this brings, on the men who can do no right and the women who stand in for family in a society where the men are often absent. As the sole member of her family to leave home and pursue higher education, she writes about this parallel American universe with the objectivity distance provides and the intimacy of utter familiarity. A brutal world rendered beautifully.
short_summary: Ward examines the deaths of five young men in her life—including her brother—and finds the devastating truth in rural poverty and systemic racism. Heartbreaking and essential.
author_bios: Jesmyn Ward received her MFA from the University of Michigan and has received the MacArthur Genius Grant, a Stegner Fellowship, the Strauss Living Prize, and the 2022 Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction. She won two National Book Awards for Fiction for Sing, Unburied, Sing and Salvage the Bones. She's also the author of Where the Line Bleeds and the memoir Men We Reaped, which won the Chicago Tribune Heartland Prize. She's a professor of creative writing at Tulane University and lives in Mississippi.
quotes:
"Men We Reaped reaffirms Ms. Ward's substantial talent. It's an elegiac book that's rangy at the same time. She thinks back about her brother, and about her old dead friends, and about their nighttime adventures in cars. Then she declares, 'I don't ride with anyone like that anymore.'"

—Dwight Garner, New York Times

"An assured yet scarifying memoir by young, supremely gifted novelist [Jesmyn] Ward... With more gumption than many, Ward battled not only the indifferent odds of rural poverty, but also the endless racism of her classmates... A modern rejoinder to Black Like Me, Beloved and other stories of struggle and redemption - beautifully written, if sometimes too sad to bear."

—Kirkus

"Ward has a soft touch, making these stories heartbreakingly real through vivid portrayal and dialogue."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Great Believers
long_summary:
In 1985 Chicago, Yale Tishman is on the verge of a career-defining moment as development director for an art gallery, securing an extraordinary collection of 1920s paintings. But as his professional life flourishes, the AIDS epidemic devastates his world. One by one, his friends are dying, and after attending his friend Nico's funeral, Yale watches the virus circle closer to home. Soon the only person he has left is Fiona, Nico's younger sister.

Thirty years later, Fiona travels to Paris to track down her estranged daughter, who has disappeared into a cult. While staying with an old friend—a photographer who documented the Chicago AIDS crisis—she finally confronts how the epidemic shaped her life and fractured her relationship with her daughter. These two intertwining narratives span decades of heartbreak and resilience, following Yale and Fiona as they search for hope and connection amid devastating loss.
short_summary: Two interconnected stories of love and loss unfold across 1980s Chicago and present-day Paris. As the AIDS epidemic devastates one man's world, a woman decades later reckons with how that crisis shaped her life.
author_bios: Rebecca Makkai's novel The Great Believers was a finalist for both the Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award, winning the ALA Carnegie Medal, Stonewall Book Award, Clark Prize, and Los Angeles Times Book Prize. The New York Times named it one of 2018's Ten Best Books. Her other works include novels The Borrower and The Hundred-Year House, plus collection Music for Wartime. A 2022 Guggenheim Fellow, she teaches in MFA programs at University of Nevada, Reno at Lake Tahoe and Northwestern University, and serves as Artistic Director of StoryStudio Chicago.
quotes:
"Tearjerker… The Great Believers asks big questions about redemption, tragedy, and connection. Makkai has written her most ambitious novel yet."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Stirring, spellbinding and full of life."

—Téa Obreht, New York Times bestselling author of The Tiger's Wife

"The Great Believers kept me up reading late into the night, and I'd wake up thinking about Makkai's vibrant, complex, and deeply human characters. This is an immersive, heartbreaking novel—I loved it."

—Maggie Shipstead, author of The Great Circle & Astonish Me

title: State of Wonder
long_summary:
Years ago, Marina Singh traded the intensity of medical practice for the quieter world of pharmaceutical research—a choice that has haunted her ever since. She's built a careful life of limited risk, sharing quiet intimacy with her widowed boss, Mr. Fox, and warm friendship with colleague Anders Eckman.

But Marina's security shatters when Anders dies on a mission to the Amazon, sent to check on a field team that's gone silent. Now Mr. Fox wants her to venture into the jungle to discover what happened.

Plagued by trepidation yet propelled by duty, Marina embarks on an odyssey into the Amazonian delta. Deep in the dense, insect-infested jungle, she must find the company's research team, led by the formidable Dr. Annick Swenson. The scientists are developing a drug that could revolutionize Western society, but they've been silent for two years.

Dr. Swenson doesn't welcome interlopers—and Marina knows this all too well. The eminent, uncompromising doctor was once her mentor, the woman she admired, emulated, and feared. To fulfill her mission, Marina must confront ghosts from her past and unfulfilled dreams, making painful moral choices that will take her deep into her own heart of darkness.
short_summary: When a colleague dies mysteriously in the Amazon, pharmaceutical researcher Marina Singh must venture into the jungle to uncover the truth. There she confronts her formidable former mentor and a research project that challenges everything she believes about science and morality.
author_bios: Ann Patchett is the author of novels, most recently the #1 New York Times bestselling Tom Lake, works of nonfiction, and children's books. She has received numerous awards, including the PEN/Faulkner, the Women's Prize for Fiction, and the Book Sense Book of the Year. Her novel The Dutch House was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Time magazine named her one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World. President Biden awarded her the National Humanities Medal. She owns Parnassus Books in Nashville, Tennessee.
quotes:
"An engaging, consummately told tale."

—New York Times

"This is surely the smartest, most exciting novel of the summer."

—Washington Post

"The Amazon setting is something Patchett does rather marvelously.… The book is serious, but also so pleasurable that you hope it won't end."

—NPR

title: Caste
subtitle: The Origins of Our Discontents
long_summary:
Beyond race, class, or other factors, there is a powerful caste system that influences people's lives and behavior and the nation's fate. Isabel Wilkerson explores eight pillars that underlie caste systems across civilizations, including divine will, bloodlines, and stigma, linking the systems of America, India, and Nazi Germany.

Using riveting stories about people—including Martin Luther King Jr., baseball's Satchel Paige, a single father and his toddler son, and Wilkerson herself—she reveals how the insidious undertow of caste is experienced every day. Through meticulous research and powerful storytelling, she exposes the invisible hierarchy that has shaped American society for centuries.

Finally, she points toward ways America can move beyond the artificial and destructive separations of human divisions, offering hope in our common humanity and a path forward from this hidden system of oppression.
short_summary: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Warmth of Other Suns examines the unspoken caste system that has shaped America. Wilkerson reveals how our lives remain defined by an invisible hierarchy of human divisions.
