genres: Social Science / Social Classes & Economic Disparity
author_bios: Isabel Wilkerson, winner of the Pulitzer Prize and the National Humanities Medal, is the author of the critically acclaimed New York Times bestseller The Warmth of Other Suns, which won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Nonfiction and was named to Time's 10 Best Nonfiction Books of the 2010s. She has taught at Princeton, Emory, and Boston Universities and has lectured at more than two hundred colleges and universities worldwide.
quotes:
"This book has the reverberating and patriotic slap of the best American prose writing. . . . Wilkerson has written a closely argued book that largely avoids the word 'racism,' yet stares it down with more humanity and rigor than nearly all but a few books in our literature. . . . It's a book that changes the weather inside a reader."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A surprising and arresting wide-angle reframing . . . Her epilogue feels like a prayer for a country in pain, offering new directions through prophetic language."

—Bilal Qureshi, The Washington Post

"This enthralling exposé deserves a wide and impassioned readership."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Tenth of December
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
George Saunders returns with a masterful collection that showcases his literary powers at their peak. These stories snare readers immediately, placing them right in the moment as events unfold with beautiful, profound meaning.

The title story offers an exquisite account of two unlikely figures meeting at a frozen lake—a young misfit and a middle-aged cancer patient contemplating suicide, who ends up saving the boy's life instead. "Home" provides a funny yet poignant portrait of a soldier returning from war, while "Victory Lap" delivers a taut, inventive narrative about the attempted abduction of a teenage girl.

Throughout, Saunders demonstrates his signature ability to find humanity in the most unexpected places. His characters are lost souls and everyday heroes, rendered with equal parts humor and heartbreak. The stories tackle weighty themes—mortality, homecoming, violence—but never feel heavy-handed or preachy.

Tenth of December represents Saunders at his absolute best, offering a collection of stories and characters that add up to something deep, irreducible, and uniquely American.
short_summary: Saunders crafts stories that are simultaneously hilarious and heartbreaking, finding profound humanity in unlikely encounters. His characters—misfits, soldiers, suburban families—navigate life's absurdities with grace and grit.
author_bios: George Saunders is the author of thirteen books, including the novel Lincoln in the Bardo, which won the Man Booker Prize, and five story collections, including Tenth of December, a National Book Award finalist, and Liberation Day (selected by President Obama as one of his ten favorite books of 2022). Three of his books—Pastoralia, Tenth of December, and Lincoln in the Bardo—were chosen for The New York Times's 100 Best Books of the 21st Century. He hosts Story Club on Substack and teaches at Syracuse University.
quotes:
"A visceral and moving act of storytelling…No one writes more powerfully than George Saunders about the lost, the unlucky, the disenfranchised."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Tenth of December shows George Saunders at his most subversive, hilarious, and emotionally piercing. Few writers can encompass that range of adjectives, but Saunders is a true original—restlessly inventive, yet deeply humane."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of A Visit from the Goon Squad

"George Saunders is a complete original, unlike anyone else, thank god—and yet still he manages to be the rightful heir to three other complete American originals—Barthelme (the lyricism, the playfulness), Vonnegut (the outrage, the wit, the scope), and Twain (the common sense, the exasperation). There is no author I recommend to people more often—for ten years I've urged George Saunders onto everyone and everyone. You want funny? Saunders is your man. You want emotional heft? Saunders again. You want stories that are actually about something—stories that again and again get to the meat of matters of life and death and justice and country? Saunders. There is no one better, no one more essential to our national sense of self and sanity."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

title: Secondhand Time
subtitle: The Last of the Soviets
long_summary:
When the Swedish Academy awarded Svetlana Alexievich the Nobel Prize, it cited her for inventing "a new kind of literary genre," describing her work as "a history of emotions—a history of the soul." Her distinctive documentary style combines extended individual monologues with a collage of voices, recording the stories of ordinary people whose experiences are often lost in official histories.

In Secondhand Time, Alexievich chronicles the demise of communism through the voices of everyday Russian citizens recounting the past thirty years. Through interviews spanning 1991 to 2012, she takes us behind propaganda and contrived media accounts, offering a panoramic portrait of contemporary Russia and Russians who carry memories of oppression, terror, and famine—but also pride, hope, and belief in a collective utopian dream.

This magnificent tapestry of human sorrow and triumph tells the stories that make up the true history of a nation. As The Nation writes, "Through the voices of those who confided in her, Alexievich tells us about human nature, about our dreams, our choices, about good and evil—in a word, about ourselves."
short_summary: Nobel laureate Alexievich weaves together voices of ordinary Russians to chronicle the collapse of the Soviet Union and its aftermath. An extraordinary oral history that captures both collective trauma and individual resilience.
author_bios: Svetlana Alexievich was born in Ivano-Frankivsk, Ukraine, in 1948 and has spent most of her life in the Soviet Union and present-day Belarus, with prolonged periods of exile in Western Europe. Starting as a journalist, she developed her own nonfiction genre gathering voices to describe historical moments. Her works include War's Unwomanly Face (1985), Last Witnesses (1985), Zinky Boys (1990), Voices from Chernobyl (1997), and Secondhand Time (2013). She won the 2015 Nobel Prize in Literature "for her polyphonic writings, a monument to suffering and courage in our time."
quotes:
"Already hailed as a masterpiece across Europe, Secondhand Time is an intimate portrait of a country yearning for meaning after the sudden lurch from Communism to capitalism in the 1990s plunged it into existential crisis."

—The New York Times

"A trove of emotions and memories, raw and powerful . . . [Secondhand Time] is one of the most vivid and incandescent accounts of [Soviet] society caught in the throes of change that anyone has yet attempted. . . . Alexievich stations herself at a crossroads of history and turns on her tape recorder. . . . [She] makes it feel intimate, as if you are sitting in the kitchen with the characters, sharing in their happiness and agony."

—The Washington Post

"[Alexievich] documents the last days of the Soviet Union and the transition to capitalism in a soul-wrenching 'oral history' that reveals the very different sides of the Russian experience. . . . [Her] work turns Solzhenitsyn inside out and overpowers recent journalistic accounts of the era. . . . She spends hours recording conversations, sometimes returning years later, and always trying to go beyond the battered and distrusted communal pravda to seek the truths hidden within individuals."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Stay True
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In the eyes of eighteen-year-old Hua Hsu, the problem with Ken—with his passion for Dave Matthews, Abercrombie & Fitch, and his fraternity—is that he is exactly like everyone else. Ken, whose Japanese American family has been in the United States for generations, is mainstream; for Hua, the son of Taiwanese immigrants who makes 'zines and haunts Bay Area record shops, Ken represents all that he defines himself in opposition to. The only thing they have in common is that American culture doesn't seem to have a place for either of them.

But despite his first impressions, Hua and Ken become friends—a friendship built on late-night conversations over cigarettes, long drives along the California coast, and the successes and humiliations of everyday college life. And then violently, senselessly, Ken is gone, killed in a carjacking not even three years after they first meet.

Determined to hold on to what was left of one of his closest friends—his memories—Hua turned to writing. Stay True is the book he's been working on ever since. A bracing memoir about growing up and moving through the world in search of meaning and belonging.
short_summary: Hua Hsu excavates the friendship that defined his college years—and the violent loss that ended it. A profound meditation on grief, identity, and the art that helps us make sense of senseless tragedy.
author_bios: Hua Hsu is a staff writer at The New Yorker and a professor of Literature at Bard College. He serves on the executive board of the Asian American Writers' Workshop and was formerly a fellow at the New America Foundation and the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center at the New York Public Library. He lives in Brooklyn with his family.
quotes:
"[Hsu] is that rare thing: a chronicler and critic who [engages] fully, emotionally as well as intellectually, with every subject. . . In Stay True Hsu makes us see how his and Ken's and their friends' stories are tossed on the sea of history, how identity takes shape from a thousand factors, how personalities flow into one another, how chance and destiny can be hard to tell apart."

—Lucy Sante, The New York Review of Books

"At once a coming-of-age memoir, a devastating elegy for a departed friend, and a mixtape of all the music and other shards of culture and experience that coalesce into an identity, Stay True is wildly original. Hua Hsu writes with such grace and wry humor about so many things: friendship and loss, being young, the joys of hanging out, the pleasures and comforts of inconsequential passions. A glorious, unforgettable book."

—Patrick Radden Keefe, winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award and New York Times bestselling author of Say Nothing and Empire of Pain

"Stay True feels like one of those books that is the sum total of a writer's life in thinking, craft, and curiosity, made felt at last, so that when the sentences come, they come with a deliberate, patient, and precise force. Hsu takes on the central theme of a friend's violent loss and casts from that void a story that, somehow, despite the hurt and confusion, embraces the world around it with a steady and capacious centrifugal force. This is the endeavor of writing at its most open, meticulous, forgiving and tender—which is to say, this is writing at its best."

—Ocean Vuong, New York Times bestselling author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous

title: Euphoria
long_summary:
English anthropologist Andrew Bankson has spent years alone in the field, studying the Kiona river tribe in the Territory of New Guinea. Haunted by his brothers' deaths and increasingly isolated by his research, Bankson teeters on the verge of suicide when a chance encounter pulls him back from the brink.

The controversial Nell Stone and her mercurial Australian husband Fen have just fled the bloodthirsty Mumbanyo tribe. Despite Nell's poor health, they're hungry for a new discovery. When Bankson finds them a new tribe nearby—the artistic, female-dominated Tam—he ignites an intellectual and romantic firestorm between the three that burns beyond anyone's control.

Set between two World Wars and inspired by events in the life of revolutionary anthropologist Margaret Mead, this enthralling novel explores passion, possession, and the dangerous territory where scientific discovery meets human desire.
short_summary: Three anthropologists in 1930s New Guinea become entangled in a love triangle that threatens their work and their lives. Inspired by Margaret Mead's controversial expeditions, this is intellectual passion at its most dangerous.
author_bios: Lily King is the New York Times bestselling author of six novels, including Euphoria and Writers & Lovers, and the story collection Five Tuesdays in Winter. Her work has won the Kirkus Prize, the New England Book Award for Fiction, the Maine Book Award for Fiction, and a Whiting Award. Her books have been translated into twenty-eight languages. She lives in Portland, Maine.
quotes:
"Atmospheric...A small gem, disturbing and haunting."

—Kirkus

"The love lives and expeditions of controversial anthropologists Margaret Mead, Reo Fortune, and Gregory Bateson are fictionalized and richly reimagined in New England Book Award winner King's (Father of the Rain) meaty and entrancing fourth book...King's immersive prose takes center stage. The fascinating descriptions of tribal customs and rituals, paired with snippets of Nell's journals—as well as the characters' insatiable appetites for scientific discovery—all contribute to a thrilling read that, at its end, does indeed feel like 'the briefest, purest euphoria.'"

—Publishers Weekly

"Atmospheric and sensual, with startling images throughout, Euphoria is an intellectually stimulating tour de force."

—NPR

title: Intimacies
long_summary:
An interpreter arrives at The Hague's International Court, fleeing New York in search of a place to finally call home. A woman of many languages and identities, she finds herself caught between worlds—professional and personal, truth and deception.

She's immediately drawn into simmering dramas: her lover Adriaan remains entangled with his estranged wife, while her friend Jana witnesses a brutal act of violence that becomes the interpreter's growing obsession as she befriends the victim's sister. When she's assigned to interpret for a former president accused of war crimes, she's thrust into an explosive political controversy.

A woman of quiet intensity, she navigates power, love, and violence both in her intimate relationships and her work at the Court. As betrayal and heartbreak threaten to overwhelm her, she's forced to confront what she truly wants from her life—and what she's willing to sacrifice to get it.
short_summary: An interpreter at The Hague's International Court becomes entangled in personal dramas and political controversy. Kitamura crafts a taut exploration of identity, power, and the search for home.
author_bios: Katie Kitamura is the author of four previous novels, most recently A Separation and Intimacies, which was longlisted for the National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award and was a finalist for a Joyce Carol Oates Prize. She is a recipient of the Rome Prize in Literature and a Lannan fellowship. Her work has been translated into twenty-one languages. She teaches in the creative writing program at New York University.
quotes:
"[C]ooly written and casts a spell… One of Kitamura's gifts… is to inject every scene with a pinprick of dread…. One of the best novels I've read in 2021… A taut, moody novel that moves purposefully between worlds."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Katie Kitamura's fourth novel spins a taut web of dread from the start. . . In cool, spare prose, Kitamura asks the book's animating query: How should you go about your little life in a world where horrible things are happening?"

—Stephanie Hayes, The Atlantic

"Fans of sparse millennial tales: Run, don't walk."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: The Sixth Extinction
subtitle: An Unnatural History
long_summary:
Over the last half billion years, five mass extinctions have dramatically contracted life on Earth. Scientists worldwide are now monitoring the sixth extinction—predicted to be the most devastating since the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs. This time, the cataclysm is us.

Two-time National Magazine Award winner and New Yorker writer Elizabeth Kolbert draws on research across multiple disciplines, accompanying scientists into the field: geologists studying deep ocean cores, botanists following tree lines climbing the Andes, marine biologists diving the Great Barrier Reef.

She introduces us to a dozen species—some already gone, others facing extinction—including the Panamanian golden frog, staghorn coral, the great auk, and the Sumatran rhino. Through these stories, Kolbert provides a moving account of disappearances occurring around us and traces extinction as a concept, from its first articulation by Georges Cuvier in revolutionary Paris to today. The sixth extinction will likely be humanity's most lasting legacy, compelling us to rethink what it means to be human.
short_summary: Kolbert follows scientists across the globe documenting the mass extinction unfolding before our eyes. A masterwork of science writing that's both intellectually rigorous and deeply moving.
author_bios: Elizabeth Kolbert is the bestselling author of Field Notes from a Catastrophe, The Sixth Extinction, for which she won the Pulitzer Prize, and Under a White Sky, which was named a top ten book of the year by The Washington Post. For her work at The New Yorker, where she's a staff writer, she has received two National Magazine Awards and the Blake-Dodd Prize from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She lives in Williamstown, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"An epic, riveting story of our species that reads like a scientific thriller--only more terrifying because it is real. Like Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, Elizabeth Kolbert's The Sixth Extinction is destined to become one of the most important and defining books of our time."

—David Grann, author of Killers of the Flower Moon & The Lost City of Z

"[The Sixth Extinction] is a wonderful book, and it makes very clear that big, abrupt changes can happen; they're not outside the realm of possibility. They have happened before, they can happen again."

—President Barack Obama

"Elizabeth Kolbert's cautionary tale, The Sixth Extinction, offers us a cogent overview of a harrowing biological challenge. The reporting is exceptional, the contextualizing exemplary. Kolbert stands at the forefront of what it means to be a socially responsible American writer today."

—Barry Lopez, author of Arctic Dreams

title: Cleopatra
subtitle: A Life
long_summary:
Her palace shimmered with onyx, garnets, and gold, but was richer still in political and sexual intrigue. Above all else, Cleopatra was a shrewd strategist and an ingenious negotiator.

Though her life spanned fewer than forty years, it reshaped the contours of the ancient world. She was married twice, each time to a brother. She waged brutal civil war against the first when both were teenagers. She poisoned the second. Ultimately she dispensed with an ambitious sister as well; incest and assassination were family specialties.

Cleopatra appears to have had relationships with only two men—but they happened to be Julius Caesar and Mark Antony, among the most prominent Romans of the day. She had a child with Caesar and three more with Antony after Caesar's murder. Already the wealthiest ruler in the Mediterranean, her alliance with Antony confirmed her status as the most influential woman of the age.

Famous long before she was notorious, Cleopatra has gone down in history for all the wrong reasons. Shakespeare, Shaw, Michelangelo, and Elizabeth Taylor have all shaped her legend. In this masterly return to classical sources, Stacy Schiff boldly separates fact from fiction to rescue the magnetic queen whose death ushered in a new world order.
short_summary: Stacy Schiff strips away centuries of myth to reveal the real Cleopatra—brilliant strategist, master negotiator, and the most powerful woman in the ancient world. A luminous biography that reads like epic drama.
author_bios: Stacy Schiff is the author of Véra (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov), winner of the Pulitzer Prize; Saint-Exupéry, a Pulitzer Prize finalist; A Great Improvisation: Franklin, France, and the Birth of America, winner of the George Washington Book Prize; Cleopatra: A Life, winner of the PEN/Jacqueline Bograd Weld Award; and The Witches: Salem, 1692. She has received fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation and the National Endowment for the Humanities. A member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, she lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Stacy Schiff does a rare thing: She gives us a book we'd miss if it didn't exist."

—Wall Street Journal

"A masterpiece."

—Daily Beast

title: The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois
long_summary:
"My life had its significance and its only deep significance because it was part of a Problem," W. E. B. Du Bois once wrote. Ailey Pearl Garfield has understood these words since childhood. Named for choreographer Alvin Ailey and her enslaved great-grandmother, she carries the weight of this Problem on her shoulders.

Raised by an accomplished doctor and strict schoolteacher, Ailey splits her time between the City and summers in Chicasetta, Georgia, where her mother's family has lived since their ancestors arrived in bondage. She struggles with this duality—caught between her exacting parents and imperious, light-skinned grandmother Nana Claire, who values skin color above all, and the pull of the "deep country" where her mother's family endured slavery and Jim Crow.

How can Ailey meet everyone's expectations when half her family rejects their fraught racial history while the rest can't break free from it? To understand who she is, Ailey embarks on a journey through her family's past, uncovering shocking tales of generations of ancestors—Black, Indigenous, and white—in the deep South. She must learn to embrace her full heritage: a legacy of oppression and resistance, bondage and independence that tells the story of the Black experience in America itself.
short_summary: Ailey Pearl Garfield navigates between her accomplished urban family and her rural Georgia roots, uncovering generations of ancestors whose stories reveal the complexity of Black American identity. A sweeping family saga that traces centuries of history through one woman's search for belonging.
author_bios: Honorée Fanonne Jeffers is a fiction writer, poet, and essayist. Her acclaimed debut novel The Love Songs of W. E. B. Du Bois became a New York Times bestseller and Oprah's Book Club pick, winning the National Book Critics Circle Award and Dayton Literary Peace Prize while earning a National Book Award nomination. She's also authored five poetry collections, including the NAACP Image Award–winning The Age of Phillis.
quotes:
"The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois is epic in its scope. [It] traces the story of a family, the town in Georgia where they come from, and their migration outward over generations. The word epic is overused these days, but this book was meant to be an epic and it is. . . . This is one of the most American books I have ever read. It's a book about the United States. It's a book about the legacy of slavery in this country. . . . And it's also a book about traumas and loves that sustain over generations."

—Noel King, NPR

"Whatever must be said to get you to heft this daunting debut novel by Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, I'll say, because The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois is the kind of book that comes around only once a decade. Yes, at roughly 800 pages, it is, indeed, a mountain to climb, but the journey is engrossing, and the view from the summit will transform your understanding of America. . . . With the depth of its intelligence and the breadth of its vision, The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois is simply magnificent."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Jeffers crafts not just a history of Black women in the United States but an essential way of looking at their inheritance—one that folds familiarity into proficiency. Generous, wise, and fearless, she travels through the wounds of past and present with remarkable grace and gripping narratives."

—Kirkus

title: The Power
long_summary:
The world starts familiar enough: a wealthy Nigerian teenager lounging by the family pool, a foster kid navigating religious parents with hidden agendas, an ambitious American politician climbing the ladder, a scrappy London girl from a complicated family.

Then everything changes. Teenage girls develop a devastating new ability—they can inflict excruciating pain, even death, with just a touch. This small twist of biology becomes a seismic shift that resets civilization entirely.

From award-winning author Naomi Alderman, The Power follows these interconnected lives as they navigate a world turned upside down. What happens when the traditionally powerless suddenly hold all the cards? Alderman crafts speculative fiction at its most provocative—a thrilling alternate reality that exposes uncomfortable truths about our own world.
short_summary: Teenage girls develop the ability to inflict pain and death with their touch, upending civilization. Alderman's speculative thriller follows interconnected lives navigating this new world order.
author_bios: Naomi Alderman is the bestselling author of The Power, which won the Women's Prize for Fiction and was chosen as a book of the year by The New York Times, The Washington Post, and the Los Angeles Times. Both Barack Obama and Bill Gates recommended it as a book of the year. Mentored by Margaret Atwood via the Rolex Arts Initiative, she is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature. Her work has been translated into more than thirty-five languages. She is also cocreator of the award-winning game Zombies, Run! and professor of creative writing at Bath Spa University.
quotes:
"Electrifying! Shocking! Will knock your socks off! Then you'll think twice, about everything."

—Margaret Atwood

"I was riveted by every page. Alderman's prose is immersive and, well, electric, and I felt a closed circuit humming between the book and me as I read."

—Amal El-Mohtar, The New York Times

"Alderman's writing is beautiful, and her intelligence seems almost limitless. She also has a pitch-dark sense of humor that she wields perfectly."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

title: Ordinary Notes
long_summary:
A singular achievement, Ordinary Notes explores profound questions about loss and the shapes of Black life that emerge in the wake. In a series of 248 notes that gather meaning as we read them, Christina Sharpe skillfully weaves artifacts from the past—public ones alongside others that are poignantly personal—with present realities and possible futures.

At the heart of this immersive portrait is the indelible presence of the author's mother, Ida Wright Sharpe. "I learned to see in my mother's house," writes Sharpe. "I learned how not to see in my mother's house... My mother gifted me a love of beauty, a love of words." Using these gifts, Sharpe steadily summons a chorus of voices and experiences to the page.

She practices an aesthetic of "beauty as a method," collects entries from a community of thinkers toward a "Dictionary of Untranslatable Blackness," and rigorously examines sites of memory and memorial. In the process, she forges a brilliant new literary form, as multivalent as the ways of Black being it traces.
short_summary: In 248 interconnected notes, Sharpe weaves personal artifacts with public history to create an immersive meditation on Black existence. A genre-defying work that practices beauty as method and forges new literary forms.
genres: Social Science / Cultural & Ethnic Studies / American / African American & Black Studies
author_bios: Christina Sharpe is the author of In the Wake: On Blackness and Being—named by The Guardian as one of the best books of 2016—and Monstrous Intimacies: Making Post-Slavery Subjects. She is the Canada Research Chair in Black Studies in the Humanities at York University in Toronto.
quotes:
"A deft blend of memoir, theory, archival documents and lyrical reflections. . . . [Ordinary Notes] build[s] into a mosaic that holds the relentless terror of Black life as well as its undeniable beauty. . . . By turning her gaze inward, Sharpe offers a framework for understanding how to move forward, even when burdened by all the knowledge of the world's cruelty. . . . [Sharpe's] most liberating and poetic experiment yet."

—The New York Times

"A genre-defying, impressionistic series of meditations on history, identity, and the way we live now."

—Toronto Star

"Ordinary Notes is like an intellectual ice climb—you move along a careful series of handholds to cross a terrain that might otherwise seem impassable, and afterward, you are amazed at the passage. At once an act of careful attention and a juxtaposition of observations and questions, the result is a powerful vision of American life, drawn from the Black intellectual history and aesthetics that Sharpe has cultivated as the means to her own liberation, so that she might offer it to others."

—Alexander Chee, author of How to Write An Autobiographical Novel

title: Baldwin: A Love Story
subtitle: A Love Story
long_summary:
The first major James Baldwin biography in three decades reveals how the writer's most intimate relationships shaped both his life and his revolutionary work. Drawing on newly uncovered archival material and original research, Nicholas Boggs tells the overlapping stories of Baldwin's most sustaining connections: with his mentor, Black American painter Beauford Delaney; with his lover and muse, Swiss painter Lucien Happersberger; and with his collaborators, Turkish actor Engin Cezzar and French artist Yoran Cazac, whose significance as Baldwin's last great love is explored here for the first time.

Boggs shows how Baldwin drew on the complex forces within these relationships—geographical, cultural, political, artistic, and erotic—and transformed them into novels, essays, and plays that spoke truth to power and left an indelible mark on the civil rights movement and Black and queer literary history. Following Baldwin's creative journey from Harlem to Paris, Switzerland to Istanbul, and beyond, this richly immersive biography magnifies our understanding of one of the twentieth century's major literary figures.
short_summary: The first major Baldwin biography in decades reveals how his intimate relationships—with mentors, lovers, and collaborators—shaped his revolutionary work. Drawing on new archival discoveries, it's a richly immersive portrait of the whole man.
author_bios: Nicholas Boggs discovered Baldwin's out-of-print children's book Little Man, Little Man in Yale's Beinecke Library as an undergraduate, leading him to track down its illustrator and coedit an acclaimed 2018 edition. His writing appears in The Cambridge Companion to James Baldwin and other collections. He's received a 2023 Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant, fellowships from the National Endowment for the Humanities, Yale's Beinecke Library, the Schomburg Center, and the National Humanities Center, plus residencies at Yaddo and MacDowell. He holds degrees from Yale, American University, and Columbia, and lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"A virtuosic feat of literary imagination, rhapsodic and transportive. Stunningly, it answers not only the question of who James Baldwin was but how he made and remade his art and his world. Fast-paced and, at times, movingly tender, with love palpable throughout, the total effect is symphonic. This book deserves a standing ovation."

—Ilyon Woo, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Master Slave Husband Wife

"Nicholas Boggs's monumental biography considers James Baldwin through the prism of love, placing four beloved men at the center of his writing, his activism, his political consciousness, his philosophy, and his life. We have been presented with many partial Baldwins over the years, but here is the whole loveable man: the radical and the celebrity, the civil rights hero and the downtown playwright, the cosmopolitan jet-setter and the son of East Harlem. Compulsively interesting and beautifully written—there is something to treasure on every page. I absolutely loved it."

—Zadie Smith

"Gorgeous. Nicholas Boggs's storytelling, so tenderly rendered, brings us the beautiful yet tattered heart of not only Baldwin the intellectual and artist, but Baldwin the vulnerable, yearning, flesh-and-blood person. This book is so important and timely."

—Imani Perry, National Book Award winner for South to America

title: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny
long_summary:
When Sonia and Sunny glimpse each other on an overnight train, they're immediately captivated—despite the embarrassing fact that their grandparents had once tried to matchmake them, a clumsy meddling that only drove them apart.

Sonia, an aspiring novelist fresh from her studies in Vermont's snowy mountains, has returned to her family in India, fearing she's haunted by a dark spell cast by an artist she once turned to for intimacy and inspiration. Sunny, a struggling journalist now in New York City, is fleeing his imperious mother and the violence of his warring clan.

Uncertain of their future, Sonia and Sunny embark on a search for happiness together as they confront the alienations of our modern world. This sweeping tale follows two young people navigating the forces that shape their lives: country, class, race, history, and the complicated bonds linking one generation to the next.
short_summary: Two young people whose fates intersect across continents and years in this epic of love, family, and the space between India and America. A sweeping exploration of tradition and modernity from the Booker Prize-winning author.
author_bios: Kiran Desai is the bestselling author of Hullabaloo in the Guava Orchard and The Inheritance of Loss, which won both the Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award. Born in India, she came to the US at sixteen and now lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Kiran Desai reveals the breadth and depth of time, how it weighs on families and nations caught within the drama of history. She captures this with a rare and astute sensitivity that, no matter her subject, casts a light on our present."

—Hisham Matar, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of The Return

"Literary love stories are vanishingly rare these days, and The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny is that even more precious thing: a love story that's also profound, sparkling, funny, exquisitely written, and that teaches us how to live in full-throated exultation for the astonishments of this world. It has so many urgent things to say—about the costs and consolations of art, about power and class and race and freedom—that reading the book feels like a long conversation at night with your most interesting and ardent friend."

—Lauren Groff

"A powerful novel by a writer strong enough to pull back together worlds that are being pulled apart."

—Mohsin Hamid, New York Times bestselling author of Exit West

title: A Marriage at Sea
subtitle: A True Story of Love, Obsession, and Shipwreck
long_summary:
Maurice and Maralyn make an odd couple. He's a loner, awkward and obsessive; she's charismatic and ambitious. But they share a horror of wasting their lives and dream of running away from it all. What if they quit their jobs, sold their house, bought a boat, and sailed away?

Most of us begin and end with the daydream. But Maurice studied nautical navigation while Maralyn made detailed lists of provisions. In June 1972, they set sail.

For nearly a year all went well, until deep in the Pacific, a breaching whale knocked a hole in their boat and it sank beneath the waves. What follows is a jaw-dropping fight to survive in the wild ocean, with little hope of rescue.

Alone together for months in a tiny rubber raft, starving and exhausted, Maurice and Maralyn must find not only ways to stay alive but ways to get along, as their inner demons emerge and their marriage faces the ultimate test. They could run away from the world, but they can't run away from themselves.

Taut and propulsive, A Marriage at Sea pairs an adrenaline-fueled high seas adventure with a devastating love story that asks why we love difficult people, and who we become under the most extreme conditions imaginable.
short_summary: When a breaching whale destroys their boat in the Pacific, Maurice and Maralyn face months adrift in a rubber raft. An electrifying survival story that's equally about enduring the ocean and each other.
author_bios: Sophie Elmhirst is an award-winning journalist who writes regularly for The Guardian Long Read and The Economist. Her work has appeared in The New York Times Magazine, The New Yorker, and Harper's Bazaar. She's won the British Press Award for Feature Writer of the Year and a Foreign Press Award. She lives in London and A Marriage at Sea is her first book.
quotes:
"A beautiful meditation on endurance, codependence, and the power of love. A dazzling book."

—Patrick Radden Keefe

"Stark, elemental, and sure to be a classic."

—Hampton Sides

"An enthralling, engrossing story of survival and the resilience of the human spirit."

—Bill Bryson

title: Demon Copperhead
long_summary:
Demon Copperhead is born with nothing but his dead father's good looks, copper-colored hair, and a fierce talent for survival. Raised by a teenage mother in a single-wide trailer in the mountains of southern Appalachia, he navigates the modern perils of foster care, child labor, failing schools, and addiction.

Relayed in his own caustic, unsparing voice, Demon's story never pauses for breath as he reckons with his invisibility in a culture that has abandoned rural people. Through athletic success, disastrous loves, and crushing losses, he fights to survive in a beautiful, cursed place he can't imagine leaving behind.

Inspired by Dickens' David Copperfield, Kingsolver transposes a Victorian epic to the contemporary American South, enlisting Dickens' anger and compassion while addressing problems of institutional poverty that persist today. Demon Copperhead speaks for a new generation of lost boys with faith in the transformative power of storytelling.
short_summary: A boy born to nothing in Appalachia navigates foster care, addiction, and systemic neglect with fierce wit and determination. Kingsolver's Dickensian epic captures rural America with devastating precision and unexpected hope.
author_bios: Barbara Kingsolver is the author of ten bestselling works including Unsheltered, The Bean Trees, and The Poisonwood Bible, plus poetry, essays, and the children's book Coyote's Wild Home. Her work has been translated into thirty languages and earned numerous honors including the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for Demon Copperhead, the National Humanities Medal, and the National Book Foundation's Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters. She lives on a farm in southern Appalachia.
quotes:
"An Appalachian David Copperfield. . . . Demon Copperhead reimagines Dickens's story in a modern-day rural America contending with poverty and opioid addiction. . . . Like Dickens, she is unblushingly political and works on a sprawling scale...Episode by episode she persuasively conveys the mind of a teenage boy. . . . It's hard to think of another living novelist who could take a stab at Dickens and rise above the level of catastrophe."

—The New York Times

"An epic…brimming with vitality and outrage….the rare 560-page book you wish would never end."

—People Magazine

"With its bold reversals of fate and flamboyant cast, this is storytelling on a grand scale. . . . As Demon discovers, owning his story—every part of it—and finding a way to tell it is how he'll wrest some control over his life. And what a story it is: acute, impassioned, heartbreakingly evocative, told by a narrator who's a product of multiple failed systems, yes, but also of a deep rural landscape with its own sustaining traditions."

—The Guardian

title: The Tiger's Wife
long_summary:
In a Balkan country slowly healing from war, Natalia, a young doctor, finds herself haunted by the mysterious circumstances surrounding her beloved grandfather's recent death. Searching for answers, she turns to his worn copy of The Jungle Book and the captivating stories he shared with her over the years—tales of his encounters with "the deathless man," a figure who seems to appear at moments of great significance.

But the most extraordinary story is one her grandfather never told her: the legend of the tiger's wife. As Natalia pieces together fragments of family history and local folklore, she discovers how myth and reality intertwine in the lives of ordinary people trying to make sense of loss, love, and survival.

Weaving together family legend and hard-won truths, Téa Obreht has crafted a luminous debut that explores how stories sustain us through the darkest times. This is a novel about the persistence of wonder in a world marked by violence, and the way folklore can illuminate the deepest human experiences.
short_summary: In war-torn Balkans, a young doctor unravels her grandfather's mysterious death through his tales of a mythical tiger and an immortal stranger. Obreht weaves folklore and reality into something luminous and unforgettable.
author_bios: Téa Obreht is the internationally bestselling author of The Tiger's Wife, which won the 2011 Orange Prize for Fiction and was a finalist for the National Book Award. Her second novel, Inland, was an instant bestseller, won the Southwest Book Award, and was a finalist for the Dylan Thomas Prize. Her work has appeared in The Best American Short Stories, The New Yorker, The Atlantic, Harper's, and Zoetrope: All-Story. Originally from the former Yugoslavia, she now resides in Wyoming.
quotes:
"Stunning . . . a richly textured and searing novel."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Spectacular . . . [Téa Obreht] spins a tale of such marvel and magic in a literary voice so enchanting that the mesmerized reader wants her never to stop."

—Entertainment Weekly

"That The Tiger's Wife never slips entirely into magical realism is part of its magic. . . . Its graceful commingling of contemporary realism and village legend seems even more absorbing."

—The Washington Post

title: Midnight in Chernobyl
subtitle: The Untold Story of the World's Greatest Nuclear Disaster
long_summary:
Early morning, April 26, 1986: Reactor Number Four of the Chernobyl Atomic Energy Station exploded, triggering history's worst nuclear disaster. In the thirty years since, Chernobyl has lodged itself in our collective nightmares—shorthand for radiation's spectral horrors, technology slipping its leash, ecological fragility, and what happens when a dishonest state endangers its citizens and the world.

But the real story, clouded from the beginning by secrecy, propaganda, and misinformation, has long remained in dispute.

Drawing on hundreds of hours of interviews conducted over more than ten years, plus letters, unpublished memoirs, and recently-declassified documents, Adam Higginbotham brings the disaster to life through the eyes of those who witnessed it firsthand. The result is a masterful nonfiction thriller and the definitive account of an event that changed history—a story more complex, more human, and more terrifying than the Soviet myth.

Midnight in Chernobyl is an indelible portrait of one of the twentieth century's great disasters, of human resilience and ingenuity, and the vital lessons learned when mankind seeks to bend the natural world to his will.
short_summary: Ten years of investigation yields the definitive account of Chernobyl. Higginbotham cuts through decades of propaganda to reveal the human story behind history's worst nuclear disaster.
author_bios: Adam Higginbotham has written for The New Yorker, The New York Times Magazine, Wired, GQ, and Smithsonian. He is the author of Midnight in Chernobyl, winner of the William E. Colby Award and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Nonfiction, and Challenger: A True Story of Heroism and Disaster on the Edge of Space. He lives with his family in New York City.
quotes:
"Superb, enthralling and necessarily terrifying . . . the accident unfurls with a horrible inevitability. Weaving together the experiences of those who were there that night, Higginbotham marshals the details so meticulously that every step feels spring-loaded with tension. . . . Amid so much rich reporting and scrupulous analysis, some major themes emerge. . . . Higginbotham's extraordinary book is another advance in the long struggle to fill in some of the gaps, bringing much of what was hidden into the light."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"Adam Higginbotham's brilliantly well-written Midnight In Chernobyl draws on new sources and original research to illuminate the true story of one of history's greatest technological failures—and, along with it, the bewildering reality of everyday life during the final years of the Soviet Union."

—Anne Applebaum, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Gulag: A History and Red Famine: Stalin's War On Ukraine & Iron Curtain

"Here is a triumph of investigative reportage, exquisite science writing, and heart-pounding storytelling. With Midnight in Chernobyl, Adam Higginbotham gives us a glimpse of Armageddon, but carries it off with such narrative verve that he somehow makes it entertaining. One thing is assured: After reading this astonishing, terrifying book, you will never think of nuclear power in quite the same way again."

—Hampton Sides, author of In the Kingdom of Ice and On Desperate Ground

title: Hidden Valley Road
subtitle: Inside the Mind of an American Family
long_summary:
Don and Mimi Galvin seemed to be living the American dream. After World War II, Don's Air Force work brought them to Colorado, where their twelve children perfectly spanned the baby boom: the oldest born in 1945, the youngest in 1965. There was an established script for families like the Galvins—aspiration, hard work, upward mobility, domestic harmony—and they worked hard to play their parts.

But behind the scenes was a different story: psychological breakdown, shocking violence, hidden abuse. By the mid-1970s, six of the ten Galvin boys were diagnosed as schizophrenic. How could this happen to one family?

What unfolded inside the house on Hidden Valley Road was so extraordinary that the Galvins became one of the first families studied by the National Institute of Mental Health. Their story offers a shadow history of schizophrenia research, from the era of institutionalization and lobotomy to the search for genetic markers, always amid profound disagreements about the illness itself. Unbeknownst to the Galvins, samples of their DNA informed decades of genetic research that continues today.

With clarity and compassion, Robert Kolker uncovers one family's unforgettable legacy of suffering, love, and hope.
short_summary: The devastating story of a midcentury American family with twelve children, six of them diagnosed with schizophrenia, that became central to our scientific understanding of the disease.
author_bios: Robert Kolker is the New York Times bestselling author of Lost Girls, named one of the New York Times's 100 Notable Books and one of Publishers Weekly's Top Ten Books of 2013. His journalism has appeared in New York magazine, Bloomberg Businessweek, The New York Times Magazine, Wired, GQ, and other publications. He's a National Magazine Award finalist and recipient of the 2011 Harry Frank Guggenheim Award for Excellence in Criminal Justice Reporting.
quotes:
"This broad-ranging, highly readable, and deeply unsettling book tells the story of a family beset with schizophrenia, and in doing so provides meaningful insights into the devastation caused by the disease. It is, equally, a study of the multiple ways in which familial denial can exacerbate the inherent pain of mental illness, and of the courage required both of those who are themselves diagnosed with it and of those who choose to help and support them."

—Andrew Solomon, author of Far From the Tree

"An extraordinary case study and tour de force of reporting."

—Sylvia Nasar, author of A Beautiful Mind

"A powerful look at schizophrenia and the quest to understand it . . . A taut and often heartbreaking narrative . . . A haunting and memorable look at the impact of mental illness on multiple generations."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Director
long_summary:
G.W. Pabst, one of cinema's greatest directors, was filming in France when the Nazis seized power. To escape the horrors of his unrecognizable homeland, he fled to Hollywood—only to discover that under the blinding California sun, the world-famous director suddenly looks like a nobody. Not even Greta Garbo, whom he made famous, can help him now.

When word arrives that his elderly mother is ill, Pabst finds himself back in Austria, now called Ostmark. He, his wife, and young son are suddenly confronted with the barbaric nature of the regime. When Joseph Goebbels sees the potential for using the European film icon's directorial genius, he makes big promises to Pabst and his family—a thinly veiled order the director must consider.

Pabst believes he can resist these advances, that he will submit to no dictatorship other than art. But he has already taken the first steps into a hopeless entanglement. Kehlmann's masterful novel explores the treacherous territory between art and power, beauty and barbarism, creative genius and moral compromise.
short_summary: When legendary director G.W. Pabst flees Nazi Germany for Hollywood, he discovers fame doesn't travel well. Forced to return home, he faces an impossible choice between his art and his conscience.
genres: Fiction / Historical / 20th Century / World War II & Holocaust
author_bios: Daniel Kehlmann was born in Munich in 1975. His novels and plays have won numerous prizes, including the Candide Prize, the Doderer Prize, the Kleist Prize, the Welt Literature Prize, and the Thomas Mann Prize. His novel Tyll was shortlisted for the 2020 International Booker Prize, and Measuring the World has been translated into more than forty languages. He lives in Berlin and New York. Ross Benjamin has translated numerous German-language works, including Franz Kafka's Diaries and Daniel Kehlmann's Tyll and You Should Have Left. He received a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship and the 2010 Helen and Kurt Wolff Translator's Prize.
quotes:
"The Director is engrossing and luminous, an epic act of historical imagination and an intimate parable about moral compromise and the seductions of art. After Tyll, I wasn't sure how Kehlmann could possibly top himself. He has. This book is a marvel."

—Ayad Akhtar, author of Homeland Elegies

"A wonderful book about complicity and the complicity of art. It's also funny, and brilliant."

—Zadie Smith, author of The Fraud, via the Ezra Klein Show

"Daniel Kehlmann is shockingly brilliant, a writer of extraordinary range and grace. At times absurdist, at times horrifyingly realist, The Director asks where the moral duty of the artist resides, and how the narcissism of the artistic project can bleed into complicity."

—Lauren Groff, author of The Vaster Wilds

title: Disappearing Earth
long_summary:
One August afternoon on the remote Kamchatka peninsula, two sisters—eight and eleven—vanish from the shoreline. As weeks turn to months, the police investigation yields nothing, but the disappearance sends shockwaves through the tightly woven community, with fear and loss reverberating most deeply among its women.

Taking us through a year in this far corner of Russia, Disappearing Earth follows a cast of interconnected characters all touched by the crime: a witness, a neighbor, a detective, a mother. Phillips transports us to landscapes of breathtaking beauty—dense forests, open tundra, soaring volcanoes, and glassy seas bordering Japan and Alaska—while revealing a region as complex as it is alluring.

Beneath the surface beauty lies a community where social and ethnic tensions simmer, where outsiders become easy targets for suspicion. Through masterful storytelling and remarkable empathy, this propulsive novel illuminates the intricate bonds of family and community in a Russia unlike any we've encountered before.
short_summary: Two sisters disappear from a remote Russian peninsula, sending ripples through their community over the course of a year. Phillips weaves together multiple perspectives in this haunting debut that's part mystery, part cultural immersion.
author_bios: Julia Phillips is the bestselling author of Disappearing Earth, a National Book Award finalist and New York Times Book Review Top 10 Book of the Year. A 2024 Guggenheim fellow, she lives with her family in Brooklyn. Her latest novel, Bear, is a national bestseller and New York Times Book Review Editors' Choice.
quotes:
"Julia Phillips is at once a careful cartographer and gorgeous storyteller. Written with passion and patience, this is the story of a people and the land that shapes them. A mystery of two missing girls burns at the center of this astonishing debut, and the complexity of ethnicity, gender, hearth and kin illuminates this question and many more."

—Tayari Jones, author of An American Marriage

"An exceptional and suspenseful debut. In the opening chapter, two sisters vanish from a beach on the Kamchatka Peninsula; their disappearance sends ripples throughout the close-knit community. Subsequent chapters chart the effect of longing and loss in a series of interconnected, equally riveting stories. The climax [is] truly nail-biting . . . Phillips's exquisite descriptions of the landscape are masterful throughout, as is her skill at crafting a complex, genuinely addictive whodunit. This novel signals the arrival of a mighty talent."

—Publishers Weekly

"[An] immersive, impressive, strikingly original debut. . . an unusual, cleverly constructed thriller, and also a deep dive into the culture of Russia's remote Kamchatka peninsula. Disappearing Earth opens with a chilling crime . . . The rest of the book is about different women on the peninsula, all with the shadow of the missing girls hanging over them as a year goes by. You submerge ever more deeply into this world, which is both so different from and so much like our own. Will we ever get closure about the girls? You'll want to start over and read it again once you know."

—Kirkus

title: People Who Eat Darkness
subtitle: The True Story of a Young Woman Who Vanished from the Streets of Tokyo—and the Evil That Swallowed Her Up
long_summary:
Lucie Blackman—tall, blond, twenty-one years old—stepped out into the vastness of Tokyo and disappeared forever. For months, the police's only lead was a suspicious message claiming she had joined a religious cult. The truth would prove much darker.

Who was the mysterious man she had gone to meet? What exactly did Lucie do at her hostess job in the notorious Roppongi nightclub district? How many others had suffered the same fate?

Richard Lloyd Parry, an award-winning foreign correspondent, covered Lucie's case from the beginning. He tracked the story across four continents, earned the trust of her family and friends, won unique access to the Japanese detectives and legal system, and delved deep into the mind of the man accused in her disappearance—Joji Obara, described by the judge as "unprecedented and extremely evil."

The result is a thrilling and revelatory work of true crime journalism that becomes a sustained work of moral inquiry.
short_summary: Foreign correspondent Parry reconstructs the disappearance of young Lucie Blackman in Tokyo's shadowy nightclub district. A masterful work of true crime journalism that becomes a profound moral inquiry.
author_bios: Richard Lloyd Parry is the Asia editor and Tokyo bureau chief of The Times (London) and the author of In the Time of Madness and People Who Eat Darkness.
quotes:
"[In People Who Eat Darkness], Mr. Parry finds his voice, and it's a sturdy one. His book becomes not merely an exemplary piece of reportage but a sustained and quietly profound work of moral inquiry as well. It becomes ominous in ways that go well beyond the calculated shock value of its cover . . . Mr. Parry writes exceedingly well . . . [and] People Who Eat Darkness is surprisingly soulful, especially in its portrait of Ms. Blackman . . . He's restored her to life in this vivid book."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A big, ambitious true crime book in the tradition of Norman Mailer's The Executioner's Song and Truman Capote's In Cold Blood."

—Esquire

"A masterpiece of writing this surely is, but it is more than that--it is a committed, compassionate, courageous act of journalism that changes the way we think. Everyone who has ever loved someone and held that life dear should read this stunning book, and shiver."

—Chris Cleave, author of Little Bee and Incendiary

title: 1Q84
long_summary:
The year is 1984 and the city is Tokyo. A young woman named Aomame follows a taxi driver's enigmatic suggestion and begins to notice puzzling discrepancies in the world around her. She has entered a parallel existence, which she calls 1Q84—"Q is for 'question mark.' A world that bears a question."

Meanwhile, an aspiring writer named Tengo takes on a suspect ghostwriting project. He becomes so wrapped up with the work and its unusual author that his previously placid life begins to unravel.

As their narratives converge over this single year, we learn of the profound connections that bind them: a beautiful, dyslexic teenage girl with a unique vision; a mysterious religious cult; a reclusive dowager who runs a shelter for abused women; a hideously ugly private investigator; and a peculiarly insistent television-fee collector.

A love story, mystery, and fantasy rolled into one, 1Q84 is Murakami's most ambitious undertaking—a tremendous feat of imagination that rivals Orwell's dystopian vision while remaining uniquely, unmistakably his own.
short_summary: In 1984 Tokyo, a woman discovers she's slipped into a parallel world while a writer becomes entangled with a mysterious cult. Murakami weaves thriller, romance, and surrealism into his most ambitious work.
author_bios: Haruki Murakami was born in Kyoto in 1949 and now lives near Tokyo. His work has been translated into more than fifty languages. Among his many international honors is the Cino Del Duca World Prize, whose previous recipients include Jorge Luis Borges, Ismail Kadare, Mario Vargas Llosa, and Joyce Carol Oates.
quotes:
"Ambitious, sprawling and thoroughly stunning . . . Orwellian dystopia, sci-fi, the modern world (terrorism, drugs, apathy, pop novels)—all blend in this dreamlike, strange and wholly unforgettable epic."

—Kirkus

"Murakami's trademark plainspoken oddness is on full display in this story of lapsed childhood friends Aomame and Tengo, now lonely adults in 1984 Tokyo, whose destinies may be curiously intertwined . . . Murakami's fans know that his focus has always been on the quiet strangeness of life, the hidden connections between perfect strangers, and the power of the non sequitur to reveal the associative strands that weave our modern world. 1Q84 goes further than any Murakami novel so far, and perhaps further than any novel before it, toward exposing the delicacy of the membranes that separate love from chance encounters, the kind from the wicked, and reality from what people living in the pent-up modern world dream about when they go to sleep under an alien moon."

—Publishers Weekly

"Murakami is clearly one of the most popular and admired novelists in the world today, a brilliant practitioner of serious, yet irresistibly engaging, literary fantasy . . . Once you start reading 1Q84, you won't want to do much else until you've finished it . . . Murakami possesses many gifts, but chief among them is an almost preternatural gift for suspenseful storytelling . . . Despite its great length, [his] novel is tightly plotted, without fat, and he knows how to make dialogue, even philosophical dialogue, exciting . . . Murakami's novels have been translated into a score of languages, but it would be hard to imagine that any of them could be better than the English versions by Jay Rubin, partnered here with Philip ­Gabriel . . . There's no question about the sheer enjoyability of this ­gigantic novel, both as an eerie thriller and as a moving love story . . . I read the book in three days and have been thinking about it ever since."

—Michael Dirda, The Washington Post

title: The Wide Wide Sea
subtitle: Imperial Ambition, First Contact and the Fateful Final Voyage of Captain James Cook
long_summary:
On July 12, 1776, Captain James Cook set off on his third voyage aboard the HMS Resolution. Two-and-a-half years later, he was killed on a Hawaiian beach in a conflict with native islanders. How did Cook—uniquely respected among captains for his treatment of Indigenous peoples—come to that fatal moment?

Hampton Sides delivers a bravura account of Cook's final journey, wrestling with his complex legacy while providing a thrilling narrative of 18th-century exploration's dangers and discoveries. Cook was renowned for his seamanship, humane leadership, and scientific dedication. On previous expeditions, he mapped vast Pacific territories, including Australia's east coast, and initiated first European contact with numerous peoples. He treated his crew well and approached new societies with curiosity rather than judgment.

Yet something changed on this last voyage. Cook became mercurial, resorting to violent discipline and leading his vessels into repeated danger. He ordered brutal retaliation against native peoples for perceived theft. His secret orders—to chart and claim lands before Britain's rivals and discover the Northwest Passage—may explain this transformation. Whatever his intentions, Cook's scientific mission served colonial conquest, with catastrophic effects for Indigenous populations worldwide.

These tensions culminated in Hawaii, where his initially harmonious landing soured into fatal confrontation upon his return from mapping the Pacific Northwest.
short_summary: Hampton Sides chronicles Captain Cook's final voyage—from celebrated explorer to his death on a Hawaiian beach in 1779. A gripping examination of how scientific discovery became the sharp edge of colonial conquest.
author_bios: Hampton Sides is the author of New York Times bestselling histories On Desperate Ground, In the Kingdom of Ice, Hellhound on his Trail, Blood and Thunder, and Ghost Soldiers, which won the PEN USA Award for Nonfiction. He lives in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
quotes:
"Hampton Sides has a gift for taking stories you thought you knew and making them feel fresh and revelatory. Along the way, he has also mastered the art of you-are-there historical narrative.  In The Wide Wide Sea, this combination is irresistible: fascinating and horrifying by turns, Sides puts us on deck with Captain Cook, one of the world's greatest and most disciplined explorers, as he comes undone in real time, in ways that make comparisons to our current planetary moment inescapable. This is a thrilling and necessary update to one of history's most consequential cultural collisions."

—John Vaillant, New York Times bestselling author of Fire Weather and The Tiger

"An acclaimed historian takes to the sea in this rousing tale of exploration . . . Sides draws on numerous contemporaneous sources to create a fascinating, immersive adventure story featuring just the right amount of historical context . . . Lusciously detailed and insightful history, masterfully told."

—Kirkus

"Gripping . . . It isn't possible in this short space to describe Side's hair-raising accounts of the journey . . . Sides recreates the newness of the experience, the vast differences in and among Indigenous cultures, and natural phenomena that were as terrifying as they were wondrous."

—The Washington Post

title: Redeployment
long_summary:
In "Redeployment," a soldier who has had to shoot dogs eating human corpses must learn what it's like to return to domestic life, surrounded by people "who have no idea where Fallujah is, where three members of your platoon died." In "After Action Report," a Lance Corporal seeks expiation for a killing he didn't commit, hoping to unburden his best friend. A Mortuary Affairs Marine collects remains of U.S. and Iraqi soldiers alike. A chaplain sees his understanding of Christianity tested by a ferocious Colonel's actions.

In the darkly comic "Money as a Weapons System," a young Foreign Service Officer faces the absurd task of helping Iraqis improve their lives by teaching them baseball. These stories reveal the intricate combination of monotony, bureaucracy, comradeship, and violence that make up a soldier's daily life at war—and the isolation, remorse, and despair that can accompany homecoming.

Written with hard-eyed realism and stunning emotional depth, Klay sets in devastating relief the two worlds a soldier inhabits: one of extremes and one of loss. This work establishes him as one of the most vital voices of his generation.
short_summary: Klay's searing debut collection follows soldiers navigating the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan—and the equally treacherous terrain of coming home. These stories capture the brutal contradictions of modern warfare with unflinching honesty.
author_bios: Phil Klay is a veteran of the US Marine Corps and author of Redeployment, which won the 2014 National Book Award for Fiction, and Missionaries, named one of the Ten Best Books of 2020 by the Wall Street Journal. His writing has appeared in The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Atlantic, and elsewhere. He teaches fiction at Fairfield University and serves on the board for Arts in the Armed Forces.
quotes:
"In Redeployment, his searing debut collection of short stories, Phil Klay—a veteran of the United States Marine Corps, who served in Iraq during the surge—gives the civilian reader a visceral feeling for what it is like to be a soldier in a combat zone, and what it is like to return home, still reeling from the dislocations of war. Gritty, unsparing and fiercely observed, these stories leave us with a harrowing sense of the war in Iraq as it was experienced, day by day, by individual soldiers."

—Michiko Kakutani, New York Times

"Klay grasps both tough-guy characterization and life spent in the field, yet he also mines the struggle of soldiers to be emotionally freed from the images they can't stop seeing. It's clear that Klay, himself a veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps who served in Iraq, has parlayed his insider's knowledge of soldier-bonding and emotional scarring into a collection that proves a powerful statement on the nature of war, violence, and the nuances of human nature."

—Publishers Weekly

"If you want to know the real cost of war for those who do the fighting, read Redeployment. These stories say it all, with an eloquence and rare humanity that will simultaneously break your heart and give you reasons to hope."

—Ben Fountain, Author of Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk

title: Far From the Tree
subtitle: Parents, Children and the Search for Identity
long_summary:
Solomon's startling proposition in Far from the Tree is that being exceptional is at the core of the human condition—that difference is what unites us. He writes about families coping with deafness, dwarfism, Down syndrome, autism, schizophrenia, and multiple severe disabilities, as well as children who are prodigies, conceived in rape, become criminals, or are transgender.

While each of these characteristics is potentially isolating, the experience of difference within families is universal, and Solomon documents triumphs of love over prejudice in every chapter. All parenting turns on a crucial question: to what extent should parents accept their children for who they are, and to what extent should they help them become their best selves?

Drawing on ten years of research and interviews with more than three hundred families, Solomon mines the eloquence of ordinary people facing extreme challenges. Elegantly reported by a spectacularly original and compassionate thinker, Far from the Tree explores how people who love each other must struggle to accept each other—a theme in every family's life.
short_summary: Through interviews with hundreds of families, Solomon examines how parents navigate raising children with profound differences. A compassionate exploration of identity, acceptance, and the universal challenges of unconditional love.
author_bios: Andrew Solomon is a professor of psychology at Columbia University, president of PEN American Center, and regular contributor to The New Yorker, NPR, and The New York Times Magazine. He's the author of Far and Away: Essays from the Brink of Change; the National Book Critics Circle Award-winner Far from the Tree, which has won thirty additional national awards; and The Noonday Demon: An Atlas of Depression, which won the 2001 National Book Award and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. His TED talks have been viewed over ten million times.
quotes:
"Solomon's first chapter, entitled 'Son,' is as masterly a piece of writing as I've come across all year. It combines his own story with a taut and elegant précis of this book's arguments. It is required reading…This is a book that shoots arrow after arrow into your heart."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Andrew Solomon has written a brave and ambitious work, bringing together science, culture and a powerful empathy. Solomon tells us that we have more in common with each other—even with those who seem anything but normal—than we would ever have imagined."

—Malcolm Gladwell, author of Revenge of the Tipping Point & Talking to Strangers

"Far from the Tree is a landmark, revolutionary book. It frames an area of inquiry—difference between parents and children—that many of us have experienced in our own lives without ever considering it as a phenomenon. Andrew Solomon plumbs his topic thoroughly, humanely, and in a compulsively readable style that makes the book as entertaining as it is illuminating."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of A Visit from the Goon Squad & The Candy House

title: Americanah
long_summary:
Ifemelu and Obinze are young and in love when they depart military-ruled Nigeria for the West. Beautiful, self-assured Ifemelu heads for America, where despite her academic success, she is forced to grapple with what it means to be Black for the first time.

Quiet, thoughtful Obinze had hoped to join her, but with post-9/11 America closed to him, he instead plunges into a dangerous, undocumented life in London. Fifteen years later, they reunite in a democratic Nigeria, and reignite their passion—for each other and for their homeland.
short_summary: Two young lovers leave Nigeria for the West, where they confront questions of race, identity, and belonging. Adichie's sweeping novel captures the immigrant experience with devastating precision and warmth.
author_bios: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie grew up in Nigeria. Her work has been translated into more than fifty-five languages. She is the author of Purple Hibiscus, which won the Commonwealth Writers' Prize; Half of a Yellow Sun, recipient of the Women's Prize for Fiction "Best of the Best" award; Americanah, which won the National Book Critics Circle Award; The Thing Around Your Neck; We Should All Be Feminists; Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions; Notes on Grief; and Mama's Sleeping Scarf. A MacArthur Fellowship recipient, she divides her time between the United States and Nigeria.
quotes:
"An expansive, epic love story."

—O: The Oprah Magazine

"An incredibly readable and rich tapestry of Nigerian and American life, and the ways a handful of vivid characters—so vivid they feel like family—try to live in both worlds simultaneously. As she did so masterfully with Half of a Yellow Sun, Adichie paints on a grand canvas, boldly and confidently, equally adept at conveying the complicated political backdrop of Lagos as she is in bringing us into the day-to-day lives of her many new Americans—a single mom, a student, a hairdresser. This is a very funny, very warm and moving intergenerational epic that confirms Adichie's virtuosity, boundless empathy and searing social acuity."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

"Elegantly written, emotionally believable . . . A sensitive portrayal of distant love, broken affinities and culture clash . . . A fine, adult love story with locations both exotic and familiar."

—Kirkus

title: Malcolm X
subtitle: A Life of Reinvention
long_summary:
Of the great figures in twentieth-century American history, perhaps none is more complex and controversial than Malcolm X. Constantly rewriting his own story, he became a criminal, a minister, a leader, and an icon, all before being felled by assassins' bullets at age thirty-nine. Through tireless work and countless speeches, he empowered hundreds of thousands of black Americans to create better lives and stronger communities while establishing the template for the self-actualized, independent African American man.

Manning Marable's biography is a stunning achievement filled with new information and shocking revelations that go beyond the Autobiography. Malcolm X unfolds a sweeping story of race and class in America, from the rise of Marcus Garvey and the Ku Klux Klan to the struggles of the civil rights movement in the fifties and sixties.

Reaching into Malcolm's troubled youth, it traces a path from his parents' activism through his engagement with the Nation of Islam, charting his astronomical rise in Black Nationalism and culminating in the never-before-told true story of his assassination. This definitive work captures with revelatory clarity a man who constantly strove to remake himself anew.
short_summary: Marable's landmark biography draws on new sources and revelatory research to present the fullest, most complex portrait yet of Malcolm X—stripping away decades of myth to reveal the man behind the icon.
author_bios: Manning Marable (1950–2011) was Professor of African-American Studies and of Public Affairs, History and Political Science at Columbia University. His books include Black American Politics, Black Leadership, Living Black History, Beyond Black and White: From Civil Rights to Barack Obama, and Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention.
quotes:
"It will be difficult for anyone to better this book. It goes deeper and richer than a mere homage to Malcolm X. It is a work of art, a feast that combines genres skillfully: biography, true-crime, political commentary. It gives us Malcolm X in full gallop, a man who died for his belief in freedom, a man whom Marable calls the 'fountainhead' of the black power movement in America."

—The Washington Post

"In his revealing and prodigiously researched new biography, Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention, Manning Marable - a professor at Columbia University and the director of its Center for Contemporary Black History, who died just last week - vividly chronicles these many incarnations of his subject. . . Mr. Marable artfully strips away the layers and layers of myth that have been lacquered onto his subject's life - first by Malcolm himself in that famous memoir, and later by both supporters and opponents after his assassination in 1965 at the age of 39."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Unlike Bruce Perry's 1991 biography, Malcolm, which entertained the most outlandish stories in an attempt to present a comprehensive portrait, Marable's biography judiciously sifts fact from myth."

—The Atlantic

title: Swamplandia!
long_summary:
The Bigtree alligator-wrestling dynasty is crumbling. Their island theme park, Swamplandia!, once the premier attraction in the Florida Everglades, faces fierce competition from the World of Darkness, a slick new rival that's stealing their customers.

When Ava's mother—the park's star performer—dies unexpectedly, the family begins to unravel. Her sister Ossie falls under the spell of a mysterious figure called the Dredgeman, who may or may not be a ghost. Her brilliant brother Kiwi defects to work for their competitors in a desperate attempt to save the family business. And their father, Chief Bigtree, has disappeared entirely.

Left alone with ninety-eight alligators and her overwhelming grief, thirteen-year-old Ava must navigate both the treacherous swampland and the even more dangerous territory of adolescence. Russell weaves together myth and reality in this stunning debut, creating a world where the line between the magical and mundane dissolves like morning mist over the Everglades.
short_summary: Thirteen-year-old Ava struggles to save her family's failing alligator theme park after her mother's death tears the Bigtrees apart. Russell's imaginative debut blends dark comedy with genuine heartbreak.
author_bios: Karen Russell is the author of six books of fiction, including the New York Times bestsellers Swamplandia! and Vampires in the Lemon Grove. She is a MacArthur Fellow, a Guggenheim Fellow, and a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. She has received two National Magazine Awards for Fiction, the Shirley Jackson Award, the 2023 Bottari Lattes Grinzane Prize, and the 2024 Mary McCarthy Prize. Born and raised in Miami, Florida, she lives in Portland, Oregon, with her family.
quotes:
"[A] cunning first novel. . . . Russell's willingness to lend flesh and blood to her fanciful, fantastical creations gives this spry novel a potent punch and announces an enthralling new beginning for a quickly evolving young author."

—Publishers Weekly

"Brilliant, funny, original . . . also creepy and sinister . . . Karen Russell's Swamplandia! is every bit as good as her short stories promised it would be. This book will not leave my mind."

—Stephen King

"Karen Russell is young and talented, and has been given just about every age-appropriate honor there is—Best Young American Novelists, 20 Under 40, 5 Under 35. With her debut novel, though, she's leaving the kids' table forever. The bewitching Swamplandia! is a tremendous achievement for anyone, period. . . . Effortless prose and [a] small, beautifully drawn cast of characters . . . as densely organic as the swamp in which it is set."

—Keith Staskiewicz, Entertainment Weekly

title: Dark Money
subtitle: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right
long_summary:
Dark Money exposes how a network of ultra-wealthy libertarian donors—led by Charles and David Koch—secretly reshaped American politics. Backed by billions, they funded think tanks, academic programs, legal cases, and political movements to block environmental reforms, weaken labor protections, and tilt tax laws in their favor.

Through five years of meticulous reporting and hundreds of interviews, Mayer uncovers how this hidden web of influence turned fringe ideas into mainstream power, culminating in a new American oligarchy. She traces the money from its sources to its impact, revealing how a small group of billionaires systematically dismantled regulations and democratic norms.

Urgent and gripping, Dark Money is essential reading for anyone concerned about inequality, democracy, and the future of American politics.
short_summary: Five years of investigative reporting reveals how billionaire libertarians secretly funded a political revolution. Mayer traces the money behind think tanks, legal cases, and movements that reshaped America.
genres: Political Science / Political Process / Campaigns & Elections
author_bios: Jane Mayer is a staff writer for The New Yorker and author of four acclaimed works of narrative nonfiction. She co-authored Landslide: The Unmaking of the President, 1984–1988 and Strange Justice: The Selling of Clarence Thomas, a National Book Award finalist.
