The Dark Side was named a New York Times Top 10 Book and won the J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize. Dark Money was also a Times Top 10 Book and received the New York Public Library's Helen Bernstein Book Award.
quotes:
"Jane Mayer's Dark Money is utterly brilliant and chilling — no matter how much you think you already know. . . . Read it!"

—Naomi Klein, bestselling author of Doppelganger: A Trip into the Mirror World, The Shock Doctrine: The Rise of Disaster Capitalism & This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs the Climate

"Revelatory. . .persuasive, timely and necessary. . . . Only the most thoroughly documented, compendious account could do justice to the Kochs' bizarre and Byzantine family history and the scale and scope of their influence."

—The New York Times

"Mayer is. . . a writer whose reporting can leave a reader breathless. . . . I urge you to read Dark Money."

—Bill Moyers

title: The Best Minds
subtitle: A Story of Friendship, Madness, and the Tragedy of Good Intentions
long_summary:
When the Rosens moved to New Rochelle in 1973, Jonathan Rosen and Michael Laudor became inseparable. Both children of college professors, the boys were best friends and keen competitors who seemed destined to join the American meritocratic elite when they both got into Yale.

Michael blazed through college in three years, graduating summa cum laude and landing a top consulting job. But beneath the surface, something was wrong. One day, Jonathan received the devastating call: Michael had suffered a serious psychotic break and was in the locked ward of a psychiatric hospital.

Diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia, Michael was still battling delusions when he left his halfway house for Yale Law School. The New York Times featured him as a role model, he sold a memoir with film rights to Ron Howard. But then Michael, in the grip of an unshakeable paranoid fantasy, killed his girlfriend Carrie and became a front-page story of an entirely different sort.

Tender, funny, and harrowing by turns, The Best Minds is Jonathan Rosen's magnificent and heartbreaking account of friendship, mental illness, and the tragic gap between good intentions and devastating outcomes.
short_summary: Two childhood friends seemed destined for greatness until one was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. Rosen's devastating memoir traces how brilliance, delusion, and society's failures converged in unthinkable tragedy.
author_bios: Jonathan Rosen is the author of two novels, Eve's Apple and Joy Comes in the Morning, and two non-fiction books, The Talmud and the Internet: A Journey Between Worlds and The Life of the Skies: Birding at the End of Nature. His essays and articles have appeared in The New York Times, The New Yorker, The Atlantic, The Wall Street Journal, and numerous anthologies. He lives with his family in New York City.
quotes:
"Brave and nuanced . . . The Best Minds is too a thoughtfully built, deeply sourced indictment of a society that prioritizes profit, quick fixes and happy endings over the long slog of care . . . Effectively taking over his friend's unfinished project, braiding it with his own story of clinical anxiety as well as skeins of history, medicine, religion and true crime, the author has transcended childhood rivalry by twinning their stories, an act of tremendous compassion and a literary triumph."

—The New York Times

"Jonathan Rosen's The Best Minds: A Story of Friendship, Madness, and the Tragedy of Good Intentions takes its title from Allen Ginsberg's Howl, and could end up as just as enduring a work of American writing. Expect to see it on 'Best Of' lists, and plan to make space for its nearly 600 pages on your shelf. A memoir, a love letter, and a biblical tragedy all at once, it avoids easy answers but clings to difficult questions. A tale told with humility, it charts the path to hell by noting every good intention along the way."

—The New York Sun

"Dazzling . . . both a breathtaking and tragic portrait of a man with vast potential and a reckoning on how schizophrenia is treated and understood. This is a tough one to forget."

—Publisher's Weekly

title: Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk
long_summary:
A ferocious firefight with Iraqi insurgents—three minutes and forty-three seconds of intensive warfare caught on tape by an embedded Fox News crew—has transformed the eight surviving men of Bravo Squad into America's most sought-after heroes. For two weeks, the Bush Administration has sent them on a media-intensive "Victory Tour" to reinvigorate public support for the war.

Now, on this chilly Thanksgiving, the Bravos are guests of the Dallas Cowboys, slated for the Halftime Show alongside Destiny's Child. Among them is Silver Star-winning Specialist William Lynn, a nineteen-year-old Texas native and hero of Al-Ansakar.

Amid clamoring patriots with flag pins and "support our troops" bumper stickers, the Bravos encounter the Cowboys' hard-nosed owner and his wealthy colleagues, a born-again cheerleader, a veteran Hollywood producer, and supersized players eager for vicarious battle stories. Between these faces Billy sees his worried sisters, broken father, and Shroom—the philosophical sergeant who died in his arms.

Over this single day, Billy will discover difficult truths about himself, his country, his struggling family, and his brothers in arms. In his final hours before returning to Iraq, he'll drink and brawl, yearn for home, face a heart-wrenching decision, and discover both pure love and bitter wisdom far beyond his years.
short_summary: Iraq War soldiers become unlikely celebrities at a Dallas Cowboys game, exposing the chasm between battlefield reality and American spectacle. Fountain's devastating satire skewers patriotism, consumerism, and our collective conscience.
author_bios: Ben Fountain's work has received the National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction, the PEN/Hemingway Award, the Los Angeles Book Prize for Fiction, and a Whiting Writers Award. He's been a National Book Award finalist and Dayton Literary Peace Prize runner-up. He lives in Dallas.
quotes:
"[An] inspired, blistering war novel…Though it covers only a few hours, the book is a gripping, eloquent provocation. Class, privilege, power, politics, sex, commerce and the life-or-death dynamics of battle all figure in Billy Lynn's surreal game day experience."

—The New York Times

"Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk is not merely good; it's Pulitzer Prize-quality good . . . A bracing, fearless and uproarious satire of how contemporary war is waged and sold to the American public."

—San Francisco Chronicle

"A masterful echo of 'Catch-22,' with war in Iraq at the center. …a gut-punch of a debut novel…There's hardly a false note, or even a slightly off-pitch one, in Fountain's sympathetic, damning and structurally ambitious novel."

—The Washington Post

title: The Copenhagen Trilogy
subtitle: Childhood; Youth; Dependency
long_summary:
Tove Ditlevsen is celebrated as one of the most important voices in twentieth-century Danish literature, and the Copenhagen Trilogy is her rediscovered masterpiece.

Childhood follows a misfit girl's fierce determination to become a poet. Youth captures her early encounters with sex, work, and independence. In Dependency, she enters the first of four marriages and spirals into drug addiction, enabled by her manipulative doctor-husband.

Throughout, Ditlevsen navigates the impossible tension between her calling as a writer and her roles as daughter, wife, mother, and addict. Dismissed by critics during her lifetime, the trilogy is now hailed as a literary triumph and spiritual ancestor of today's autofiction.

Remarkable for its unflinching intensity, the work offers an immersive exploration of female friendship, family dynamics, and a young woman's struggle to be taken seriously as an artist—all while chronicling the devastating descent into addiction.
short_summary: Ditlevsen chronicles her journey from working-class girlhood to literary ambition to devastating addiction. Her prose cuts like glass—unflinching, darkly funny, and utterly mesmerizing.
author_bios: Tove Ditlevsen was born in 1917 in a working-class Copenhagen neighborhood. Her first poetry volume appeared in her early twenties, followed by numerous books including the three volumes of the Copenhagen Trilogy: Childhood (1967), Youth (1967), and Dependency (1971). She died in 1976.
quotes:
"A particular kind of masterpiece, one that helps fill a particular kind of void. Ditlevsen's voice, diffident and funny, dead-on about her own mistakes, is a welcome addition to that canon of women who showed us their secret faces so that we might wear our own."

—The New York Times

"Ditlevsen's taut, simple prose shines a light on what life and love were like for working-class women in 20th century Copenhagen. Elena Ferrante fans, take note."

—Stylist

"Intense and elegant ... an absolute tour de force."

—Lucy Scholes, The Paris Review

title: The Art of Fielding
long_summary:
At Westish College, a small school on the shore of Lake Michigan, baseball star Henry Skrimshander seems destined for big league stardom. But when a routine throw goes disastrously off course, the fates of five people are upended.

Henry's fight against self-doubt threatens to ruin his future. College president Guert Affenlight, a longtime bachelor, has fallen unexpectedly and helplessly in love. Owen Dunne, Henry's gay roommate and teammate, becomes caught up in a dangerous affair. Mike Schwartz, the Harpooners' team captain and Henry's best friend, realizes he has guided Henry's career at the expense of his own. And Pella Affenlight, Guert's daughter, returns to Westish after escaping an ill-fated marriage, determined to start a new life.

As the season counts down to its climactic final game, these five are forced to confront their deepest hopes, anxieties, and secrets. In the process they forge new bonds, and help one another find their true paths. Written with boundless intelligence and filled with the tenderness of youth, The Art of Fielding is an expansive, warmhearted novel about ambition and its limits, about family and friendship and love, and about commitment—to oneself and to others.
short_summary: One errant throw sends five lives spinning at a small Midwestern college. Baseball becomes the backdrop for a tender, expansive story about ambition, love, and finding your true path.
author_bios: Chad Harbach grew up in Wisconsin and graduated from Harvard in 1997. He was a Henry Hoyns Fellow at the University of Virginia, where he received an MFA in Fiction in 2004. He is currently a co-editor of n+1, which he cofounded, and lives in Virginia.
quotes:
"Reading The Art of Fielding is like watching a hugely gifted young shortstop: you keep waiting for the errors, but there are no errors. First novels this complete and consuming come along very, very seldom."

—Jonathan Franzen, author of Freedom

"An intricate, poised, tingling debut. Harbach's muscular prose breathes new life into the American past-time, recasts the personal worlds that orbit around it, and leaves you longing, lingering, and a baseball convert long after the last page."

—Téa Obreht, author of The Tiger's Wife

"Written with wit and grace and the true fan's eye and ear for the subtleties of the game. With The Art of Fielding, Harbach turns a double play that would make Skrimshander and Roth proud: The book will knock out baseball and literature fans alike."

—Sports Illustrated

title: Priestdaddy
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Father Greg Lockwood is unlike any Catholic priest you have ever met—a man who lounges in boxer shorts, loves action movies, and whose constant jamming on the guitar reverberates "like a whole band dying in a plane crash in 1972." His daughter is an irreverent poet who long ago left the Church's country. When an unexpected crisis leads her and her husband to move back into her parents' rectory, their two worlds collide.

In Priestdaddy, Lockwood interweaves emblematic moments from her childhood and adolescence—from an ill-fated family hunting trip and an abortion clinic sit-in where her father was arrested to her involvement in a cultlike Catholic youth group—with scenes that chronicle the eight-month adventure she and her husband had living in her parents' household after a decade on their own.

Lockwood details her education of a seminarian also living at the rectory, tries to explain Catholicism to her mystified husband, and encounters mysterious substances on hotel beds with her mother. She pivots from the raunchy to the sublime, from the comic to the deeply serious, exploring issues of belief, belonging, and personhood. An entertaining, unforgettable portrait of how one balances hard-won identity with the weight of family and tradition.
short_summary: When a crisis forces poet Patricia Lockwood back into her guitar-obsessed priest father's rectory, hilarity and heartbreak collide. A brilliant memoir about faith, family, and finding yourself.
author_bios: Patricia Lockwood is the bestselling author of the Booker Prize finalist and Dylan Thomas Prize-winning novel No One Is Talking About This, named one of the 10 Best Books of 2021 by The New York Times Book Review and one of The Atlantic's Great American Novels of the past 100 years. Her other books include the memoir Priestdaddy and two poetry collections. She is a contributing editor at the London Review of Books.
quotes:
"Priestdaddy roars from the gate . . . it's not just that Lockwood has fresh eyes and quick wits, but that in her father she's lucked upon one of the great characters of this nonfiction decade . . . Lockwood's prose is cute and dirty and innocent and experienced, Betty Boop in a pas de deux with David Sedaris . . . I suspect it may mean a lot to many people, especially the lapsed Catholics among us. It is, for sure, like no book I have read."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Remarkable . . . Lockwood proceeds with a near unflagging sense of ironic exuberance and verbal inventiveness . . . this superabundance of comic energy and literary vigor is a measure of Lockwood's seriousness."

—The Washington Post

"Patricia Lockwood's side-splitting Priestdaddy puts the poetry back in memoir. Her verbal verve creates a reading experience of effervescent joy, even as Lockwood takes you through some of her life's darker passages. Destined to be a classic, Priestdaddy is this year's must-read memoir."

—Mary Karr, author of The Liars' Club

title: My Friends
long_summary:
One evening in Benghazi, young Khaled hears a bizarre short story on the radio—about a man being eaten alive by a cat—and senses his life has changed forever. Obsessed by the power of those words and their enigmatic author, Hosam Zowa, he eventually leaves Libya to pursue his studies at the University of Edinburgh.

Thrust into an open society miles away from the world he knew, Khaled begins to transform. When he attends a protest against the Qaddafi regime in London, it explodes into tragedy. In a flash, he finds himself injured, clinging to life, unable to leave Britain or return home. Even telling his parents what he has done would expose them to danger on tapped phone lines.

A chance hotel encounter brings Khaled face-to-face with Hosam Zowa himself, leading to the deepest friendship of his life. It's a bond that sustains him but eventually forces him, as the Arab Spring erupts, to confront agonizing tensions between revolution and safety, family and exile, and how to define himself against those closest to him.

A devastating meditation on friendship, family, and the ways time tests and frays our deepest bonds.
short_summary: When a radio story changes young Khaled's life forever, he leaves Libya for Edinburgh, only to find himself trapped in exile after a protest turns tragic. A profound meditation on friendship, family, and the impossible choices of displacement.
author_bios: Hisham Matar was born in New York City to Libyan parents, spent his childhood in Tripoli and Cairo, and has lived most of his life in London. His memoir The Return won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize, the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, and the Rathbones Folio Prize. His novel In the Country of Men was shortlisted for the Booker Prize. He is also the author of Anatomy of a Disappearance and A Month in Siena. Matar is a professor at Barnard College and Columbia University, a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, and an honorary fellow of the Royal Academy of Arts.
quotes:
"Dazzling . . . a personal, deeply felt work . . . tightly structured and controlled, looping back and forth through time and memory, building on itself in a process of gradual expansion and revelation."

—Toronto Star

"Matar channels Roberto Bolaño's theme of literary obsession in this sublime novel of a Libyan exile in London whose two friends return to Libya in 2011 to take part in the overthrow of Gadhafi. As the narrator describes his quest to understand life through literature, the novel's sense of truthfulness and urgency restores the reader's belief in what fiction can do."

—Publishers Weekly

"Riveting and humane . . . At the core of My Friends is a powerful juxtaposition of loneliness and camaraderie, self-reliance and dependence, which defines the outline of exile. . . ."

—The Atlantic

title: The Goldfinch
long_summary:
Thirteen-year-old Theo Decker miraculously survives a terrorist attack at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art that kills his mother. In the chaos, he impulsively takes a small Dutch painting—The Goldfinch—that becomes his most treasured connection to her.

Abandoned by his father, Theo is taken in by the wealthy Barbour family on Park Avenue. Bewildered by his strange new world and tormented by grief, he clings to the mysterious painting that draws him into an insular community of art dealers and collectors.

As an adult, Theo moves between the drawing rooms of the rich and the dusty corners of an antique shop where he works. Still haunted by loss and increasingly entangled in the art underworld, he finds himself at the center of a narrowing, ever more dangerous circle.

This mesmerizing novel examines the devastating impact of grief, the ruthless machinations of fate, and the transformative power of art in an unforgettable story of survival and self-invention.
short_summary: When a museum bombing kills his mother, thirteen-year-old Theo steals a priceless painting that becomes his obsession. Tartt's Pulitzer-winning masterpiece follows his journey from grief-stricken boy to conflicted adult navigating New York's shadowy art world.
author_bios: Donna Tartt is an American writer whose novels have been published in forty languages. Her debut, The Secret History, was published in 1992. She received the WH Smith Literary Award for The Little Friend, which was also nominated for the Orange Prize for Fiction. She won the Pulitzer Prize and Andrew Carnegie Medal for Fiction for The Goldfinch.
quotes:
"Dazzling....[A] glorious, Dickensian novel, a novel that pulls together all Ms. Tartt's remarkable storytelling talents into a rapturous, symphonic whole and reminds the reader of the immersive, stay-up-all-night pleasures of reading."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"A long-awaited, elegant meditation on love, memory, and the haunting power of art....Eloquent and assured, with memorable characters....A standout-and well-worth the wait."

—Kirkus

"A soaring masterpiece."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The Gene
subtitle: An Intimate History
long_summary:
Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee follows his Pulitzer Prize-winning The Emperor of All Maladies with an even more ambitious work that braids science, history, and memoir into an epic exploration of human heredity. The Gene brings to life our quest to understand how genetics influences our lives, personalities, identities, and fates.

Mukherjee weaves together centuries of research and experimentation—from Aristotle and Pythagoras to Mendel and Darwin, from early geneticists to the revolutionary innovators who mapped the human genome. Throughout, he grounds abstract scientific concepts in deeply personal stories, including his own family's tragic history with mental illness, reminding us of the complex questions surrounding our ability to translate genetic science into real-world applications.

Written with scientific rigor wrapped in lyrical prose, this revelatory work captures both the wonder of genetic discovery and the sobering implications of our growing power to manipulate the very code of life.
short_summary: From the Pulitzer Prize-winning author comes a sweeping exploration of genetics that weaves together scientific discovery, family memoir, and the ethical questions surrounding our genetic future.
author_bios: Siddhartha Mukherjee is the author of The Song of the Cell, The Gene: An Intimate History (#1 New York Times bestseller), The Emperor of All Maladies (2011 Pulitzer Prize winner), and The Laws of Medicine. An associate professor of medicine at Columbia University, he's also a cancer physician and researcher. A Rhodes Scholar, he graduated from Stanford, Oxford, and Harvard Medical School. Elected to the National Academy of Medicine in 2023, he's published in Nature, The New England Journal of Medicine, Cell, and The New Yorker.
quotes:
This is perhaps the greatest detective story ever told—a millennia-long search, led by a thousand explorers, from Aristotle to Mendel to Francis Collins, for the question marks at the center of every living cell. Like The Emperor of All Maladies, The Gene is prodigious, sweeping, and ultimately transcendent. If you're interested in what it means to be human, today and in the tomorrows to come, you must read this book.

—Anthony Doerr, author of All the Light We Cannot See

Sobering, humbling, and extraordinarily rich reading from a wise and gifted writer who sees how far we have come—but how much farther far we have to go to understand our human nature and destiny.

—Kirkus

Mukherjee deftly relates the basic scientific facts about the way genes are believed to function, while making clear the aspects of genetics that remain unknown. He offers insight into both the scientific process and the sociology of science... By relating familial information, Mukherjee grounds the abstract in the personal to add power and poignancy to his excellent narrative.

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Argonauts
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Maggie Nelson's The Argonauts is a genre-bending memoir that offers fresh, fierce thinking about desire, identity, and the possibilities of love and language. At its center is a romance: Nelson's relationship with artist Harry Dodge, who is fluidly gendered, and her journey through pregnancy—an intimate portrayal of the complexities and joys of queer family-making.

Writing in the spirit of public intellectuals like Susan Sontag and Roland Barthes, Nelson binds personal experience to rigorous exploration of what iconic theorists have said about sexuality, gender, and the institutions of marriage and child-rearing. Her insistence on radical individual freedom and the value of caretaking becomes the rallying cry of this thoughtful, unabashed, uncompromising work of autotheory.
short_summary: Nelson weaves personal narrative with critical theory to explore queer love, family-making, and identity. Intellectually rigorous yet deeply intimate, this genre-bending memoir challenges conventional thinking about desire and language.
author_bios: Maggie Nelson is the author of The Argonauts, Bluets, Like Love, On Freedom, The Red Parts, and, most recently, Pathemata, Or, The Story of My Mouth. She teaches at the University of Southern California and lives in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"Maggie Nelson cuts through our culture's prefabricated structures of thought and feeling with an intelligence whose ferocity is ultimately in the service of love. No piety is safe, no orthodoxy, no easy irony. The scare quotes burn off like fog."

—Ben Lerner, author of The Topeka School

"What a dazzlingly generous, gloriously unpredictable book! Maggie Nelson shows us what it means to be real, offering a way of thinking that is as challenging as it is liberating. She invites us to 'pay homage to the transitive' and enjoy 'a becoming in which one never becomes.' Reading The Argonauts made me happier and freer."

—Eula Biss, author of Immunity

"It's Nelson's articulation of her many selves-the poet who writes prose; the memoirist who considers the truth specious; the essayist whose books amount to a kind of fairy tale, in which the protagonist goes from darkness to light, and then falls in love with a singular knight-that makes her readers feel hopeful."

—Hilton Als, The New Yorker

title: The Paying Guests
long_summary:
London, 1922. Ex-servicemen wander the streets disillusioned, while the hungry and out-of-work demand change. In genteel Camberwell, Mrs. Wray and her spinster daughter Frances inhabit a large, silent villa—once filled with brothers, husband, and servants, now echoing with loss and genteel poverty.

Desperation forces them to take in lodgers: Lilian and Leonard Barber, a modern young couple from the emerging clerk class. With their arrival, the house's careful routines begin to fracture in unexpected ways.

What the Wrays don't anticipate is how profoundly these new tenants will alter Frances's carefully ordered existence. As passions mount and long-suppressed frustrations bubble to the surface, the disturbances will reach far beyond anyone's imagination—with devastating consequences that will reshape all their lives.
short_summary: When a widowed mother and daughter take in lodgers in 1922 London, their genteel world fractures. Waters masterfully explores the collision of class and desire in post-war Britain.
author_bios: Sarah Waters is the New York Times–bestselling author of The Paying Guests, The Little Stranger, The Night Watch, Fingersmith, Affinity, and Tipping the Velvet. She has three times been short-listed for the Man Booker Prize, twice been a finalist for the Orange Prize, and was named one of Granta's best young British novelists. Waters lives in London.
quotes:
"An exquisitely tuned exploration of class in post-Edwardian Britain—with really hot sex…Tension is high from the first paragraph…Waters is a master of pacing, and her metaphor-laced prose is a delight…until the last page, the reader will have no idea what's going to happen. Waters keeps getting better, if that's even possible after the sheer perfection of her earlier novels."

—Kirkus

"An absorbing character study [and] expertly paced and gripping psychological narrative…Readers of Water's previous novels know that she brings historical eras to life with consummate skill, rendering authentic details into layered portraits of particular times and places…breathtaking"

—Publisher's Weekly

"Gripping… Sarah Waters is, quite simply, a marvelous writer…[with] complete mastery over her material."

—The Globe and Mail

title: House of Stone
subtitle: A Memoir of Home, Family, and a Lost Middle East
long_summary:
In spring 2011, Anthony Shadid was one of four New York Times reporters captured in Libya, cuffed and beaten, as that country was seized by revolution. When he was freed, he didn't return to Boston or Beirut—where he lived—or to Oklahoma City, where his Lebanese-American family had settled. Instead, he went home to his great-grandfather's estate, a house he had begun rebuilding three years earlier.

House of Stone chronicles both a battle-scarred home and a war correspondent's jostled spirit, revealing how reconstructing one came to fortify the other. In this poignant memoir, the author of the award-winning Night Draws Near creates a mosaic of past and present, tracing the house's renewal alongside his family's flight from Lebanon and resettlement in America.

Shadid memorializes a lost world while documenting the shifting Middle East, providing profound insights into this volatile landscape. The result is an unforgettable meditation on war, exile, rebirth, and the universal yearning for home.
short_summary: War correspondent Anthony Shadid rebuilds his great-grandfather's Lebanese estate while grappling with trauma from covering Middle Eastern conflicts. A profound meditation on home, heritage, and healing.
author_bios: Anthony Shadid (1968-2012), author of Night Draws Near, was an unparalleled chronicler of the human stories behind the news. He won the Pulitzer Prize for his front-page reports from Iraq in the Washington Post, then earned his second Pulitzer in 2010 as Middle East correspondent for the New York Times, covering the Arab Spring from Egypt to Libya to Syria. He died tragically on assignment in Syria in February 2012.
quotes:
"An honest-to-god, hands-down, undeniable and instant classic . . . written with levity and candor and lyricism that makes the book, improbably, both a compulsive read and one you don't want to end."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

"This is not just the Arab world's Year in Provence. It is as if Shadid has combined the breakthrough effects of Amy Tan's The Joy Luck Club, William Faulkner's As I Lay Dying,and Frances Fitzgerald's Fire in the Lake into one enormously likeable book. It is a masterpiece."

—John Freeman, Boston Globe

"Elegiac, heartbreaking . . . A book conceived as an introspective project of personal recovery — as well as a meditation on politics, identity, craft, and beauty in the Levant — now stands as a memorial. It is a fitting one because of the writing skill and deep feeling [Shadid] unobtrusively displays."

—Steve Coll, The New York Times

"House of Stone is a haunting, beautifully realized piece of writing."

—Nick Flynn, author of The Ticking Is the Bomb

"What a beautiful introduction to a world that I knew so little about. House of Stone is engaging, poignant, and funny."

—Abraham Verghese, author of The Covenant of Water & Cutting for Stone

title: The Surrendered
long_summary:
June Han was only a girl when the Korean War left her orphaned. Hector Brennan was a young GI who fled his small town's petty tragedies to serve his country. When the war ended, their lives collided at a Korean orphanage where they competed for the attention of Sylvie Tanner, a beautiful yet deeply damaged missionary wife whose elusive love seemed to transform everything.

Thirty years later and on the other side of the world, June and Hector are reunited in circumstances that force them to confront the mysterious secrets of their past and the shocking acts of love and violence that bind them together.

Lee weaves a profound meditation on heroism and sacrifice, the power of love, and the possibilities for mercy and salvation. Combining the complex themes of identity from his earlier works with ambitious storytelling, he delivers his most unforgettable novel yet—elegantly suspenseful and deeply affecting.
short_summary: Three lives intersect at a Korean War orphanage, then collide again thirty years later. Lee's ambitious novel explores how love and violence echo across decades with devastating emotional precision.
author_bios: Chang-rae Lee is the author of Native Speaker, winner of the Hemingway Foundation/PEN Award for first fiction, as well as My Year Abroad, On Such a Full Sea, A Gesture Life, Aloft, and The Surrendered, winner of the Dayton Peace Prize and a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. A 2021 winner of the Award of Merit for the Novel from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, he teaches writing at Stanford University.
quotes:
"Lee's masterful fourth novel bursts with drama and human anguish as it documents the ravages and indelible effects of war. . . . Powerful, deeply felt, compulsively readable and imbued with moral gravity, the novel does not peter out into easy redemption. It's a harrowing tale: bleak, haunting, often heartbreaking and not to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly

"[The Surrendered] is epic in scope, masterful in execution, heart stopping at times, and heartbreaking at others. The meticulous narrative unfolds over 52 years and across three continents. Nothing is rushed; nothing is overlooked. We can even feel the buzz of a window pane on our fingertips as rumbling Japanese military vehicles approach along a gravel road...Lee understands that in art and in stories what is perhaps most valuable is not what can be explained but what can be felt."

—The Boston Globe

"Lee...writes dense and gorgeous prose...Lee shows great tenderness for his [characters], even as he refuses them easy redemption. The final paragraph of his beautiful and tragic novel is as sublime and transcendent as any I can remember."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Barkskins
long_summary:
In late seventeenth-century New France, two penniless Frenchmen—René Sel and Charles Duquet—arrive bound to a feudal lord for three years in exchange for land. Both become wood-cutters, or "barkskins," but their paths quickly diverge.

René suffers extraordinary hardship in the oppressive forest he's charged with clearing. Forced to marry a Mi'kmaw woman, his descendants live trapped between two conflicting cultures. Duquet, crafty and ruthless, escapes his indenture to become a fur trader and eventually builds a timber empire.

Proulx follows both family lines across three centuries as they travel throughout North America, Europe, China, and New Zealand under brutal conditions—facing rival attacks, accidents, disease, and cultural destruction. Generation after generation seizes what they can from seemingly infinite forests, leaving modern descendants to confront potential ecological collapse.

Proulx creates characters so vivid in their greed, vengefulness, and hope that we follow them with fierce attention. This magnificent marriage of history and imagination stands as her most formidable work—an epic that traces how humanity's insatiable appetite shaped both families and the natural world.
short_summary: Two French indentured servants in 17th-century New France take vastly different paths—one trapped between cultures, the other building a timber empire. Proulx traces their descendants across three centuries of environmental destruction.
author_bios: Annie Proulx is the author of eleven books, including the novels The Shipping News and Barkskins, and the story collection Close Range. Her many honors include a Pulitzer Prize, a National Book Award, the Irish Times International Fiction Prize, and a PEN/Faulkner award. Her story "Brokeback Mountain" was made into an Academy Award–winning film. She lives in New Hampshire.
quotes:
"Annie Proulx's Barkskins is remarkable not just for its length, but for its scope and ambition. It's a monumental achievement, one that will perhaps be remembered as her finest work. . . It's exhilarating to read Proulx, a master storyteller; she is as adept at placing us in the dripping, cold Mi'kma'ki forests as in the stuffy Duke & Sons parlors. Despite the length, nothing seems extraneous, and not once does the reader sense the story slipping from Proulx's grasp, resulting in the kind of immersive reading experience that only comes along every few years."

—Publishers Weekly

"Part ecological fable à la Ursula K. Le Guin, part foundational saga along the lines of Brian Moore's Black Robe and, yes, James Michener's Centennial, Proulx's story builds in depth and complication without becoming unduly tangled and is always told with the most beautiful language. Another tremendous book from Proulx, sure to find and enthrall many readers."

—Kirkus

"Magnificent... Barkskins flies... One of the chief pleasures of Proulx's prose is that it conveys you to so many vanished wildwoods, where you get to stand 'tiny and amazed in the kingdom of pines.' This is also the great sadness of Barkskins. The propulsive tension here is generated not by wondering what will happen to each character, but by knowing that the forests will be leveled one after another... If Barkskins doesn't bear exquisite witness to our species's insatiable appetite for consumption, nothing can."

—Anthony Doerr, Outside Magazine

title: Deep Down Dark
subtitle: The Untold Stories of 33 Men Buried in a Chilean Mine, and the Miracle That Set Them Free
long_summary:
When the San José mine collapsed outside of Copiapó, Chile, in August 2010, it trapped thirty-three miners beneath thousands of feet of rock for a record-breaking sixty-nine days. The entire world watched the grueling rescue unfold above ground, but the saga of what happened below the Earth's surface has never been told—until now.

For Deep Down Dark, Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Héctor Tobar received exclusive access to the miners and their stories. These thirty-three men came to think of the mine—a cavern inflicting constant, thundering aural torment—as both coffin and church, a place where they sought redemption through prayer while confronting their mortality. Even while buried, they agreed that if any escaped alive, they would share their story only collectively. Tobar was the person they chose to tell it.

The result is masterful narrative journalism: a riveting, emotionally textured account of a singular human event. Deep Down Dark brings to haunting life the experience of being imprisoned inside a mountain of stone, the horror of slow-consuming hunger, and the spiritual elements that surrounded working in such a dangerous place.
short_summary: Thirty-three miners trapped beneath thousands of feet of rock for sixty-nine days finally tell their story. Tobar's exclusive access creates masterful narrative journalism about survival, faith, and the human spirit.
author_bios: Héctor Tobar is a Pulitzer Prize–winning journalist and novelist. He's the author of the critically acclaimed New York Times bestseller Deep Down Dark, as well as The Last Great Road Bum, The Barbarian Nurseries, Translation Nation, and The Tattooed Soldier. A contributing writer for the New York Times opinion section and professor at UC Irvine, he's written for The New Yorker and the Los Angeles Times. The son of Guatemalan immigrants, he lives in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"The equal, if the geographical inverse, of Into Thin Air."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"That Tobar has so vividly reconstructed a life-threatening event remembered differently by thirty-three minds is a mountainous feat of reportage."

—The Washington Post

"My favorite book of the year. Perfect for fans of Unbroken."

—Ann Patchett, People

title: The Lonely Polygamist
long_summary:
Golden Richards, husband to four wives and father to twenty-eight children, is having the mother of all midlife crises. His construction business is failing, his family has grown into an overpopulated mini-dukedom beset with insurrection and rivalry, and he's drowning in grief from the accidental death of a daughter and the stillbirth of a son.

Brady Udall tells the tragicomic story of a deeply faithful man who, crippled by loss and overwhelmed by the demands of work and family, becomes entangled in an affair that threatens to destroy everything. Udall creates characters that engage us fully as they grapple with the nature of need, love, and belonging.

Beautifully written, keenly observed, and ultimately redemptive, The Lonely Polygamist is an unforgettable story of an American family—with its inevitable dysfunction, heartbreak, and comedy—pushed to its outer limits.
short_summary: Golden Richards, a polygamist with four wives and 28 children, struggles with desire, secrecy, and the chaos of family life. Udall blends humor and pathos in a sprawling American tragicomedy.
author_bios: Brady Udall is the author of New York Times bestseller The Lonely Polygamist, The Miracle Life of Edgar Mint, and Letting Loose the Hounds. He teaches at Boise State University and lives in Boise, Idaho, with his wife and children.
quotes:
"[An] exceptional tale of an exceptional family."

—The New York Times

"The novel you must read this summer.... a riveting emotional tornado of a novel."

—Entertainment Weekly

"This is big-hearted American storytelling, the best new book I've read in years."

—Bonnie Jo Campbell, author of Once Upon a River & American Salvage

title: Fire Weather
subtitle: A True Story from a Hotter World
long_summary:
In May 2016, Fort McMurray—the hub of Canada's oil industry and America's biggest foreign supplier—was overrun by wildfire. The multi-billion-dollar disaster melted vehicles, turned entire neighborhoods into firebombs, and drove 88,000 people from their homes in a single afternoon.

Through the lens of this apocalyptic conflagration, John Vaillant warns that this was not a unique event, but a shocking preview of what we must prepare for in a hotter, more flammable world. Fire has been our partner for hundreds of millennia, shaping culture, civilization, and very likely our brains. It has enabled us to cook our food, defend our homes, and power the machines that drive our economy. Yet this volatile energy source has always threatened to elude our control.

With masterly prose and a cinematic eye, Vaillant takes us on a riveting journey through the intertwined histories of North America's oil industry and the birth of climate science, to the unprecedented devastation wrought by modern forest fires, and into lives forever changed by these disasters. This is urgent work from our new century of fire, which has only just begun.
short_summary: The 2016 Fort McMurray wildfire becomes a lens for understanding our changing relationship with fire itself. Vaillant weaves together oil industry history, climate science, and human stories in this urgent exploration of our increasingly flammable world.
author_bios: John Vaillant's acclaimed nonfiction books, The Golden Spruce and The Tiger, were national bestsellers. His debut novel, The Jaguar's Children, was a finalist for the Rogers Writers' Trust Fiction Prize and the International Dublin Literary Award. He has received the Governor General's Literary Award, British Columbia's National Award for Canadian Non-Fiction, the Windham-Campbell Literature Prize, and the Pearson Writers' Trust Prize for Nonfiction. He has written for The New Yorker, The Atlantic, National Geographic, and The Guardian.
quotes:
"This acclaimed and award-winning book offers a braided history of the rise of the oil sector and climate science. Set against the backdrop of the 2016 Fort McMurray, Alta., wildfires it is just the right amount of terrifying."

—The Globe and Mail

"All-too-timely....The real protagonist here is the fire itself: an unruly and terrifying force with insatiable appetites. This book is both a real-life thriller and a moment-by-moment account of what happened—and why, as the climate changes and humans don't, it will continue to happen again and again."

—The New York Times

"There's a lot of good Elizabeth Kolbert–level popular science writing here along with grittier portraits of the lives of the people who make their living among the tar sands and scrub. Vaillant...asks interesting questions...Perhaps the one most worthy of pondering being a deceptively simple one: 'Is fire alive?' A timely, well-written work of climate change reportage."

—Kirkus

title: The Return
subtitle: Fathers, Sons and the Land in Between
long_summary:
In 2012, after Qaddafi's overthrow, acclaimed novelist Hisham Matar returns to his native Libya after thirty years in exile. When he was eight, his family fled for political reasons. Eight years later, his father—a former diplomat turned dissident—was kidnapped from Cairo's streets by the Libyan government and imprisoned in the regime's most notorious jail.

Now the prisons stand empty, and little hope remains that Jaballah Matar will be found alive. Yet hope, as Matar writes, is "persistent and cunning." What emerges is both a deeply personal search and a meditation on loss, exile, and the enduring bonds between fathers and sons.

This profound memoir captures a family torn apart by political violence while painting an affecting portrait of Libya and its people at a moment of historic change. It's also a timeless examination of how absolute power destroys lives and the complex nature of grief when closure remains elusive.
short_summary: A son returns to post-revolution Libya searching for answers about his father's disappearance under Qaddafi's regime. Matar weaves personal loss with political upheaval in this haunting meditation on exile and hope.
author_bios: Hisham Matar was born in New York City to Libyan parents, spent his childhood in Tripoli and Cairo, and has lived most of his life in London. His memoir The Return won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize, the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, and the Rathbones Folio Prize. His novel In the Country of Men was shortlisted for the Booker Prize. He is also the author of Anatomy of a Disappearance and A Month in Siena. Matar is a professor at Barnard College and Columbia University, a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, and an honorary fellow of the Royal Academy of Arts.
quotes:
"[Hisham Matar] writes with both a novelist's eye for physical and emotional detail, and a reporter's tactile sense of place and time. The prose is precise, economical, chiseled; the narrative elliptical, almost musical…. The Return is, at once, a suspenseful detective story about a writer investigating his father's fate at the hands of a brutal dictatorship, and a son's efforts to come to terms with his father's ghost, who has haunted more than half his life by his absence."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"A moving, unflinching memoir of a family torn apart by the savage realities of today's Middle East. The crushing of hopes raised by the Arab spring—at both the personal and national levels—is conveyed all the more powerfully because Matar's anger remains controlled, his belief in humanity undimmed."

—Kazuo Ishiguro, "The Best Summer Books," The Guardian

"What a brilliant book. Hisham Matar has the quality all historians—of the world and the self—most need: He knows how to stand back and let the past speak. In chronicling his quest for his father, his manner is fastidious, even detached, but his anger is raw and unreconciled; through his narrative art he bodies out the shape of loss and gives a universality to his very particular experience of desolation. The Return reads as easily as a thriller, but is a story that will stick: A person is lost, but gravity and resonance remain."

—Hilary Mantel, author of Wolf Hall & Bring Up the Bodies

title: The Sisters
long_summary:
Meet the Mikkola sisters: Ina, Evelyn, and Anastasia. Their mother is a Tunisian carpet seller, their father a mysterious Swede who abandoned them years ago. Ina is tall, serious, obsessively organized. Evelyn is dreamy and magnetic, a natural performer. Anastasia is moody and chaotic, quick to anger and impossible to pin down.

Ina meets her future husband when her sisters drag her to a New Year's rave, only to suffer the ultimate betrayal. Evelyn drifts through life before launching a wild acting career. Anastasia flees to Tunisia, where she falls in love with a woman who will later transform everything.

Watching from afar is Jonas, son of a Swedish mother and Tunisian father. Over three decades, his life weaves through theirs—from a chance encounter in Tunis to the scene of a fighter jet crash in Stockholm. When Evelyn vanishes during a trip to New York, Jonas tracks her down and helps break the curse that's haunted the Mikkolas for decades. In the process, a shocking revelation changes everything they thought they knew about themselves.

Narrated in six parts spanning periods from years to minutes, this is an addictively entertaining family saga of the highest order.
short_summary: Three sisters navigate love, betrayal, and family secrets across continents and decades. When one disappears, a shocking revelation threatens to unravel everything they thought they knew about themselves.
author_bios: Jonas Hassen Khemiri is the author of six novels, seven plays, and a collection of short stories and essays. The Family Clause was a finalist for the National Book Award for Translated Literature. Invasion! won an Obie Award for best script. He's received a Cullman Fellowship at the New York Public Library, and his work has appeared in The New York Times, The New Yorker, and numerous other publications. The Sisters is his first book written in English. He lives in Brooklyn with his family and teaches in the creative writing program at New York University.
quotes:
"If you welcome this novel into your mind, it will warm and transform you."

—Tess Gunty, author of The Rabbit Hutch

"Jonas Hassen Khemiri is the very rare combination of a deep intellectual and a true storyteller, as smart as he is entertaining."

—Fredrik Backman author of A Man Called Ove

"Jonas Hassen Khemiri illuminates complex familial intimacies with utter clarity."

—Raven Leilani, author of Luster

title: Steve Jobs
long_summary:
Based on more than forty interviews with Steve Jobs and conversations with over 100 family members, friends, competitors, and colleagues, Walter Isaacson delivers a riveting portrait of the creative entrepreneur who revolutionized six industries: personal computers, animated movies, music, phones, tablet computing, and digital publishing.

Jobs emerges as the ultimate icon of applied imagination—someone who understood that twenty-first-century value comes from connecting creativity with technology. He built a company where leaps of imagination merged with remarkable engineering feats.

Though Jobs cooperated fully with Isaacson, he demanded no editorial control and put nothing off-limits. He encouraged brutal honesty from everyone involved. The result is an unvarnished view of the passions, perfectionism, obsessions, and compulsive need for control that shaped both his business approach and the innovative products that followed.

This tale is both instructive and cautionary, offering essential lessons about innovation, leadership, character, and values from one of history's most complex and influential figures.
short_summary: The definitive biography of Apple's mercurial cofounder, built from unprecedented access to Jobs himself and those closest to him. Isaacson captures both the visionary genius and the complicated human behind the revolution.
author_bios: Walter Isaacson is the bestselling author of biographies of Elon Musk, Jennifer Doudna, Leonardo da Vinci, Steve Jobs, Benjamin Franklin, and Albert Einstein. He is a professor of history at Tulane and was CEO of the Aspen Institute, chair of CNN, and editor of Time. He was awarded the National Humanities Medal in 2023.

title: Lincoln in the Bardo
long_summary:
February 1862. The Civil War has begun in earnest, and President Lincoln's beloved eleven-year-old son Willie lies gravely ill in the White House. Within days, despite predictions of recovery, Willie dies and is laid to rest in a Georgetown cemetery. Newspapers report that a grief-stricken Lincoln returns alone to the crypt to hold his boy's body.

From this historical truth, George Saunders spins an unforgettable story that breaks free of realistic framework into a supernatural realm both hilarious and terrifying. Willie Lincoln finds himself in a strange purgatory where ghosts mingle, gripe, commiserate, and enact bizarre acts of penance. Within this transitional state—the bardo of Tibetan tradition—a monumental struggle erupts over young Willie's soul.

Formally daring and generous in spirit, Lincoln in the Bardo deploys a kaleidoscopic, theatrical panorama of voices to explore how we live and love when everything we cherish must end. It's an astonishing feat of imagination and a bold step forward from one of our most important writers.
short_summary: George Saunders transforms the historical death of Lincoln's son into supernatural brilliance. Willie finds himself in a purgatory populated by quarreling ghosts, while his grieving father visits the crypt in this formally daring exploration of love and loss.
author_bios: George Saunders is the author of thirteen books, including the novel Lincoln in the Bardo, which won the Man Booker Prize, and five story collections, including Tenth of December, a National Book Award finalist, and Liberation Day (selected by President Obama as one of his ten favorite books of 2022). Three of his books—Pastoralia, Tenth of December, and Lincoln in the Bardo—were chosen for The New York Times's 100 Best Books of the 21st Century. He hosts Story Club on Substack and teaches at Syracuse University.
quotes:
"A luminous feat of generosity and humanism."

—Colson Whitehead, The New York Times

"A masterpiece."

—Zadie Smith

"An extended national ghost story . . . As anyone who knows Saunders's work would expect, his first novel is a strikingly original production."

—The Washington Post

title: The Vanishing Half
long_summary:
The Vignes twin sisters will always be identical. But after growing up together in a small, southern black community and running away at age sixteen, it's not just the shape of their daily lives that is different as adults—it's everything: their families, their communities, their racial identities.

Many years later, one sister lives with her black daughter in the same southern town she once tried to escape. The other secretly passes for white, and her white husband knows nothing of her past. Still, even separated by so many miles and just as many lies, the fates of the twins remain intertwined.

Weaving together multiple strands and generations of this family, from the Deep South to California, from the 1950s to the 1990s, Bennett produces a story that is at once a riveting, emotional family story and a brilliant exploration of the American history of passing. Looking well beyond issues of race, The Vanishing Half considers the lasting influence of the past as it shapes a person's decisions, desires, and expectations, exploring the multiple reasons people sometimes feel pulled to live as something other than their origins.
short_summary: Twin sisters choose radically different paths when one decides to pass for white while the other remains in their black community. A multigenerational saga exploring identity, family secrets, and the weight of the past.
author_bios: Born and raised in Southern California, Brit Bennett graduated from Stanford University and earned her MFA at the University of Michigan. Her debut, The Mothers, was a New York Times bestseller and finalist for the NBCC John Leonard First Novel Prize and PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize. The Vanishing Half was an instant #1 New York Times bestseller, longlisted for the National Book Award, and named one of the ten best books of the year by The New York Times. She's a National Book Foundation 5 Under 35 honoree and Time Next 100 Influential People selection.
quotes:
"[Bennett's] second [book], The Vanishing Half, more than lives up to her early promise. . . more expansive yet also deeper, a multi-generational family saga that tackles prickly issues of racial identity and bigotry and conveys the corrosive effects of secrets and dissembling. It's also a great read that will transport you out of your current circumstances, whatever they are. . . Like The Mothers, this novel keeps you turning pages not just to find out what happens."

—NPR

"Bennett's gorgeously written second novel, an ambitious meditation on race and identity, considers the divergent fates of twin sisters, born in the Jim Crow South, after one decides to pass for white. Bennett balances the literary demands of dynamic characterization with the historical and social realities of her subject matter."

—The New York Times

"Assured and magnetic. . .Bennett is deeply engaged in the unknowability of other people and the scourge of colorism…calls up Toni Morrison's The Bluest Eye, the book's 50-year-old antecedent. . . .  [a] rich, sharp story about the way identity is formed."

—Kirkus

title: Iron Curtain
subtitle: The Crushing of Eastern Europe, 1944-1956
long_summary:
At the end of World War II, the Soviet Union found itself controlling a vast swath of Eastern Europe. Stalin and his secret police set out to convert a dozen radically different countries to Communism—a completely new political and moral system that would reshape millions of lives.

In Iron Curtain, Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Anne Applebaum reveals how Communist regimes were systematically created across Eastern Europe and what daily life looked like once they took hold. Drawing on newly opened archives, interviews, and personal accounts translated for the first time, she portrays the devastating dilemmas faced by ordinary people trying to survive a system that challenged their every belief and stripped away everything they had built.

Applebaum captures the cruelty, paranoia, and bizarre aesthetics of this lost civilization with electrifying detail, showing how an entire region was transformed in the space of just a few years.
short_summary: Applebaum reveals how Stalin systematically converted Eastern Europe to Communism after WWII, transforming millions of lives in the process. Drawing on newly opened archives and survivor interviews, she captures a lost civilization defined by cruelty and paranoia.
author_bios: After seventeen years as a columnist at The Washington Post, Anne Applebaum became a staff writer at The Atlantic in 2020. She is the author of many acclaimed books, including Twilight of Democracy, Red Famine, Iron Curtain, Between East and West, and Gulag, winner of the Pulitzer Prize. She divides her time between Poland and Washington, D.C.
quotes:
"One of the most compelling but also serious works on Europe's past to appear in recent memory…In her relentless quest for understanding, Applebaum shines light into forgotten worlds of human hope, suffering and dignity."

—The Washington Post

"Remarkable…a book that reanimates a world that was largely hidden from Western eyes, and that many people who lived and suffered in it would prefer to forget….Iron Curtain gives us some idea of what it was like to be trapped in the Soviet experiment, to be a witness to the demolition and reconstruction of one's environment."

—Louis Menand, The New Yorker

"Iron Curtain is a superb, revisionistic, brilliantly perceptive, often witty, totally gripping history, filled with colorful character sketches of Stalinist monsters, based on Soviet and local archives, on hundreds of interviews with survivors, and on the widest reading, that tells the dramatic, unknown and terrifying story of the Stalinization of eastern Europe….The book is full of things I didn't know — but should have."

—Simon Sebag Montefiore, London Evening Standard

title: The Big Short
subtitle: Inside the Doomsday Machine
long_summary:
When the U.S. stock market crashed in fall 2008, it was already old news. The real crash had taken place over the previous year in shadowy derivative markets where geeks invented impenetrable securities to profit from Americans who couldn't pay their debts.

The smart people who understood what was happening stayed silent, paralyzed by hope and fear. The crucial question: Who saw the risk in ever-rising real estate prices and the arcane securities built on doubtful mortgages?

Michael Lewis flips the inquiry to ask: Who got it right? Who saw the real estate market as the black hole it would become and made billions from that insight? What made these unlikely heroes persist when colleagues dismissed them as doomsayers?

From this handful of contrarians, Lewis crafts a character-driven narrative brimming with indignation and dark humor—a fitting sequel to his bestselling Liar's Poker that proves he remains our finest chronicler of financial folly.
short_summary: Michael Lewis tells the story of the contrarians who saw the 2008 financial crisis coming and bet against the system. Character-driven financial journalism with Lewis's signature wit and insight.
author_bios: Michael Lewis is the bestselling author of Liar's Poker, Moneyball, The Blind Side, The Big Short, The Fifth Risk, and Going Infinite. He lives in Berkeley, California, with his family.
quotes:
"No one writes with more narrative panache about money and finance than Mr. Lewis....[he] does a nimble job of using his subjects' stories to explicate the greed, idiocies and hypocrisies of a system notably lacking in grown-up supervision....Writing in faintly Tom Wolfe-ian prose, Mr. Lewis does a colorful job of introducing the lay reader to the Darwinian world of the bond market."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"One of the best business books of the past two decades."

—Malcolm Gladwell, The New York Times

"Superb: Michael Lewis doing what he does best, illuminating the idiocy, madness and greed of modern finance. . . . Lewis achieves what I previously imagined impossible: He makes subprime sexy all over again."

—Andrew Leonard, Salon.com

title: Trust Exercise
long_summary:
At a competitive performing arts high school in 1982, freshmen David and Sarah fall into intense first love while studying under the magnetic acting teacher Mr. Kingsley. In this rarified world of Shakespeare and movement classes, they and their classmates exist in an ambitious bubble, devoted entirely to their craft.

But as the students rise through the ranks, the outside pressures of family, economics, and future plans begin to intrude. A sudden spiral of events brings the first part of their story to a startling close.

Then the novel takes an unexpected turn. In the second section, readers discover that what seemed true about the story so far is incomplete—not entirely false, but not the whole truth either. The plot accelerates and tightens until a stunning final revelation reshapes everything we thought we understood.

As captivating and tender as it is brilliantly surprising, Trust Exercise ignites conversations about fiction and truth, friendships and loyalties, while offering profound insights into adolescent capacity and adult responsibility.
short_summary: Two drama students fall in love at a competitive 1980s arts high school, but their story fractures into competing narratives about memory, power, and truth. Choi's bold novel reshapes itself before your eyes.
author_bios: Susan Choi is the author of Trust Exercise, which received the National Book Award for Fiction, as well as the novels The Foreign Student, American Woman, A Person of Interest, and My Education. She is a recipient of the Asian American Literary Award for fiction, the PEN/W. G. Sebald Award, a Lambda Literary Award, the Sunday Times Audible Short Story Award, and fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation. She teaches in the Writing Seminars at Johns Hopkins University and lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"[Trust Exercise] burns more brightly than anything [Choi's] yet written. This psychologically acute novel enlists your heart as well as your mind. Zing will go certain taut strings in your chest. . . . Choi builds her novel carefully, but it is packed with wild moments of grace and fear and abandon. . . . [A] delicious and, in its way, rather delicate . . . phosphorescent examination of sexual consent."

—The New York Times

"A gonzo literary performance one could mistake for a magic trick, duping its readers with glee before leaving them impossibly moved. . . . Facts are debated in Trust Exercise, yes, but Choi always tells the truth."

—Entertainment Weekly

"What begins as the story of obsessive first love between drama students at a competitive performing arts high school in the early 1980s twists into something much darker in Choi's singular new novel . . . an effective interrogation of memory, the impossible gulf between accuracy and the stories we tell. . . . The writing (exquisite) and the observations (cuttingly accurate) make Choi's latest both wrenching and one-of-a-kind. Never sentimental; always thrillingly alive."

—Kirkus

title: The Wren, the Wren
long_summary:
Nell McDaragh never knew her grandfather Phil, the celebrated Irish poet whose love poems seem to speak directly to her. At twenty-two, restless and wryly self-assured, she leaves her mother Carmel's orderly home to find her own voice as a writer and live a poetical life. As she chases obsessive love, damage, and transcendence in Dublin and beyond, her grandfather's poetry seems to guide her home.

Nell's mother, Carmel, knows the magic of her father's poetry too well—the kind that makes women slip outside for a kiss and then elope, as her own mother Terry had done. In his poems, Phil envisions Carmel as a bright-eyed wren escaping from his hand. But it is Phil who departs, abandoning his wife and two young daughters. Carmel struggles to reconcile "the poet" with the father whose desertion scars her life, along with that of her fiercely dutiful sister and their gentle, cancer-ridden mother.

The Wren, the Wren brings to life three generations of McDaragh women who must contend with inheritances—of poetic wonder and of abandonment by a man lauded in public but carelessly selfish at home. Their stronger inheritance is a sustaining love that is "more than a strand of DNA, but a rope thrown from the past."
short_summary: Three generations of Irish women reckon with the legacy of a celebrated poet who was also an absent father. Enright weaves family trauma and transcendence into something luminous and unforgettable.
author_bios: Anne Enright is the author of eight novels, most recently The Wren. She has been awarded the Man Booker Prize and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction, and was named the inaugural Laureate for Irish Fiction. In 2022, Enright received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Irish Book Awards. She lives and works in Dublin.
quotes:
"This is a powerful, thoughtful book by one of the great living writers on the subject of family. Speaking about love in terms both domestic and transcendent, Enright coos through newly connected wires."

—The New York Times

"To call Anne Enright's new novel a moving, nuanced glimpse at three generations of Irish life underplays its thrilling expansiveness: in the end, The Wren, The Wren is an electrifying romp through language itself—its dizzying possibilities and satisfactions—led by one the most gifted writers working in English today."

—Jennifer Egan, author of A Visit From the Goon Squad & The Candy House

"The power of Enright's novel derives not so much from the age-old tale of men behaving badly, but from the beauty and depth of her own style. She's so deft at rendering arresting insights into personality types or situations."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here
subtitle: The United States, Central America, and the Making of a Crisis
long_summary:
Hundreds of thousands of people arrive at the US-Mexico border each year, traveling vast distances from homes they can no longer safely inhabit. While many come from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras, others begin their journeys from much farther away. Some flee persecution, others escape crime or hunger. Many have already been deported but see the United States as their only hope for safety and prosperity.

As Jonathan Blitzer reveals through forensic, unprecedented reporting, this crisis stems from decades of misguided policy and sweeping corruption. He brilliantly weaves together the stories of Central Americans whose lives have been devastated by chronic political conflict and violence with those of American activists, government officials, and politicians responsible for the country's tragically tangled immigration policy.

Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here tells the epic story of people whose lives ebb and flow across the border, delving into the heart of American life itself. This vital story has shaped the nation's turbulent politics and culture in countless ways—and will almost certainly determine its future.
short_summary: Forensic reporting reveals how decades of policy failures created the humanitarian crisis at the southern border. Blitzer weaves together migrant stories with political machinations in this essential chronicle of American immigration.
genres: History / United States / State & Local / Southwest (AZ, NM, OK, TX)
author_bios: Jonathan Blitzer is a staff writer at The New Yorker. He has won a National Award for Education Reporting and an Edward R. Murrow Award, and was a 2021 Emerson Fellow at New America. He lives with his family in New York City.
quotes:
"This book will tear your heart out. Both intimate and comprehensive, it treks deep into the tragedies of El Salvador, Guatemala, and US immigration policy. Jon Blitzer's reporting is vast, meticulous, and authoritative. The main characters are drawn with the richness of great fiction."

—William Finnegan, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Barbarian Days

"As Jonathan Blitzer shows in Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here, his timely and instructive history of the immigration crisis, the trouble at the border isn't likely to be solved soon, since it is the outcome of a long and vexed entanglement between the United States and its southern neighbors . . . Conflicts over immigration often arise from similarity rather than difference, and the strangers at our border have a familiar history that Blitzer tells in meticulous and vivid detail. It is our own."

—Matthieu Aikins, The New York Times

"What we're seeing today on the southern border and in cities including New York, where more than 100,000 migrants arrived in the past year—are reverberations of a long, violent history that implicates the United States for its meddling in Central America. This is the story that Jonathan Blitzer painstakingly documents in his new book, Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here . . . Blitzer shows all the ways our immigration system is in shambles. A series of misguided actions and their consequences brought us to this point. This book begins the reckoning we desperately need."

—The Atlantic

title: The Buffalo Hunter Hunter
long_summary:
A diary written in 1912 by a Lutheran pastor is discovered within a wall, unveiling a slow massacre—a chain of events that traces back to 217 Blackfeet dead in the snow.

The story unfolds through transcribed interviews with a Blackfeet man named Good Stab, who shares the narrative of his peculiar life over a series of confessional visits. What emerges is an American Indian revenge story that spans generations, exploring the bloody intersections of faith, guilt, and retribution.

Stephen Graham Jones, one of horror's new masters, crafts a spellbinding tale that confronts one of the most significant and brutal chapters in American history. Through Good Stab's voice, the novel becomes both a reckoning with historical violence and a supernatural thriller that refuses to let the past stay buried.
short_summary: A Lutheran pastor's 1912 diary reveals a slow massacre tied to 217 dead Blackfeet. Told through confessional interviews with a man named Good Stab, this supernatural revenge story confronts America's bloodiest historical sins.
author_bios: Stephen Graham Jones is the New York Times bestselling author of The Only Good Indians, My Heart Is a Chainsaw, and I Was a Teenage Slasher. He's received an NEA fellowship and numerous awards including the Ray Bradbury Award, Bram Stoker Award, Shirley Jackson Award, Jesse Jones Award, Independent Publishers Award for Multicultural Fiction, and the Alex Award. He's the Ivena Baldwin Professor of English at the University of Colorado Boulder.
quotes:
"The Buffalo Hunter Hunter is Stephen Graham Jones' horror masterpiece. The prose is gorgeous and the plot is complex. The author of The Only Good Indians returns again with a spellbinding yarn about one of the bloodiest, most significant parts of the nation's history."

—NPR

"Inventive and spine-tingling, The Buffalo Hunter Hunter is the best book I've read in ages. It's a master class in voice... Queasy, uneasy, The Buffalo Hunter Hunter plays with the interplay between religion and historical guilt, identity and appetite."

—The Washington Post

"Jones has written his Interview With the Indigenous Vampire...A landmark of horror and historical fiction alike, perhaps the closest thing we have to horror's Moby-Dick."

—Vulture

title: The Sleepwalkers
subtitle: How Europe Went to War in 1914
long_summary:
On June 28, 1914, when Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife Sophie Chotek arrived at Sarajevo Railway Station, Europe was at peace. Thirty-seven days later, it was at war—a conflict that would kill over fifteen million people, destroy three empires, and permanently alter world history.

The Sleepwalkers reveals in gripping detail how this crisis unfolded. Drawing on fresh sources, Clark traces the paths to war in a minute-by-minute narrative that cuts between key decision centers in Vienna, Berlin, St. Petersburg, Paris, London, and Belgrade. He examines the decades of history that informed the events of 1914 and details the mutual misunderstandings and unintended signals that drove the crisis forward.

How did the Balkans—a peripheral region far from Europe's centers of power—come to be the center of such magnitude? Clark reveals a Europe racked by chronic problems, a fractured world of instability saddled with conspicuously ineffectual political leaders. These rulers, who prided themselves on modernity and rationalism, stumbled through crisis after crisis and finally convinced themselves that war was the only answer.

Meticulously researched and masterfully written, The Sleepwalkers is a magisterial account of one of the most compelling dramas of modern times.
short_summary: Clark traces Europe's stumble into World War I through thirty-seven fateful days in 1914. Meticulously researched and grippingly told, revealing how misunderstandings and ineffectual leadership dragged the world into catastrophe.
author_bios: Christopher Clark is a professor of modern European history and fellow of St. Catharine's College at the University of Cambridge. He is the author of Revolutionary Spring, The Sleepwalkers, Time and Power, Iron Kingdom, and other books.
quotes:
"Excellent. . . . The book is stylishly written as well as superb scholarship. No analysis of the origins of the First World War will henceforth be able to bypass this magisterial work."

—Ian Kershaw, BBC

"The distinctive achievement of The Sleepwalkers is Clark's single-volume survey of European history leading up to the war. That may sound dull. Quite the contrary. It is as if a light had been turned on a half-darkened stage of shadowy characters cursing themselves without reason. . . . A thoroughly comprehensive and highly readable account. . . . The brilliance of Clark's far-reaching history is that we are able to discern how the past was genuinely prologue. . . . In conception, steely scholarship and piercing insights, his book is a masterpiece."

—Harold Evans, The New York Times

"Easily the best book ever written on the subject. . . . A work of rare beauty that combines meticulous research with sensitive analysis and elegant prose. The enormous weight of its quality inspires amazement and awe. . . . Academics should take note: Good history can still be a good story."

—The Washington Post

title: Wave
long_summary:
On December 26, 2004, Sonali Deraniyagala lost everything that mattered to her. The tsunami that struck Sri Lanka's southern coast claimed her parents, her husband, and her two young sons—while she miraculously survived.

In this devastating memoir, Deraniyagala chronicles both the horror of that morning and the impossible journey that followed. She writes with unflinching honesty about the early months of grief, when she fought furiously against a reality too brutal to accept. Then, slowly and reluctantly, she begins to let memory carry her back through the rich life she's mourning—from her family's London home to her children's births, from meeting her English husband at Cambridge to her childhood in Colombo.

This is a story about learning to live with unbearable loss while keeping love alive. Deraniyagala's prose is searingly frank yet beautifully controlled, creating an account that is both heartbreaking and unexpectedly life-affirming.
short_summary: Deraniyagala survived the 2004 tsunami that killed her entire family on a Sri Lankan beach. Her memoir traces the aftermath with devastating honesty and unexpected grace.
author_bios: Sonali Deraniyagala teaches in the Department of Economics at SOAS, University of London. Her acclaimed memoir Wave (2013) recounts her experiences during and after the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami.
quotes:
"Courageous, truthful and, above all, generous . . . What amazed me most about the book is what good company it is. Deraniyagala is accepting and tender in her record of grief . . . Wave is in fact full of persisting life."

—Globe & Mail

"A devastating but ultimately redemptive memoir . . . The craft and control reflect an exceptional literary command . . . Excellent. Reading Deraniyagala's account proves almost as cathartic as writing it must have been."

—Kirkus

"Deraniyagala has written a book teaming with beautiful ruminations on the bittersweetness of memory and the precariousness of life."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Audition
long_summary:
Two people meet for lunch in a Manhattan restaurant. She's an elegant, accomplished actress in rehearsals for an upcoming premiere. He's attractive, troubling, and young—young enough to be her son.

Who is he to her, and who is she to him? In this compulsively readable novel, two competing narratives unspool, rewriting our understanding of the roles we perform daily—partner, parent, creator, muse—and the truths every performance masks, especially from those who think they know us best.

Taut and hypnotic, Audition showcases Kitamura at her virtuosic best, crafting a brilliant exploration of identity, performance, and the stories we tell ourselves about the people closest to us.
short_summary: Two competing narratives unspool around a lunch between an accomplished actress and a troubling young man. A hypnotic exploration of performance, identity, and the roles we play.
author_bios: Katie Kitamura is the author of four previous novels, most recently A Separation and Intimacies, which was longlisted for the National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award and was a finalist for a Joyce Carol Oates Prize. She is a recipient of the Rome Prize in Literature and a Lannan fellowship. Her work has been translated into twenty-one languages. She teaches in the creative writing program at New York University.
quotes:
"Katie Kitamura is a dizzyingly skilled writer whose fictions always seem to manage two contradictory effects: a supple seductive surface, under which the chaos of minds and repressed realities roil. She's an original, building an entire metier of her own."

—Rachel Kushner, author of The Flamethrowers and The Mars Room

"You have never read anything like this gorgeously disquieting book. Audition challenges our preconceptions about love, art, and selfhood—and, magnificently, our very idea of how a novel should unfold. If all the world's a stage, Kitamura reminds us that we never stop auditioning for our parts."

—Hernan Diaz, author of Trust

"Katie Kitamura is one of our most brilliant writers, saying far more in her silences, blank spaces, and disruptions than most novelists can say in a hundred thousand words. Audition is eerie, a book so cold it feels hot. It hooked into my mind like a burr."

—Lauren Groff, author of The Vaster Wilds and Fates and Furies

title: In the Darkroom
long_summary:
In 2004, Susan Faludi set out to investigate someone she scarcely knew: her father. The project began with a grievance—the grievance of a daughter whose parent had absconded from her life.
