She was pursuing a scofflaw who had skipped out on obligation, affection, and contrition. She was preparing an indictment. But somewhere along the line, the prosecutor became a witness.

When the feminist writer learned that her 76-year-old father—long estranged and living in Hungary—had undergone sex reassignment surgery, her investigation turned personal and urgent. How was this new parent who claimed to be "a complete woman now" connected to the silent, explosive father she had known?

Faludi chases that mystery through her father's many incarnations: American dad, Alpine mountaineer, swashbuckling adventurer, Jewish fugitive in Holocaust Budapest. When she travels to Hungary for their reunion, she drops into a labyrinth of dark histories and dangerous politics in a country hell-bent on repressing its past.

Her struggle to understand her father's reinvented self takes her across borders—historical, political, religious, sexual—to confront the question of our age: Is identity something you choose, or the very thing you can't escape?
short_summary: When feminist writer Susan Faludi learns her estranged 76-year-old father has undergone sex reassignment surgery, she embarks on a haunting investigation into identity, family, and reinvention that spans continents and generations.
author_bios: Susan Faludi is a Pulitzer Prize–winning journalist and author of The Terror Dream, Stiffed, and Backlash, which won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Nonfiction. A former Wall Street Journal reporter, she has written for The New Yorker, The New York Times, Harper's, and The Baffler.
quotes:
"In the Darkroom is a compelling, lyrical, and candid exploration of identity, gender, and the intensely complex relationship between a transgendered father and her daughter. More than memoir, or biography, it's a detective story with two unforgettable characters...[and] a landmark achievement in which Faludi uses her well-honed journalistic talents to tell the most intimate story she could possibly tell, her father's journey into womanhood."

—Kirkus Reviews' Judges' Statement

"A gripping and honest personal journey."

—Entertainment Weekly

"A wrought and multi-layered memoir...Powerful and absorbing."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Chain-Gang All Stars
long_summary:
Loretta Thurwar and Hamara "Hurricane Staxxx" Stacker are the stars of Chain-Gang All-Stars, the cornerstone of CAPE—Criminal Action Penal Entertainment. This highly popular, highly controversial program has become a profit-raising juggernaut in America's increasingly dominant private prison industry. It's the return of the gladiators, and prisoners are competing for the ultimate prize: their freedom.

In CAPE, prisoners travel as Links in Chain-Gangs, competing in death matches before packed arenas with righteous protestors at the gates. Thurwar and Staxxx, both teammates and lovers, are the fan favorites. If all goes well, Thurwar will be free in just a few matches—a fact she carries as heavily as her lethal hammer.

As she prepares to leave her fellow Links, Thurwar considers how she might help preserve their humanity in defiance of these so-called games. But CAPE's corporate owners will stop at nothing to protect their status quo, and the obstacles they lay in Thurwar's path have devastating consequences.
short_summary: Two women gladiators fight for freedom in a brutal private prison entertainment system. Adjei-Brenyah imagines American incarceration as deadly spectacle in this explosive debut novel.
author_bios: Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah is the New York Times-bestselling author of Friday Black. His work has appeared in The New York Times Book Review, Esquire, The Paris Review, and elsewhere. He was a National Book Foundation "5 Under 35" honoree, winner of the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award and the Saroyan Prize, and finalist for the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Award for Best First Book. Raised in Spring Valley, New York, he now lives in the Bronx.
quotes:
"Given how incredible his debut collection was and is, it is no surprise to me that Adjei-Brenyah's debut novel is this extraordinary! Told with bold, muscular prose, this book is filled with surprising tenderness. Some of the best and most beautiful descriptions of action and violence I have ever read, which is not to say the book celebrates violence so much as it uses violence to explore American incarceration by imagining it as spectacle. As big as it is dazzling. Just wild how good and original this book is. A revelation!"

—Tommy Orange, author of Wandering Stars & There, There

"As vital as it is brutal. Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah illuminates darkness with the electricity of his prose. The massive weight of the subject is matched by the sheer scope of Adjei-Brenyah's imagination. A startling, important novel that will inspire and inform many conversations."

—Charles Yu, author of Interior Chinatown

"In a narrative world where the real is growingly more unbelievable than the make believe, Chain-Gang All-Stars is an uncanny, singular feat of literature. I've never read satire so bruising, so brolic, so tender and really, so pitch-perfect. It's nuts brilliant. Just read it!"

—Kiese Laymon, author of Heavy: An American Memoir

title: The Sellout
long_summary:
Born in the "agrarian ghetto" of Dickens on the southern outskirts of Los Angeles, our narrator has resigned himself to a modest fate: dying in the same bedroom where he grew up, staring at ceiling cracks from the '68 earthquake. Raised by a single father—a controversial sociologist—he spent his childhood as a subject in racially charged psychological studies, promised that his father's work would become a lucrative memoir.

But when his father is killed in a police shoot-out, he discovers there never was a memoir. All that's left is the bill for a drive-thru funeral.

Fueled by this betrayal and his hometown's literal erasure from the map (removed to save California embarrassment), he sets out to restore Dickens' identity through the most outrageous means imaginable. Enlisting help from the town's most famous resident—Hominy Jenkins, the last surviving Little Rascal—he reinstates slavery and segregates the local high school, landing himself before the Supreme Court.

Beatty's comic genius challenges every sacred American institution: the Constitution, civil rights, father-son relationships, and that holy grail of racial equality—the black Chinese restaurant.
short_summary: When his California hometown gets erased from the map, a young man decides to restore it through the most provocative means possible: reinstating slavery and segregation. Beatty's satirical masterpiece is both hilarious and devastatingly sharp.
author_bios: Paul Beatty is the author of four novels—The Sellout, Slumberland, Tuff, and The White Boy Shuffle—and two books of poetry: Big Bank Take Little Bank and Joker, Joker, Deuce. He is the editor of Hokum: An Anthology of African-American Humor and lives in New York City.
quotes:
"The first 100 pages of [Paul Beatty's] new novel, The Sellout, are the most caustic and the most badass first 100 pages of an American novel I've read in at least a decade."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"The Sellout isn't just one of the most hilarious American novels in years, it also might be the first truly great satirical novel of the century . . . [It] is a comic masterpiece, but it's much more than just that-it's one of the smartest and most honest reflections on race and identity in America in a very long time."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"[The Sellout] is among the most important and difficult American novels written in the 21st century . . . It is a bruising novel that readers will likely never forget."

—Kiese Laymon, Los Angeles Times

title: Bossypants
long_summary:
Before Liz Lemon, before "Weekend Update," before "Sarah Palin," Tina Fey was just a young girl with a dream: a recurring stress dream that she was being chased through a local airport by her middle-school gym teacher. She also had a dream that one day she would be a comedian on TV. She has seen both these dreams come true.

At last, Tina Fey's story can be told. From her youthful days as a vicious nerd to her tour of duty on Saturday Night Live; from her passionately halfhearted pursuit of physical beauty to her life as a mother eating things off the floor; from her one-sided college romance to her nearly fatal honeymoon.

Tina Fey reveals all, and proves what we've always suspected: you're no one until someone calls you bossy. Includes special, never-before-solicited opinions on breastfeeding, princesses, Photoshop, the electoral process, and Italian rum cake.
short_summary: Tina Fey chronicles her journey from awkward nerd to comedy superstar with trademark wit and self-deprecating humor. Sharp observations on everything from motherhood to show business make this memoir irresistible.
author_bios: Tina Fey lives in Denver with her ferret, Jacoby.
quotes:
"You'd be really pretty if you lost weight."

—College Boyfriend, 1990

"Tina Fey is an ugly, pear-shaped, overrated troll."

—The Internet

"I hope that's not really the cover. That's really going to hurt sales."

—Don Fey, Father of Tina Fey

"Absolutely delicious!"

—A Guy Who Eats Books

"Totally worth it."

—Trees

"Do not print this glowing recommendation of Tina Fey's book until I've been dead a hundred years."

—Mark Twain

title: The MANIAC
long_summary:
Benjamín Labatut's When We Cease to Understand the World electrified readers worldwide, earning Booker Prize and National Book Award nominations. In The MANIAC, Labatut delivers an even more ambitious tour de force.

John von Neumann was a prodigy whose gifts terrified those around him. He transformed every field he touched—inventing game theory and the first programmable computer, pioneering AI, digital life, and cellular automata. Through a chorus of family members, friends, colleagues, and rivals, Labatut traces the evolution of an unmatched mind and a body of work that has fundamentally unmoored our world.

The MANIAC places von Neumann at the center of a literary triptych. It begins with Paul Ehrenfest, an Austrian physicist and friend of Einstein who fell into despair watching science become a tyrannical force. It ends a century later with the showdown between Go master Lee Sedol and the AI program AlphaGo—an encounter embodying the central question of von Neumann's most ambitious unfinished project: creating a self-reproducing machine, an intelligence able to evolve beyond human understanding or control.

A work of beauty and momentum, The MANIAC confronts us with the deepest questions we face as a species.
short_summary: Hungarian polymath John von Neumann invented game theory, built the first programmable computer, and pioneered AI. Labatut's haunting triptych traces how one brilliant mind unleashed forces that continue reshaping our world.
author_bios: Benjamín Labatut is a Chilean author born in the Netherlands in 1980. Raised in The Hague before settling in Chile, he is the author of Antarctica starts here (2009), After the Light (2016), The Stone of Madness (2021), and When We Cease to Understand the World (2021), which has been translated into over thirty languages.
quotes:
"Labatut's latest virtuosic effort, at once a historical novel and a philosophical foray, is a thematic sequel, an exploration of what results when we take reason to even further extremes . . . A contemporary writer of thrilling originality . . . The MANIAC is a work of dark, eerie and singular beauty."

—Becca Rothfeld, The Washington Post

"Labatut elegantly captures the sense of geniuses outstripping the typical boundaries of intellectual achievement and paying a price for it . . . Sharply written fiction ably capturing primitive emotions and boundary-breaking research."

—Kirkus

"After the slender yet incendiary When We Cease to Understand the World, Labatut returns with a sensational epic of the Hungarian American physicist and computer scientist John von Neumann . . . Labatut mesmerizes in his accessible depictions of complex scientific material and in his inspired portraits of the innovators. In his previous book, Labatut grappled with the ways in which scientific breakthroughs offered new means of experiencing reality; this one succeeds at showing how acts of genius might break the world forever. Readers won't be able to turn away."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Empathy Exams
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
Beginning with her experience as a medical actor paid to perform symptoms for student doctors, Leslie Jamison crafts visceral essays that probe essential questions about human connection: How should we care for each other? How can we truly feel another's pain, especially when that pain might be assumed, distorted, or performed?

Drawing from her own experiences of illness and injury, Jamison ventures far beyond personal narrative. She explores poverty tourism and phantom diseases, street violence and reality television, illness and incarceration—all in service of understanding empathy's complexities. Is empathy a tool for genuine connection, or has it become a way to test and grade each other?

Through unflinching examination of pain both real and imagined, Jamison uncovers our cultural urgency to feel. Her search is for a kind of sight shaped by humility and grace, one that might help us navigate the treacherous territory between self and other.
short_summary: Jamison transforms personal experiences with illness and medical role-playing into profound meditations on empathy, pain, and human connection. Intellectually rigorous yet deeply felt.
author_bios: Leslie Jamison is the author of New York Times bestsellers The Recovering and The Empathy Exams, plus the essay collection Make It Scream, Make It Burn, a PEN/Diamonstein-Spielvogel Award finalist, and the novel The Gin Closet, an LA Times Book Prize finalist. A contributing writer for the New York Times Magazine, her work appears in The Atlantic, Harper's, and Virginia Quarterly Review. She teaches at Columbia University and lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"Extraordinary. . . . she calls to mind writers as disparate as Joan Didion and John Jeremiah Sullivan as she interrogates the palpitations of not just her own trippy heart but of all of ours. . . . Her cerebral, witty, multichambered essays tend to swing around to one topic in particular: what we mean when we say we feel someone else's pain. . . . I'm not sure I'm capable of recommending a book because it might make you a better person. But watching the philosopher in Ms. Jamison grapple with empathy is a heart-expanding exercise."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A virtuosic manifesto of human pain. . . . Jamison stitches together the intellectual and the emotional with the finesse of a crackerjack surgeon. . . . The result is a soaring performance on the humanizing effects of empathy."

—NPR

"The Empathy Exams is a work of tremendous pleasure and tremendous pain. Leslie Jamison is so intelligent, so compassionate, and so fiercely, prodigiously brave. This is the essay at its creative, philosophical best."

—Eleanor Catton, author of Birnam Wood & The Luminaries, winner of the 2013 Man Booker Prize

title: Heavy
subtitle: An American Memoir
long_summary:
Kiese Laymon writes with unflinching honesty about growing up as a Black son to a brilliant, complicated mother in Jackson, Mississippi. In Heavy, he charts his complex relationships with family, his body, and a nation obsessed with progress yet unwilling to reckon with its past.

Laymon's memoir spans from early experiences of sexual violence through his suspension from college to his journey as a young professor in New York. He explores his struggles with anorexia, obesity, gambling, and the weight of secrets he and his mother spent years avoiding. This isn't just personal confession—it's an urgent examination of how few people in America actually know how to love responsibly or live with the weight of true freedom.

Defiant yet vulnerable, Heavy combines piercing intellect with raw storytelling. Laymon invites readers to confront uncomfortable truths about identity, family, and what it means to survive in a country that demands both assimilation and authenticity. The result is a memoir that illuminates national failures through deeply personal revelation.
short_summary: Laymon's unflinching memoir examines the weight of family secrets, personal trauma, and survival as a Black man in America. Raw, brilliant, and essential—a reckoning with love, lies, and what freedom actually costs.
author_bios: Born and raised in Jackson, Mississippi, Kiese Laymon is the Ottilie Schillig Professor in English and Creative Writing at the University of Mississippi. He's the author of the novel Long Division, the memoir Heavy, and the essay collection How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America. He was named a 2022 MacArthur Fellow.
quotes:
"Heavy is a gorgeous, gutting book that's fueled by candor yet freighted with ambivalence. It's full of devotion and betrayal, euphoria and anguish, tender embraces and rough abuse…the liberation on offer doesn't feel light and unburdened; it feels heavy like the title, and heavy like the truth…Salvation would feel too weightless—as if [Laymon] could forget who he is and where he has been. This generous, searching book explores all the forces that can stop even the most buoyant hopes from ever leaving the ground."

—The New York Times

"There are those rare writers in the world whose work unearths the stories that have been buried in and around us for so long. They force us to confront all that we would be rather not see, and ask us to reckon with why we have failed to see it for so long. Kiese Laymon is one such rare writer. Heavy is a memoir, yes, but it is also a testament to a sort of truth and self-reflection that is increasingly rare in our world today. If for some reason you were not already convinced, there should no longer be any doubt that Kiese Laymon is one of the important writers of our time."

—Clint Smith, author of How the Word is Passed & Counting Descent

"Heavy is an act of truth telling unlike any other I can think of in American literature, partly due to Laymon's uniquely gifted mind—his ability to pursue the ways we lie to each other while also loving each other, or, not, and the humility he brings to bear while doing so, this consistently brings us back to life, to what matters in this world. Heavy is a gift to us, if we can pick it up—a moral exercise and an intimate history that is at the same time a story about America."

—Alexander Chee, author of How to Write an Autobiographical Novel

title: The Topeka School
long_summary:
Adam Gordon is a senior at Topeka High School, class of '97. His mother Jane is a famous feminist author, his father Jonathan specializes in helping "lost boys" open up—both work at a psychiatric clinic that attracts staff and patients worldwide. Adam is a renowned debater expected to win nationals before college, one of the cool kids ready to fight or freestyle to maintain his reputation.

When Adam and other seniors bring loner Darren Eberheart into their social circle—unaware he's his father's patient—the results are disastrous. Deftly shifting perspectives and time periods, Lerner weaves a story of family struggles and strengths: Jane's reckoning with an abusive father's legacy, Jonathan's marital transgressions, and the challenge of raising a good son in a culture of toxic masculinity.

This is also a riveting prehistory of our present moment—the collapse of public discourse, the rise of trolls and tyrants, and the ongoing crisis of identity among white men.
short_summary: Lerner weaves family drama with cultural prophecy in 1990s Kansas. A story of adolescence and toxic masculinity that traces the roots of our current political moment with devastating precision.
author_bios: Ben Lerner is the author of eight previous books of poetry and prose, plus collaborations with visual artists. A recipient of Fulbright, Guggenheim, and MacArthur fellowships, he's been a National Book Award finalist and Pulitzer Prize finalist. He's Distinguished Professor of English at Brooklyn College.
quotes:
"[An] essayistic and engrossing novel . . . Few writers are so deeply engaged as Lerner in how our interior selves are shaped by memory and consequence . . . Increasingly powerful and heartbreaking as the story moves on. Autofiction at its smartest and most effective: self-interested, self-interrogating, but never self-involved."

—Kirkus

"The Topeka School is [Lerner's] most discerning, ambitious, innovative, and timely novel to date. It's a complete pleasure to read Lerner experimenting with other minds and times, to watch his already profound talent blooming into new subjects, landscapes, and capacities. This book is a prehistory of a deeply disturbing national moment, but it's written with the kind of intelligence, insight, and searching that makes one feel well-accompanied and, in the final hour, deeply inspired."

—Maggie Nelson, author of The Argonauts

"Ben Lerner has redefined what it means for a writer to inhabit an American present by showing how a family reckons with its past. Here the personal and political are masterfully interwoven. The Topeka School is brave, furious, and, finally, a work of love."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous

title: The Country of the Blind
subtitle: A Memoir at the End of Sight
long_summary:
Andrew Leland finds himself suspended between two worlds—caught in the liminal space of the soon-to-be blind. Born with retinitis pigmentosa, a condition that gradually steals sight from the outside in, he's spent decades watching his vision slowly fade since his teenage years. Soon, though he doesn't know exactly when, he will likely have no sight left.

Full of apprehension but driven by curiosity, Leland embarks on an exploration of the state awaiting him—not just the physical reality of blindness, but its rich language, politics, and customs. He navigates shifting relationships with his wife and son while reimagining his sense of self as he moves from mainstream life to one with disability.

Part memoir, part cultural investigation, The Country of the Blind captures Leland's determination not merely to survive this transition but to flourish within it. He seeks out what makes blindness enlightening, discovering an entire world he never knew existed. Brimming with warmth and humor, it's an exhilarating tour of a new way of being.
short_summary: Leland chronicles his gradual transition from sight to blindness with curiosity and humor, discovering blindness as a rich culture with its own language and customs. A revelatory exploration of adaptation, identity, and finding light in unexpected places.
author_bios: Andrew Leland's writing has appeared in The New York Times Magazine, The New Yorker, McSweeney's, The San Francisco Chronicle, and Art in America. From 2013 to 2019, he hosted The Organist podcast for KCRW and has produced for Radiolab and 99% Invisible. He's been an editor at The Believer since 2003 and lives in western Massachusetts.
quotes:
"The Country of the Blind is about seeing—but also about marriage and family and the moral and emotional challenge of accommodating the parts of ourselves that scare us. A warm, profound, and unforgettable meditation on how we adjust to new ways of being in the world."

—Rachel Aviv, author of Strangers to Ourselves

"[Leland's] education in navigating the world without his eyes is an entry point into a fascinating cultural history of blindness. The great strength of this memoir is its voracious, humble curiosity; throughout, Leland treats losing his vision as just as much an opportunity as a foreclosure."

—The Atlantic

"This is such a gorgeous book. Andrew Leland manages to deftly balance the personal, historical and political as he documents—documents is too sterile a word; he gently sings about—his becoming blind. There is a great nonfiction book here about the history of blindness and the pioneers who have built a world of access and empowerment. But crucially, Leland weaves into that larger tapestry the deeply touching story of how he, his wife Lily, and his son Oscar face their myriad new challenges—with open minds and abundant wit, and always fearlessly together."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King, The Circle & A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius

title: Great Circle
long_summary:
After being rescued as infants from a sinking ocean liner in 1914, Marian and Jamie Graves are raised by their dissolute uncle in Missoula, Montana. When a pair of barnstorming pilots pass through town in beat-up biplanes, Marian begins her lifelong love affair with flight.

At fourteen she drops out of school and finds an unexpected patron in a wealthy bootlegger who provides a plane and subsidizes her lessons—an arrangement that will haunt her for the rest of her life, even as it allows her to pursue her destiny: circumnavigating the globe by flying over the North and South Poles.

A century later, Hadley Baxter is cast to play Marian in a film centered on the aviator's disappearance in Antarctica. Vibrant, canny, and disgusted with Hollywood's claustrophobia, Hadley is eager to redefine herself after a romantic film franchise imprisoned her in cult celebrity. Her immersion into Marian's character unfolds alongside Marian's own story, as both women's fates—and their hunger for self-determination across vastly different times and places—collide in this epic, meticulously researched novel.
short_summary: Two women separated by a century share an uncompromising hunger for freedom. Shipstead weaves together the stories of a daredevil 1920s aviator and a modern Hollywood actress with breathtaking skill.
author_bios: Maggie Shipstead is the New York Times-bestselling author of three novels and a short story collection. Great Circle was shortlisted for the Booker Prize and is a finalist for the Women's Prize. She's a graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop, recipient of a National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, and winner of the Dylan Thomas Prize and the L.A. Times Book Prize for First Fiction.
quotes:
"A soaring work of historical fiction . . . So convincingly does Shipstead stitch her fictional heroine into the daring flight paths of early aviators that you'll be convinced that you remember the tragic day her plane disappeared. Great Circle is a relentlessly exciting story about a woman maneuvering her way between tradition and prejudice to get what she wants. It's also a culturally rich story that takes full advantage of its extended length to explore the changing landscape of the 20th century. My top recommendation for this summer."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A feat of a story in every sense."

—Entertainment Weekly

"The destinies of [Shipstead's] unforgettable characters intersect in ways that reverberate through a hundred years of story. Whether Shipstead is creating scenes in the Prohibition-era American West, in wartime London, or on a Hollywood movie set, her research is as invisible as it should be, allowing a fully immersive experience. Ingeniously structured and so damn entertaining; this novel is as ambitious as its heroines—but it never falls from the sky."

—Kirkus

title: The Patriarch
subtitle: The Remarkable Life and Turbulent Times of Joseph P. Kennedy
long_summary:
In this magisterial biography, celebrated historian David Nasaw tells the full story of Joseph P. Kennedy, founder of the twentieth century's most famous political dynasty. As the only biographer granted unrestricted access to Kennedy's papers, Nasaw tracks his astonishing passage from East Boston outsider to supreme Washington insider.

Kennedy's seemingly limitless ambition drove his career to extraordinary heights—banker, World War I shipyard manager, Hollywood studio head, Wall Street operator, New Deal presidential adviser, and founding chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. His astounding fall from grace came during the years surrounding America's entry into World War II, when his antiwar stance as the first Irish American ambassador to London earned him White House ire and popular contempt.

This is also the story of the family Kennedy raised and the children who completed the journey he began. Of his many roles, father was most dear to him, though tragedies would mark his final years with unspeakable suffering.

Drawing on never-before-published materials from archives on three continents, Nasaw answers the haunting questions about Kennedy's life and legacy. In studying Kennedy's story, we relive the history of the American Century itself.
short_summary: The definitive biography of Joseph P. Kennedy, based on exclusive access to his private papers. Nasaw chronicles the patriarch's rise from Boston outsider to Washington insider, and his transformation from New Deal hero to wartime pariah.
author_bios: David Nasaw is a historian, two-time Pulitzer Prize finalist, and bestselling author of The Last Million, The Patriarch (a New York Times Five Best Non-Fiction Books of the Year), Andrew Carnegie (a New York Times Notable Book and winner of the New-York Historical Society's American History Book Prize), and The Chief (winner of the Bancroft Prize). He is Arthur M. Schlesinger, Jr. Professor of History Emeritus at the CUNY Graduate Center and past president of the Society of American Historians.
quotes:
"Riveting… The Patriarch is a book hard to put down…As his son indelibly put it some months before his father was struck down: 'Ask not what your country can do for you – ask what you can do for your county.' One wonders what was going through the mind of the patriarch, sitting a few feet away listening to that soaring sentiment as a fourth-generation Kennedy became president of the United States. After coming to know him over the course of this brilliant, compelling book, the reader might suspect that he was thinking he had done more than enough for his country. But the gods would demand even more."

—Christopher Buckley, The New York Times

"A spellbinding book."

—Slate

"[A] sprawling, highly readable biography of the dynast and larger-than-life figure whose presence still haunts American political life... Working from his subject's extensive archives, Nasaw (Andrew Carnegie, 2006, etc.) pieces together a sometimes-sympathetic, sometimes-critical view of Joseph P. Kennedy (1888–1969), father of John F. Kennedy and most definitely a man of parts... Exhaustive yet accessible, Nasaw's book illuminates."

—Kirkus

title: The Marriage Plot
long_summary:
It's the early 1980s—the country is in recession, and life after college feels impossible. In the cafés on College Hill, the wised-up kids are inhaling Derrida and listening to Talking Heads. But Madeleine Hanna, dutiful English major, is writing her senior thesis on Jane Austen and George Eliot, purveyors of the marriage plot at the heart of the greatest English novels.

As Madeleine questions why it became laughable to read writers like Cheever and Updike in favor of the Marquis de Sade, real life intervenes in the form of two very different guys. Leonard Bankhead—charismatic loner, college Darwinist, and lost Portland boy—suddenly appears in a semiotics seminar, drawing Madeleine into a charged erotic and intellectual relationship. Meanwhile, her old friend Mitchell Grammaticus resurfaces, obsessed with Christian mysticism and convinced that Madeleine is destined to be his mate.

Over the next year, as the triangle graduates and enters the real world, events force them to reevaluate everything they learned in school. Leonard and Madeleine move to a biology lab on Cape Cod, but can't escape the secret behind Leonard's inexhaustible energy and plunging moods. Mitchell travels the world trying to forget Madeleine, only to confront ultimate questions about life, God, and love.

With devastating wit and deep affection for his characters, Eugenides creates a story so contemporary it reads like the intimate journal of our own lives.
short_summary: At Brown in the 1980s, three students navigate love, literature, and post-graduation reality. Eugenides crafts a witty, deeply felt novel that reimagines the classic marriage plot for the modern era.
author_bios: Jeffrey Eugenides was born in Detroit and attended Brown and Stanford Universities. His first novel, The Virgin Suicides, was published to great acclaim in 1993. He received the Pulitzer Prize for Middlesex (2002), which was also a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, the International IMPAC Dublin Literary Award, and France's Prix Médicis. The Marriage Plot (2011) was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist and won both the Prix Fitzgerald and the Madame Figaro Literary Prize. His story collection Fresh Complaint was published in 2017. He is a professor of creative writing at Princeton.
quotes:
"Remind[s] us with uncommon understanding what it is to be young and idealistic, in pursuit of true love, and in love with books and ideas."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Deeply humane and elegantly constructed."

—NPR

"Playful and profound.... A great offering by one of America's best writers."

—Mark Medley, National Post

title: The Son
long_summary:
Part epic of Texas, part classic coming-of-age story, part unflinching portrait of the bloody price of power, The Son maps the legacy of violence in the American West through the lives of the McCulloughs, an ambitious family as resilient and dangerous as the land they claim.

Spring, 1849. Eli McCullough is thirteen when Comanche raiders storm his homestead, brutally murdering his mother and sister and taking him captive. The first male child born in the newly established Republic of Texas, Eli quickly adapts to Comanche life, learning their language, earning a place as the chief's adopted son, and waging war against their enemies—including white men. When disease and overwhelming numbers of armed Americans decimate the tribe, Eli finds himself alone. Neither white nor Indian, he must carve a place in a world where he doesn't fully belong.

Intertwined with Eli's story are those of his son Peter, who bears the emotional cost of his father's ruthless ambition, and JA, Eli's great-granddaughter, who must fight hardened rivals to succeed in a man's world. Meyer deftly explores how Eli's steely pragmatism transforms subsequent generations as the McCulloughs become one of Texas's most powerful ranching-and-oil dynasties. Yet like all empires, they must eventually face the consequences of their choices.
short_summary: Three generations of the McCullough family build a Texas empire through violence and ambition. From Comanche captivity to oil wealth, this multigenerational saga explores the bloody price of power.
author_bios: Philipp Meyer is the author of American Rust, winner of the 2009 Los Angeles Times Book Prize. It was an Economist Book of the Year, a Washington Post Top Ten Book, and a New York Times Notable Book. A Cornell graduate with an MFA from the University of Texas at Austin, where he was a James Michener Fellow, he's a Baltimore native who now lives mostly in Texas.
quotes:
"Sweeping, absorbing epic. . . Meyer's sophomore novel deftly opens with entwined, impending deaths across generations, joining tangled stories over three centuries, the contested line between the U.S. and Mexico, and very different cultures; if sometimes it hints of McMurtry's Lonesome Dove and Ferber's Giant, it more often partakes of the somber, doomed certainty of Faulkner. . . An expertly written tale of ancient crimes, with every period detail-and every detail, period-just right."

—Kirkus

"One of the most solid, unsparing pieces of American historical fiction to come out this century . . . a brilliant chronicle of Texas . . . stunning, raw and epic. . . . The Son is vast, brave and, finally, unstoppable."

—NPR

"The greatest things about The Son are its scope and ambition. . . . It's an enveloping, extremely well-wrought, popular novel with passionate convictions about the people, places and battles that it conjures."

—The New York Times

title: Mother Emanuel
subtitle: Two Centuries of Race, Resistance, and Forgiveness in One Charleston Church
long_summary:
Few people beyond South Carolina's Lowcountry knew of Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church before June 17, 2015, when a white supremacist walked into Bible study and murdered nine worshippers, including the charismatic pastor. Though the shooter targeted Mother Emanuel—the first AME church in the South—hoping to ignite racial strife, he couldn't have anticipated what followed: an outpouring of forgiveness from victims' families and a profound reckoning with Charleston's deep racial divisions.

In Mother Emanuel, Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Kevin Sack explores the inspiring history that brought the church to that tragic moment and the depth of desecration committed in its fellowship hall. He reveals how African Methodism grew from the harshest American soil, and how Black suffering shaped forgiveness into both religious practice and survival tool.

Sack uses the church's story to trace the long arc of Black life in Charleston, where nearly half of enslaved Africans disembarked and the Civil War began. Through one congregation's journey—from its daring 1817 breakaway from white churches, through Civil War and Reconstruction traumas, to its pivotal Civil Rights role—he explores the development of a unique Christian practice. At its core, this is an epic account of perseverance: not just of a congregation, but of a people who withstood enslavement, Jim Crow, and violence with unbending faith.
short_summary: A sweeping history of one of America's most important Black churches and a profound story of courage and grace amid the fight for racial justice.
author_bios: Kevin Sack is a veteran journalist who has written about national affairs for over four decades and has been part of three Pulitzer Prize-winning teams. A Jacksonville native and Duke graduate, he spent thirty years at The New York Times specializing in long-form narrative and investigative reports, often on race. His work has also appeared in the Los Angeles Times, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, and The New York Times Magazine. He was a 2019 Emerson Collective Fellow at New America.
quotes:
"Mother Emanuel is a masterpiece . . . Sack, a former reporter for The New York Times, delivers a dense, rich, captivating narrative, featuring vivid prose, prodigious research and a palpable emotional engagement that is disciplined by a meticulous attention to the facts. His excavation is an essential addition to existing histories and ought to be recognized as a singular journalistic performance."

—The New York Times

"[Mother Emanuel is a] searching history of the Charleston church brought into the headlines by mass murder . . . A sobering, expertly told history of the struggle for equality as waged from pulpit and pew."

—Kirkus Reviews, starred review

"This book shook me with its power and beauty. Mother Emanuel is a book of enormous ambition, meticulously researched, gorgeously written, and deeply fulfilling."

—Jonathan Eig, Pulitzer prize-winning author of King: A Life

title: The Flamethrowers
long_summary:
The year is 1975, and Reno—named for her birthplace—arrives in New York determined to transform her obsession with motorcycles and speed into art. She enters a world exploding with creative energy: artists have colonized the industrial wasteland of SoHo, staging provocative actions in the East Village and erasing boundaries between life and art.

Reno falls in with a circle of dreamers and raconteurs who become her unlikely teachers. Ardent and vulnerable yet fearless, she begins an affair with Sandro Valera, an artist and semi-estranged heir to an Italian tire and motorcycle empire. When they travel to his family home in Italy, Reno becomes entangled with members of the radical movement that consumed Italy in the seventies. Betrayal ultimately pulls her into a dangerous clandestine world.

The Flamethrowers is an electrifying exploration of art, identity, and rebellion. At its heart is Kushner's brilliantly realized protagonist—a young woman balanced on the edge of transformation. Thrilling and fearless, this is a major American novel from a writer of spectacular imagination.
short_summary: Reno arrives in 1975 New York to make art from her obsession with speed and motorcycles. Her affair with an Italian artist leads her from SoHo's exploding art scene to Italy's radical underground.
author_bios: Rachel Kushner is the author of the New York Times bestseller Creation Lake, the acclaimed essay collection The Hard Crowd, and the internationally bestselling novels The Mars Room, The Flamethrowers, and Telex from Cuba. She has won the Prix Médicis, been twice a Booker Prize and National Book Award finalist, and received the Harold D. Vursell Memorial Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. A Guggenheim Fellow, her books have been translated into twenty-seven languages.
quotes:
"Oscillating between the hedonistic New York artworld and Italy in the midst of the Years of Lead, The Flamethrowers is that rare thing, a novel that uses recent history not as a picturesque backdrop, but as a way of interrogating the present. Kushner's urgent prose and psychological acuity make this one of the most compelling and enjoyable novels I've read this year."

—Hari Kunzru, author of White Tears & Gods Without Men

"This rich second novel from Kushner takes place in late-'70s New York City and Italy…Kushner's psychological explorations of her characters are incisive, the novel is peppered with subtle '70s details, and it bursts with you-are-there depictions of its time and places."

—Publishers Weekly

"I loved Rachel Kushner's The Flamethrowers."

—Jonathan Franzen, The New York Times

title: No Visible Bruises
subtitle: What We Don’t Know About Domestic Violence Can Kill Us
long_summary:
We call it domestic violence, private violence, or intimate terrorism. Whatever the name, we generally don't believe it affects us—despite the World Health Organization calling it a "global epidemic." In America, intimate partner violence accounts for 15 percent of all violent crime, yet it remains shrouded in silence, even as its impact reaches into every corner of society: our economy, education system, mass shootings, mass incarceration, and #MeToo.

In No Visible Bruises, journalist Rachel Louise Snyder delivers an urgent investigation into domestic violence's true scope, structured around case studies that shatter common myths. That victims would simply leave if things were bad enough. That violent people can't change. That shelters provide adequate solutions. That home violence exists separately from mass shootings, gang violence, and sexual assault.

Through stories of victims, perpetrators, law enforcement, and reform movements nationwide, Snyder explores domestic violence's real roots, its far-reaching societal consequences, and what genuine solutions require.
short_summary: A devastating investigation into America's domestic violence epidemic that shatters myths and reveals how intimate partner violence connects to broader patterns of societal violence.
author_bios: Rachel Louise Snyder is the author of Fugitive Denim, the novel What We've Lost is Nothing, and No Visible Bruises, a New York Times Top Ten Book of the Year, winner of the J. Anthony Lukas Work-in-Progress Award, the Hillman Prize, and the Helen Bernstein Book Award, and finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, LA Times Book Prize, and Kirkus Award. Her work has appeared in the New Yorker, the New York Times, and Slate. A Guggenheim Fellow, she teaches at American University.
quotes:
"This is terrifying, courageous reportage from our internal war zone, a fair and balanced telling of an unfair and unbalanced crisis in American family life. Snyder writes with stark lucidity and great compassion, and tells stories of utmost urgency with considerable narrative skill."

—Andrew Solomon, National Book Award-winning, bestselling author of Far From the Tree

"A powerful exploration of the sinister, insidious nature of domestic violence in America… Bracing and gut-wrenching, with slivers of hope throughout, this is exemplary, moving reportage on an important subject that often remains in the dark due to shame and/or fear."

—Kirkus

"[A] powerful investigation into intimate partner abuse . . . with closely observed, compassionate portraits of victims, advocates, abusers and police. Penetrating and wise, and written in sometimes novelistic prose, Snyder's sobering analysis will reward readers' attention."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Lab Girl
long_summary:
Acclaimed scientist Hope Jahren has built three laboratories studying trees, flowers, seeds, and soil. Her debut memoir is a revelatory treatise on plant life—but it's also so much more.

Lab Girl weaves together work, love, and the mountains that can be moved when those forces combine. Jahren shares remarkable stories: her childhood in rural Minnesota with an uncompromising mother and a father who encouraged hours of play in his classroom labs; how she found sanctuary in science and learned to perform lab work done "with both the heart and the hands"; and the inevitable disappointments alongside triumphs and exhilarating discoveries of scientific work.

At the book's core is Jahren's relationship with Bill, a brilliant, wounded man who becomes her lab partner and best friend. Their sometimes rogue adventures take them from the Midwest across the United States, over the Atlantic to the ever-light skies of the North Pole, and to tropical Hawaii.

Jahren's insights on plants and astonishing tenacity enliven every page. She opens your eyes to the sophisticated mechanisms within every leaf, blade of grass, and flower petal, while demonstrating what happens when you find the passion and sacrifice needed to make a life from what you truly love.
short_summary: A brilliant memoir weaving together plant science, friendship, and self-discovery. Jahren transforms how you see the natural world while chronicling her journey as a woman in science.
author_bios: Hope Jahren is an award-winning scientist pursuing independent research in paleobiology since 1996. Recognized by Time in 2016 as one of the 100 most influential people in the world, she's received three Fulbright Awards and served as tenured professor at the University of Hawaii from 2008 to 2016, where she built isotope geobiology laboratories. She currently holds the J. Tuzo Wilson professorship at the University of Oslo, Norway.
quotes:
"Some people are great writers, while other people live lives of adventure and importance. Almost no one does both. Hope Jahren does both. She makes me wish I'd been a scientist."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Lab Girl made me look at trees differently. It compelled me to ponder the astonishing grace and gumption of a seed. Perhaps most importantly, it introduced me to a deeply inspiring woman—a scientist so passionate about her work I felt myself vividly with her on every page. This is a smart, enthralling, and winning debut."

—Cheryl Strayed, author of Wild

"Lab Girl surprised, delighted, and moved me. I was drawn in from the start by the clarity and beauty of Jahren's prose, whether she was examining the inner world of a seed,  the ecosystem around the trunk of a tree, or recounting her own inspiring journey. With Lab Girl, Jahren joins those talented scientists who are able to reveal to us the miracle of this world in which we live."

—Abraham Verghese, The Covenant of Water & Cutting for Stone

title: A Constellation of Vital Phenomena
long_summary:
Eight-year-old Havaa wakes to find her house burned and her father taken by federal agents. Hidden in the snowy woods, she's discovered by her neighbor Akhmed, who faces an impossible choice: walking away means safety, but getting involved could cost him his life.

In a village where neighbors become informers for a loaf of bread, Akhmed makes a dangerous decision. He smuggles Havaa through the forest to an abandoned hospital where Sonja Rabina, the sole remaining doctor, treats the wounded. Though Sonja insists her hospital isn't an orphanage, she agrees to keep the child for a trial period.

Over five extraordinary days, these three unlikely companions discover the intricate web of connections binding their pasts together. As Sonja's world shifts on its axis, their intertwined stories reveal how love and compassion can transcend even the brutality of war.
short_summary: When eight-year-old Havaa's father is taken and her house burned, a neighbor risks everything to hide her in an abandoned hospital. A luminous debut about unexpected connections and love's power to transcend brutality.
author_bios: Anthony Marra is the New York Times bestselling author of The Tsar of Love and Techno and A Constellation of Vital Phenomena, winner of the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize and the Anisfield-Wolf Book Award, and longlisted for the National Book Award.
quotes:
"My favorite book of the year....Many people can write beautifully, but few manage to create a whole that is more valuable than the sum of its parts. Marra does this in spades. It is a brilliant book."

—Ann Patchett, New York Times bestselling author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"A Constellation of Vital Phenomena is ambitious and intellectually restless....[Marra is] a lover not a fighter, a prose writer who resembles the Joseph Heller of Catch-22 and the Jonathan Safran Foer of Everything Is Illuminated."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"A flash in the heavens that makes you look up and believe in miracles....Here, in fresh, graceful prose, is a profound story that dares to be as tender as it is ghastly, a story about desperate lives in a remote land that will quickly seem impossibly close and important....I haven't been so overwhelmed by a novel in years. At the risk of raising your expectations too high, I have to say you simply must read this book."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: When Breath Becomes Air
long_summary:
At thirty-six, on the verge of completing a decade of neurosurgical training, Paul Kalanithi was diagnosed with stage IV lung cancer. One day he was a doctor treating the dying; the next, a patient struggling to live. The future he and his wife had imagined suddenly evaporated.

When Breath Becomes Air chronicles Kalanithi's transformation from a medical student possessed by questions of what makes life virtuous and meaningful, to a Stanford neurosurgeon working in the brain—the most critical place for human identity—and finally to a patient and new father confronting his own mortality.

What makes life worth living in the face of death? What do you do when the future flattens from a ladder toward goals into a perpetual present? What does it mean to nurture new life as another fades away?

Kalanithi died in March 2015 while working on this book, yet his words endure as both guide and gift. This unforgettable memoir reflects on facing death and the relationship between doctor and patient, from a brilliant writer who became both.
short_summary: A neurosurgeon facing terminal cancer at thirty-six grapples with mortality, meaning, and new fatherhood. Kalanithi's luminous prose transforms devastating circumstances into profound meditation on what makes life worth living.
author_bios: Paul Kalanithi was a neurosurgeon and writer who grew up in Kingman, Arizona. He graduated from Stanford University with degrees in English literature and human biology, earned an MPhil in history and philosophy of science from Cambridge, and graduated cum laude from Yale School of Medicine. He completed his neurosurgical residency and postdoctoral fellowship at Stanford, receiving the American Academy of Neurological Surgery's highest research award. He died in March 2015, survived by his wife Lucy and daughter Elizabeth Acadia.
quotes:
"I guarantee that finishing this book and then forgetting about it is simply not an option. . . . Part of this book's tremendous impact comes from the obvious fact that its author was such a brilliant polymath. None of it is maudlin. Nothing is exaggerated. As he wrote to a friend: 'It's just tragic enough and just imaginable enough.' And just important enough to be unmissable."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Paul Kalanithi's memoir, When Breath Becomes Air, written as he faced a terminal cancer diagnosis, is inherently sad. But it's an emotional investment well worth making: a moving and thoughtful memoir of family, medicine and literature. It is, despite its grim undertone, accidentally inspiring."

—The Washington Post

"Kalanithi uses the pages in this book to not only tell his story, but also share his ideas on how to approach death with grace and what it means to be fully alive."

—James Clear, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Atomic Habits

title: The Good Lord Bird
long_summary:
Henry Shackleford is a young slave living in the Kansas Territory in 1856—a battleground between anti- and pro-slavery forces—when legendary abolitionist John Brown arrives. When an argument between Brown and Henry's master turns violent, Henry is forced to leave town along with Brown, who believes Henry to be a girl and his good luck charm.

Over the ensuing months, Henry, whom Brown nicknames Little Onion, conceals his true identity to stay alive. Eventually Brown sweeps him into the historic raid on Harpers Ferry in 1859—one of the great catalysts for the Civil War.

An absorbing mixture of history and imagination, told with McBride's meticulous eye for detail and character, The Good Lord Bird is both a rousing adventure and a moving exploration of identity and survival.
short_summary: A young enslaved boy gets swept into John Brown's antislavery crusade and must pass as a girl to survive. McBride transforms a pivotal moment in American history into an unforgettable story of identity and resilience.
author_bios: James McBride is the author of the bestselling The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store, Oprah's Book Club selection Deacon King Kong, National Book Award-winning The Good Lord Bird, the classic The Color of Water, novels Song Yet Sung and Miracle at St. Anna, story collection Five-Carat Soul, and Kill 'Em and Leave. Recipient of a National Humanities Medal and accomplished musician, McBride is distinguished writer in residence at New York University.
quotes:
"You may know the story of John Brown's unsuccessful raid on Harpers Ferry, but author James McBride's retelling of the events leading up to it is so imaginative, you'll race to the finish."

—NPR

"A boisterous, highly entertaining, altogether original novel ...There is something deeply humane in this [story], something akin to the work of Homer or Mark Twain."

—The Washington Post

"The Good Lord Bird is just so brilliant. It had everything I want in a novel and left me feeling both transported and transformed."

—John Green

title: Traveling
subtitle: On the Path of Joni Mitchell
long_summary:
For decades, Joni Mitchell has enraptured listeners as one of the most celebrated artists of her generation. She's inspired countless musicians—from James Taylor to Prince to Brandi Carlile—yet she remains tantalizingly elusive, beckoning us closer while simultaneously pushing us away. Music critic Ann Powers wondered if there was another way to understand this singular artist who never stops moving, never stops experimenting.

In Traveling, Powers seeks to understand Mitchell through her myriad journeys. Through extensive interviews and deep archival research, she takes readers to rural Canada, mapping Mitchell's childhood battle with polio. She charts the course of Mitchell's musical evolution from early folk to jazz fusion to pop experimentation, following her collaborations with other greats and the loves that emerged along the way—all through to Mitchell's remarkable return to music-making after the 2015 aneurysm that nearly took her life.

Powers' wide-ranging exploration reconsiders the biographer's role and how it intertwines with the reality of being a fan, illustrating the ultimate contradiction of celebrity: that an icon cannot truly, completely be known. Kaleidoscopic in scope and intimate in detail, Traveling is a fresh addition to the Joni Mitchell canon.
short_summary: Music critic Ann Powers traces Joni Mitchell's artistic evolution through her literal and metaphorical journeys. A kaleidoscopic biography that captures the restless spirit of its elusive subject.
author_bios: Ann Powers has been a music critic for over thirty years, working for NPR, the Los Angeles Times, the New York Times, and other publications. At NPR, she writes extensively on music and culture and appears regularly on All Songs Considered and news shows including All Things Considered and Morning Edition. Her books include memoir Weird Like Us: My Bohemian America; Good Booty: Love and Sex, Black and White, Body and Soul in American Music; and Piece by Piece with Tori Amos. Powers lives in Nashville.
quotes:
"Brilliant and layer book...A full and generous examination of a life that feels rich, caring, done with an investment that can only come from being heolden enough to an artist and their work..."

—Hanif Abdurraqib, author of There's Always This Year & A Little Devil in America

"Remarkably insightful … Powers proves an adroit codebreaker for the uniquely complex cross-pollination of romantic ennui, class consciousness, spiritual striving and occasional narcissism that characterizes the full sweep of the Joni Mitchell enterprise."

—The Washington Post

"A vibrant critical assessment of the eclectic and enigmatic folk/jazz/pop icon...Those simply looking for loving commentaries on Mitchell classics like Blue will find them, but Powers offers more than mere hagiography, positioning Mitchell as 'an embodiment of freedom and singularity, of sorrow and of play.' A top-notch music critic set loose on a worthy subject."

—Kirkus

title: Fates and Furies
long_summary:
Every marriage has two sides, and sometimes the key to lasting love isn't truth—it's secrets.

At twenty-two, Lotto and Mathilde are tall, glamorous, madly in love, and destined for greatness. Their whirlwind romance captivates everyone around them, and a decade later, their marriage remains the envy of their friends.

But Lauren Groff's masterful novel reveals that things are far more complicated and remarkable than they appear. Following this couple over twenty-four years, Fates and Furies becomes a dazzling examination of marriage, creative partnership, and the stories we tell ourselves about love.

With stunning revelations and multiple narrative threads, Groff delivers a deeply satisfying exploration of art, creativity, and power. Her prose is vibrantly alive and original, creating a portrait of a relationship that defies expectation at every turn. Profound, surprising, and emotionally riveting, this is a novel about the myths we create around love—and the electric thrill of discovering what lies beneath.
short_summary: Twenty-four years of marriage unfold in two acts, revealing that every love story has hidden depths. Groff's dazzling novel explores the secrets that sustain relationships and the myths we build around love.
author_bios: Lauren Groff is a three-time National Book Award finalist and New York Times bestselling author of the novels The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, and the short story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. She has won The Story Prize, the ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Her work appears regularly in The New Yorker and The Atlantic and has been translated into thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband own the independent bookstore The Lynx.
quotes:
"One of the pleasures of reading Ms. Groff is her sheer unpredictability: She can inject her narrator's voice at any time, turn a sentence into a small hurricane."

—The New York Times

"Even from her impossibly high starting point, Lauren Groff just keeps getting better and better. Fates and Furies is a clear-the-ground triumph."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Fates and Furies is a dazzling novel, its people and its prose wondrously alive from page one. At once intimate and sweeping, this is the story of a marriage as parallel myths— flaring with passion and betrayal, with redemption and retribution, with the sort of heart-breaking, head-slapping secrets that make you want to seek out someone else who's read it. Lauren Groff is a powerful and graceful writer, one of the best of her generation."

—Jess Walter, New York Times-bestselling author of Beautiful Ruins

title: How to Say Babylon
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Throughout her childhood, Safiya Sinclair's father—a volatile reggae musician and militant Rastafarian—became obsessed with protecting his daughters from what Rastas call Babylon: the corrupting influences of the Western world. He believed womanhood would make them morally weak and impure, that a woman's highest virtue was obedience.

To keep Babylon at bay, he forbade almost everything. The women wore only long skirts and dresses, head wraps to cover their hair, no makeup, no jewelry. No opinions, no friends. Safiya's mother, while loyal to her husband, secretly gave her children the gift of books and poetry, which became Safiya's lifeline.

As Safiya watched her mother struggle voicelessly under housework and rigid beliefs, she used education as a tool to find her voice and break free. Her growing rebellion sparked increasingly violent clashes with her father, whose rage and paranoia knew no bounds.

How to Say Babylon is Sinclair's reckoning with the culture that nourished but ultimately sought to silence her. Written with the rich lyricism only a poet could evoke, it's both a universal story of a woman claiming her power and a rare glimpse into the world of Rastafari.
short_summary: Growing up under her militant Rastafarian father's oppressive control in Jamaica, Sinclair used poetry and education to break free from patriarchal traditions. A lyrical memoir about finding voice and power.
author_bios: Safiya Sinclair was born and raised in Montego Bay, Jamaica. Her memoir How to Say Babylon won the National Book Critics Circle Award and was named one of the best books of 2023 by The New York Times, The Washington Post, TIME, and The Atlantic. A finalist for the Women's Prize in Nonfiction, the OCM Bocas Prize, and the Kirkus Prize, it was also a Read with Jenna/TODAY book club pick and one of President Barack Obama's favorite books of the year.
quotes:
"An essential memoir. Sinclair's devotion to language has been lifelong, and How to Say Babylon is the result. This book is lit from the inside by Sinclair's determination to learn and live freely, and to see her beloveds freed, too."

—Jesmyn Ward, author of Sing, Unburied Sing, Men We Reaped & Let Us Descend

"When a gifted poet applies her hand to prose, magical, even revelatory things can result. Happily, this is the case with Safiya Sinclair. In this lyrical, startling, and magnetic memoir about growing up Rastafari, she weaves a story rich in unsettling visions that goad and haunt while waves crest and soar in the background, beckoning a young girl toward a mysterious future. Her words sparkle like silver or pour like lava, depending on the need."

—Jabari Asim, author of Yonder

"Dazzling. Potent. Vital. A light shining on the path of self-deliverance."

—Tara Westover, author of Educated

title: Klara and the Sun
long_summary:
Klara is an Artificial Friend with exceptional observational abilities who watches the world from her place in a store window. She carefully studies the customers who browse inside and the people who pass by on the street, remaining hopeful that someone will choose her.

When she's finally selected to be a companion for a teenage girl, Klara enters a complex human world filled with love, loss, and difficult choices. Through her unique perspective—both deeply empathetic and refreshingly naive—she navigates family dynamics, witnesses the bonds between humans, and grapples with questions about devotion and sacrifice.

Ishiguro crafts a quietly devastating exploration of what it means to love and be loved. Klara's voice is both innocent and wise, offering a fresh lens through which to examine our changing world and the fundamental connections that define us.
short_summary: Through the eyes of an Artificial Friend devoted to her human child, Ishiguro explores love, sacrifice, and connection. Klara's innocent yet wise perspective creates a quietly devastating meditation on what makes us human.
author_bios: Kazuo Ishiguro was born in Nagasaki in 1954 and moved to Britain at age five. His eight previous works have earned him the Nobel Prize in Literature and the Booker Prize. The Remains of the Day and Never Let Me Go have each sold over 2 million copies and been adapted into acclaimed films. He received a knighthood in 2018 for Services to Literature.
quotes:
"There is something so steady and beautiful about the way Klara is always approaching connection, like a Zeno's arrow of the heart. People will absolutely love this book, in part because it enacts the way we learn how to love. Klara and the Sun is wise like a child who decides, just for a little while, to love their doll. "What can children know about genuine love?" Klara asks. The answer, of course, is everything."

—Anne Enright, The Guardian

"One of the most affecting and profound novels Ishiguro has written….I'll go for broke and call Klara and the Sun a masterpiece that will make you think about life, mortality, the saving grace of love: in short, the all of it."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"What stays with you in 'Klara and the Sun' is the haunting narrative voice—a genuinely innocent, egoless perspective on the strange behavior of humans obsessed and wounded by power, status and fear."

—The Booker Prize committee

title: The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store
long_summary:
In 1972, construction workers in Pottstown, Pennsylvania, discover a skeleton at the bottom of a well—a grim reminder of secrets long buried by the residents of Chicken Hill, a struggling neighborhood where immigrant Jews and African Americans lived side by side.

Chicken Hill was home to Moshe and Chona Ludlow—he ran an integrated theater, she operated the Heaven & Earth Grocery Store. When the state threatened to institutionalize a deaf boy, Chona partnered with Nate Timblin, the Black janitor at Moshe's theater and unofficial leader of the neighborhood's Black community, to keep the child safe.

As these interconnected stories unfold, McBride reveals how people living on the margins of white, Christian America fight to survive and protect each other. When the truth finally emerges about what happened on Chicken Hill—and the role the town's white establishment played—we see that even in the darkest times, love and community sustain us. McBride brings his masterful storytelling and deep faith in humanity to create a novel as compassionate as it is revelatory.
short_summary: When construction workers discover a skeleton in 1972, the secrets of Chicken Hill—a neighborhood where Jewish immigrants and African Americans lived side by side—begin to surface. McBride weaves a powerful story about community, survival, and the bonds that sustain us.
author_bios: James McBride is the author of the bestselling The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store, Oprah's Book Club selection Deacon King Kong, National Book Award-winning The Good Lord Bird, the classic The Color of Water, novels Song Yet Sung and Miracle at St. Anna, story collection Five-Carat Soul, and Kill 'Em and Leave. Recipient of a National Humanities Medal and accomplished musician, McBride is distinguished writer in residence at New York University.
quotes:
"I keep thinking every time I read one of his books, 'That's his best book.' No. THIS is his best book."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Classic McBride: He doesn't shy away from bold statements about the national catastrophes of race and xenophobia, and he always gives us a spoonful of sugar to help the medicine go down. The sugar is McBride's spitfire dialogue and murder-mystery-worthy plot machinations; his characters' big personalities and bigger storylines; his wisecracking, fast-talking humor; and prose so agile and exuberant that reading him is like being at a jazz jam session. . . . Reading McBride just feels good—we are comforted and entertained, and braced for the hard lessons he also delivers."

—The Atlantic

"The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store is one of the best novels I've read this year. It pulls off the singular magic trick of being simultaneously flattening and uplifting."

—NPR

title: How the Word Is Passed
subtitle: A Reckoning with the History of Slavery Across America
long_summary:
Beginning in his hometown of New Orleans, Clint Smith leads readers on an unforgettable tour of monuments and landmarks that offer an intergenerational story of how slavery has shaped our nation's collective history.

It's the story of Monticello Plantation, where Thomas Jefferson wrote letters espousing liberty while enslaving more than four hundred people. It's the story of the Whitney Plantation, one of the only former plantations devoted to preserving the experience of the enslaved people whose lives and work sustained it. It's the story of Angola, a former plantation turned maximum-security prison in Louisiana, filled with Black men who work across 18,000 acres for virtually no pay. And it's the story of Blandford Cemetery, final resting place of tens of thousands of Confederate soldiers.

This deeply researched exploration reveals how some of our country's most essential stories hide in plain view—in places we drive by on our way to work, holidays like Juneteenth, or neighborhoods like downtown Manhattan, where the brutal history of the slave trade has been deeply imprinted. Informed by scholarship and brought to life through the stories of people living today, Smith's debut offers a new understanding of the hopeful role that memory and history can play in making sense of our country.
short_summary: Smith journeys from Monticello to Angola Prison, revealing how slavery's legacy hides in plain sight across America. A poet's soul meets an educator's heart in this essential exploration of memory and history.
author_bios: Clint Smith is a staff writer at The Atlantic and author of How the Word Is Passed: A Reckoning With the History of Slavery Across America, a #1 New York Times bestseller that won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Nonfiction and the Hillman Prize for Book Journalism. His poetry collection Counting Descent won the 2017 Literary Award for Best Poetry Book from the Black Caucus of the American Library Association. His writing appears in The New Yorker, The New York Times Magazine, Poetry Magazine, and The Paris Review. He holds a B.A. from Davidson College and Ph.D. from Harvard University.
quotes:
"Raises questions that we must all address, without recourse to wishful thinking or the collective ignorance and willful denial that fuels white supremacy."

—Martha Anne Toll, The Washington Post

"The detail and depth of the storytelling is vivid and visceral, making history present and real. Equally commendable is the care and compassion shown to those Smith interviews — whether tour guides or fellow visitors in these many spaces. Due to his care as an interviewer, the responses Smith elicits are resonant and powerful. . . . Smith deftly connects the past, hiding in plain sight, with today's lingering effects."

—Hope Wabuke, NPR

"The power of an itinerant narrator—Smith journeys to Monticello, Angola Prison, Blandford Cemetery, and downtown Manhattan—is that it reveals slavery's expansive, geographical legacy. Smith tells his stories with the soul of a poet and the heart of an educator."

—The Millions

title: Fosse
long_summary:
More than a quarter-century after his death, Bob Fosse's fingerprints on popular culture remain indelible. The only person ever to win Oscar, Emmy, and Tony awards in the same year, Fosse revolutionized nearly every facet of American entertainment, forever marking Broadway and Hollywood with his iconic style—hat tilted, fingers splayed—that would influence generations of performing artists.

Yet despite Fosse's innumerable achievements, no accomplishment ever seemed to satisfy him, and offstage his life was shadowed in turmoil and anxiety. Bestselling author Sam Wasson unveils the man behind the swaggering sex appeal, tracing Fosse's untold reinventions over a career that spawned The Pajama Game, Cabaret, Pippin, All That Jazz, and Chicago, one of the longest-running Broadway musicals ever.

Drawing on unpublished material and hundreds of sources—friends, enemies, lovers, and collaborators, many speaking publicly about Fosse for the first time—Wasson illuminates both Fosse's prodigious professional life and his close, conflicted relationships with everyone from Liza Minnelli to Ann Reinking to Jessica Lange and Dustin Hoffman. This sweeping biography reveals the deep wounds that propelled Fosse's insatiable appetites for spotlights, women, and life itself.
short_summary: Behind the jazz hands and razzle-dazzle lay profound insecurity and relentless ambition. Wasson's definitive biography captures the contradictions of the only artist to win Oscar, Emmy, and Tony in one year.
author_bios: Sam Wasson is the author of seven books on film, including the New York Times bestsellers Fifth Avenue, 5 A.M.: Audrey Hepburn, Breakfast at Tiffany's, and the Dawn of the Modern American Woman; The Big Goodbye: Chinatown and the Last Years of Hollywood; and Fosse. With Jeanine Basinger, he is the coauthor of Hollywood: The Oral History. He lives in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"Mr. Wasson is a smart and savvy reporter, and his book abounds with colorful firsthand tales—required reading for anyone eager to understand his brand of — to use a term that appears here constantly, and can't be outdone — razzle-dazzle."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Scintillating . . . There's an enormous amount of scholarship here, yet the story never drags, so adroitly does [Wasson] blend his material into a fluent narrative around evocative scenes where character emerges novelistically."

—Publishers Weekly

"He thought he was the best, and he thought he was terrible. The man in question is legendary choreographer and director Bob Fosse, whose celebrated life and career get their due in Sam Wasson's spellbinding 695-page biography, Fosse. You don't need to be a Broadway expert to enjoy this portrait of a man whose rise to power was famously fueled by insecurity. It's all here: accounts of his monstrous, masterful directing style; the explosive personal battles behind his Tony-winning triumphs; his incendiary relationship with Gwen Verdon. Wasson simply doesn't miss a thing. Give the guy a (jazz) hand."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Birnam Wood
long_summary:
A landslide has cut off the town of Thorndike on New Zealand's South Island, leaving a sizable farm abandoned. For Birnam Wood—an undeclared guerrilla gardening collective that plants crops wherever no one will notice—this disaster presents an opportunity. The group has struggled financially for years, and occupying the farm could finally mean solvency.

But enigmatic American billionaire Robert Lemoine also has designs on the property. He's bought it to build his end-times bunker, or so he tells Birnam's founder, Mira, when he catches her trespassing. Intrigued by both Mira and her collective, Lemoine suggests an unlikely alliance. Though they're poles apart politically, it seems they might have enemies in common.

But can Birnam trust him? And as their ideals are tested, can they trust one another? A gripping psychological thriller from the Booker Prize-winning author of The Luminaries, Birnam Wood is Shakespearean in its drama and fascinated by what drives us to survive.
short_summary: When a landslide cuts off a New Zealand town, a guerrilla gardening collective sees opportunity—but so does a mysterious billionaire. Catton crafts a brilliant psychological thriller about idealism, survival, and the costs of compromise.
author_bios: Eleanor Catton is the author of the international bestseller The Luminaries, winner of the Man Booker Prize and a Governor General's Literary Award. Her debut novel, The Rehearsal, won the Betty Trask Award and was short-listed for the Guardian First Book Award and the Dylan Thomas Prize. She also wrote the screenplay for the 2020 film adaptation of Emma. Born in Canada and raised in New Zealand, she lives in Cambridge, England.
quotes:
"A generational cri de coeur . . . A sophisticated page-turner . . . Birnam Wood nearly made me laugh with pleasure. The whole thing crackles . . . Greta Gerwig could film this novel, but so could Quentin Tarantino."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Birnam Wood is terrific. As a multilayered, character-driven thriller, it's as good as it gets. Ruth Rendell would have loved it. A beautifully textured work—what a treat."

—Stephen King

"Dark in both its outlook and omnipresent humor . . . A sincere interrogation of the relationship between morality and the ability to bring about positive change."

—Lily Meyer, The Atlantic

title: G-Man
subtitle: J. Edgar Hoover and the Making of the American Century
long_summary:
We remember J. Edgar Hoover as a bulldog—squat frame, bulging eyes, fearsome jowls—but in 1924, when he became FBI director, he was the trim, dazzling wunderkind of the administrative state. He transformed a scandal-riddled law enforcement backwater into a modern machine, believing in the federal government's power to do great things for the nation.

He also believed that certain people—many of them communists or racial minorities—didn't deserve to be included in that American project. Hoover rose to power and stayed there for decades, using state tools to create a personal fiefdom unrivaled in U.S. history.

Beverly Gage's monumental biography explores the full sweep of Hoover's life, from his 1895 birth to a modest Washington family through his 1972 death. Her nuanced portrait reveals how Hoover was more than a one-dimensional tyrant. As FBI director for 48 years, he was confidant, counselor, and adversary to eight presidents. He wasn't above blackmail and intimidation, but he also embodied conservative values that garnered him millions of admirers.

G-Man places Hoover at the center of American political history and uses his story to explain the trajectories of governance, policing, race, and federal power throughout the twentieth century.
short_summary: Beverly Gage's monumental biography draws from never-before-seen sources to reveal how J. Edgar Hoover dominated half a century of American history and planted seeds for today's conservative political landscape.
author_bios: Beverly Gage teaches American history at Yale. Her book G-Man: J. Edgar Hoover and the Making of the American Century received the 2023 Pulitzer Prize for Biography, the Bancroft Prize in American History, the National Book Critics Circle Award for Biography, and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize in Biography.
