She's also author of The Day Wall Street Exploded: A Story of America in its First Age of Terror, and writes for The New Yorker, The New York Times, and The Washington Post.
quotes:
"What hath Hoover wrought? No one has answered that question as exhaustively or as astutely as the inimitable Beverly Gage. Hoover, at long last, has met his match. G-Man is unflinching, incisive, and riveting, part biography, part political thriller, and much more: an essential new history of twentieth-century America."

—Jill Lepore, author of Book of Ages & These Truths: A History of the United States

"Gage's penetrating account of Hoover's career, especially his many long-eclipsed triumphs, offers a well-timed and sobering perspective as yet another institution in our fractured country struggles to maintain trust."

—The Atlantic

"Revelatory...an acknowledgment of the complexities that made Hoover who he was, while charging the turbulent currents that eventually swept him aside."

—The New York Times

title: A Guardian and a Thief
long_summary:
In a near-future Kolkata, Ma, her two-year-old daughter, and her elderly father are just days from leaving the collapsing city behind to join Ma's husband in Ann Arbor, Michigan. After procuring long-awaited visas from the consulate, they pack their bags for the flight to America. But in the morning they awaken to discover that Ma's purse, containing their treasured immigration documents, has been stolen.

Set over the course of one week, A Guardian and a Thief tells two stories: Ma's frantic search for the thief while keeping hunger at bay during a worsening food shortage; and the story of Boomba, the thief, whose desperation to care for his family drives him to commit escalating crimes whose consequences he cannot fathom.

With stunning control, Majumdar paints a kaleidoscopic portrait of two families, each operating from a place of ferocious love and undefeated hope, each discovering how far they will go to secure their children's future as catastrophe encroaches.
short_summary: Two families in a collapsing near-future Kolkata battle each other while trying to protect their children. Majumdar's taut, propulsive novel explores how desperation transforms ordinary people into both victims and perpetrators.
author_bios: Megha Majumdar is the author of the New York Times bestselling novel A Burning, which was nominated for the National Book Award, the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize, and the American Library Association's Andrew Carnegie Medal. It was named one of the best books of the year by The Washington Post, The New York Times, NPR, The Atlantic, Vogue, and TIME Magazine. A 2022 Whiting Award winner, she was born in Kolkata, India, and holds degrees from Harvard and Johns Hopkins. She lives in New York.
quotes:
"Wondering if there's a novel out there that gives Cormac McCarthy's The Road a run for its money? Here you go."

—Stacy Schiff, author of Cleopatra: A Life

"[A Guardian and a Thief] is a perfect novel: 200 pages of tightly honed panic about life in a collapsing society. . . . The book's simple structure feels reminiscent of a fairy tale, which helps account for the deep, visceral terror the story generates."

—The Washington Post

"A mesmerizing morality play that demonstrates how categories like 'victim' and 'thief' collapse under conditions of scarcity."

—The Atlantic

title: Detransition, Baby
long_summary:
Reese almost had it all: a loving relationship with Amy, an apartment in New York City, a job she didn't hate. She had scraped together what previous generations of trans women could only dream of—a life of mundane, bourgeois comforts. The only thing missing was a child.

But then her girlfriend, Amy, detransitioned and became Ames, and everything fell apart. Now Reese is caught in a self-destructive pattern, avoiding her loneliness by sleeping with married men.

Ames isn't happy either. He thought detransitioning would make life easier, but that decision cost him his relationship with Reese—and losing her meant losing his only family. When Ames's boss and lover, Katrina, reveals she's pregnant with his baby, he wonders if this is his chance. Could the three of them form some kind of unconventional family?

This provocative debut explores the emotional, messy, vulnerable corners of womanhood that platitudes can't reach. Peters brilliantly navigates the most dangerous taboos around gender, sex, and relationships, delivering a thrillingly original and deeply moving novel.
short_summary: Three women—transgender and cisgender—find their lives colliding when an unexpected pregnancy forces them to confront their deepest desires for family, love, and belonging.
author_bios: Torrey Peters is the author of the bestselling novel Detransition, Baby, which won the PEN/Hemingway Award for Debut Novel and was named one of the 100 Best Books of the 21st Century by The New York Times. She rides a pink motorcycle and splits her time between Brooklyn and an off-grid cabin in Vermont.
quotes:
"Detransition, Baby is so good I want to scream."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of In the Dream House & Her Body & Other Parties

"[Detransition, Baby] is going to play a role in defining the literature of 2021 and beyond."

—The Millions

"A tale of love, loss, and self-discovery as singular as it is universal, and all the sweeter for it."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: When the Clock Broke
subtitle: Con Men, Conspiracists, and How America Cracked Up in the Early 1990s
long_summary:
With the Soviet Union extinct and U.S. power at its zenith, the early 1990s promised a "kinder, gentler America." Instead, it was a period of rising anger and domestic turmoil that anticipated the polarization and extremism we know today.

In When the Clock Broke, acclaimed political writer John Ganz tells the story of America's late-century discontents. From upheavals in Crown Heights and Los Angeles to the advent of David Duke and heartland survivalists, from Rush Limbaugh's broadcasts to bitter disputes between neoconservatives and the "paleo-con" right, Ganz immerses us in a time when what Philip Roth called the "indigenous American berserk" took new and wilder forms.

During the 1992 campaign, Pat Buchanan's and Ross Perot's insurgent populist bids upended the political establishment while Americans struggled through recession, alarm about racial and social change, the specter of a new power in Asia, and the end of Cold War–era political norms. Conspiracy theories surged as intellectuals and activists strove to understand the "Middle American Radicals" whose alienation fueled new causes. Meanwhile, Bill Clinton appeared to forge a vital new center, though it wouldn't hold for long.

In this rollicking, eye-opening book, Ganz narrates the fall of the Reagan order and the rise of a more turbulent America.
short_summary: Political writer John Ganz excavates the forgotten convulsions of the early 1990s—from Crown Heights to Pat Buchanan's insurgency—revealing how America's current polarization began when the Reagan order collapsed.
author_bios: John Ganz writes the widely acclaimed Unpopular Front newsletter for Substack. His work has appeared in The Washington Post, Artforum, the New Statesman, and other publications.
quotes:
"[A] terrific new book . . . Vibrant . . . [Ganz] has the skills of a gifted storyteller-one with excellent comedic timing, too-slipping in the most absurd and telling details . . . Urgent and illuminating . . . Like the cultural moment he covers, Ganz gets energized by mixing high and low. When the Clock Broke is one of those rarest of books: unflaggingly entertaining while never losing sight of its moral core."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"A searching history of a time, not so long ago, when the social contract went out the window and Hobbesian war beset America . . . Ganz makes a convincing, well-documented case that everything old is indeed new again. A significant, provocative work."

—Kirkus

"Lucid and propulsive . . . [When the Clock Broke is] woven throughout with astute analysis of the period's political commentary . . . Ganz's dry wit is ever-present . . . This is a revelation."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Hemingway's Boat
subtitle: Everything He Loved in Life, and Lost, 1934-1961
long_summary:
Focusing on the years 1934 to 1961—from Hemingway's pinnacle as the reigning monarch of American letters until his suicide—Paul Hendrickson traces the writer's exultations and despair around the one constant in his life: his beloved boat, Pilar.

We follow him from Key West to Paris, to New York, Africa, Cuba, and finally Idaho, as he wrestles with his best angels and worst demons. Whenever he could, he returned to his beloved fishing cruiser to exult in the sea, fight the biggest fish he could find, drink, entertain celebrities and seduce women, and be with his children. But as he began to succumb to the diseases of fame, Pilar was also where he cursed his critics, saw marriages and friendships dissolve, and tried in vain to escape his increasingly diminished capacities.

Generally thought of as a great writer and an unappealing human being, Hemingway emerges here in a far more benevolent light. Drawing on previously unpublished material, including interviews with Hemingway's sons, Hendrickson shows that for all the writer's boorishness, depression, and alcoholism, he was capable of remarkable generosity—to struggling writers, to lost souls, to the dying son of a friend.

Most poignantly, we see his relationship with his youngest son, Gigi, who lived his adult life mostly as a cross-dresser and died alone in a Miami women's jail. Hendrickson's bold and beautiful book makes the case that both men were braver than we know, struggling against the complicated emotions swirling around them.
short_summary: Using Hemingway's beloved boat Pilar as an anchor point, Hendrickson traces the writer's final decades with remarkable nuance. Drawing on unpublished material, this biography reveals unexpected generosity beneath the familiar boorishness and cruelty.
author_bios: Paul Hendrickson is a three-time National Book Critics Circle Award finalist and winner in 2003 for Sons of Mississippi. The Living and the Dead was a 1996 National Book Award finalist. Hemingway's Boat was a New York Times bestseller. He has received fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation, National Endowment for the Arts, Lyndhurst Foundation, and Alicia Patterson Foundation. Since 1998, he has taught in the Creative Writing Program at the University of Pennsylvania. He lives with his wife, Cecilia, outside Philadelphia and in Washington, DC.
quotes:
"Large-minded [and] rigorously fair…An indispensable document…With this sterling summation of the entire Hemingway canon, Hendrickson shows what has eluded some very able scholars. A writer's life can contain two conflicting existences, one of purely original genius and one of irreversible destructiveness. It's a lucky genius who gets credit for the first and a free pass on the second. Hendrickson issues no free pass to Papa. He gives the ravaged old man something more honest: a fair summing-up of a life like no other."

—Howell Raines, The Washington Post

"Splendid…A moving, highly evocative account…Seven years in the making, this vivid portrait allows us to see Hemingway on the Pilar once again, standing on the flying bridge and guiding her out of the harbor at sunrise. Appearing on the 50th anniversary of Hemingway's death, this beautifully written, nuanced meditation deserves a wide audience."

—Kirkus

"Admirably absorbing, important, and moving…Poignant…Acutely sensitive to his subject's volatile, 'gratuitously mean' personality, Hendrickson offers fascinating details and sheds new light on Hemingway's kinder, more generous side."

—Publishers Weekly

title: A Hologram for the King
long_summary:
In a rising Saudi Arabian city, far from weary, recession-scarred America, a struggling businessman pursues a last-ditch attempt to stave off foreclosure, pay his daughter's college tuition, and finally do something great.

Dave Eggers takes us around the world to show how one man fights to hold himself and his splintering family together in the face of the global economy's gale-force winds. This taut, richly layered novel captures the disorientation of middle-aged professionals cast adrift by economic forces beyond their control.

With his signature blend of humor and pathos, Eggers crafts an elegiac portrait of contemporary anxiety—the fear of obsolescence, the weight of unfulfilled promises, and the desperate hope that one last deal might change everything. A moving exploration of how we navigate personal failure against the backdrop of global transformation.
short_summary: A struggling American businessman travels to Saudi Arabia for one last deal that might save his finances and dignity. Eggers captures middle-aged anxiety with humor and grace.
author_bios: Dave Eggers is the author of many books, including The Every, The Circle, Museum of Rain, The Monk of Mokha, and the National Book Award finalist A Hologram for the King, as well as numerous books for young readers, including Her Right Foot, Faraway Things, and The Lifters. He is the founder of McSweeney's and ScholarMatch, co-founder of 826 Valencia, and winner of the Muhammad Ali Humanitarian Award for Education and the Dayton Literary Peace Prize.
quotes:
"Mr. Eggers uses a new, pared down, Hemingwayesque voice to recount his story... he demonstrates in Hologram that he is master of this more old-fashioned approach as much as he was a pioneering innovator with A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius....[This] sad-funny-dreamlike story unfolds to become an allegory about the frustrations of middle-class America, about the woes unemployed workers and sidelined entrepreneurs have experienced in a newly globalized world in which jobs are being outsourced abroad.... A comic but deeply affecting tale about one man's travails that also provides a bright, digital snapshot of our times."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Eerie, suspenseful and tightly controlled? Exciting stuff."

—Cynthia Macdonald, The Globe and Mail

"A potent, well-drawn portrait of one man's discovery of where his personal and professional selves split and connect."

—Kirkus

title: Transcendent Kingdom
long_summary:
Gifty is a sixth-year PhD candidate in neuroscience at Stanford, studying reward-seeking behavior in mice and the neural circuits of depression and addiction. Her research feels deeply personal: her brother Nana, a gifted high school athlete, died of a heroin overdose after an ankle injury left him hooked on OxyContin. Now her mother, consumed by grief and depression, has moved into Gifty's apartment and barely leaves her bed.

Determined to find scientific answers to her family's suffering, Gifty throws herself into her work. But even as she turns to hard science to unlock the mysteries of addiction and loss, she finds herself grappling with questions that can't be solved in a lab. She hungers for the childhood faith that once sustained her, wrestling with the evangelical church that raised her—its promise of salvation as tantalizing as it remains elusive.

Transcendent Kingdom is a deeply moving portrait of a Ghanaian immigrant family ravaged by addiction and grief. Gyasi weaves together science and faith, family and identity, in an exquisitely written novel about what we inherit and what we choose to carry forward.
short_summary: A neuroscience PhD student researches addiction while caring for her grieving mother and grappling with her brother's overdose death. Gyasi weaves science and faith into a devastating portrait of a Ghanaian immigrant family's struggle with loss.
author_bios: Yaa Gyasi was born in Ghana and raised in Huntsville, Alabama. Her debut novel, Homegoing, won the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Award, the PEN/Hemingway Award, the National Book Foundation's "5 under 35" honors, and the American Book Award. She lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"I would say that Transcendent Kingdom is a novel for our time (and it is) but it is so much more than that. It is a novel for all times. The splendor and heart and insight and brilliance contained in the pages holds up a light the rest of us can follow."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Meticulous, psychologically complex...At once a vivid evocation of the immigrant experience and a sharp delineation of an individual's inner struggle, the novel brilliantly succeeds on both counts."

—Publishers Weekly

"Gyasi's wise second novel pivots toward intimacy... In precise prose, Gyasi creates an ache of recognition, especially for readers knowledgeable about the wreckage of addiction. Still, she leavens this nonlinear novel with sly humor... The author is astute about childhood grandiosity and a pious girl's deep desire to be good; she conveys in brief strokes the notched, nodding hook of heroin's oblivion...final chapter that gives readers a taste of hard-won deliverance."

—Kirkus

title: Unworthy Republic
subtitle: The Dispossession of Native Americans and the Road to Indian Territory
long_summary:
In May 1830, the United States formally launched a policy to expel Native Americans from the East to territories west of the Mississippi River. Justified as a humanitarian enterprise, the undertaking was to be systematic and rational, overseen by Washington's small but growing bureaucracy.

But as the policy unfolded over the next decade, thousands of Native Americans died under the federal government's auspices, and thousands of others lost their possessions and homelands in an orgy of fraud, intimidation, and violence. Drawing on firsthand accounts and voluminous federal records, Saunt reveals how this deportation of 80,000 men, women, and children became national policy.

This deeply researched book argues that Indian Removal was not an inevitable chapter in U.S. expansion. Rather, it was a fiercely contested political act designed to secure new lands for slavery's expansion and consolidate southern power. Indigenous peoples fought relentlessly against the policy, while many U.S. citizens insisted it betrayed the nation's values. When Congress passed the act by a razor-thin margin, it authorized one of the first state-sponsored mass deportations in the modern era.

Saunt demonstrates how white supremacy's politics and economics drove Native American expulsion, how corruption and administrative incompetence contributed to its catastrophic implementation, and how the consequences still resonate today.
short_summary: Saunt chronicles the brutal reality behind Indian Removal—the 1830s policy that forcibly displaced 80,000 Native Americans. Meticulously researched and unflinching, this essential history exposes how white supremacy and greed drove state-sponsored mass deportation.
author_bios: Claudio Saunt is the Richard B. Russell Professor in American History at the University of Georgia. He is the author of award-winning books, including A New Order of Things; Black, White, and Indian; and West of the Revolution. He lives in Athens, Georgia.
quotes:
"Unworthy Republic" is a powerful and lucid account, weaving together events with the people who experienced them up close.…Saunt has written an unflinching book that reckons with this history and its legacy."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"Saunt presents a stark and well-documented case that Native American expulsion was a political choice rather than an inevitable tragedy. This searing account forces a new reckoning with American history."

—Publishers Weekly

"A significant, well-rendered study of a disturbing period in American history."

—Kirkus

title: A Brief History of Seven Killings
long_summary:
On December 3, 1976, seven gunmen stormed Bob Marley's house in Kingston, Jamaica, machine guns blazing. The attack came just before the general election and two days before Marley's planned Smile Jamaica Concert—a show meant to ease political tensions. The singer, his wife, and manager were wounded, but little was officially released about the gunmen's identities or motives.

Marlon James transforms this real event into an epic exploration of Jamaica's turbulent history. Through the voices of gunmen, drug dealers, CIA agents, and even ghosts, he chronicles thirty years of violence and consequence. The story moves from the dangerous streets of 1970s Kingston to the crack houses of 1980s New York, finally returning to a radically altered Jamaica of the 1990s.

James creates an unforgettable cast of characters whose fates intertwine across decades. As they navigate a world where politics and crime blur together, they discover that evil casts long shadows and no one can truly escape their past. Gripping and inventive, this is a mesmerizing novel of power, violence, and the stories we tell ourselves to survive.
short_summary: Seven gunmen storm Bob Marley's house in 1976 Kingston, launching an epic chronicle of violence, politics, and consequence across three decades. James weaves together multiple voices in this sprawling, unforgettable exploration of Jamaica's turbulent history.
author_bios: Marlon James is the author of the New York Times bestsellers Black Leopard, Red Wolf, which was a finalist for the National Book Award, and A Brief History of Seven Killings, which won the 2015 Man Booker Prize, as well as the novels The Book of Night Women and John Crow's Devil. A professor at Macalester College in St. Paul, Minnesota, he lives in New York City.
quotes:
"How to describe Marlon James's monumental new novel A Brief History of Seven Killings? It's like a Tarantino remake of The Harder They Come but with a soundtrack by Bob Marley and a script by Oliver Stone and William Faulkner, with maybe a little creative boost from some primo ganja. It's epic in every sense of that word: sweeping, mythic, over-the-top, colossal and dizzyingly complex. It's also raw, dense, violent, scalding, darkly comic, exhilarating and exhausting—a testament to Mr. James's vaulting ambition and prodigious talent."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"It will come to be seen as a classic of our times…that's what judges of the prestigious Man Booker Prize have said about this year's winner."

—NPR

"An astonishing portrait of the politics of everyday life…Just as he is sharply aware of the nuances of their voices, James has the confidence not to deny his characters their humanity by turning them into moral exemplars, nor paper over the infected wounds that score across the country by suggesting that the loveliness of some of its territory makes up for the savage effects of poverty."

—The Washington Post

title: One of Us
subtitle: The Story of Anders Breivik and the Massacre in Norway
long_summary:
On July 22, 2011, Anders Behring Breivik detonated a bomb outside government buildings in central Oslo, killing eight people. He then proceeded to a youth camp on the island of Utøya, where he killed sixty-nine more—most of them teenage members of Norway's governing Labour Party.

In One of Us, journalist Åsne Seierstad tells the story of this terrible day and what led up to it. What made Breivik, a gifted child from an affluent Oslo neighborhood, become a terrorist?

Seierstad delves deep into Breivik's troubled childhood, showing how a hip-hop and graffiti aficionado became a right-wing activist and Internet game addict, then an entrepreneur, Freemason, and self-styled master warrior who sought to "save Norway" from Islam and multiculturalism. She writes with equal intimacy about Breivik's victims, tracing their political awakenings, aspirations to improve their country, and ill-fated journeys to the island.

By the time Seierstad reaches Utøya, we know both the killer and those he will kill. We have also gotten to know an entire country—famously peaceful and prosperous, and utterly incapable of protecting its youth.
short_summary: Seierstad delivers a devastating account of the 2011 Norway attacks, examining both the terrorist's radicalization and his victims' lives. Forensic in its detail, compassionate in its scope.
author_bios: Åsne Seierstad has worked as a correspondent since 1993. She has written seven books and received numerous awards for her journalism. The Bookseller of Kabul was translated into over 40 languages. One of Us was selected as one of the ten best books of 2015 by the New York Times and was awarded the 2018 Leipzig Book Award for European Understanding. Her latest work, Two Sisters, was awarded the Brage Prize in Norway.
quotes:
"Asne Seierstad's One of Us is almost unbearable to read and absolutely impossible to turn away from: its account of an unthinkable tragedy is reported with staggering rigor and recounted with grace. It's hard to leave this book without feeling incredible grief, without feeling shaken to the core, without feeling urged toward essential questions about what we call evil and how it comes to pass."

—Leslie Jamison, author of The Empathy Exams

"Engrossing, important . . . There are many, many indelible images in Seierstad's account . . . As hard as it is to read about the attack, as frustrating as it is to learn how many delaying mistakes the first responders made and as monstrous as Breivik is, [his victims] on that island that day were beautiful in their idealism. They deserve to be witnessed, which is the ultimate reason to read One of Us."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"The roughly 70 pages Ms. Seierstad devotes to [the attacks] are harrowing in their forensic exactitude . . . These scenes are balanced by moments of tremendous heroism, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't read the final half of One of Us with perpetually moist cheeks . . . The nonfiction horror story told in One of Us moves slowly, inexorably and with tremendous authority."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: Biography of X
long_summary:
When X—an iconoclastic artist and shape-shifter—falls dead in her office, her widow CM hurls herself into writing X's biography. Though X was recognized as a crucial creative force of her era, she kept a tight grip on her life story. In CM's quest to unravel it, she opens a Pandora's box of secrets and destruction.

All the while, she immerses herself in the history of the Southern Territory, a fascist theocracy that split from the rest of the country after World War II, as it is finally forced into an uneasy reunification in the present day.

This masterfully constructed literary adventure follows CM as she traces X's trajectory over decades, from Europe to America's divided territories, and through her collaborations and feuds with everyone from Bowie and Waits to Sontag and Acker. When she finally understands the scope of X's defining artistic project, CM realizes her wife's deceptions were far crueler than she imagined.

Pulsing with suspense and intellect, Biography of X plumbs the depths of grief, art, and love, introducing us to an unforgettable character who shows us the fallibility of the stories we craft for ourselves.
short_summary: Wild with grief, a widow investigates her late wife's secret past and uncovers a web of artistic deceptions. Lacey constructs an ambitious literary thriller about love, art, and the stories we tell ourselves.
author_bios: Catherine Lacey is the author of the novels Biography of X, Pew, The Answers, and Nobody Is Ever Missing as well as the short-story collection Certain American States. She has received a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Whiting Award, the New York Public Library Young Lions Fiction Award, the Brooklyn Public Library Book Prize, a Lambda Literary Award, and a residency at the Jan Michalski Foundation.
quotes:
"Biography of X is the most ambitious book I've ever read from a writer of my own generation. Epic world-building revealed through intimate emotion and dangerously honed sentences; a story that mixes fact and fiction to create a new register of truth, a register that belongs entirely to Catherine Lacey. I'm awed."

—Torrey Peters, author of Detransition, Baby

"Sly, brilliant, philosophically acute, bitingly funny, and a pure joy to spend hours with . . . Suffice it to say that it feels fairly rare for a novel to be hugely intelligent and moving and fun in equal measure, but with Biography of X, Catherine Lacey somehow-magically-makes the nearly impossible look easy."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates & Furies, Matrix & Arcadia

"This is a major novel, and a notably audacious one. Lacey is pulling from a deep reservoir. Beneath the counterfactuals, and the glamour and squalor of Manhattan nightlife, and the mythologies bought and sold, she's telling a love story of a broken sort. C.M. is flinging rope between her present and past. This book is about facing, and accepting, the things you didn't want to know."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: Killers of the Flower Moon
subtitle: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI
long_summary:
In the 1920s, the Osage Nation in Oklahoma became the richest people per capita in the world after oil was discovered beneath their land. They rode in chauffeured automobiles, built mansions, and sent their children to study in Europe.

Then the murders began. Members of Mollie Burkhart's family became prime targets—one relative shot, another poisoned. As more Osage died under mysterious circumstances, those who dared investigate were themselves killed.

With the death toll rising, the newly created FBI took up the case. Young director J. Edgar Hoover turned to former Texas Ranger Tom White, who assembled an undercover team including a Native American agent who infiltrated the region. Working alongside the Osage, they began to expose one of the most chilling conspiracies in American history—a systematic campaign of greed and racism that would reshape how we understand the American West.
short_summary: The shocking true story of how the oil-rich Osage Nation became targets of a murderous conspiracy in 1920s Oklahoma. Grann's meticulous investigation exposes forgotten American horrors.
author_bios: David Grann is the author of #1 New York Times bestsellers Killers of the Flower Moon and The Lost City of Z. Killers of the Flower Moon was a National Book Award finalist and won an Edgar Allan Poe Award. He also wrote The White Darkness and The Devil and Sherlock Holmes. His investigative reporting has earned a George Polk Award among other honors.
quotes:
"[C]lose to impeccable. It's confident, fluid in its dynamics, light on its feet.... The crime story it tells is appalling, and stocked with authentic heroes and villains. It will make you cringe at man's inhumanity to man."

—The New York Times

"The best book of the year so far."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Disturbing and riveting.... Grann has proved himself a master of spinning delicious, many-layered mysteries that also happen to be true.... It will sear your soul."

—Dave Eggers, Author of A Hologram for the King

title: Crying in H Mart
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In this exquisite story of family, food, grief, and endurance, Michelle Zauner proves herself far more than a dazzling musician. With humor and heart, she tells of growing up one of the few Asian American kids in Eugene, Oregon, struggling with her mother's particular expectations and navigating a painful adolescence. She treasures memories of months spent in her grandmother's tiny Seoul apartment, where she and her mother would bond late into the night over heaping plates of food.

As she moved to the East Coast for college, worked in restaurants, and performed with her fledgling band, her Koreanness began to feel increasingly distant—even as she found the life she wanted to live. Her mother's terminal cancer diagnosis when Michelle was twenty-five forced a reckoning with her identity and brought her to reclaim the gifts of taste, language, and history her mother had given her.

Vivacious and plainspoken, lyrical and honest, Zauner's voice radiates as brilliantly on the page as it does onstage. Rich with intimate anecdotes and family photos, this is a memoir to cherish and reread.
short_summary: From Japanese Breakfast's Michelle Zauner comes a luminous memoir exploring Korean American identity through the lens of food and family. When her mother's terminal illness forces a reckoning with heritage, cooking becomes both grief and healing.
author_bios: Michelle Zauner is the singer and guitarist behind the acclaimed indie pop project Japanese Breakfast. She has won international praise for albums including Psychopomp (2016), Soft Sounds from Another Planet (2017), Jubilee (2021), and For Melancholy Brunettes (and Sad Women) (2025).
quotes:
"Crying in H Mart powerfully maps a complicated mother-daughter relationship . . . Zauner writes about her mother's death [with] clear-eyed frankness . . . The book is a rare acknowledgement of the ravages of cancer in a culture obsessed with seeing it as an enemy that can be battled with hope and strength. Zauner plumbs the connections between food and identity . . . her food descriptions transport us to the table alongside her. What Crying in H Mart reveals is that in losing her mother and cooking to bring her back to life, Zauner became herself."

—NPR

"Poignant . . . A tender, well-rendered, heart-wrenching account of the way food ties us to those who have passed. The author delivers mouthwatering descriptions of dishes like pajeon, jatjuk, and gimbap, and her storytelling is fluid, honest, and intimate. When a loved one dies, we search all of our senses for signs of their presence. Zauner's ability to let us in through taste makes her book stand out—she makes us feel like we are in her mother's kitchen, singing her praises."

—Kirkus

"Lyrical... Earnest... Zauner does a good job capturing the grief of losing a parent with pathos. Fans looking to get a glimpse into the inner life of this megawatt pop star will not be disappointed."

—Publishers Weekly

title: NW
long_summary:
Set in northwest London, Zadie Smith's brilliant tragicomic novel follows four locals—Leah, Natalie, Felix, and Nathan—as they try to make adult lives outside of Caldwell, the council estate of their childhood.

In private houses and public parks, at work and at play, these Londoners inhabit a complicated place, as beautiful as it is brutal, where the thoroughfares hide the back alleys and taking the high road can sometimes lead you to a dead end.

Depicting the modern urban zone familiar to city-dwellers everywhere, NW is a quietly devastating novel of encounters, mercurial and vital, like the city itself.
short_summary: Four Londoners who grew up in the same council estate navigate adulthood, class divides, and shifting identities. Smith's formally experimental novel captures the fractured rhythms of contemporary urban life.
author_bios: Zadie Smith is the author of the novels White Teeth, The Autograph Man, On Beauty, NW, Swing Time, and The Fraud; the novella The Embassy of Cambodia; three essay collections, Changing My Mind, Feel Free and Intimations; the short story collection Grand Union; and the play The Wife of Willesden, adapted from Chaucer. She was born in north-west London, where she still lives.
quotes:
"This is a book in which you never know how things will come together or what will happen next... NW represents a deliberate undoing; an unpacking of Smith's abundant narrative gifts to find a deeper truth, audacious and painful as that truth may be. The result is that rare thing, a book that is radical and passionate and real."

—Anne Enright, The New York Times Book Review

"Endlessly fascinating... remarkable. ...The impression of Smith's casual brilliance is what constantly surprises, the way she tosses off insights about parenting and work that you've felt in some nebulous way but never been able to articulate."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A powerful portrait of class and identity in multicultural London."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Stone Yard Devotional
long_summary:
Burnt out and seeking refuge, a middle-aged woman leaves Sydney for the stark plains of rural Australia, taking shelter in a small religious community. She doesn't believe in God or understand prayer, yet finds herself living this strange, reclusive existence almost by accident.

But three unsettling events shatter her retreat. First comes a devastating mouse plague, each day bringing fresh battles against the rising infestation. Then the skeletal remains of a sister who disappeared decades earlier are discovered—a woman presumed murdered long ago. Finally, a troubling visitor forces the narrator to confront her buried past.

Meditative and finely observed, this Booker Prize-shortlisted novel explores what it means to withdraw from the world, the complex nature of forgiveness, and grief's enduring grip on the human soul.
short_summary: Seeking refuge in a remote religious community, a woman confronts three unsettling events: a mouse plague, her sister's discovered remains, and a visitor from her past. Booker Prize-shortlisted fiction about retreat, forgiveness, and grief.
author_bios: Charlotte Wood is the author of seven novels and three books of nonfiction. Her 2016 novel The Natural Way of Things won the Stella Prize and was joint winner of the Australian Prime Minister's Literary Award for Fiction. Her 2020 novel, The Weekend, was an international bestseller.
quotes:
"Founded on the same rock of introspection that anchors the Gilead series….Stone Yard Devotional not only stays aloft but soars… A strange sense of engagement with these pages gives way to sheer gratitude for the chance to be in the presence of such restraint and wisdom."

—Washington Post

"A book about what it means to be good: simply and with great humility, it asks the big questions, leaving the reader feeling kinder, more brave, enlarged."

—Anne Enright

"The novel is, in many ways, an extended meditative vigil...Activism, abdication, atonement, grace: In this novel no one of these paths is holier than another; Wood is more invested in noticing the human pursuit of holiness itself."

—New York Times

title: The Fate of the Day
subtitle: The War for America, Fort Ticonderoga to Charleston, 1777-1780
long_summary:
The first twenty-one months of the American Revolution ended with Washington's ragged Continental Army barely escaping annihilation. By winter 1777, they had survived—but little more.

Two years into the war, the conflict has grown far more complex. King George III remains determined to crush his rebellious colonies, but fighting across the Atlantic has become ruinously expensive. Worse still, spies report that France and Spain threaten to join the American cause.

Prize-winning historian Rick Atkinson delivers a riveting account of the Revolution's pivotal middle years. In Paris, Benjamin Franklin woos the French court. In Pennsylvania, Washington desperately pleads with Congress for money, men, and supplies. In New York, General William Howe commands the greatest army Britain has ever sent overseas—yet doubts whether he can win this brutal war.

What follows brings epic battles at Brandywine, Saratoga, and Monmouth, the suffering of Valley Forge, and constant appeals for sacrifice from every American committed to the struggle. Timed for the Revolution's 250th anniversary, Atkinson's brilliant narrative offers both spectacular drama and fresh insight into the demands democracy makes on its citizens.
short_summary: The Revolution's brutal middle years, when Washington's army fought on the knife's edge between survival and annihilation. Atkinson brings epic battles and desperate diplomacy to vivid life.
author_bios: Rick Atkinson is the #1 New York Times bestselling author of eight narrative histories about five American wars, including The Long Gray Line, the Liberation Trilogy (An Army at Dawn, The Day of Battle, and The Guns at Last Light), and The British Are Coming. He has won Pulitzer Prizes for both history and journalism.
quotes:
"Atkinson writes with tremendous verve and detail. The result is a book that infuses the events… of the war with striking vibrancy, essentially bringing the conflict to life again. . . . Regular readers of history will have already heard of many of the people Atkinson describes—but after finishing this book, they might feel like they have met them."

—The Washington Post

"As ever with Atkinson, an exemplary work of narrative history."

—Kirkus Reviews, starred review

"Epic in scale but rich in detail, this captures the drama and world-historical significance of the revolution."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Shirley Jackson
subtitle: A Rather Haunted Life
long_summary:
Still known to millions primarily as the author of "The Lottery," Shirley Jackson (1916–1965) has been curiously absent from the mainstream American literary canon. A genius of literary suspense and psychological horror, Jackson plumbed the cultural anxiety of postwar America more deeply than anyone.

Biographer Ruth Franklin reveals the tumultuous life and inner darkness of the author of such classics as The Haunting of Hill House and We Have Always Lived in the Castle. Placing Jackson within an American Gothic tradition that stretches back to Hawthorne and Poe, Franklin demonstrates how her unique contribution came from her focus on "domestic horror." Almost two decades before The Feminine Mystique ignited the women's movement, Jackson's stories were already exploring the exploitation and desperate isolation of women in American society.

The increasingly prescient Jackson emerges as a ferociously talented writer in a time when it was unusual for a woman to have both family and profession. A mother of four and wife of prominent New Yorker critic Stanley Edgar Hyman, she lived a seemingly bucolic life in Vermont. Yet much like her stories, which channeled the occult while exploring the claustrophobia of marriage and motherhood, Jackson's creative ascent was haunted by darkness. Her marriage became tenuous, her anxiety mounted, and she became addicted to amphetamines and tranquilizers.

Based on previously undiscovered correspondence and dozens of new interviews, this becomes the definitive biography of an American literary giant.
short_summary: Ruth Franklin's masterful biography rescues Shirley Jackson from literary obscurity, revealing how the author of The Lottery and The Haunting of Hill House pioneered domestic horror while navigating the contradictions of mid-century American womanhood.
author_bios: Ruth Franklin is the author of A Thousand Darknesses: Lies and Truth in Holocaust Fiction, a finalist for the Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature, and Shirley Jackson: A Rather Haunted Life, winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award for Biography. She lives in Brooklyn, NY.
quotes:
"With this welcome new biography Franklin makes a thoughtful and persuasive case for Jackson as a serious and accomplished literary artist. . . . [Franklin] sees Jackson not as an oddball, one-off writer of horror tales and ghost stories but as someone belonging to the great tradition of Hawthorne, Poe and James, writers preoccupied, as she was, with inner evil in the human soul."

—Charles McGrath, The New York Times

"Ruth Franklin's sympathetic and masterful biography both uncovers Jackson's secret and haunting life and repositions her as a major artist whose fiction so uncannily channeled women's nightmares and contradictions that it is 'nothing less than the secret history of American women of her era.'"

—Elaine Showalter, The Washington Post

"This meticulous biography tackles the work of Shirley Jackson with the kind of studied seriousness some might give to a male titan of history like Robert Moses. And thank goddess for that, as Ruth Franklin wisely rescues Shirley Jackson from any semblance of obscurity. Despite her well-documented magnetism (and dalliances in the dark arts) Jackson's work was often dismissed as mere genre nonsense or, worse yet, women's fiction and Franklin's sensitive, witty and rigorous work makes an airtight case for just why this isn't right. The ire Jackson's short stories inspired in New Yorker readers is only a hint of the drama and intensity that characterized her short but beguiling life, with Franklin captures with a hefty dose of wit and suspense. One of the best literary biographies I've ever encountered."

—Lena Dunham

title: The Wilderness
long_summary:
Desiree, January, Monique, and Nakia are in their early twenties, navigating the beginning of everything—careers, marriage, motherhood, and big-city lives in New York and Los Angeles. They're finding their way through that wilderness period when the reality of contemporary adulthood swoops in with all its overwhelming freedom and consequences.

Desiree is estranged from her sister Danielle, and both nurse bitter family wounds in different ways. January has a relationship with a "good" man she feels ambivalent about, even after her surprise pregnancy. Monique, a librarian and aspiring blogger, finds unexpected online fame after calling out her university's plans to whitewash fraught history. Nakia is trying to get her restaurant off the ground without relying on her upper middle-class family, who wonder aloud if she should be doing something better with her life.

As these friends move from the late 2000s into the late 2020s—from young adults to grown women—they must figure out what they mean to one another amid political upheaval, economic and environmental instability, and the increasing volatility of modern American life. Flournoy captures with disarming wit and electric language how the most profound connections over a lifetime can lie in the tangled, uncertain thicket of friendship.
short_summary: Four Black women navigate two decades of friendship through the chaos of contemporary American life. Flournoy's electric prose captures how we grow and change while holding onto the people who matter most.
author_bios: Angela Flournoy is the author of The Turner House, which was a finalist for the National Book Award, a finalist for the Center for Fiction First Novel Prize, a Barnes & Noble Discover Great New Writers selection, an Indie Next pick, and a New York Times Notable Book of the Year. Her fiction has appeared in The Paris Review, and she has written for The New York Times, The New Yorker, Los Angeles Times, and elsewhere. A graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop, Flournoy has taught at the University of Iowa, Princeton University, and UCLA.
quotes:
"Angela Flournoy's vivid second novel, The Wilderness, treats friendship with the dignity and fascination it deserves."

—Washington Post

"Astonishing.... The book's shifting perspectives trace these women as they mature and negotiate tensions within themselves and with one another, all while the world is tumbling ever more precipitously toward hell. Think: if Waiting to Exhale were also about the difficulty of breathing in the Anthropocene amid frequent wildfires and unpredictable political weather.... Transcendent."

—New York Times Book Review

"A rangy novel, crisscrossing the continent to trace the fates of five friends as they navigate relationships, career pivots and entrenchments, and the loss of or estrangement from family. The Wilderness uses social events (recent racial reckonings, the pandemic) as material but has a more seasoned perspective than that of novels written in their immediate wake. The gestation of this book seems to have served it well in that respect, giving it a wisdom—worn lightly and with humor—on the promise and reality of historic inflection points and how a tightly knit group might respond to them differently."

—Vogue

title: Unbroken
subtitle: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption
long_summary:
On a May afternoon in 1943, an Army Air Forces bomber crashed into the Pacific Ocean. From the wreckage emerged Louis Zamperini, a young bombardier who pulled himself onto a life raft and began one of World War II's most extraordinary survival stories.

Zamperini had been a cunning delinquent in boyhood—breaking into houses, brawling, riding the rails. As a teenager, he channeled his defiance into running, discovering a prodigious talent that carried him to the Berlin Olympics and within sight of the four-minute mile. When war came, the athlete became an airman, embarking on a journey that led to his doomed flight.

Ahead lay thousands of miles of open ocean, leaping sharks, a foundering raft, thirst and starvation, enemy aircraft—and beyond that, an even greater trial. Driven to his limits, Zamperini would answer desperation with ingenuity, suffering with hope and humor, brutality with rebellion. His fate would hang on the fraying wire of his will.

Hillenbrand writes with the same rich narrative voice she displayed in Seabiscuit, crafting an unforgettable story of human extremity and an testament to the resilience of mind, body, and spirit.
short_summary: The epic true story of Louis Zamperini—Olympic runner turned bombardier—whose extraordinary will to survive became the stuff of legend. Hillenbrand transforms wartime heroism into unforgettable storytelling.
author_bios: Laura Hillenbrand is the author of #1 New York Times bestseller Seabiscuit: An American Legend, a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist that won the Book Sense Book of the Year Award and inspired the Academy Award-nominated film. Her New Yorker article "A Sudden Illness" won the 2004 National Magazine Award, and she's a two-time Eclipse Award winner. She co-founded Operation International Children with actor Gary Sinise and lives in Washington, D.C.
quotes:
"Hillenbrand has once again brought to life the true story of a forgotten hero, and reminded us how lucky we are to have her, one of our best writers of narrative history. You don't have to be a sports fan or a war-history buff to devour this book—you just have to love great storytelling."

—Rebecca Skloot, author of The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks

"Moving and, yes, inspirational . . . [Laura] Hillenbrand's unforgettable book . . . deserve[s] pride of place alongside the best works of literature that chart the complications and the hard-won triumphs of so-called ordinary Americans and their extraordinary time."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"A meticulous, soaring and beautifully written account of an extraordinary life."

—The Washington Post

title: Matrix
long_summary:
Cast out by Eleanor of Aquitaine and deemed too coarse for courtly life, seventeen-year-old Marie de France is exiled to England as prioress of a failing abbey. The nuns are starving, diseased, and desperate.

At first overwhelmed by the severity of her new world, Marie discovers unexpected purpose in collective life with her singular sisters. In this crucible, she transforms—replacing her longing for family and homeland with fierce devotion to her community and trust in her own divine visions.

Born into a lineage of women warriors and crusaders, Marie is determined to chart a revolutionary course for the women under her protection. But in a shifting world that cannot reconcile itself with her existence, will the sheer force of her vision prove strong enough?

Equally attuned to the sacred and profane, Matrix weaves together violence, sensuality, and religious ecstasy in a mesmerizing portrait of consuming passion and aberrant faith. Groff's first novel since Fates and Furies offers a defiant exploration of raw female creativity flourishing in a corrupted world.
short_summary: Exiled from Eleanor of Aquitaine's court, teenage Marie de France transforms a dying abbey into a radical sanctuary. Groff crafts a mesmerizing tale of mysticism, ambition, and women reshaping their world.
author_bios: Lauren Groff is a three-time National Book Award finalist and New York Times bestselling author of the novels The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, and the short story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. She has won The Story Prize, the ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Her work appears regularly in The New Yorker and The Atlantic and has been translated into thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband own the independent bookstore The Lynx.
quotes:
"A radiant novel about the 12th-century poet and mystic Marie de France. . . Groff richly imagines Marie's decades of exile in a royal convent, which she eventually leads. A charged novel about female ambition."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR's Fresh Air

"An audacious piece of storytelling, full of passion, wisdom and magic."

—Sarah Waters, New York Times bestselling author of The Paying Guests

"A thrillingly vivid, adventurous story about women and power that will blow readers' minds. Left me gasping."

—Emma Donoghue, author of Room

title: Wild
subtitle: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail
long_summary:
At twenty-two, Cheryl Strayed thought she had lost everything. In the wake of her mother's death, her family scattered and her marriage crumbled. Four years later, with nothing left to lose, she made the most impulsive decision of her life: to hike the Pacific Crest Trail alone from the Mojave Desert through California and Oregon to Washington State.

She had no experience as a long-distance hiker, and the trail was little more than "an idea, vague and outlandish and full of promise." But it was a promise of piecing back together a life that had come undone.

Strayed faces down rattlesnakes and black bears, intense heat and record snowfalls, and both the beauty and crushing loneliness of the trail. Told with suspense and sparkling with warmth and humor, Wild vividly captures the terrors and pleasures of one young woman forging ahead against all odds on a journey that maddened, strengthened, and ultimately healed her.
short_summary: Following her mother's death and the collapse of her marriage, Cheryl Strayed embarks on an eleven-hundred-mile solo hike along the Pacific Crest Trail. A blazingly honest memoir about breaking down and building back up again.
author_bios: Cheryl Strayed is the author of the number-one New York Times bestseller Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail, which has sold more than four million copies worldwide and was made into an Oscar-nominated film. Tiny Beautiful Things was adapted as a play and Hulu series. She's also the author of Brave Enough and the novel Torch, and has hosted the podcasts Sugar Calling and Dear Sugars. She lives in Portland, Oregon.
quotes:
"A rich, riveting true story . . . During her grueling three-month journey, Strayed circled around black bears and rattlesnakes, fought extreme dehydration by drinking oily gray pond water, and hiked in boots made entirely of duct tape.  Reading her matter-of-fact take on love and grief and the soul-saving quality of a Snapple lemonade, you can understand why Strayed has earned a cult following as the author of Dear Sugar, a popular advice column on therumpus.net. . . . With its vivid descriptions of beautiful but unforgiving terrain, Wild is a cinematic story, but Strayed's book isn't really about big, cathartic moments. The author never 'finds herself' or gets healed. When she reaches the trail's end, she buys a cheap ice cream cone and continues down the road. . . . It's hard to imagine anything more important than taking one step at a time. That's endurance, and that's what Strayed understands, almost 20 years later. As she writes, 'There was only one [option], I knew. To keep walking."

—Melissa Maerz, Entertainment Weekly

"In the summer of 1995, at age 26 and feeling at the end of her rope emotionally, Strayed resolved to hike solo the Pacific Crest Trail . . . In this detailed, in-the-moment re-enactment, she delineates the travails and triumphs of those three grueling months. Living in Minneapolis, on the verge of divorcing her husband, Strayed was still reeling from the sudden death four years before of her mother; the ensuing years formed an erratic, confused time 'like a crackling Fourth of July sparkler.' Hiking the trail helped decide what direction her life would take, even though she had never seriously hiked or carried a pack before. . . . Eventually she began to experience 'a kind of strange, abstract, retrospective fun,' meeting the few other hikers along the way, all male; jettisoning some of the weight from her pack and burning books she had read; and encountering all manner of creature and acts of nature, from rock slides to snow. Her account forms a charming, intrepid trial by fire, as she emerges from the ordeal bruised but not beaten, changed, a lone survivor."

—Publishers Weekly

"Unsentimental memoir of the author's solo hike from California to Washington along the Pacific Crest Trail. Following the death of her mother, Strayed's life quickly disintegrated. . . . While waiting in line at an outdoors store, [she] read the back cover of a book about the Pacific Crest Trail. Initially, the idea of hiking the trail became a vague apparition, then a goal. Woefully underprepared for the wilderness, out of shape and carrying a ridiculously overweight pack, the author set out from the small California town of Mojave, toward a bridge ('the Bridge of the Gods') crossing the Columbia River at the Oregon-Washington border. Strayed's writing admirably conveys the rigors and rewards of long-distance hiking. Along the way she suffered aches, pains, loneliness, blistered, bloody feet and persistent hunger. Yet the author also discovered a newfound sense of awe . . . stunned by how the trail both shattered and sheltered her. Most of the hikers she met along the way were helpful, and she also encountered instances of trail magic . . . A candid, inspiring narrative of the author's brutal physical and psychological journey through a wilderness of despair to a renewed sense of self."

—Kirkus

title: Station Eleven
long_summary:
An audacious, darkly glittering novel set in the eerie days following civilization's collapse, Station Eleven tells the spellbinding story of a nomadic group of actors roaming the scattered outposts of the Great Lakes region, risking everything for art and humanity.

Fifteen years after a flu pandemic wiped out most of the world's population, Kirsten performs with the Traveling Symphony, a small troupe moving across the gutted landscape, bringing Shakespeare and music to scattered communities of survivors.

But when they arrive in the outpost of St. Deborah by the Water, they encounter a violent prophet who digs graves for anyone who dares to leave. Spanning decades and moving back and forth in time, this suspenseful, elegiac novel vividly depicts life before and after the disaster, telling a story about the relationships that sustain us even in the darkest times.
short_summary: After a flu pandemic collapses civilization, a troupe of actors and musicians travels the Great Lakes, preserving art in the ruins. Haunting and luminous, this is survival fiction with uncommon grace.
author_bios: Emily St. John Mandel's five novels include The Glass Hotel and Station Eleven, which was a finalist for a National Book Award and the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and has been translated into thirty-five languages. She lives in New York City.
quotes:
"A novel that carries a magnificent depth . . . We get to see something that is so difficult to show or feel – how small moments in time link together. And how these moments add up to a life . . . Her best yet. It feels as though she took the experience earned from her previous writing and braided it together to make one gleaming strand . . . An epic book."

—Claire Cameron, The Globe and Mail

"Deeply melancholy, but beautifully written, and wonderfully elegiac . . . A book that I will long remember, and return to."

—George R. R. Martin

"Station Eleven is so compelling, so fearlessly imagined, that I wouldn't have put it down for anything."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonweath & State of Wonder

title: Playground
long_summary:
Four lives converge in Richard Powers' sweeping new novel. Twelve-year-old Evie Beaulieu explores the depths of a Montreal swimming pool with one of the world's first aqualungs. Ina Aroita grows up on naval bases across the Pacific, finding home only in art. At an elite Chicago high school, two unlikely friends bond over an ancient board game—Rafi Young loses himself in literature while Todd Keane pursues groundbreaking AI research.

Their paths cross on Makatea, a history-scarred atoll in French Polynesia. Once vital for its phosphorus deposits that helped feed the world, this tiny island now faces a momentous decision. Developers want to use Makatea as the launching point for floating, autonomous cities on the open sea—but first, residents must vote on whether to embrace this vision or reject it entirely.

Set against the vast Pacific, Powers explores the last wild frontier we have yet to colonize. He weaves together luminous prose, complex characters, and profound questions about technology, environment, and what connects us as human beings in an ever-changing world.
short_summary: Four interconnected lives converge on a remote Pacific atoll where residents must decide whether to host humanity's next frontier: floating cities on the open sea. Powers weaves technology, environment, and human connection into something transcendent.
author_bios: Richard Powers is the author of fourteen novels, including The Overstory, Bewilderment, and Orfeo. He is the recipient of a MacArthur Fellowship, the Pulitzer Prize, and the National Book Award. He lives in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains.
quotes:
"Prepare to be awed… A mind-blowing reflection on what it means to live on a dying planet… I wasn't prepared for the astonishing resolution that Powers delivers. In the now-vast library of fiction and nonfiction books reminding us of the planet's imperiled condition, I can't think of another novel that treats the Earth's plight with such an expansive and disorienting vision… Powers manages to entwine our longing for friendship, paradise and immortality with the algorithms of artificial intelligence that surpass all understanding."

—Ron Charles, Washington Post

"An extraordinarily immersive journey through lives linked in mysterious ways—gripping, alarming, and uplifting."

—Emma Donoghue, author of Room

"Powers is a master of taking important topics of our times—from threats to our oceans and climate change to AI—and turning them into riveting and fiercely relevant books imbued with psychological insight and a deep awe for nature. This eloquent dance of the scientific and emotional makes him one of our finest storytellers. Playground is brilliant, captivating, and important—and the best book I've read this year."

—Andrea Wulf

title: Strangers to Ourselves
subtitle: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us
long_summary:
What happens when psychiatric explanations fail to capture who we really are? Drawing on deep original reporting and unpublished journals and memoirs, Rachel Aviv explores people who have come up against the limits of how we understand mental illness.

She follows an Indian woman celebrated as a saint who lives in healing temples in Kerala; an incarcerated mother seeking her children's forgiveness after recovering from psychosis; a man who devotes his life to revenge against his psychoanalysts; and an affluent young woman who goes off her medication after a decade of defining herself through her diagnosis.

Animated by profound empathy, Aviv's exploration is refracted through her own experience of living in a psychiatric ward at age six and meeting a fellow patient whose life runs parallel to hers—until it no longer does. She asks how the stories we tell about mental disorders shape their course in our lives and our identities. Challenging how we understand and discuss illness, this is a testament to the porousness and resilience of the mind.
short_summary: What happens when psychiatric explanations fail to capture who we really are? Aviv follows people who've hit the limits of how we understand mental illness, weaving their stories with her own powerful personal account.
author_bios: Rachel Aviv is a staff writer at The New Yorker, covering medicine, education, and criminal justice. She won a 2022 National Magazine Award for Profile Writing and received a Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant to support this book. A 2019 national fellow at New America, she lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"In this penetrating, landmark book, Rachel Aviv investigates what she calls the 'psychic hinterlands,' drawing on her customary vivid reporting and her own extraordinary personal story to pose unsettling questions about the ways in which we reckon with mental illness by categorizing it, diagnosing it, giving it a name. Threading together the intimate and emotionally shattering stories of a series of very different people who have struggled to live with and to understand their own psychological afflictions, Aviv has created an arresting work of profound empathy and insight."

—Patrick Radden Keefe, author of Say Nothing and Empire of Pain

"Intimate and revelatory . . . attuned to subtlety and complexity . . . This isn't an anti-psychiatry book- Aviv is too aware of the specifics of any situation to succumb to anything so sweeping and polemical . . . a book-length demonstration of Aviv's extraordinary ability to hold space for the 'uncertainty, mysteries and doubts' of others."

—Jennifer Szalai, New York Times

"Aviv writes with an unpredictable mixture of intimacy and distance, exploring how psychiatric language often alters what it names. She has assembled a remarkable archive of unpublished materials-memoirs, poems, journals (including her own)-that offers a visceral counterpoint to the official languages of institutions and expertise. I admire her rigor and eloquence but also her restraint-she makes vivid experiences we can't explain."

—Ben Lerner, author of The Topeka School

title: Frederick Douglass
subtitle: Prophet of Freedom
long_summary:
Born into slavery, Frederick Douglass (1818–1895) escaped from Baltimore as a young man, armed with literacy secretly taught by his owner's wife. He would become one of America's major literary figures, his very existence challenging the lies slaveholders told about Black humanity.

Initially mentored by William Lloyd Garrison, Douglass transformed his personal story into a powerful weapon against slavery. By the Civil War, he had become the nation's most celebrated orator, traveling widely to bear witness to slavery's brutality. In his unique and eloquent voice, Douglass emerged as both a fierce critic of America and a radical patriot.

David Blight's masterful biography draws on previously untapped private collections and recently discovered issues of Douglass's own newspapers. The result is an intimate portrait that reveals Douglass's complex family life, his two marriages, and his sometimes contentious relationships with younger African Americans after the war, even as he never abandoned his commitment to civil rights and the Republican party.
short_summary: The definitive biography of Frederick Douglass, who escaped slavery to become America's greatest 19th-century orator and a towering abolitionist. Blight masterfully captures both the public figure and the deeply human man behind the legend.
author_bios: David W. Blight is Sterling Professor of History and Director of the Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition at Yale University. He has authored or edited a dozen books, including American Oracle: The Civil War in the Civil Rights Era and Race and Reunion: The Civil War in American Memory, plus annotated editions of Douglass's first two autobiographies. His work has earned the Bancroft Prize, Abraham Lincoln Prize, and Frederick Douglass Prize.
quotes:
"The first major biography of Douglass in nearly three decades. . . . Blight isn't looking to overturn our understanding of Douglass, whose courage and achievements were unequivocal, but to complicate it — a measure by which this ambitious and empathetic biography resoundingly succeeds."

—Jennifer Szalai, The New York Times

"Extraordinary. . . . In Blight's pages, [Douglass's] voice again rings out loud and clear, melancholy and triumphant — still prophesying, still agitating, still calling us to action."

—Adam Goodheart, The Washington Post

"Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom is a triumph—elegantly written, with much new material about one of the most famous and important men in modern history. David Blight has created a vibrant and convincing portrait of a towering figure who was also, Blight says, 'thoroughly and beautifully human.' A great American gets the stellar biography he deserves from one our country's greatest historians."

—Annette Gordon-Reed, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family & On Juneteenth

title: Young Mungo
long_summary:
Growing up in a housing estate in Glasgow, Mungo and James are born under different stars—Mungo a Protestant and James a Catholic—and they should be sworn enemies. Yet against all odds, they fall in love as they find sanctuary and dream of escape in the pigeon dovecote that James has built for his prize racing birds.

But when Mungo's mother sends him on a fishing trip to a remote loch with two strange men, he will need all his strength and courage to find his way back to a place where he and James might still have a future. This brilliantly constructed and deeply moving story of queer love and working-class families comes from the Booker Prize–winning author of Shuggie Bain.

A national bestseller acclaimed as one of the best books of the year by NPR, Kirkus Reviews, Time, and Amazon, Young Mungo weaves between past and present to create an unforgettable portrait of love blooming in the most unlikely circumstances.
short_summary: Two boys from opposite sides of Glasgow's sectarian divide fall in love amid violence and poverty. Stuart's tender, brutal follow-up to Shuggie Bain explores queer love in a world determined to destroy it.
author_bios: Douglas Stuart is a Scottish-American author whose debut novel Shuggie Bain won the 2020 Booker Prize and the Sue Kaufman Prize, and was a finalist for the National Book Award and PEN/Hemingway Award. His latest novel Young Mungo was a national bestseller and British Book Award finalist. His work appears in the New Yorker and Literary Hub.
quotes:
"Page-turning, beautifully written . . . In a narrative that weaves seamlessly back and forth between the camping trip and Mungo's life before the trip, Stuart creates a world we can almost feel."

—Deborah Dundas, Toronto Star

"The Sighthill tenement where Shuggie Bain, Stuart's Booker Prize–winning debut, unfurled is glimpsed in his follow-up, set in the 1990s in an adjacent neighborhood. You wouldn't think you'd be eager to return to these harsh, impoverished environs, but again this author creates characters so vivid, dilemmas so heart-rending, and dialogue so brilliant that the whole thing sucks you in like a vacuum cleaner . . . Romantic, terrifying, brutal, tender, and, in the end, sneakily hopeful. What a writer."

—Kirkus

"The astonishing sophomore effort from Booker Prize winner Stuart details a teen's hard life in north Glasgow in the post-Thatcher years . . . Stuart's writing is stellar . . . He's too fine a storyteller to go for a sentimental ending, and the final act leaves the reader gutted. This is unbearably sad, more so because the reader comes to cherish the characters their creator has brought to life. It's a sucker punch to the heart."

—Publishers Weekly

title: On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous
long_summary:
On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous unfolds as a letter from a son to a mother who cannot read. Written when Little Dog is in his late twenties, the letter excavates a family history rooted in Vietnam and serves as a doorway into parts of his life his mother has never known.

At once a witness to the fraught yet undeniable love between a single mother and her son, it's also a brutally honest exploration of race, class, and masculinity. Asking questions central to our American moment—immersed as we are in addiction, violence, and trauma—the novel is undergirded by compassion and tenderness.

With stunning urgency and grace, Vuong writes of people caught between disparate worlds, asking how we heal and rescue one another without forsaking who we are. As much about the power of telling one's own story as it is about the obliterating silence of not being heard, this is a novel that transforms the question of how to survive into something approaching joy.
short_summary: A son writes to his illiterate mother, excavating family history and first love. Vuong's epistolary debut transforms trauma into something approaching grace through the sheer power of storytelling.
author_bios: Ocean Vuong is the author of the critically acclaimed poetry collections Night Sky with Exit Wounds and Time Is a Mother, as well as the New York Times bestselling novel On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous. A MacArthur Fellowship and American Book Award recipient, he was born in Saigon, Vietnam, and splits his time between western Massachusetts and New York City.
quotes:
"A bruised, breathtaking love letter never meant to be sent. A powerful testimony to magic and loss. A marvel."

—Marlon James, author of A Brief History of Seven Killings & Black Leopard, Red Wolf

"This is one of the best novels I've ever read. I always want my favorite poets to write novels and here it's happened. Ocean Vuong is a master. This book a masterpiece. On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous is an ode to loss and struggle, to being a Vietnamese American, to Hartford, Connecticut, and it's a compassionate epistolary ode to a mother who may or may not know how to read. I dog-eared so many pages the book almost collapsed—I almost did."

—Tommy Orange, author of Wandering Stars & There There

"Ocean Vuong runs up against the limits of language—this book is addressed to a mother who cannot read it—and expands our sense of what literature can make visible, thinkable, felt across borders and generations and genres. This is a courageous, embodied inquiry into the tangle of colonial and personal histories. It is also a gorgeous argument for astonishment over irony—for the transformative possibilities of love."

—Ben Lerner, author of The Topeka School, Leaving the Atocha Station & 10:04

title: Water Mirror Echo
subtitle: Bruce Lee and the Making of Asian America
long_summary:
More than a half-century after his death, Bruce Lee remains a towering global icon. He popularized martial arts in the West, bridged Eastern and Western cultures, and was poised to conquer Hollywood when cerebral edema claimed his life at thirty-two. His legend has only grown since—but it has also eclipsed the man himself.

Forgotten is the reality of a baby born in segregated San Francisco who spent his youth in war-ravaged, fight-crazy Hong Kong. Forgotten is the curious teenager who returned to America, embracing West Coast counterculture while staying rooted in Asian philosophies. Forgotten is the man whose very presence broke barriers and helped define what it meant to be Asian in America at the dawn of Asian America.

Water Mirror Echo—titled after Lee's own philosophy of movement and response—reclaims that story. Award-winning author Jeff Chang, whose cultural criticism has made him one of our most distinctive voices, brings authenticity and depth to Lee's biography. Based on intimate interviews with Lee's closest confidants, thousands of newly available personal documents, and dozens of gorgeous family photographs, Chang achieves the nearly impossible: revealing the man behind the mythology while showing how Lee's fame ushered in something even more enduring—the creation of Asian America itself.
short_summary: Jeff Chang excavates the man behind the Bruce Lee mythology, revealing how a curious kid from segregated San Francisco became both global icon and catalyst for Asian America. Intimate, sweeping, and essential cultural biography.
author_bios: Jeff Chang's Can't Stop Won't Stop: A History of the Hip-Hop Generation was named one of the best American nonfiction books of the last quarter century. A USA Ford Fellow in Literature, he has won the American Book Award and Asian American Literary Award. Chang has written three other acclaimed bestsellers on American history, culture, and the arts. He co-created a PBS digital series adaptation of We Gon' Be Alright and has been featured in ESPN's Be Water, PBS's Asian Americans, and CNN's This Is Life.
quotes:
"Water Mirror Echo is a remarkable story of a man, the traditions and communities that created him, and the new worlds he made possible. Like Bruce Lee himself, Jeff Chang is blessed with the vision to see things we do not yet see, thinking and writing with a restless, chasm-crossing, almost prophetic ambition."

—Hua Hsu, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Stay True: A Memoir

"[A] panoramic biography.... Peppering the narrative with rich historical details and poignant analyses, Chang persuasively argues that Lee's presence on screen helped shape the idea of what it means to be Asian in America. This definitive account cements Chang as a preeminent chronicler of Asian American history."

—Publishers Weekly

"This book is as celebratory as it is incisive, as it is, at times, heartbreaking. A massive achievement."

—Hanif Abdurraqib, National Book Award-winning author of There's Always This Year and A Little Devil in America

title: Once Upon a River
long_summary:
Bonnie Jo Campbell has created an unforgettable heroine in sixteen-year-old Margo Crane, a beauty whose unflinching gaze and uncanny ability with a rifle have not made her life any easier. After her father's violent death, in which she is complicit, Margo takes to the Stark River in her boat with only a few supplies and a biography of Annie Oakley, searching for her vanished mother.

But the river—Margo's childhood paradise—proves dangerous for a young woman traveling alone. She must rely on her knowledge of the natural world and her ability to look unsparingly into the hearts of those around her to survive. Her odyssey through rural Michigan becomes a defining journey, one that leads her beyond mere self-preservation to confronting what price she's willing to pay for her choices.
short_summary: After her father's violent death, sixteen-year-old Margo Crane takes to Michigan's waterways searching for her missing mother. Campbell crafts a fierce coming-of-age tale about survival, identity, and the dangerous currents of both rivers and human nature.
author_bios: Bonnie Jo Campbell is the author of six works of fiction, including American Salvage, finalist for the National Book Award and the National Book Critics Circle Award, and Once Upon a River, a national bestseller. She's received a Guggenheim Fellowship, AWP's Grace Paley Prize for Short Fiction, and a Pushcart Prize. She lives outside Kalamazoo, Michigan, with her husband and donkeys.
quotes:
"Campbell is a bard, a full-throated singer whose melodies are odes to farms and water and livestock and fishing rods and rifles, and to hardworking folks who know the value of life as well as the randomness of life's troubles."

—Lisa Schwarzbaum, Entertainment Weekly
