For cynical Americans, disaster buffs, and engineers, Challenger will be a quick, devastating read. In Higginbotham's deft hands, the human element—sometimes heroic, sometimes cloaked in doublespeak and bluster—shines through the many technical aspects of this story, a constant reminder that every decision was made by people weighing risks versus expediency, their minds distorted by power, money, politics, and yes-men. It's a universal story that transcends time."

—The New York Times

title: The Book of Aron
long_summary:
Aron is an engaging but troubled young boy whose family flees the German invasion from rural Poland to Warsaw, where they face escalating deprivation, disease, and persecution. He joins a handful of children who risk their lives smuggling contraband through the ghetto's quarantine walls, desperately trying to keep their families alive while dodging blackmailers and Jewish, Polish, and German police—not to mention the Gestapo.

When Aron's family is finally torn away, he finds refuge with Janusz Korczak, a doctor celebrated throughout prewar Europe as a champion of children's rights. Under Nazi rule, Korczak runs the Warsaw orphanage, but Treblinka looms ahead for them all. The question becomes whether Aron can escape—as his mentor believes possible—to bear witness to these atrocities.

Shepard masterfully crafts this child's perspective on history's darkest chapter into something mesmerizing and, against all odds, sometimes even comic. The result is truly heartbreaking yet inspiring, with a voice that lingers long after the final page.
short_summary: Young Aron smuggles contraband through Warsaw's ghetto walls, fighting to keep his family alive during the Holocaust. Shepard transforms this harrowing story into something mesmerizing and unforgettable through a child's eyes.
author_bios: Jim Shepard is the author of seven novels, including The Book of Aron (winner of the PEN New England Award, the Sophie Brody Medal, the Ribalow Prize, and the Clark Fiction Prize, and a finalist for the National Jewish Book Award), and five story collections, including Like You'd Understand, Anyway, a National Book Award finalist and winner of The Story Prize. His fiction appears in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, The Paris Review, and The Atlantic, and has been anthologized in The Best American Short Stories and The PEN/O. Henry Prize Stories. He teaches at Williams College.
quotes:
"Shepard has created a stark masterpiece. His brilliant, iconic book ranks with the best literature that explores the dark side of the human soul."

—Linda Diebel, The Toronto Star

"An immensely rewarding, shocking and beautiful book. . . . Shepard, who for years has been one of this country's greatest fiction writers, is as original here as he has ever been. . . . Aron himself becomes an unforgettable character almost instantly."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"A masterpiece. . . a remarkable novel destined to join the shelf of essential Holocaust literature. . . . a story of such startling candor about the complexity of heroism that it challenges each of us to greater courage. . . . Shepard has created something transcendent and timeless."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: The Violinist's Thumb
subtitle: And Other Lost Tales of Love, War, and Genius, as Written by Our Genetic Code
long_summary:
In The Disappearing Spoon, bestselling author Sam Kean unlocked the mysteries of the periodic table. In The Violinist's Thumb, he explores the wonders of DNA—life's magical building block.

Kean reveals genes that explain everything from crazy cat ladies to people born without fingerprints, from nuclear bomb survivors to JFK's bronze skin (spoiler: it wasn't a tan). He shows how genetics illuminates Einstein's genius and proves that Neanderthals and humans bred far more recently than we'd like to think.

Some people, blessed with exceptionally flexible thumbs and fingers, can become truly singular violinists—hence the book's title. Kean's vibrant storytelling makes science entertaining, weaving together human history, scientific whimsy, and insights into how DNA will shape our species' future.
short_summary: From crazy cat ladies to Einstein's genius, Kean transforms genetics into witty tales of human oddity and scientific discovery. Science writing that's actually fun to read.
author_bios: Sam Kean is the New York Times bestselling author of The Bastard Brigade, Caesar's Last Breath (the Guardian's Science Book of the Year), The Tale of the Dueling Neurosurgeons, The Violinist's Thumb, and The Disappearing Spoon. A two-time PEN/E.O. Wilson Literary Science Writing Award finalist, his work appears in The Best American Science and Nature Writing, The New Yorker, The Atlantic, and the New York Times Magazine. He's been featured on NPR's Radiolab, All Things Considered, Science Friday, and Fresh Air. His podcast debuted at #1 on iTunes science charts.
quotes:
"Kean is one of America's smartest and most charming science writers, and his new book could be perfect for summer readers who prefer some substance with their fun."

—Michael Schaub, NPR

"As he did in his debut bestseller, The Disappearing Spoon, Sam Kean educates readers about a facet of science with wonderfully witty prose and enthralling anecdotes....Kean's thoughtful, humorous book is a joy to read."

—Publishers Weekly

"Kean's accessible genetic overview, written for the layman, is often as simple and elegant as a double helix."

—Keith Staskiewicz, Entertainment Weekly

title: Super Sad True Love Story
long_summary:
In a very near future, a functionally illiterate America teeters on collapse. But don't tell that to Lenny Abramov, a thirty-nine-year-old son of an angry Russian immigrant, proud author of what may be the world's last diary, and owner of a bald spot shaped like Ohio. Despite working at Post-Human Services—which provides immortality for super-rich clients—death stalks this cholesterol-rich man.

Lenny's from a different century. He loves books (now called "printed, bound media artifacts"), though his peers find them smelly and annoying. Even more than books, he loves Eunice Park, an impossibly cute and cruel twenty-four-year-old Korean American who graduated from Elderbird College with a major in Images and a minor in Assertiveness.

After meeting on a Roman holiday, blistering Eunice teaches this "ancient dork" to brush his teeth properly and buy flame-resistant clothes. But America proves less fire-resistant than Lenny's wardrobe. Credit crisis crushes the country, riots erupt in Central Park, National Guard tanks line streets, and patient Chinese creditors prepare to foreclose on the whole mess.

Undeterred, Lenny vows to love both Eunice and his homeland, determined to prove there's still value in being human.
short_summary: Lenny Abramov keeps a diary in dystopian America where books are obsolete and the country's collapsing. His obsession with a cruel younger woman becomes both salvation and torment in Shteyngart's prescient satire.
author_bios: Gary Shteyngart was born in Leningrad in 1972 and came to the United States seven years later. His debut novel, The Russian Debutante's Handbook, won the Stephen Crane Award for First Fiction and the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction. His second novel, Absurdistan, was named one of the 10 Best Books of the Year by The New York Times Book Review. His novel Super Sad True Love Story won the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize. His memoir, Little Failure, was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. His books have been published in thirty countries.
quotes:
"[A] smart send-up of our info-overload age… Love Story is funny, on-target, and ultimately sad as it captures the absurdity and anxiety of navigating an increasingly out-of-control world."

—Entertainment Weekly

"This cyber-apocalyptic vision of an American future seems eerily like the present, in a bleak comedy that is even more frightening than funny. Though Shteyngart received rave reviews for his first two novels (The Russian Debutante's Daughter, 2001; Absurdistan, 2006), those appear in retrospect to be trial runs for his third and darkest to date."

—Kirkus

"[A] profane and dizzying satire, a dystopic vision of the future as convincing-and, in its way, as frightening as Cormac McCarthy's The Road. It's also a pointedly old-fashioned May-December love story. . . . a heartbreaker worthy of its title, this is Shteyngart's best yet."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Invisible Kingdom
subtitle: Reimagining Chronic Illness
long_summary:
A silent epidemic of chronic illnesses afflicts tens of millions of Americans—diseases that are poorly understood, frequently marginalized, and often go undiagnosed altogether. Renowned writer Meghan O'Rourke delivers a revelatory investigation into this elusive category of "invisible" illness that encompasses autoimmune diseases, post-treatment Lyme syndrome, and long COVID.

Drawing on her own medical experiences and a decade of interviews with doctors, patients, researchers, and public health experts, O'Rourke traces how Western definitions of illness have led us to ignore hard-to-understand conditions that resist easy description or simple cures. The populations most likely to be neglected include women, the working class, and people of color.

Blending lyricism and erudition, candor and empathy, O'Rourke synthesizes her roles as critic, journalist, poet, and patient into one monumental project. The Invisible Kingdom offers hope for the sick, insight for their loved ones, and argues for a radical new understanding of our bodies and health.
short_summary: O'Rourke combines memoir, medical investigation, and cultural criticism to expose how millions suffer from misunderstood chronic illnesses. Essential reading that argues for a complete reimagining of how we approach disease and healing.
genres: Health & Fitness / Diseases & Conditions / Immune & Autoimmune
author_bios: Meghan O'Rourke is the author of The Long Goodbye and the poetry collections Sun in Days, Once, and Halflife. The recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship and other awards, she is the editor of The Yale Review. Her writing appears in The Atlantic Monthly, The New Yorker, and The New York Times.
quotes:
"The Invisible Kingdom is a vivid account of the lived experience of chronic illness. Meghan O'Rourke exposes a system of thought in which people with poorly understood illnesses are dismissed and disbelieved, blamed for their own suffering, and left to take desperate risks in pursuit of treatment. Crucially, her perspective offers insight into how we can do better."

—Eula Biss, author of On Immunity & Having and Being Had

"An authentically original voice and, perhaps more startlingly, an authentically original perspective….The book is not only a memoir of her illness, but also a document of years of research."

—Andrew Solomon, National Book Award-winning author of The Noonday Demon, in The New York Times

"With a poet's sensibility, journalist's rigor, and patient's personal investment, O'Rourke sheds light on the physical and mental toll of having a mysterious chronic illness…Readers will be left in awe."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Telling Room
subtitle: A Tale of Love, Betrayal, Revenge, and the World's Greatest Piece of Cheese
long_summary:
In 1991, while working at a gourmet deli in Ann Arbor, Michael Paterniti encountered a legendary piece of cheese. This was Paramo de Guzman, a rare Spanish queso reputed to be the finest—and most expensive—in the world. Made from an ancient family recipe in the medieval Castilian village of Guzman (population 80), the cheese was submerged in olive oil and aged in a cave where it supposedly gained magical qualities. Legend claimed that eating it might recover long-lost memories.

Too broke to buy the cheese, Paterniti made a quixotic vow: he would meet this cheese again someday. Ten years later, he finally found his way—family in tow—to that tiny hilltop village to meet the famous cheesemaker himself, a voluble, magnetic, heartbroken genius named Ambrosio.

What Paterniti discovers in Guzman is nothing like the idyllic slow-food fable he imagined. Instead, he wanders into the heart of an unfolding mystery, becoming deeply implicated as the village begins to spill its long-held secrets. Nothing is quite what it seems in this transporting work of literary journalism.
short_summary: Ten years after encountering a legendary Spanish cheese, journalist Michael Paterniti travels to a tiny Castilian village to meet its maker. What begins as culinary quest becomes something far more mysterious and profound.
author_bios: Michael Paterniti is a journalist, essayist, and bestselling author of Driving Mr. Albert and The Telling Room, the latter named one of the best books of the year by NPR, Entertainment Weekly, and The Christian Science Monitor. Nominated eight times for the National Magazine Award, he's also received an NEA grant and two MacDowell Fellowships. His stories have appeared in The New York Times Magazine, National Geographic, Harper's, Outside, Esquire, and GQ, where he works as a correspondent. He co-founded a children's storytelling center in Portland, Maine, where he lives with his wife and three children.
quotes:
"Michael Paterniti is one of the best living practitioners of the art of literary journalism, able to fully elucidate and humanize the everyday and the epic. In his hands, every subject, every moment of personal or global upheaval, is treated with the same curiosity, respect, empathy, and clear-eyed wisdom."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King

"For my money, Paterniti is one of the most expansive and joyful writers around-big-hearted and humane and funny. This book is a wild and amazing ride."

—George Saunders, author of Tenth of December

"Captivating…Paterniti's writing sings, whether he's talking about how food activates memory, or the joys of watching his children grow."

—NPR

title: Mecca
long_summary:
Johnny Frias has California in his blood. A descendant of the state's Indigenous people and Spanish settlers, he carries Southern California's forgotten towns and canyons in his soul. He spends his days working for the California Highway Patrol, pulling over speeders, ignoring their racist insults, and pushing past the trauma of his rookie year when he killed a man assaulting a young woman named Bunny—who then ran away.

But like the Santa Ana winds that bring annual risk of fire, Johnny's moment of action twenty years ago sparks a slow-burning chain of connections. It unites a vibrant, complex cast of characters in ways they never saw coming.

In Mecca, celebrated novelist Susan Straight crafts an unforgettable American epic, examining race, history, family, and destiny through interlocking stories of native Californians all gasping for air. With sensitivity, fury, and cinematic scope, she captures California in all its injustice, history, and glory. This is the American West told through the eyes of the people who built it—and continue to sustain it.
short_summary: Johnny Frias carries California's Indigenous and Spanish heritage in his blood, but a violent encounter from his past as a highway patrol officer ignites unexpected connections across communities. Straight weaves an epic portrait of native Californians fighting for survival and belonging.
author_bios: Susan Straight has published nine novels, including Mecca, A Million Nightingales, and Highwire Moon, and one memoir, In the Country of Women. She's been a finalist for the National Book Award, Kirkus Prize, and Dayton Literary Peace Prize, and received the Lannan Prize, O. Henry Award, Edgar Award, Guggenheim Fellowship, and Robert Kirsch Award for lifetime achievement. Born in Riverside, California, where she lives with her family.
quotes:
"Susan Straight writes like a dream. In Mecca the landscapes and the passions of California come vividly and unforgettably to life, adding another triumph to her oeuvre, and one more gift to the literature of the West. Once again, Straight shines a light on the people at the margins of our seemingly prosperous country, illuminating their lives with her boundless empathy."

—Héctor Tobar, author of Deep Down Dark & The Last Great Road Bum

"A terrifically engaging novel about a network of people related by blood, love and duty . . . what might be most impressive about this novel is how large it becomes without ever feeling bloated by extraneous plotlines or too neatly sewn up . . . Remarkably, the most persistent impression here is not one of suffering but of determined survival, even triumph."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"Against the alternating currents of boosterism and doom-speak so often associated with California, Susan Straight's Mecca focuses on the people who don't usually appear in literary and cinematic depictions of a place so big it could be a country. A heartbreaker from beginning to end, Mecca both shocks and moves in its powerful and unrelenting portrait of this sunny, fiery state."

—Viet Thanh Nguyen, author of The Sympathizer and The Committed

title: A Wilder Shore
subtitle: The Romantic Odyssey of Fanny and Robert Louis Stevenson
long_summary:
He was an ambitious but drifting writer from a prominent Scottish family. She was a tough Nevada silver miner's wife with children. Who could have predicted that Fanny Van de Grift and Robert Louis Stevenson would create one of history's great literary marriages?

From their first encounter in France in 1876, Fanny and Louis's partnership transcended societal expectations to become a literary union that was progressive, eccentric, and tempestuous, but always animated by profound mutual respect. Seeking creative freedom, inspiration, and better health for Louis, who battled chronic illness, they embarked on a whirlwind journey around the world—from the bohemian enclaves of Europe to the shores of Samoa, where they joined native islanders' fight for independence from imperialist powers.

Amid their stormy yet deeply loving relationship, Fanny wrote colorful accounts of her life, contributed to Louis's work, and kept him alive to pen classics like Treasure Island, Kidnapped, and Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. A portrait of two extraordinary people and a testament to love's power to foster the human spirit, A Wilder Shore captures the resilience, courage, and devotion that sparked some of our most enduring literary masterpieces.
short_summary: The extraordinary story of Robert Louis Stevenson and Fanny Van de Grift's creative partnership. Their unconventional marriage defied Victorian norms and fueled the creation of literary classics like Treasure Island and Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.
author_bios: Camille Peri is an author and journalist who founded the groundbreaking website Mothers Who Think at Salon. She coedited the national bestseller Mothers Who Think: Tales of Real-Life Parenthood and Because I Said So: 33 Mothers Write About Children, Sex, Men, Aging, Faith, Race & Themselves, which received an American Book Award. She has written for Vogue, Ladies' Home Journal, Los Angeles Times Magazine, Mother Jones, and the San Francisco Chronicle.
quotes:
"[Peri's] richly researched and vivid double portrait makes a convincing case that Fanny pulled off a rare feat, enabling Louis's genius to mature while releasing his boyish energies . . . I am grateful to Peri for telling the story of their marriage, in all its complexity, with sympathy and spirit."

—Phyllis Rose, The Atlantic

"[A book] to lift your spirits . . . [Fanny's] support allowed Stevenson to write without distraction, and their circumvention of Victorian norms allowed for a marriage where love flourished."

—The Washington Post

"Ambitious . . . Speaking for myself, after reading A Wilder Shore, I'm inspired to do two things: I want to reread Robert Louis Stevenson's three great works of fiction: Treasure Island, Kidnapped and The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. And, I want to schedule a séance with Fanny to get some one-on-one instruction on how to live more fearlessly as a woman."

—NPR

title: All This Could Be Different
long_summary:
Fresh out of college during a brutal recession, Sneha lands an entry-level corporate job in Milwaukee—grueling work that becomes her lifeline to independence. She can finally pick up dinner tabs with her new friend Tig, get her college buddy Thom hired, and send money to her parents in India.

As Sneha begins dating women, she develops an intense crush on Marina, a captivating dancer who always seems just beyond reach. But stability proves fragile: painful secrets surface, jobs derail, evictions threaten. Despite deepening friendships and a dizzying romance with Marina, Sneha struggles with true intimacy and openness.

When their world starts crumbling, Tig proposes a radical solution to save them all. Rendered in singular, unforgettable prose, this wise and tender debut captures young people forging love and community amid struggle—a moving portrait of one immigrant's journey to make her home in the world.
short_summary: Fresh out of college, Sneha navigates corporate life, queer love, and friendship in recession-era Milwaukee. Mathews crafts an extraordinary debut about building community and finding home as a young immigrant in America.
author_bios: Sarah Thankam Mathews grew up between Oman and India, immigrating to the United States at seventeen. She's a recipient of fellowships from the Asian American Writers Workshop and the Iowa Writers Workshop. All This Could Be Different is her first novel.
quotes:
"All This Could Be Different is an extraordinary novel, spiny and delicate, scathingly funny and wildly moving. Sarah Thankam Mathews is a brilliant writer, one whose every ringing sentence holds both bite and heart."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates & Furies, Arcadia & Matrix

"Mathews's poignant and illuminating debut centers on an aloof 22-year-old Indian immigrant whose first job out of college brings her to the Midwest . . . Mathews [charts] the wonders of community-building, delving into the strenuous work that goes into sustaining meaningful friendships as well as the heartbreak that ensues when connections are fractured by dishonesty. [A] thoughtful exploration of how the legacies of trauma make an impact."

—Publishers Weekly

"Sarah Thankam Mathews's All This Could Be Different is a deeply honest and compelling testimony. It is breathtaking in its beauty and profound in its meaning. Mathews captures the complexities, contradictions, and dissonances of life with astounding aplomb and care. All This Could Be Different is quietly epic."

—Robert Jones, Jr., author of The Prophets

title: The Cold Millions
long_summary:
The Dolan brothers live by their wits, jumping freight trains and lining up for day work at crooked job agencies. While sixteen-year-old Rye yearns for a steady job and a home, his dashing older brother Gig dreams of a better world, fighting alongside other union men for fair pay and decent treatment.

Enter Ursula the Great, a vaudeville singer who performs with a live cougar, and who introduces the brothers to a far more dangerous creature: a wealthy mining magnate who will stop at nothing to keep his wealth and his hold on Ursula. Dubious of his brother's idealism, Rye finds himself drawn to a fearless nineteen-year-old activist and feminist named Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, her passion sweeping him into the workers' cause.

But a storm is coming, threatening to overwhelm them all, and Rye will be forced to decide where he stands. Is it enough to win the occasional battle, even if you cannot win the war?

Set against the panoramic backdrop of early twentieth-century America, this intimate story of brotherhood, love, sacrifice and betrayal offers a kaleidoscopic portrait of a nation grappling with the chasm between rich and poor. Featuring an unforgettable cast of cops and tramps, suffragists and socialists, madams and murderers, it's a powerful and moving tour de force that eerily echoes our own time.
short_summary: Two brothers ride the rails in early twentieth-century America—one an idealistic union fighter, the other just trying to survive. When they encounter a vaudeville performer and her dangerous patron, their bond faces the ultimate test.
author_bios: Jess Walter is the author of eight novels, including the bestsellers So Far Gone, The Cold Millions, and Beautiful Ruins, the National Book Award Finalist The Zero, and Citizen Vince, winner of the Edgar Award for best novel. His short fiction, collected in The Angel of Rome and We Live in Water, has won the O. Henry Prize, the Pushcart Prize and appeared three times in Best American Short Stories. As a reporter, he was a finalist for the 1993 Pulitzer Prize for his coverage of Ruby Ridge. He lives in Spokane, Washington.
quotes:
"The fact that the same author has written books as wildly different and all as transporting as The Zero, The Financial Lives of the Poets, Beautiful Ruins, and now this latest tour de force is testimony to Walter's protean storytelling power and astounding ability to set a scene, any scene…. We have heard that Jess Walter writes nonstop: Seven days a week, 365 days a year. Please, never stop."

—Kirkus

"A work of irresistible characters, harrowing adventures and rip-roaring fun … bursting with a dazzling range of outrageous characters…. One of the most captivating novels of the year."

—The Washington Post

"The Cold Millions is a literary unicorn: a book about socio-economic disparity that's also a page-turner, a postmodern experiment that reads like a potboiler, and a beautiful, lyric hymn to the power of social unrest in American history. It's funny and harrowing, sweet and violent, innocent and experienced; it walks a dozen tightropes. Jess Walter is a national treasure."

—Anthony Doerr, author of All the Light We Cannot See & Cloud Cuckoo Land

title: The Last Train to Zona Verde
subtitle: My Ultimate African Safari
long_summary:
Paul Theroux embarks on what he declares will be his final African journey, traveling from Cape Town through Namibia to Angola's remote corners. This isn't the romantic Africa of safari brochures, but a continent grappling with the legacy of colonialism, crushing poverty, and uncertain futures.

With his characteristic blend of curiosity and curmudgeonry, Theroux encounters everyone from fellow travelers to local guides, from aid workers to ordinary people trying to survive. He reflects honestly on his own privilege as a Western observer while documenting the raw realities he witnesses. The journey becomes both an external exploration of southern Africa's landscapes and communities, and an internal reckoning with what it means to be a lifelong traveler confronting mortality.

Theroux's prose captures both the beauty and brutality of the places he visits, offering no easy answers about Africa's challenges or his own complicated relationship with the continent. This is travel writing at its most unflinching—gorgeous, uncomfortable, and deeply human.
short_summary: Theroux's final African odyssey takes him from Cape Town to Angola's remote reaches. A master travel writer confronts mortality, privilege, and the continent's harsh realities with unflinching honesty.
author_bios: Paul Theroux is the author of many highly acclaimed books. His novels include Burma Sahib, The Bad Angel Brothers, The Lower River, Jungle Lovers, and The Mosquito Coast. His renowned travel books include The Last Train to Zona Verde, Ghost Train to the Eastern Star, On the Plain of Snakes, and Dark Star Safari. He lives in Hawaii and on Cape Cod.
quotes:
"Theroux's prose is as vividly descriptive and atmospheric as ever and, though a bit curmudgeonly, he's still wide open to raw, painful interactions between his psyche and his surroundings."

—Publishers Weekly (starred review)

"In this intensely personal book, Theroux honestly confronts racism, stigma, privilege and expectations...Reading this enlightening book won't only open a window into Theroux's mind, it will also impart a deeper understanding of Africa and travel in general."

—Kirkus

"Thoroughly engrossing—from Cape Town to Namibia to the Okavango Delta, Theroux is his inimitable, delightfully grouchy and incisive self…At times tragic, often comical and always gorgeously written, this is a paean to a continent, by a writer unafraid to give it some tough love."

—Washington Post

"He has no illusions about the fact that he is just a passing visitor (a privileged one at that), but that doesn't make his observations, or exquisite writing, any less engaging."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Theroux is at his best when he tells their stories, happy and sad...Theroux's great mission had always been to transport us beyond that reading chair, to challenge himself—and thus, to challenge us."

—The Boston Globe

title: A Little Life
long_summary:
Four college friends arrive in New York broke, adrift, and sustained only by their friendship and ambition as they chase fame and fortune. Over the decades, their relationships deepen and grow complicated—marked by addiction, success, and pride—but they remain bound together by their devotion to Jude, the most brilliant and enigmatic among them.

Jude carries the scars of an unspeakable childhood trauma that slowly reveals itself as the story unfolds. What emerges is both a hymn to brotherly bonds and an unflinching exploration of how we survive the worst life can offer. Yanagihara's masterful novel examines the families we're born into and those we create for ourselves, tracing how love persists and transforms across decades of joy and devastating loss.
short_summary: Four friends navigate decades of friendship in New York, bound together by their devotion to enigmatic Jude. An unflinching exploration of trauma, love, and the families we choose for ourselves.
author_bios: Hanya Yanagihara lives in New York City.
quotes:
"With her sensitivity to everything from the emotional nuance to the play of light inside a subway car, Yanagihara is superb at capturing the radiant moments of beauty, warmth and kindness that help redeem the bad stuff. In A Little Life, it's life's evanescent blessings that maybe, but only maybe, can save you."

—John Powers, NPR

"Through insightful detail and her decade-by-decade examination of these people's lives, Yanagihara has drawn a deeply realized character study that inspires as much as devastates. It's a life, just like everyone else's, but in Yanagihara's hands, it's also tender and large, affecting and transcendent; not a little life at all."

—Nicole Lee, The Washington Post

"This is a novel that values the everyday over the extraordinary, the push and pull of human relationships—and the book's effect is cumulative. There is real pleasure in following characters over such a long period, as they react to setbacks and successes, and, in some cases, change. By the time the characters reach their 50s and the story arrives at its moving conclusion, readers will be attached and find them very hard to forget."

—Publishers Weekly

title: There's Always This Year
subtitle: On Basketball and Ascension
long_summary:
Growing up in Columbus, Ohio, in the 1990s, Hanif Abdurraqib witnessed a golden era of basketball—one in which legends like LeBron James were forged and countless others weren't. His lifelong love of the game leads him into a lyrical exploration of what it means to make it, who deserves success, and the tension between excellence and expectation.

Abdurraqib weaves together basketball history with intimate personal storytelling, examining role models, fatherhood, and belonging. "Here is where I would like to tell you about the form on my father's jump shot," he writes. "The truth, though, is that I saw my father shoot a basketball only one time."

There's Always This Year is a triumph, brimming with joy, pain, solidarity, and hope. Abdurraqib's exquisite writing transforms every subject—basketball, music, performance—into poetry, offering a profound reimagining of how we think about culture, country, and ourselves.
short_summary: Basketball becomes poetry in Abdurraqib's mixtape-memoir of Ohio gyms, LeBron, and fatherhood. A meditation on making it and not making it, propulsive as a fast break and tender as a huddle.
genres: Social Science / Cultural & Ethnic Studies / American / African American & Black Studies
author_bios: Hanif Abdurraqib is a poet, essayist, and cultural critic from Columbus, Ohio, and recipient of a MacArthur Foundation "Genius" grant. His book A Little Devil in America won the Carnegie Medal and Gordon Burns Prize and was a National Book Award finalist. They Can't Kill Us Until They Kill Us was named a book of the year by NPR, Esquire, and others. Go Ahead in the Rain was a New York Times bestseller and National Book Critics Circle Award finalist.
quotes:
"Mesmerizing . . . not only the most original sports book I've ever read but one of the most moving books I've ever read, period."

—Steve James, director of Hoop Dreams

"Lyrically stunning and profoundly moving, the confessional text wanders through a variety of topics without ever losing its vulnerability, insight, or focus . . . A formally inventive, gorgeously personal triumph."

—Kirkus

"Cultural critic Abdurraqib returns with a triumphant meditation on basketball and belonging. . . . The narrative works as if by alchemy, forging personal anecdotes, sports history, and cultural analysis into a bracing contemplation of the relationship between sports teams and their communities. This is another slam dunk for Abdurraqib."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Soldiers and Kings
subtitle: Survival and Hope in the World of Human Smuggling
long_summary:
Political instability, poverty, climate change, and the demand for cheap labor fuel clandestine movement across borders. As those borders harden, the need for smugglers—or coyotes, or guides—increases every year. Yet the real lives of smugglers are only reported from a distance, using tired stereotypes that depict them as violent warlords.

To understand this essential yet extralegal billion-dollar global industry, internationally recognized anthropologist Jason De León embedded with smugglers moving migrants across Mexico over seven years. The result is unprecedented access to a hidden world.

SOLDIERS AND KINGS offers the first in-depth, character-driven look at human smuggling. This heart-wrenching narrative revolves around one coyote who falls in love and tries to leave smuggling behind. De León chronicles the lives of low-level foot soldiers breaking into the game and morally conflicted gang leaders who oversee ragtag crews along the migrant trail. This groundbreaking work is both an intimate glimpse into a difficult-to-access world and a masterpiece of narrative nonfiction.
short_summary: Seven years embedded with human smugglers across Mexico yields this unprecedented look at the clandestine world of migration. De León's intimate, character-driven narrative follows coyotes trying to survive in a billion-dollar underground industry.
author_bios: Jason De León is professor of Anthropology and Chicana/o Studies and director of the Cotsen Institute of Archaeology at UCLA. He's executive director of the Undocumented Migration Project and a 2017 MacArthur Foundation Fellow. His previous book, The Land of Open Graves: Living and Dying on the Migrant Trail, won multiple awards.
quotes:
"This is a real one. A work of extraordinary reportage and compassion, Soldiers and Kings takes us deep inside the lives of smugglers guiding desperate migrants across Latin America. One breathtaking scene follows another, rendered in vibrant, unsparing prose documenting grinding poverty and violence, but also young love and redemption. It will shock you, move you, and leave you changed."

—Matthew Desmond, Pulitzer Prize-winning and New York Times bestselling author of Evicted and Poverty, by America

"A harrowing account of the work of human smugglers in bringing aspirational immigrants to America's southern border...[and] an exemplary ethnography of central importance to any discussion of immigration policy or reform."

—Kirkus

"A rare inside look at human smuggling on the border . . . Smuggling, [De León] says, 'is not the problem.' But as his own book memorably recounts, in a world with no shortage of problems, it's nevertheless one of them."

—The New York Times

title: Herscht 07769
long_summary:
Florian Herscht is a gentle giant with a catastrophic worldview. After faithfully attending Herr Köhler's adult education physics classes, he's convinced that disaster is imminent—the complete destruction of all physical matter. His solution? A one-sided correspondence with Chancellor Angela Merkel to warn her of the impending doom.

Meanwhile, Florian works for the Boss, head of a local neo-Nazi gang in the small eastern German town of Kana, who has given him work as a graffiti cleaner and a one-room apartment. The Boss is a Bach fanatic and amateur orchestra director, enraged by a graffiti artist defacing monuments to Johann Sebastian Bach throughout Thuringia with wolf emblems. Determined to catch the culprit, he enlists his gang—including Florian—in the chase.

When real wolves are sighted in the area, the situation spirals into chaos. Written as one cascading sentence with the power of atomic particles colliding, Krasznahorkai's tour de force is simultaneously a morality play, blistering satire, and devastating exploration of our helplessness against moral and environmental collapse.
short_summary: Written as one sprawling sentence, this urgent novel follows a gentle giant caught between neo-Nazis, particle physics, and a mysterious graffiti artist defacing Bach monuments in eastern Germany.
author_bios: László Krasznahorkai, winner of the 2019 National Book Award for Translated Literature and the 2015 Man Booker International Prize for lifetime achievement, was born in Gyula, Hungary.
quotes:
"The best new novel I have read this year is written in a single sentence that sprawls over 400 pages. Herscht 07769 by the Hungarian genius László Krasznahorkai [is] an urgent depiction of our global social and political crises, rendering our impotent slide into authoritarianism with compassionate clarity. It is also a book whose timeliness derives precisely from the way its unusual style disrupts the ordinary literary mechanics of time....A masterful study in what it means to keep trudging through a world that is always ending but will not end."

—Jacob Brogan, The Washington Post

"Krasznahorkai's latest postmodern experiment explores small-town discontents in post-unification eastern Germany. Brilliant, like all of Krasznahorkai's books—and just as challenging, though well worth the effort required."

—Kirkus

"Krasznahorkai's brilliantly cacophonous novel, which conveys the sense that the end is already here, and that the trappings of civilization are easier to scrape away than paint from stone. This stands with Krasznahorkai's best work."

—Publisher's Weekly

title: Blue Nights
long_summary:
From one of our most powerful writers comes a work of stunning frankness about losing a daughter. Joan Didion examines her thoughts, fears, and doubts regarding parenthood, illness, and growing old, weaving together fragments of her childhood and married life with John Gregory Dunne and daughter Quintana Roo.

Blue Nights opens on July 26, 2010, as Didion thinks back to Quintana's wedding in New York seven years before. This triggers vivid snapshots of Quintana's childhood—in Malibu, in Brentwood, at school in Holmby Hills. Reflecting on her daughter and her role as a parent, Didion asks the candid questions any parent might: How did she fail? What cues did she miss? "How could I have missed what was clearly there to be seen?"

Seamlessly woven throughout are incidents that underscore Didion's own aging, something she finds difficult to acknowledge. Blue Nights—those long, light evening hours that signal the summer solstice, "the opposite of the dying of the brightness, but also its warning"—delivers the same incisive honesty that made The Year of Magical Thinking iconic, haunting and profoundly moving.
short_summary: Didion's devastating meditation on losing her daughter Quintana weaves together memory, aging, and the impossible questions of parenthood. Incisive and haunting—essential reading.
author_bios: Joan Didion (1934–2021) was one of the most distinct American literary voices of the last century, author of five novels and nine nonfiction books, including Slouching Towards Bethlehem, The White Album, Play It As It Lays, and bestsellers The Year of Magical Thinking, Blue Nights, and South and West. She received the National Book Award for Nonfiction and the National Book Foundation's Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters.
quotes:
"A haunting memoir . . . Didion is, to my mind, the best living essayist in America . . . What appears on the surface to be an elegantly, intelligently, deeply felt, precisely written story of the loss of a beloved child is actually an elegantly, intelligently, deeply felt, precisely written glimpse into the abyss, a book that forces us to understand, to admit, that there can be no preparation for tragedy, no protection from it, and so, finally, no consolation . . . The book has . . . an incantatory quality: it is a beautiful, soaring, polyphonic eulogy, a beseeching prayer the is sung even as one knows the answer to one's plea, and that answer is: No."

—Cathleen Schine, The New York Times

"Darkly riveting . . . The cumulative effect of watching her finger her recollections like beads on a rosary is unexpectedly instructive. None of us can escape death, but Blue Nights shows how Didion has, with the devastating force of her penetrating mind, learned to simply abide."

—Louisa Kamps, Elle

"Brilliant...Nothing Didion has written since Play It As It Lays seems to me as right and true as Blue Nights. Nothing she has written seems as purposeful and urgent to be told."

—Joe Woodward, The Huffington Post

title: The War for Gloria
long_summary:
Corey Goltz grows up in working-class Boston as the only child of Gloria, whose early ambitions were derailed but who has always given her son everything she can. Restless and dreaming of adventure, Corey instead faces a devastating blow at fifteen when Gloria is diagnosed with ALS.

Too late, his estranged father Leonard—a man of great charisma but dubious moral character—reenters their lives. Determined to be his mother's hero at any cost, Corey begins shouldering responsibility for her expensive medical care, pushing himself to his physical and emotional limits as her disease cruelly progresses.

As Leonard's influence over Corey grows, the young man must dismantle the myth of his father's genius and confront the darkness beneath it. Gritty and profoundly stirring, this is the story of a son straddling childhood and adulthood, whose fierce desire to protect his mother forces him to risk destroying his father.
short_summary: When fifteen-year-old Corey's mother is diagnosed with ALS, his charismatic but morally bankrupt father reappears. Shouldering crushing responsibility for her care, Corey must choose between protecting his mother and confronting his father's true nature.
author_bios: Atticus Lish is the author of The War for Gloria and Preparation for the Next Life, which won the 2015 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and the 2016 Grand Prix de Littérature Américaine. He lives in California.
quotes:
"Solemn, punishing, kinetic, in easy contact with dark areas of the psyche, and yet heartbreaking in its portrait of a mother and son facing her mortal illness . . . Lish's novel is powerful, intelligent, brooding and most of all convincing; it earns its emotions . . . It more than pays off on the promise of his first novel, Preparation for the Next Life, which won the 2015 PEN/Faulkner award . . . You never sense [Lish] is merely writing "quality fiction"; he seems to draw instead from a deep well of experience, especially when it comes to the tastes and textures of life on the economic margins . . . The War for Gloria works because the details are so casually drilled home . . . Gloria is this novel's great, glowing presence. Lish is exacting in his portraiture."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"The War For Gloria is an ambitious book with a lot to say about family loyalty and love . . . Lish is a sensational literary craftsman, using the words in his toolbelt to construct narrative that is at once coolly dispassionate and red hot with emotion . . . I will be thinking about The War For Gloria for a long time."

—Martha Anne Toll, NPR

"Unflinching and heartbreaking . . . Lish imbues the male characters' varied pitches of toxic masculinity with great sadness, smoothing the edges off their macho posturing, and he writes with devastating empathy of Gloria's highs and lows. This is a tremendous achievement."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Lost Children Archive
long_summary:
A mother and father set out with their two children, driving from New York to Arizona in the heat of summer. Their destination: Apacheria, the place the Apaches once called home. Why Apaches? asks the ten-year-old son. Because they were the last of something, answers his father.

In their car, they play games and sing along to music. But on the radio, there is news about an "immigration crisis": thousands of kids trying to cross the southwestern border into the United States, getting detained—or lost in the desert along the way.

As the family drives through Virginia to Tennessee, across Oklahoma and Texas, we sense they are on the brink of their own crisis. A fissure grows between the parents, one the children can almost feel beneath their feet. They are led, inexorably, to a grand, harrowing adventure—both in the desert landscape and within the chambers of their own imaginations.

Told through multiple compelling voices and blending texts, sounds, and images, this is an astonishing feat of literary virtuosity. It's a richly engaging story of how we document our experiences and remember what matters most, probing the nature of justice and equality with urgency and empathy.
short_summary: Two parallel journeys unfold as a family road trip collides with the immigration crisis at America's border. Luiselli weaves together intimate family drama and urgent political reality with breathtaking literary innovation.
author_bios: Valeria Luiselli was born in Mexico City and grew up in South Korea, South Africa, and India. She is the author of Sidewalks; the novels Faces in the Crowd and The Story of My Teeth; and Tell Me How It Ends: An Essay in Forty Questions. She is a MacArthur "Genius Grant" recipient; winner of two Los Angeles Times Book Prizes, an American Book Award, and the 2021 Dublin Literary Award; and has been nominated for the National Book Critics Circle Award twice and the Kirkus Prize three times. Her work has appeared in The New York Times, Granta, and McSweeney's, and has been translated into more than twenty languages.
quotes:
"Lost Children Archive is political . . . but Luiselli doesn't let this obscure her story about family: about a marriage coming apart and the bond between a sister and brother. She paints beautiful scenes of family and wonderful portraits of the children. It's a road trip: there are fights, there are meltdowns, there is singing, there are pit stops; most of all, there are stories. Luiselli's stories are special, the result of a towering intellect and a remarkable imagination."

—David Ebner, The Globe and Mail

"Impossibly smart, full of beauty, heart and insight. Everyone should read this book."

—Tommy Orange, author of There There

"The novel truly becomes novel again in Luiselli's hands—electric, elastic, alluring, new . . . She is a superb chronicler of children: the daughter and son feel piercingly real—perceptive, irreplaceable, wonderfully odd. The book [is] an archive of curiosities, yearnings, animated by the narrator's restless energy . . . It breaks out of the rhythms of the road trip, into a heart-stopping climax."

—Parul Sehgal, The New York Times

title: Thank You for Your Service
long_summary:
The wars of the past decade have been covered by brave and talented reporters, but none has reckoned with the psychology of these wars as intimately as Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist David Finkel. For The Good Soldiers, his bestselling account from the front lines of Baghdad, Finkel embedded with the men of the 2-16 Infantry Battalion during the infamous "surge"—a grueling fifteen-month tour that changed them all forever.

In Thank You for Your Service, Finkel has done something even more extraordinary. He has embedded with some of the same soldiers from the 2-16, but this time at home after their deployments have ended. He follows them through their most intimate, painful, and hopeful moments as they try to recover, creating an essential portrait of what life after war is like—not just for these soldiers, but for their wives, widows, children, and friends, and for the professionals struggling to undo the damage that has been done.

With his unparalleled reporting ability, Finkel climbs into the hearts and minds of those he writes about. Thank You for Your Service offers a complete picture of two essential questions: When we ask young men and women to go to war, what are we asking of them? And when they return, what are we thanking them for?
short_summary: Following soldiers from Iraq back to American soil, Finkel examines the hidden costs of war through intimate portraits of trauma, family struggles, and the fight for recovery.
author_bios: David Finkel is an editor and writer at The Washington Post and winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Explanatory Reporting. A MacArthur Fellowship recipient, he is the author of Thank You for Your Service and The Good Soldiers.
quotes:
"Together with its masterful prequel The Good Soldiers, [Thank You for Your Service] measures the wages of the war in Iraq--the wages of war, period--as well as anything I've read . . . [Finkel] atones for our scant attention by paying meticulous heed."

—Frank Bruni, The New York Times

"I'm urging everyone I know to give Thank You for Your Service just a few pages, a few minutes out of their busy lives. The families honored in this urgent, important book will take it from there."

—Katherine Boo, National Book Award–winning author of Behind the Beautiful Forevers

"In a series of interconnected stories, Finkel follows a handful of soldiers and their spouses through the painful, sometimes-fatal process of reintegration into American society. The author gives a clear-eyed, frightening portrayal of precisely what it is like to suffer with post-traumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury and what it is like to have the specter of suicide whispering into your ear every day."

—Kirkus

title: A Children's Bible
long_summary:
Pulitzer Prize finalist Lydia Millet's sublime new novel follows twelve eerily mature children on a forced vacation with their families at a sprawling lakeside mansion.

Contemptuous of their parents, who pass their days in a stupor of liquor, drugs, and sex, the children feel both neglected and suffocated. When a destructive storm descends on the summer estate, the group's ringleaders—including Eve, who narrates the story—decide to run away, leading the younger ones into the apocalyptic chaos outside.

As scenes of devastation begin to mirror events in the dog-eared picture Bible carried by her beloved little brother, Eve devotes herself to keeping him safe from harm. A prophetic, heartbreaking story of generational divide and a haunting vision of what awaits us on the far side of Revelation.
short_summary: Twelve children abandon their dysfunctional parents when environmental disaster strikes their lakeside retreat. Millet crafts a haunting allegory about generational betrayal and climate collapse.
author_bios: Lydia Millet is the author of A Children's Bible, a finalist for the National Book Award and a New York Times Top Ten book of the Year. Her first work of short fiction, Love in Infant Monkeys, was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. She lives outside Tucson, Arizona.
quotes:
"[A] blistering little classic…Millet's wit and her penchant for strange twists produce the kind of climate fiction we need: a novel that moves beyond the realm of reporting and editorial, a story that explores how alarming and baffling it feels to endure the destruction of one's world. Take this book, eat it up."

—Ron Charles, Washington Post

"Eco-fiction dystopias often make our climate future outright calamities of tidal waves and massive tree die-offs. Millet…knows what's coming is likely to be more subtle, and the slow-motion collapse she imagines in her latest novel is what makes it so harrowing."

—Mark Athitakis, Kirkus

"Blazingly witty."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: The Fault in Our Stars
long_summary:
Despite the tumor-shrinking medical miracle that has bought her a few years, Hazel has never been anything but terminal, her final chapter inscribed upon diagnosis. But when a gorgeous plot twist named Augustus Waters suddenly appears at Cancer Kid Support Group, Hazel's story is about to be completely rewritten.

Insightful, bold, irreverent, and raw, The Fault in Our Stars brilliantly explores the funny, thrilling, and tragic business of being alive and in love. Green's most ambitious and heartbreaking work refuses to sentimentalize its subject, instead finding genuine humor and hope in the face of mortality.
short_summary: Two teenagers with cancer fall in love and confront mortality with humor, irreverence, and unflinching honesty. Green refuses to sentimentalize, finding genuine hope in the most heartbreaking circumstances.
author_bios: John Green is the award-winning, #1 bestselling author of Looking for Alaska, The Fault in Our Stars, Turtles All the Way Down, and Everything is Tuberculosis. His books have received a Printz Medal, Printz Honor, and Edgar Award. He's been a two-time Los Angeles Times Book Prize finalist and was named one of TIME's 100 Most Influential People. He hosts the podcast The Anthropocene Reviewed and co-created Vlogbrothers and Crash Course with his brother Hank.
quotes:
"This is a book that breaks your heart—not by wearing it down, but by making it bigger until it bursts."

—The Atlantic

"[Green's] voice is so compulsively readable that it defies categorization. You will be thankful for the little infinity you spend inside this book."

—NPR

"John Green deftly mixes the profound and the quotidian in this tough, touching valentine to the human spirit."

—The Washington Post

title: Sam Bed Different Dreams
long_summary:
In 1919, far-flung patriots establish the Korean Provisional Government to protest Japanese occupation. Though mostly symbolic, this government-in-exile becomes the foundation for an extraordinary what-if: What if the KPG still existed, secretly working toward Korean reunification?

Soon Sheen, a former writer now employed by tech giant GLOAT, discovers an unfinished manuscript seemingly authored by the KPG. The book reveals a riveting revisionist history connecting famous figures to the organization's grand project—from Syngman Rhee and architect-poet Yi Sang to Jack London and Marilyn Monroe. M*A*S*H appears alongside the Moonies, while a thread of violence stretches from President McKinley's assassination to a Reagan-era passenger plane downing that nearly triggers global war.

Park weaves together three distinct narrative voices with mysterious archival images, twisting reality like a kaleidoscope. Korean history collides with American pop culture and our tech-saturated present in this raucously funny feat of imagination—a thrilling blend of history and fiction that pulls readers into an alternate dimension where utopia remains possible.
short_summary: A kaleidoscopic alternate history imagining a secret Korean government still operating today. Park connects assassins and poets, pop culture and politics in a wildly inventive novel about hidden histories and impossible dreams.
author_bios: Ed Park is the author of the novels Personal Days and Same Bed Different Dreams. A founding editor of The Believer, he has worked in newspapers, book publishing, and academia. His writing appears in The New Yorker, The New York Review of Books, Harper's Magazine, The Atlantic, and elsewhere. Born in Buffalo, he lives in Manhattan with his family.
quotes:
"I can't stop reading, thinking, and dreaming about this feverish, mind-altering marvel of a book."

—Hua Hsu, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Stay True

"A novel to get lost in and a feat of imagination . . . I read it with awe for its construction and for the sheer pleasure of its language."

—Charles Yu, National Book Award–winning author of Interior Chinatown

"Same Bed Different Dreams is a kaleidoscope of Koreamericana; a crowd of cracked voices; a gorgeous, hilarious, provisional dream; a wonder."

—Namwali Serpell, author of The Furrows

title: Things in Nature Merely Grow
long_summary:
"There is no good way to say this," Yiyun Li writes at the beginning of this book. "There is no good way to state these facts, which must be acknowledged. My husband and I had two children and lost them both: Vincent in 2017, at sixteen, James in 2024, at nineteen. Both chose suicide, and both died not far from home."

There is no good way to say this—because words fall short. It takes only an instant for death to become fact, "a single point in a timeline." Living now on this single point, Li turns to thinking and reasoning and searching for words that might hold a place for James.

Li does what she can: "doing the things that work," including not just writing but gardening, reading Camus and Wittgenstein, learning the piano, and living thinkingly alongside death.

This is a book for James, but it is not a book about grieving or mourning. As Li writes, "The verb that does not die is to be. Vincent was and is and will always be Vincent. James was and is and will always be James. We were and are and will always be their parents. There is no now and then, now and later, only, now and now and now and now." Things in Nature Merely Grow is a testament to Li's indomitable spirit.
short_summary: Yiyun Li's extraordinary work of radical acceptance as she considers the loss of her son James. A testament to an indomitable spirit that refuses to look away.
author_bios: Yiyun Li is the author of Wednesday's Child; The Book of Goose; Must I Go; Where Reasons End; Kinder Than Solitude; Gold Boy, Emerald Girl; The Vagrants; A Thousand Years of Good Prayers; and the memoir Dear Friend, from My Life I Write to You in Your Life. She has received a PEN/Faulkner Award, PEN/Malamud Award, PEN/Hemingway Award, PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, MacArthur Fellowship, and Windham-Campbell Prize, and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. She teaches at Princeton University.
quotes:
"A memoir unlike others, strange and profound and fiercely determined not to look away."

—The New York Times

"Li recounts both boys' lives with palpable love and paints complex, distinct portraits of each . . . Readers who've dealt with their own tragedies will find comfort and understanding here."

—Publishers Weekly

"To be in Li's head is a rare privilege—she is a writer of elegance and clarity and is a deeply interesting thinker. And the book, surprisingly, is not sad. It is moving and even funny in places as she writes about her wonderful friends, a few awful strangers, but most of all her extraordinary sons. You may find yourself transformed after reading it. I did."

—NPR

title: My Work
long_summary:
After giving birth, Anna is utterly lost. She and her family move to the unfamiliar, snowy city of Stockholm, where anxiety threatens to completely engulf her. She obsessively devours online news and compulsively orders clothes she can't afford.

To avoid sinking deeper into depression, she forces herself to read and write. What emerges is a raw, uncompromising exploration of new motherhood that refuses to romanticize the experience.

My Work is a genre-defying novel that mixes fiction, essay, poetry, memoir, and letters to explore the relationship between motherhood, work, individuality, and literature. Ravn writes with unflinching honesty about the fundamental experience of giving birth and its aftermath—the way it transforms not just your body, but your entire sense of self.
short_summary: Genre-defying fiction about new motherhood that refuses all sentimentality. Ravn mixes poetry, memoir, and raw honesty to explore how giving birth transforms your entire sense of self.
author_bios: Olga Ravn is a Danish novelist and poet. She edited a selection of Tove Ditlevsen's texts for Gyldendal that relaunched Ditlevsen's readership worldwide. Her novel The Employees was shortlisted for the Booker Prize in 2021.
quotes:
"My Work is ferocious, horrific, elegant, insightful, irreverent, and funny. Can a woman still be a person after motherhood? Of course not, Ravn argues, or rather, admits. And in prose, poems, and journal entries, she documents all the absurdity and repulsiveness of growing a creature in your body and then raising it. It is a magnificent and satisfying meditation. One of the most honest and revelatory works of fiction about motherhood I have ever read. Ravn's writing is ecstatic, philosophical, and addictive."

—Heather O'Neill

"[My Work] is exactly right, capturing the overwhelming disorientation of early motherhood… It should be read by everyone."

—Thessaly La Force, The New York Times

"An unflinchingly honest reflection of a woman's experience of her own body as it becomes a body that belongs also to the child. This experience includes beauty and pain, rage and tenderness, fear, suspicion, doubt…A stunning book that speaks aloud thoughts the reader believed had been theirs alone in long nursery hours of the night."

—Kirkus

title: Is a River Alive?
long_summary:
Hailed in the New York Times as "a naturalist who can unfurl a sentence with the breathless ease of a master angler," Robert Macfarlane brings his glittering style to a profound exploration of an ancient, urgent idea: that rivers are living beings who should be recognized as such in imagination and law.

Macfarlane takes readers on three unforgettable journeys: to the miraculous cloud-forests and mountain streams of Ecuador, to the wounded creeks and lagoons of India, and to the spectacular wild rivers of Canada—imperiled respectively by mining, pollution, and dams. Braiding these journeys is the life story of the fragile chalk stream a mile from Macfarlane's house, a waterway that flows through his own years and days.

Powered by dazzling prose and illuminated by other minds and voices, this is travel writing, reportage, and natural history at its finest—a joyful, mind-expanding work that will open hearts, challenge perspectives, and remind us that our fate flows with that of rivers.
short_summary: Three journeys across Ecuador, India, and Canada explore whether rivers should be considered living beings with legal rights. Macfarlane's luminous prose transforms travel writing into something transcendent.
author_bios: Robert Macfarlane is the internationally bestselling author of Underland, The Old Ways, The Wild Places, and other award-winning books translated into more than thirty languages. His collaborations include The Lost Words and The Lost Spells with Jackie Morris, as well as films and stage works. A recipient of the E. M. Forster and Henry David Thoreau prizes, he is a fellow of Emmanuel College, Cambridge.
quotes:
"Rivers in Ecuador, India, and Canada provide the settings for this elegant travelogue, which asks whether a natural entity, such as a river, can be regarded as a living thing."

—The New Yorker

"Like its subject, Is a River Alive? is work of flow and counter-flow. It is lyrical, evocative, closely observed, and deeply moving. Robert Macfarlane offers new ways to think and, just as importantly, feel about the majestic and mysterious non-human world."

—Elizabeth Kolbert, author of The Sixth Extinction

"A lyrical inquiry into the implications of treating rivers as living beings worthy of reverence and legal rights. … Macfarlane skillfully braids his immersive travel writing with illuminating historical background, all told in lithe prose. Nature lovers will be riveted."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Joyride
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
"The story of my life is the story of my stories," writes Susan Orlean in this extraordinary memoir from one of narrative nonfiction's greatest practitioners. Joyride is a magic carpet ride through Orlean's life and career, where every day offers discovery and every moment holds potential for wonder.

Throughout her storied career, curiosity draws her to explore the most ordinary and extraordinary places—from getting inside the head of a regular ten-year-old boy for her legendary profile "The American Man Age Ten" to reporting on a woman who owns twenty-seven tigers, from capturing the routine magic of Saturday night to climbing Mt. Fuji.

Orlean's account offers invaluable insights for writers and an essential guide to embracing any creative path. She reveals her process of dreaming up ideas, managing deadlines, connecting with sources, confronting writer's block, and crafting the perfect lede.

While Orlean has always written her way into other people's lives, Joyride is her most personal book—a searching journey through finding her feet as a journalist, recovering from her first marriage's collapse, falling in love again, becoming a mother while mourning her own mother's decline, and confronting mortality. It's also a time machine to journalism's bygone era, from alt-weeklies' golden age to working alongside icons like Robert Gottlieb, Tina Brown, and David Remnick.
short_summary: Susan Orlean's most personal book yet—a luminous memoir about building a creative life. From legendary profiles to personal reckonings, she reveals how curiosity transforms the ordinary into the extraordinary.
author_bios: Susan Orlean has been a staff writer at The New Yorker since 1992. She is the New York Times bestselling author of seven books, including The Library Book, Rin Tin Tin, Saturday Night, and The Orchid Thief, which was made into the Academy Award–winning film Adaptation. She lives with her family in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"Readers will love it; writers will learn from it . . . Orlean's anecdotes sing with the pleasure of a person born to her passion and purpose."

—Carolyn Kellogg, Los Angeles Times

"In Joyride, the takeaway often has as much to do with the art of living as the art of writing. . . . It's Orlean's sense of mission that propels the reader along."

—Lauren Puckett-Pope, Elle

"Brilliant . . . A high-spirited, exhilarating memoir."

—Moira Hodgson, The Wall Street Journal

title: Wayward
long_summary:
Samantha Raymond's life is unraveling. Her mother is ill, her teenage daughter grows more distant by the day, and at fifty-two, she finds herself wide awake during "the Mids"—that liminal hour between three and four in the morning when women of a certain age contemplate motherhood, mortality, and the state of our fracturing nation.

When she impulsively buys a beautiful, crumbling house in a rough Syracuse neighborhood, she abandons her suburban existence—and her family—to grapple with what it means to be a wife, mother, and daughter in a country coming apart at the seams.

Spiotta's Wayward is a provocative exploration of aging, the female body, and the complexity of contemporary womanhood. Both brainy and sensual, it captures our strange historical moment—our resistance and reforms, our utopian longings, and the unexpected beauty found in ruins.
short_summary: When fifty-two-year-old Samantha Raymond impulsively buys a crumbling house in Syracuse, she abandons suburban life to navigate midlife reckonings. Spiotta crafts a provocative meditation on aging, motherhood, and contemporary American womanhood.
author_bios: Dana Spiotta is the author of Innocents and Others, winner of the St. Francis College Literary Prize and Los Angeles Times Book Prize finalist; Stone Arabia, a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist; Eat the Document, a National Book Award finalist; and Lightning Field. She has received a Guggenheim Fellowship, the Rome Prize, and the John Updike Prize from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She teaches in the Syracuse University MFA program.
quotes:
"What a thrilling experience to take a wayward journey along with Dana Spiotta's heroine, in the social landscape of America when America is probing its future, in a woman's complex internal landscape as she forges forward. Wayward is a fiercely funny and deliciously subversive novel."

—Yiyun Li

"An urgent, deeply moving, wholly original novel by one of the most wildly talented writers in America. This is Spiotta's best book yet, rich with all the joyful immersion-in-culture that characterized her earlier work, and of which she is a master, but with, it seems to me, more heart, hope, and urgency. There's not a smarter, more engaging, more celebratory writer working today than Dana Spiotta, and here she shows us to ourselves with stunning, sometimes lacerating, honesty, but also with a feeling of genuine hope for us, i.e., with kindness. I finished the book last night and woke this morning both fonder of, and more terrified for, America."

—George Saunders

"A dazzling lightning bolt of a novel which illuminates the sometimes exhilarating, sometimes heartbreaking moments of connection and disconnection in our lives. What begins as a vertiginous leap into hilarious rabbit holes ends as a brilliant meditation on mortality and time. How does she do it? Only Dana Spiotta knows. I'm just happy to see her work her magic."

—Jenny Offill

title: Faithful Place
long_summary:
In 1985, nineteen-year-old Frank Mackey was ready to escape Dublin's Faithful Place—the cramped flat, the poverty, his alcoholic father and unstable mother. He and Rosie Daly had it all planned: run away to London, get married, build new lives far from the suffocating neighborhood that trapped their families.

But Rosie never showed up that winter night. Frank assumed she'd dumped him, probably ashamed of his dysfunctional family. Heartbroken and humiliated, he left Dublin and never looked back. Neither did Rosie—or so everyone thought. The neighborhood assumed she'd made it to England and was living her dream life.

Twenty-two years later, Rosie's suitcase turns up behind a fireplace in a derelict Faithful Place house, and Frank—now a detective—finds himself dragged back into the world he fought so hard to escape. The cops want him off the case, worried his family loyalty makes him a liability. The neighborhood wants him gone because Faithful Place has never trusted police. But Frank is determined to discover what really happened to Rosie Daly, no matter what it costs him—or anyone else who gets in his way.
short_summary: Detective Frank Mackey returns to his impoverished Dublin childhood neighborhood when his first love's suitcase surfaces after twenty-two years. French weaves a haunting mystery about buried secrets, family loyalty, and the places that never let us go.
author_bios: Tana French is the New York Times–bestselling author of nine books, including In the Woods, The Searcher, The Hunter, and The Trespasser. Her novels have sold over eight million copies worldwide and won numerous awards, including the Edgar, Anthony, Macavity, and Barry Awards, the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Best Mystery/Thriller, and the Irish Book Award for Crime Fiction. She lives in Dublin with her family.
quotes:
"[French] revisits, evocatively and lyrically, themes she's used before: love, loss, memory, murder, and life in modern Ireland. French's writing remains brilliant, and her dialogue is sharp, often lacerating, and sometimes mordantly funny. Faithful Place is her best book yet."

—Booklist

"The charming narrative will leave readers begging for a sequel."

—Kirkus

"Part Raymond Chandler, part Roddy Doyle, crime fiction's rising star takes it into mesmerizing new territory . . . French's hypnotic storytelling remains in full force in this novel . . . Faithful Place is wrenching to a degree that detective fiction rarely achieves . . . French does something fresh with every novel, each one as powerful as the last but in a very different manner. Perhaps she has superpowers of her own? Whatever the source of her gift, it's only growing more miraculous with every book."

—Salon

title: Black in Blues
subtitle: How a Color Tells the Story of My People
long_summary:
Throughout history, the concept of Blackness has been remarkably intertwined with another color: blue. In daily life, it is evoked in countless ways—blue skies and blue water offer hope for that which lies beyond current conditions, while blue also carries deep melancholy and heartache, echoing Louis Armstrong's question, "What did I do to be so Black and blue?"

Celebrated author Imani Perry uses the world's favorite color as a springboard for a riveting emotional, cultural, and spiritual journey that transcends politics or ideology. She traces both blue and Blackness from their earliest roots to contemporary culture, drawing from her own life as well as art and history: the dyed indigo cloths of West Africa traded for human life in the 16th century, the mixture of awe and aversion in characterizations of dark-skinned people as "Blue Black," the fundamentally American art form of blues music sitting at the crossroads of pain and pleasure, and the blue flowers Perry plants to honor a loved one gone too soon.

Poignant, spellbinding, and utterly original, this brilliant work is attuned to both harrowing and sublime aspects of human experience—as vivid, rich, and striking as blue itself.
short_summary: National Book Award winner Imani Perry explores the profound connections between the color blue and Black history, weaving together personal reflection, cultural analysis, and historical insight in luminous prose.
author_bios: Imani Perry is the National Book Award–winning author of South to America, as well as seven other books of nonfiction. She is the Henry A. Morss Jr. and Elisabeth W. Morss Professor of Studies of Women, Gender, and Sexuality and of African and African American Studies at Harvard University, and is a 2023 MacArthur Fellow.
quotes:
"Ultimately, Black in Blues is an encyclopedia, an intentional threading of the composite nature of blue and Black. Through her study, Perry demonstrates that the creation, adoration, and use of blue in global Blackness isn't accidental. It's a strategy, a language, a point of departure for us and by us."

—Guardian

"This prismatic volume finds the National Book Award-winning Princeton professor meditating on skin color and the indigo trade, Louis Armstrong's music and Toni Morrison's writing, in short, lyrical chapters."

—New York Times

"Revelatory. . . .[Black in Blues] is attuned to the high, the low, and the blue notes that compose Blackness—and we would all do well to listen."

—Omari Weekes, Atlantic

title: This Is How You Lose Her
long_summary:
On a beach in the Dominican Republic, a doomed relationship flounders. In a New Jersey laundry room, a woman does her lover's washing and thinks about his wife. In Boston, a man buys his love child, his only son, a first baseball bat and glove.

At the heart of these stories is the irrepressible, irresistible Yunior, a young hardhead whose longing for love is equaled only by his recklessness—and by the extraordinary women he loves and loses. In prose that is endlessly energetic, inventive, tender, and funny, these linked tales lay bare the infinite longing and inevitable weakness of the human heart.

They remind us that passion always triumphs over experience, and that the half-life of love is forever.
short_summary: Díaz charts the romantic misadventures of Yunior, a Dominican American man whose infidelity and longing expose the messy realities of love and masculinity. Raw, funny, and devastatingly honest.
author_bios: Junot Díaz is the author of Drown; The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, which won the 2008 Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award; and This Is How You Lose Her, a New York Times bestseller and National Book Award finalist. His first picture book, Islandborn, was a New York Times Bestseller and won the CLASP Américas Award 2019.
quotes:
"Nobody does scrappy, sassy, twice-the-speed of sound dialogue better than Junot Díaz. His exuberant short story collection, called This Is How You Lose Her, charts the lives of Dominican immigrants for whom the promise of America comes down to a minimum-wage paycheck, an occasional walk to a movie in a mall and the momentary escape of a grappling in bed."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"Junot Díaz has one of the most distinctive and magnetic voices in contemporary fiction: limber, streetwise, caffeinated and wonderfully eclectic… The strongest tales are those fueled by the verbal energy and magpie language that made Brief Wondrous Life so memorable and that capture Yunior's efforts to commute between two cultures, Dominican and American, while always remaining an outsider."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Searing, sometimes hilarious, and always disarming… Readers will remember why everyone wants to write like Díaz, bring him home, or both. Raw and honest, these stories pulsate with raspy ghetto hip-hop and the subtler yet more vital echo of the human heart."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Guns at Last Light
subtitle: The War in Western Europe, 1944-1945
long_summary:
The final volume of Rick Atkinson's acclaimed Liberation Trilogy chronicles the most dramatic chapter of World War II: the titanic battle for Western Europe that would determine the fate of the continent.

Beginning with D-Day's bold gamble, Atkinson delivers a riveting account of the final campaign that brought Nazi Germany to its knees. From the brutal fight in Normandy to the liberation of Paris, from the disaster of Operation Market Garden to the horrific Battle of the Bulge, each pivotal moment comes alive through meticulous research and masterful storytelling.

Atkinson tells this epic story from every perspective—presidents and generals, war-weary lieutenants and terrified teenage riflemen. His sweeping narrative captures both the devastating human cost of this global conflict and the enormous effort required to achieve Allied victory. When Germany finally surrenders, readers understand anew what it took to unshackle a continent and preserve freedom in the West.

With this stirring conclusion, Atkinson completes his monumental trilogy and delivers the definitive chronicle of the war that changed the world.
short_summary: The stirring finale to Atkinson's Liberation Trilogy chronicles the final campaign of World War II, from D-Day through Germany's surrender. Epic in scope, intimate in detail.
genres: History / Wars & Conflicts / World War II
author_bios: Rick Atkinson is the #1 New York Times bestselling author of eight narrative histories about five American wars, including The Long Gray Line, the Liberation Trilogy (An Army at Dawn, The Day of Battle, and The Guns at Last Light), and The British Are Coming. He has won Pulitzer Prizes for both history and journalism.
quotes:
"A magnificent book...[Atkinson] is an absolute master of his material."

—Max Hastings, The Wall Street Journal

"A tapestry of fabulous richness and complexity...The Liberation Trilogy is a monumental achievement, about 2,500 pages in all, densely researched but supremely readable."

—The New York Times
