"Superb…The book is distinguished by its astonishing range of coverage…[Atkinson's] lively, occasionally lyric prose brings the vast theater of battle, from the beaches of Normandy deep into Germany, brilliantly alive. It is hard to imagine a better history of the western front's final phase."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Before Carrie Brownstein became a music icon, she was a young girl growing up in the Pacific Northwest just as it was becoming ground zero for one of rock's most important movements. Seeking home and identity, she discovered both while moving from spectator to creator, experiencing the transformative power of live performance.

With Sleater-Kinney, Brownstein and her bandmates rose to prominence in the burgeoning underground feminist punk movement that defined music and culture in the 1990s. They earned recognition as "America's best rock band" from legendary critic Greil Marcus for their defiant, exuberant punk that resisted labels and redefined gender in rock.

Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl chronicles Brownstein's escape from turbulent family life into a world where music became the means toward self-invention, community, and rescue. She captures the excitement and contradictions of the era's fiercely independent music subculture, including experiences that later inspired the observational satire of Portlandia. Raw, honest, and heartfelt, this memoir reveals what it means to be a young woman, born performer, and outsider who finds her calling through courage and the intoxicating power of rock and roll.
short_summary: Sleater-Kinney's guitarist chronicles her journey from Pacific Northwest teenager to feminist punk icon. Raw and revelatory, this memoir captures the transformative power of music and the underground scene that shaped a generation.
author_bios: Carrie Brownstein is a musician, writer, and actor who became widely known as guitarist and vocalist of Sleater-Kinney and later as creator, writer, and co-star of the Emmy-nominated, Peabody Award-winning television show Portlandia. Her writing has appeared in The New York Times, The Believer, Slate, and numerous music and culture anthologies. She lives in Portland, Oregon and Los Angeles.
quotes:
"In the vast library of recent rock memoirs... Ms. Brownstein's may be the one that most nakedly exposes its author's personality."

—The New York Times

"A memoir that's both candid and brave, and a powerful tribute to the power of music to heal, to connect, to break you down and then make you whole again……Brownstein's music has always helped people feel like they really do belong somewhere, and her wonderful memoir does the same thing."

—NPR

"[Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl] is earnest, endearing, at times angry, critical, confessional, raw… [it's] the compelling chronicle of a born performer, from fandom to stardom… The richness of the writing ensures that Hunger will satisfy die-hard Sleater-Kinney fans as well as those who've never heard a note."

—Kirkus

title: Our Share of Night
long_summary:
A young father and son embark on a devastating road trip following the death of the wife and mother they both loved. United in grief, they travel to her ancestral home, where they must confront the terrifying legacy she has left behind: a family called the Order that commits unspeakable acts in search of immortality.

For Gaspar, the son, this maniacal cult represents his destiny. As the Order tries to pull him into their evil, he and his father take flight, attempting to outrun a powerful clan that will do anything to ensure its own survival. But how far will Gaspar's father go to protect his child? And can anyone escape their fate?

Moving back and forth in time, from London in the swinging 1960s to the brutal years of Argentina's military dictatorship and its turbulent aftermath, Our Share of Night weaves together family saga, ghost story, and occult horror. This sprawling masterwork explores the complexities of love and longing while confronting the ways violence echoes across generations.
short_summary: In Argentina, a father and son confront a secret occult society seeking immortality through dark rituals. Blending horror with political allegory, this sprawling gothic masterpiece explores inheritance, violence, and survival.
author_bios: Mariana Enriquez is a writer based in Buenos Aires. She has published the novel Our Share of Night and three story collections: A Sunny Place for Shady People, Things We Lost in the Fire, and The Dangers of Smoking in Bed, which was a finalist for the International Booker Prize, the Kirkus Prize, the Ray Bradbury Prize for Science Fiction, Fantasy, & Speculative Fiction, and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize in Fiction.
quotes:
"Reader, beware! Our Share of Night is a novel so disquieting, so unsettling that I could neither put it down nor read it late at night . . . [this] novel is going to haunt me for the rest of my life."

—Kelly Link, author of The Book of Love & White Cat, Black Dog

"A literary achievement, gorgeous and exacting in its execution . . . Our Share of Night is not only a bloody valentine to the bonds between parent and child, but also an inspired evisceration of how the powerful prey on the powerless . . ."

—The Washington Post

"A haunting generational horror story."

—Silvia Moreno-Garcia

title: Gone Girl
long_summary:
On their fifth wedding anniversary in North Carthage, Missouri, Amy Dunne vanishes without a trace. Her husband Nick becomes the prime suspect, but he's not exactly helping his case—his behavior grows increasingly suspicious as police and media scrutiny intensifies.

Through alternating perspectives, we see Nick's evasive responses to investigators and Amy's diary entries revealing the cracks in their seemingly perfect marriage. Amy emerges as an alpha-girl perfectionist whose exacting standards may have pushed someone too far. Meanwhile, Nick parades lies and inappropriate behavior that make him look guilty, even as he protests his innocence.

Under mounting pressure from Amy's doting parents and a media circus, the golden boy facade crumbles. But in this psychological thriller, nothing is quite what it seems. Flynn masterfully peels back layers of deception, revealing how well we really know the people closest to us—and how marriage can become a battleground where truth is the first casualty.
short_summary: When Amy Dunne disappears on her wedding anniversary, her husband Nick becomes the prime suspect. Flynn's psychological thriller peels back layers of a marriage built on lies and manipulation.
author_bios: Gillian Flynn is the author of the #1 New York Times bestseller Gone Girl, for which she wrote the Golden Globe–nominated screenplay; the New York Times bestsellers Dark Places and Sharp Objects; and a novella, The Grownup. A former Entertainment Weekly critic, she lives in Chicago with her husband and children.
quotes:
"Ice-pick-sharp . . . spectacularly sneaky . . . impressively cagey . . . Gone Girl is Ms. Flynn's dazzling breakthrough. It is wily, mercurial, subtly layered and populated by characters so well imagined that they're hard to part with."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Ms. Flynn writes dark suspense novels that anatomize violence without splashing barrels of blood around the pages . . . Ms. Flynn has much more up her sleeve than a simple missing-person case. As Nick and Amy alternately tell their stories, marriage has never looked so menacing, narrators so unreliable."

—The Wall Street Journal

"The story unfolds in precise and riveting prose . . . even while you know you're being manipulated, searching for the missing pieces is half the thrill of this wickedly absorbing tale."

—O: The Oprah Magazine

title: The Beauty and the Sorrow
subtitle: An Intimate History of the First World War
long_summary:
In The Beauty and the Sorrow, Peter Englund offers a masterful and original history of World War I, told through the journals and letters of twenty men and women from across the globe. Their stories span Belgium, France, Germany, Britain, Italy, Russia, the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Australia, New Zealand, Venezuela, and the United States.

Englund captures the war through diverse perspectives—soldiers, nurses, surgeons, pilots, prisoners, civil servants, and children. From the exhilaration of early victories to the collapse of ideals and the devastation of daily life, he presents a brilliant mosaic of voices that reveal not only the tragedy and horror of the Great War, but also its absurdity, moments of resilience, and even fleeting beauty.

Both intimate and expansive, this unforgettable narrative restores humanity to a conflict too often reduced to statistics, allowing forgotten witnesses to speak for themselves and for a generation shaped by the war.
short_summary: Englund reconstructs World War I through the diaries and letters of twenty individuals from different nations. A brilliant mosaic of human experience that reveals both tragedy and unexpected beauty.
genres: History / Wars & Conflicts / World War I
author_bios: Peter Englund is a historian, journalist, and member of the Swedish Academy, which chooses Nobel Prize winners. He has received the August Prize for best Swedish book of the year and the Selma Lagerlöf literature prize. Author of ten previous books, Englund lives in Uppsala, Sweden.
quotes:
"Intense and bighearted…The best books about World War I have often been oblique, like Paul Fussell's Great War and Modern Memory, or novels, like Erich Maria Remarque's All Quiet on the Western Front, rather than comprehensive histories. Englund's volume joins an unconventional pantheon…The accounts of [these] lives can be terrifying or stirring, but are most fully alive in Englund's accumulation of small moments, stray details…His book has the most devastating ending I can remember in a piece of nonfiction."

—The New York Times

"A brilliant feat of retrospective journalism…Englund's deft collation provides insights into more than the carnage…This book fleshes out the grim statistics of the Great War…The eloquence of everyday participants will link the reader to the era when the origins of the ensuing century's conflicts became apparent."

—Publishers Weekly

"An exquisite book…There are adventures and battles, of course, but also many moments of quiet contemplation with closely observed details of street scenes, restaurants, railway stations, and deserted battlefields…By turns pithy, lyrical, colorful, poignant, and endlessly absorbing."

—Kirkus

title: Bettyville
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
When George Hodgman leaves Manhattan for his hometown of Paris, Missouri, he finds himself an unlikely caretaker in a head-on collision with his aging mother, Betty—a woman of wit and will. Will George lure her into assisted living? When hell freezes over. He can't bring himself to force her from the home both treasure, where his father's voice still lingers and shared jokes mix with old skirmishes.

Behind the dusty antiques lies a rarely acknowledged conflict: Betty, who speaks her mind but cannot quite reveal her heart, has never really accepted that her son is gay. As these two unforgettable characters try to bring their different worlds together, Hodgman reveals the challenges of Betty's life and his own struggle for self-respect.

Moving from their crumbling but colorful small town to the star-studded corridors of Vanity Fair, this New York Times bestselling debut creates both an indelible portrait of family and an exquisitely told tale of a prodigal son's return.
short_summary: George Hodgman returns from Manhattan to care for his formidable mother Betty in small-town Missouri. A witty, heartbreaking exploration of family secrets, acceptance, and the complicated love between mothers and sons.
author_bios: George Hodgman is a veteran magazine and book editor who has worked at Simon & Schuster, Vanity Fair, and Talk magazine. His writing has appeared in Entertainment Weekly, Interview, W, and Harper's Bazaar. He lives in New York City and Paris, Missouri.
quotes:
"A remarkable, laugh-out-loud book . . . Rarely has the subject of elder care produced such droll human comedy, or a heroine quite on the mettlesome order of Betty Baker Hodgman. For as much as the book works on several levels (as a meditation on belonging, as a story of growing up gay and the psychic cost of silence, as metaphor for recovery), it is the strong-willed Betty who shines through."

—The New York Times

"Bettyville is a gorgeous memoir. I was completely engaged, not just because of George Hodgman's great ear and his sense of timing, but because he delivers Betty to us in such a manner that she steps off the page . I felt transported to a better place, to a time period and a web of relationships with which we can all identify, no matter where we grew up. Beyond the humor and the pathos, the quotidian and the bizarre, there remain profound lessons about life and love that I will carry away."

—Abraham Verghese, author of The Covenant of Water & Cutting for Stone

"An exquisitely written memoir about the complicated but deeply genuine love a son feels for his courageous, headstrong, vulnerable mother in the twilight of her life. George Hodgman is stunningly clear-eyed and yet so darned big-hearted. Bettyville is just wonderful."

—Jeannette Walls, author of The Glass Castle

title: Crossroads
long_summary:
It's December 23, 1971, and heavy weather is forecast for Chicago. Russ Hildebrandt, the associate pastor of a liberal suburban church, is on the brink of breaking free of a marriage he finds joyless—unless his wife, Marion, who has her own secret life, beats him to it.

Their eldest child, Clem, is coming home from college on fire with moral absolutism, having taken an action that will shatter his father. Clem's sister, Becky, long the social queen of her high-school class, has sharply veered into the counterculture, while their brilliant younger brother Perry, who's been selling drugs to seventh graders, has resolved to be a better person. Each of the Hildebrandts seeks a freedom that each of the others threatens to complicate.

A tour de force of interwoven perspectives and sustained suspense, its action largely unfolding on a single winter day, Crossroads captures a Midwestern family at a pivotal moment of moral crisis. Franzen's gift for melding intimate family drama with the broader sweep of American social change has never been more dazzlingly evident.
short_summary: December 1971: A pastor's family fractures as each member pursues their own version of freedom. Franzen weaves generational conflict and moral crisis into an intimate portrait of America at a cultural crossroads.
author_bios: Jonathan Franzen is the author of five novels, including The Corrections, Freedom, and Purity, and five works of nonfiction, most recently Farther Away and The End of the End of the Earth, all published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux. He lives in Santa Cruz, California.
quotes:
"With its dazzling style and tireless attention to the machinations of a single family, Crossroads is distinctly Franzen-esque, but it represents a marked evolution . . . It's an electrifying examination of the irreducible complexities of an ethical life. With his ever-parsing style and his relentless calculation of the fractals of consciousness, Franzen makes a good claim to being the 21st century's Nathaniel Hawthorne."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"[Franzen] imbues his books with big ideas, in this case about responsibility to family, self, God, country, and one's fellow man, among other matters, all the while digging deep into his characters' emotions, experiences, desires, and doubts in a way that will please readers seeking to connect to books heart-first . . . Franzen's intensely absorbing novel is amusing, excruciating, and at times unexpectedly uplifting—in a word, exquisite."

—Kirkus

"Franzen returns with a sweeping and masterly examination of the shifting culture of early 1970s America, the first in a trilogy . . . Throughout, Franzen exhibits his remarkable ability to build suspense through fraught interpersonal dynamics. It's irresistible."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Afterlives
long_summary:
When Ilyas was just a boy, German colonial troops stole him from his parents on the coast of east Africa. After years fighting against his own people, he returns home to find his parents gone and his sister Afiya abandoned into slavery.

Hamza also returns from the war, scarred in body and soul with nothing but the clothes on his back—until he meets the beautiful, undaunted Afiya. As these young people work and fall in love, their fates become ever more tightly knotted together.

But the shadow of a new war on another continent falls over them, threatening once again to carry them away from everything they've fought to rebuild.
short_summary: Nobel laureate Gurnah weaves a devastating story of siblings torn apart by German colonial violence in east Africa. When they finally reunite, love offers hope—but history threatens to separate them again.
genres: Fiction / World Literature / Africa / East Africa
author_bios: Abdulrazak Gurnah won the 2021 Nobel Prize in Literature. He's the author of nine novels, including Paradise (shortlisted for the Booker Prize), By the Sea (longlisted for the Booker Prize and Los Angeles Times Book Prize finalist), and Desertion. Born in Zanzibar, he's Professor Emeritus of English and Postcolonial Literatures at the University of Kent and lives in Canterbury, England.
quotes:
"A work of extraordinary power, giving us a colonial world with utmost intimacy, capturing its cruelties and complexities, immersing us in vividly evoked characters, showing us moments of incredible tenderness and beauty, and quietly reordering our sense of history."

—Phil Klay, author of Redeployment and Missionaries

"At once a globe-spanning epic of European colonialism and an intimate look at village life in one of the many overlooked corners of the Earth. Both parts — reclamations of history and heart — are equally revelatory. . . . Gurnah's greatest act of love and artistry [is] his ability to gather the fragments of broken lives and create a breathtaking mosaic in print."

—The Washington Post

"Riveting. . . . Gurnah's spare, unvarnished prose shines a harsh but honest light on the brutality of Africa's colonial past. . . and through his rich main characters, the impact of colonialism and other key global events truly hits home. This profound account of empire and the everyman is not to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Rogue Heroes
subtitle: The History of the SAS, Britain's Secret Special Forces Unit That Sabotaged the Nazis and Changed the Nature of War
long_summary:
Britain’s Special Air Service—or SAS—was the brainchild of David Stirling, a young, gadabout aristocrat whose aimlessness in early life belied a remarkable strategic mind. Where most of his colleagues looked at a battlefield map of World War II’s African theater and saw a protracted struggle with Rommel’s desert forces, Stirling saw an opportunity: given a small number of elite, well-trained men, he could parachute behind enemy lines and sabotage their airplanes and war material. Paired with his constitutional opposite, the disciplined martinet Jock Lewes, Stirling assembled a revolutionary fighting force that would upend not just the balance of the war, but the nature of combat itself. He faced no little resistance from those who found his tactics ungentlemanly or beyond the pale, but in the SAS’s remarkable exploits facing the Nazis in the Africa and then on the Continent can be found the seeds of nearly all special forces units that would follow.

Bringing his keen eye for psychological detail to a riveting wartime narrative, Ben Macintyre uses his unprecedented access to SAS archives to shine a light inside a legendary unit long shrouded in secrecy. The result is not just a tremendous war story, but a fascinating group portrait of men of whom history and country asked the most.
short_summary: The incredible untold story of WWII’s greatest secret fighting force, as told by our great modern master of wartime intrigue
genres: History / Wars & Conflicts / World War II
author_bios: Ben Macintyre is a writer-at-large for The Times (U.K.) and the bestselling author of Agent Sonya, The Spy and the Traitor, A Spy Among Friends, Double Cross, Operation Mincemeat, Agent Zigzag, and Rogue Heroes, among other books. Macintyre has also written and presented BBC documentaries of his work.
quotes:
“Ben Macintyre’s suspenseful new book, Rogue Heroes, about the founding of Britain’s S.A.S. during World War II, reads like a mashup of 'The Dirty Dozen' and 'The Great Escape,' with a sprinkling of “Ocean’s 11” thrown in for good measure… Mr. Macintyre draws sharp, Dickensian portraits of these men, and he displays his usual gifts here for creating a cinematic narrative that races along… Mr. Macintyre is masterly in using details to illustrate his heroes’ bravery, élan and dogged perseverance…a gripping account of the early days of S.A.S.”—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"Rogue Heroes is a terrific story of human enterprise, endurance and achievement and vividly brings to life an extraordinary cast of characters…. An absorbing story of derring-do, told with skill and flair.”—The Wall Street Journal

“[A] riveting new history… Macintyre has produced yet another wonderful book… even minor characters bristle with life.... This is the spot in the book review where I’m supposed to find some point to quibble with, some omission, some historical inaccuracy, some flaw. Sorry to disappoint. The fact is Macintyre has produced yet another wonderful book. As Captain What What might have put it, this is a ripping good read.”—The Washington Post

title: The Cooked Seed
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
From Anchee Min, author of the internationally bestselling memoir Red Azalea, comes the eagerly awaited sequel: a moving immigrant story of survival, resilience, and self-discovery.

Arriving in America without language, money, or direction, Min teaches herself English by watching Sesame Street, works multiple jobs to stay afloat, and endures hardship, exploitation, and loneliness. Yet amid these struggles she finds strength through motherhood, eventually building a new life as a successful writer, devoted mother, and loving wife.

Candid and powerful, this continuation of her life story traces the journey from the brutal deprivations of China's Cultural Revolution to the challenges and possibilities of America, offering an unforgettable testament to perseverance and the universal search for identity and belonging.
short_summary: Min's follow-up to Red Azalea chronicles her harrowing journey from Mao's China to America. A testament to survival, resilience, and the immigrant experience.
author_bios: Anchee Min was born in Shanghai in 1957. At seventeen she was sent to a labor collective, where a talent scout for Madame Mao's Shanghai Film Studio recruited her as a movie actress. She moved to the United States in 1984. Her first memoir, Red Azalea, was an international bestseller published in twenty countries. She has since published six novels, most recently Pearl of China.
quotes:
"Moving...A uplifting work of incredibly grit and fortitude."

—Kirkus

"Her memoir methodically reconstructs those painstaking first years in Chicago, living on a pittance, scrounging for work, amazed at what she considered luxurious dorm living, and guilt-ridden at her inability to rescue her family back home. Along the way, she offers candid observations on American naiveté, casual waste, and lack of Chinese stick-to-itness, yet writes poignantly of being treated with decency and warmth, inspiring her to work harder. Watching Mister Rogers' Neighborhood and reading Jane Eyre helped pave her yellow brick road to literary success, as she delineates captivatingly in this work."

—Publishers Weekly

"[The] preeminent chronicler of women's lives in China's ill-starred Cultural Revolution."

—Elle

title: Homegoing
long_summary:
The unforgettable New York Times bestseller begins with two half-sisters in eighteenth-century Ghana, separated by forces beyond their control: one sold into slavery, the other married to a British slaver. Written with tremendous sweep and power, Homegoing traces the generations that follow across two continents and three hundred years of history.

Effia and Esi are born into different villages. Effia is married off to an Englishman and lives in comfort in the palatial rooms of Cape Coast Castle. Unbeknownst to her, Esi is imprisoned beneath her in the castle's dungeons, sold into the Gold Coast's booming slave trade and shipped to America.

One thread follows Effia's descendants through centuries of warfare in Ghana, as the Fante and Asante nations wrestle with the slave trade and British colonization. The other follows Esi's lineage into America—from Southern plantations to the Civil War and Great Migration, from Alabama coal mines to Harlem's jazz clubs and dope houses, right up to the present day. Gyasi makes history visceral, capturing with stunning immediacy how the memory of captivity became inscribed in the soul of a nation.
short_summary: Two half-sisters in 18th-century Ghana are separated—one sold into slavery, the other married to a slave trader—launching a lineage that spans continents and centuries. Sweeping yet intimate, a mosaic of how history moves through families.
author_bios: Yaa Gyasi was born in Ghana and raised in Huntsville, Alabama. Her debut novel, Homegoing, won the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Award, the PEN/Hemingway Award, the National Book Foundation's "5 under 35" honors, and the American Book Award. She lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"Gyasi's characters are so fully realized, so elegantly carved—very often I found myself longing to hear more. Craft is essential given the task Gyasi sets for herself—drawing not just a lineage of two sisters, but two related peoples. Gyasi is deeply concerned with the sin of selling humans on Africans, not Europeans. But she does not scold. She does not excuse. And she does not romanticize. The black Americans she follows are not overly virtuous victims.  Sin comes in all forms, from selling people to abandoning children.  I think I needed to read a book like this to remember what is possible.  I think I needed to remember what happens when you pair a gifted literary mind to an epic task. Homegoing is an inspiration."

—Ta-Nehisi Coates, National Book Award-winning author of Between the World and Me

"The hypnotic debut novel by Yaa Gyasi, a stirringly gifted writer . . . magical . . . the great, aching gift of the novel is that it offers, in its own way, the very thing that enslavement denied its descendants: the possibility of imagining the connection between the broken threads of their origins."

—Isabel Wilkerson, The New York Times

"Homegoing is a remarkable feat—a novel at once epic and intimate, capturing the moral weight of history as it bears down on individual struggles, hopes, and fears. A tremendous debut."

—Phil Klay, National Book Award-winning author of Redeployment

title: Colored Television
long_summary:
Jane has high hopes her life is about to turn around. After years of living precariously, she, her painter husband Lenny, and their two kids have landed a house-sitting gig in a luxurious home high in the hills above Los Angeles—perfectly timed with Jane's sabbatical. If she can just finish her latest novel, Nusu Nusu, the centuries-spanning epic Lenny calls her "mulatto War and Peace," she'll have tenure and some semblance of stability within her grasp.

But things don't work out as hoped. In search of a plan B, Jane turns her desperate gaze to Hollywood like countless writers before her. When she finaggles a meeting with a hot young producer with a seven-figure deal to create "diverse content" for a streaming network, he seems excited to work with a "real writer" on what he envisions as the greatest biracial comedy ever to hit the small screen.

Things finally seem to be going right for Jane—until they go terribly wrong. Funny, piercing, and page-turning, this is Senna's sharpest novel yet.
short_summary: When a struggling writer's academic dreams crumble, she pivots to Hollywood—with disastrous results. Senna delivers biting satire about creative desperation and the commodification of identity.
author_bios: Danzy Senna is the bestselling author of six previous books, including Caucasia, New People, and most recently Colored Television. The recipient of numerous awards and honors, she teaches writing at the University of Southern California.
quotes:
"There is no one else who writes like Senna. In all her books she tackles so many different subjects, all the while telling a story with characters so real and compelling you never think about how many ideas are being developed, and discussed, only that you want to find out what happens next, and how the ideas and the characters and the story will coalesce, all the way up until the last page, when you won't want it to have to end."

—Tommy Orange, The Guardian

"I couldn't stop turning the pages, and only when it was all over did I realize what Senna had done. Addictive, hilarious and relatable, yes, but Colored Television is after something larger and more elusive, a very modern reckoning with the ambiguities triangulated by race, class, creativity and love. She nails it."

—Miranda July, author of All Fours and The First Bad Man

"If you thought California was burning before, wait until you read how literary arsonist Danzy Senna gleefully incinerates its values through the eyes of Jane Gibson—a heroine whose insecurity, mistakes, and lies will keep you riveted from start to finish."

—James Hannaham, author of Delicious Foods and Nobody Gives a Shit What Happened to Carlotta

title: I Can't Breathe
subtitle: A Killing on Bay Street
long_summary:
On July 17, 2014, Eric Garner was killed by police officer Daniel Panteleo on Bay Street in Staten Island, New York. The final moments of Garner's life—and his final words, "I can't breathe," repeated eleven times—were captured in a disturbing video seen by millions. In an era of contested police killings of African Americans, this case seemed the clearest cut of all—yet the officer was never indicted.

The story behind this fateful encounter runs much deeper than those few minutes of video could capture. Garner was a larger-than-life figure, both comic and tragic—a father and son, husband and dreamer, black market entrepreneur and neighborhood fixture—whose rocky journey through life eventually narrowed to a single point: a Staten Island corner where he sold loose cigarettes.

The police department he encountered had its own troubled history—bad policy, perverse incentives, and an uncertain mission, all shadowed by racial control's dominant role in American policing. Taibbi masterfully weaves together Garner's vivid, moving story with the dramatic aftermath of his killing, bringing readers to an urgent question: what job have we given our police, and who suffers when they do it?
short_summary: Taibbi weaves together the vivid life of Eric Garner with the broken system that killed him. Essential journalism that examines how policing, race, and justice collide in America.
author_bios: Matt Taibbi is a contributing editor for Rolling Stone and winner of the 2008 National Magazine Award for columns and commentary. He's the author of the New York Times bestsellers Insane Clown President, The Divide, Griftopia, and The Great Derangement, as well as I Can't Breathe: A Killing on Bay Street.
quotes:
"A complex and textured examination of the complicated personalities, flawed legal system, and politics revolving around the police killing of forty-three-year-old Eric Garner, whose final words became a rallying cry for the Black Lives Matter movement."

—The Boston Globe

"[A] brilliant work of narrative nonfiction…[Matt] Taibbi is unsparing is his excoriation of the system, police, and courts that led to the fatal choke hold and worked to blur the abuse afterward…. This is a necessary and riveting work."

—Booklist

"[A] searing exposé…After deeply exploring Garner's life from a variety of perspectives, Taibbi offers detailed reporting about the out-of-control Staten Island police officers present at the death scene…[and] the futile efforts of the Garner family to achieve posthumous justice…. What emerges from the author's superb reporting and vivid writing is a tragically revealing look at a broken criminal justice system geared to serve white citizens while often overlooking or ignoring the rights of others."

—Kirkus

title: The Rules Do Not Apply
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
All her life, Ariel Levy was told she was too fervent, too forceful, too much. As a young woman, she decided that becoming a writer would perfectly channel her strength and desire. She would be a professional explorer—"the kind of woman who is free to do whatever she chooses."

Levy moved to Manhattan to pursue her dream and spent years traveling the world, writing stories about unconventional heroines and following their fearless examples in her own life. But when she experiences unthinkable heartbreak, Levy is forced to surrender her illusion of control.

In telling her story with unflinching honesty, Levy captures a portrait of our time—of the shifting forces in American culture, of what has changed and what has remained. Most importantly, she shows us how to begin again.
short_summary: Levy examines her relentless pursuit of freedom and adventure until devastating loss forces her to confront what control really means. Raw, honest, and ultimately hopeful.
author_bios: Ariel Levy joined The New Yorker as a staff writer in 2008 and received the National Magazine Award for Essays and Criticism in 2014 for her piece "Thanksgiving in Mongolia." She is the author of Female Chauvinist Pigs and was a contributing editor at New York for twelve years.
quotes:
"Unflinching and intimate, wrenching and revelatory, Ariel Levy's powerful memoir about love, loss, and finding one's way shimmers with truth and heart on every page."

—Cheryl Strayed

"Every deep feeling a human is capable of will be shaken loose by this profound book. Ariel Levy has taken grief and made art out of it."

—David Sedaris

"Levy has the rare gift of seeing herself with fierce, unforgiving clarity. And she deploys prose to match, raw and agile. She plumbs the commotion deep within and takes the measure of her have-it-all generation."

—The Atlantic

title: The Pale King
long_summary:
When David Foster Wallace arrives as a trainee at the IRS Regional Examination Center in Peoria, Illinois, his colleagues seem ordinary enough. But as he settles into work so mind-numbingly repetitive that new employees receive actual boredom-survival training, he discovers the extraordinary range of personalities drawn to this peculiar profession.

Wallace has arrived at a pivotal moment—forces within the IRS are plotting to strip away what little humanity and dignity remain in the work. Left unfinished at the time of the author's death, The Pale King is nevertheless a deeply satisfying novel, hilarious and fearless in its originality.

Through characters imagined with Wallace's signature interior force and generosity, the novel grapples with ultimate questions about life's meaning and the value of work in society. Along the way, it suggests a radical new conception of heroism found in the most mundane circumstances.
short_summary: Wallace's unfinished masterpiece transforms an IRS office into a meditation on boredom, attention, and what makes life meaningful. Hilarious and profound, it finds unexpected heroism in the most tedious work imaginable.
author_bios: David Foster Wallace was born in Ithaca, New York, in 1962 and raised in Illinois, where he was a regionally ranked junior tennis player. He received bachelor of arts degrees in philosophy and English from Amherst College, writing his first novel, The Broom of the System, as his senior thesis. After earning his MFA from University of Arizona in 1987, he briefly pursued graduate work in philosophy at Harvard. His second novel, Infinite Jest, was published in 1996.
quotes:
"Deeply sad, deeply philosophical...breathtakingly brilliant...funny, maddening and elegiac...[David Foster Wallace's] most emotionally immediate work...It was in trying to capture the hectic, chaotic reality--and the nuanced, conflicted, ever-mutating thoughts of his characters--that Wallace's synesthetic prose waxed so prolix, his sentences unspooling into tangled skeins of words, replete with qualifying phrases and garrulous footnotes...because in almost everything Wallace wrote, including THE PALE KING, he aimed to use words to lasso and somehow subdue the staggering, multifarious, cacophonous predicament that is modern American life."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"One hell of a document and a valiant tribute to the late Wallace.....Stretches of this are nothing short of sublime--the first two chapters are a real put-the-reader-on-notice charging bull blitz, and the David Foster Wallace sections...are tiny masterpieces of that whole self-aware po-mo thing of his that's so heavily imitated.... often achingly funny...pants-pissingly hilarious....Yet, even in its incomplete state...the book is unmistakably a David Foster Wallace affair. You get the sense early on that he's trying to cram the whole world between two covers. As it turns out, that would actually be easier to than what he was up to here, because then you could gloss over the flyover country that this novel fully inhabits, finding, among the wigglers, the essence of our fundamental human struggles."

—Publishers Weekly

"It could hardly be more engaging. The Pale King is by turns funny, shrewd, suspenseful, piercing, smart, terrifying and rousing."

—Laura Miller, Salon

title: I'm Glad My Mom Died
long_summary:
Jennette McCurdy was six years old when she had her first acting audition. Her mother's dream was for her only daughter to become a star, and Jennette would do anything to make her mother happy. So she went along with what Mom called "calorie restriction," eating little and weighing herself five times a day. She endured extensive at-home makeovers while Mom chided, "Your eyelashes are invisible, okay? You think Dakota Fanning doesn't tint hers?" She was even showered by Mom until age sixteen while sharing her diaries, email, and all her income.

In I'm Glad My Mom Died, Jennette recounts all this in unflinching detail—just as she chronicles what happens when the dream finally comes true. Cast in the Nickelodeon series iCarly, she's thrust into fame. Though Mom is ecstatic, emailing fan club moderators and getting on a first-name basis with the paparazzi, Jennette is riddled with anxiety, shame, and self-loathing, which manifest as eating disorders, addiction, and unhealthy relationships.

These issues only worsen when, soon after taking the lead in the iCarly spinoff Sam & Cat, her mother dies of cancer. Finally, after discovering therapy and quitting acting, Jennette embarks on recovery and decides for the first time what she really wants. Told with refreshing candor and dark humor, this is an inspiring story of resilience, independence, and the joy of shampooing your own hair.
short_summary: Former Nickelodeon star Jennette McCurdy delivers a devastating memoir about surviving child stardom and an abusive mother. Raw, funny, and unflinchingly honest about eating disorders, addiction, and finding herself after fame.
author_bios: Jennette McCurdy is the author of I'm Glad My Mom Died, winner of the 2023 American Library Association Alex Award. The #1 New York Times bestseller spent over eighty weeks on the list, has been published in more than thirty countries, and has sold over three million copies. McCurdy is creating, writing, executive producing, directing, and showrunning an Apple TV+ series loosely inspired by the book, starring Jennifer Aniston. Her debut novel, Half His Age, publishes January 2026.
quotes:
"[A] layered account of a woman reckoning with love and violence at once…[Not] a flippant exposé of childhood stardom, nor an angry diatribe directed at an abuser. This complexity is what makes I'm Glad My Mom Died feel real…Some supposed literary types will think the immense popularity of I'm Glad My Mom Died—the hardcover initially sold out at many major bookstores—is merely the result of McCurdy's former stardom and modern culture's thirst for a sensational take. With its bold headline and bright cover featuring a smirking McCurdy holding a pink urn, the book feels deliberately marketed for virality, perfect for sharing on the internet and catching the eye of bookstore browsers. I've mentioned the title of this memoir to some people who have dismissed it out of hand, remarking that being glad one's parent is dead is crude and a sentiment that should be kept to oneself. But those people haven't read the book. McCurdy takes her time to remember difficult and complex moments of her life, staying true to her younger self while ultimately trying to come to terms with who she is as an independent adult. It's a triumph of the confessional genre."

—Nina Li Coomes, The Atlantic

"[An] explosive debut…insightful and incisive, heartbreaking and raw, McCurdy's narrative reveals a strong woman who triumphs over unimaginable pressure to emerge whole on the other side. Fans will be rapt."

—Publishers Weekly

"Delivered with captivating candor and grace."

—Kirkus

title: Memorial
long_summary:
Benson and Mike have been together for a few good years in Houston—Mike's a Japanese American chef at a Mexican restaurant, Benson's a Black day care teacher—but lately they're questioning what holds them together beyond great sex, home-cooked meals, and love.

When Mike's estranged father starts dying in Osaka, and his sharp-tongued Japanese mother Mitsuko arrives in Texas for a visit, Mike abruptly flies to Japan to say goodbye. There he undergoes an extraordinary transformation, discovering truths about his family and past he never knew existed.

Back in Houston, Mitsuko and Benson become unlikely roommates in an absurd domestic arrangement that surprises them both with its meaning. Without Mike's gravitational pull, Benson begins pushing outward, finally realizing what he wants from life—and that he might actually have what it takes to get it.

Both men will change in ways that either strengthen their bond or shatter everything they've built. This funny, profound novel explores family in all its strange forms and the hard-won vulnerability required to become who you're meant to be.
short_summary: When Mike flies to Japan to see his dying father, his boyfriend Benson gets stuck with Mike's acerbic mother as a roommate. A tender, funny exploration of love's limits and family's unexpected forms.
author_bios: Bryan Washington is the author of Lot, Memorial, and Family Meal. A National Book Award 5 Under 35 Honoree, he won the Dylan Thomas Prize, the NYPL Young Lions Fiction Award, the Ernest J. Gaines Award, two Lambda Literary Awards, and an O. Henry Prize. He is based in Tokyo.
quotes:
"Memorial dares to insist on the mundane, thoroughly lived life as a site of perennial hope, joy, and abundance. It casts a fresh take on the American family that becomes truer because of its disparate origins, the queerness of its genesis, and the buoyed wonder it finds in surviving grief and loss towards the rare and forgiving ground of difficult, hard-won love. All of this done in sentences clean and clear as cut glass. This book, in what feels like a new vision for the 21st century novel, made me happy."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous

"Bryan Washington is an expert in illuminating the way we love. Memorial perfectly captures the lives lived in-between what we do and what we say, what we need and what we allow ourselves to have. It is a beautiful heartbreak."

—Mira Jacob, author of Good Talk

"Tender like a bruise, Memorial is a novel of uncommon depth and feeling. It is about everything that matters in life: love, loss, community and communion. Bryan Washington will take your breath away."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies & A Separation

title: The Interestings
long_summary:
The summer Nixon resigns, six teenagers at an arts camp become inseparable. Decades later, their bond endures, but everything else has shifted dramatically.

Wolitzer follows these friends from the height of youth through middle age, as their talents, fortunes, and satisfaction levels diverge in unexpected ways. The creativity rewarded at fifteen doesn't always sustain someone at thirty—not everyone can maintain in adulthood what seemed so special in adolescence.

Jules Jacobson, an aspiring comic actress, eventually accepts a more practical life. Her friend Jonah, a gifted musician, abandons guitar for engineering. But Ethan and Ash, Jules's now-married best friends, achieve shocking success—staying true to their artistic dreams with the wealth and access that allows those dreams to keep expanding.

The friendships endure and even prosper, but they also underscore the stark differences in their fates. Set against a changing New York City, The Interestings explores talent, envy, and the roles of class, art, money, and power—and how it can all shift precipitously over the course of a friendship and a life.
short_summary: Six teenagers bond at arts camp the summer Nixon resigns, then navigate decades of diverging fortunes. Wolitzer masterfully examines how talent evolves—and how envy operates even within the closest friendships.
author_bios: Meg Wolitzer is the New York Times-bestselling author of The Interestings, The Uncoupling, The Ten-Year Nap, The Position, The Wife, and Sleepwalking. She also wrote the young adult novel Belzhar and lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Wolitzer is as precise and rigorous an observer of social status as Tom Wolfe; she is as incisive and pitiless and clear-eyed a chronicler of female-male tandems as Philip Roth or John Updike. . . . She writes at the eye-level. . . . Wolitzer is terrific at depicting the ambiguity of modern family life, its murky moral choices and thorny dilemmas."

—Chicago Tribune

"All of Wolitzer's characters are so articulate and insightful that it's a pleasure to listen to them think. . . . [Her] scenes are intensely observed and nuanced."

—The Atlantic

"Holds a mirror up to modern America, offering a shock of recognition amid the laughter."

—People

title: My Year of Rest and Relaxation
long_summary:
Our narrator should be happy, shouldn't she? She's young, thin, pretty, a recent Columbia graduate with an easy job at a hip art gallery and an Upper East Side apartment paid for by her inheritance. But there's a dark, vacuous hole in her heart that goes beyond losing her parents, her Wall Street boyfriend's treatment of her, or her toxic friendship with Reva.

It's the year 2000 in a city glittering with wealth and possibility—so what could be so terribly wrong? Through the story of a year spent under the influence of a truly mad combination of prescription drugs designed to heal our heroine's alienation, Moshfegh shows us how reasonable, even necessary, that disconnection can be.

Both tender and blackly funny, merciless and compassionate, this novel showcases the gifts of a major writer working at the height of her powers.
short_summary: A young woman with every advantage decides to spend a year in drug-induced hibernation on the Upper East Side. Moshfegh's darkly funny novel transforms privileged ennui into something profound and devastating.
author_bios: Ottessa Moshfegh is a fiction writer from New England. Her debut novel Eileen was shortlisted for the National Book Critics Circle Award and the Man Booker Prize, and won the PEN/Hemingway Award. My Year of Rest and Relaxation and Death in Her Hands were New York Times bestsellers. She's also the author of Homesick for Another World and the novella McGlue. She lives in Southern California.
quotes:
"I don't think I'm ever going to get over Ottessa Moshfegh's My Year of Rest and Relaxation."

—Parul Sehgal, The New York Times

"A strange, exhilarating triumph…Moshfegh writes with a singular wit and clarity that, on its own, would be more than enough. (Her 2015 debut, Eileen, was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize, and Rest has already been optioned for film by Australian actress Margot Robbie). But the cumulative power of her narrative—and the sharp turn she takes in its last 30 pages—becomes nothing less than a revelation: sad, funny, astonishing, and unforgettable."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Bizarrely fascinating…Moshfegh knows how to spin perversity and provocation into fascination, and bleakness into surprising tenderness."

—NPR

title: Girl, Woman, Other
long_summary:
Bernardine Evaristo's Booker Prize-winning novel weaves together the lives of twelve Black British women in a stunning exploration of identity, community, and belonging. The characters span generations and experiences: Amma, a newly acclaimed playwright exploring her Black lesbian identity; Shirley, a teacher worn down by years in underfunded London schools; Carole, Shirley's former student turned successful investment banker; and Carole's mother Bummi, a cleaner worried about her daughter's disconnection from her roots.

From a nonbinary social media influencer to a 93-year-old woman on a Northern England farm, these unforgettable women intersect across lines of age, sexuality, and class. Their stories paint a vivid portrait of contemporary Britain while examining the lasting impact of colonial history in Africa and the Caribbean.

Written in an innovative form that borrows from poetry—with long, flowing lines and no periods—the novel pulses with energy and wit. Evaristo centers voices often marginalized, creating a polyphonic celebration of what connects us even when forces try to drive us apart.
short_summary: Twelve Black British women's lives intersect across generations in this Booker Prize-winning novel. Evaristo weaves their stories with innovative, poetry-inspired prose that's both witty and deeply moving.
author_bios: Bernardine Evaristo won the 2019 Booker Prize for Girl, Woman, Other, which became a global bestseller and winner of numerous awards including the Women's Prize for Fiction and Dublin Literary Award. She's authored nine other books exploring the African diaspora, spanning verse fiction, poetry, essays, and drama. Evaristo is President of the Royal Society of Literature, Professor of Creative Writing at Brunel University London, and Honorary Fellow of St Anne's College, Oxford. She received an OBE in 2020 and lives in London. Her most recent book is Manifesto: On Never Giving Up.
quotes:
"Among the bustling cast of characters in Evaristo's kaleidoscopic novel about the lives of a large group of Black British women are several indelible mother-daughter pairs who try—and often fail—to make sense of one another across generational, ideological, and economic divides . . . Even when these children and parents wound one another, Evaristo takes no sides, instead extending empathy and offering insights into what compels their sometimes maddening, sometimes relatable decisions."

—The Atlantic

"Girl, Woman, Other received half a Booker Prize, but it deserves all the glory . . . A breathtaking symphony of black women's voices, a clear-eyed survey of contemporary challenges that's nevertheless wonderfully life-affirming . . . Together, all these women present a cross-section of Britain that feels godlike in its scope and insight."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A big, busy novel with a large root system . . . Evaristo has a gift for appraising the lives of her characters with sympathy and grace while gently skewering some of their pretensions . . . Evaristo's lines are long, like Walt Whitman's or Allen Ginsberg's, and there are no periods at the ends of them. There's a looseness to her tone that gives this novel its buoyancy. Evaristo's wit helps too."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: What If?
subtitle: Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions
long_summary:
Millions of people visit xkcd.com each week to read Randall Munroe's iconic webcomic. His stick-figure drawings about science, technology, language, and love have earned a passionate following—and generated some wonderfully strange questions. What if you tried to hit a baseball pitched at 90 percent the speed of light? How fast can you hit a speed bump while driving and live? If there was a robot apocalypse, how long would humanity last?

In pursuit of answers, Munroe runs computer simulations, pores over stacks of declassified military research, solves differential equations, and consults with nuclear reactor operators. His responses are masterpieces of clarity and hilarity, complemented by signature xkcd comics. They often predict the complete annihilation of humankind, or at least a really big explosion.

The book features new and never-before-answered questions, along with updated and expanded versions of the most popular answers from the xkcd website—essential reading for anyone who loves to ponder the hypothetical.
short_summary: The creator of beloved webcomic xkcd tackles absurd hypothetical questions with rigorous science and signature humor. Munroe's answers are both hilarious and genuinely informative, making complex physics accessible through stick-figure wisdom.
author_bios: Randall Munroe is the author of the webcomic xkcd and the New York Times bestsellers What If?, What If? 2, Thing Explainer, and How To. A former NASA roboticist, he left the agency in 2006 to draw comics on the internet full time. The International Astronomical Union named asteroid 4942 Munroe after him. He lives in Massachusetts.
quotes:
"What If? maintains a delightfully free-wheeling tone throughout, especially when complicated calculations lead to whimsical results...Despite all the hard facts and gigantic numbers, it never feels like a textbook—and you don't have to be a rocket scientist to enjoy it. A."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Catchy and approachable...There's plenty of scientific rigor behind his elaborate explanations but he punctuates them with sly humor and winningly primitive cartoon diagrams...A cut above so many popular science and technology books."

—NPR

"It's fun to watch as Munroe tackles each question and examines every possible complication with nerdy and methodical aplomb, his distinctive scribblings providing clever running commentary of peanut-gallery jokes as his train of thought (sometimes) happily derails. The delightfully demented What If? is the most fun you can have with math and science, short of becoming your own evil genius...We feel the tug of Munroe's playful yet existentially-tinged worldview, and all that geek logic and number-crunching becomes unexpectedly poignant."

—The Boston Globe

title: Delicious Foods
long_summary:
After her husband's sudden death, Darlene turns to drugs to numb her grief—and one day simply vanishes. Her eleven-year-old son Eddie searches desperately for her, unaware that she's been lured by false promises to a remote farm run by Delicious Foods, a shady company that traps workers in modern-day slavery.

Held captive and forced into brutal labor to pay off fabricated debts, Darlene is kept compliant with a steady drug supply. Meanwhile, Eddie grows up haunted by her disappearance, determined to find the mother he lost.

Hannaham tells this harrowing story through three unforgettable voices: a mother, her son, and even the drug that ensnares her. His daring, shape-shifting prose infuses devastating experience with unexpected wit and grace. At once contemporary and historical, this powerful novel explores the unbreakable bond between mother and child while wrestling with questions of love and freedom, forgiveness and survival.
short_summary: When grief drives Darlene to drugs, she vanishes into a world of modern slavery while her young son searches desperately for her. Told through three voices—including the drug itself—this is both devastating social commentary and profound love story.
author_bios: James Hannaham is the author of God Says No, a Stonewall Book Award finalist, and Delicious Foods, which won the PEN/Faulkner Award and the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award. The novel was also a Los Angeles Times Book Prize and Dayton Literary Peace Prize finalist and a New York Times Notable Book. He lives in Brooklyn and teaches at the Pratt Institute.
quotes:
"This is a book of astonishing originality and power. In Delicious Foods, James Hannaham has created a wholly new world--a hallucinatory place shot through with struggle and terrible deeds--but one never lacking light or hope. Hannaham reinvents the Southern gothic with prose at once brutal and lyrical and drop-dead gorgeous. This is a hell of a novel."

—Dave Eggers, author of A Hologram for the King and The Circle

"James Hannaham's new novel is a tour de force. Gripping, haunting, and deeply moving, it beguiles the reader with the urgent immediacy of its characters' lives, while also reverberating with universal themes of freedom and enslavement, love and survival."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize winner for A Visit from the Goon Squad

"Hannaham's seductive and disturbing second novel grips the reader from page one... The light he shines on the realities of racial injustice, human trafficking, drug abuse, and exploitation make a deep imprint on the reader. But as devastating as Darlene, Eddie, and the other laborers' situations become, the heroic themes of love, forgiveness, and redemption carry this memorable story."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Pulphead
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
In Pulphead, John Jeremiah Sullivan takes readers on an exhilarating tour of American culture—popular, unpopular, and completely forgotten. Channeling the gonzo energy of Hunter S. Thompson and the sharp insight of Joan Didion, Sullivan brings his own laid-back, erudite Southern charm to show us how we really live now.

From his native Kentucky, Sullivan introduces us to Constantine Rafinesque, a nineteenth-century polymath who concocted a fantastical prehistory of the New World. In modern times, he ventures to a Christian rock festival in the Ozarks, meets MTV's Real World alumni who've created their own economy of minor celebrity in Florida, and follows the trail of the blues across the South. He investigates the formative years of Michael Jackson and Axl Rose in Indiana, then travels to the Gulf Coast in Katrina's wake—and returns as residents confront the BP oil spill.

Gradually, a unifying narrative emerges about America that we've never heard told this way. It's a fun-house mirror tour that reveals who we are in ways we never imagined. We don't know whether to laugh or cry at this reflection—and those inevitable sob-guffaws attest to Sullivan's remarkable power.
short_summary: Sullivan dissects American pop culture with hilarious precision and hang-dog charm. From Christian rock festivals to MTV alumni, his essays reveal the age-old strangeness of how we live now.
author_bios: John Jeremiah Sullivan lives in Wilmington, North Carolina, and is a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine. He is the author of Blood Horses: Notes of a Sportswriter's Son and the essay collection Pulphead. His awards include the Whiting Award, the National Magazine Award, the James Beard Writing Award, and the Windham-Campbell Prize.
quotes:
"[The essays in Pulphead are] among the liveliest magazine features written by anyone in the past 10 years . . . What they have in common, though, whether low or high of brow, is their author's essential curiosity about the world, his eye for the perfect detail, and his great good humor in revealing both his subjects' and his own foibles . . . a collection that shows why Sullivan might be the best magazine writer around."

—NPR

"One ascendant talent who deserves to be widely read and encouraged is John Jeremiah Sullivan . . . Pulphead is one of the most involving collections of essays to appear in many a year."

—Larry McMurtry, Harper's Magazine

"The age-old strangeness of American pop culture gets dissected with hilarious and revelatory precision…Sullivan writes an extraordinary prose that's stuffed with off-beat insight gleaned from rapt, appalled observations and suffused with a hang-dog charm. The result is an arresting take on the American imagination."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Memorial Drive
subtitle: A Daughter's Memoir
long_summary:
At nineteen, Natasha Trethewey's world shattered when her former stepfather shot and killed her mother. Grieving and thrust into unimaginable trauma, she confronted the twin pulls of life and death—an experience that would lastingly shape the artist she became.

With penetrating insight and a searing voice that moves from wrenching to elegiac, the Pulitzer Prize–winning poet investigates this profound experience of pain, loss, and grief as an entry point into understanding her mother's tragic life and her own inheritance of fierce love and resilience. Moving through her mother's history in the deeply segregated South and her own girlhood as a "child of miscegenation" in Mississippi, Trethewey plumbs her sense of dislocation and displacement leading up to the harrowing crime on Memorial Drive in Atlanta in 1985.

Memorial Drive offers a compelling look at the shared human experience of sudden loss while providing a piercing glimpse at the enduring effects of white racism and domestic abuse. Animated by unforgettable prose and inflected by a poet's attention to language, this is a luminous, urgent, and visceral memoir from one of our most important contemporary writers.
short_summary: When Trethewey was nineteen, her former stepfather murdered her mother in a crime that would define both women's legacies. A luminous memoir about grief, resilience, and the enduring effects of racism and domestic violence.
author_bios: Natasha Trethewey is a former US poet laureate and author of five poetry collections and a book of creative nonfiction. She is Board of Trustees Professor of English at Northwestern University and won the 2007 Pulitzer Prize in Poetry for Native Guard.
quotes:
"Beautifully composed, achingly sad...This profound story of the horrors of domestic abuse and a daughter's eternal love for her mother will linger long after the book's last page is turned."

—Publishers Weekly

"[A] graceful, moving memoir...Delicate prose distinguishes a narrative of tragedy and grief."

—Kirkus

"Natasha Trethewey has composed a riveting memoir that reads like a detective story about her mother's murder by a malevolent ex-husband. It reads with all the poise and clarity of Trethewey's unforgettable poetry—heartrending without a trace of pathos, wise and smart at once, unforgettable. The short section her mother penned as she was trying to escape the marriage moved me to tears. I read the book in one gulp and expect to reread it more than once. A must-read classic."

—Mary Karr, author of The Liars' Club, Cherry & Lit

title: Fourth of July Creek
long_summary:
In the remote towns of western Montana, social worker Pete Snow battles professional isolation, personal demons, and a culture deeply suspicious of government interference. When he encounters Benjamin Pearl—an undernourished, nearly feral eleven-year-old living in the wilderness—Pete meets the boy's father, Jeremiah, a paranoid survivalist convinced the End Times are coming.

With careful persistence, Pete slowly earns fragile trust from both father and son. But when his own estranged thirteen-year-old daughter vanishes, Pete confronts a devastating irony: the man dedicated to saving other people's children has catastrophically failed his own.

As Jeremiah's activities draw FBI attention, Pete finds himself caught in the crossfire of a massive manhunt that will leave no one unscathed. Set against Montana's brutal beauty, this unflinching debut explores America's violent contradictions—freedom and paranoia, independence and isolation, the reverberations of neglect in innocent lives.
short_summary: When a Montana social worker encounters a survivalist and his feral son living off-grid, their fragile trust unravels as FBI attention and personal tragedy collide in devastating ways.
author_bios: Smith Henderson is the author of Fourth of July Creek and lives in California and Montana.
quotes:
"This book left me awestruck; a stunning debut which reads like the work of a writer at the height of his power. Begins with the story of one struggling man and his family and soon seems to encompass and address all of modern America's problems. Fourth of July Creek is a masterful achievement and Smith Henderson is certain to end up a household name."

—Philipp Meyer, New York Times bestselling author of The Son

"Fourth of July Creek is also an impressive book —deeply so. Cormac McCarthy's shadow may loom heavy across the prose—darkling it, to use one of the McCarthyesque verbs that Henderson deploys—but the story this prose conveys, and the manner in which Henderson unfurls it, bears its own unalloyed power."

—The New York Times

"Breathtaking...heartbreaking…Henderson's immersive, colorful style makes this scenic journey worthwhile. He's a curious kind of hard-boiled poet - part Raymond Chandler, part Denis Johnson."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: The Largesse of the Sea Maiden
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
The Largesse of the Sea Maiden is the long-awaited new story collection from Denis Johnson, written in the luminous prose that made him one of the most beloved and important writers of his generation. This collection finds Johnson in new territory, contemplating the ghosts of the past and the elusive and unexpected ways the mysteries of the universe assert themselves.

Finished shortly before Johnson's death, this collection serves as the final word from a writer whose work will live on for many years to come. Each story is weighted with astonishing humanity and generosity of spirit, balanced by lyrical examinations of time's passage and the mysteries of human connection. Johnson turns toward the past, conjuring up the ghosts of those he's loved and lost, writing of wild experiences with affectionate abandon.
short_summary: Johnson's final collection finds the master storyteller contemplating mortality and transcendence with his signature luminous prose. A posthumous gift that cements his status as one of literature's essential voices.
author_bios: Denis Johnson was the author of nine novels, one novella, two books of short stories, five collections of poetry, two collections of plays, and one book of reportage. His novel Tree of Smoke won the 2007 National Book Award and was a finalist for the 2007 Pulitzer Prize, and Train Dreams was a finalist for the 2012 Pulitzer Prize.
quotes:
"A posthumous masterpiece . . . With this book, Johnson has only cemented his status as one of his generation's greatest writers. . . . Each story in Largesse is weighted by an astonishing humanity, a generosity of spirit that's evened out by lyrical dissections of time's passage and the mysteries of connection. . . . Here's an author turning toward the past, conjuring up the ghosts of those he's loved and lost, writing of wild experiences with affectionate abandon. Few have linked themselves between the reader and the page so intimately—so cosmically—as he does here."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Nobody ever wrote like Denis Johnson. Nobody ever came close . . . We're just left with this miraculous book, these perfect stories, the last words from one of the world's greatest writers."

—NPR

"Sly, open-ended, and meticulously wise . . . Johnson, in all his work, aimed to locate the hidden, actual face of things. But the new stories build without those miraculous balls of hail, and their truths are necessarily deeper, and more precise. . . . [Johnson] is a writer whose ambitions were in their own way as broad and burgeoning as Dostoyevsky's. He is for all time."

—Rachel Kushner, Bookforum

title: The Iliad
long_summary:
When Emily Wilson's translation of The Odyssey appeared in 2017, critics hailed it as "a revelation" and "a cultural landmark" that would forever change how Homer is read in English. Now Wilson returns with an equally transformative translation of Homer's other great epic—the most revered war poem of all time.

The Iliad roars with the clamor of arms, the bellowing boasts of victors, the fury and grief of loss, and the anguished cries of dying men. It sings, too, of the sublime magnitude of the world—the fierce beauty of nature and the gods' grand schemes beyond mortal understanding.

In Wilson's hands, this thrilling, magical, and often horrifying tale gallops at a pace befitting its legendary battle scenes. Her crisp but resonant language evokes the poem's deep pathos and reveals palpably real, complex characters—both human and divine. The culmination of a decade of intense engagement with antiquity's most beautiful and emotionally complex poetry, Wilson's Iliad gives us a complete Homer for our generation.
short_summary: Homer's epic war poem gets the Emily Wilson treatment. Her translation captures both the thunder of battle and the intimate grief of loss with language that feels urgent and alive.
author_bios: HOMER's identity remains shrouded in mystery. Most scholars agree that an epic poet named Homer likely existed between 900 to 700 B.C.E. Legend says he was a blind bard from Ionia, but no account can be verified. The Iliad and The Odyssey were derived from oral storytelling tradition and remain among the most significant narratives in Western literature. Emily Wilson is a professor of classical studies at the University of Pennsylvania, a MacArthur Fellow, and a Guggenheim Fellow. She has translated works by Sophocles, Euripides, and Seneca.
quotes:
"Emily Wilson's translation of the Iliad brings Homer's great war story to rousing new life….propulsive….buoyant and expressive."

—Natalie Haynes, The New York Times

"Readable, relevant and from the heart, this is the Iliad we have all been waiting for, whether we knew it or not."

—Naoíse Mac Sweeney, The Washington Post

"Masterful…A bloody tale of ancient war and grief comes to vibrant life in modern-day English. Wilson has again presented a Homer that sings."

—Kirkus

title: The Yellow Birds
long_summary:
"The war tried to kill us in the spring." So begins this devastating account of friendship forged in combat.

In Al Tafar, Iraq, twenty-one-year-old Private Bartle and eighteen-year-old Private Murphy fight to survive as their platoon launches a brutal battle for the city. Bound together since basic training—when Bartle promises to bring Murphy safely home—the two young soldiers find themselves dropped into a war neither could have imagined.

In the relentless days that follow, they struggle to protect each other from forces pressing in on every side: insurgents, crushing fatigue, and the psychological toll of constant danger. As reality blurs into nightmare, Murphy becomes increasingly detached from the world around him, and Bartle takes actions he never thought possible.

With profound emotional insight into the hidden costs of war—especially on the mothers and families left behind—The Yellow Birds captures the devastating beauty found even in humanity's darkest moments.
short_summary: Two young soldiers bound by an impossible promise struggle to survive the Iraq War. Powers writes with devastating beauty about friendship, loss, and the hidden costs of combat.
author_bios: Kevin Powers is the author of The Yellow Birds, which won the PEN/Hemingway Award, the Guardian First Book Award, and was a National Book Award Finalist. Born and raised in Richmond, Virginia, he graduated from Virginia Commonwealth University and holds an MFA from the University of Texas at Austin, where he was a Michener Fellow in Poetry. He served in the US Army in Iraq from 2004 to 2005.
quotes:
"Remarkable for its intensity of both feeling and expression. In this book about death, every line is a defiant assertion of the power of beauty to revivify, whether beauty shows itself in nature or (later) in art. Graves, Owen, and Sassoon would have recognised this war and the strange poetry it has bred."

—Hilary Mantel, author of Bring Up the Bodies & Wolf Hall

"Compelling, brilliantly written, and heart-breakingly true, The Yellow Birds belongs in the same category as Tim O'Brien's The Things They Carried and Norman Mailer's The Naked and the Dead. Thus far the definitive novel of our long wars in the Middle East; this book is certain to be read and taught for generations to come."

—Philipp Meyer, author of The Son & American Rust

"The Yellow Birds is harrowing, inexplicably beautiful, and utterly, urgently necessary."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

title: Replaceable You
subtitle: Adventures in Human Anatomy
long_summary:
The human body is the world's most complex machine—and the only one without replacement parts from the manufacturer. For centuries, medicine has improvised with whatever's available: sculpting noses from brass, borrowing skin from frogs, crafting eye parts from jet canopies and breasts from petroleum by-products. Today we're attempting to grow body parts from scratch using stem cells and 3D printers.

In Replaceable You, Mary Roach explores the remarkable advances and difficult questions prompted by our bodies' inevitable failings. When does a person decide they'd be better off with a prosthetic than their existing limb? Can a donated heart be made to beat forever? Can an intestine substitute for a vagina?

Roach dives in with characteristic verve and infectious wit. Her travels take her to a legendary Boston burn unit, a "superclean" xeno-pigsty in China, and a stem cell "hair nursery" in San Diego's tech hub. She spends time in a working 1950s iron lung, stays up all night with recovery techs as they disassemble and reassemble a tissue donor, and travels across Mongolia with cataract surgeons.

Irrepressible and accessible, Replaceable You immerses readers in the wondrous, improbable quest to build a new you.
short_summary: Roach explores medicine's quest to replace failing body parts, from brass noses to 3D-printed organs. Her journey through burn units, pig farms, and stem cell labs reveals the wondrous complexities of rebuilding human anatomy.
genres: Science / Life Sciences / Human Anatomy & Physiology
author_bios: Mary Roach is the author of seven best-selling works of nonfiction, including Grunt, Stiff, and Fuzz. Her writing has appeared in National Geographic and the New York Times Magazine, among other publications. She lives in California.
quotes:
"Since she burst onto the scene with 2003's Stiff: The Curious Lives of Human Cadavers, the science writer Mary Roach has been grossing readers out with curiosity, humanity — and alarming gusto. And we can't look away."

—The New York Times

"This book is so good and it's on my list because it's right on topic with Gone Before Goodbye. Replaceable You by Mary Roach is all about how in the future, we will be able to replace every organ in our body that fails."

—Reese Witherspoon

"Science writer Roach engagingly explores the past, present, and future of fabricated replacement body parts and regenerative medicine. She has previously penned books about the body, including Gulp (2013), and brings her distinctive nonfiction writing style, headlined by curiosity, enthusiasm, and lots of humor, to this subject, too. . . .  Highly recommended reading for those curious about 'fixes' for the body and the world of biotechnology."

—Tony Miksanek - Booklist

title: There But For The
long_summary:
At a dinner party in posh Greenwich, Miles Garth abruptly leaves the table, locks himself in an upstairs room, and refuses to come out. As news of his peculiar protest spreads, an eclectic group of neighbors and friends gathers around the house, trying to make sense of what's happened.

Miles's story unfolds through four distinct perspectives: Anna, a woman in her forties; Mark, a man in his sixties; May, a woman in her eighties; and ten-year-old Brooke. The twist? None of these narrators knows Miles more than slightly. Through their attempts to understand this stranger's breakdown, Smith poses profound questions about human connection: How much can we ever truly know about another person? What are the consequences of our most fleeting daily encounters?

Brilliantly audacious and disarmingly playful, There but for the showcases Smith's trademark wit and wordplay while exploring our need for separation—from our pasts and from one another—and the redemptive possibilities that emerge when we try to bridge those gaps.
short_summary: When a man locks himself in a room at a dinner party and refuses to leave, four near-strangers become unlikely witnesses to his breakdown. Smith's witty, inventive novel probes the mysteries of human connection.
author_bios: Ali Smith is the author of many works of fiction, including, most recently, Companion Piece, the "Seasonal Quartet," Public library and other stories, and How to be both, which won the Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction, the Goldsmiths Prize, and the Costa Novel Award. Her work has four times been short-listed for the Man Booker Prize. Most recently, she won the George Orwell Prize for Political Fiction for Summer. Born in Inverness, Scotland, she lives in Cambridge, England.
quotes:
"You could call Ali Smith's new novel, There But For The, a tragicomedy . . . The fun comes in the form of Smith's satire of the media . . . of new technology users and of upper-middle-class snobbery . . . Though the locations shift and characters appear out of nowhere, Smith agilely keeps the narrative together. Everything connects—even if the people can't. A must-read."

—Toronto NOW

"In There But For The Ali Smith displays her usual fizz and artistry. She always surprises, she never disappoints."

—Kate Atkinson, author of Shrines of Gaiety, Life After Life & Started Early, Took My Dog

"A beguiling ode to human connection shot through with existential wonder and virtuosic wordplay. If you fell for Jennifer Egan's A Visit From the Goon Squad, you'll appreciate Smith's formal twists and turns—and there's more where There came from."

—Time

title: In the Kingdom of Ice
subtitle: The Grand and Terrible Polar Voyage of the USS Jeannette
long_summary:
In the late nineteenth century, one of the last unmapped areas of the globe obsessed explorers and dreamers alike: the North Pole. No one knew what lay beyond the fortress of ice rimming the northern oceans, though theories abounded. The world's foremost cartographer, German August Petermann, believed warm currents sustained a verdant island at the top of the world.

James Gordon Bennett, the eccentric and stupendously wealthy owner of The New York Herald, had recently captured global attention by dispatching Stanley to find Dr. Livingstone in Africa. Now he was keen to recreate that sensation on an even grander scale. He funded an official U.S. naval expedition to reach the Pole, choosing as captain young officer George Washington De Long, who had gained fame for a daring rescue off Greenland's coast.

On July 8, 1879, the USS Jeannette set sail from San Francisco with 32 men aboard, carrying the aspirations of a young country burning to become a world power.
