The ship sailed into uncharted seas but was soon trapped in pack ice. Two years into the harrowing voyage, the hull was breached and the crew abandoned ship. The Jeannette sank within an hour, leaving the men marooned a thousand miles north of Siberia with minimal supplies.

Thus began their desperate march across endless ice—a frozen hell in the world's most lonesome corner, battling madness, starvation, and the unforgiving Arctic in their fight for survival.
short_summary: The true story of the USS Jeannette's doomed 1879 Arctic expedition, when 32 men became trapped in ice and fought for survival across a thousand miles of frozen wasteland. Gripping polar adventure meets Gilded Age ambition.
author_bios: Hampton Sides is the author of New York Times bestselling histories On Desperate Ground, In the Kingdom of Ice, Hellhound on his Trail, Blood and Thunder, and Ghost Soldiers, which won the PEN USA Award for Nonfiction. He lives in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
quotes:
"First-rate polar history and adventure narrative...wonderfully evocative.... Sides vividly recounts the horrors [of the voyage]. In the Kingdom of Ice is a harrowing story, well told."

—The New York Times

"Unforgettable…a pulse-racing epic of endurance set against an exceedingly bizarre Arctic backdrop…[Sides'] descriptions of the physical challenges the men face and the eerie landscape that surrounds them are masterful. As De Long and his crew attempt to save themselves, the story grows in suspense and psychological complexity…More strange and fantastic turns follow, involving uncharted and uninhabited lands, and it pains me that I cannot describe them without spoiling the pleasure of those who have not yet read In the Kingdom of Ice. Sides' book is a masterful work of history and storytelling."

—The Los Angeles Times

"America's own brush with epic polar tragedy, the subject of Hampton Sides' phenomenally gripping new book, is a less well-known affair…What ensued — a struggle to survive and a nearly 1,000-mile trek across the Arctic Ocean and into the vastness of Siberia — stands as one of the most perilous journeys ever. Sides works story-telling magic as he evokes the pathos and suffering of what unfolded: De Long and his crew endured hardships that boggle the mind. But there is also beauty here… [Sides] writes superbly on the geography of Siberia and the Arctic, and the abundant bird and animal life the explorers encountered on their travels, which took them across ice, storm-tossed seas, treacherous tundra, rocky seacoasts, and volcanic islands."

—The Boston Globe

title: Black Is the Body
subtitle: Stories from My Grandmother's Time, My Mother's Time, and Mine
long_summary:
In these twelve deeply personal, interconnected essays, Bernard explores the complexities of race, identity, and belonging through the lens of her own experiences. She examines growing up Black in the South with a family name inherited from a white man, surviving a random stabbing at a New Haven coffee shop, and marrying a white man from the North before bringing him home to meet her family.

Bernard also writes about adopting two children from Ethiopia and navigating life as a professor in a predominantly white New England college town. Each essay seeks to discover new ways of talking about race and telling difficult truths with unflinching honesty.

Through intimate storytelling that weaves personal narrative with broader American histories, Bernard creates a powerful meditation on what it means to live in a Black body in contemporary America. Her voice is both vulnerable and incisive, offering fresh perspectives on familiar struggles while illuminating the ongoing complexities of racial identity in our divided nation.
short_summary: Twelve interconnected essays explore race, identity, and belonging through Bernard's personal experiences—from growing up Black in the South to raising adopted Ethiopian children in predominantly white New England.
author_bios: Emily Bernard was born and raised in Nashville, Tennessee, and received her PhD in American studies from Yale University. She has received grants from the Ford Foundation and NEH, plus a W. E. B. Du Bois Resident Fellowship at Harvard University. Her essays have appeared in The American Scholar, Best American Essays, and Best African American Essays. She is the Julian Lindsay Green and Gold Professor of English at the University of Vermont.
quotes:
"My very favorite book that I have read so far this year…It's really life changing. If you get no other book this year, get Black Is the Body by Emily Bernard."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Of the 12 essays here, there's not one that even comes close to being forgettable. Bernard's language is fresh, poetically compact, and often witty ... Bernard proves herself to be a revelatory storyteller of race in America who can hold her own with some of those great writers she teaches."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"Contemplative and compassionate ... Bernard's voice is personable yet incisive in exploring the lived reality of race ... [Her] wisdom and compassion radiate throughout this collection."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Man in the Woods
long_summary:
Paul has been on his own since he was a teenager—hunting for food in Alaska, fighting forest fires, being deputized in manhunts across South Dakota. He thought his life would remain untethered, touched only by transient strangers.

Then he met Kate and her daughter Ruby, who offered something he'd never known: order, stability, love. But Paul is a man of deep convictions, and the compromises most people make to get along in the world elude him.

After getting fired from his job remodeling a luxurious Manhattan apartment, Paul stops at a campground along the highway to gather his thoughts. Instead of peace, he finds a man savagely beating his dog—forcing Paul to make a fateful decision that will change everything.

With psychological acuity and razor-sharp prose, award-winning novelist Scott Spencer delivers an unforgettable journey of conscience, morality, and what it means to be a man of principle in a compromised world.
short_summary: After witnessing brutal animal abuse at a roadside campground, a principled carpenter makes a split-second decision that unravels his carefully rebuilt life. Spencer crafts a taut psychological thriller about conscience and consequence.
author_bios: Scott Spencer is the author of twelve novels, including Endless Love, Waking the Dead, A Ship Made of Paper, and Willing. He has taught at Columbia University, the Iowa Writers' Workshop, Williams College, the University of Virginia, and at Eastern Correctional Facility as part of the Bard Prison Initiative. He lives in upstate New York.
quotes:
"We don't often encounter novels that combine shrewd plotting, strong characters and gorgeous writing, but Scott Spencer's "Man in the Woods" does precisely that."

—The Washington Post

"Spencer, a deft explorer of obsessive love and violence, confronts the consequences of doing wrong for all the right reasons in his exquisite latest."

—Publishers Weekly

"[A] compelling setup and stunning conclusion...The depth of the characters, the questions they ask and the challenge they confront stay with the reader long after the conclusion."

—Kirkus

title: Memorial Days
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Many cultural and religious traditions expect those who are grieving to step away from the world. In contemporary life, we are more often met with red tape and to-do lists. This is exactly what happened to Geraldine Brooks when her partner of more than three decades, Tony Horwitz—just sixty years old and seemingly healthy—collapsed and died on a Washington, D.C. sidewalk.

After spending their early years together as foreign correspondents in conflict zones, Geraldine and Tony had settled into a rich life on Martha's Vineyard, raising two boys. Their days were filled with meaningful work, good humor, and tenderness—writing during the day, cooking family dinners in the evening, watching sunsets at the beach with friends. All of this ended abruptly on Memorial Day 2019 with the phone call we all dread.

The demands were immediate and relentless. Without space to grieve, the sudden loss became a yawning gulf. Three years later, Brooks booked a flight to a remote island off the coast of Australia, finally giving herself time to mourn. In a shack on the pristine, rugged coast, she often went days without seeing another person, pondering how different cultures grieve and what rituals might help rebuild a life around the void of Tony's death.

A spare and profoundly moving memoir, Memorial Days captures both a larger-than-life man and a timeless love, exquisitely revealing the joy, agony, and mystery of life.
short_summary: Brooks retreats to a remote Australian island three years after her husband's sudden death, seeking the space to grieve that modern life denied her. An exquisite meditation on loss and love.
author_bios: Geraldine Brooks is the author of six novels, including Horse, People of the Book, Year of Wonders, and the Pulitzer Prize–winning March. She has also written acclaimed works of nonfiction, including Nine Parts of Desire and Foreign Correspondence. Her books have been translated into more than thirty languages and have sold millions of copies worldwide. Born and raised in Australia, Brooks divides her time between Sydney and Martha's Vineyard.
quotes:
"Memorial Days joins Joan Didion's The Year of Magical Thinking and Michelle Zauner's Crying in H Mart as memoirs of grief worth seeking out. ... Memorial Days gives due justice to what it means to live and love and experience loss."

—Chicago Tribune

"This intimate memoir of grief is a lifeline to others dealing with loss. ... Intensely intimate and candid ... Brooks tracks the geography of grief with patience and grace as she comes to terms with the ongoing nature of outliving the ones you love most. ... Her memoir is certainly a testament to her own unique loss, but it's moreover a lifeline to others who will find themselves in this familiar, shattered landscape of grief."

—Los Angeles Times

"Brooks wield[s] precise and often beautiful language and, in the most graceful way possible, point[s] a way forward. A rich account of marriage and mourning ... Memorial Days contains much compassionate advice for those who have, or will, suffer the same ferocious blow."

—The Washington Post

title: Heart the Lover
long_summary:
You knew I'd write a book about you someday.

Our narrator understands good love stories—their secrets and subtext, their highs and free falls. But her greatest love story never followed the simple rules.

In the fall of her senior year, she meets two star students from her 17th-Century Lit class: Sam and Yash. Best friends living off campus in an elegant professor's house, the boys invite her into their intoxicating world of academic fervor, rapid-fire banter and raucous card games. They nickname her Jordan, and she quickly discovers the pleasures of friendship, love and her own intellectual ambition.

But youthful passion is unpredictable, and soon she finds herself at the center of a charged triangle. As graduation approaches, choices made will alter these three lives forever.

Decades later, the vulnerable days of Jordan's youth seem comfortably behind her. But when a surprise visit brings unexpected news, the past crashes into the present. She must return to a world she left behind and confront the decisions and deceptions of her younger self.

Written with superb wit and emotional sensitivity, Heart the Lover is a deeply moving love story that celebrates literature, forgiveness, and the transformative bonds that shape our lives.
short_summary: College seniors navigate friendship, literature, and desire in this intimate novel about choices that echo across decades. When the past resurfaces unexpectedly, our narrator must reckon with her younger self and the love triangle that changed everything.
author_bios: Lily King is the New York Times bestselling author of six novels, including Euphoria and Writers & Lovers, and the story collection Five Tuesdays in Winter. Her work has won the Kirkus Prize, the New England Book Award for Fiction, the Maine Book Award for Fiction, and a Whiting Award. Her books have been translated into twenty-eight languages. She lives in Portland, Maine.
quotes:
"Time moves like memory in Heart the Lover—urgent, intimate, elusive. What does it mean to carry a story you never get to finish? With breathtaking precision, Lily King writes about love that lingers and choices that haunt. I read it in a single, breathless sitting."

—Ruth Ozeki, author of the Women's Prize for Fiction winner The Book of Form and Emptiness

"King is a genius at writing love stories . . . Her mostly sunny version of the campus novel is an enjoyable alternative to the current vogue for dark academia. Tragedies are on the way, though, as we know they must be, as nothing gold can stay and these darn fictional characters seem to make the same kinds of stupid mistakes that real people do. Tenderhearted readers will soak the pages of the last chapter with tears. That college love affair you never got over? Come wallow in this gorgeous version of it."

—Kirkus

"Indescribably good. It is incredible that Lily has managed to tell such an epic love story in just 250 pages, and I emerged feeling ruined for all other books. I adored these characters and feel lucky to have known them. I'm in awe. A perfect literary love story."

—Florence Knapp, New York Times bestselling author of The Names

title: Kansas City Lightning
subtitle: The Rise and Times of Charlie Parker
long_summary:
Charlie "Yardbird" Parker lived one of the most dramatic and tragic lives in American music. From his breakthrough as a Kansas City prodigy in the late 1930s to his death in 1955 at just thirty-five, Parker revolutionized jazz with the creation of bebop, even as drug addiction shadowed his career and cut it short.

Since then, Parker has become legend—immortalized in bootlegs and reissues, in the graffiti "Bird Lives!", in annual festivals and daily radio tributes, and on screen in Clint Eastwood's Bird. Yet his full story has rarely been told.

In this first volume of a projected two-part biography, Stanley Crouch draws on decades of research and interviews to uncover the real Parker: the gifted teenager shaped by Depression-era Kansas City, the apprentice absorbing lessons from Lester Young and Count Basie, and the young man torn between music, drugs, his domineering mother, and his teenage bride.

With the authority of a jazz scholar and the storytelling skill of a novelist, Crouch brings Parker vividly to life.
short_summary: Stanley Crouch's long-awaited biography captures Charlie Parker as a young genius coming of age in Depression-era Kansas City. An intimate portrait of the artist before the legend.
author_bios: Stanley Crouch was twice nominated for the National Book Critics Circle Award for Notes of a Hanging Judge and The All-American Skin Game. His other books include Always in Pursuit, The Artificial White Man, and the acclaimed novel Don't the Moon Look Lonesome. He served as artistic consultant for jazz programming at Lincoln Center, was president of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation, and was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He died in 2020.
quotes:
"A tour de force that is the print equivalent of a long, bravura jazz performance. . . . Crouch has given us a bone-deep understanding of Parker's music and the world that produced it. In his pages, Bird still lives."

—The Washington Post

"It is from Mr. Crouch, a novelist as well as a critic and essayist, that we come to see Charlie Parker in the context of his time and place in America. . . . One comes away from Mr. Crouch's book wanting more."

—The Wall Street Journal

"A book about a jazz hero written in a heroic style. . . a bebop Beowulf."

—The New York Times

title: Katabasis
long_summary:
Alice Law has sacrificed everything—her pride, her health, her love life, and definitely her sanity—for one goal: becoming one of the brightest minds in Magick. All to work with Professor Jacob Grimes at Cambridge, the greatest magician in the world.

That is, until he dies in a magical accident that could possibly be her fault.

Grimes is now in Hell, and Alice is going in after him. His recommendation could determine her entire future, and even death won't stop her pursuit of academic glory. Neither will the fact that her rival, Peter Murdoch, has reached the same conclusion.

With nothing but tales of Orpheus and Dante to guide them, enough chalk to draw the necessary Pentagrams, and burning desire to make their academic trauma mean something, they venture across Hell to save a man they don't even like.

But Hell isn't like the storybooks describe, Magick isn't always the answer, and something in Alice and Peter's shared past could forge them into perfect allies—or lead to their doom.
short_summary: Two rival graduate students venture into Hell to rescue their dead professor's soul—and salvage their academic futures. Dark academia meets infernal adventure in this wickedly smart fantasy about ambition, trauma, and unlikely alliances.
author_bios: Rebecca F. Kuang is the #1 New York Times and Sunday Times bestselling author of the Poppy War trilogy, Babel: An Arcane History, and Yellowface. Her work has won the Nebula, Locus, Crawford, and British Book Awards. A Marshall Scholar, she has an MPhil in Chinese Studies from Cambridge and an MSc in Contemporary Chinese Studies from Oxford. She is pursuing a PhD in East Asian Languages and Literatures at Yale, studying diaspora, contemporary Sinophone literature, and Asian American literature.
quotes:
"Rich with allusion and illusion, Kuang crafts a witty, gory, harrowing ride that thoroughly roasts the perils and power structures of academia, while never losing sight of what it means to have a fragile, human heart."

—Leigh Bardugo, #1 New York Times bestselling author

"This is a tightly constructed novel that aims a clear lens on academia, with both its faults and its virtues. The heady draw of discovery is ever-present, even if what Alice is discovering is Hell. A learned, literary manifesto on academia—and its darkness."

—Kirkus

"What an adventure! Katabasis is a tour de force – literate, witty, and wise, it thrills and delights all the way to a hugely satisfying conclusion. I enjoyed it tremendously."

—Gareth Brown, international bestselling author of The Book of Doors

title: The God of the Woods
long_summary:
August 1975: a camp counselor discovers an empty bunk at an Adirondack summer camp. Barbara Van Laar, thirteen years old and daughter of the family that owns the camp, has vanished without a trace.

This isn't the first time tragedy has struck the Van Laars. Barbara's older brother disappeared fourteen years earlier and was never found. As panic spreads and a desperate search begins, the investigation unearths long-buried secrets that connect the wealthy camp-owning family to the blue-collar community that depends on them for survival.

Moore weaves together multiple storylines to create a gripping portrait of class, family dysfunction, and the dark undercurrents of a seemingly idyllic summer retreat. The God of the Woods is her most ambitious novel yet—a mystery that expands into something much larger and more devastating.
short_summary: When a teenager vanishes from her family's Adirondack summer camp, the investigation unearths secrets connecting a wealthy dynasty to the working-class community in its shadow.
author_bios: Liz Moore is the author of the New York Times bestselling novel Long Bright River, which was a Good Morning America Book Club pick and one of Barack Obama's favorite books of the year, as well as the acclaimed novels Heft and The Unseen World. A winner of the 2014-2015 Rome Prize in Literature, she lives in Philadelphia.
quotes:
"A riveting tale of a missing child that widens into a vast, acute portrait of youth, friendship, family secrets, and conflicting social circles. Intelligently done, and with a gimlet eye for telling detail, it's a brilliant trap full of secrets and lies."

—Douglas Stuart, Booker Prize winning author of Shuggie Bain & Young Mungo

"Riveting from page one to the last breathless word, The God of the Woods is about the many ways we find and lose both ourselves and others. This book flew by at lightning speed, but will stick with me for a very long time."

—Rebecca Makkai, New York Times bestselling author of I Have Some Questions For You

"The God of the Woods, like The Secret History, transports readers so deeply into its richly peopled, ominous world that, for hours, everything else falls away. . . . Breaking free of the spell Moore casts is close to impossible."

—The Washington Post

title: There is Power in a Union
subtitle: The Epic Story of Labor in America
long_summary:
From the textile mills of Lowell, Massachusetts—America's first real factories—to the triumph of unions in the twentieth century and their decline today, the contest between labor and capital has shaped our national experience.

Philip Dray's ambitious narrative chronicles organized labor's vital accomplishments and illuminates its central role in America's social, political, and cultural evolution. This epic, character-driven story unfolds across picket lines and union halls, jails and assembly lines, corporate boardrooms and the halls of Congress.

Dray demonstrates the urgency of the fight for fairness and economic democracy with visceral, dramatic storytelling. He reveals how this struggle for security and dignity remains especially relevant today, when ordinary Americans face mounting economic anxiety and uncertainty.
short_summary: An epic chronicle of American labor from the industrial age to today. Dray brings visceral storytelling to the ongoing struggle between workers and capital that has shaped our national character.
author_bios: Philip Dray is the author of several books of American cultural and political history, including At the Hands of Persons Unknown: The Lynching of Black America, which won the Robert F. Kennedy Book Award and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist; There Is Power in a Union: The Epic Story of Labor in America; and Capitol Men: The Epic Story of Reconstruction Through the Lives of the First Black Congressmen. He is an adjunct professor in the Journalism + Design Department at Eugene Lang College of Liberal Arts and lives in Brooklyn, New York.
quotes:
"Philip Dray's big and bold history of organized labor in America splendidly retells a story - or a multitude of stories - badly in need of retelling. The labor movement's decline in recent decades has accompanied a great national amnesia about all that the movement achieved for the nation. That amnesia threatens those achievements, so Dray's book is timely as well as gripping."

—Sean Wilentz, author of Chants Democratic: New York City and the Rise of the American Working Class & Bob Dylan in America

"The unending struggle between unions and big business has never been more vividly told. Philip Dray is a marvelous story teller who brings history memorably alive, and you will not soon forget the tales of murder and greed, commitment and sacrifice, that fill these pages. But this is more than history; the compelling saga of labor as a crucible for social change should prompt some honest and hard debate about what's happening to working men and women today."

—Bill Moyers

"Any union leader working to define and strengthen the role of organized labor in the 21st century must read There Is Power in a Union, a comprehensive and fascinating history of the American labor movement."

—Michael Winship, President, Writers Guild of America

title: Beautiful World, Where Are You
long_summary:
Alice, a novelist, meets Felix, who works in a warehouse, and asks him if he'd like to travel to Rome with her. In Dublin, her best friend Eileen is getting over a breakup and slips back into flirting with Simon, a man she has known since childhood.

Alice, Felix, Eileen, and Simon are still young—but life is catching up with them. They desire each other, they delude each other, they get together, they break apart. They have sex, they worry about sex, they worry about their friendships and the world they live in.

Are they standing in the last lighted room before the darkness, bearing witness to something? Will they find a way to believe in a beautiful world?
short_summary: Two couples navigate desire, friendship, and existential anxiety across Dublin and Rome. Rooney's epistolary novel captures millennial love with piercing intelligence and devastating clarity.
author_bios: Sally Rooney is an Irish novelist and author of Conversations with Friends, Normal People, and Beautiful World, Where Are You. She contributed to the writing and production of the Hulu/BBC television adaptation of Normal People.
quotes:
"[Rooney's] writing about sex is taut and direct. It's a narrative style I associate with the films of Andrew Haigh and Joanna Hogg, two great visual poets of social anxiety and reticence. Rooney's dialogue is frequently perfect . . . Beautiful World, Where Are You is Rooney's best novel yet."

—Brandon Taylor, The New York Times

"A tour de force. The dialogue never falters, and the prose burns up the page."

—Anne Enright, The Guardian

"It's a testament to Rooney's curious, cerebral gifts as a writer that she not only draws her readers into tolerating long stretches of such ruminations but makes them so entertaining. We feel we're in good company with our own end-time anxieties . . . In this ambitious novel of sentiment and ideas, which is so up to the minute in its global concerns, Rooney ironically reaches back to one of the oldest forms of the novel, the epistolary or letter form, to tell her story."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Toms River
subtitle: A Story of Science and Salvation
long_summary:
One of New Jersey's quiet seaside towns, Toms River became the unlikely setting for a decades-long environmental disaster that culminated in 2001 with one of the largest toxic dumping settlements in legal history. A community known for its Little League World Series champions instead made headlines for a different reason: a cluster of childhood cancers scientifically linked to local pollution.

For years, chemical companies had used Toms River as their private dumping ground, burying tens of thousands of leaky drums and discharging billions of gallons of contaminated wastewater into the town's river. In this astonishing work of investigative reporting, prize-winning journalist Dan Fagin recounts sixty years of rampant pollution and regulatory failure.

Fagin brings to life the everyday heroes who fought for justice: a young boy whose tumors had ravaged his body since birth, a nurse who documented alarming cancer rates, and a mother whose advocacy transformed her grief into action. He also chronicles the pioneering scientists who first linked pollutants to cancer, creating a gripping human drama rooted in scientific discovery.

A tale of corporate greed, government neglect, and ordinary people who refused to stay silent, Toms River serves as a cautionary example for industrial communities worldwide.
short_summary: Environmental disaster meets human courage in this investigation of a New Jersey town's fight against toxic pollution. Fagin transforms complex science into gripping narrative, revealing how ordinary people exposed corporate dumping and its devastating health consequences.
author_bios: Dan Fagin is associate professor of journalism and director of the Science, Health, and Environmental Reporting Program at New York University's Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute. For fifteen years, he was environmental writer at Newsday, where he was twice a principal member of Pulitzer Prize finalist teams. His cancer epidemiology articles earned the Science Journalism Award from the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the Science in Society Award from the National Association of Science Writers.
quotes:
"It's high time a book did for epidemiology what Jon Krakauer's best-selling Into Thin Air did for mountain climbing: transform a long sequence of painfully plodding steps and missteps into a narrative of such irresistible momentum that the reader not only understands what propels enthusiasts forward, but begins to strain forward as well, racing through the pages to get to the heady views at the end. And such is the power of Dan Fagin's Toms River, surely a new classic of science reporting . . . a sober story of probability and compromise, laid out with the care and precision that characterizes both good science and great journalism."

—The New York Times

"A thrilling journey full of twists and turns, Toms River is essential reading for our times. Dan Fagin handles topics of great complexity with the dexterity of a scholar, the honesty of a journalist, and the dramatic skill of a novelist."

—Siddhartha Mukherjee, M.D., author of the Pulitzer Prize–winning The Emperor of All Maladies & The Gene

"At once intimate and objective, Toms River is the heartbreaking account of one town's struggle with a legacy of toxic pollution. Dan Fagin has written a powerful and important book."

—Elizabeth Kolbert, author of the Pulizter Prize-winning The Sixth Extinction & Field Notes from a Catastrophe

title: The Covenant of Water
subtitle: An Oprah’s Book Club Selection
long_summary:
Abraham Verghese's long-awaited masterpiece spans the years 1900 to 1977, following three generations of a Christian family in Kerala, South India, bound by a haunting mystery: in every generation, at least one person dies by drowning.

The story opens as a twelve-year-old girl travels by boat to meet her husband for the first time. She becomes Big Ammachi, the beloved matriarch of an extraordinary family that will endure profound hardship, celebrate unexpected triumph, and witness the sweeping changes of a rapidly transforming world.

This epic novel weaves together love, faith, and medicine across decades of Indian history. As each generation grapples with their strange inheritance, they must also navigate the complexities of colonial rule, independence, and modernization. Verghese brings his unique perspective as both physician and storyteller to create an unforgettable portrait of family resilience and the mysteries that bind us across time.
short_summary: Three generations of a South Indian family are haunted by a peculiar curse—someone in each generation drowns. Verghese weaves medicine, history, and family saga into something transcendent.
author_bios: Abraham Verghese is a graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop and author of NBCC Award finalist My Own Country and New York Times Notable Book The Tennis Partner. His novel Cutting for Stone spent 107 weeks on the New York Times bestseller list, sold over two million copies worldwide, and was translated into more than twenty languages. Verghese received the National Humanities Medal from President Obama and is an elected member of the National Academy of Medicine and American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He is the Linda R. Meier and Joan F. Lane Provostial Professor at Stanford University School of Medicine.
quotes:
"One of the best books I've read in my entire life. It's epic. It's transportive . . . It was unputdownable!"

—Oprah Winfrey

"From the very first page of Abraham Verghese's The Covenant of Water, I was overtaken with joy. Truly, I caught my breath, absorbing such beauty. What a sure faith this novel is—what an agreement with language. What a glorious story of land and family. What a brilliant path written across generations."

—Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, author of The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois

"A novel of utter beauty, The Covenant of Water is worthy of all praise in its depiction of medical ingenuity and family love; it is epic and eye-opening, the sort of story that only a singular mind like Abraham Verghese's could have woven."

—Imbolo Mbue, author of How Beautiful We Were

title: The Swerve
subtitle: How the World Became Modern
long_summary:
Nearly six hundred years ago, a sharp-eyed book hunter pulled an ancient manuscript from a monastery shelf and changed the world. That book was the last surviving copy of Lucretius's *On the Nature of Things*—a Roman philosophical epic filled with revolutionary ideas that the universe operated without gods, that religious fear damaged human life, and that all matter consisted of tiny particles in constant motion.

Stephen Greenblatt traces how this single act of literary rescue fueled the Renaissance and shaped modernity itself. The rediscovered poem inspired Botticelli's art and Bruno's philosophy, influenced the thinking of Galileo and Darwin, and left its mark on writers from Montaigne to Shakespeare to Thomas Jefferson.

This is both a thrilling story of discovery and an innovative work of intellectual history, showing how one manuscript—plucked from a thousand years of neglect—made possible the world as we know it. Greenblatt reveals the concentrated force of ideas to transform civilizations and the fragile threads by which knowledge survives.
short_summary: How one forgotten Roman poem about atoms and godless universes sparked the Renaissance. Greenblatt traces the thrilling rediscovery of Lucretius and shows how dangerous ancient ideas reshaped the modern world.
author_bios: Stephen Greenblatt is Cogan University Professor of the Humanities at Harvard University. He's written fourteen books, including The Swerve, winner of the Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award, and Will in the World, a Pulitzer Prize finalist. He serves as general editor of The Norton Anthology of English Literature and The Norton Shakespeare.
quotes:
"The ideas in The Swerve are tucked, cannily, inside a quest narrative. . . . The details that Mr. Greenblatt supplies throughout The Swerve are tangy and exact. . . . There is abundant evidence here of what is Mr. Greenblatt's great and rare gift as a writer: an ability, to borrow a phrase from The Swerve, to feel fully 'the concentrated force of the buried past."

—The New York Times

"In this gloriously learned page-turner, both biography and intellectual history, Harvard Shakespearean scholar Greenblatt turns his attention to the front end of the Renaissance as the origin of Western culture's foundation: the free questioning of truth."

—Publishers Weekly

"More wonderfully illuminating Renaissance history from a master scholar and historian."

—Kirkus

title: After Visiting Friends
subtitle: A Son's Story
long_summary:
Michael Hainey was six when his uncle delivered devastating news: his father Bob, a 35-year-old assistant copy desk chief at the Chicago Sun-Times, had been found dead near his car on Chicago's North Side. Heart attack, they said. Bob was a rising star in the hard-living world of newspapers, where booze-soaked nights bled into dawn—until suddenly he was gone, leaving behind a young widow, two sons, and a fractured family.

For decades, questions about that mysterious night obsessed Michael. The obituaries were vague: died "after visiting friends." But which friends? Where? The details never added up. Finally, at roughly the same age his father was when he died, Michael—now a seasoned reporter himself—set out to uncover the truth.

At the heart of his investigation stands his mother: courageous, tenacious, and determined never to look back. Working through his father's old newspaper buddies, bound by their own code of silence, Michael pushes past family myths to reconcile the father he'd imagined with the man he discovers.

A stirring portrait of family secrets and fierce loyalties, After Visiting Friends captures a vanished world of midnight deadlines and masculine codes while exploring the universal mystery of who our parents really were.
short_summary: When his newspaper reporter father died mysteriously in 1970s Chicago, six-year-old Michael Hainey was left with questions that haunted him for decades. A moving investigation into family secrets and the vanished world of hard-drinking journalists.
author_bios: Michael Hainey is the deputy editor of GQ. He was born in Chicago and now lives in Manhattan.
quotes:
"After Visiting Friends is full of love for the lost world of nocturnal newspaper work and after-hours boozing."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"Part what next? detective story, part moving family portrait, and part wistful ode to the whiskey-sloshed mid-century Chicago newspaper world…"

—Rob Brunner, Entertainment Weekly

"A book whose heartbreak and humor, in the true Irish tradition, can't be untangled. It's a kind of detective story, but the mystery is the past itself."

—John Jeremiah Sullivan, author of Pulphead

title: The Emperor of Gladness
long_summary:
One late summer evening in post-industrial East Gladness, Connecticut, nineteen-year-old Hai stands on a bridge in pelting rain, ready to jump. A voice across the river stops him—Grazina, an elderly widow succumbing to dementia, who convinces him to choose another path. Bereft and out of options, Hai becomes her caretaker.

Over the course of a year, this unlikely pair develops a life-altering bond built on empathy, spiritual reckoning, and heartbreak. Their relationship transforms Hai's connection to himself, his family, and a community on the brink.

Following the cycles of history, memory, and time, The Emperor of Gladness reveals how love, labor, and loneliness form the bedrock of American life. At its heart is a brave epic about existing on society's fringes and reckoning with wounds that haunt our collective soul. Vuong's signature formal innovation and syntactic dexterity are on full display in this story of loss, hope, and how far we'll go for life's most fleeting mercy: a second chance.
short_summary: When a suicidal teenager becomes caretaker to an elderly woman with dementia, their unlikely bond transforms both their lives. Vuong crafts a tender epic about chosen family and second chances.
author_bios: Ocean Vuong is the author of the critically acclaimed poetry collections Night Sky with Exit Wounds and Time Is a Mother, as well as the New York Times bestselling novel On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous. A MacArthur Fellowship and American Book Award recipient, he was born in Saigon, Vietnam, and splits his time between western Massachusetts and New York City.
quotes:
"Stunning . . . A heartfelt and powerful examination of those living on the fringes of society, and the unique challenges they face to survive and thrive."

—Oprah Winfrey

"[A]mbitious . . . The references to Slaughterhouse-Five and The Brothers Karamazov underscore Vuong's interest in exploring war and morality, but this is remarkable as a novel that tries to look at those themes outside of conventional realism or combat porn . . . A sui generis take on the surprising and cruel ways violence is passed on across generations."

—Kirkus

"Tender and moving, The Emperor of Gladness is about people on the margins of society and sanity. To my surprise and delight, Vuong's novel is also wryly, subtly, wittily—and sometimes outrageously—a comedy as well as a tragedy."

—Rebecca Solnit, author of A Field Guide to Getting Lost and Recollections of My Nonexistence

title: Johnny Cash
subtitle: The Life
long_summary:
As music critic for the Los Angeles Times, Hilburn had unprecedented access to Cash throughout his life—he was the only music journalist at the legendary Folsom Prison concert in 1968, and he interviewed both Cash and June Carter just months before their deaths.

Drawing upon never-before-seen material from the singer's inner circle, Hilburn creates a deeply human portrait of a towering figure who shaped country music, influenced rock, and became an icon of American culture. His reporting reveals the astonishing highs and devastating lows of a man marked by great faith and humbling addiction, who consistently used his music to lift people's spirits despite his own struggles.
short_summary: The definitive biography of an American icon whose extraordinary career stretched from Sun Records alongside Elvis to his haunting final act with the "Hurt" video at age 69.
author_bios: Robert Hilburn was chief pop music critic and editor of the Los Angeles Times from 1970 through 2005. Since then, he has focused on writing biographies of celebrated musicians including John Lennon, Johnny Cash, and Paul Simon. He lives in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"The Man in Black's many fans will find this huge, sympathetic yet critical study of his serial rises, falls, betrayals and redemptions definitive."

—The Globe and Mail

"Between his love of music, his experience as one of the nation's leading music critics, and his long personal friendship with the subject, there is no one on earth more qualified to write this definitive book on the roller-coaster life of Johnny Cash than Robert Hilburn. Between the amount of research and the degree of detail he's put into this book, even Johnny would have learned something about himself if he were here to read it. Highly recommended!"

—Rick Rubin, author of The Creative Act

"Robert Hilburn displays a deeply felt affinity with his subject, illuminating Johnny Cash as the moral compass of country music."

—Patti Smith, author of Just Kids

title: And the Mountains Echoed
long_summary:
From Khaled Hosseini, the #1 New York Times–bestselling author of The Kite Runner and A Thousand Splendid Suns, comes a sweeping novel about love, sacrifice, and the invisible threads connecting families across generations.

Moving between Kabul, Paris, San Francisco, and the Greek island of Tinos, Hosseini follows parents and children, brothers and sisters, cousins and caretakers as their lives intersect in unexpected ways. He explores how families nurture and wound in equal measure, how they betray and honor, and how a single choice can ripple through decades.

Expansive in scope yet intimate in detail, this powerful story grows richer and more emotionally resonant with every page, revealing the complex ways our past shapes our present.
short_summary: Hosseini's multivoiced epic traces how a childhood choice reverberates across decades and continents through intertwined lives. A compassionate, page-turning story about family bonds that refuse to break.
author_bios: Khaled Hosseini was born in Kabul, Afghanistan, and moved to the United States in 1980. He is the author of the #1 New York Times bestsellers The Kite Runner, A Thousand Splendid Suns, and And the Mountains Echoed, as well as the illustrated book Sea Prayer. He serves as a U.S. Goodwill Envoy to the United Nations Refugee Agency and founded The Khaled Hosseini Foundation, which provides humanitarian assistance to the people of Afghanistan.
quotes:
"[Hosseini's] most assured and emotionally gripping story yet . . . Hosseini's narrative gifts have deepened over the years. . . . [And the Mountains Echoed] grapples with many of the same themes that crisscross his early novels: the relationship between parents and children, and the ways the past can haunt the present. And it shares a similar penchant for mapping terrain midway between the boldly colored world of fable and the more shadowy, shaded world of realism… [W]e finish this novel with an intimate understanding of who his characters are and how they've defined themselves over the years through the choices they have made between duty and freedom, familial responsibilities and independence, loyalty to home and exile abroad… a deeply affecting choral work… a testament both to his intimate knowledge of their inner lives, and to his power as an old-fashioned storyteller."

—Michiko Kakutani, The New York Times

"The beautiful writing, full of universal truths of loss and identity, makes each section a jewel . . . Hosseini's eye for detail and emotional geography makes this a haunting read."

—Publishers Weekly

"I'm not an easy touch when it comes to novels, but Hosseini's new book, And the Mountains Echoed, had tears dropping from my eyes by Page 45. . . . It's hard to do justice to a novel this rich in a short review. There are a dozen things I still want to say — about the rhyming pairs of characters, the echoing situations, the varied takes on honesty, loneliness, beauty and poverty, the transformation of emotions into physical ailments. Instead, I'll just add this: Send Hosseini up the bestseller list again."

—The Washington Post

title: The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace
subtitle: A Brilliant Young Man Who Left Newark for the Ivy League
long_summary:
When Jeff Hobbs arrived at Yale, he became roommates with Robert Peace, a brilliant student from Newark's crime-ridden streets. Robert's father was in jail, his mother earned less than $15,000 a year, but his intellect earned him a spot studying molecular biochemistry and biophysics at one of America's most elite universities.

Yet Yale didn't make life easier. Robert carried the weight of his dual existence—navigating the ivy-covered campus while remaining connected to home, where he dealt drugs to support his family.

Through Robert's relationships with his struggling mother, incarcerated father, teachers, friends, and fellow dealers, this biography explores America's most enduring conflicts: race, class, drugs, education, and family. It's about the collision between two insular worlds and the near-impossible challenge of moving between them.

This is a story about poverty, single motherhood, and finding role models in communities where men are more likely to go to prison than college. About reaching your potential while taking responsibility for family, no matter the cost. Most of all, it's about one singular young man whose violent end is heartbreaking and unforgettable.
short_summary: Jeff Hobbs chronicles his Yale roommate Robert Peace, a brilliant young man from Newark who navigated between two worlds—elite academia and the dangerous streets of home. A devastating portrait of talent, loyalty, and the weight of impossible choices.
author_bios: Jeff Hobbs is the New York Times bestselling author of The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace, which won the Los Angeles Times Book Prize, was a finalist for the Pen/Faulkner Award in Biography and Carnegie Medal in nonfiction, and became the 2024 film Rob Peace. He also wrote Show Them You're Good and Children of the State. He lives in Los Angeles with his family.
quotes:
"A haunting work of nonfiction.... Mr. Hobbs writes in a forthright but not florid way about a heartbreaking story."

—The New York Times

"I can hardly think of a book that feels more necessary, relevant, and urgent."

—Grantland

"The Short Tragic Life of Robert Peace is a book that is as much about class as it is race. Peace traveled across America's widening social divide, and Hobbs' book is an honest, insightful and empathetic account of his sometimes painful, always strange journey."

—The Los Angeles Times

title: Fleishman Is in Trouble
long_summary:
Toby Fleishman thought he knew what to expect from his separation: weekends with the kids, some residual bitterness, the occasional co-parenting tension. He never predicted that one summer day, Rachel would drop off their two children and simply vanish.

Just as Toby was finding his footing—juggling hospital patients, parental duties, and his newfound dating app success—his ex-wife disappears without explanation. His tidy narrative of being the spurned husband with an overly ambitious wife becomes his only consolation.

But if Toby wants to understand what really happened to Rachel and their marriage, he'll have to consider that maybe he didn't see things clearly in the first place. This searing debut is an insightful, unsettling, and often hilarious exploration of modern marriage, ambition, and the fault lines of an institution that inspires both wariness and hope.
short_summary: When Toby's ex-wife vanishes after dropping off their kids, his carefully constructed post-divorce life crumbles. A razor-sharp dissection of modern marriage that's both devastatingly funny and unexpectedly profound.
author_bios: Taffy Brodesser-Akner is a staff writer at The New York Times Magazine and author of two novels: Fleishman Is in Trouble, which she adapted into an Emmy-nominated FX limited series, and Long Island Compromise. She lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Whip-smart, gleefully scatological . . . [Brodesser-Akner] aims a perfect gimlet eye at the city's relentless self-regard. . . . But her best trick may be the novel's narrator: An elusive presence identified at first only as an old friend of Toby's from their study-abroad days, she turns out to be both the book's Trojan horse and—in a brilliant third-act pivot—its greatest gift, transforming a fizzy comedy of manners into something genuinely, unexpectedly profound."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Many novelists have written excellent fictional indictments of interpersonal and systemic sexism. Not since Teju Cole's Open City—a very different book in all other respects—has a novelist put the reader on the wrong side the way Brodesser-Akner does. To do so, she uses a lot of intelligence, a lot of anger, a great sense of humor and a whole new variation on the magic we know from her magazine work. The result is a maddening, unsettling masterpiece, and, yes, you will be moved and inexplicably grateful at the end."

—NPR

"In her witty and well-observed debut, Taffy Brodesser-Akner updates the miserable-matrimony novel, dropping it squarely in our times. . . . Brodesser-Akner has written a potent, upsetting and satisfying novel, illustrating how the marital pledge—build our life together—overlooks a key fact: There are two lives."

—The New York Times

title: Charlie Chan
subtitle: The Untold Story of the Honorable Detective and His Rendezvous with American History
long_summary:
On a July night in 1904, Hawaiian cop Chang Apana single-handedly arrested forty gamblers in Honolulu's Chinatown—an episode that inspired the creation of Charlie Chan, one of Hollywood's most iconic and controversial detectives.

In this groundbreaking work, Yunte Huang uncovers the real story behind Apana and traces the character's evolution from local legend to pop culture symbol. Drawing on decades of research in both English and Chinese sources, from Hawaiian cemeteries to Harvard archives, Huang reveals how this figure both reflected and distorted America's perceptions of Asians and Asian Americans.

Weaving together Apana's rough-and-tumble career, the complex history of territorial Hawaii, and the rise of Hollywood's Charlie Chan films, the result is a masterful narrative that blends biography, cultural history, and personal memoir—permanently reshaping how we understand this troubled yet gripping American story.
short_summary: The fascinating true story behind Charlie Chan and the Hawaiian cop who inspired him. Huang excavates decades of research to reveal how this controversial detective both reflected and distorted American perceptions of Asian identity.
author_bios: Yunte Huang, a Guggenheim Fellow, is Distinguished Professor of English at UC Santa Barbara and has taught at Harvard. Author of the Edgar Award–winning Charlie Chan and Inseparable, both NBCC finalists, he speaks frequently about American popular culture.
quotes:
"In this original, deeply personal account, Huang illuminates every conceivable aspect of Chan and his place in American culture.... vibrant narrative.... Multilayered, provocative and highly accessible."

—Kirkus

"A virtuoso of curiosity.... Huang digs up fascinating research on everything from the demographics of capital punishment in Honolulu to the origins of The Manchurian Candidate.... a work of exhaustively researched popular history that reads like a dime-store romance."

—Pico Iyer, Time

"Charlie Chan remains, in himself, a sly and delightful figure, worthy of nostalgia—and of Huang's very original, good-humored and passionately researched book."

—Richard Schickel, The New York Times

title: Beyond the Door of No Return
long_summary:
Paris, 1806. The renowned botanist Michel Adanson lies on his deathbed, his life's masterwork still incomplete. As he expires, the last word to escape his lips is a woman's name: Maram.

The key to this mysterious woman's identity lies in Adanson's unpublished memoir, concealed in a secret compartment. Within its pages unfolds a story as fantastical as it is tragic: Maram is the fabled revenant, a young woman of noble birth from the kingdom of Waalo who was sold into slavery but escaped from the Island of Gorée—a major embarkation point of the transatlantic slave trade—to a hidden village in the forest.

While on a research expedition in West Africa as a young man, Adanson heard the story of the revenant and became obsessed with finding her. Accompanied by his guide, he ventured deep into the Senegalese bush on a journey that revealed not only the savagery of French colonial occupation but also the unlikely transports of the human heart.

Drawing on the richness and lyricism of Senegal's oral traditions, Diop has constructed a love story like few others—a historical epic of the highest order.
short_summary: When a French botanist dies uttering a mysterious woman's name, his hidden memoir reveals an obsessive search through 18th-century Senegal for an escaped slave known as the revenant. Historical fiction that pulses with the power of oral tradition.
author_bios: David Diop is the author of At Night All Blood Is Black, which was awarded the International Booker Prize and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for Fiction. Born in Paris and raised in Senegal, he is a professor of literature at the University of Pau, where his research encompasses eighteenth-century French literature and European representations of Africa.
quotes:
"[A] mesmerizingly layered work of historical fiction . . . Diop, with remarkable tonal and narrative deftness, evokes and complicates [his character's] cathartic hopes in a way that feels unexpectedly timeless."

—The Atlantic

"A mesmerizing tale . . . Less brutal than Diop's International Booker Prize–winning At Night All Blood is Black (2020) but no less powerful . . . With its sumptuous physical descriptions, shades of language, and smooth overlap of truth and invention, this is masterful storytelling. The ease with which the narratives (including Aglaé's) unfold belies the emotional force they gather."

—Kirkus

"A captivating intergenerational epic influenced by Senegalese oral tradition . . . Told as a series of fast-paced stories within stories, the novel contemplates race, hierarchy, religion, legends . . . Diop writes excellently of historical and regional minutiae, as in his descriptions of the sheer heat and exhaustion his characters face on their travels. This is a novel to devour quickly, but which will leave readers contemplating its story long after."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Negroland
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
At once incendiary and elegant, mischievous and deeply felt—this is a brilliant meditation on race, class, and identity through the lens of America's Black elite.

Born into upper-crust Black Chicago, Margo Jefferson grew up in what she calls "Negroland"—a small, privileged enclave where residents were "sheltered by a certain amount of privilege and plenty." Her father headed pediatrics at the nation's oldest Black hospital; her mother moved in socialite circles. Since the nineteenth century, this colored aristocracy has stood apart, measuring itself against both white society and the broader Black community while maintaining careful distance from both.

Jefferson reckons with the psychological contradictions of this rarefied world at pivotal moments—the civil rights era, the dawn of feminism, the illusion of post-racial America. She charts how these cultural pressures shaped a life caught between worlds, exploring the strictures and demands of her upbringing with unflinching honesty. Despite confronting despair and depression, this memoir ultimately becomes a triumphant testament to perseverance and grace.
short_summary: Jefferson excavates her privileged upbringing in Chicago's Black elite, examining the psychological costs of living between worlds. A fearless reckoning with race, class, and identity.
author_bios: Margo Jefferson is a Pulitzer Prize-winning cultural critic and former theater critic for The New York Times. She has written for publications including Vogue, New York Magazine, and The Nation, and has taught at Columbia University and Eugene Lang College. Jefferson is the author of On Michael Jackson and Negroland, which won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Autobiography.
quotes:
"Ever provocative and insightful, the cultural critic Margo Jefferson bravely directs the focus inward to her own life and times as a child of the rigid and nearly invisible world of black elites in pre-Civil Rights, mid-century America. By turns, melancholic and hopeful, raw and disarming, she weighs the psychic toll of constructed divisions at the intersection of race, gender, caste and privilege. A moving memoir that is an act of courage in its vulnerability."

—Isabel Wilkerson, author of Caste & The Warmth of Other Suns

"Treads briskly and fearlessly across the treacherous terrain of race, class, gender and entitlement in this tightly edited memoir that recalls her youth in 1950s and 60s Chicago. . . . [Jefferson] is a poetic and bracing memoirist. . . . Lean, specific and personal . . . enlightening."

—Robin Givhan, The Washington Post

"At the heart of Margo Jefferson's masterpiece—a phenomenal study-cum-memoir about the black bourgeoisie—is a sensibility that belongs to no group or community other than the author's sorority of one. Jefferson has lived and worked like the great reporter she is, traversing a little-known or -understood landscape peopled by blacks and whites, dreamers and naysayers, the privileged and the strivers who make up the mosaic known as America."

—Hilton Als

title: Book Lovers
long_summary:
Nora Stephens knows exactly who she is: a cutthroat literary agent who lives for landing enormous deals and protecting her beloved little sister Libby. She's definitely not heroine material—not plucky, not a dream girl, and certainly not sweet.

So when Libby begs for a sisters' trip to Sunshine Falls, North Carolina, Nora reluctantly agrees to a month of small-town life, even though Libby has visions of some magical transformation ahead. But instead of meet-cutes with charming country doctors, Nora keeps running into Charlie Lastra, a brooding book editor from back home in the city.

It would be romantic if they hadn't already met many times before—and if those meetings had ever gone well. Charlie knows he's nobody's hero, and Nora knows she's nobody's ideal heroine. But as a series of coincidences no self-respecting editor would allow keeps throwing them together, they begin to discover that the carefully crafted stories they've written about themselves might need some serious revisions.
short_summary: When a ruthless literary agent escapes to small-town North Carolina, she keeps colliding with a grumpy editor from her past. Sharp, self-aware romance that gleefully subverts every meet-cute expectation.
author_bios: Emily Henry is the #1 New York Times bestselling author of Great Big Beautiful Life, Funny Story, Happy Place, Book Lovers, People We Meet on Vacation, and Beach Read. She studied creative writing at Hope College and now spends most of her time in Cincinnati, Ohio, and the part of Kentucky just beneath it.
quotes:
"Book Lovers is a rom-com lover's dream of a book. . . . Readers know that Emily Henry never fails to deliver great banter and a romance to swoon over but this may just be her best yet."

—Taylor Jenkins Reid, New York Times bestselling author of Malibu Rising

"Emily Henry's books are a gift, the perfect balance between steamy and sweet. The prose is effortless, the characters charming. The only downside is reaching the end."

—V.E. Schwab, New York Times bestselling author The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue

"Charming, earnest, and clever, Book Lovers is Schitt's Creek for book nerds. A total delight . . . Nobody does it quite like Emily Henry."

—Casey McQuiston, New York Times bestselling author of One Last Stop

title: How We Fight for Our Lives
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In this haunting coming-of-age memoir, Jones chronicles his journey as a young Black gay man from the South fighting to carve out space for himself—within his family, his country, and his own hopes and fears.

Through vivid vignettes that traverse the American landscape, Jones draws readers into his boyhood and adolescence, navigating tumultuous family relationships and fleeting connections with lovers, friends, and strangers. Each piece builds toward a larger examination of race and queerness, power and vulnerability, love and grief—revealing what we do for one another, and to one another, as we fight to become ourselves.

An award-winning poet, Jones brings a voice that shifts like a river, resonates like blues, and blazes like fire across a night sky. The result is a memoir that cements Jones as an essential voice for our time.
short_summary: Jones chronicles his journey as a young Black gay man in the South, weaving poetry and raw honesty into a memoir about family, desire, and the fierce work of becoming yourself.
author_bios: Saeed Jones is the author of Prelude to Bruise, winner of the 2015 PEN/Joyce Osterweil Award for Poetry and the 2015 Stonewall Book Award/Barbara Gittings Literature Award. The collection was also a finalist for the 2015 National Book Critics Circle Award and Lambda Literary and Publishing Triangle awards. Born in Memphis and raised in Lewisville, Texas, Jones earned a BA at Western Kentucky University and an MFA at Rutgers University-Newark. He lives in Columbus, Ohio.
quotes:
"[A] devastating memoir….Jones is fascinated by power (who has it, how and why we deploy it), but he seems equally interested in tenderness and frailty. We wound and save one another, we try our best, we leave too much unsaid….A moving, bracingly honest memoir that reads like fevered poetry."

—The New York Times

"A raw and eloquent memoir. One could say that Saeed Jones' new memoir, How We Fight for Our Lives, is a classic coming-of-age story….But Jones' voice and sensibility are so distinct that he turns one of the oldest of literary genres inside out and upside down. How We Fight for Our Lives is at once explicitly raunchy, mean, nuanced, loving and melancholy. It's sometimes hard to read and harder to put down."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"There will be little left to say, and so much left to make after the world experiences Saeed Jones's How We Fight for Our Lives. This is that rare piece of literary art that teaches us how to read and write on every page. It's so black. So queer. So subtextual, and amazingly so sincere. Saeed changes everything we thought we knew about memoir writing, narrative structure, and heart meat. All three are obliterated. All three are tended to over and over again. All three will never ever be the same after this book. It's really that good."

—Kiese Laymon, author of Heavy

title: All the Lovers in the Night
long_summary:
Fuyuko Irie is a freelance copy editor in her mid-thirties, working and living alone in Tokyo with little contact beyond her editor, Hijiri—a woman of the same age but completely different disposition. When Fuyuko catches her reflection in a storefront window one day, she sees a drab, awkward, spiritless woman who has lacked the strength to change her life.

She decides to do something about it.

As long-overdue changes begin to occur, painful episodes from Fuyuko's past surface and her behavior slips further beyond the pale. Kawakami crafts an acute and insightful portrait of a woman's transformation—one that will make readers laugh and cry, but also remind them that sometimes the pain is worth it.
short_summary: A lonely Tokyo copy editor catches her reflection and decides to change her spiritless life. Kawakami's masterful portrait of transformation reveals how painful self-discovery can be worth the struggle.
author_bios: Mieko Kawakami was born in Osaka in 1976. She began as a singer, releasing three albums before transitioning to writing. She won the Akutagawa Prize in 2008, followed by the MEXT Award for New Artists and Murasaki Shikibu Literary Prize for her novel Heaven. She is the author of Breasts and Eggs.
quotes:
"The attention to sensory experience is particularly keen, concise, and meaningful...The startling vividness of Kawakami's images draws the reader deeper into the emotional intensity of the scenes....[she] has good instincts for creating an air of suspense, although that's not what sets her novels apart. It's her ability to make the mere passing of time, choosing to step outside and be alive, seem like an event."

—Idra Novey, The Atlantic

"The author dazzles with her exploration of emotions... An invigorating and empowering portrait. It's a winner."

—Publishers Weekly

"Kawakami has created a rich and notable examination of the varied ways women choose to live their lives and the gains and losses that come with the choices they've made. Kawakami writes with the tender and incisive sensibilities of a poet.... An unforgettable and masterful work."

—Kirkus

title: The Sport of Kings
long_summary:
Hellsmouth, an indomitable Thoroughbred with Triple Crown bloodlines, runs for the glory of the Forge family—one of Kentucky's oldest and most powerful dynasties. Henry Forge has partnered with his daughter Henrietta in an endeavor of raw obsession: to breed the next superhorse, the next Secretariat.

But when Allmon Shaughnessy, an ambitious young black man, comes to work on their farm, the violence of the Forges' history and the brutal realities of appetite are brought starkly into view. Entangled in fear, prejudice, and lust, the three tether their personal dreams of glory to the speed and grace of Hellsmouth.

This spiraling tale of wealth and poverty, racism and rage, unfolds as an unflinching portrait of lives cast in shadow by slavery's enduring legacy. Morgan has crafted a story as mythic and fraught as the South itself—a moral epic for our time.
short_summary: Spanning generations of a Kentucky dynasty obsessed with breeding champion racehorses, this sweeping novel confronts race, inheritance, and the brutal costs of American ambition.
author_bios: C. E. Morgan lives with her husband, Will Guild, in Berea, Kentucky. She is the author of The Sport of Kings and All the Living.
quotes:
"Novelists can do things that other writers can't—and Morgan can do things that other novelists can't...Tremendous."

—Kathryn Schulz, The New Yorker

"Ravishing and ambitious…It's a mud-flecked epic, replete with fertile symbolism, that hurtles through generations of Kentucky history."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"[A] sprawling, magisterial Southern Gothic for the 21st century."

—O: The Oprah Magazine

title: Under a White Sky
subtitle: The Nature of the Future
long_summary:
"That man should have dominion over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth" is a prophecy that has hardened into fact. So pervasive are human impacts on the planet that it's said we live in a new geological epoch: the Anthropocene.

In Under a White Sky, Elizabeth Kolbert takes a hard look at the new world we are creating. She meets biologists preserving the world's rarest fish in a single tiny pool in the Mojave, engineers turning carbon emissions to stone in Iceland, Australian researchers developing "super coral" that can survive on a hotter globe, and physicists contemplating shooting tiny diamonds into the stratosphere to cool the earth.

One way to look at human civilization, Kolbert argues, is as a ten-thousand-year exercise in defying nature. In The Sixth Extinction, she explored how our capacity for destruction has reshaped the natural world. Now she examines how the very interventions that imperiled our planet are increasingly seen as the only hope for its salvation. By turns inspiring, terrifying, and darkly comic, Under a White Sky is an utterly original examination of the challenges we face.
short_summary: After documenting humanity's destructive impact on nature, Kolbert now explores a paradox: the same interventions that damaged our planet may be our only hope for saving it. Riveting science writing that's both alarming and oddly hopeful.
author_bios: Elizabeth Kolbert is the bestselling author of Field Notes from a Catastrophe, The Sixth Extinction, for which she won the Pulitzer Prize, and Under a White Sky, which was named a top ten book of the year by The Washington Post. For her work at The New Yorker, where she's a staff writer, she has received two National Magazine Awards and the Blake-Dodd Prize from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She lives in Williamstown, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"What makes Under A White Sky so valuable and such a compelling read is Kolbert tells by showing. Without beating the reader over the head, she makes it clear how far we already are from a world of undisturbed, perfectly balanced nature—and how far we must still go to find a new balance for the planet's future that still has us humans in it."

—NPR

"Every paragraph of Kolbert's books has a mountain of reading and reporting behind it . . . Urgent, absolutely necessary reading as a portrait of our devastated planet."

—Kirkus

"Riveting . . . Under a White Sky expertly mixes travelogue, science reporting and explanatory journalism."

—The Washington Post

title: Bleeding Edge
long_summary:
It's 2001 in New York City, in that strange lull between the dot-com crash and September 11th. Maxine Tarnow runs a small fraud investigation business on the Upper West Side, and life is ticking along nicely until she starts digging into the finances of a computer-security firm and its billionaire geek CEO.

Soon she's tangled up with a drug runner in an art deco motorboat, a professional nose obsessed with Hitler's aftershave, a neoliberal enforcer with serious footwear issues, and an eclectic cast of bloggers, hackers, code monkeys, and entrepreneurs—some of whom start turning up mysteriously dead.

Will the perpetrators be revealed, let alone brought to justice? Will Maxine have to pull that handgun from her purse? Will Jerry Seinfeld make an unscheduled cameo? Will accounts both secular and karmic finally balance out? In Pynchon's hands, these questions become a wild ride through the early internet age.
short_summary: Fraud investigator Maxine Tarnow gets mixed up with tech billionaires, drug runners, and mysterious deaths in pre-9/11 New York. Pynchon's gonzo take on the early internet era is both hilarious and haunting.
author_bios: Thomas Pynchon is the author of V.; The Crying of Lot 49; Gravity's Rainbow; Slow Learner, a collection of short stories; Vineland; Mason & Dixon; Against the Day; Inherent Vice; and Bleeding Edge. He received the National Book Award for Gravity's Rainbow in 1974.
quotes:
"Brilliantly written… a joy to read…Full of verbal sass and pizzazz, as well as conspiracies within conspiracies, Bleeding Edge is totally gonzo, totally wonderful. It really is good to have Thomas Pynchon around, doing what he does best."

—Michael Dirda, The Washington Post

"No one, but no one, rivals Pynchon's range of language, his elasticity of syntax, his signature mix of dirty jokes, dread and shining decency… Bleeding Edge is a chamber symphony in P major, so generous of invention it sometimes sprawls, yet so sharp it ultimately pierces."

—Publishers Weekly

"A much-anticipated return, and it's trademark stuff: a blend of existential angst, goofy humor and broad-sweeping bad vibes."

—Kirkus

title: Soul Mining
subtitle: A Musical Life
long_summary:
Bob Dylan, Willie Nelson, Emmylou Harris, U2, Peter Gabriel, and the Neville Brothers all have something in common: some of their best albums were produced by Daniel Lanois. A French-speaking kid from Canada, Lanois was driven by his innate curiosity and intense love of music to transcend his small-town origins and become one of the world's most prolific and successful record producers, as well as a brilliant musician in his own right.

Lanois takes us through his childhood—from being one of four kids raised by a single mother on a hairdresser's salary, to his discovery by Brian Eno, to his work on albums such as U2's The Joshua Tree, Bob Dylan's Time Out of Mind, and Emmylou Harris's Wrecking Ball. Revealing for the first time his unique recording secrets and innovations, Lanois delves into the ongoing evolution of technology, from his earliest sonic experiments with reel-to-reel decks to the arrival of the download era.

Part technological treatise, part philosophical manifesto on the nature of artistic excellence, Soul Mining brings readers viscerally inside the recording studio. Beyond skill, beyond record budgets, beyond image and ego, Lanois's work shows the value of dedication and soul in his lifelong quest to find the perfect mixture of tradition and innovation.
short_summary: The legendary producer behind U2's The Joshua Tree and Bob Dylan's Time Out of Mind shares his unconventional journey from small-town Canada to music's upper echelon.
author_bios: Daniel Lanois is one of the most respected producers in the music industry, having won eight Grammy Awards for his work with artists like U2, Bob Dylan, and Emmylou Harris. He is also an acclaimed musician in his own right and currently performs with the band Black Dub.
quotes:
"This book is bursting with memorable anecdotes about [Lanois's] collaborators, another of the debut author's many gifts to fans of rock and country music."

—Kevin Canfield, San Francisco Chronicle

"The master musician and producer offers a typically idiosyncratic take on his life and art . . . Readers will savor the unique character of the producer's unconventional technique, which often employs setting up a jerry-rigged studio with vintage gear in an exotic locale. . . Lanois' book bursts with atmosphere and feeling. He is that rare breed, a lyrical technocrat, and he emerges from the work as one of music's most unusual and charismatic figures. There's really nothing like this oft-rapturous work in the canon of musical memoirs."

—Kirkus

"In his humble, self-effacing memoir of growing up poor in Canada, Lanois, born in a small Quebec town, describes the difficulties he faced . . . He discusses specific albums, including U2's The Joshua Tree and the Unforgettable Fire, Dylan's Oh Mercy and Time Out of Mind, and Harris's Wrecking Ball. And that makes this a real treat for serious music fans."

—Booklist

title: Here After
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Amy Lin never expected to find a love like the one she shares with her husband, Kurtis, a gifted young architect who pulls her toward joy, adventure, and greater self-acceptance. On a sweltering August morning, only a few months shy of the newlyweds' move to Vancouver, thirty-two-year-old Kurtis heads out to run a half-marathon with Amy's family.

It is the last time she sees her husband alive.

What follows is a rich and unflinchingly honest account of her life with Kurtis and the vortex created by his death. Here After is an intimate story of deep love followed by dizzying loss—a memoir so finely etched that its power will remain with you long after the final page.
short_summary: An unflinching memoir about profound love cut short by sudden tragedy. Lin writes with devastating clarity about grief's wilderness and love's enduring force.
author_bios: Amy Lin is a writer and educator who lives in Calgary, Canada. Her work has been published in Ploughshares and she has been awarded residencies from Yaddo and Casa Comala. Here After is her first book.
quotes:
"It has been years since I have been so rocked, so moved, by any book, as I have been by Here After by the earthquaking new talent Amy Lin. Lin invites us into this place of exquisite pain and beauty; what a great gift she has given us."

—Lauren Groff, author of Fates and Furies

"How gorgeously Here After tackles the twin specters of grief and survival; a steely, symphonic memoir of unexpected loss—and what (necessarily, unbearably) comes next."

—Carmen Machado, author of In the Dream House

"Here After is a searing account of a young couple's lost future and a writer's descent into the soul-ravaging, shape-shifting wilderness of grief. Amy Lin writes with devastating clarity about the wounds that do not heal, the stories that remain forever fractured, and love's enduring force. This is a profound and essential memoir."

—Laura van den Berg, author of The Third Hotel

title: Normal People
long_summary:
Connell and Marianne grow up in the same small Irish town but inhabit completely different worlds. At school, Connell is popular and well-liked, while Marianne exists on the margins as a loner. When they strike up their first conversation—awkward but electrifying—something life-changing begins.

A year later, both are studying at Trinity College in Dublin, but their social positions have reversed. Marianne has found her place in a new world while Connell hangs at the sidelines, shy and uncertain. Throughout their university years, they circle one another in an intricate dance, straying toward other people and possibilities but always drawn magnetically back together.

As Marianne veers toward self-destruction and Connell searches for meaning elsewhere, each must confront how far they're willing to go to save the other. Normal People follows their mutual fascination from that first conversation through the years beyond, chronicling two people who try to stay apart but discover they can't.
short_summary: Connell and Marianne orbit each other from small-town Ireland to Trinity College Dublin, their connection surviving class differences and personal demons. Rooney's precision with intimacy and miscommunication makes this devastating.
author_bios: Sally Rooney is an Irish novelist and author of Conversations with Friends, Normal People, and Beautiful World, Where Are You. She contributed to the writing and production of the Hulu/BBC television adaptation of Normal People.
quotes:
"A future classic."

—The Guardian

"Rooney is a tough girl; her papercut-sharp sensibility is much more akin to writers like Rachel Kushner, Mary Gaitskill, and the pre–Manhattan Beach Jennifer Egan. . . . Normal People is a nuanced and flinty love story about two young people who 'get' each other, despite class differences and the interference of their own vigorous personal demons. But honestly, Sally Rooney could write a novel about bath mats and I'd still read it. She's that good and that singular a writer."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

"[Rooney] has written two fresh and accessible novels. . . . There is so much to say about Rooney's fiction—in my experience, when people who've read her meet they tend to peel off into corners to talk."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: Destiny and Power
subtitle: The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush
long_summary:
Drawing on President Bush's personal diaries, Barbara Bush's private writings, and extraordinary access to the forty-first president and his family, Meacham paints an intimate portrait of an intensely private man who led the nation through tumultuous times.
