From the Oval Office to Camp David, from the fall of the Berlin Wall to the first Gulf War to the end of Communism, Destiny and Power charts the thoughts, decisions, and emotions of a modern president who may have been the last of his kind. This is the human story of a man who was, like the nation he led, at once noble and flawed.

Meacham sheds new light on the rise of the right wing in the Republican Party, a shift that signaled the beginning of the end of the center in American politics. The result is an affecting portrait of a man driven by destiny and duty, who forever sought to put the country first.
short_summary: Meacham crafts an intimate portrait of George H.W. Bush using personal diaries and family access. A nuanced look at the last president of the old political center.
genres: Biography & Autobiography / Presidents & Heads Of State
author_bios: Jon Meacham is a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer and the Rogers Chair in the American Presidency at Vanderbilt University. He is the author of the New York Times bestsellers His Truth Is Marching On: John Lewis and the Power of Hope, The Hope of Glory: Reflections on the Last Words of Jesus, Destiny and Power: The American Odyssey of George Herbert Walker Bush, Thomas Jefferson: The Art of Power, American Lion: Andrew Jackson in the White House, American Gospel, and Franklin and Winston.
quotes:
"Meticulously researched . . . a revealing biography that should serve as the starting point for future evaluations of the forty-first president."

—Kirkus

"A vivid, well-written account."

—Publishers Weekly

"This astonishing book is both timely and timeless. Based on candid interviews and intimate letters and diaries, it provides a deep insight into the character of George H. W. Bush, flavored with colorful anecdotes depicting his relationships with people ranging from Gorbachev and Reagan to his sons George and Jeb. The result is a fascinating and insightful portrayal of the life of an exemplary American citizen."

—Walter Isaacson, author of Steve Jobs

title: Flashlight
long_summary:
One night, Louisa and her father take a walk on the beach. He's carrying a flashlight. He cannot swim. Later Louisa is found washed up by the tide, barely alive. Her father is gone. She is ten years old.

In chapters that shift from one family member to the next, turning back again and again to that night by the sea, Susan Choi's Flashlight chases the shockwaves of one family's catastrophe. Louisa is an only child of parents who have severed themselves from the past. Her father, Serk, an ethnic Korean born and raised in Japan, lost touch with his family when they relocated to North Korea after the war. Her American mother, Anne, is estranged from her family after a reckless adventure in her youth.

Then there is Tobias, Anne's illegitimate son, whose reappearance in their lives will have astonishing consequences. What really happened to Louisa's father? Why did he take his family to Japan just before he disappeared? And how can we love, or make sense of our lives, when there's so much we can't see?
short_summary: When a father vanishes during a beach walk with his ten-year-old daughter, the mystery ripples across generations and continents. Choi weaves a haunting meditation on family secrets and the weight of history.
author_bios: Susan Choi is the author of Trust Exercise, which received the National Book Award for Fiction, as well as the novels The Foreign Student, American Woman, A Person of Interest, and My Education. She is a recipient of the Asian American Literary Award for fiction, the PEN/W. G. Sebald Award, a Lambda Literary Award, the Sunday Times Audible Short Story Award, and fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation. She teaches in the Writing Seminars at Johns Hopkins University and lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"Instantly bewitching . . . Susan Choi's fictional investigation reveals a writer at the height of her spectacular powers."

—Jennifer Egan, author of The Candy House

"This gripping story of a family in crisis is tough to shake."

—Publishers Weekly

"Ferociously smart and full of surprises, Flashlight is thrilling to the last."

—Eleanor Catton, author of Birnam Wood

title: I Hate to Leave This Beautiful Place
long_summary:
The life of acclaimed novelist Howard Norman has had its share of "arresting strangeness"—moments that most of us would struggle to process, let alone transform into art. In this spellbinding memoir, Norman connects these experiences to show how life tangles with the psyche to become literature.

His story begins with a Midwest boyhood summer working in a bookmobile, shadowed by a grifter father and shaped by the erotic tutelage of his brother's girlfriend—a portrait both harrowing and hilarious. From there, his journey takes him to the Arctic, where he spends part of a decade translating Inuit tales, including the story of a soapstone carver transformed into a goose whose migration lament is "I hate to leave this beautiful place." It's there he hears over the radio that "John Lennon was murdered tonight in the city of New York."

Years later, in Washington D.C., another act of violence strikes closer to home when Norman and his wife loan their house to a poet and her young son, only to have it become the site of a murder-suicide. Yet Norman's story is also stitched together with moments of uncanny solace, particularly in his beloved Vermont farmhouse, where "everything I love most happens most every day."
short_summary: Novelist Howard Norman weaves together the haunting and redemptive moments of his life—a con-man father, Arctic translations, a murder-suicide in his home. Each incident stranger than fiction, transformed into luminous art.
author_bios: Howard Norman is the author of novels, memoirs, and books for children. Twice a finalist for the National Book Award in fiction, he received the Lannan Award in Literature. He is completing Rain Enters My Diary, a collection of letters sent from Japan to poet W. S. Merwin, an epistolary biography of a friendship. He lives in Vermont.
quotes:
"Norman's tale is conversational, elegant, and full of life…All Norman's stories – even the last, of a tragedy visited on him and his family, another intimation of death-are related with grace. He shows that the pleasures of the memoir often lie not in a life of dramatic incident but in the flights and transfigurations of a contemplative mind."

—Jane Smiley, Harper's Magazine

"Some books celebrate the human condition; others commiserate with us. This memoir does both, and offers fine, subtly fey companionship to boot."

—Helen Oyeyemi, NPR

"Five stellar personal essays by Norman that shed light on his melancholy, tragedy-struck fiction and larger human failures....A bracing, no-nonsense memoir, infused with fresh takes on love, death and human nature."

—Kirkus

title: Open City
long_summary:
Along the streets of Manhattan, a young Nigerian doctor doing his residency wanders aimlessly. The walks meet a need for Julius: they are a release from the tightly regulated mental environment of work, and they give him the opportunity to process his relationships, his recent breakup, his present, his past. Though he navigates the busy parts of town, the impression of countless faces does nothing to assuage his feelings of isolation.

But it's not only a physical landscape he covers—Julius crisscrosses social territory as well, encountering people from different cultures and classes who provide insight on his journey. His wanderings take him to Brussels, to the Nigeria of his youth, and into the most unrecognizable facets of his own soul.

A haunting novel about national identity, race, liberty, loss, dislocation, and surrender, Teju Cole's Open City seethes with intelligence. Written in a clear, rhythmic voice that lingers, this is a mature, profound work by an important author who has much to say about our country and our world.
short_summary: A young Nigerian doctor wanders Manhattan, processing art, history, and memory while confronting uncomfortable truths about himself and America. Meditative and devastating in equal measure.
author_bios: Teju Cole was born in the United States in 1975 to Nigerian parents and grew up in Lagos. His books include the novel Open City, essay collections Known and Strange Things and Black Paper, and experimental photo book Blind Spot. He has received the PEN/Hemingway Award, Internationaler Literaturpreis, Windham-Campbell Prize, and Guggenheim Fellowship. An elected member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, Cole is professor of creative writing at Harvard University and contributing writer to The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"A gorgeous, crystalline, and cumulative investigation of memory, identity, and erasure. It gathers its power inexorably, page by page, and ultimately reveals itself as nothing less than a searing tour de force. Teju Cole might just be a W. G. Sebald for the twenty-first century."

—Anthony Doerr, author of All the Light We Cannot See, Cloud Cuckoo Land & The Shell Collector

"Reminiscent of the works of W.G. Sebald, this dreamy, incantatory debut was the most beautiful novel I read this year—the kind of book that remains on your nightstand long after you finish so that you can continue dipping in occasionally as a nighttime consolation."

—Ruth Franklin, The New Republic

"A psychological hand grenade."

—Alexis Madrigal, The Atlantic

title: Manhattan Beach
long_summary:
Anna Kerrigan is nearly twelve when she accompanies her father to visit Dexter Styles, a man who seems crucial to her family's survival. She's mesmerized by the sea beyond his house and the charged mystery between the two men.

Years later, her father has vanished and the country is at war. Anna works at the Brooklyn Naval Yard, where women now hold jobs that once belonged to men fighting abroad. She becomes the first female diver—the most dangerous and exclusive occupation—repairing ships that will help America win the war.

One evening at a nightclub, Anna encounters Dexter Styles again and begins to understand the complexity of her father's life and the reasons he might have disappeared. With the atmosphere of a noir thriller, Egan follows Anna and Styles into a world of gangsters, sailors, divers, and union men—a deft exploration of a transformative moment in the lives of women and men, America and the world.
short_summary: During World War II, Anna Kerrigan becomes the Brooklyn Naval Yard's first female diver while searching for answers about her vanished father. A noir-tinged exploration of wartime transformation and family secrets.
author_bios: Jennifer Egan is the author of six books of fiction: Manhattan Beach, winner of the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Fiction; A Visit from the Goon Squad, which won the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award; The Keep; the story collection Emerald City; Look at Me, a National Book Award Finalist; and The Invisible Circus. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, and The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"A bounteous miracle that makes you feel that past time, and our time, differently; everything becomes freshly energized, infused with humanity, vital, sad, and full of importance. To see the world through Egan's eyes is to be moved, through language, to new adoration of the world. I don't know a better writer working today. There is a generosity in her prose that is vastly enlivening to its reader and brings about that beautiful effect fiction sometimes causes: more, and better-grounded, fondness for reality, just as it is."

—George Saunders

"Manhattan Beach is ambitiously and deliciously plot-driven."

—NPR

"Egan's first foray into historical fiction makes you forget you're reading historical fiction at all."

—Elle

title: The Unwinding
subtitle: An Inner History of the New America
long_summary:
In The Unwinding, George Packer traces America's past three decades through the lives of ordinary citizens and public figures, revealing a nation transformed by economic upheaval, political dysfunction, and cultural change.

From a factory worker in the Rust Belt to a Silicon Valley billionaire, Packer weaves intimate portraits with snapshots of leaders and icons, capturing the unraveling of institutions and the widening divide between winners and losers. The result is a powerful, kaleidoscopic history of an America on the brink—where the social contract has frayed and the American Dream feels increasingly out of reach for millions.
short_summary: Packer weaves together intimate portraits of ordinary Americans with snapshots of public figures to reveal how three decades of upheaval unraveled the social contract.
genres: Political Science / Political Ideologies / Conservatism & Liberalism
author_bios: George Packer is an award-winning author and staff writer at The Atlantic. His books include The Unwinding: An Inner History of the New America (winner of the National Book Award), The Assassins' Gate: America in Iraq, and Our Man: Richard Holbrooke and the End of the American Century (winner of the Hitchens Prize and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for biography). He has also written two novels and a play, and edited a two-volume edition of George Orwell's essays.
quotes:
"Original, incisive, courageous, and essential. One of the best works of nonfiction I've read in years."

—Katherine Boo, National Book Award–winning author of Behind the Beautiful Forevers

"George Packer serves us the history of our own life and times in a magisterial look at the America we lost."

—Lawrence Wright, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Thirteen Days in September, The Looming Tower & Going Clear

"As with George Orwell's, each of George Packer's sentences carries a pulse of moral force. The Unwinding is a sweeping and powerful book that everyone should read."

—David Grann, author of Killers of the Flower Moon & The Lost City of Z

title: The End of Your Life Book Club
long_summary:
In The End of Your Life Book Club, Will Schwalbe tells the inspiring true story of how he and his mother, Mary Anne, created an intimate "book club" as she faced a terminal cancer diagnosis.

Over two years of reading together, their conversations move from classics to mysteries to poetry, touching on questions of faith, courage, gratitude, and the meaning of life. Through books like Crossing to Safety and The Elegance of the Hedgehog, they explore everything from humanitarian work to family history, finding comfort and connection in shared stories.

More than a memoir of illness, this is a moving celebration of books, family, and the power of literature to illuminate even our darkest moments. Schwalbe captures how reading together became both refuge and revelation, proving that stories can sustain us through anything.
short_summary: Schwalbe chronicles the profound book club he formed with his mother during her final battle with cancer. A tender exploration of how literature becomes lifeline, offering solace and connection when it matters most.
author_bios: Will Schwalbe has worked in book publishing as an editor at Macmillan, in digital media, and as a journalist for The New York Times and South China Morning Post. He is the author of Books for Living, The End of Your Life Book Club, and coauthor of Send. He lives in New York.
quotes:
"With a refreshing forthrightness, and an excellent list of books included, this is an astonishing, pertinent, and wonderfully welcome work."

—Publishers Weekly

"Will Schwalbe gives us two love stories in one: that of his relationship with his dynamo of a mother as her horizons shrink, and that of their mutual devotion to the printed word, infinitely and insistently engaging. Tender and touching and beautifully done."

—Stacy Schiff, author of Cleopatra

"In a heartfelt tribute to his mother, Schwalbe illustrates the power of the written word to expand our knowledge of ourselves and others."

—Kirkus

title: The Mighty Red
long_summary:
In Argus, North Dakota, a collection of people revolve around a fraught wedding that will change everything.

Gary Geist, a terrified young man set to inherit two farms, desperately wants to marry Kismet Poe, an impulsive lapsed Goth who can't read her future but seems to resolve his. Hugo, a gentle red-haired homeschooled giant, is also in love with Kismet—and he's determined to steal her away. Meanwhile, Kismet's mother Crystal hauls sugar beets for Gary's family, tuning into late-night radio on her nightly runs, seeing visions of guardian angels, and worrying about the future.

Against the backdrop of the Red River Valley, human time collides with deep geological time, the half-life of pesticides, and the urgent speed of climate change. The economic meltdown of 2008 looms over everything, making every purchase—a dress, a used car, cinnamon rolls—feel fraught with meaning.

The Mighty Red is a novel of tender humor and hallucinatory mourning, about ordinary people who dream, fall in love, struggle, and endure. Erdrich creates a starkly beautiful prairie community whose members must cope with devastating consequences as powerful forces upend their lives, exploring our tattered bond with the earth and love in all its absurdity and splendor.
short_summary: Three people orbit a wedding in North Dakota farm country as economic collapse and environmental crisis reshape their world. Erdrich weaves humor and heartbreak into a luminous portrait of ordinary lives under extraordinary pressure.
author_bios: Louise Erdrich, a member of the Turtle Mountain Band of Chippewa, is the award-winning author of many novels as well as volumes of poetry, children's books, and a memoir of early motherhood. Erdrich lives in Minnesota with her daughters and is the owner of Birchbark Books, a small independent bookstore.
quotes:
"[Erdrich is] a master, a legend at building stories around community. . . . This is a book about family and community. It is a book about upward mobility and finding our true passions. You will love Kismet."

—Jenna Bush Hager, The Read with Jenna Book Club

"In The Mighty Red, humor and sorrow are fused together like twined tree trunks that keep each other standing.... Erdrich is so good at romantic comedy, with her special blend of Austen sense and Ojibwe sensibility. As the funny scenes flow one after another, you may not even notice the stray drops of blood scattered along the novel's margins. . . . As usual when closing a book by Louise Erdrich, I'm left wondering, how can a novel be so funny and so moving? How can life?"

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A captivating tale of love and everyday life amid environmental upheaval and the 2008 financial crisis. . . . Erdrich excels at the slow simmer, and once again she delivers a deliciously seductive masterwork."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Book of Lives
subtitle: A Memoir of Sorts
long_summary:
Raised by scientifically minded parents, Margaret Atwood spent most of each year in the wild forests of northern Quebec—a vast playground for her entomologist father and independent, resourceful mother. It was an unfettered and nomadic childhood, sometimes isolated but always thrilling and beautiful.

From this unconventional start, Atwood unfolds the story of her life, linking key moments to the books that have shaped our literary landscape. She traces the cruel school year that would become Cat's Eye and the unease of 1980s Berlin, where she began The Handmaid's Tale.

In pages alive with the natural world, reading, major political turning points, and her lifelong love for writer Graeme Gibson, we meet poets, bears, Hollywood stars, and larger-than-life characters straight from an Atwood novel. As she explores her past, Atwood reveals the connections between real life and art—and the workings of one of our greatest literary imaginations.
short_summary: Atwood traces her unconventional childhood in the Quebec wilderness to becoming one of our most essential writers. A luminous memoir that reveals how life transforms into art.
author_bios: Margaret Atwood is the author of more than fifty books of fiction, poetry, and critical essays. Her novels include Cat's Eye, The Robber Bride, Alias Grace, The Blind Assassin, and the MaddAddam trilogy. Her 1985 classic, The Handmaid's Tale, was followed in 2019 by The Testaments, which won the Booker Prize. She has won numerous awards, including the Arthur C. Clarke Award, the Franz Kafka Prize, and the PEN America Lifetime Achievement Award. She lives in Toronto.
quotes:
"Luminous prose, a palpable lust for life, and an invaluable glimpse into the mind of a literary giant make this a must-read."

—Publishers Weekly

"Engaging, wise, and marvelously witty—illuminating both the craft of writing and the art of living."

—Kirkus Reviews

"Atwood's long-awaited memoir covers her arc to becoming one of the leading voices of modern literature."

—New York Magazine

title: Lesser Known Monsters of the 21st Century
long_summary:
In these twelve unforgettable tales, the strange becomes familiar and the familiar turns strange. A girl sprouting wings on her legs feels like an ordinary rite of passage, while a bug-infested house transforms into an impossible, Kafkaesque nightmare.

Each story builds its own vivid world: children steal a haunted doll, a runaway bride encounters a sea monster, a vendor sells toy boxes that seemingly control time itself, and an insomniac finds herself seduced by the Sandman. These visions of modern life wrestle with death and technological consequence, guilt and sexuality, unmasking the contradictions that exist within all of us.

Mesmerizing, electric, and wholly original, Kim Fu's collection blurs the boundaries between real and fantastic, offering intricate and surprising insights into human nature.
short_summary: Twelve speculative stories where the surreal lurks beneath everyday life. Fu transforms modern anxieties into haunting fables about technology, desire, and what it means to be human.
author_bios: Kim Fu is the author of two novels, a collection of poetry, and the story collection Lesser Known Monsters of the 21st Century, winner of the Washington State Book Award, the Pacific Northwest Book Award, and the Danuta Gleed Literary Award, as well as a finalist for the Scotiabank Giller Prize, the Ignyte Awards, and the Shirley Jackson Awards. Fu lives in Seattle, Washington.
quotes:
"The strange and wonderful define Kim Fu's story collection, where the line between fantasy and reality fades in and out, elusive and beckoning."

—The New York Times Book Review

"Stellar. . . . Fu's stories crackle with quirky plots, and her characters' problems and hunger for new possibilities are palpable. This is a winner."

—Publishers Weekly

"Powerful. . . . Fu addresses questions of technology and community with grace and subtlety."

—Kirkus

title: Are You My Mother?
subtitle: A Comic Drama
long_summary:
Following her acclaimed Fun Home, Alison Bechdel turns her graphic memoir lens on her mother: voracious reader, music lover, passionate amateur actor. Also a woman unhappily married to a closeted gay man, whose artistic aspirations simmered beneath the surface of Bechdel's childhood—and who stopped touching or kissing her daughter good night when she was seven.

Poignantly and hilariously, Bechdel embarks on a quest for answers about the mother-daughter gulf. It's a richly layered search that leads from the fascinating work of psychoanalyst Donald Winnicott to one explosively illuminating Dr. Seuss illustration to Bechdel's own adult love life.

Finally, it circles back to Mother—to a truce, fragile and real-time, that will move all adult children of gifted mothers. This is filial sleuthery at its finest, a brilliant exploration of creativity, family, and the complicated inheritance between mothers and daughters.
short_summary: Bechdel follows her acclaimed Fun Home with another brilliant graphic memoir, this time exploring her complex relationship with her artistically gifted mother. A tender, funny excavation of family secrets and creative inheritance.
author_bios: Alison Bechdel's cult following for her comic strip Dykes to Watch Out For expanded wildly with her family memoirs, the New York Times bestselling Fun Home and Are You My Mother? Fun Home was Time magazine's #1 Book of the Year and adapted into a Tony Award–winning musical. The Secret to Superman Strength was named a New York Times Best Graphic Novel of 2021. Bechdel is a MacArthur Fellow.
quotes:
"Sad, funny, sprawling graphic memoir...An intensely personal, specific story, but Bechdel's imaginative narrative techniques make it easily as compelling as any fiction...Its stylistic flexibility accomodates more layers than any straight documentary or prose memoir could support...This work is her link in the long chain connecting her foremothers and their daughters and all of the other women who shaped her."

—The Atlantic

"...Magnificent... Whatever issues Bechdel has with her mother, one always has the sense that she likes her as much as she loves her. That affection — and the real sense one gets of her mother reading these pages, running her finger over the tenderly drawn panels of their history — gives this book an urgency and an intimacy that Fun Home, in retrospect, lacked... Bechdel's triumph is not just that she's emerged from her tunnel, with weary but clear eyes, but that she's brought her mother with her. Grade: A"

—Entertainment Weekly

"...Are You My Mother is as complicated, brainy, inventive and satisfying as the finest prose memoirs...The tragedy and comedy are so entwined, so gloriously balanced, the reader can't help being fascinated. The book delivers lightening bolts of revelation...I haven't encountered a book about being an artist, or about the punishing entanglements of mothers and daughters, as engaging, profound or original as this one in a long time. In fact, the book made such a deep impression on me that after reading it I walked around for days seeing little bits and snatches of my life as Alison Bechdel drawings."

—The New York Times

title: The Bright Sword
subtitle: A Novel of King Arthur
long_summary:
A gifted young knight named Collum arrives at Camelot to compete for a place at the Round Table, only to discover he's two weeks too late. King Arthur is dead, fallen at the Battle of Camlann, and only a handful of knights remain.

These survivors aren't the legendary heroes like Lancelot or Gawain. They're the Round Table's misfits: Sir Palomides, the Saracen Knight; Sir Dagonet, Arthur's fool who was knighted as a joke; and Nimue, Merlin's former apprentice who turned against her master and buried him under a hill.

Now this unlikely fellowship must rebuild Camelot in a world thrown off balance. God has abandoned Britain, and the old gods are returning, led by Morgan le Fay. To restore order, they must reclaim Excalibur and solve the mystery of why the brilliant, lonely King Arthur fell.

Steeped in Arthurian tradition yet thoroughly modern, The Bright Sword delivers classic elements—duels and quests, magic swords and Fisher Kings—while exploring what happens when broken people try to heal a broken land. It's an epic about imperfect heroes discovering that sometimes the aftermath of legend is where the real story begins.
short_summary: After King Arthur's death, his surviving misfits—outcasts, fools, and former enemies—must rebuild Camelot from the ruins. Grossman crafts a brilliant post-apocalyptic take on Arthurian legend.
author_bios: Lev Grossman is the author of the #1 New York Times bestselling Magicians trilogy—The Magicians, The Magician King, and The Magician's Land—published in thirty countries and adapted as a five-season SYFY series. He's also a screenwriter and author of two children's books, The Golden Swift and The Silver Arrow. His journalism has appeared in Time, Vanity Fair, The Wall Street Journal, and The New York Times. He lives with his wife and children in New York City.
quotes:
"For anyone who's ever craved a seat at the Round Table. Utterly enchanting."

—Rebecca Yarros, #1 New York Times bestselling author of Fourth Wing and Iron Flame

"If you love King Arthur as much as I do, you'll love Lev Grossman's The Bright Sword, a fresh and engrossing take on the Matter of Britain featuring a colorful cast of Round Table knights who don't often get as much story time as they deserve. The creator of The Magicians has woven another spell."

—George R. R. Martin, #1 New York Times bestselling author of A Game of Thrones

"The story of King Arthur has been told and substantially altered many times over the centuries, and explored by a multitude of contemporary novelists, but the author of the Magicians trilogy makes room for himself here. . . . Very few writers have explored post-Arthurian Britain or focused quite so much on developing the stories of the minor characters in the saga. . . . A fresh take."

—Kirkus

title: Get the Picture
subtitle: A Mind-Bending Journey among the Inspired Artists and Obsessive Art Fiends Who Taught Me How to See
long_summary:
Award-winning journalist Bianca Bosker's life was upended when she wandered into the art world—and couldn't look away. Intrigued by artists who hyperventilate around their favorite colors and art fiends who max out credit cards for hunks of metal they think can change the world, Bosker grew fixated on understanding why art matters and how any of us could engage with it more deeply.

In Get the Picture, Bosker throws herself into the nerve center of art and the people who live for it: gallerists, collectors, curators, and artists themselves—the kind who work multiple jobs to afford their studios while scrambling to get eyes on their work. She stretches canvases until her fingers blister, talks her way into A-list parties full of billionaire collectors, has her face sat on by a nearly-naked performance artist, and forces herself to stare at a single sculpture for hours while working as a museum security guard.

Probing everything from cave paintings to Instagram, and from the science of sight to the importance of beauty, Get the Picture examines art's role in our culture, economy, and hearts. It's a rollicking adventure that will change the way you see forever.
short_summary: The Cork Dork author infiltrates New York's exclusive art world with her signature immersive journalism. Hilarious, revelatory, and surprisingly moving—a brilliant exploration of why art matters.
author_bios: Bianca Bosker is the New York Times bestselling author of Cork Dork and a contributing writer at The Atlantic. Her writing has appeared in The New Yorker, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and The Best American Travel Writing, and been recognized with awards from the New York Press Club and Society of Professional Journalists.
quotes:
"[Bosker] has written a dark comedy of manners, and what she exposes here might be a new kind of country club mentality, where the cultural elite can no longer exclude people based on race, gender or sexual identity, so they come up with clever new ways to build moats around their little castles. . . . Get the Picture is one of the funniest books I've read about New York's contemporary art scene . . . Brilliant."

—The Washington Post

"Just about every page of Bianca Bosker's deep dive into New York's exclusive art world made me laugh . . . Useful to anyone who has been intimidated by hallowed art institutions or been confounded by what's on their walls."

—NPR

"This book freaked me out. Bosker's accessible, conversational spelunking into the world of contemporary art so powerfully rehydrated the PTSD in me between the little kid artist I once was with the self-consciously constricted thinker I became in art school that at one point I simply had to put it down, shaken. If you've ever wondered 'what happened' to art—galleries, critics, collectors—and, of course, artists—then this book is a very companionable start. It's also very funny, to say nothing of very vivid. And, confoundingly, very, very difficult to put down."

—Chris Ware, New Yorker artist/writer, author of Building Stories

title: The Lowland
long_summary:
From the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Namesake comes an extraordinary novel spanning India and America—a tale of two brothers bound by tragedy, a brilliant woman haunted by her past, and a love that transcends death.

Born just fifteen months apart, Subhash and Udayan Mitra are inseparable brothers in 1960s Calcutta, often mistaken for each other yet destined for vastly different futures. Udayan—charismatic and impulsive—throws himself into the Naxalite movement, a violent rebellion against poverty and inequity. Subhash, the dutiful son, leaves for America to pursue scientific research in quiet coastal isolation.

When Subhash learns what happened to his brother in the lowland outside their family home, he returns to India hoping to heal the wounds Udayan left behind—including those carved into his brother's wife's heart.

Masterfully suspenseful and piercingly intimate, The Lowland is both an engrossing family saga and a story steeped in history. Lahiri delivers a work of stunning beauty and complex emotion that spans generations and continents with seamless authenticity.
short_summary: Two brothers in 1960s Calcutta are bound by love but torn apart when one joins a violent political rebellion. Lahiri weaves a multigenerational saga of family, exile, and the wounds that echo across continents.
author_bios: Jhumpa Lahiri is the author of four works of fiction: Interpreter of Maladies, The Namesake, Unaccustomed Earth, and The Lowland; and a work of nonfiction, In Other Words. She has received the Pulitzer Prize, PEN/Hemingway Award, PEN/Malamud Award, Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award, Premio Gregor von Rezzori, DSC Prize for South Asian Literature, 2014 National Humanities Medal, and Premio Internazionale Viareggio-Versilia.
quotes:
"A tale of two continents in an era of political tumult, rendered with devastating depth and clarity by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author. The narrative proceeds from the simplicity of a fairy tale into a complex novel of moral ambiguity and aftershocks, with revelations that continue through decades and generations until the very last page. . . . The story of two brothers in India who are exceptionally close to each other, and yet completely different, the novel spans more than four decades in the life of [their] family, shaped and shaken by the events that have brought them together and tear them apart. . . . Lahiri has earned renown for her short stories, [yet] this masterful novel deserves to attract an even wider readership."

—Kirkus

"Lahiri's work resists pithy quotation, and until now, has avoided fireworks. But [her] first sentence works like a slow fuse. Divided consciousness has been her recurrent theme, [which] the transplanted Indian families in her earlier work know well. This time, she daringly redraws the map—[as] one of two close-knit brothers becomes a revolutionary while the other proceeds to the U.S. Loyalties are tested, twisted to extremes that become clear only toward the end. Here worlds, new and old, contain terrors."

—Ann Hulbert

"Lahiri tracks, with patience and tenacity, the emotional and geographical distances that time opens up between people, the things that get lost in those spaces, and the rare and surprising things that endure. In The Lowland, we are all emigrants, not from one country to another but from the present to the future. Lahiri's prose style is legendarily smooth, unshowy, unvarying . . . The Lowland gains tremendous power as it goes on. Language takes on the role of time itself. The Lowland feels less like a story being told than a tide slowly going out, gradually, inevitably revealing the shape of what was there all along."

—Lev Grossman

title: The Line Becomes a River
subtitle: Dispatches from the Border
long_summary:
For Francisco Cantú, the border runs in his blood. His mother, a park ranger and daughter of a Mexican immigrant, raised him in the scrublands of the Southwest. Driven to understand the hard realities of the landscape he loves, Cantú joins the Border Patrol.

He and his partners learn to track other humans under blistering sun and through frigid nights. They haul in the dead and deliver to detention those they find alive. Plagued by growing awareness of his complicity in a dehumanizing enterprise, he abandons the Patrol for civilian life.

But when an immigrant friend travels to Mexico to visit his dying mother and doesn't return, Cantú discovers that the border has migrated with him. Now he must confront the full extent of the violence it wreaks on both sides of the line.
short_summary: A former Border Patrol agent chronicles his time policing the U.S.-Mexico border in this searing blend of memoir and moral reckoning. Cantú's unflinching prose reveals how violence follows him long after leaving the job.
author_bios: Francisco Cantú was a Border Patrol agent from 2008 to 2012, working in the deserts of Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas. A former Fulbright fellow, he's received a Pushcart Prize, a 2017 Whiting Award, and a 2018 Art for Justice fellowship. His writing has appeared in The New York Times, Best American Essays, Harper's, Guernica, and This American Life. He coordinates the Southwest Field Studies in Writing Program at the University of Arizona.
quotes:
"Fresh, urgent...A devastating narrative of the very real human effects of depersonalized policy."

—Kirkus

"Cantú's rich prose and deep empathy make this an indispensable look at one of America's most divisive issues."

—Publishers Weekly

"A beautiful, fiercely honest, and nevertheless deeply empathetic look at those who police the border and the migrants who risk – and lose -- their lives crossing it. In a time of often ill-informed or downright deceitful political rhetoric, this book is an invaluable corrective."

—Phil Klay, author of Redeployment

title: The Dream Hotel
long_summary:
When Sara lands at LAX after a work conference, agents from the Risk Assessment Administration are waiting. Their algorithm has analyzed her dreams and determined she's about to commit a crime—against her own husband. For his safety, she must be detained for twenty-one days.

Sara is transferred to a retention center filled with other "dreamers," all women trying to prove their innocence. The facility's rules are strict and constantly changing, and every violation extends their stay. Months pass with no sign of release.

Then a new resident arrives, disrupting the center's rigid order and setting Sara on a collision course with the very companies that stripped away her freedom.

Eerie and urgent, The Dream Hotel explores technology's seductive grip—how it promises convenience while binding us in digital shackles. Lalami asks profound questions about privacy, freedom, and whether even the most invasive surveillance can truly capture who we are.
short_summary: Dreams become evidence in Lalami's chilling near-future thriller. When an algorithm predicts Sara will harm her husband based on her subconscious, she's detained indefinitely alongside other women fighting to prove their innocence.
author_bios: Laila Lalami is the author of five books, including The Moor's Account, which won the American Book Award, Arab-American Book Award, and Hurston/Wright Legacy Award, was longlisted for the Booker Prize, and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Her most recent novel, The Other Americans, was a national bestseller, won the Simpson/Joyce Carol Oates Prize, and was a National Book Award finalist. Her books have been translated into twenty languages. She's been awarded fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation and Radcliffe Institute at Harvard University.
quotes:
"A gripping, Kafkaesque foray into an all-too-plausible future where data collection penetrates interior life, The Dream Hotel is also an elegant meditation on identity and what we sacrifice, unthinkingly, for the sake of convenience."

—Jennifer Egan, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Candy House

"The Dream Hotel offers a stark vision of the future—in which America is a surveillance state, ruled by the intertwined forces of capital and government, powered by all-too-fallible algorithm that determines criminality based on citizen's dreams. That's plainly a metaphor for extant practices of social control, but Laila Lalami's extraordinary new novel is more than just a political warning; the book is an exploration of the psyche itself, the strange ungovernable forces of fate and emotion that make us human."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

"The world in Lalami's novel feels one step away from ours, which makes it astonishingly easy to slip inside. The women in The Dream Hotel grapple with the ways in which capitalism and technology sell off the pieces of ourselves most personal, most vulnerable, most private. A thrilling, urgent, and large-hearted novel that I can't wait to press upon other readers."

—Kelly Link, author of The Book of Love

title: Mark Twain
long_summary:
Before he was Mark Twain, he was Samuel Langhorne Clemens—a Missouri boy who dreamed of piloting steamboats on the Mississippi. When the Civil War interrupted his river career, young Clemens headed west to Nevada Territory and landed a newspaper job, writing dispatches that attracted attention for their brashness and humor. It wasn't long before this former steamboat pilot was recognized nationwide for his literary brilliance, writing under a pen name he would immortalize.

In this richly nuanced portrait, acclaimed biographer Ron Chernow brings his considerable powers to bear on a man who shamelessly sought fame and fortune while crafting his persona with meticulous care. After establishing himself as journalist, satirist, and lecturer, Twain settled in Hartford with his wife and three daughters, where he wrote The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn. He threw himself into American culture and emerged as the nation's most notable political pundit.

Yet his madcap business ventures eventually bankrupted him, forcing the family into nine years of European exile. He endured the deaths of his wife and two daughters, and his final years were marked by heartache, political crusades, and eccentric behavior that sometimes obscured darker forces at play. Drawing on thousands of letters and hundreds of unpublished manuscripts, Chernow masterfully captures the man whose career reflected America's westward expansion and industrialization—the most important white author of his generation to grapple fully with slavery's legacy.
short_summary: Ron Chernow's monumental biography captures the magnificent and often maddening life of Samuel Clemens, the Missouri dreamer who became Mark Twain. From steamboat pilot to America's first literary celebrity, this is the definitive portrait.
author_bios: Ron Chernow is the prizewinning author of seven previous books and recipient of the 2015 National Humanities Medal. The House of Morgan won the National Book Award, Washington: A Life won the Pulitzer Prize for Biography, and Alexander Hamilton won the George Washington Book Prize. He's been twice finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award and is one of only three living biographers to win the Gold Medal for Biography from the American Academy of Arts and Letters.
quotes:
"A comprehensive biography of one of the most important writers and social commentators in American history."

—Barack Obama

"It's a monstrous good time for a body to take an interest in Twain. In recent years, the humorist has seen his life and books reinterpreted by a literary darling, a graphic novel, a work of scholarship—even by himself, in an autobiography that waited a century for publication. Now, one of our most celebrated biographers is taking his own swing at a life so full, lively and multifarious—dare I say—picaresque, it would not have been out of place in one of Twain's own novels."

—NPR

"Remarkable . . . Chernow is an exceptional portraitist, adding depth and shadow to bring his subject fully to life. The impeccable research blends seamlessly into a narrative that examines Twain in all his guises: devoted family man, writer, publisher, entrepreneur, and inventor. Like his subject, Chernow has a keen ear for the perfect quote, insult, and witty rejoinder. This monumental achievement will stand as the definitive life of Mark Twain."

—Booklist

title: Matterhorn
subtitle: A Novel of the Vietnam War
long_summary:
Young Marine lieutenant Waino Mellas and his comrades in Bravo Company are dropped into the mountain jungles of Vietnam as boys, forced to fight their way into manhood. They battle not only the North Vietnamese but also monsoon rains, disease, hunger, and the wilderness itself.

Beyond the external threats, they must confront divisions within their own ranks—racial tension, clashing ambitions, and the failures of their commanders. When Bravo Company finds itself surrounded and outnumbered by a massive enemy force, the Marines are plunged into the raw terror of combat in an ordeal that will change them forever.

Written over thirty years by a decorated Marine veteran, Matterhorn captures both the futility and fierce brotherhood of war with unflinching honesty. This is an epic that stands alongside the great war novels, exploring what it means to survive when everything—including your own side—seems determined to destroy you.
short_summary: Young Marines battle Vietnamese forces and their own internal divisions in the jungle hell of Vietnam. Marlantes captures war's brutality and brotherhood with devastating authenticity.
author_bios: Karl Marlantes graduated from Yale University and was a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University before serving as a Marine in Vietnam, where he was awarded the Navy Cross, the Bronze Star, two Navy Commendation Medals for valor, two Purple Hearts, and ten air medals. He is the bestselling author of Matterhorn and What It Is Like to Go to War. He lives in rural Washington.
quotes:
"I've laughed at Catch-22 and wept at The Thin Red Line, but I've never encountered a war novel as stark, honest and wrenching as Matterhorn. . . . By turns, this book horrified me, crushed me and beat me up, but I found it nearly impossible to stop reading. More than any living American novelist I've read, Marlantes made me feel what I already must have known: that war is worse than hell."

—NPR

"Never have we seen the particular horrors and challenges of Vietnam so richly explored, and never have we felt the tactile experience of the war depicted with such mesmerizing force. We see the big picture, but as with all great novels, it's the tiny details—the mud, the leeches, the adrenaline-drenched dread of combat, and the tender joy of comradeship—that linger with the reader long after the story is over."

—Hampton Sides, author of Ghost Soldiers and Hellhound on His Trail

"These are the words I wrote down while reading Matterhorn: authentic, funny, heartbreaking, infuriating, devastating. This great book crawled under my skin on the first page, and I suspect it will remain there for a very long time."

—David Finkel, author of The Good Soldiers

title: Connie
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
Connie Chung is a pioneer. The youngest of ten children, she was the only one born in the U.S., after her parents escaped war-torn China in a harrowing journey to America, where Connie would one day make history as the first woman and Asian to co-anchor the CBS Evening News.

Profoundly influenced by her family's cultural traditions yet growing up completely Americanized, she dealt with overt sexism and racism. Despite this, her tenacity led her to become a household name.

In this revealing memoir, Chung pulls back the curtain on her singular life. From her close relationship with Maury Povich, her husband and professional confidant, to the horrific memory of being molested by the doctor who had delivered her, to her joy of adopting their son when she was almost fifty, she doesn't hold back. She talks honestly about the good, bad, and ugly in her personal and professional life—this is Connie Chung like you've never seen her before.
short_summary: Television news pioneer Connie Chung delivers a sharp, witty memoir that pulls no punches. From breaking barriers as the first Asian woman in network news to navigating personal trauma and triumph, she reveals it all.
author_bios: Connie Chung was the first woman to co-anchor the CBS Evening News and only the second woman to anchor any network evening broadcast in television history. A pioneer news anchor and reporter, she broke significant barriers in the overwhelmingly white, male-dominated television news industry.
quotes:
"This delightful memoir is filled with Connie Chung's trademark wit, sharp insights, and deep understanding of people. It's a revealing account of what it's like to be a woman breaking barriers in the world of TV news, filled with colorful tales of rivalry and triumph. But it also has a larger theme: how the line between serious reporting and tabloid journalism became blurred."

—Walter Isaacson, New York Times bestselling author of Steve Jobs

"[F]rank and entertaining...Chung writes breezily and with irreverent humor about the scoops, the internal politics and the pure hustle that eventually got her to the top."

—The New York Times

"Lucky for readers, Chung is a sharer; her candor is commendable and unvarnished...Chung's memoir, often enchanting and enlightening, serves as a historical account of broadcast news during its most powerful, competitive and sometimes most absurd era."

—The Washington Post

title: Absolution
long_summary:
In Saigon in 1963, two young American wives form a wary alliance. Tricia is a starry-eyed newlywed, married to a rising oil engineer "on loan" to US Navy Intelligence. Charlene is a practiced corporate spouse and mother of three, a talented hostess and determined altruist on a mission to relieve the "wretchedness" she sees all around her.

When Tricia miscarries, Charlene sweeps her into a cabal of well-dressed do-gooder American wives. Armed with baskets filled with candy and toys, they descend on hospitals, orphanages, and a leper colony on the coast, determined to relieve suffering, no matter the cost.

Sixty years later, Charlene's daughter reaches out to Tricia, now widowed and living in Washington. As the two women relive their shared experience in Saigon, they are forced to come to terms with the ways their own lives have been shaped and stunted by Charlene's pursuit of "inconsequential good."

With narrative impact that recalls Graham Greene's The Quiet American, McDermott confronts the unresolved mysteries and ironies of America's tragic interference in Southeast Asia.
short_summary: Two American wives navigate Saigon in 1963, their well-intentioned charity work revealing the complexities of privilege and power. McDermott delivers a masterful exploration of how good intentions can shape and stunt lives across decades.
author_bios: Alice McDermott is the author of eight novels, including The Ninth Hour, Someone, After This, At Weddings and Wakes, and That Night—all published by FSG. That Night, At Weddings and Wakes, and After This were Pulitzer Prize finalists. She also wrote the essay collection What About the Baby?: Some Thoughts on the Art of Fiction. Her work has appeared in The New York Times, The Washington Post, The New Yorker, and Harper's Magazine. For over two decades she was the Richard A. Macksey Professor for Distinguished Teaching in the Humanities at Johns Hopkins University.
quotes:
"Alice McDermott has always been one of our greatest writers but here she exceeds every expectation. Absolution is one of the finest contemporary novels I've read. It is a moral masterpiece."

—Ann Patchett, author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"Enveloping . . . Retrospect amplifies McDermott's narrative approach; her work lives in its shimmering details . . . The debacle of America's involvement in Vietnam might easily have overdetermined McDermott's story, and it is a measure of her skill that Absolution maintains an oblique relationship to the war . . . What difference might it have made, for everyone, if those wives had been given a choice in the decision-making? Without posing this question directly, Absolution leaves the reader in its provocative shadow."

—Jennifer Egan, The New York Times

"It's futile to predict where a great writer's boundless imagination will take us and, as Absolution affirms, McDermott is a great writer . . . McDermott possesses the rare ability to evoke and enter bygone worlds-pre-Vatican II Catholicism, pre-feminist-movement marriages-without condescending to them. She understands that the powerhouses can dominate the helpmeets. She also understands that playing God is the role of a lifetime-and every human actor should turn it down."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: The Ninth Hour
long_summary:
On a dim winter afternoon, a young Irish immigrant opens a gas tap in his Brooklyn tenement. He is determined to prove—to the subway bosses who have recently fired him, to his badgering, pregnant wife—that "the hours of his life . . . belonged to himself alone." In the aftermath of the fire that follows, Sister St. Saviour, an aging nun from the Little Nursing Sisters of the Sick Poor, appears unbidden to direct the way forward for his widow and unborn child.

In Catholic Brooklyn of the early twentieth century, decorum, superstition, and shame collude to erase the man's brief existence. Yet his suicide, though never spoken of, reverberates through many lives—testing the limits and demands of love and sacrifice, forgiveness and forgetfulness, across multiple generations. Rendered with remarkable delicacy, heart, and intelligence, McDermott's novel explores how one moment of desperation ripples outward, shaping the lives of those left behind.
short_summary: When a desperate Irish immigrant takes his own life in 1920s Brooklyn, the reverberations shape generations. McDermott weaves a luminous story of nuns, widows, and the weight of unspoken grief.
author_bios: Alice McDermott is the author of eight novels, including The Ninth Hour, Someone, After This, At Weddings and Wakes, and That Night—all published by FSG. That Night, At Weddings and Wakes, and After This were Pulitzer Prize finalists. She also wrote the essay collection What About the Baby?: Some Thoughts on the Art of Fiction. Her work has appeared in The New York Times, The Washington Post, The New Yorker, and Harper's Magazine. For over two decades she was the Richard A. Macksey Professor for Distinguished Teaching in the Humanities at Johns Hopkins University.
quotes:
"McDermott delivers an immense, brilliant novel about the limits of faith, the power of sacrifice, and the cost of forgiveness . . . It's the thread that follows Sally's coming of age and eventual lapse of faith that is the most absorbing. Scenes detailing her benevolent encounters . . . are paradoxically grotesque and irresistible . . . McDermott exhibits a keen eye for character."

—Publishers Weekly

"Everything that her readers, the National Book Award committee, and the Pulitzer Prize judges love about McDermott's stories of Irish-Catholic American life is back."

—Kirkus

"A remarkable snapshot of early 20th-century Irish-Catholic Brooklyn."

—Entertainment Weekly

title: Known and Strange Things
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
With more than fifty pieces spanning politics, photography, travel, history, and literature, Teju Cole demonstrates why he's become one of today's most essential voices. His prose is dense with beauty and ideas, finding fresh ways to interpret art, people, and pivotal moments—taking in subjects from Virginia Woolf and Shakespeare to Instagram, Barack Obama, and Boko Haram.

Cole brings new perspectives to James Baldwin in the age of Black Lives Matter and the African American photographer Roy DeCarava, who worked with film calibrated exclusively for white skin tones yet found his way to startling depictions of Black subjects. In one particularly provocative essay, he examines the White Savior Industrial Complex—the system by which African nations receive sentimental aid from an America "developed on pillage."

Persuasive and provocative, erudite yet accessible, this collection offers readers a chance to live within Cole's wide-ranging enthusiasms and see the world through surprising new frames.
short_summary: Cole's incisive essays traverse literature, photography, politics, and travel with surgical precision. From James Baldwin to Instagram, his reflections illuminate our cultural moment with rare intelligence and humanity.
author_bios: Teju Cole was born in the United States in 1975 to Nigerian parents and grew up in Lagos. His books include the novel Open City, essay collections Known and Strange Things and Black Paper, and experimental photo book Blind Spot. He has received the PEN/Hemingway Award, Internationaler Literaturpreis, Windham-Campbell Prize, and Guggenheim Fellowship. An elected member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, Cole is professor of creative writing at Harvard University and contributing writer to The New York Times Magazine.
quotes:
"The forms of resistance depend on the culture they resist, and in our era of generalizations and approximations and sloppiness, Teju Cole's precise and vivid observation and description are an antidote and a joy. This is a book written with a scalpel, a microscope, and walking shoes, full of telling details and sometimes big surprises."

—Rebecca Solnit, author of Men Explain Things to Me

"Cole is a literary performance artist, his words meticulously chosen and deployed with elegance and force. To read, see, and travel with him is to be changed by the questions that challenge him."

—Publishers Weekly

"Cole's insights cast fresh light on even the most quotidian of objects . . . [and his] collection performs an important service by elevating public discourse in an unsettled time."

—Booklist

title: Grief Is for People
long_summary:
When Sloane Crosley's closest friend Russell dies by suicide just one month after her apartment is burglarized, she's thrust into a profound reckoning with loss, memory, and meaning. What follows is both deeply moving memoir and unexpectedly suspenseful meditation on friendship and resilience.

As Crosley revisits her years with Russell—their shared life in New York's literary world, their laughter and work together—she confronts impossible questions about security, memory, and what it means to hold on without being destroyed. With her signature wit now sharpened by raw grief, she transforms the traditional grief memoir into something entirely fresh: a modern elegy that's frank, darkly funny, and profoundly empathetic.

Crosley spans art, philosophy, and the bonds of chosen family in her search for understanding, reshaping how we think about loss and survival. The result offers genuine solace and insight for an age defined by grief.
short_summary: Following her friend's suicide and a devastating burglary, Crosley transforms profound loss into a darkly funny, deeply moving meditation on friendship and survival.
author_bios: Sloane Crosley is the author of essay collections I Was Told There'd Be Cake (2009 Thurber Prize finalist), How Did You Get This Number, and Look Alive Out There (2019 Thurber Prize finalist); novels The Clasp and Cult Classic; and memoir Grief Is for People. A Vanity Fair contributing editor, she lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Grief Is for People captures the feeling of watching a beloved, inappropriate and wild person fit less and less with the times we live in. Like Didion's The Year Of Magical Thinking or Defoe's Journal of a Plague Year, Grief Is for People takes us through the ordinary, awful and never-quite-ending experience of loss. It also made me laugh very hard, many times. I can't stop thinking about it."

—John Mulaney

"In this vivid, and bitingly funny account, Sloane Crosley exposes the magical thinking and murk that follow a friend's suicide. Crosley's prose is honest, lucid, and always surprising; I can't imagine a better companion to guide us through the pain of losing a friend. A painful and necessary book; I will be keeping it close for years to come."

—Meghan O'Rourke, author of The Invisible Kingdom

"Potent and propulsive, a lyrical meditation on loss and what comes after. Grief Is for People is heartbreaking and wholly original."

—Tara Westover, author of Educated

title: The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet
long_summary:
The year is 1799, the place Dejima in Nagasaki Harbor—a high-walled, fan-shaped artificial island that serves as the Japanese Empire's single port and sole window onto the world. This outpost of the war-ravaged Dutch East Indies Company is a de facto prison for the dozen foreigners permitted to live and work there.

To this place of devious merchants, deceitful interpreters, costly courtesans, earthquakes, and typhoons comes Jacob de Zoet, a devout and resourceful young clerk. He has five years in the East to earn a fortune large enough to win the hand of his wealthy fiancée back in Holland.

But Jacob's plans shift after a chance encounter with Orito Aibagawa, the disfigured daughter of a samurai doctor and midwife to the city's powerful magistrate. The borders between propriety, profit, and pleasure blur until Jacob finds his vision clouded, one rash promise made and then fatefully broken. The consequences will extend beyond his worst imaginings.

A magnificent mix of luminous writing, prodigious research, and vivid imagination, this novel showcases Mitchell's masterful ability to bring historical worlds to stunning life.
short_summary: A Dutch clerk arrives in 1799 Japan seeking fortune but finds forbidden love and cultural collision on the isolated trading island of Dejima. Mitchell delivers a sweeping historical epic with exquisite prose and meticulous period detail.
author_bios: David Mitchell is the author of Ghostwritten, number9dream, Cloud Atlas, Black Swan Green, The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet, The Bone Clocks, and Slade House. Twice shortlisted for the Booker Prize, he won the Sunday Times Award for Literary Excellence in 2018.
quotes:
"An achingly romantic story of forbidden love . . . Mitchell's incredible prose is on stunning display. . . . A novel of ideas, of longing, of good and evil and those who fall somewhere in between [that] confirms Mitchell as one of the more fascinating and fearless writers alive."

—Dave Eggers, The New York Times

"The novelist who's been showing us the future of fiction has published a classic, old-fashioned tale . . . an epic of sacrificial love, clashing civilizations and enemies who won't rest until whole family lines have been snuffed out."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A beautiful novel, full of life and authenticity, atmosphere and characters that breathe."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Raising Hare
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In February 2021, political advisor Chloe Dalton stumbles upon a newborn hare—a leveret—that had been chased by a dog. Fearing for its life, she brings it home, only to discover how impossible it is to rear a wild hare, most of whom perish in captivity from shock or starvation.

Through trial and error, she learns to feed and care for the leveret with every intention of returning it to the wilderness. Instead, it becomes her constant companion, wandering the fields and woods at night and returning to Dalton's house by day. Though she fears the hare will be preyed upon by foxes, stoats, feral cats, and raptors, she never restricts it to the house. Each time the hare leaves, Chloe knows she may never see it again—yet she understands that to confine it would be its own kind of death.

Raising Hare chronicles their extraordinary relationship while diving deep into the lives and nature of hares, and how they've been viewed throughout history in art, literature, and folklore. A reminder that the most beautiful experiences arise when we least expect them.
short_summary: During lockdown in the English countryside, a political advisor rescues an abandoned leveret and forms an unlikely bond. A tender meditation on freedom, wildness, and letting go.
author_bios: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie grew up in Nigeria. Her work has been translated into more than fifty-five languages. She is the author of Purple Hibiscus, which won the Commonwealth Writers' Prize; Half of a Yellow Sun, recipient of the Women's Prize for Fiction "Best of the Best" award; Americanah, which won the National Book Critics Circle Award; the story collection The Thing Around Your Neck; and the essays We Should All Be Feminists and Dear Ijeawele, or A Feminist Manifesto in Fifteen Suggestions. Her recent works include Notes on Grief and the children's book Mama's Sleeping Scarf. A MacArthur Fellowship recipient, she divides her time between the United States and Nigeria.
quotes:
"An astounding debut memoir in which Dalton shows how a serene and long-misunderstood creature opened her eyes in many ways. It just might do the same for readers. . . . Soulful and gracefully written."

—Kirkus

"This book tells a story of true friendship with great respect . . . If you love animals, this book is incredibly beautiful and moving and helped me see nature differently. I think it's the best non-fiction book of the year."

—Elizabeth Gilbert

"Dalton's clear, measured prose and Denise Nestor's delicate drawings provide . . . a bit of solace in a world that has now returned to an even more frenetic state. In Raising Hare, nature, indeed, takes its course."

—The New York Times

title: The Committed
long_summary:
The long-awaited sequel to The Sympathizer follows the unnamed narrator as he arrives in 1980s Paris with his blood brother Bon. The pair attempt to rebuild their lives through capitalism in its purest form: drug dealing.

Traumatized by reeducation at the hands of his former best friend Man, the Sympathizer struggles to assimilate into French culture while finding Paris both seductive and disturbing. Through dinner parties hosted by his French Vietnamese "aunt," he falls in with left-wing intellectuals who provide stimulation for his mind—and customers for his merchandise.

But his new life brings unforeseen perils: the self-torture of addiction, the authoritarianism of a colonial state, and the seemingly impossible task of reuniting his two closest friends whose opposing worldviews put them in direct conflict. The Sympathizer will need all his wits, resourcefulness, and moral flexibility to survive.

Both literary thriller and novel of ideas, The Committed delivers a blistering portrayal of loyalty and betrayal that cements Nguyen's place in contemporary American literature.
short_summary: The unnamed narrator from The Sympathizer navigates 1980s Paris through drug dealing and left-wing intellectual circles. Nguyen weaves crime, philosophy, and politics into a searing meditation on exile and identity.
author_bios: Viet Thanh Nguyen was born in Vietnam and raised in America. He is the author of The Sympathizer, winner of the 2016 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, the short story collection The Refugees, and the nonfiction book Nothing Ever Dies, a National Book Award finalist. He is the Aerol Arnold Professor of English and American Studies and Ethnicity at USC and a recipient of Guggenheim and MacArthur fellowships.
quotes:
"An elegy to idealism, Orientalism, and existentialism in all its tragic forms, Nguyen's novel doesn't so much inhabit early eighties Paris, as it pulls the plug on the City of Light. Think of The Committed as the declaration of the 20th ½ Arrondissement. A squatter's paradise for those with one foot in the grave and the other shoved halfway up Western civilization's ass."

—Paul Beatty

"In a decade whose fiction is dominated by autofiction, there's something de´mode´ about Nguyen's novels, which I think can fairly be considered a single artistic endeavor . . . The Sympathizer and The Committed are, to borrow James Wood's phrase for such novels, perpetual-motion machines, their exuberance perhaps a suitable method given how vast a subject he aims to tackle. The breathless voice and sprawling plots of these novels made me think of Midnight's Children: manic language and impossible story suit the strange truth of colonialism. Nguyen does Salman Rushdie one better by deploying the conventions of genre fiction; he gently seduces the reader into two rambling, discursive works passionately interested in war and violence, race and identity, colonialism and history."

—Rumaan Alam, The New York Times

"The Committed is nothing short of revelatory. As it haunts, bifurcates, and envelops us in its illumination of all that we have failed to notice about the far reaches of colonization, we are also thrilled by its many turns and charms. This book is fierce, and unrelentingly good. Hilarious and subversive, philosophical and hallucinatory, it is much more than a sequel, more like a necessary appendage in a brilliant and expansive anti-colonial body of work, from the twisted and playful mind of the one and only Viet Thanh Nguyen. Bravo."

—Tommy Orange, New York Times-bestselling author of There There

title: Claire McCardell
subtitle: The Designer Who Set Women Free
long_summary:
Claire McCardell forever changed fashion—and most importantly, the lives of women. She shattered cultural norms around women's clothes, and today much of what we wear traces back to her ingenious, rebellious mind.

McCardell invented ballet flats and mix-and-match separates, introducing wrap dresses, hoodies, leggings, and denim into womenswear. She tossed out corsets in favor of comfortable elegance and insisted on pockets, even as male designers didn't see a need for them. She made zippers easy to reach because a woman "may live alone and like it," McCardell once wrote, "but you may regret it if you wrench your arm trying to zip a back zipper into place."

After World War II, McCardell fought the severe, hyper-feminized silhouette championed by male designers like Christian Dior. Dior claimed he wanted to "save women from nature." McCardell, by contrast, wanted to set women free. She became, as young journalist Betty Friedan called her in 1955, "The Gal Who Defied Dior."

Filled with personal drama and industry secrets, this story reveals how McCardell built an empire when women rarely reached business's upper echelons. At its core, hers is a story about our right to choose how we dress—and how we live.
short_summary: The riveting hidden history of Claire McCardell, the most influential fashion designer you've never heard of. From ballet flats to wrap dresses, her revolutionary designs liberated women from corsets and convention.
author_bios: Elizabeth Evitts Dickinson is an award-winning journalist whose writing has appeared in The New York Times, Harper's Magazine, The New Yorker, The Southern Review, and The Washington Post Magazine. A National Endowment for the Arts Creative Writing Fellow, her work has earned recognition in The Best American Essays and Maryland's prestigious Mary Sawyers Imboden Prize for literature. She lives in Baltimore with her husband and daughter.
quotes:
"An insightful, beautifully written tribute to a designer who was ahead of her time. In a world where women are still fighting for full agency, this book reminds us that fashion, at its best, is about freedom on our own terms. It's an essential read."

—Susan Magsamen, New York Times bestselling co-author of Your Brain on Art

"In the hands of Dickinson, this is more than just the biography of a fashion revolutionary: It is a story of the fight for women's identity and, incidentally, the birth of an American industry."

—The New York Times

"Dickinson illustrates how fashion served as a mirror for sociopolitical change...Fashion aficionados won't want to miss this."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Mina's Matchbox
long_summary:
In the spring of 1972, twelve-year-old Tomoko leaves her mother behind in Tokyo and boards a train alone for Ashiya, a coastal town where she'll stay with her aunt's family. Her aunt is an enigma—an outlier in their working-class family whose magnificent home and handsome foreign husband, the president of a soft drink company, are symbols of her elevated status.

The seventeen-room mansion is filled with German-made furnishings, sprawling gardens, and even an old zoo where the family's pygmy hippopotamus resides. The family is just as beguiling as their home: Tomoko's dignified aunt, her German great-aunt, and her dashing uncle who confidently presides as patriarch. At the center is Tomoko's cousin Mina, a precocious, asthmatic thirteen-year-old who draws Tomoko into an intoxicating world of secret crushes and elaborate storytelling.

In this elegant jewel box of a novel, Yoko Ogawa captures a powerful and formative interlude in Tomoko's life. Behind the family's sophistication lurk complications she struggles to understand—her uncle's mysterious absences, her great-aunt's wartime experiences, her aunt's hidden misery. Rich with the magic and mystery of youthful experience, this is an evocative snapshot of childhood wonder shadowed by adult secrets.
short_summary: Twelve-year-old Tomoko spends a transformative summer with her wealthy relatives in 1970s Japan. Ogawa captures childhood's ephemeral magic while revealing the adult secrets lurking beneath a family's polished surface.
author_bios: Yoko Ogawa has won every major Japanese literary award. Her fiction has appeared in The New Yorker, A Public Space, and Zoetrope: All-Story. Her works include The Memory Police, The Diving Pool, The Housekeeper and the Professor, Hotel Iris, and Revenge. She lives in Ashiya, Japan.
quotes:
"There's such an elegance to the way Mina's Matchbox unfolds...The world Yoko Ogawa builds is quiet, warm and it should feel comforting. But there are peculiarities about the whole thing that keep you on the tips of your toes."

—NPR

"Focusing on characters of an age when the world seems full of wonder and possibility, this engaging bildungsroman explores the friendship and mutual curiosity between two extraordinary young people… Facing complicated themes with deceptively simple language, she pulls off a neat trick here, painting everything in miniature and often in hindsight without losing the immediacy of Tomoko's experiences. A charming yet guileless exploration of childhood's ephemeral pleasures and reflexive poignancy."

—Kirkus

"Captivating…Ogawa pulls off the rare feat of making childhood memories both credible and provocative. Readers will be hypnotized."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Fi
subtitle: A Memoir of My Son
long_summary:
"Fair to say, I was in a ribald state the summer before my fiftieth birthday." So begins Alexandra Fuller's devastating new memoir about a year that would change everything.

It's midsummer in Wyoming and Alexandra is barely holding on. She's grieving her father, pining for her home country of Zimbabwe, reeling from a midlife breakup, newly sober, and navigating an uncertain relationship with a younger woman. She's determined to find her footing again.

Then the unthinkable happens: her 21-year-old son Fi dies suddenly in his sleep.

No stranger to loss—young siblings, a parent, a homeland—Alexandra is nonetheless shattered. But she knows she cannot abandon her two surviving daughters as her own mother had done. From a sheep wagon in the Wyoming mountains to a grief sanctuary in New Mexico to a silent meditation retreat in Alberta, Alexandra travels the spine of the Rockies searching for how to grieve herself whole.

There are no easy answers, only the wild medicine of poetry, ritual, nature, and the indigenous wisdom she absorbed as a child in Zimbabwe. By turns disarming, devastating, and unexpectedly funny, this memoir chronicles the painstaking work of grieving a child in a culture that offers no roadmap.
short_summary: A devastating memoir about losing a child, told with the unflinching honesty and unexpected humor that made Fuller's previous work essential reading. Raw, beautiful, and ultimately about finding ways to survive the unsurvivable.
author_bios: Alexandra Fuller is the author of four memoirs, including Don't Let's Go To The Dogs Tonight—a New York Times Notable Book, Booksense Best Non-fiction winner, and recipient of the Winifred Holtby Memorial Prize—and the New York Times-bestselling Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness, plus two non-fiction books and the novel Quiet Until The Thaw. Her writing appears in the New Yorker, National Geographic, Granta, The New York Times, Guardian and Financial Times.
quotes:
"Fuller is sagacious and perspicacious. She is a sublime writer. In the hands of another memoirist, the story of Fi might be unbearably sad, but this book is a mesmeric celebration of a boy who died too soon, a mother's love and her resilience. It will help others surviving loss — surviving life."

—David Sheff, The New York Times

"Fuller is unyielding in her honesty, laying herself bare on the page. With unflinching candour she recounts the agonizing weeks, days, hours and minutes following Fi's death, her downward spiral into grief and her eventual reconnection with herself and the world around her. And only Fuller could inject humour into a story such as this . . . Fi will undoubtedly hit home with any readers grieving the loss of a loved one. It may also offer hope."

—The Winnipeg Free Press

"A truly extraordinary memoir about a mother's loss of her son: beautiful, fearless, raw and an utterly compelling read."

—Helen Macdonald, author of H Is For Hawk

title: Wandering Stars
long_summary:
Colorado, 1864. Star, a young survivor of the Sand Creek Massacre, is imprisoned at Fort Marion, where evangelical guard Richard Henry Pratt forces him to abandon his identity for English and Christianity. Pratt will later found the Carlisle Indian Industrial School, dedicated to erasing Native history and culture.

A generation later, Star's son Charles is sent to Carlisle, where he endures brutalization by the same man who once imprisoned his father. Under Pratt's harsh regime, Charles finds solace in stolen moments with fellow student Opal Viola, as they dream of escape from the institutional violence that haunts their bloodlines.

Tommy Orange conjures the ancestors of the family readers first met in There There—warriors, survivors, outlaws—asking what it means to be children of massacre. This shattering and wondrous novel explores how trauma travels through generations, creating a modern epic about resilience and the weight of history.
short_summary: From the Sand Creek Massacre to modern Oakland, Orange traces a Native family across generations, showing how historical trauma echoes through bloodlines. Epic in scope, intimate in detail.
author_bios: Tommy Orange is a graduate of the MFA program at the Institute of American Indian Arts. An enrolled member of the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes of Oklahoma, he was born and raised in Oakland, California. His first book, There There, was a finalist for the 2019 Pulitzer Prize and received the 2019 American Book Award.
quotes:
"In Wandering Stars, Tommy Orange finds different pockets, not just to flex, but to really get to beyond the marrow of this wonderfully blistered world. The work is so varied and textured but also ruthlessly clear in what it's costing and what it's destroying."

—Kiese Laymon, author of Heavy

"If there was any doubt after his incredible debut, there should be none now: Tommy Orange is one of our most important writers.
