The way he weaves time and life together, demands we remember how our history shapes us. In this novel the pain and resilience of generations are summoned beautifully. A wonderous journey and a necessary reminder."

—Nana Kwame Adjei Brenyah, author of Chain Gang All Stars

"In Wandering Stars, Tommy Orange opens us up to these big lives full of hope and triumph and love and freedom—but then the world comes in, history comes in, drugs and nation and bullets and the big and small lonelinesses come in. Richard Pryor said he wanted to get you laughing so your mouth would be open when he poured the poison down, and that's what Orange is doing here. Anyone can say a complicated thing in a complicated way, but Tommy says the hardest things plain—beyond artifice, beyond confection. That clarity, that radical lucidity, that's the mark of true genius, a word I use here without hyperbole. Think Kafka, Lispector, Borges. Wandering Stars is the kind of book that saves lives, that makes remaining in the world feel a little more possible. It's art of the highest order, written by one of our language's most significant and urgent practitioners."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

title: The Hounding
long_summary:
Even before the rumors about the Mansfield girls begin, Little Nettlebed is a village steeped in the uncanny. Strange creatures wash up on the riverbank, portentous ravens gather on roofs of people about to die. But when villagers start hearing barking—and one claims to see the Mansfield sisters transform before his very eyes—the allegations spark fascination and fear like nothing before.

The truth is that though the inhabitants of Little Nettlebed have never much liked the Mansfield girls, they've always had plenty to say about them. A little odd, think some; a little high on themselves, perhaps. As the rotating perspectives of five villagers make clear, now is no exception.

Even if local belief in witchcraft is waning, an aversion to difference is as widespread as ever. These conflicting narratives all point to the same ultimate conclusion: Something isn't right in Little Nettlebed, and the sisters will be the ones to pay for it.

A richly atmospheric parable of female defiance, The Hounding considers whether in any age it might be safer to be a dog than an unusual young girl.
short_summary: Five sisters in an eighteenth-century English village face accusations of witchcraft when neighbors become convinced they're transforming into dogs. Gothic paranoia meets sharp social commentary in this haunting debut.
author_bios: Xenobe Purvis was born in Tokyo in 1990. She studied English Literature at Oxford, has an MA in creative writing from Royal Holloway, and was part of the London Library's Emerging Writers Programme. Her essays have appeared in the Times Literary Supplement, the London Magazine, and elsewhere.
quotes:
"What takes this novel past conceit to commentary lies in its exploration of interiority among all of the characters, not simply the suspected women, but those who observe, accuse and fear. When a community cannot explain misfortune, who suffers? Purvis makes a clever but careful case for combining the Gothic with the paranormal."

—Los Angeles Times

"With hints of superstition akin to Shirley Jackson's "The Lottery" and the puritanical overtones of Nathaniel Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter, Purvis's The Hounding taps into universal themes of fear, violence, lust, and also empathy."

—Shelf Awareness

"The Hounding is a debut novel bound to be a cult classic. It's a tale set centuries ago that throbs with a bloody, living heart. It's a jewel dug from the depths of Xenobe Purvis's imagination. It's exquisite."

—Julia Phillips, author of Bear

title: Girl on Girl
subtitle: How Pop Culture Turned a Generation of Women Against Themselves
long_summary:
What happened to feminism in the twenty-first century? This question feels increasingly urgent in a moment of cultural and legislative backlash, when widespread uncertainty about the movement's power and focus threatens decades of progress.

Sophie Gilbert identifies an inflection point in the late 1990s and early 2000s, when the energy of third-wave and riot grrrl feminism collapsed into a regressive period of hyper-objectification and infantilization. Mining the darker side of nostalgia, Gilbert trains her keen analytic eye on the most revealing cultural objects of the era—music, film, television, fashion, tabloid journalism, and more.

What she recounts is harrowing: the leering gaze of the paparazzi, the gleeful cruelty of early reality TV, and a burgeoning internet culture vicious toward women in the spotlight. Gilbert tracks many of the period's dominant themes back to the rise of internet porn, which gained widespread influence as it pervaded our collective consciousness.

The result is a devastating portrait of a time when American excess, materialism, and power worship collided with reactionary, puritanical currents. Amid a collective reconsideration of how women are treated in public, Girl on Girl is a blistering indictment of the matrix of misogyny that shaped early twenty-first century culture—and continues to shape our world today.
short_summary: Atlantic critic Sophie Gilbert excavates the cultural wreckage of the early 2000s, when third-wave feminism collapsed into hyper-objectification and cruelty. A devastating analysis of how we got here.
author_bios: Sophie Gilbert is a staff writer at The Atlantic, where she writes about television, books, and popular culture. She won the 2024 National Magazine Award for Reviews and Criticism and was a finalist for the 2022 Pulitzer Prize in Criticism. She lives in London.
quotes:
"Girl on Girl is a work of overwhelming meticulousness and clarity. If you're confused about the current uncertainty about feminism's power, Sophie Gilbert has done the work of painstakingly and granularly tracing every cultural thread to reveal how we got here. Gilbert unmasks an insidious cultural coup that seemingly overnight dethroned the transgressive women of the 90s; 'Just like that they were gone–replaced by girls,' she writes. Over and over, Gilbert reminds us: it wasn't always this bad–in fact, it was getting better, then it got taken away. Girl on Girl is a necessary corrective of cultural memory, but more importantly, it is a definitive archive of that disempowerment and its ensuing cruelties."

—Elamin Abdelmahmoud, host of CBC's Commotion and author of Son of Elsewhere

"Searing . . . There were several passages in Gilbert's blistering, sobering book Girl on Girl that challenged my selective nostalgia, making me wince. If you too came of age around the late 1990s and early aughts, prepare to have the balloon string of sentimentality pried from your grip. The party's over. It's been over . . . Her book is a course correction of sorts, taking a holistic tack to explain our current sociopolitical reality: one in which women's hard-fought gains are quickly eroding, and men and boys are in crisis . . . Across 10 rigorously researched but never stuffy chapters, Gilbert has compiled perhaps the first comprehensive examination of turn-of-the-millennium mainstream, cool-kid trends and ephemera, and how they were largely molded by those in power to sell a generation of girls and young women reality-warping lies . . . Gilbert isn't concerned with softening the blow. Instead, she's intent on snapping millennials out of any instinct to idealize the decades that shaped us—even if that awareness stings."

—New York Times

"So clear-eyed that it's startling . . . Girl on Girl covers how American culture writ large treated women from the 1990s to the 2010s. It's to Gilbert's credit that she makes a cohesive history emerge from this morass of references . . . Her organization is as confident and nimble as her arguments . . . The informed and persuasive essays in Girl on Girl stand alone, even as they build on one another. A chapter on the early years of reality television is exceptional . . . This ground is well-trod, but rarely trod so well . . . Gilbert is a critic skilled in the art of seeing close-up and faraway all at once, a Vertigo effect of cultural observation. Girl on Girl doesn't settle into outrage or pity, but instead offers a clear-eyed, unblinking stare that conveys one thing: I see what you're doing."

—The Washington Post

title: The End of Drum-Time
long_summary:
In 1851, at a remote village in the Scandinavian tundra, a Lutheran minister known as Mad Lasse tries in vain to convert the native Sámi reindeer herders to his faith. When one of the most respected herders has a dramatic awakening and dedicates his life to the church, his impetuous son, Ivvár, is left to guard their diminishing herd alone.

By chance, he meets Mad Lasse's daughter Willa, and their blossoming infatuation grows into something that ultimately crosses borders—of cultures, of beliefs, and of political divides—as Willa follows the herders on their arduous annual migration north to the sea.

Gorgeously written and sweeping in scope, The End of Drum-Time immerses readers in a world lit by the northern lights, steeped in age-old rituals, and guided by passions that transcend place and time.
short_summary: When a reindeer herder's son meets a minister's daughter in 1851 Scandinavia, their forbidden romance bridges cultures and faiths. Pylväinen crafts an intimate epic that feels both timeless and urgent.
author_bios: Hanna Pylväinen is the author of We Sinners, which received a Whiting Award and a Balcones Fiction Prize. Her work has appeared in Harper's Magazine, the New York Times, the New York Times Magazine, Chicago Tribune, and the Wall Street Journal. She has received fellowships from Princeton University's Lewis Center for the Arts, the American-Scandinavian Foundation, and the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers at the New York Public Library, plus residencies from MacDowell, Yaddo, and the Lásságámmi Foundation. She teaches at Warren Wilson College MFA Program for Writers and lives in Philadelphia.
quotes:
"The End of Drum-Time explores some of the most complex themes in literature in some of the most gorgeous prose imaginable. Hanna Pylväinen's novel of cultural collision in the far north is an extraordinary feat of research and imagination by an author who reminds you with every page what fiction can accomplish."

—Anthony Marra, New York Times bestselling author of A Constellation of Vital Phenomena & Mercury Pictures Present

"The End of Drum-Time is a novel like no other. It is as much a historical epic as it is an intimate love story—as much a vast cultural record as it is a detailed study of a person's soul. It is infinitely rich and rewarding. In these pages, Hanna Pylväinen tells a story of love, faith, reindeer herding, and human failing. She has written a masterpiece."

—Julia Phillips, author of the National Book Award finalist Disappearing Earth

"In prose that is both luxuriant and precise, Hanna Pylväinen vividly transports the reader to the remote Scandinavian tundra of the 1850s, introducing complicated characters who reveal their deepest joys, sorrows, fears, and hopes. This stunning novel manages to explore major themes of identity, race, politics, and faith, all while putting the focus firmly on the human stories at hand. The End of Drum-Time masterfully takes us to a place, people, and time unfamiliar to most readers but one that becomes completely alive—and closely mirrors the most divisive and potent aspects of our contemporary lives."

—The 2023 National Book Award Citation

title: The Bully Pulpit
subtitle: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism
long_summary:
Doris Kearns Goodwin brings to life the turbulent first decade of the Progressive Era, when widening inequality, political stalemate, and corporate power threatened to tear America apart. At the center is the friendship—and later bitter rivalry—between Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft, a relationship that shaped the course of reform and ultimately fractured the Republican Party in 1912.

Goodwin also captures the rise of the muckraking press, led by Ida Tarbell, Lincoln Steffens, Ray Stannard Baker, and William Allen White, whose fearless reporting galvanized the spirit of change. Drawing on letters, diaries, and personal accounts, she delivers both an intimate portrait of two presidents and a sweeping narrative of an America in upheaval, showing how leadership, journalism, and activism converged to bring the nation closer to its founding ideals.
short_summary: The friendship and bitter rivalry between Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft shaped America's Progressive Era. Goodwin masterfully weaves together presidential politics and muckraking journalism in this vivid portrait of reform.
author_bios: Doris Kearns Goodwin is a Pulitzer Prize–winning presidential historian and bestselling author. Her books include Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream; No Ordinary Time, winner of the Pulitzer Prize; Team of Rivals, which earned the Lincoln Prize and inspired Steven Spielberg's film Lincoln; The Bully Pulpit, winner of the Carnegie Medal; Leadership: In Turbulent Times; and An Unfinished Love Story: A Personal History of the 1960s.
quotes:
"If you find the grubby spectacle of today's Washington cause for shame and despair—and really, how could you not?—then I suggest you turn off the TV and board Doris Kearns Goodwin's latest time machine. … [Goodwin puts] political intrigues and moral dilemmas and daily lives into rich and elegant language. Imagine 'The West Wing' scripted by Henry James."

—Bill Keller, The New York Times

"Doris Kearns Goodwin tells this tale with her usual literary skill and deep research. … Goodwin not only sheds light on the birth of the modern political world but chronicles a remarkable friendship between two remarkable men."

—The Wall Street Journal

"Goodwin's evocative examination of the Progressive world is smart and engaging. . . . She presents a highly readable and detailed portrait of an era. The Bully Pulpit brings the early 20th century to life and firmly establishes the crucial importance of the press to Progressive politics."

—The Washington Post

title: Intermezzo
long_summary:
Aside from the fact that they are brothers, Peter and Ivan Koubek seem to have little in common.

Peter is a Dublin lawyer in his thirties—successful, competent, and apparently unassailable. But in the wake of their father's death, he's medicating himself to sleep and struggling to manage his relationships with two very different women: his enduring first love Sylvia, and Naomi, a college student for whom life is one long joke.

Ivan is a twenty-two-year-old competitive chess player who has always seen himself as socially awkward, a loner, the antithesis of his glib elder brother. Now, in the early weeks of his bereavement, Ivan meets Margaret, an older woman emerging from her own turbulent past, and their lives become rapidly and intensely intertwined.

For two grieving brothers and the people they love, this is a new interlude—a period of desire, despair, and possibility; a chance to find out how much one life might hold inside itself without breaking.
short_summary: Two grieving Dublin brothers navigate love and loss in the wake of their father's death. Rooney's latest is her most emotionally expansive yet—tender, wise, and utterly absorbing.
author_bios: Sally Rooney is an Irish novelist and author of Conversations with Friends, Normal People, and Beautiful World, Where Are You. She contributed to the writing and production of the Hulu/BBC television adaptation of Normal People.
quotes:
"Intermezzo, [Rooney's] fourth novel, is her most fully developed and moving yet . . . Intermezzo propels you to its well-earned, moving climax with nary a false move."

—Heller McAlpin, NPR

"What's fascinating about Rooney's more recent attempts is how attuned she is to every social tightrope that constrains what we might have imagined would be free adulthood . . . There's something brilliant and refreshing in Rooney's choice to follow the private love affairs of two siblings once so closely connected . . . It's a pleasure, this time, to get under the skin and into the compassionate private realities of these brothers who misperceive each other as villains."

—Lillian Fishman, The Washington Post

"Wise, resonant and witty . . . There is so much restraint and melancholy profundity in her prose that when she allows the flood gates to open, the parched reader is willing to be swept out to sea . . . Rooney has an exquisite perceptiveness and a zest for keeping us reading . . . Intermezzo wears its heart on its sleeve."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

title: Inferno
subtitle: The World at War, 1939-1945
long_summary:
World War II involved tens of millions of soldiers and cost sixty million lives—an average of twenty-seven thousand a day. For thirty-five years, Max Hastings has researched and written about different aspects of the war. Now, for the first time, he gives us a magnificent, single-volume history of the entire conflict.

Through strikingly detailed stories of everyday people—soldiers, sailors and airmen; British housewives and Indian peasants; SS killers and the citizens of Leningrad, some of whom resorted to cannibalism during the two-year siege; Japanese suicide pilots and American carrier crews—Hastings provides an intimate portrait of the world at war.

He traces major developments like Hitler's refusal to retreat from the Soviet Union until it was too late, Stalin's ruthless use of superior population to wear down the German army, Churchill's leadership during the dark days of 1940-41, and Roosevelt's steady hand before and after America entered the war. But he also illuminates darker, less explored regions: the conflict between the Soviet Union and Finland, where the Finns fiercely resisted Stalin's invading Red Army, and the Bengal famine of 1943-44, when at least one million people died in what Nehru called "the final epitaph of British rule" in India.

Remarkably informed and wide-ranging, Inferno offers a new and essential understanding of one of the greatest and bloodiest events of the twentieth century.
short_summary: Hastings delivers a sweeping yet intimate portrait of World War II, weaving together major political developments with the deeply human stories of ordinary people caught in history's most devastating conflict.
genres: History / Wars & Conflicts / World War II
author_bios: Max Hastings is the author of more than thirty books, including Inferno and The Secret War. Knighted in 2002 and a fellow of the Royal Society of Literature, he served as editor-in-chief of The Daily Telegraph, then editor of the Evening Standard. He lives in West Berkshire, England.
quotes:
"A new, original, necessary history, in many ways the crowning of a life's work. A professional war correspondent who has personally witnessed armed conflict in Vietnam, the Falkland Islands and other danger zones, Hastings has a sober, unromantic and realistic view of battle that puts him into a different category from the armchair generals whose gung-ho, schoolboy attitude to war fills the pages of a great majority of military histories. He writes with grace, fluency and authority…Inferno is superb."

—Richard J. Evans, The New York Times

"If there is a contemporary British historian who is the chronicler of World War II, it would be Max Hastings…[Inferno] is a true distillation of everything this historian has learned from a lifetime of scholarship-and more important, of real thought-on what he calls 'the greatest and most terrible event in human history.'"

—Martin Rubin, San Francisco Chronicle

"A relatively brief review can only begin to indicate the depth, breadth, complexity and pervasive humanity of this extraordinary book. The literature of World War II is, as Hastings notes at the beginning of his bibliography, so vast as almost to defy enumeration or comprehension, but "Inferno" immediately moves to the head of the list. It is in all ways a monumental achievement."

—Jonathan Yardley, The Washington Post

title: The Book of My Lives
long_summary:
Aleksandar Hemon's lives begin in Sarajevo, where childhood means street soccer with neighborhood kids, sibling rivalry, and trips with his engineer-turned-beekeeper father. As a young man, he pokes at the city's pretensions through American music, bad poetry, and slightly better journalism.

Then comes Chicago: watching helplessly as war engulfs Sarajevo, unable to return home. His parents and sister flee with only the family dog, abandoning everything they'd ever known. Hemon starts over, building a new life and family in an unfamiliar city.

Yet this isn't really a memoir. The Book of My Lives defies convention—it's simultaneously a love song to two cities, a heartbreaking tribute to family bonds, and a stirring call to go play soccer (not for exercise). Built on fierce intelligence and devastating experience, it's driven by passion and sharp insight. Like the best narratives, it will leave you fundamentally changed, seeing the world through new eyes.
short_summary: Essays spanning Sarajevo and Chicago explore displacement, family, and identity with devastating wit. Hemon transforms personal upheaval into universal truths about home and belonging.
author_bios: Aleksandar Hemon is the author of The Lazarus Project, a finalist for the 2008 National Book Award and National Book Critics Circle Award, along with three story collections—The Question of Bruno; Nowhere Man, also a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist; and Love and Obstacles—and the novel The Making of Zombie Wars. He wrote two essay volumes, The Book of My Lives and My Parents/This Does Not Belong to You. He has received a MacArthur Fellowship, Guggenheim Fellowship, PEN/W.G. Sebald Award, and 2020 John Dos Passos Prize. He cowrote The Matrix Resurrections and teaches at Princeton University.
quotes:
"Aleksandar Hemon is, quite frankly, the greatest writer of our generation. His literature is deep, agile, funny, graceful, searing, angry, raw, questioning. The Book of My Lives is worth it simply for the dedication: 'For Isabel, forever breathing on my chest.' He writes it, and so she breathes on ours too. Such is the function of storytelling: to get to the essence of that which might eventually break our hearts. This is a book--like all of Aleksandar Hemon's books--that is an aria for our times. I will cherish it."

—Colum McCann

"Aleksandar Hemon's work crackles with so much humor and irony, so much compassion and humanity, that The Book of My Lives's true calling almost goes by unnoticed: it is, without doubt, the most necessary, intimate, and heartbreaking portrait of a world lost to one of history's darkest conflicts."

—Téa Obreht

"I'm not quite sure Aleksandar Hemon counts as an American writer, but he is one of my favorite American writers. Before The Book of My Lives, I never really thought of him as a nonfiction person, but this new book--a memoir in essays--has some of his best writing. When Hemon's work is funny, it can make you laugh in spite of everything, and when it is sad, it's hard to stand up afterward."

—John Jeremiah Sullivan, author of Pulphead

title: The Antidote
long_summary:
The Antidote opens on Black Sunday, as a historic dust storm ravages the fictional town of Uz, Nebraska. But Uz is already collapsing—not just under the weight of the Great Depression and dust bowl drought, but beneath its own violent histories.

Russell weaves together the stories of five unforgettable characters: a "Prairie Witch" whose body serves as a bank vault for people's memories and secrets; a Polish wheat farmer who learns how quickly a hoarded blessing can become a curse; his orphan niece, a basketball star and witch's apprentice in furious flight from her grief; a voluble scarecrow; and a New Deal photographer whose time-traveling camera threatens to reveal both the town's secrets and its fate.

This novel is above all a reckoning with a nation's forgetting—enacting the settler amnesia and willful omissions passed down from generation to generation, and unearthing not only horrors but shimmering possibilities. The Antidote echoes with urgent warnings for our own climate emergency, challenging readers with a vision of what might have been—and what still could be.
short_summary: Five characters' fates intertwine after a devastating dust storm hits Depression-era Nebraska. Russell's latest is a reckoning with American amnesia—part climate warning, part magical excavation of buried histories.
author_bios: Karen Russell is the author of six books of fiction, including the New York Times bestsellers Swamplandia! and Vampires in the Lemon Grove. She is a MacArthur Fellow, a Guggenheim Fellow, and a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. She has received two National Magazine Awards for Fiction, the Shirley Jackson Award, the 2023 Bottari Lattes Grinzane Prize, and the 2024 Mary McCarthy Prize. Born and raised in Miami, Florida, she lives in Portland, Oregon, with her family.
quotes:
"The Antidote is an achingly gorgeous book about dust, memory, basketball, murder, yearning, photography, and the way the land holds both the memory of what went before and the dreams of what may come. Karen Russell is one of our most humane and generous writers; this book is as profound as it is wonderfully strange."

—Lauren Groff, author of The Vaster Wilds

"In The Antidote, Karen Russell writes indelible characters who keep choosing messy community over silo'd righteousness, motion over despair. She presents for inspection America's most persistent chorus of moral self-defense, "Better them than us," and shows how it rots the minds, hearts, and land of all who sing it. Only Karen Russell could write a dust bowl opus with such raucous brio—The Antidote soars with exigent joy and laugh-out-loud scenes, with memory witches and enchanted cameras and the world's most lovable sentient scarecrow. It's magic, a book doing this big work and also making it propulsive, eminently readable. If irony bypasses the difficulty of describing things, then the vivid sincerity on display here marks a virtuosic artist at the height of her lucidity. Russell has rendered with soul and urgency the vast inexpressible ache at the heart of American gratitude."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

"This novel swept me up and carried me away, even while somehow burying me, and digging up something about the story of this country I didn't know I needed to know. As with all of Russell's work, heaviness and levity are always kept in balance, and so I was lifted even while being devastated by the book's many brutal truths and stark beauty. I'd already considered Russell's vivid and inventive imagination to be endless, but here exploring a history of Nebraska we get an unearthing of this country's still relatively untold origin story, the part about its original people, and the cost paid in order that this country might be formed. Finishing the book I felt completely covered in the forgotten dust of what too few look back on, with rare clarity, not to mention the intricate braid of narratives masterfully woven here. The Antidote is one, for an all too poisoned American narrative about land and family and belonging."

—Tommy Orange, author of Wandering Stars

title: Long Island
long_summary:
Eilis Lacey is Irish, married to Tony Fiorello, a plumber and one of four Italian American brothers living in neighboring houses on a Long Island cul-de-sac. It's spring 1976, and Eilis is now forty with two teenage children, surrounded by Tony's extended family. Though her ties to Ireland remain stronger than those binding her to America, she hasn't returned in decades.

One day, while Tony is at work, an Irishman appears at her door asking for Eilis by name. He delivers devastating news: his wife is pregnant with Tony's child, and when the baby is born, he won't raise it but will instead leave it on Eilis's doorstep.

What Eilis chooses to do—and what she refuses to do—in response to this shattering revelation drives Tóibín's riveting and suspenseful novel, exploring the weight of choices and the complexity of loyalty.
short_summary: Eilis Lacey has built a life on Long Island with her Italian American husband and their children. When a stranger arrives with news that threatens to destroy everything, her response will define her future.
author_bios: Colm Tóibín is the author of eleven novels, including Long Island, an Oprah's Book Club Pick; The Magician, winner of the Rathbones Folio Prize; The Master, winner of the Los Angeles Times Book Prize; Brooklyn, winner of the Costa Book Award; and Nora Webster, winner of the Hawthornden Prize. He's also written three story collections and several books of criticism. He is the Irene and Sidney B. Silverman Professor of the Humanities at Columbia University and was named the 2022–2024 Laureate for Irish Fiction by the Arts Council of Ireland. In 2021, he was awarded the David Cohen Prize for Literature.
quotes:
"I was captivated. A wonderful page-turner to start your summer reading."

—Oprah Winfrey

"A brilliant novel. Beautifully crafted… makes for a riveting, wonderful read."

—Elizabeth Strout, The Guardian

"Eilis is an interesting and vivid character because she manages to make her destiny her choice... In her own mind, and in the eyes of sympathetic readers, she is free."

—The New York Times

title: Falling Upwards
subtitle: How We Took to the Air
long_summary:
Richard Holmes follows the pioneer generation of balloon aeronauts—the daring men and women who risked everything to take to the skies. This heart-lifting chronicle explores why they did it, what their contemporaries thought of them, and how their flights revealed our planet's secrets.

Holmes brings to life the early Anglo-French balloon rivalries, the firework flights of the beautiful Sophie Blanchard, and the long-distance voyages of American entrepreneur John Wise and French photographer Felix Nadar. He documents balloons used to observe Civil War battles (including a flight by George Armstrong Custer) and the legendary sixty-seven manned balloons that escaped from Paris during the Prussian siege of 1870-71—the first successful civilian airlift in history.

The book captures James Glaisher's high-altitude exploits seven miles above earth without oxygen, helping establish meteorology as a science, and explores how Mary Shelley, Edgar Allan Poe, and Jules Verne felt flight's imaginative impact. A seamless fusion of history, art, science, and biography, Falling Upwards offers a masterly portrait of human endeavor, recklessness, and vision.
short_summary: The daring pioneers who first took to the skies in balloons come alive in this captivating cultural history. Holmes weaves together science, adventure, and human folly in an irresistible chronicle of flight.
author_bios: Richard Holmes is the author of The Age of Wonder, short-listed for the Samuel Johnson Prize, winner of the Royal Society Prize for Science Books and National Book Critics Circle Award. His other works include Falling Upwards, Shelley: The Pursuit (Somerset Maugham Award winner), Coleridge: Early Visions (Whitbread Book of the Year), and Dr. Johnson & Mr. Savage (James Tait Black Prize winner). He was awarded the OBE in 1992 and lives in England.
quotes:
"An unconventional history of ballooning, this quirky, endearing, and enticing collection melds the spirit of discovery with chemistry, physics, engineering, and the imagination."

—Publishers Weekly

"Gripping…Meticulous history illuminated and animated by personal passion, carried aloft by volant prose."

—Kirkus

"In the same month that Julian Barnes published Levels of Life, with its melancholy meditations on balloon flight, Richard Holmes presents a full-blown, lyrical history of the same subject, investigating the strangeness, detachment and powerful romance of 'falling upwards' into a seemingly alien and uninhabitable element. Holmes lovingly charts a course from the Montgolfier brothers' first hydrogen-fuelled flights in the 1780s to the use of balloons by fugitive East Germans in the 1970s and the latest forays by polar explorer David Hempleman-Adams, a history full of awe and inefficiency…Holmes is a truly masterly storyteller."

—London Evening Standard

title: Rejection
long_summary:
Sharply observant and outrageously funny, Rejection is a provocative plunge into the touchiest problems of modern life. Seven connected stories seamlessly transition between personal crises and the comic tragedies of sex, relationships, identity, and the internet.

In "The Feminist," a young man's passionate allyship turns to furious nihilism as he realizes, over thirty lonely years, that it isn't getting him laid. A young woman's unrequited crush in "Pics" spirals into borderline obsession and systematic destruction of her sense of self. In "Ahegao; or, The Ballad of Sexual Repression," a shy late bloomer's flailing efforts at a first relationship lead to a life-upending mistake.

As characters pop up in each other's dating apps and social media feeds, or meet in dimly lit bars and bedrooms, they reveal how our delusions can warp our desire for connection. These brilliant satires explore the underrated sorrows of rejection with the authority of a modern classic and the manic intensity of a manifesto.
short_summary: Seven wickedly funny, interconnected stories follow characters whose romantic disasters and digital obsessions reveal the brutal comedy of modern rejection. Tulathimutte dissects desire with surgical precision and savage wit.
author_bios: Tony Tulathimutte is the author of Private Citizens and Rejection. His work has appeared in The Paris Review, n+1, The Nation, The New Republic, and The New York Times. The recipient of an O. Henry Award and a Whiting Award, he runs the writing class CRIT in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"Obsessively readable, acerbic, Foster Wallace–inflected."

—Vanity Fair

"Tulathimutte is such an acutely observant writer that I was entranced by his book despite its narrowness and emotional barbarity. One of Tulathimutte's primal topics is online culture and its diseased repercussions, and he writes about these things in the way Anthony Bourdain wrote about restaurants, Hunter S. Thompson wrote about motorcycle gangs and Molly Ivins wrote about water-headed Texas politicians. He's alert, in other words; he's tanked up, bleakly funny and always stropping his knife. . . . Tulathimutte is a big talent and he is clearly just getting started."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Rejection could be the year's feel-bad book, but Tulathimutte's inventiveness, his intellect, his sense of humor, and his precise style make his characters' mortifications a pleasure to read. . . Like [Philip] Roth, Tulathimutte knows desire can be as ludicrous as it is urgent; like Roth, he likes a good dirty joke. . . . [Rejection] deserves many and enthusiastic readers."

—Matthew Keeley, The Boston Globe

title: Strangers in the Land
subtitle: Exclusion, Belonging, and the Epic Story of the Chinese in America
long_summary:
Strangers in the Land tells the story of Chinese immigrants who began arriving in America in the mid-nineteenth century by the tens of thousands, seeking their fortune in what they called Gum Shan—Gold Mountain. Initially welcomed, these newcomers soon faced horrific racial terror as economic downturns created scapegoats and white resentment grew.

What followed was unprecedented: a series of federal laws aimed at excluding Chinese laborers, marking the first time the United States barred people based on race. Michael Luo follows this community from these brutal early years to modern times, revealing how they persisted despite systematic persecution.

Luo chronicles early victims like Gene Tong, a Los Angeles herbalist lynched by a mob, and demagogues like Denis Kearney, whose sandlot speeches fueled anti-Chinese hatred. He also highlights pioneering activists like Wong Chin Foo, who fought for their community's rights. At the book's heart lies a shameful chapter: the brutal expulsion of Chinese residents from towns across the American West, creating the country's first undocumented immigrants.

Drawing on archives nationwide and written with a New Yorker writer's precision, this revelatory history traces a through-line from 1889—when the Supreme Court labeled Chinese Americans "strangers in the land"—to today's twenty-two million Asian Americans, many still fighting the same battles for belonging.
short_summary: Michael Luo chronicles the Chinese American experience from the Gold Rush to today, revealing how a community persevered through exclusion laws, violence, and systematic persecution. Essential history that illuminates ongoing struggles for belonging.
author_bios: Michael Luo is an executive editor at The New Yorker, writing regularly on politics, religion, and Asian American issues. Previously, he spent thirteen years at the New York Times as metro reporter, national correspondent, and investigative reporter and editor. He's a recipient of a George Polk Award and a Livingston Award for Young Journalists.
quotes:
"Strangers in the Land is what history should be--richly detailed, authoritative, and compelling. Luo pieces together the stunning and shocking story of a people's journey to this country, and in the process reveals an essential part of the story of America."

—David Grann, New York Times-bestselling author of The Wager and Killers of the Flower Moon

"An epic of both the best and worst aspects of the American experiment, Strangers in the Land is a work of history that is deeply researched, deftly written, and highly relevant today. In the vivid, often heartbreaking, and ultimately inspiring experiences of Chinese immigrants and Chinese Americans, Luo finds a deeper story about aspiration and belonging that is as universal as it is profound."

—Patrick Radden Keefe, New York Times-bestselling author of Say Nothing

"Tracing echoes of today's debates around immigration and exclusion to the past, Luo's vividly told, carefully researched, and deeply compassionate book is an essential contribution to the continually unfolding story of the Chinese in America."

—Hua Hsu, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Stay True

title: State of Paradise
long_summary:
A ghostwriter returns to her Florida hometown with her husband, seeking refuge in her mother's house as summer heat intensifies. But this isn't the homecoming she expected. Her mercurial sister, living next door, becomes increasingly obsessed with MIND'S EYE, a virtual reality device distributed by tech company ELECTRA during the pandemic's aftermath.

Something sinister lurks beneath the town's surface—ominous cats roam the streets, her mother joins a burgeoning cult, and her own belly button transforms into an increasingly deep cavern. Most disturbing are the missing person posters scattered throughout the neighborhood.

When her sister vanishes during a violent rainstorm and returns days later sprawled on their mother's lawn, speaking of alternate dimensions, the ghostwriter must investigate. Her search reveals uncanny connections between ELECTRA, the famous author she works for, and the nature of reality itself.

Van den Berg crafts a sticky, rain-soaked thriller about storytelling's elusive power. With masterful control and thrilling style, she plunges into the void between reality and fiction, emerging with something far stranger than either.
short_summary: When a ghostwriter returns to her Florida hometown, she discovers her sister obsessed with virtual reality and townspeople mysteriously disappearing. A mind-bending thriller about technology, family secrets, and reality's slippery nature.
author_bios: Laura van den Berg is the author of three story collections, including I Hold a Wolf by the Ears, named one of Time's ten best fiction books of 2020, and the novels Find Me and The Third Hotel, a finalist for the NYPL Young Lions Fiction Award. She's received a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, the Bard Fiction Prize, and a PEN/O. Henry Award. Born and raised in Florida, she splits her time between Boston and Central Florida.
quotes:
"Pitch perfect and exquisitely composed. Laura van den Berg is a gifted and audacious writer and she's written a novel of weight, power and beauty. I couldn't put it down."

—Charles Yu, author of Interior Chinatown

"State of Paradise chronicles strange pandemic days, the rise of mindless electronic escape, and grief's otherworldly whims in a wholly original and epically engaging novel from a master of episodic oddity. I'll follow Laura van den Berg wherever she wants to take me, even Florida."

—Rachel Yoder, author of Nightbitch

"State of Paradise is deeply, thrillingly weird. With missing sisters, sinkholes, cults, and floods, the novel is as surprising and compelling as Florida itself. Laura van den Berg's brilliance is only further confirmed by every book she writes—this newest one will blow your mind."

—Julia Phillips, author of Disappearing Earth & Bear

title: Underland
subtitle: A Deep Time Journey
long_summary:
Hailed as "the great nature writer of this generation" by the Wall Street Journal, Robert Macfarlane embarks on an epic journey into the Earth's hidden realms in this masterpiece exploration of the mythic, literary, and geological underworld.

A sequel to his international bestseller The Old Ways, Underland travels through "deep time"—from the birth of the universe to a post-human future. Macfarlane descends into prehistoric caves in Norway, plunges into the depths of the Greenland ice cap, explores Bronze Age tombs and Parisian catacombs, and investigates fungal networks that allow trees to communicate. He ventures into vast repositories where nuclear waste will lie for 100,000 years.

Along the way, he interweaves stories of explorers, mourners, artists, and dreamers who have descended into the underworld seeking meaning, survival, or revelation. Global in scope and lyrical in style, Underland asks a profound, urgent question: "Are we being good ancestors to the future Earth?" At once ancient and contemporary, this transformative book reveals the hidden world beneath our feet.
short_summary: Macfarlane descends into caves, catacombs, and ice caps on an epic journey through deep time. A lyrical exploration of the underground world that asks whether we're being good ancestors to future Earth.
author_bios: Robert Macfarlane is the internationally bestselling author of Underland, The Old Ways, The Wild Places, and other award-winning books translated into more than thirty languages. His collaborations include The Lost Words and The Lost Spells with Jackie Morris, as well as films and stage works. A recipient of the E. M. Forster and Henry David Thoreau prizes, he is a fellow of Emmanuel College, Cambridge.
quotes:
"Profound in every sense of the word."

—Richard Powers

"An excellent book—fearless and subtle, empathic and strange."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Reading Macfarlane connects us to dazzling new worlds. It's a connection that brings, more than anything else, joy."

—Barbara J. King, NPR

title: In the Dream House
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
In the Dream House is Carmen Maria Machado's engrossing and wildly innovative account of a relationship gone bad—a bold dissection of psychological abuse that explodes what memoir can do.

Tracing the arc of a harrowing relationship with a charismatic but volatile woman, Machado struggles to make sense of how what happened shaped who she was becoming. That struggle drives the book's original structure: each chapter uses a different narrative trope—haunted house, erotica, bildungsroman—to examine events from new angles.

She looks back at her religious adolescence, unpacks the stereotype of lesbian relationships as safe and utopian, and widens the view with essayistic explorations of abuse in queer relationships. Machado casts her critical eye over legal proceedings, fairy tales, Star Trek, and Disney villains, as well as iconic works of film and fiction.

Her dire narrative is leavened with characteristic wit, playfulness, and openness to inquiry. The result is a wrenching, riveting book that reinvents memoir entirely.
short_summary: Each chapter uses a different narrative form to examine an abusive relationship from new angles. Machado's innovative structure transforms personal trauma into groundbreaking memoir that's both devastating and brilliant.
author_bios: Carmen Maria Machado is the author of the bestselling memoir In the Dream House, the graphic novel The Low, Low Woods, and the award-winning short story collection Her Body and Other Parties. She has been a National Book Award finalist and winner of the Bard Fiction Prize, Lambda Literary Awards for both Lesbian Fiction and LGBTQ Nonfiction, Brooklyn Public Library Literature Prize, Shirley Jackson Award, and National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize. The New York Times named Her Body and Other Parties one of "15 remarkable books by women shaping 21st century fiction."
quotes:
"Machado's writing is full of repressed physical energy and the raw juice of annihilating female fury."

—Louise Erdrich, The Millions

"[Machado's] use of a vivid experimental lens to show women struggling for agency is startling."

—The New Yorker

"With Machado, everything feels razed and built anew."

—Star Tribune (Minneapolis)

title: Crook Manifesto
long_summary:
It's 1971. Trash piles up on the streets, crime is at an all-time high, the city is careening towards bankruptcy, and a shooting war has broken out between the NYPD and the Black Liberation Army. Amidst this collective nervous breakdown, furniture store owner and ex-fence Ray Carney tries to keep his head down and his business thriving. His days moving stolen goods are over—until he needs Jackson 5 tickets for his daughter and decides to hit up his old police contact Munson. But Munson has his own favors to ask, and staying out of the game gets a lot more complicated and deadly.

1973. The counter-culture has created a new generation, but there's one constant: Pepper, Carney's endearingly violent partner in crime. When it gets harder to put together reliable crews for heists, Pepper takes on security for a Blaxploitation shoot in Harlem. He finds himself in a freaky world of Hollywood stars, up-and-coming comedians, and celebrity drug dealers—adversaries who underestimate the seasoned crook to their regret.

1976. Harlem is burning block by block while the country gears up for Bicentennial celebrations. When a fire severely injures one of Carney's tenants, he enlists Pepper to investigate. Our crooked duo must battle through a crumbling metropolis run by the shady, violent, and utterly corrupted.

Whitehead's darkly funny tale captures a city under siege while offering a sneakily searching portrait of family and survival.
short_summary: Ray Carney and Pepper navigate 1970s Harlem through three explosive years of crime, corruption, and survival. Whitehead's darkly comic sequel captures a burning city with masterful prose.
author_bios: Colson Whitehead is the #1 New York Times bestselling author of twelve works of fiction and nonfiction, and two-time Pulitzer Prize winner for The Nickel Boys and The Underground Railroad, which also won the National Book Award. A MacArthur and Guggenheim fellow, he lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Remarkable…For all its slapstick fun, this project also contains the same gravitas as August Wilson's seminal 10-play Century Cycle about Black life in Pittsburgh … When Carney is reflecting, attempting to better understand how Black Harlemites and Black Americans have survived before and will survive again, Whitehead is at his best. It makes this story feel important, not just entertaining, not just suspenseful, not just another surefire bestseller from a beloved author. These are crime novels, yes; funny and fast-paced. They are also the first two installments of a grand historical epic. Novel writing at its best. Bigger and better, together, than anything Whitehead has written before."

—The Washington Post

"Whitehead's flair for texture is as sharp as ever…Ray, May, Elizabeth and Pepper in particular are by turns exasperating and aspirational. Life gets thrown at them, and they throw themselves back in return. These are people you crave to catch up with, and in Whitehead's hands, the vast and intangible forces of society, injustice, morality, survival and love are distilled in them."

—NPR

"Dazzling … a glorious and intricate anatomy of the heist, the con and the slow game … [Whitehead] uses the crime novel as a lens to investigate the mechanics of a singular neighborhood at a particular tipping point in time. He has it right: the music, the energy, the painful calculus of loss. Structured into three time periods — 1971, 1973 and finally the year of America's bicentennial celebration, 1976 — "Crook Manifesto" gleefully detonates its satire upon this world while getting to the heart of the place and its people."

—Walter Mosley, The New York Times

title: This Strange Eventful History
long_summary:
Over seven decades, from 1940 to 2010, the pieds-noirs Cassars live in an itinerant state—separated in the chaos of World War II, running from a complicated colonial homeland, and after Algerian independence, without a homeland at all.

This is above all a family story: of patriarch Gaston and his wife Lucienne, whose myth of perfect love sustains them and stifles their children; of François and Denise, devoted siblings connected by their family's strangeness; of François's union with Barbara, a woman so culturally different they can barely comprehend one another; of Chloe, the result of that union, who believes that telling these buried stories will bring them all peace.

Inspired by stories from her own family's history, Claire Messud animates her characters' rich interior lives amid the social and political upheaval of the recent past. As profoundly intimate as it is expansive, This Strange Eventful History captures the weight of displacement and the enduring power of family mythology.
short_summary: Messud traces the pieds-noirs Cassars across seven decades of displacement, from World War II through Algerian independence. A multigenerational saga about family mythology and the search for home.
author_bios: Claire Messud is the author of six works of fiction. A recipient of Guggenheim and Radcliffe Fellowships and the Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, she teaches at Harvard University and lives in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"A tour de force, This Strange Eventful History is one of those rare novels which a reader doesn't merely read but lives through with the characters. Call it the War and Peace of the 20th and 21st century; call it The Long View of a family migrating through many borders, worlds, and eras; call it anything and we fall short. Claire Messud is a magnificent storyteller, and the novel, an all-encompassing history of many human hearts and any human heart, will linger and haunt us as the best and the most heartbreaking memory."

—Yiyun Li, author of the PEN/Faulkner Award-winning The Book of Goose

"[Claire Messud] paints compelling portraits of internal conflicts and tangled relationships, dropping along the way tantalizing references to crucial events that will be clarified later, in a rich narrative that defies summary…[her] gimlet eye and quietly masterful way with words make every character and incident gripping. Brilliant and heart-wrenching; Messud is one of contemporary literature's best."

—Kirkus

"[Messud] draws from her own family history for this exquisite multigenerational saga of the Cassars, a pied-noir clan exiled from Algeria by the country's 1954–62 war of independence…In her characteristically artful prose, Messud burrows inside the hearts and minds of her key players, bringing to their struggles and self-deceptions a deep-veined empathy made even more remarkable by how close she is to the story. This is an astonishment."

—Publishers Weekly

subtitle: Uncovering the New World Columbus Created
long_summary:
More than 200 million years ago, the continents split apart, evolving in isolation until Columbus's arrival in the Americas ended that separation at a stroke. His voyages unleashed the "Columbian Exchange"—a vast transfer of plants, animals, and microbes that transformed diets, landscapes, and lives across the planet. Tomatoes reached Italy, chili peppers reached Asia, earthworms and rats spread everywhere.

Decades later, the Spanish established global trade through Manila, linking American silver, Asian silk, and European markets in the first true world economy. In 1493, Charles C. Mann reveals how this worldwide network fostered Europe's rise, convulsed Africa, weakened China, and for two centuries made Mexico City the hub of global interaction.

Drawing on cutting-edge research, Mann shows how the ecological and economic revolutions set in motion by Columbus still reverberate in today's fiercest debates over immigration, trade, and culture.
short_summary: Following his bestselling 1491, Mann explores the biological collision that reshaped our world. The most momentous ecological event since the dinosaurs—told with startling research and brilliant clarity.
genres: History / Americas (North, Central, South, West Indies)
author_bios: Charles C. Mann writes for The Atlantic, Science, and Wired, and has contributed to Fortune, The New York Times, Smithsonian, Technology Review, Vanity Fair, The Washington Post, HBO, and Law & Order. A three-time National Magazine Award finalist, he has received writing awards from the American Bar Association, American Institute of Physics, Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, and Lannan Foundation.
quotes:
"Revelatory."

—Lev Grossman, Time

"Compelling and eye-opening."

—Publishers Weekly

"In the wake of his groundbreaking book 1491 Charles Mann has once again produced a brilliant and riveting work that will forever change the way we see the world. Mann shows how the ecological collision of Europe and the Americas transformed virtually every aspect of human history. Beautifully written, and packed with startling research, 1493 is a monumental achievement."

—David Grann, author of Killers of the Flower Moon, The Lost City of Z

title: The Woman Upstairs
long_summary:
Nora Eldridge, an elementary school teacher in Cambridge, has long ago compromised her dreams of being a successful artist. She has become the "woman upstairs"—a reliable friend and neighbor always on the fringe of others' achievements.

Then the glamorous Shahid family enters her life: Reza, an enchanting student; his father Skandar, a dashing Lebanese professor on fellowship at Harvard; and his mother Sirena, an effortlessly alluring Italian artist. When Reza is attacked by schoolyard bullies, Nora is drawn deep into their complex world, falling in love with them separately and together.

Nora's happiness explodes her boundaries, and she discovers in herself an unprecedented ferocity—one that puts her beliefs and sense of self at stake. Told with urgency and piercing emotion, this brilliant novel explores the intensity, thrill, and devastating cost of embracing an authentic life.
short_summary: Elementary school teacher Nora Eldridge has settled into life as the reliable woman upstairs until the glamorous Shahid family awakens her buried dreams and desires. What follows is an intoxicating, devastating reckoning with authenticity and artistic ambition.
author_bios: Claire Messud is the author of six works of fiction. A recipient of Guggenheim and Radcliffe Fellowships and the Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, she teaches at Harvard University and lives in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"Almost without knowing it, I was hungry for Nora Eldridge, the hero of Messud's new novel. The title names an archetype: the nice, unmarried lady on the third floor who smiles in the lobby and is quickly forgotten. Nora is a caring schoolteacher seemingly content to look after her ailing father, her dreams of living the life of an artist subsumed by the act of simply living a life. Bitterly funny and self-aware, she claims to be having a 'Lucy Jordan moment,' name-checking the Marianne Faithfull song . . . It seems right that Messud's follow-up to The Emperor's Children grasps furiously at life and punches back at encroaching age. In The Woman Upstairs, she abandons the polyphonic narration of the previous novel for first-person carpe diem prose that is leaner and meaner. . . . Nora [is] exhilarating, a fiery heroine who arrives to serve [both] middle-aged readers, and the young women who will soon see what it's like when the spotlight swings away, urging us to make the most of that time between here and the finish line."

—Katrina Onstad, Toronto Life

"Intimate . . . Messud's cosmopolitan sensibilities infuse her fiction with a refreshing cultural fluidity. . . . The Woman Upstairs opens with extraordinary heat and momentum . . . [and] brims with energy and ideas. . . . A suspenseful psychological thriller . . . Brilliant."

—Jane Ciabattari, NPR

"From its opening lines, Messud's new novel grips like a choke hold. . . .The most unlikely hero, Nora, self-identifies with scornful wit and rage as the titular Woman Upstairs. But oh how Messud, whose last novel was the sharp and brilliant The Emperor's Children, gives her woman room to roar. . . . Sirena awakens in her an unapologetic lust of life that Nora was previously too good or too scared to claim. The narrative burns toward an inevitable betrayal of startling proportions, one that instead of diminishing Nora lights her ablaze. This is a book sweating with rage, and an exhilarating one. Read it in an openmouthed gulp. After the final powerful paragraphs, in which Nora howls in galvanized fury, throw it down and have a drink, or a dreamless nap. Don't be surprised if you then pick it back up and start all over again."

—Karen Valby, Entertainment Weekly

title: Command and Control
subtitle: Nuclear Weapons, the Damascus Accident, and the Illusion of Safety
long_summary:
In Command and Control, acclaimed journalist Eric Schlosser uncovers the hidden history of America's nuclear arsenal—its accidents, near-misses, technological breakthroughs, and moments of extraordinary heroism. At the heart of the book is the dramatic story of a missile silo accident in rural Arkansas, interwoven with a gripping account of how, for more than fifty years, scientists, policymakers, and servicemen have struggled to prevent nuclear catastrophe.

Drawing on declassified documents and first-hand interviews, Schlosser reveals how human error and technological complexity continue to make nuclear weapons both indispensable and terrifyingly uncontrollable. Audacious and unforgettable, Command and Control reads like a thriller even as it lays bare the gravest risk of the nuclear age.
short_summary: Schlosser investigates the history and danger of America's nuclear arsenal, weaving gripping narrative with chilling detail. Reads like a thriller while exposing the terrifying reality of nuclear accidents.
author_bios: Eric Schlosser is a correspondent for The Atlantic. His work has also appeared in Rolling Stone, Vanity Fair, The Nation, and The New Yorker. He has received a National Magazine Award and a Sidney Hillman Foundation Award for reporting.
quotes:
"Schlosser's book reads like a thriller, but it's masterfully even-handed, well researched, and well organised. Either he's a natural genius at integrating massive amounts of complex information, or he worked like a dog to write this book. You wouldn't think the prospect of nuclear apocalypse would make for a reading treat, but in Schlosser's hands it does."

—Jonathan Franzen, The Guardian

"Nail-biting... thrilling... Mixing expert commentary with hair-raising details of a variety of mishaps, [Eric Schlosser] makes the convincing case that our best control systems are no match for human error, bad luck, and ever-increasing technological complexity."

—Publishers Weekly

"Vivid and unsettling... An exhaustive, unnerving examination of the illusory safety of atomic arms."

—Kirkus

title: The Imperfectionists
long_summary:
Set against the gorgeous backdrop of Rome, Tom Rachman's wry debut follows the chaotic private lives of reporters, editors, and executives at an international English-language newspaper as they struggle to keep both it and themselves afloat.

Fifty years have passed since the paper was founded by an enigmatic millionaire. Now, amid stained carpeting and dingy office furniture, the staff's personal dramas overshadow the daily headlines. Kathleen, the imperious editor in chief, nurses wounds from a betrayal in her open marriage. Arthur, the lazy obituary writer, is transformed by personal tragedy. Abby, the embattled financial officer, discovers her job cuts and love life are unexpectedly intertwined.

Out in the field, a veteran Paris freelancer goes to desperate lengths for his next byline, while the new Cairo stringer falls prey to an outrageous war correspondent's manipulations. Lurking in the shadows is the isolated young publisher who lavishes more attention on his basset hound, Schopenhauer, than on his family's quirky newspaper.

As print news yields to the Internet age and this imperfect crew stumbles toward an uncertain future, the paper's rich history unfolds, revealing surprising truths about its founder's original intentions.
short_summary: Behind the scenes at a struggling English-language newspaper in Rome, personal dramas eclipse the headlines. Rachman's interconnected debut captures journalism's twilight with wit, heart, and sharp observation.
author_bios: Tom Rachman is the author of three novels: The Italian Teacher, The Rise & Fall of Great Powers, and the New York Times bestseller The Imperfectionists. His work has been translated into more than twenty-five languages. Born in London and raised in Vancouver, Rachman worked at the Associated Press as a foreign-news editor in Manhattan and Rome before becoming a novelist. His writing has appeared in the New York Times, The Atlantic, the Washington Post, the Wall Street Journal, The New Yorker, and elsewhere. He lives with his family in London.
quotes:
"Marvelous … A rich, thrilling book that is both a love letter to and epitaph for the newspaper world…Mr. Rachman's transition from journalism to fiction writing is nothing short of spectacular. The Imperfectionists is a splendid original, filled with wit and structured so ingeniously that figuring out where the author is headed is half the reader's fun. The other half comes from his sparkling descriptions not only of newspaper office denizens but of the tricks of their trade, presented in language that is smartly satirical yet brimming with affection."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"[A] beguiling first novel…One by one these journalists are trotted through their tragicomic hamster wheels…Rachman [is] always finding new ways to surprise us."

—The Washington Post

"In his zinger of a debut, Rachman deftly applies his experience as foreign correspondent and editor to chart the goings-on at a scrappy English-language newspaper in Rome. Chapters read like exquisite short stories, As the ragtag staff faces down the implications of the paper's tilt into oblivion, there are more than enough sublime moments, unexpected turns and sheer inky wretchedness to warrant putting this on the shelf next to other great newspaper novels."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Dead and Alive
subtitle: Essays
long_summary:
In this eagerly awaited new collection, Zadie Smith brings her signature intelligence and insight to subjects that have captured her attention in recent years.

She takes an exhilaratingly close look at visual artists Toyin Ojih Odutola, Kara Walker, and Celia Paul. She invites us to the movies to see and think about Tár, and to New York to reflect on spontaneous moments that connect us. She walks us down Kilburn High Road in her beloved North-West London and welcomes us to mourn with her the passing of literary giants Joan Didion, Martin Amis, Hilary Mantel, Philip Roth, and Toni Morrison.

She considers changes of government on both sides of the Atlantic and examines the meaning of "the commons" in all our lives. Throughout this thrilling collection, Smith demonstrates her unrivalled ability to think through some of the most urgent preoccupations of our troubled times with both critical precision and deep humanity.
short_summary: Smith's latest essay collection roams from visual art to politics to grief with her trademark intelligence. Whether mourning literary giants or dissecting contemporary culture, she finds profound connections in unexpected places.
author_bios: Zadie Smith is the author of the novels White Teeth, The Autograph Man, On Beauty, NW, Swing Time, and The Fraud; the novella The Embassy of Cambodia; three essay collections, Changing My Mind, Feel Free and Intimations; the short story collection Grand Union; and the play The Wife of Willesden, adapted from Chaucer. She was born in north-west London, where she still lives.
quotes:
"Novelist and critic Smith brings an incisive eye and keen wit to art, music, fiction, politics, and more in this wide-ranging essay collection . . . Smith delivers original insights couched in sly, artful prose . . . Readers will be rewarded by this unforgettable collection."

—Publishers Weekly

"Written between 2016 and 2025, these often compelling essays are divided into five sections: Eyeballing, Considering, Reconsidering, Mourning, and Confessing. That means pieces on visual artists like Kara Walker and films like Tár, a memorial for Wolf Hall author Hilary Mantel, and a new essay about technology that is one of the book's high points . . . Smith leaves room for disagreement and still maintains her high-minded humanistic ideas."

—Vulture

"[Dead and Alive] showcases a writer whose curiosity remains undimmed. [Zadie Smith] effortlessly transitions from art critique–focusing on Toyin Ojih Odutola and Kara Walker–to musings on politics, grief and pop culture, including reflections on the artistic drama Ta´r or Stormzy's Glastonbury performance."

—The Mirror

title: Dearie
subtitle: The Remarkable Life of Julia Child
long_summary:
Bob Spitz delivers the definitive biography of Julia Child, the larger-than-life woman who forever changed how America eats, cooks, and thinks about food.

From her unlikely beginnings as a gawky, directionless young woman who joined a spy agency during World War II, to her transformative years in Paris where she discovered French cuisine, Julia's journey was anything but ordinary. She co-authored Mastering the Art of French Cooking, launched The French Chef at age fifty, and became the first educational TV star, helping shape PBS and inspiring generations of cooks.

Fearless, funny, and endlessly ambitious, Julia Child broke rules and brought joy to the kitchen, while her marriage to Paul Child added a touching love story to her legend. Both intimate and expansive, Dearie captures Julia's indelible influence on food, culture, and America itself.
short_summary: From wartime spy to culinary icon, Julia Child's unlikely journey gets the biography it deserves. Spitz captures both her revolutionary impact on American cooking and the irrepressible joy she brought to every kitchen.
author_bios: Bob Spitz is the award-winning author of the biographies The Beatles and Dearie: The Remarkable Life of Julia Child, both New York Times bestsellers, plus six other nonfiction books and a screenplay. He helped manage Bruce Springsteen and Elton John at crucial career moments and has written hundreds of major profiles ranging from Keith Richards to Jane Fonda.
quotes:
"It's a revelation."

—Lev Grossman, Time Magazine

"Spitz captures another side of [Julia's] complex personality: her fierce diligence in mastering the science as well as the art of cooking through detailed experimentation and her concern to translate the preparation of complex French recipes for readers in America…An engrossing biography of a woman worthy of iconic status."

—Kirkus

"After wiping your drool off the page, you might wonder where Spitz uncovered such narrative gold…Author and subject almost become one, as Spitz channels the spirit of Child in his own words…His detailed research into mid-century American cooking helps us understand why exactly Child was such a big deal"

—Becky Krystal, The Washington Post

title: What Storm, What Thunder
long_summary:
At the end of a sweltering day in Port-au-Prince, a 7.0 magnitude earthquake devastates Haiti's capital. Award-winning author Myriam J. A. Chancy masterfully charts the inner lives of those caught in the disaster's wake.

Richard, a wealthy water-bottling executive harboring the secret of a daughter he's never acknowledged. Anne, that same daughter—an architect designing affordable housing for a global NGO. Leopold, a small-time drug trafficker pining for a beautiful call girl. Sonia and her business partner Dieudonné, shadowed by what they believe is the vodou spirit of death. Didier, an emigrant musician driving taxi in Boston. Sara, a mother haunted by her children's ghosts in an IDP camp, and her husband Olivier, an accountant forced to abandon the wife he loves. Their son Jonas, who haunts them both. And Ma Lou, the old woman selling produce who remembers them all.

Fiercely imagined and deeply haunting, What Storm, What Thunder becomes both a reckoning with heartbreaking trauma and an unforgettable testimony to the tenacity of the human spirit.
short_summary: Ten interwoven voices capture life before, during, and after Haiti's devastating 2010 earthquake. Chancy transforms catastrophe into a profound meditation on resilience, grief, and the unbreakable bonds of community.
author_bios: Myriam J. A. Chancy is the author of Village Weavers (Tin House), a Time Best Book of April 2024 and winner of the 2025 OCM Bocas Prize for Fiction. Her work has earned numerous honors, including the American Book Award, the Guyana Prize for Literature, the Foreword INDIES Gold Prize, and the Isis Duarte Book Prize. What Storm, What Thunder was named a Best Book of 2021 by NPR, Kirkus, Library Journal, the Boston Globe, and the Globe & Mail. A Guggenheim Fellow, she is HBA Chair of the Humanities at Scripps College.
quotes:
"One of the finest examples of someone writing from a place of deep love and deep grief simultaneously—the story itself is wondrous and very, very human."

—Omar El Akkad, CBC

"Extraordinary. . . . lyrical. . . . dazzling. . . . Each of the voices entrances, thanks to Chancy's beautiful prose and rich themes. This is not to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly

"Virtuosic."

—The Globe and Mail

title: Swing Time
long_summary:
Two brown girls from North West London dream of being dancers—but only Tracey has real talent. Her unnamed friend has something else: sharp ideas about rhythm and time, about black bodies and black music, about what makes a person truly free.

Their close but complicated childhood friendship ends abruptly in their twenties, never to be revisited but never forgotten. Tracey makes it to the chorus line yet struggles with adult life, while her friend escapes their old neighborhood entirely, traveling the world as assistant to Aimee, a famous pop star, observing how the one percent live.

When Aimee develops grand philanthropic ambitions, the story shifts from London to West Africa. Here, diaspora tourists search for their roots, young men risk everything for different futures, and women dance with the same twists and shakes as Tracey. Smith weaves together friendship, fame, and global inequality in this ambitious exploration of how the past and present move to the same complex rhythm.
short_summary: Childhood friends from London take divergent paths—one becomes a dancer, the other assists a pop star whose philanthropy leads them to West Africa. Smith weaves friendship and global inequality into a complex, rhythmic narrative.
author_bios: Zadie Smith is the author of the novels White Teeth, The Autograph Man, On Beauty, NW, Swing Time, and The Fraud; the novella The Embassy of Cambodia; three essay collections, Changing My Mind, Feel Free and Intimations; the short story collection Grand Union; and the play The Wife of Willesden, adapted from Chaucer. She was born in north-west London, where she still lives.
quotes:
"This is a story at once intimate and global, as much about childhood friendship as international aid, as fascinated by the fate of an unemployed single mother as it is by the omnipotence of a world-class singer . . . Smith's attention to the grace notes of friendship is as precise as ever . . . Swing Time uses its extraordinary breadth and its syncopated structure to turn the issues of race and class in every direction…We finally have a big social novel nimble enough to keep all its diverse parts moving gracefully toward a vision of what really matters in this life when the music stops."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

"A dance itself, syncopated, unexpected, and vital . . . Swing Time may not parse easily and fits no mold, but it is uncommonly full of life."

—Claire Messud, The New York Times

"A multilayered tour-de-force . . . Smith burnishes her place in the literary firmament with her fifth novel . . . The work is so absorbing that a reader might flip it open randomly and be immediately caught up. Its precision is thrilling even as it grows into a book-length meditation on cultural appropriation, played out on a celebrity-besotted global stage . . . Smith's novels are set in motion by character, complex portraits that are revelatory of race and class."

—Karen Long, Los Angeles Times

title: The Barn
subtitle: The Secret History of a Murder in Mississippi
long_summary:
In The Barn, Wright Thompson uncovers the long-buried truths behind the 1955 torture and murder of fourteen-year-old Emmett Till, one of the most infamous crimes in American history. Though Roy Bryant and J. W. Milam were acquitted and later gave a false confession, Thompson reveals new evidence that the killing took place inside a barn on family land, with at least eight people present.

Drawing on deep research and a personal connection to the Mississippi Delta, he explores the cover-up that began immediately and continues to obscure the full story. This powerful investigation examines property, power, and white supremacy while honoring the small group of people determined to bring the truth to light.

By putting the barn on the map, Thompson insists that America confront its darkest past as a necessary step toward healing its deepest wound.
short_summary: Thompson uncovers shocking new evidence about Emmett Till's murder, revealing how global forces converged on the Mississippi Delta and why the truth remained buried for decades.
genres: History / United States / State & Local / South (AL, AR, FL, GA, KY, LA, MS, NC, SC, TN, VA, WV)
author_bios: Wright Thompson is the bestselling author of Pappyland and The Cost of These Dreams. He lives in Oxford, Mississippi, with his family.
quotes:
"[Thompson's] extraordinary new book The Barn is not only an intimate history of the tragedy, but also a deep meditation on Mississippi and America . . . While sifting through the dirt that buried the facts about Till's death, Thompson credits the work of the historians, journalists and filmmakers who have sought to tell the true tale. But he crafts a wider, deeper narrative. The Barn is serious history and skillful journalism, but with the nuance and wallop of a finely wrought novel . . . The Barn describes not just the poison of silence and lies, but also the dignity of courage and truth."

—The Washington Post

"The Barn is the most brutal, layered and absolutely beautiful book about Mississippi, and really how the world conspired with the best and worst parts of Mississippi, I will ever read. In Mississippi, we talk about athletes who bust their ass, skills be damned. Well, every generation you get a few writers with the engine of a 747 and the skill of a wizard. We see it in Ward, Wright, Faulkner and Trethewey. And that finely crafted motor is on full display in this work by Wright Thompson. The Barn is the new standard in research and book-making. There is one Wright Thompson. And we are so lucky he loves Mississippi. Reporting and reckoning can get no better, or more important, than this. Mississippi, goddamn."

—Kiese Laymon, author of Long Division and Heavy: An American Memoir

"Geography, wrote Ralph Ellison, is fate—an axiom painstakingly proven in the compelling architecture of Wright Thompson's The Barn. Though grounded in a small radius within the landscape of Mississippi, this capacious examination of a terrible history is both expansive and granular, national and personal. Thompson writes with a tone of relentless urgency at once tempered by a deep reflection on what becomes, ultimately, a seemingly unavoidable trajectory, a cataclysmic inevitability—the consequences of material greed and cruel disregard—into which our nation and the people in it were thrust. He writes, too, with a true storyteller's gift for language and image, and the ability to make grand connections across time and space, to see all the forces culminating in one terrible moment, all the lives destroyed or forever marked by what happened that night. Follow them though time, Thompson writes—and we do—into a world not only harrowing but also, we come to see, redeemable when the act of remembering, of looking unflinchingly at the troubled fabric of our nation is itself a kind of accountability, and redemption."

—Natasha Trethewey, author of Memorial Drive: A Daughter's Memoir

title: Another Word for Love
subtitle: A Memoir
long_summary:
We are born, and life breaks us. We spend the rest of our lives trying to put ourselves back together. "To return, to be made whole again. This is another word for love," writes Carvell Wallace.

In Another Word for Love, Wallace excavates layers of his own history, situated in the struggles and beauty of growing up Black and queer in America. What follows could be another narrow story of pain and survival, recounting hurt and centering suffering. But this is not that kind of memoir.

Wallace is an award-winning journalist who has built his career writing unforgettable profiles, bringing provocative and engaged sensitivity to his subjects. Now he turns the focus on himself, examining his own life and what frames it—making sense of seeking refuge from homelessness with a young single mother, living in a ghostly white Pennsylvania town, becoming a partner and parent, raising two teenagers in what feels like a collapsing world.

With courage, vulnerability, and remarkable expansiveness, Another Word for Love makes an irresistible case for life, the fullness of our humanity, and love itself. This extraordinary book is a radical meditation on healing, told through lenses of justice, sex, family, and death.
short_summary: Wallace excavates his own history as a Black queer man in America with the same provocative sensitivity he brings to his acclaimed journalism. A radical meditation on healing that makes an irresistible case for love.
author_bios: Carvell Wallace is a writer and podcaster covering race, arts, culture, film, and music. He has written profiles for GQ, Esquire, Glamour, The New Yorker, and The New York Times.
