Each brings expectations that Amadeo, who often solves his problems with a beer in his hand, doesn't think he can live up to. Valdez Quade conjures characters that linger long after the final page, bringing to life their struggles to parent children they may not be equipped to save.
short_summary: When pregnant fifteen-year-old Angel arrives at her unemployed father's doorstep during Holy Week, five generations of a New Mexican family must navigate love, sacrifice, and redemption together.
author_bios: Kirstin Valdez Quade is the author of Night at the Fiestas, winner of the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize. The recipient of a "5 Under 35" award from the National Book Foundation, she teaches at Princeton University and lives in New Jersey.
quotes:
"Kirstin Valdez Quade writes with exquisite precision about the fragility and resilience of the Padilla family…I loved The Five Wounds, which reminded me that growing pains are not confined to adolescence and that people can be newborn at any age. Even its most excruciating moments are charged with a luminous compassion."

—Karen Russell, author of Orange World and Other Stories & Swamplandia!

"With deep empathy, fierce intelligence, and subtle wit, Kirstin Valdez Quade has crafted an indelible portrait of a family living in precarity. The characters in The Five Wounds are so vivid, their grasping efforts toward love and redemption so finely wrought, and each page full of such immaculate prose, that I read this novel with ever-increasing breathless urgency."

—Phil Klay, author of Redeployment & Missionaries

"You hold in your hands a small, complete universe vibrating with joy and grief, humor and absurdity and delight. All the fabulous mess of humanity is, somehow, in these pages. The Five Wounds is bighearted, tender, wise, and shot through with moments of pure grace."

—C Pam Zhang, author of Land of Milk and Honey & How Much of These Hills Is Gold

title: The New Earth
long_summary:
For fifteen years, the Wilcoxes have been a family in name only. Though never the picture of happiness, they once seemed like a typical white Jewish clan from the Upper West Side. But in the early 2000s, two events ruptured the relationships between them forever.

First, Naomi revealed to her children that her biological father was actually Black. In the aftermath, college-age daughter Bering left home to become a radical peace activist in Palestine's West Bank, where she was killed by an Israeli Army sniper.

Now, in 2018, Winter Wilcox is getting married, and her only demand is that her mother, father, and brother emerge from their self-imposed isolations and gather once more. After decades of neglecting personal and political wounds, each remaining family member must face their fractured history and decide if they can ever reconcile.

Assembling a vast chorus of voices and ideas from across the globe, Row explodes the family saga from within—bringing politics, race, theory, and narrative self-awareness into sharp focus. The New Earth is a commanding investigation of our deep and impossible desire to undo the injustices we have both inflicted and been forced to endure.
short_summary: Fifteen years after tragedy tore them apart, the Wilcox family must reunite for a wedding and confront the personal and political wounds they've spent decades avoiding.
author_bios: Jess Row is the author of the novel Your Face in Mine, the essay collection White Flights: Race, Fiction, and the American Imagination, and two short story collections, The Train to Lo Wu and Nobody Ever Gets Lost. He's received a Guggenheim Fellowship and a Whiting Writers Award; his writing has appeared in The New Yorker, The Atlantic, Granta, and many other publications. He teaches at NYU and lives in New York City and Plainfield, Vermont.
quotes:
"Magnificent…The Wilcoxes suffer as many contemporary crises as the Lamberts of Jonathan Franzen, but they prove both more engaged and more moving. The panorama that comes to life around them feels like a masterpiece for our fractured time."

—Los Angeles Times

"[A] deeply ambitious, genre-defying work, which hops back and forth in time, shifts between various points of view, and incorporates a massive amount of politics and theory on race, Zen Buddhism, climate change, the history of Israel and Palestine, and, among other things, the novel itself as a literary form."

—Kirkus

"A rich, rollicking novel about a dysfunctional Jewish clan from the Upper West Side and the 2003 West Bank tragedy that derailed them. . . Row] gracefully balances multiple registers to craft a reader's delight. . . . Row retains a deep affection for his cast, arguably more than they deserve. He breathes wondrous life into them. Their neuroses — so many neuroses — click into place. Each character's thoughts scamper like mice through mazes, a science experiment gone wrong, and yet the data they yield bolsters a tale that's both experimental and Balzacian, lighthearted and dead serious."

—The Washington Post

title: Hombrecito
long_summary:
Santiago Jose Sanchez delivers a stunning debut that follows one boy's journey between worlds. When his mother takes him and his brother from Colombia to Miami, leaving their absent father behind, she essentially disappears herself once they arrive—working as a waitress despite once being a doctor.

In America, the boy embraces both his queer identity and his new home, though not without profound loss. As he grows, his relationship with his mother becomes beautifully fraught—a love so intense it borders on pain, yet remains the axis around which every decision revolves.

Moving to New York, he drifts between lovers, searching for something to make him whole. When his mother invites him back to Colombia, he returns as a young man seeking peace with his father, his homeland, and who he's become. Finally, we come to know her secrets, her complex ambivalence, and her fierce love.

Hombrecito—"little man"—is a moving portrait of identity caught between cultures. Told with startling beauty and intensity, this is a story for anyone searching for home and a way to love.
short_summary: A Colombian boy and his mother navigate exile, identity, and the fierce complexity of their bond. Sanchez crafts a luminous debut about queerness, immigration, and finding home between worlds.
author_bios: Santiago Jose Sanchez is a queer Colombian American writer born in Ibagué, Colombia. Their stories appear in McSweeney's Quarterly, ZYZZYVA, Subtropics, and Joyland. A graduate of the Iowa Writers' Workshop and Yale University, Sanchez teaches at Grinnell College and lives between Iowa, Miami, and New York City. Hombrecito is their debut novel.
quotes:
"Dynamic, electrifying, and oh so tender, Hombrecito is the rare kind of page-turner I devoured in two sittings. Utterly American and Colombian, this is a magnificent story for anyone on a mission to redefine home, loss, and love in all its complicated forms and sources."

—Xochitl Gonzalez, author of Anita de Monte Laughs Last & Olga Dies Dreaming

"Captures with rare vividness the rapture and terror of childhood, the way self-making and self-destruction can grow so tangled as to be indistinguishable. This is a novel of enormous insight, musicality, and love. Sanchez is a stunning new talent."

—Garth Greenwell, author of Cleanness

"Hombrecito soars. A gorgeous, intense, and moving portrait of queerness, migration, desire, and abiding love. Sanchez has made something beautiful."

—Sarah Thankam Mathews, author of All This Could Be Different

title: The History of Sound
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In twelve luminous stories spanning three centuries, The History of Sound examines the unexpected ways the past returns to us and how love and loss transform across generations. Ben Shattuck's ingenious collection pairs each story with a companion piece that reveals hidden truths about its predecessor—mysteries and murders surface, history refracts, and deep emotional connections weave through characters and families.

The haunting title story follows two men who meet around a piano in a smoky bar, then spend a summer walking the Maine woods collecting folk songs in the shadow of World War I, forever marked by their odyssey. Decades later, a woman discovers their wax cylinder recordings while cleaning out her new Maine house.

Shattuck's inventive stories transport readers from 1700s Nantucket to contemporary New Hampshire forests. Memories, artifacts, paintings, and journals resurface in surprising ways among evocative beaches, woods, and orchards, revealing secrets, misunderstandings, and enduring love that echo across centuries. Written with breathtaking humanity and humor, this collection is both a love letter to New England and a moving meditation on the abiding search for home.
short_summary: Twelve interconnected stories span three centuries of New England history, where mysteries from one tale find resolution in another. Love, loss, and secrets echo across generations in this luminous exploration of how the past never truly leaves us.
author_bios: Ben Shattuck is the author of Six Walks: In the Footsteps of Henry David Thoreau, a New Yorker Best Book of 2022, Wall Street Journal Best Book of Spring, New York Times Best Book of Summer, New England Indie Bestseller, and Massachusetts Book Award nominee. He's an Iowa Writers' Workshop graduate and winner of the PEN/Robert J. Dau Short Story Prize and a Pushcart Prize. He lives on the Massachusetts coast with his wife and daughter, where he runs America's oldest general store (built in 1793) and directs the Cuttyhunk Island Writers' Residency.
quotes:
"A magnificent collection about love, longing, and New England history. . . . Shattuck shines especially in his depiction of nature. . . . Deeply felt and impeccably researched, these exquisite stories capture the spirit of the Northeast."

—Publishers Weekly

"Exquisitely crafted, deeply imagined, exhilaratingly diverse, The History of Sound places Ben Shattuck firmly among the very finest of our storytellers."

—Geraldine Brooks, New York Times bestselling author of Horse

"In braiding themselves together, The History of Sound's stories generate the most ingenious and pleasing and moving evocation of New England, in all its seasonal and geographic variety. Over time—from 1696 to Radiolab—mysteries posed in one story are off-handedly addressed years later in another, protagonists become someone else's minor character, and fates are meted out as each new narrative throws a crucial contextualizing light upon the other. Ben Shattuck is a devoted magpie: these stories celebrate the earth's music and bounty, and remind us how diminished we are when severed from who and what we loved."

—Jim Shepard, author of The Book of Aron and Like You'd Understand, Anyway

title: Companion Piece
long_summary:
A story is never an answer. A story is always a question.
 
A day spent locked in a room by border officials without any explanation as to why. A riddle that seemingly has no answer: curlew or curfew, you choose. A phone call from a college friend who hasn't been in touch in years.  And all of it is somehow inextricably linked to the life of a young blacksmith hounded from her trade and branded a vagrant nearly 500 years ago.

Award-winning author Ali Smith shines a guiding light through the nightmarish now with a provocative novel that intertwines our atomized present and the uncannily parallel era of the Black Plague. In the hope that our medieval past may unlock the answers we seek to understand our hazy future, Companion Piece is a kaleidoscope of human history and experience, and a stunning addition to Smith's gorgeous canon.
short_summary: A woman receives a cryptic phone call that spirals into reflections on language, art, and connection during lockdown. Smith blends playfulness and poignancy in a novel both timely and timeless.
author_bios: Ali Smith is the author of many works of fiction, including, most recently, Companion Piece, the "Seasonal Quartet," Public library and other stories, and How to be both, which won the Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction, the Goldsmiths Prize, and the Costa Novel Award. Her work has four times been short-listed for the Man Booker Prize. Most recently, she won the George Orwell Prize for Political Fiction for Summer. Born in Inverness, Scotland, she lives in Cambridge, England.
quotes:
“Superb. . . . Martina was held and questioned while transporting the centuries-old Boothby Lock for the museum where she works. “It’s really beautiful,” Martina tells Sandy. “It’s really cunning too. You could never tell by looking at it that it’s even a lock, or that it has any mechanism at all inside it, never mind find how or where the key goes into it to open it.” Which is, of course, a fine description of this novel, itself a lock, crafted by a smith, that is, by A. Smith, demanding in the engagement it requires, and rewarding of that engagement, as one picks away at the words she has used to build it. . . . [A] remarkable novel.”—Mohsin Hamid, The New York Times

"Intricate . . . Expansive and tantalizing . . . As ever, Smith’s flawless stream-of-conscious narration is at once accessible and transforming, and with it she manages to contain eye-blinking hallucinatory images, such as a shattered clock that reconstitutes itself. This is a captivating Rubik’s cube of fiction.”—Publishers Weekly

“[T]his touching entertainment . . . is Smith's pandemic land, where myth and reality converse, where lockdown might evoke medieval artisanry, and where wordplay is more than playful. The Scottish author’s 12th novel displays once again her ingenuity in pulling together disparate narrative strands . . . With art and humor, Ali is the smith who forges links for her idiosyncratic narrative, one of which is the value of acts of kindness amid distress. A truly marvelous tale of pandemic and puns and endurance.“—Kirkus

title: Flesh
long_summary:
Teenaged István lives with his mother in a quiet apartment complex in Hungary. Shy and new in town, he becomes a stranger to the social rituals of his classmates and finds himself isolated, drawn into a series of events that leave him forever estranged from his peers, his mother, and himself.

In the years that follow, István drifts along carried by the goodwill—or self-interest—of strangers, charting a rocky yet upward trajectory that takes him further from his childhood and its defining tragedies than he could have imagined.

A collection of intimate moments spanning decades, Flesh chronicles a man at odds with himself, estranged by circumstances beyond his control and the roles he's asked to play. Shadowed by past trauma and modern apathy, the tension between István and all that alienates him builds toward sudden tragedy that throws his life into jeopardy once again. Szalay traces the imperceptible but indelible contours of unresolved trauma with incisive insight and startling humanity.
short_summary: István drifts through decades haunted by childhood trauma, estranged from himself and everyone around him. Szalay crafts an existential portrait of modern masculinity with spare prose that resonates long after reading.
author_bios: David Szalay is the author of Flesh, Turbulence, Spring, The Innocent, London and the South-East, and All That Man Is. He's been awarded the Booker Prize, the Gordon Burn Prize, and The Paris Review Plimpton Prize for Fiction. Born in Canada, he grew up in London and now lives in Vienna, Austria.
quotes:
"Astonishing...sometimes when I'm reading, one of the things I'm looking for is, how has this person made the novel new? And for me, this novel [is] new...Extraordinary."

—Zadie Smith, Pulitzer Prize finalist and author of The Fraud

"Spare and detached on the page, lush in resonance beyond it, Szalay's new novel reads a bit like an immigrant bildungsroman flavored with Albert Camus."

—NPR

"In István David Szalay has created a modern existential antihero in the grand tradition of Camus and Dostoevsky. Amid the random accidents and desultory decisions that shape his life, and come to feel like fate, he is at once a cool observer and a towering presence. Taut, spare and perfectly structured, Flesh reads like a gripping thriller which slowly gathers to itself the emotional power of classical tragedy."

—Carys Davies, author of Clear

title: Filthy Animals
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In this collection of linked stories set among young creatives in the American Midwest, Brandon Taylor explores the delicate terrain of modern intimacy. A young man navigates sexually charged encounters with two dancers in an open relationship, weighing vulnerability against loneliness. A young woman battles the cancers consuming both her body and her family relationships.

Menacing tensions among a group of teenagers explode into winter violence, while a tornado of a little girl drives her babysitter to the breaking point. Throughout, couples probe the jagged edges of connection, comfort, and cruelty.

Following his Booker Prize-shortlisted debut Real Life, Taylor trains his precise, unsentimental gaze on the spaces between friends and family, lovers and strangers. Psychologically taut and quietly devastating, Filthy Animals captures the fierce longing for intimacy, the stubborn presence of pain, and the desire for love in a world that often withholds it.
short_summary: Young adults navigate desire, violence, and the brutal mechanics of intimacy in Taylor's psychologically precise follow-up to his Booker-shortlisted debut Real Life.
author_bios: Brandon Taylor is the author of The Late Americans and Real Life, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle John Leonard Prize, and named a New York Times Book Review Editors' Choice. His collection Filthy Animals was awarded The Story Prize and shortlisted for the Dylan Thomas Prize. He lives in New York City.
quotes:
"The characters at the heart of this elegant storm of stories are ablaze with risk and tenderness. Their voices are bright and clear, the contours of their pains and desires sharp and urgent. A profoundly gifted writer."

—Laura Van Den Berg

"A dazzling showcase for Brandon Taylor's formidable talents—his fierce intellect, his emotional and linguistic precision, his dry and unflinching humor. He is a writer of rare daring, his fiction a series of revelations."

—Katie Kitamura

"A writer who meets life with a rare combination of will, wonderment, temperament, and vitality."

—Yiyun Li

title: Minor Black Figures
long_summary:
Wyeth is a Black painter new to New York, trying to navigate Manhattan's competitive art scene while struggling with creative block. The gallery shows feel hollow, the artists pretentious, and despite engaging part-time work as an art restorer, his own painting has stalled.

Everything shifts when he meets Keating, a white former seminarian who left the priesthood. Their connection forces Wyeth to reconsider how he observes the world, sparking difficult questions about Black and white art, the white gaze on the Black body, and the compromises we make in both art and life.

From the Booker finalist behind Real Life and bestselling The Late Americans, Brandon Taylor delivers another nuanced exploration of contemporary life. Set against New York's art world, this is a tender portrait of friendship, creativity, and the complex connections between them.
short_summary: A Black painter new to Manhattan's art world meets a former seminarian, sparking questions about creativity, desire, and compromise. Taylor's nuanced exploration of friendship and artistic identity.
author_bios: Brandon Taylor is the author of The Late Americans and Real Life, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle John Leonard Prize, and named a New York Times Book Review Editors' Choice. His collection Filthy Animals was awarded The Story Prize and shortlisted for the Dylan Thomas Prize. He lives in New York City.
quotes:
"A sharp, resonant novel about a young Black gay painter adrift in New York who spends one life-changing summer grappling with questions of faith, desire, and creative purpose."

—Bustle

"Contemplative and sensuous [with]… the shape of a romance… Taylor is onto something rich and appealing—a story unafraid to foreground love and lust, and that treats emotional ambiguity as a starting point, not as the fuzzy ending common in literary fiction. A piercing, precise, and affecting tale of young love and high art."

—Kirkus

"A brilliant and bold study of racial conflict within art, the white gaze and the Black body, and the messy, traumatic ways people sacrifice for art and life."

—Library Journal

title: God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer
long_summary:
After returning from Iraq, Joseph Thomas struggles to find his place in civilian life. Now a doctoral student and EMS worker, he navigates late-night shifts where he encounters echoes of his past and glimpses of possible futures—including people connected to his estranged father, imprisoned for the statutory rape of Joseph's teenage mother.

Meanwhile, Joseph and his best friend Ray, both veterans, bond over their shared wartime experience while wrestling with the complexities of readjustment. Their friendship becomes a lifeline as they cycle through moments of connection and isolation, desire and heartbreak.

Juggling single fatherhood, academic demands, and endless hospital shifts, Joseph finds himself unexpectedly drawn closer to understanding his father. He tries to articulate his lived experience of sociopolitical realities—as both participant and observer—while pushing back against the assumptions of friends and colleagues. Thomas crafts a powerful examination of everyday Black life, exploring health and sexuality, race and punishment, and the persistent gaps between our desires and our politics.
short_summary: A veteran returns from Iraq to navigate doctoral studies, EMS work, and single fatherhood while reckoning with his imprisoned father's legacy. Thomas delivers a raw, innovative exploration of Black life that merges social realism with startling formal invention.
author_bios: Joseph Earl Thomas is the author of memoir Sink, novel God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer, and story collection Leviathan Beach (Grand Central, 2026). His work appears in The Kenyon Review, Virginia Quarterly Review, and The New York Times Book Review. Sink was longlisted for the PEN/Jean Stein Book Award and shortlisted for the William Saroyan International Prize for Writing. He earned his MFA from University of Notre Dame and PhD from University of Pennsylvania, and teaches at Sarah Lawrence College and The Brooklyn Institute for Social Research.
quotes:
"[M]agnificent...In a remarkable feat of formal invention, Thomas collapses time and space, melding Joey's memories with descriptions of patients in the ER...Thomas scales great heights with this innovative blend of social realism and surrealism."

—Publishers Weekly

"Joseph Earl Thomas is a writer of incredible gifts. The voice here is so distinctive, galloping with intelligence, poetry, honesty, and humor. Bless You Otis Spunkmeyer spun me around, like many of my favorite novels, it reads like direct communication from the soul."

—Justin Torres, author of Blackouts & We Were Animals

"What's thrilling to me about God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer is the faith Joseph Earl Thomas places in his readers. There's a supersaturation here that reminds me of Denis Johnson's vertiginous moral questing, and a topography of mind and place that kept making me think of Teju Cole's poet-doctor of the modern metropolis. Thomas gives us a fully peopled world, not by speaking in grand oracular exposition, but by getting granular—we see the Reebok slides on a romantic rival, the crinkled cookie wrappers out of which grow a friendship. It's such a deftly choreographed dance—intoxicating, propulsive—and the result is utterly mesmerizing: here is a whole cosmos, as vivid and unprecedented as our own."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

title: The Books of Jacob
long_summary:
In mid-eighteenth century Poland, a young Jew of mysterious origins arrives in a village and transforms himself into Jacob Frank—a charismatic figure who will reshape religious and social boundaries across Europe. Experiencing what appear to be divine visions, Frank attracts fervent disciples as he reinvents himself repeatedly, converting first to Islam, then Catholicism, while being simultaneously pilloried as a heretic and revered as the Messiah.

Frank traverses the Habsburg and Ottoman empires with throngs of followers, wreaking havoc on conventional Jewish and Christian order through scandalous rumors of secret rituals and increasingly iconoclastic beliefs. Based on a real historical figure shrouded in mystery and controversy, this story becomes the perfect canvas for Olga Tokarczuk's genius.

Narrated through multiple perspectives—those who worship Frank, those who despise him, the friend who betrays him, and the lone woman who sees his true nature—The Books of Jacob captures a world on the cusp of momentous change, searching for certainty while longing for transcendence. In a nod to Hebrew texts, the novel is uniquely paginated in reverse, from page 955 to page 1.
short_summary: Tokarczuk's Nobel Prize-winning epic follows the rise and fall of Jacob Frank, a real historical figure who blazed across eighteenth-century Europe as a messianic leader, upending religious and social order.
author_bios: Olga Tokarczuk has won the Nobel Prize in Literature and the International Booker Prize, among many other honors. She is the author of more than a dozen works of fiction, two collections of essays, and a children's book; her work has been translated into more than fifty languages.
quotes:
"Sophisticated and ribald and brimming with folk wit. . . The comedy in this novel blends, as it does in life, with genuine tragedy."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Monumental . . . could help the Swedish Academy restore its rather tattered reputation as an arbiter of serious literature. …Tokarczuk is as comfortable rendering the world of the Jewish peasantry as that of the Polish royal court. . . . Incalculably rich in learning and driven by a faith in the numinous properties of knowledge."

—The Wall Street Journal

"It's just as awe-inspiring as the Nobel judges claimed. . . . Miraculously entertaining and consistently fascinating. Despite his best efforts, Frank never mastered alchemy, but Tokarczuk certainly has. . . . Haunting and irresistible."

—The Washington Post

title: We the Animals
long_summary:
Three brothers tear their way through childhood—smashing tomatoes all over each other, building kites from trash, hiding out when their parents do battle, tiptoeing around the house as their mother sleeps off her graveyard shift. Paps and Ma are from Brooklyn—he's Puerto Rican, she's white—and their love is a serious, dangerous thing that makes and unmakes a family many times.

Life in this family is fierce and absorbing, full of chaos and heartbreak and the euphoria of belonging completely to one another. From the intense familial unity felt by a child to the profound alienation he endures as he begins to see the world, this beautiful novel reinvents the coming-of-age story in a way that is sly and punch-in-the-stomach powerful.

Written in magical language with unforgettable images, this is a stunning exploration of the viscerally charged landscape of growing up, how deeply we are formed by our earliest bonds, and how we are ultimately propelled at escape velocity toward our futures.
short_summary: Three mixed-race brothers navigate a childhood of chaos, violence, and fierce love in upstate New York. Torres crafts a coming-of-age story that's both brutal and tender, written in prose that cuts deep.
author_bios: Justin Torres is the author of We the Animals, which won the VCU Cabell First Novelist Award, was translated into fifteen languages, and was adapted into a feature film. He was named one of the National Book Foundation's 5 Under 35, a Wallace Stegner Fellow at Stanford University, a fellow at the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University, and a fellow at the New York Public Library's Cullman Center. His short fiction has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, Granta, Tin House, and The Washington Post. He's an associate professor of English at UCLA and lives in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"We the Animals is a dark jewel of a book. It's heartbreaking. It's beautiful. It resembles no other book I've read. We should all be grateful for Justin Torres, a brilliant, ferocious new voice."

—Michael Cunningham

"A slender but affecting debut novel by Justin Torres...[a] sensitive, carefully wrought autobiographical first novel...The scenes have the jumbled feel of homemade movies spliced together a little haphazardly, echoing the way memory works: moments of fear or excitement sting with bright clarity years later, while the long passages in between dissolve into nothingness. From the patchwork emerges a narrative of emotional maturing and sexual awakening that is in many ways familiar...but is freshened by the ethnicity of the characters and their background, and the blunt economy of Mr. Torres's writing, lit up by sudden flashes of pained insight."

—The New York Times

"In language brilliant, poised and pure, We the Animals tells about family love as it is felt when it is frustrated or betrayed or made to stand in the place of too many other needed things, about how precious it becomes in these extremes, about the terrible sense of loss when it fails under duress, and the joy and dread of realizing that there really is no end to it."

—Marilynne Robinson

title: Family Meal
long_summary:
The ghost of Kai, the love of Cam's life, won't leave him alone. Kai follows Cam from LA back home to Houston, his visits wild, tender, and unpredictable. But Cam has changed, and when he reenters the orbit of his childhood best friend TJ and his family's bakery, neither is sure how to navigate their charged estrangement.

Searching for a way past all the wounds and secrets—a way to be okay together, maybe for the first time—the pair find hope and sustenance from the most unlikely source. From the bestselling, award-winning author of Memorial and Lot, an irresistible, intimate novel about how those who know us longest—even when they hurt us most—can also set the benchmark for love.
short_summary: Haunted by his dead lover and estranged from his best friend, Cam returns to Houston seeking connection. Washington crafts an intimate story about grief, chosen family, and finding nourishment in unexpected places.
author_bios: Bryan Washington is the author of Lot, Memorial, and Family Meal. A National Book Award 5 Under 35 Honoree, he won the Dylan Thomas Prize, the NYPL Young Lions Fiction Award, the Ernest J. Gaines Award, two Lambda Literary Awards, and an O. Henry Prize. He is based in Tokyo.
quotes:
"What makes Washington's writing about family so refreshing and complex is how he shows the ways people attempt to demonstrate the emotions they otherwise have trouble expressing to the ones they hold dear.... Family Meal juggles a lot — Cam and TJ are both dealing with their present situations and with the phantoms of opportunities ignored and hard choices enacted — but Washington lays it all out with the control and artistry of a ballet choreographer. Each story line gives the other strength."

—The New York Times

"[A]n achingly and beautifully etched ensemble of young Americans learning to navigate a more universal and human struggle: grief. …Washington is a generous and gentle writer, with a profound capacity to face the cruelty and pain of contemporary American life while simultaneously offering his characters — and readers – an expansive space for self-forgiveness, hope and nourishment."

—The Washington Post

"Family Meal is filled with love—for the sensual pleasure of life, the places that we call home, the beauty of the people around us. This novel will break your heart twice over, with sadness, sure, but more unexpectedly, with joy. It takes a generous writer to show us the world in this way, and Bryan Washington is one of our best."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

title: Ours
long_summary:
In this ingenious, sweeping novel, Phillip B. Williams introduces us to Saint, a fearsome conjurer who in the 1830s annihilates plantations across Arkansas to rescue enslaved people. She brings those she has freed to a haven of her own creation: a town just north of St. Louis, magically concealed from outsiders, named Ours.

In this miraculous place, Saint's grand experiment takes root—a truly secluded community where her people may flourish. But although Saint does her best to protect the inhabitants of Ours, over time her conjuring and memories begin to betray her, leaving the town vulnerable to intrusions by newcomers with powers of their own.

As cracks in Saint's creation are exposed, some begin to wonder whether the community's safety might be yet another form of bondage. Set over four decades and steeped in Black surrealism, mythology, and spirituality, Ours is a stunning exploration of the possibilities and limitations of love and freedom by a writer of extraordinary vision.
short_summary: Saint, a powerful conjurer, creates a magical sanctuary for formerly enslaved people in 1830s America. But her utopia faces threats that force residents to question whether safety itself can become another kind of prison.
author_bios: Phillip B. Williams is from Chicago and author of two poetry collections: Thief in the Interior, winner of the Kate Tufts Discovery Award and Lambda Literary Award, and Mutiny, finalist for the PEN/Voelcker Award and winner of a 2022 American Book Award. He's received a Whiting Award and fellowships from Harvard's Radcliffe Institute and the National Endowment for the Arts. He teaches in NYU's MFA program and Randolph College's low-residency MFA.
quotes:
"A gorgeously written, evocative saga of Black American survival and transcendence, blending elements of fantasy, mythology, and multigenerational history . . . resonant [and] wildly imaginative . . . As in the magical realist sagas of Latin America or the grand fictions of Russian literature, time itself becomes a morphing, enigmatic character in Williams's novel. . . . What keeps you attentive, and the sweeping narrative anchored, are the rich characterizations and, most of all, the often-startling impact of Williams's poetically illuminated language. A multilayered, enrapturing chronicle of freedom that interrogates the nature of freedom itself."

—Kirkus

"Ambitious and lyrical . . . Williams's accomplished narrative leaves readers with much to ponder."

—Publishers Weekly

"Ours is the epic and lyrical debut novel by poet Phillip B. Williams, featuring unforgettable characters woven together with folklore and humanity's search for freedom."

—B&N

"A beautifully written and ambitious epic about the complexity of freedom. Williams crafts an expansive, original world filled with characters who linger long after the final page."

—Brit Bennett, New York Times–bestselling author of The Vanishing Half

title: The Pelican Child
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
"Night was best, for, as everyone knows, but does not tell, the sobbing of the earth is most audible at night." Joy Williams' sentences are like no other—coiled wit, a sense of confused and ruined landscape, even a slight chortle of hope lurking between words. The scrupulous effort of telling in these eleven stories creates ravishing beauty that belies their dark substance.

We meet lost souls navigating an indifferent world: twin-sister heiresses of a dirty industrial fortune who must commit a violent act in recompense for their family's deeds; a newly grown man still revolving in dreamscapes of boarding-school innocence; the ghost of George Gurdjieff on an obsessive visit to Susan Sontag's Arizona birthplace; the "pelican child" living with the bony, ill-tempered Baba Yaga in a hut on chicken legs.

These characters explore, often at their peril, a caustic world where they struggle against our degradation of climate, each other, and honest human experience. Each brief, haunted triumph of understanding is celebrated by Williams, a writer for our time and all time.
short_summary: Eleven haunting stories from a master of the form. Williams conjures lost souls navigating an indifferent world—from twin heiresses seeking violent recompense to dreamers clinging to childhood innocence.
author_bios: Joy Williams is the author of five novels—including Harrow, a finalist for the PEN/Jean Stein and Los Angeles Times book prizes, and The Quick and the Dead, a Pulitzer Prize finalist—plus four story collections. Her essay collection Ill Nature was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. Her honors include the Rea Award for the Short Story and the Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, which elected her in 2008. She lives in Tucson, Arizona, and Laramie, Wyoming.
quotes:
"The protagonists of these gorgeous stories from Williams grapple with mortality and their hold on reality. . . . Throughout, Williams grabs the reader's attention with striking dialogue and arresting conceits. This collection is a gift from a master of the form."

—Publishers Weekly

"Enigmatic, elegant stories by a writer at the pinnacle of her art. Williams has long worked magic with stories that, on the surface, seem quite quotidian, save that something unspoken—and occasionally sinister—lies beneath. . . . Superb, and yet more evidence that Williams should be next in line for the Nobel Prize in Literature."

—Kirkus

"An American master is back with crystalline stories that map the personal and political minefields of her unmoored characters. Williams blends everyday dramas with surreal imagery, her voice and range inspiring awe."

—Boston Globe

title: Interior Chinatown
long_summary:
Willis Wu doesn't see himself as the protagonist of his own life—he's merely Generic Asian Man. Sometimes he gets to be Background Oriental Making a Weird Face or even Disgraced Son, but always he's relegated to a prop.

Every day, he leaves his tiny room in a Chinatown SRO and enters the Golden Palace restaurant, where Black and White, a procedural cop show, is in perpetual production. He's a bit player here too, but he dreams of being Kung Fu Guy—the most respected role that anyone who looks like him can attain. Or is it?

After stumbling into the spotlight, Willis finds himself launched into a wider world than he's ever known, discovering not only the secret history of Chinatown, but the buried legacy of his own family. Infinitely inventive and deeply personal, Interior Chinatown explores pop culture, assimilation, and immigration with Yu's signature blend of humor and heartbreak.
short_summary: Willis Wu lives as Generic Asian Man in a perpetual cop show production, dreaming of better roles while uncovering his family's buried history. Yu's inventive novel skewers stereotypes with devastating wit and unexpected tenderness.
author_bios: Charles Yu is the author of four books, including Interior Chinatown (winner of the 2020 National Book Award for fiction) and How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe (a New York Times Notable Book). He received the National Book Foundation's 5 Under 35 Award and earned two Writers Guild nominations for HBO's Westworld. His work appears in The New Yorker, The New York Times, and Wired. He established the Betty L. Yu and Jin C. Yu Writing Prizes honoring his parents.
quotes:
"I'm a big fan of Charles Yu's writing because of his wit and inventiveness. These talents are front and center in the brilliant and hilarious Interior Chinatown, which satirizes the racist imagination and brings us deep into the humanity of those who suffer from—and struggle against—dehumanization."

—Viet Thanh Nguyen, Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Sympathizer & The Committed

"Interior Chinatown is wrenching, hilarious, sharp, surreal, and above all, original. This is an extraordinary book by an immensely talented writer."

—Emily St. John Mandel, National Book Award finalist and author of The Glass Hotel

"This is a hilarious book. You'll laugh at the universe Charles Yu creates, kitty-corner to our own and just so off-kilter - and then, without warning, you'll be pulled under by the riptide and everything will suddenly make beautiful, perfect, heartbreaking, unexplainable sense. In Interior Chinatown, Yu builds a world out of clichés and stereotypes, then finds a tiny hole in the back and slowly fills it with life and history and nuance and anguish and joy and desire and grief. There is no writer with a greater talent for taking the flattening indignities of life and exploding them into vibrant, poignant mythology."

—Raphael Bob-Waksberg, creator of BoJack Horseman and author of Someone Who Will Love You in All Your Damaged Glory

title: Land of Milk and Honey
long_summary:
A smog has spread. Food crops are rapidly disappearing. A chef escapes her dying career in a dreary city to take a job at a decadent mountaintop colony seemingly free of the world's troubles.

There, the sky is clear again. Rare ingredients abound. Her enigmatic employer and his visionary daughter have built a lush new life for the global elite, one that reawakens the chef to the pleasures of taste, touch, and her own body.

In this atmosphere of hidden wonders and cool, seductive violence, the chef's boundaries undergo a thrilling erosion. Soon she is pushed to the center of a startling attempt to reshape the world far beyond the plate.

Sensuous and surprising, joyous and bitingly sharp, Land of Milk and Honey lays provocatively bare the ethics of seeking pleasure in a dying world. It's a daringly imaginative exploration of desire and deception, privilege and faith, and the roles we play to survive—above all, a love letter to food, wild delight, and the transformative power of a woman embracing her own appetite.
short_summary: A chef flees her crumbling city for an elite mountaintop colony where rare ingredients flow freely. Zhang crafts a seductive, unsettling tale about pleasure and power in a dying world.
author_bios: C Pam Zhang is the author of How Much of These Hills Is Gold, winner of the Academy of Arts and Letters Rosenthal Award and the Asian/Pacific Award for Literature, longlisted for the Booker Prize, a finalist for the PEN/Hemingway Award and the National Book Critics' John Leonard Prize, and one of Barack Obama's favorite books of the year. She is a National Book Foundation 5 Under 35 Honoree and a New York Public Library Cullman Fellow.
quotes:
"A book of appetite, rich with ideas and emotion. Zhang possesses a wonderfully bold and playful imagination; this novel is further proof of her extraordinary talent."

—Katie Kitamura, bestselling author of Intimacies

"It's rare to read anything that feels this unique. A richly imagined, ambitious, and haunting novel that is striking for its deft juxtaposition of small, human moments with larger concerns about the world."

—Gabrielle Zevin, New York Times bestselling author of Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow

"Deeply humane and fiercely political, this book is feast of delights, of appetites denied and realised, surfeit and sacrifice, scarcity and want, passing and vulnerability, luxury and the quotidian, the terrifying, vertiginous workings of the hyper-wealthy, and how we might ground ourselves and continue to exist in a broken world. I adored it."

—Helen Macdonald, New York Times bestselling author of H is for Hawk and Prophet

title: Cursed Daughters
long_summary:
When Ebun gives birth to her daughter, Eniiyi, on the day they bury her cousin Monife, there is no denying the startling resemblance between the child and the dead woman. So begins the belief, fostered by the entire family, that Eniiyi is the actual reincarnation of Monife, fated to follow in her footsteps—including that tragic end.

There is also the matter of the family curse: "No man will call your house his home. And if they try, they will not have peace..." This hex has been handed down from generation to generation, breaking hearts and causing three generations of abandoned Falodun women to live under the same roof.

When Eniiyi falls in love with the handsome boy she saves from drowning, she can no longer run from her family's history. As several women before her have done, she ill-advisedly seeks answers in older, darker spiritual corners of Lagos, demanding solutions. Is she destined to live out the habitual story of love and heartbreak? Or can she break the pattern once and for all—not only avoiding the spiral that led Monife to her lonely death, but liberating herself from all the family secrets and unspoken traumas that have dogged her steps since birth?

Cursed Daughters is a brilliant cocktail of modernity and superstition, vibrant humor and hard-won wisdom, romantic love and familial obligation.
short_summary: Three generations of women live under one roof, haunted by a family curse that dooms their romantic relationships. When young Eniiyi falls in love, she must decide whether she's truly the reincarnation of her tragic cousin—or something entirely her own.
author_bios: Oyinkan Braithwaite is the author of My Sister, the Serial Killer. Born in Lagos, Nigeria and raised there and in the UK, she currently lives in London with her family.
quotes:
"A sweeping and sobering take on romantic fatalism . . . Braithwaite's prose is lush and spooky. . . . Our three female protagonists are rich, full characters. We go deep into their worlds as they struggle to reconcile their love for their family and culture with their desire to be free of the curse. It's fascinating to watch them bob and weave."

—The New York Times

"Infused with Nigerian culture and magical realism, the novel showcases Braithwaite's rich characterizations, atmospheric settings and a daring premise. It also offers a multilayered story that makes Cursed Daughters a captivating, immersive read."

—NPR

"I devoured Cursed Daughters and immediately wanted to start all over again. It's a triumph: bold, searing, and utterly original. From the first page, it grips with an electric pulse. Funny and fearless, soaked in secrets, spirit, heartbreak, and love, it's told in a voice as scalding as it is tender. I won't soon forget Eniiyi, Grandma East, Grandma West, Ebun, and Monife—daring and luminous, as lost as she is unforgettable—the one who carved herself deepest into memory. This is a taut, feverish novel that burns itself into you. Impossible to put down."

—Abi Daré, New York Times bestselling author of Girl with the Louding Voice

title: Shrines of Gaiety
long_summary:
London, 1926. The city pulses with a delirious new energy as it shakes off the shadows of the Great War. In Soho's glittering clubs, aristocrats mingle with starlets, diplomats with gangsters, and girls sell dances for a shilling.

Reigning over this intoxicating world is Nellie Coker—ruthless nightclub queen with fierce ambitions for her six children, including her enigmatic eldest son Niven, whose soul was forged in the hell of the Somme. But Nellie's empire attracts dangerous enemies, and threats emerge from every corner of her domain.

Beneath Soho's dazzling surface lurks a dark underbelly where fortunes are made and lost, and souls disappear without a trace. Atkinson captures this vanished world with her signature Dickensian flair—slyly funny, brilliantly observed, and ingeniously plotted. A masterful portrait of an era caught between trauma and transformation.
short_summary: Nellie Coker rules 1926 London's glittering nightclub scene with an iron fist, determined to secure her children's futures. But beneath Soho's jazz-age glamour lies a treacherous world of gangsters and secrets.
author_bios: Kate Atkinson is one of the world's foremost novelists. She won the Whitbread Book of the Year with her debut Behind the Scenes at the Museum. Her critically acclaimed novels include the recent Shrines of Gaiety, and her Second World War trilogy: Life After Life, A God in Ruins (both Costa Novel Award winners), and Transcription. Her bestselling Jackson Brodie crime series became a BBC television series. She was awarded an MBE in 2011 and is a Fellow of The Royal Society of Literature.
quotes:
"If Dickens had lived to write about The Jazz Age, he would have produced a novel much like Kate Atkinson's Shrines of Gaiety. A sprawling and sparkling tale set in London in 1926...A smartly entertaining read that captures the excitement of Roaring 20s London."

—The Washington Post

"Like all of Atkinson's novels, her latest defies easy categorization. It's historical fiction, but there's a sense of knowingness that feels contemporary...The adjective Dickensianfeels too clichéd to be meaningful, but Atkinson does excel at creating a big, bustling universe fully inhabited by vivid characters...Already one of the best writers working, Atkinson just gets better and better."

—Kirkus

"[A] glittering foray into London's post-WWI Soho...Atkinson's incisive prose and byzantine narrative elegantly excavate the deceit, depravity, and destruction of Nellie's world. She also turns this rich historical into a sophisticated cat-and-mouse tale as the various actors try to move in on Nellie's turf. Atkinson is writing at the top of her game."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Beautyland
long_summary:
At the moment Voyager 1 launches into space carrying its famous golden record, a baby of unusual perception is born to a single mother in Philadelphia. Adina Giorno is tiny and jaundiced, but she reaches for warmth and light. As a child, she recognizes that she is different: She possesses knowledge of a faraway planet.

The arrival of a fax machine enables her to contact her extraterrestrial relatives, beings who have sent her to report on the oddities of Earthlings. For years, as she moves through the world and makes a life for herself among humans, she dispatches transmissions on the terrors and surprising joys of their existence.

Then, at a precarious moment, a beloved friend urges Adina to share her messages with the world. Is there a chance she is not alone? Bertino's Beautyland is a novel of startling originality about the fragility and resilience of life on our Earth and in our universe—a remarkable evocation of feeling in exile at home.
short_summary: When Adina Giorno realizes she's been sent to Earth to report on human behavior, she begins transmitting observations to her alien relatives. A wise, tender novel about feeling like a stranger in your own world.
author_bios: Marie-Helene Bertino is the author of Parakeet, 2 A.M. at The Cat's Pajamas, and the story collection Safe as Houses. She was the 2017 Frank O'Connor International Short Story Fellow in Cork, Ireland. She has received the O. Henry Prize, the Pushcart Prize, the Iowa Short Fiction Award, and fellowships from MacDowell, Sewanee, and New York City's Center for Fiction. Her work has been featured twice on NPR's Selected Shorts. She teaches at New York University and Yale University and lives in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"[A] remarkable funny-sad novel . . . Astonishing."

—Alexandra Jacobs, The New York Times

"This book is endlessly surprising on the sentence level, but also as a story, and also in its tenderness. We might all need the unexpected love and perspective of a child alien at this point in human history. Beautyland is beautiful and hilarious and transcendent. It honestly feels like a message from another planet. Marie-Helene Bertino is an otherworldly talent."

—Tommy Orange, author of There, There

"Marie-Helene Bertino's delicious, uncanny vision throughout Beautyland makes everything feel brand-new. The chapters are so propulsive one doesn't even fully notice the way she's subtly deconstructing the world. One page swiftly returns ubiquity to wonder, while the next reminds us that cruelty is a choice, that nothing is inevitable but death. It's impossible for a book to feel this fun and this urgent. Beautyland is a miracle. I'll be rereading it forever."

—Kaveh Akbar, author of Martyr!

title: Long Island Compromise
long_summary:
"Were we gangsters? No. But did we know how to start a fire?"

In 1980, wealthy businessman Carl Fletcher is kidnapped from his driveway, brutalized, and held for ransom. He's returned to his family less than a week later, and the Fletchers resume their prized place in the American dream, comforted that while their money endangered them, it also assured their safety.

But nearly forty years later, nobody has gotten over anything. Carl secretly seeks closure while his wife Ruth protects his emotional health. Their three grown children are struggling: Nathan's chronic fear stalls his law career, Beamer numbs his terror through substances and excess, and Jenny has spent her life proving she's not a product of family pathology—only to embody it.

As they hover at the precipice of survival, they discover the family fortune has dwindled to nothing. They must confront how much their wealth shaped both their successes and failures.

Spanning decades and generations, Long Island Compromise winds through the mainstays of American Jewish life: tradition, ambition, terror of history, evil eyes, inheritance, pyramid schemes, psychics, and the mostly unspoken love that unites a family forever.
short_summary: Forty years after a kidnapping shatters their suburban paradise, the Fletcher family discovers their fortune has vanished—and must reckon with how wealth shaped their trauma, their choices, and their love for each other.
author_bios: Taffy Brodesser-Akner is a staff writer at The New York Times Magazine and author of two novels: Fleishman Is in Trouble, which she adapted into an Emmy-nominated FX limited series, and Long Island Compromise. She lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Is this book as good [as Fleishman is in Trouble]? It's better. Sprawling yet nimble, this is [Brodesser-Akner's] Big American Reform Jewish Novel . . . Brodesser-Akner is empathetic to her characters' pathological inability to know themselves, but she is also merciless when it comes to the idea that acknowledging confusion is not enough."

—The New York Times

"Comprising immersive, tragicomic deep dives into the Fletchers' personal pathologies and inner demons . . . Long Island Compromise is ingeniously plotted, its various storylines building toward several extremely satisfying plot twists . . .The potentially corrosive nature of wealth has rarely been explored with such humanity."

—The Atlantic

"Brodesser-Akner's latest combines the smarts of Sarah Silverman's stand-up, the polymath verisimilitude of Tom Wolfe's novels, and the Jewish soul of Sholem Aleichem's stories. This is a comedic feast."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Your Utopia
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Bora Chung's inimitable blend of horror, absurdity, and dark humor reaches its peak in these tales of loss and discovery, dystopia and idealism, death and immortality. In a thrilling translation by the acclaimed Anton Hur, readers will experience a variety of possible fates for humanity, from total demise via a disease whose only symptom is casual cannibalism to a world in which even dreams can be monitored and used to convict people of crimes.

In "The Center for Immortality Research," a low-level employee runs herself ragged planning a fancy gala for donors only to be blamed for the chaos that ensues in front of mysterious celebrity benefactors hoping to live forever. In "A Song for Sleep," an AI elevator in an apartment complex develops a tender, one-sided love for an elderly resident. "Seed" traverses the final frontier of capitalism's destruction of the planet—but nature always creeps back to life.

If you haven't yet experienced the fruits of Chung's singular imagination, Your Utopia is waiting.
short_summary: Chung's uncanny imagination conjures futures both terrifying and tender—from casual cannibalism to lovelorn AI elevators. These stories glisten at the border between our weird world and all our other possible worlds.
author_bios: Bora Chung is a writer and translator whose works include the National Book Award finalist and International Booker Prize-shortlisted Cursed Bunny. She has an MA in Russian Studies from Yale University and a PhD in Slavic literature from Indiana University. She teaches at Yonsei University and translates modern literary works from Russian and Polish into Korean.
quotes:
"Bora Chung's stories glisten at the border of our weird world, and all our other weird worlds. A truly sublime book."

—Samantha Hunt, bestselling author of The Seas and The Unwritten Book

"Chung builds out her stories with imagination, absurdity and a dry sense of humor, all applied with X-Acto knife precision"

—The New York Times

"Inventive tales... offer an absurd look into a distant future... With a touch of melancholy, Chung explores the psychological and sociological effects that advanced technology may have on humankind, while also encouraging readers to imagine, as she writes in her author's note, 'a better world for both you and me."

—Time

title: The Catch
long_summary:
Twin sisters Clara and Dempsey have always struggled to relate, their bond severed after their mother vanished into the Thames as infants. Adopted into different families—Clara with a successful upper-class couple, Dempsey with a sullen city councilor—they've grown content being estranged.

Until Clara sees a woman on London's streets who looks exactly like their mother. The catch: this version of Serene hasn't aged a day and has enjoyed a childless life—the very life she might have had if the girls had never been born.

Clara, a celebrity author with a penchant for drinking and one-night stands, welcomes the confident, temperamental Serene into her home. But reclusive Dempsey, who does data entry from her apartment, believes this stranger is running an elaborate con. As they clash over this woman who burrows deeper into their lives, the sisters hurtle toward a confrontation that threatens their very existence.

In her riveting fiction debut, Yrsa Daley-Ward conjures a kaleidoscopic exploration of daughterhood and mother-want, examining the sacrifices women make for self-actualization. The result boldly asks: How can it ever be a crime to choose yourself?
short_summary: Twin sisters estranged since childhood encounter a woman who looks exactly like their vanished mother—except she hasn't aged and lived a childless life. A kaleidoscopic debut about daughterhood, sacrifice, and choosing yourself.
author_bios: Yrsa Daley-Ward is a poet, writer, and actress. She is the author of The How, bone, and The Terrible, for which she won the PEN Ackerley Prize. She lives in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"[Daley-Ward] has a knack for getting directly to a story's heat-point, and once there, to distill the emotions within it down to a line or two."

—Hanif Abdurraqib, Atlantic

"Yrsa's work is like holding the truth in your hands. It sweats and breathes before you. A glorious living thing."

—Florence Welch, Florence + the Machine

"Poet Daley-Ward (Bone) makes her fiction debut with an engrossing and off-kilter tale of twin sisters and their mother, a Black woman who left them when they were infants. The dreamy novel is propelled by searching questions about how to be a mother and how to find fulfillment. It's a singular family drama."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Fellowship Point
long_summary:
Celebrated children's book author Agnes Lee is determined to secure her legacy—completing the final volume of her pseudonymous Franklin Square novels and protecting the majestic Maine peninsula known as Fellowship Point. To donate the land to a trust, Agnes must convince shareholders to dissolve a generations-old partnership. One of those shareholders is her best friend, Polly.

Polly Wister has led a different life: that of a well-off married woman devoted to her husband, a philosophy professor with an inflated sense of stature. She strives to create beauty and harmony in her home, friendships, and family. Soon Polly finds her loyalties torn between her best friend's wishes and those of her three sons—but what does Polly want for herself?

Agnes's plans become complicated when enterprising young book editor Maud Silver arrives, determined to convince Agnes to write her memoirs. Agnes's resistance cannot prevent long-buried memories and secrets from surfacing, with far-reaching repercussions for all. Fellowship Point reads like a nineteenth-century epic but feels entirely contemporary in its reflections on aging, writing, stewardship, and responsibility.
short_summary: Eighty years of friendship between two women—one a celebrated author, the other a devoted wife—comes to a crossroads over a pristine Maine peninsula. Dark weaves a sweeping story about loyalty, legacy, and what we owe the places we love.
author_bios: Alice Elliott Dark is the author of the novels Fellowship Point and Think of England, plus two short story collections, In the Gloaming and Naked to the Waist. Her work has appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's, The New York Times, Best American Short Stories, and O. Henry: Prize Stories. Her award-winning story "In the Gloaming" was made into two films and chosen for Best American Stories of the Century. Dark is a past recipient of a National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship and associate professor at Rutgers-Newark in the MFA program.
quotes:
"Into every long and lazy summer, at least one great heavyweight novel must fall. . . . Dark's brisk, generous prose is worth the weight."

—Leah Greenblatt, Entertainment Weekly

"A sweeping story of lifelong best friends...you will surely want to read this book. Elegantly structured, beautifully written, and altogether diverting, with a powerful message about land ownership in America."

—Kirkus

"Enthralling, masterfully written . . . Fellowship Point is a novel rich with social and psychological insights, both earnest and sly, big ideas grounded in individual emotions, a portrait of a tightly knit community made up of artfully drawn, individual souls."

—Kate Christensen, The New York Times

title: If I Survive You
long_summary:
In the 1970s, Topper and Sanya flee political violence in Kingston for Miami, but America proves far from the promised land. Excluded from society as Black immigrants, the family endures Hurricane Andrew and the 2008 recession, living in a house so cursed that even the pet fish launches itself from its tank rather than stay.

Yet even as things fall apart, they remain driven by what younger son Trelawny calls "the exquisite, racking compulsion to survive." These linked stories follow Trelawny as he struggles to carve out a place for himself amid financial disaster, racism, and relentless bad luck. After a fight with his father, he claws his way out of homelessness through a series of odd, often hilarious jobs.

Meanwhile, his brother Delano attempts a disastrous cash grab to get his kids back, and cousin Cukie searches for a father who doesn't want to be found. Pulsing with vibrant lyricism and sly humor, Escoffery's debut unravels what it means to be caught between homes and cultures in a world ruled by capitalism and whiteness.
short_summary: Linked stories follow a Jamaican family navigating racism, financial disaster, and the American dream in Miami. Escoffery writes with devastating humor about survival, belonging, and the spaces between cultures.
author_bios: Jonathan Escoffery is recipient of the 2020 Plimpton Prize for Fiction, a 2020 National Endowment for the Arts Literature Fellowship, and the 2020 ASME Award for Fiction. His work has appeared in The Paris Review, American Short Fiction, Prairie Schooner, AGNI, and Electric Literature, and been anthologized in The Best American Magazine Writing. He's a fellow in USC's PhD in Creative Writing and Literature Program and received a 2021 Wallace Stegner Fellowship from Stanford University. Raised in Miami, If I Survive You is his first book.
quotes:
"It's truly a feat that a book of short stories tackling such big stuff—family, love, violence, race—could be so damn funny. A welcome reminder of what fiction can do."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

"If I Survive You is a collection of brilliant wit, real heart, and electric humor. Jonathan Escoffery masterfully mines from his life and emerges, in this debut, as a talent not to be ignored."

—Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah, author of Chain Gang All Stars & Friday Black

"These are superb stories about identity, family, and place. There is a beautiful economy in the telling that never sacrifices the depth, complexity, and richness of the worlds these characters inhabit. Jonathan Escoffery's is a strong, much-needed new voice in our literature."

—Percival Everett, author of James & The Trees

title: Ripe
long_summary:
A year into her dream job at a cutthroat Silicon Valley start-up, Cassie finds herself trapped in a corporate nightmare. Between the long hours, toxic bosses, and unethical projects, she struggles to reconcile the glittering promise of a city where obscene wealth lives alongside abject poverty. Ivy League grads complain about snack selections while unhoused people bathe in the bay below their conference room windows.

Though isolated, Cassie is never alone. From her earliest memory, a miniature black hole has been her constant companion. It feeds on her depression and anxiety, growing or shrinking with her distress. The black hole watches, but it also waits, its relentless pull drawing Cassie ever closer as the world around her unravels.

When she ends up unexpectedly pregnant just as her CEO's demands cross into illegal territory, Cassie must decide whether Silicon Valley's tempting fruits are really worth it. Sharp but vulnerable, unsettling yet darkly comic, Ripe offers a brilliantly incisive look at one millennial woman's journey through our late-capitalist hellscape.
short_summary: When corporate life becomes unbearable, Cassie's lifelong companion—a literal black hole that feeds on her anxiety—grows stronger. A surreal, darkly comic reckoning with Silicon Valley's promises and perils.
author_bios: Sarah Rose Etter is the author of the chapbook Tongue Party and The Book of X, winner of a Shirley Jackson Award for best novel. Her work has appeared in Time, Guernica, BOMB, the Bennington Review, The Cut, VICE, and elsewhere. She has been awarded residencies at the Jack Kerouac House, the Disquiet International program in Portugal, and the Gullkistan in Iceland. She lives in Los Angeles.
quotes:
"It's impossible to not feel pulled into Sarah Rose Etter's Ripe, a beautifully paced 2023 novel featuring an intimate inner voice and a surreal, sinister plot. . . . At times darkly funny, this is a razor-sharp and honest portrayal of late-stage capitalism in the tech sphere."

—The Huffington Post

"An explosive narrative of a woman coming undone as the world burns. . . . A deliciously bitter irony pervades. . . . A scathing look at corporate greed and its many dire consequences, this is deeply felt and cathartic."

—Publishers Weekly

"Sarah Rose Etter is a wonder, and this novel is a knife to the heart."

—Carmen Maria Machado, author of Her Body and Other Parties

title: Great Black Hope
long_summary:
An arrest for cocaine possession on the last day of a sweltering New York summer leaves Smith, a queer Black Stanford graduate, in turmoil. Pulled into the court system and mandated treatment, he finds himself in an absurd but dangerous situation: his class protects him, but his race does not.

It's just weeks after the death of his beloved roommate Elle, the daughter of a famous soul singer, and he's still reeling from the tabloid spectacle—as well as lingering questions around how well he really knew his closest friend. He flees to his hometown of Atlanta, only to buckle under the weight of expectations from his family of doctors and lawyers. But when Smith returns to New York, it's not long before he begins to lose himself to his old life—drawn back into the city's underworld, where his search for answers may cost him his freedom and his future.

Smith's dizzying journey takes him through nightlife circuits, anonymous recovery rooms, Atlanta's Black society set, police investigations and courtroom dramas. Great Black Hope is a propulsive story about existing between worlds, being upwardly mobile yet spiraling downward, and finding a way back to hope.
short_summary: Smith's arrest for cocaine possession sends him spiraling between worlds—his Stanford pedigree and dangerous reality, his dead roommate's secrets and his own unraveling. Franklin's debut burns with intelligence and raw honesty.
author_bios: Born and raised in Atlanta, Rob Franklin is a writer of fiction and poetry, and cofounder of Art for Black Lives. A Kimbilio Fiction Fellow and finalist for the New England Review Emerging Writer Award, he has published work in New England Review, Prairie Schooner, and The Rumpus. Franklin lives in Brooklyn, teaches writing at the School of Visual Arts, and Great Black Hope is his first novel.
quotes:
"A beautifully expansive novel about race and class…Franklin's emotional and intellectual range is vast…. An exceptional debut."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Audition and Intimacies

"It's thrilling to see any author today aiming for the big stuff all at once: death, race, sex, class, addiction. It's beyond thrilling—incandescent, even—when a writer like Rob Franklin comes along with the formal virtuosity to carry those lofty conceptual ambitions. Franklin's prose is eminently readable, frequently laugh-out-loud funny, and full of sentences I want to cut out and glue to my forehead. This book is so smart, so moving, so earned; as soon as I finished, I started reading it again."

—Kaveh Akbar, New York Times bestselling author of Martyr!

"Great Black Hope is at once a novel of crime—with a gripping pace, propelled by a question that needs answering—and a timeless coming of age story."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Entitlement

title: Everyone Knows Your Mother Is a Witch
long_summary:
The year is 1618 in the German duchy of Württemberg. Plague spreads through the land, the Thirty Years' War has begun, and fear permeates the Holy Roman Empire. In the small town of Leonberg, Katharina Kepler faces a terrifying accusation: witchcraft.

Katharina is an illiterate widow known for her herbal remedies and her successful children—including her eldest son Johannes, the Imperial Mathematician and renowned author of the laws of planetary motion. Her prominence breeds jealousy, and Katharina's tendency to involve herself in everyone's business hasn't helped her cause. When the deranged Ursula Reinbold accuses Katharina of offering her a bitter, witchy drink that made her ill, Katharina's life hangs in the balance.

Her scientist son must abandon his study of celestial music to defend his mother. Facing financial ruin, torture, and possible execution, Katharina tells her story to Simon, her reclusive widower neighbor who harbors secrets of his own.

Drawing on real historical documents, Galchen infuses this tale with her signature intellectual fire, sly humor, and imaginative intensity. This story of collective aggression and hysterical fear resonates powerfully today, illuminating how superstition and state power can destroy both society and family.
short_summary: When Katharina Kepler—mother of the famous astronomer—is accused of witchcraft in 17th-century Germany, her survival depends on wit and resilience. Galchen transforms real historical events into a darkly comic masterpiece about fear, community, and the dangerous power of rumors.
author_bios: Rivka Galchen has received a William Saroyan International Prize for Fiction and a Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award. A regular contributor to The New Yorker, she was selected for their 20 Under 40 list in 2010. Her debut novel Atmospheric Disturbances and story collection American Innovations were both New York Times Best Books of the Year. She holds an MD from the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and lives in New York City.
quotes:
"Captivating . . . . Mesmerizing details abound . . . Galchen portrays her characters as complicated and full of wit . . . This is a resounding delight."

—Publishers Weekly

"I cannot think of a more singular writer than Rivka Galchen. Here, she brings her forensic intelligence and wit to a historical novel that sheds bright light on our present. Everyone Knows Your Mother is a Witch is fiercely original, a mordant and ultimately devastating portrait of loss and terror from one of the most brilliant writers at work today."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies & A Separation

"The comedy that runs through [Everyone Knows Your Mother Is a Witch] is a magical brew of absurdity and brutality. Galchen has a Kafkaesque sense of the way the exercise of authority inflates egos and twists logic . . . There's real sorcery here, but it arises only from the way Galchen fuses ancient and modern consciousness."

—Ron Charles, The Washington Post

title: Anita de Monte Laughs Last
long_summary:
1985. Anita de Monte, a rising star in the art world, is found dead in New York City. Her tragic death becomes the talk of the town—until it isn't. By 1998, Anita's name has been all but forgotten.

Raquel, a third-year art history student, feels like an outsider on College Hill. Surrounded by privileged students whose futures are already paved, she knows the pressure of working twice as hard for the same opportunities. Students of color like her are the minority, and it shows.

When Raquel becomes romantically involved with a well-connected older art student, she finds herself unexpectedly rising through the social ranks. As she attempts to straddle both worlds, she stumbles upon Anita's forgotten story—raising uncomfortable questions about the dynamics of her own relationship, which eerily mirrors that of the lost artist.

Moving between past and present through both women's perspectives, this is a propulsive examination of power, love, and art that dares to ask who gets to be remembered and who gets left behind in the rarefied world of the elite.
short_summary: Two women, decades apart, navigate the treacherous waters of art world elites and dangerous relationships. Gonzalez weaves a sharp, propulsive story about who gets remembered and who gets erased.
author_bios: Xochitl Gonzalez is the New York Times bestselling author of Anita de Monte Laughs Last, a Reese's Book Club Pick longlisted for the Aspen Words Literary Prize, and the award-winning Olga Dies Dreaming, named a Best of 2022 by The New York Times, TIME, Kirkus, the Washington Post, and NPR. Gonzalez is a staff writer for the Atlantic and was recognized as a 2023 Pulitzer Prize finalist in Commentary. A native Brooklynite and proud public school graduate, she holds a BA from Brown University and an MFA from the Iowa Writers' Workshop.
quotes:
"Gonzalez crafts excoriating and whip-smart commentary on the art world's Eurocentric conceptions of beauty and the racism faced by first-generation students of color. This is incandescent."

—Publishers Weekly

"Funny, piercing, and full of moxie, Anita de Monte Laughs Last is unsparing in its assessment of what goes on behind the castle walls, the price people pay to be accepted into those hallowed halls, and what it takes to liberate oneself from the dangers that lurk within. Really, what Xochitl Gonzalez has written is an affirmation for anyone who's ever had to 'work twice as hard to get half as much.' Anita de Monte Laughs Last is rollicking, melodic, tender, and true. And oh so very wise."

—Robert Jones, Jr., author of The Prophets, a finalist for the National Book Award for Fiction

"An uncompromising message, delivered via a gripping story with two engaging heroines."

—Kirkus

title: Olga Dies Dreaming
long_summary:
It's 2017, and Olga and her brother Pedro "Prieto" Acevedo are boldfaced names in New York. Prieto is a popular congressman representing their gentrifying Latinx neighborhood in Brooklyn, while Olga orchestrates lavish weddings for Manhattan's power brokers.

Despite their alluring public lives, behind closed doors things are far less rosy. Olga can craft perfect love stories for the one percent, but she can't seem to find her own—until she meets Matteo, who forces her to confront long-held family secrets.

Their mother Blanca, a former Young Lord turned radical, abandoned her children to advance a militant political cause, leaving them to be raised by their grandmother. Now, with the winds of hurricane season, Blanca has come barreling back into their lives.

Set against the backdrop of New York City in the months surrounding Hurricane Maria, Gonzalez's debut examines political corruption, familial strife, and the American dream—all while asking what it really means to weather a storm.
short_summary: A blazing debut about a status-driven wedding planner grappling with her social ambitions, absent mother, and Puerto Rican roots in the wake of Hurricane Maria.
author_bios: Xochitl Gonzalez is the New York Times bestselling author of Anita de Monte Laughs Last, a Reese's Book Club Pick longlisted for the Aspen Words Literary Prize, and the award-winning Olga Dies Dreaming, named a Best of 2022 by The New York Times, TIME, Kirkus, the Washington Post, and NPR. Gonzalez is a staff writer for the Atlantic and was recognized as a 2023 Pulitzer Prize finalist in Commentary. A native Brooklynite and proud public school graduate, she holds a BA from Brown University and an MFA from the Iowa Writers' Workshop.
quotes:
"Atmospheric, intelligent, and well informed: an impressive debut."

—Kirkus

"The extraordinary accomplishment of Olga Dies Dreaming is in how a familiar-enough tale—a woman seeking love, happiness, and fulfillment in the big city—slowly reveals itself to be something else altogether. It's a book about a New York that isn't always celebrated, the one that belongs to immigrant communities; about money, class, and political power; about one vividly-imagined family and the very idea of the American Dream."

—Rumaan Alam, author of Leave the World Behind

"[An] edifying debut... Gonzalez elevates this family drama with a great deal of insight on the characters' diaspora and politics."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Isola
long_summary:
Heir to a fortune, Marguerite is destined for a life of prosperity and gentility. Then she is orphaned, and her guardian—an enigmatic and volatile man—spends her inheritance and insists she accompany him on an expedition to New France.

Isolated and afraid, Marguerite befriends her guardian's servant and the two develop an intense attraction. But when their relationship is discovered, they are brutally punished and abandoned on a small island with no hope for rescue.

Once a child of privilege who dressed in gowns and laced pearls in her hair, Marguerite finds herself at the mercy of nature. As the weather turns, blanketing the island in ice, she discovers a faith she'd never before needed.

Inspired by the real life of a sixteenth-century heroine, Isola is the timeless story of a woman fighting for survival.
short_summary: When Marguerite and her lover are abandoned on a remote island, survival becomes her only inheritance. Goodman transforms a sixteenth-century legend into breathtaking historical fiction about courage, faith, and human resilience.
