author_bios: Allegra Goodman is the author of six novels, including the national bestseller Sam, which was a Read with Jenna selection; two short story collections; and a novel for young readers. Her fiction has appeared in The New Yorker and has been anthologized in The O. Henry Awards and Best American Short Stories. She lives with her family in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
quotes:
"Engrossing . . . Goodman brilliantly depicts Marguerite's courage as she fights to survive the bitter Canadian winter. It's a rousing portrait of an undaunted woman."

—Publishers Weekly

"What a gift this novel is: vast, lush, feminist, and brilliantly crafted. Allegra Goodman is one of our finest writers."

—Ann Napolitano, New York Times bestselling author of Hello Beautiful

"Blazing action on each page—Marguerite's shrewd deploying of tactics for her own salvation—reminds readers to place our money on the power of human female ingenuity."

—The Washington Post

title: Florida
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Lauren Groff brings readers into a physical world that is at once domestic and wild—a place where natural hazards lie waiting to pounce, yet the greatest threats remain emotional and psychological. A family retreat can be derailed by a prowling panther, or by a sexual secret.

Among those navigating this treacherous landscape are a resourceful pair of abandoned sisters, a lonely boy grown up, a restless childless couple, a searching homeless woman, and an unforgettable recurring character—a steely and conflicted wife and mother.

These stories span characters, towns, decades, even centuries, but Florida becomes their gravitational center: an energy, a mood, as much as a place of residence. Groff transports readers, then jolts us alert with crackling wit, waves of sadness, and flashes of cruelty as she writes about loneliness, rage, family, and the passage of time. With shocking accuracy, she pinpoints the moments and decisions behind human pleasure and pain, hope and despair—the moments that make us alive.
short_summary: Eleven fierce stories of mothers, storms, snakes, and heat forge a portrait of a state alive with dread and radiance. Groff distills the instability of climate and family into taut, unforgettable fiction.
author_bios: Lauren Groff is a three-time National Book Award finalist and New York Times bestselling author of the novels The Monsters of Templeton, Arcadia, Fates and Furies, Matrix, and The Vaster Wilds, and the short story collections Delicate Edible Birds and Florida. She has won The Story Prize, the ABA Indies' Choice Award, France's Grand Prix de l'Héroïne, and the Joyce Carol Oates Prize. Her work appears regularly in The New Yorker and The Atlantic and has been translated into thirty-six languages. She lives in Gainesville, Florida, where she and her husband own the independent bookstore The Lynx.
quotes:
"Lauren Groff is a great storyteller . . . Florida is restorative fiction for these urgent times. Its final gestures, even the most ominous . . . lean toward love and the promise of good people, in not just this state but the world."

—The New York Times

"She hasn't lost a step since Fates And Furies . . . Groff's language is, as always, gorgeous and precise. Her ability to map the inner contours of characters who seem to exist entirely in extremis — and, almost entirely, within a fragile shell of feigned competence and normalcy — is remarkable. Her Florida is a frightening place that bends (solely through the eyes and experiences of her characters) into a discomfortingly modern Southern Gothic tradition. Her stories — all of them — are haunted."

—NPR

"Groff fans will recognize the descriptive zest instantly. . . raw, danger-riddled, linguistically potent pieces. They unsettle their readers at every pass . . . A literary tour de force of precariousness set in a blistering place, a state shaped like a gun."

—Kirkus

title: To the End of the Land
long_summary:
In To the End of the Land, David Grossman tells the powerful story of Ora, an Israeli mother whose son Ofer has returned to the front lines just as his military service was ending. Terrified of receiving devastating news, she embarks on a hike through the Galilee with Avram, her estranged family friend and former lover.

Avram was once a brilliant artist but was broken by his capture and torture during the Yom Kippur War. As they walk across hills and valleys, Ora brings Ofer to life through stories of her motherhood, weaving the joys and sorrows of family life into the ever-present shadow of conflict.

At once intimate and sweeping, this profound novel captures the anguish of love in wartime, the bonds of family and friendship, and the heavy toll of violence across generations. It stands as one of the great antiwar novels of our time.
short_summary: An Israeli mother, terrified her soldier son will die in combat, embarks on a hiking journey to outrun devastating news. Grossman weaves an unflinching portrait of love and loss in wartime.
author_bios: David Grossman was born in Jerusalem and is the author of acclaimed works of fiction, nonfiction, and children's literature. His books have been translated into more than forty languages, and his writing has appeared in The New Yorker. He has received numerous international awards including the Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres, Israel's EMET Prize, the Albatross Prize, the Erasmus Prize, and the Man Booker International Prize. He lives in Jerusalem.
quotes:
"Very rarely, a few times in a lifetime, you open a book and when you close it again nothing can ever be the same. To the End of the Land is a book of this magnitude. David Grossman may be the most gifted writer I've ever read.... Powerful, shattering, and unflinching. To read it is to have yourself taken apart, undone, touched at the place of your own essence."

—Nicole Krauss

"This is a book of overwhelming power and intensity, David Grossman's masterpiece. Flaubert created his Emma, Tolstoy made his Anna, and now we have Grossman's Ora — as fully alive, as fully embodied, as any character in recent fiction. I devoured this long novel in a feverish trance. Wrenching, beautiful, unforgettable."

—Paul Auster

"There are some writers in whose words one recognizes the texture of life. David Grossman is such a writer. His characters don't so much lie on the page as rise before the reader's eyes, in three dimensions, their skin covered in prose that both stabs with insight and shines with compassion."

—Yann Martel

title: Theft
long_summary:
At the turn of the twenty-first century, three young people come of age in Tanzania. Karim returns to his sleepy hometown after university in Dar es Salaam with new swagger and ambition, catching the eye of Fauzia, who sees in him a chance to escape her smothering upbringing.

When the two offer haven to Badar, a poor boy uncertain if the future holds anything for him at all, they can't imagine how deeply their fates will entwine and diverge. As rapidly accelerating global change reaches their quiet corner of the world—bringing tourists, technology, and unexpected opportunities and perils—each arrives at a different understanding of what it means to take your fate into your own hands.

Gurnah crafts an intimate portrait of friendship, ambition, and the weight of choice in a world transformed by forces beyond any individual's control.
short_summary: Three young Tanzanians navigate friendship, ambition, and global change in this intimate portrait from the Nobel Prize-winning author. Gurnah captures the weight of choice in a transforming world.
genres: Fiction / World Literature / Africa / East Africa
author_bios: Abdulrazak Gurnah is the 2021 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature. He is the author of nine previous novels, including Paradise (shortlisted for the Booker Prize), By the Sea (longlisted for the Booker Prize and a finalist for the Los Angeles Times Book Prize), and Desertion. Born and raised in Zanzibar, he is Professor Emeritus of English and Postcolonial Literatures at the University of Kent and lives in Canterbury, England.
quotes:
"Compassionate, revelatory. . .a kind of argument about the value of true character, about worth calibrated outside the marketplace of money, status and drama. . .[Gurnah's] sentences follow the riverbed of some ancient legend, even as he describes complicated modern lives."

—Washington Post

"Nobel Prize-winning novelist Gurnah delivers a story whose title reverberates throughout. . . No word is wasted. . .A tightly constructed family drama with surprising complications."

—Kirkus Reviews

"Intimate. . .but the way Gurnah writes it, it all comes off as pretty heroic."

—NPR

title: The Other Black Girl
long_summary:
Twenty-six-year-old editorial assistant Nella Rogers is exhausted from being the only Black employee at Wagner Books. Fed up with isolation and constant microaggressions, she's thrilled when Harlem-born Hazel starts working in the cubicle beside hers.

They've barely begun bonding over natural hair care routines when everything shifts. A string of uncomfortable events elevates Hazel to Office Darling, leaving Nella behind. Then the anonymous notes begin appearing on Nella's desk: LEAVE WAGNER. NOW.

It's hard to believe Hazel could be behind these hostile messages. But as Nella spirals and obsesses over the sinister forces at play, she realizes there's much more at stake than her career. What starts as workplace tension evolves into something far more dangerous.

This whip-smart thriller doubles as sly social commentary, perfect for anyone who has felt manipulated, threatened, or overlooked at work.
short_summary: When a second Black woman joins a predominantly white publishing house, workplace dynamics turn sinister. Sharp social commentary wrapped in an addictive thriller about ambition, identity, and survival.
author_bios: Zakiya Dalila Harris received her MFA in creative writing from The New School. Her debut novel, The Other Black Girl, was an instant New York Times bestseller and is now a critically acclaimed Hulu Original Series. Her essays and reviews have appeared in Cosmopolitan, The Guardian, The New York Times, and The Rumpus. She lives in Brooklyn with her husband.
quotes:
"A thrilling, edgier Devil Wears Prada that explores privilege and racism."

—The Washington Post

"Harris' genre-bending evisceration of workplace privilege is set to become the debut of the summer."

—Entertainment Weekly

"Wholly earned brilliance. Harris makes her entrance as an author with singular style. Whatever she does next might seem quieter, but watch for it: It will be brilliant."

—NPR

title: Imagine Me Gone
long_summary:
When Margaret's fiancé John is hospitalized for depression in 1960s London, she faces an impossible choice: marry him despite his mental illness, or walk away from love to avoid future suffering. She chooses love.

Imagine Me Gone follows the decades-long consequences of this act of faith. At the story's heart is their eldest son Michael, a brilliant and anxious music obsessive who navigates the world through wit and parody. His younger siblings—responsible Celia and tightly controlled Alec—join their mother in caring for Michael's increasingly precarious mental state as he inherits his father's devastating depression.

Told through alternating perspectives of all five family members, this searing novel explores the fierce love of a mother for her children, the inescapable devotion between siblings, and how one father's pain echoes through generations. Haslett's emotionally precise prose captures both the humor and heartbreak of a family bound by shared crisis, creating an unforgettable portrait of how far we'll go to save the people we love most.
short_summary: From a Pulitzer finalist, a devastating family saga about inherited depression and unconditional love. Told through five voices across decades, following a brilliant son's mental illness and his family's fierce devotion.
author_bios: Adam Haslett is the author of You Are Not a Stranger Here, Union Atlantic, and Imagine Me Gone. He has twice been a Pulitzer Prize finalist, as well as a National Book Award and National Book Critics Circle Award finalist and Los Angeles Times Book Prize winner. He is the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship, the PEN/Malamud Award, the Berlin Prize, and the Strauss Living Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He directs the MFA Program at Hunter College.
quotes:
"Haslett's latest is a sprawling, ambitious epic about a family bound not only by familial love, but by that sense of impending emergency that hovers around Michael, who has inherited his father John's abiding depression and anxiety....This is a book that tenderly and luminously deals with mental illness and with the life of the mind....In Michael, Haslett has created a most memorable character. This is a hypnotic and haunting novel."

—Publishers Weekly

"An extraordinary blend of precision, beauty, and tenderness . . . Haslett's prose rises to the challenge, lushly capturing the dense fog of depression that blankets John [the father] and occasionally lifts just enough to reveal the 'beast' moving in on him. But Haslett really shows his chops channeling [oldest son] Michael's amped-up voice . . . I got caught up in the beauty of Haslett's sentences and the lives of these oh-so-human people bound by shared duress and cycles of hope. Haslett's signature achievement in Imagine Me Gone is to temper the harrowing with the humorous while keeping a steady bead on the pathos. You want sympathetic characters? You want a narrative that showcases love as a many-splendored thing capacious enough to encompass stalwart, long-suffering spouses, loyal siblings, suffocatingly obsessive crushes, and casual, noncommittal relationships (both gay and straight) that morph as if by magic into soul-sustenance? You want writing that thrums with anguish and compassion? It's all here."

—Heller McAlpin, NPR

"The family Adam Haslett has created in Imagine Me Gone feels as true and as complex as our own actual families are, and lays nearly as deep a claim upon our love and loyalty. The eldest son, Michael, is simply one of the finest characters I've ever come across in fiction. This beautiful, tragic novel will haunt you for the rest of your life and you will be all the more human for it."

—Paul Harding, Pulitzer Prize winner for Tinkers

title: The Great Reclamation
long_summary:
Ah Boon grows up in a fishing village along Singapore's coast during the final years of British rule. A gentle boy with little interest in fishing, he prefers spending time with his neighbor Siok Mei. Everything changes when he discovers his extraordinary gift: the ability to locate magical, movable islands that remain invisible to everyone else. This rare talent gives him new purpose and a way to contribute to his community—and perhaps impress the spirited girl he loves.

As teenagers, Ah Boon and Siok Mei find themselves swept up in history's tragic currents. The Japanese army invades, resistance movements emerge, and their fishing village's very survival hangs in the balance. With Singapore hurtling toward independence and rebirth, the two friends must navigate impossible choices about identity, sacrifice, and belonging.

This aching love story and powerful coming-of-age tale grapples with the complex legacies of colonialism, wartime occupation, and rapid modernization. Heng confronts the painful costs of progress and the heartbreak of defining home when the very land shifts beneath your feet.
short_summary: In colonial Singapore, a boy who can find mystical floating islands navigates first love and wartime upheaval. Heng weaves an aching tale of sacrifice, belonging, and the costs of progress.
author_bios: Born and raised in Singapore, Rachel Heng is the author of Suicide Club, translated into ten languages. Her short fiction has appeared in The New Yorker, Glimmer Train, and McSweeney's. She received her MFA from the Michener Center for Writers and fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts, Sewanee Writers' Conference, and the National Arts Council of Singapore. She is currently an assistant professor of English at Wesleyan University.
quotes:
"Through the story of one remarkable boy, Rachel Heng's breathtaking epic of 20th century Singapore shows us the human and environmental costs of a nation's quest for freedom, prosperity, and order. Told with great tenderness and moral clarity, and alive to the beauty and mystery of the natural world as well as the human heart, The Great Reclamation is timeless, timely, and unforgettable."

—Jessamine Chan, New York Times bestselling author of The School for Good Mothers

"Heng wrings a great deal of emotion from Boon's experiences and relationships. . .skillfully capturing the inner psyche of a Singaporean everyman caught between two immovable worlds. This epic undertaking is not to be missed."

—Publishers Weekly

"[A] story scaffolded against a sweeping backdrop—the politics of colonialism, World War II in Southeast Asia, ecology, the inexorable forces of development and modernization—with very little of that ever mentioned, instead focusing on the experiences of the characters in language of perfect simplicity. . .Like a drop of rain that holds the reflection of the world, crystalline and beautiful."

—Kirkus

title: The Removed
long_summary:
In the fifteen years since their teenage son Ray-Ray was killed in a police shooting, the Echota family has been suspended in private grief. Maria increasingly struggles to manage her husband Ernest's onset of Alzheimer's. Their adult daughter Sonja leads a life of solitude, punctuated only by spells of dizzying romantic obsession. And their son Edgar fled home long ago, turning to drugs to mute his feelings of alienation.

With the family's annual bonfire approaching—marking both the Cherokee National Holiday and Ray-Ray's death—Maria attempts to call the family together from their physical and emotional distances once more. But as the bonfire draws near, each feels a strange blurring between normal life and the spirit world.

Maria and Ernest take in a foster child who seems to miraculously keep Ernest's mental fog at bay. Sonja becomes dangerously fixated on a man named Vin, despite his ties to tragedy in her lifetime and lifetimes before. And after a suicide attempt, Edgar finds himself in the mysterious Darkening Land—a place between the living and the dead, where old atrocities echo.

Drawing deeply on Cherokee folklore, The Removed seamlessly blends the real and spiritual to excavate the deep reverberations of trauma—a meditation on family, grief, home, and the power of stories on both personal and ancestral levels.
short_summary: Fifteen years after their son's death in a police shooting, a Cherokee family grapples with grief and trauma. Hobson weaves folklore into a haunting meditation on loss and healing.
author_bios: Brandon Hobson is an enrolled citizen of the Cherokee Nation tribe of Oklahoma. His novel Where the Dead Sit Talking was a finalist for the 2018 National Book Award for Fiction.
quotes:
"[A] mythic, sweeping novel."

—The New York Times

"Deeply resonant and profound, and not only because of its exquisite lyricism. It's also a hard and visceral entrance into our own reckoning as a society and civic culture with losses we created, injustices we allowed, and family separations we ignored…. The Removed is powerful storytelling."

—NPR

"If we tell ourselves stories to expand our worldview, then modern literature is one of society's most powerful tools.... Rich in Cherokee folklore."

—San Francisco Chronicle

title: Calling for a Blanket Dance
long_summary:
Oscar Hokeah's electric debut follows Ever Geimausaddle, whose family—part Mexican, part Native American—fights to hold onto their community despite obstacles at every turn. When Ever's father is injured by corrupt police during a visit to family in Mexico, his mother struggles to keep her job while caring for her husband. Young Ever feels lost and angry, his sense of safety undermined by a world he doesn't understand.

Ever's relatives all have strong ideas about who he is and who he should become. His Cherokee grandmother urges the family to move across Oklahoma to be near her, understanding the importance of proximity. His grandfather tries to reconnect Ever with his heritage through traditional gourd dances, watching their traditions slip away. Through it all, every relative wants the same thing: to remind Ever of the rich, supportive communities that surround him and teach him to take their strength to save not only himself but the next generation.

How will this young man find his place when the world hasn't made room for him? Honest, heartbreaking, and ultimately uplifting, Calling for a Blanket Dance is the story of how Ever Geimausaddle finds his way home.
short_summary: Ever Geimausaddle navigates family expectations and cultural identity in this powerful debut about finding home. Hokeah writes with unflinching honesty about community, heritage, and the strength we inherit from those who love us.
author_bios: Oscar Hokeah is a citizen of Cherokee Nation and the Kiowa Tribe of Oklahoma from his mother's side and has Mexican heritage through his father. He holds an MA in English with a concentration in Native American Literature from the University of Oklahoma and a BFA in Creative Writing from the Institute of American Indian Arts, with a minor in Indigenous Liberal Studies. He is a recipient of the Truman Capote Scholarship Award and winner of the Native Writer Award through the Taos Summer Writers Conference. His stories have appeared in American Short Fiction, Yellow Medicine Review, and Red Ink Magazine. He works with Indian Child Welfare in Tahlequah.
quotes:
"With intricate prose and unflinching vernacular, Oscar Hokeah chronicles a family and a community. We learn trials and aspirations for each generation, and witness what is woven into complicated arrival. We need these characters and their testimonies. But more than that, we crave –I crave—this kind of honest storytelling. These rhythms. These dances. This beauty. This welcoming to a place where the people speak and are unafraid."

—Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, author of The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois

"Oscar Hokeah is the real deal.  A new voice with ancient music."

—Luis Alberto Urrea, author of The House of Broken Angels

"[A] captivating debut . . . with striking insight into human nature and beautiful prose, this heralds an exciting new voice."

—Publishers Weekly

title: The Rib King
long_summary:
For fifteen years, August Sitwell has worked for the Barclays, a well-to-do white family who plucked him from an orphan asylum and gave him a job as groundskeeper. He's part of the household's all-black staff, along with Miss Mamie, the talented cook; pretty new maid Jennie Williams; and three young kitchen apprentices—the latest orphan boys Mr. Barclay has taken in to "civilize."

But the Barclays' fortunes have fallen, and their money is almost gone. When a prospective business associate proposes selling Miss Mamie's delicious rib sauce to local markets under the brand name "The Rib King"—using a caricature of a wildly grinning August on the label—Mr. Barclay, desperate for cash, agrees. Yet neither Miss Mamie nor August will see a dime.

Humiliated, August grows increasingly distraught, his anger building to a rage that explodes in shocking tragedy. Elegantly written and exhaustively researched, The Rib King is an unsparing examination of America's fascination with black iconography and exploitation, revealing who people actually are—and most importantly, who and what they are not.
short_summary: When a white family's fortune crumbles, they exploit their Black servants' talents for profit, using a degrading caricature without compensation. Hubbard delivers a searing examination of American racism and the dangerous seeds of rage.
author_bios: Ladee Hubbard is the author of The Rib King and The Talented Ribkins, which received the 2018 Ernest J. Gaines Award for Literary Excellence and the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award for Debut Fiction. Her writing has appeared in Guernica, The Times Literary Supplement, Copper Nickel and Callaloo. She's received a Radcliffe Institute Fellowship, Berlin Prize Fellowship, Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award, and fellowships from MacDowell, Art Omi, Hedgebrook, and others. Born in Massachusetts and raised in the U.S. Virgin Islands and Florida, she currently lives in New Orleans.
quotes:
"Ladee Hubbard's sophomore novel, The Rib King, is a fascinating story about the intersection of ambition, race and revenge. . . Hubbard crafts unforgettable characters and masterfully builds suspense."

—The Washington Post

"Hubbard's own superpower is her gift for building extraordinary worlds that examine troubled periods of America's past while shedding light on the unquestionable innovation and determination of African Americans who, perhaps improbably, thrived within them."

—Los Angeles Times

"One will be impressed at all times with Hubbard's control over her historical milieu as well as her complicated, intriguing characterizations. . . . An imaginative work craftily depicting the failure of imagination that is American racism."

—Kirkus

title: My Monticello
long_summary:
Tough-minded, vulnerable, and brave, Jocelyn Nicole Johnson's precisely imagined debut explores burdened inheritances and extraordinary pursuits of belonging.

Set in the near future, the eponymous novella follows a diverse group of Charlottesville neighbors fleeing violent white supremacists. Led by Da'Naisha, a young Black descendant of Thomas Jefferson and Sally Hemings, they seek refuge in Jefferson's historic plantation home in a desperate attempt to outlive the nation's racial and environmental unraveling.

In "Control Negro," a university professor devotes himself to studying racism by clinically observing his own son from birth, hoping to "painstakingly mark the route of this Black child too, one whom I could prove was so strikingly decent and true that America could not find fault in him unless we as a nation had projected it there."

Johnson's characters all seek home as both place and internal state—whether a Nigerian widower adrift in Alexandria, a young mixed-race woman adopting a new identity to escape rural Virginia, or a single mother seeking salvation through "Buying a House Ahead of the Apocalypse."

United by these characters' relentless struggles against reality and fate, My Monticello bears witness to this country's legacies while announcing the arrival of a wildly original voice in American fiction.
short_summary: Characters fighting to survive in an America teetering toward collapse—a woman descended from Jefferson and Hemings fleeing white militia, a professor secretly experimenting on his own son, a mother buying her first home as catastrophe looms.
author_bios: Jocelyn Nicole Johnson's writing has appeared in Guernica, the Guardian, Kweli, Joyland, phoebe, Prime Number Magazine, and elsewhere. Her story "Control Negro" was anthologized in Best American Short Stories 2018 and read live by LeVar Burton on PRI's Selected Shorts. She has been a fellow at Hedgebrook, Tin House Summer Workshops, and VCCA. A veteran public-school art teacher, Johnson lives and writes in Charlottesville, Virginia.
quotes:
"My Monticello is a gorgeous, devastating collection of stories spotlighting the ways a life, a country, and a planet can tend toward disaster but still be worth fighting for. Johnson's stories exquisitely balance the interior and the exterior: the world of inequalities and disappointments stacked against her characters is illuminated by their full and compelling desires, and by her honest exploration of the major and minor cruelties survival requires. This is a stunning debut by a brilliant and original new voice."

—Danielle Evans, author of Before you Suffocate Your Own Fool Self & The Office of Historical Corrections

"There is a special pleasure in discovering a voice that is vital and unlike anything else you've known before. Jocelyn Nicole Johnson is such a voice. One that is necessary and brimming with both heart and imagination, Johnson's My Monticello is a beautiful debut work of art."

—Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah, New York Times bestselling author of Chain Gang All Stars & Friday Black

"My Monticello is a magnificent debut that holds so much in its gaze—great love and great oppression, tremendous individual courage and systemic racism, futures of joyful justice and futures of extremism. This breathtaking, artful book is a gift."

—Megha Majumdar, New York Times bestselling author of A Burning

title: Vladimir
long_summary:
When our narrator—a popular English professor—confesses her childhood fondness for old men, we know we're in for a provocative ride. Her charismatic husband, also a professor at their small liberal arts college, is under investigation for inappropriate relationships with former students.

The couple has long maintained a mutual understanding about their extramarital pursuits, but these new allegations have made life decidedly uncomfortable. When our narrator becomes increasingly infatuated with Vladimir, a celebrated young novelist who's just arrived on campus, their already precarious world threatens to explode.

Julia May Jonas delivers a bold, uncommonly assured debut that ventures into charged territory where moral boundaries collide with human impulses. Propulsive, darkly funny, and wildly entertaining, Vladimir captures the personal and political minefield of our current moment, exposing the nuanced gray areas between power and desire.
short_summary: An English professor's marriage implodes when her husband faces accusations from former students—just as she develops her own dangerous obsession. Darkly funny and provocative.
author_bios: Julia May Jonas is a writer and theater director who has taught at Skidmore College and New York University. She lives in Brooklyn with her family. Vladimir is her debut novel.
quotes:
"Funny, wise and instantly engaging, Vladimir is how I like my thrill rides: brainy and sexy."

—Maria Semple, author of Where'd You Go Bernadette

"Vladimir is a thrilling debut—smart, sharp, and über provocative. I devoured it with fascination and awe."

—Lily King, author of Writers and Lovers & Euphoria

"Delightful…a witty dance with the ghost of Nabokov and a razor-edged commentary on academia at our current fraught moment...by turns, cathartic, devious and terrifically entertaining."

—Jean Hanff Korelitz, The New York Times

title: Greek Lessons
long_summary:
In a classroom in Seoul, a young woman watches her Greek language teacher at the blackboard. She tries to speak but has lost her voice. Her teacher finds himself drawn to the silent woman, for day by day he is losing his sight.

Soon the two discover a deeper pain binds them together. For her, in the space of just a few months, she has lost both her mother and the custody battle for her nine-year-old son. For him, it's the pain of growing up between Korea and Germany, being torn between two cultures and languages, and the fear of losing his independence.

Greek Lessons tells the story of two ordinary people brought together at a moment of private anguish—the fading light of a man losing his vision meeting the silence of a woman who has lost her language. Yet these are the very things that draw them to each other. Slowly the two discover a profound sense of unity, their voices intersecting with startling beauty as they move from darkness to light, from silence to breath and expression.
short_summary: Two wounded souls meet in a Seoul language classroom—she has lost her voice, he is losing his sight. Han Kang crafts an exquisite meditation on connection and healing.
author_bios:
Han Kang was born in 1970 in South Korea. She is the author of The Vegetarian, winner of the International Booker Prize, as well as Human Acts, The White Book, Greek Lessons, and We Do Not Part. In 2024, she was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.

 Deborah Smith was a co-winner of the International Booker Prize for her translation of The Vegetarian. 

Emily Yae Won is a translator based in Seoul.
quotes:
"Sinuous and sublime . . . an extraordinary meditation on language, violence, loss and intimacy. Han Kang is a writer like no other. In a few lines, she seems to traverse the entirety of human experience."

—Katie Kitamura, author of Intimacies

"A love letter to language, learning, and the hope of connection. It is about the mind and the body, our thoughts and our senses—about what it means to be a person in the world."

—Julia Phillips, author of Disappearing Earth

"[Kang] is an astute chronicler of unusual, insubordinate women. . . [Greek Lessons is] for readers drawn to considering language itself as a source of self-revelation . . . a celebration of the ineffable trust to be found in sharing language."

—The New York Times

title: Yellowface
long_summary:
Authors June Hayward and Athena Liu were supposed to be twin rising stars: same year at Yale, same debut year in publishing. But Athena's a cross-genre literary darling, and June didn't even get a paperback release. Nobody wants stories about basic white girls, June thinks.

So when June witnesses Athena's death in a freak accident, she acts on impulse: she steals Athena's just-finished masterpiece, an experimental novel about the unsung contributions of Chinese laborers during World War I.

So what if June edits the novel and sends it to her agent as her own work? So what if she lets her publisher rebrand her as Juniper Song—complete with an ambiguously ethnic author photo? The New York Times bestseller list seems to agree with her logic.

But June can't escape Athena's shadow, and emerging evidence threatens to bring her stolen success crashing down. As she races to protect her secret, she discovers exactly how far she'll go to keep what she thinks she deserves.

With its razor-sharp first-person voice, Yellowface tackles diversity, racism, and cultural appropriation in publishing while exposing the persistent erasure of Asian-American voices by Western white society. Kuang's novel is timely, cutting, and absolutely unputdownable.
short_summary: When her successful friend dies in a freak accident, struggling writer June steals her manuscript and rebrands herself as Juniper Song. A razor-sharp thriller about literary fraud and cultural appropriation.
author_bios: Rebecca F. Kuang is the #1 New York Times and Sunday Times bestselling author of the Poppy War trilogy, Babel: An Arcane History, and Yellowface. Her work has won the Nebula, Locus, Crawford, and British Book Awards. A Marshall Scholar, she has an MPhil in Chinese Studies from Cambridge and an MSc in Contemporary Chinese Studies from Oxford. She is pursuing a PhD in East Asian Languages and Literatures at Yale, studying diaspora, contemporary Sinophone literature, and Asian American literature.
quotes:
"This is a great read. Crime, satire, horror, paranoia, questions of cultural appropriation. Plenty of nasty social media pile-ons, too. But, basically, just a great story. Hard to put down, harder to forget."

—Stephen King

"Viciously satisfying…addictive."

—The New York Times

"Well-executed, gripping, fast-paced novel."

—NPR

title: Babel
subtitle: Or the Necessity of Violence: An Arcane History of the Oxford Translators' Revolution
long_summary:
1828. Robin Swift, orphaned by cholera in Canton, is brought to London by the mysterious Professor Lovell. There, he trains for years in Latin, Ancient Greek, and Chinese, all in preparation for the day he'll enroll in Oxford University's prestigious Royal Institute of Translation—also known as Babel.

Babel is the world's center for translation and, more importantly, magic. Silver working—the art of manifesting the meaning lost in translation using enchanted silver bars—has made the British unparalleled in power, serving the Empire's quest for colonization.

For Robin, Oxford initially appears as a utopia dedicated to the pursuit of knowledge. But knowledge obeys power, and as a Chinese boy raised in Britain, Robin realizes serving Babel means betraying his motherland. As his studies progress, he finds himself caught between Babel and the shadowy Hermes Society, an organization dedicated to stopping imperial expansion.

When Britain pursues an unjust war with China over silver and opium, Robin faces an impossible choice. Can powerful institutions be changed from within, or does revolution always require violence?
short_summary: Dark academia meets anticolonial fantasy in this brilliant exploration of language as power. Robin Swift must choose between Oxford's magical translation institute and his loyalty to China as the British Empire weaponizes words themselves.
author_bios: Rebecca F. Kuang is the #1 New York Times and Sunday Times bestselling author of the Poppy War trilogy, Babel: An Arcane History, and Yellowface. Her work has won the Nebula, Locus, Crawford, and British Book Awards. A Marshall Scholar, she has an MPhil in Chinese Studies from Cambridge and an MSc in Contemporary Chinese Studies from Oxford. She is pursuing a PhD in East Asian Languages and Literatures at Yale, studying diaspora, contemporary Sinophone literature, and Asian American literature.
quotes:
"Babel has earned tremendous praise and deserves all of it. It's Philip Pullman's The Golden Compass by way of N.K. Jemisin's The Fifth Season: inventive and engaging, passionate and precise. Kuang is fiercely disciplined even when she's playful and experimental … Like the silver bars at its heart—like empires and academic institutions both—Babel derives its power from sustaining a contradiction, from trying to hold in your head both love and hatred for the charming thing that sustains itself by devouring you."

—The New York Times

"A fantastical takedown of 19th-century imperialism that's as meaty as its title. R.F. Kuang proved her prowess at blending history and magic with her debut series, The Poppy War, and she's done it once again in this sweeping novel that blends historical fantasy and dark academia…If, as Babel suggests, words contain magic, then Kuang has written something spellbinding."

—Oprah Daily

"It's ambitious and powerful while displaying a deep love of language and literature...Dark academia as it should be."

—Kirkus

title: Lone Women
long_summary:
Adelaide Henry carries an enormous steamer trunk wherever she goes. It's locked at all times—because when it opens, people around Adelaide start to disappear.

The year is 1915, and Adelaide is in serious trouble. Her secret sin killed her parents, forcing her to flee California and make her way to Montana as a homesteader. She'll become one of the "lone women" taking advantage of the government's offer of free land for those brave enough to tame it.

But Adelaide isn't really alone. The terrible secret she's desperately tried to lock away might be the only thing that helps her survive the brutal territory ahead.

Crafted by a modern master of magical suspense, Lone Women blends shimmering prose with an unforgettable cast of adventurers who find both horror and sisterhood in an unforgiving landscape. At its heart lies the gripping story of a woman desperate to bury her past—or finally redeem it.
short_summary: In 1915, Adelaide Henry hauls a locked steamer trunk with a deadly secret to the Montana frontier, seeking redemption as a homesteader. Western gothic horror meets historical fiction.
author_bios: Victor LaValle is the author of seven works of fiction: four novels, two novellas, and a collection of short stories. His novels have appeared on best-of-the-year lists by The New York Times Book Review, Los Angeles Times, The Washington Post, and Publishers Weekly. He's received a Guggenheim Fellowship, an American Book Award, the Shirley Jackson Award, and the Key to Southeast Queens. He teaches at Columbia University and lives in the Bronx.
quotes:
"Enthralling . . . The combination of LaValle's agile prose, the velocity of the narrative and the pleasure of upended expectations makes this book almost impossible to put down . . . Lone Women deftly weaves history, horror, suspense and the perspectives of those rarely recorded in the West."

—The New York Times

"Propulsive [with] a fast-paced plot—though I found myself gripped just as much by Adelaide's defiant, glorious stubbornness and guarded wit. Lone Women combines elements of Western fiction, horror and magical realism, while featuring queer, POC characters inventing lives for themselves in the last years of the American frontier. It's impossible to categorize and impossible to put down."

—NPR

"LaValle gets coy in Lone Women, teasing us by trickling details that gradually reveal Adelaide's intricate connection to the creature. Meanwhile, he adroitly intertwines the eerie fairy tale with early 20th-century historical realism."

—The Washington Post

title: The Book of Goose
long_summary:
Fabienne is dead. Her childhood best friend, Agnès, receives the news in America, far from the French countryside where the two girls were raised—the place that Fabienne helped Agnès escape ten years ago. Now Agnès is free to tell her story.

As children in a war-ravaged backwater town, they'd built a private world, invisible to everyone but themselves—until Fabienne hatched the plan that would change everything, launching Agnès on an epic trajectory through fame, fortune, and terrible loss.

A magnificent, beguiling tale winding from the postwar rural provinces to Paris, from an English boarding school to the quiet Pennsylvania home where a woman can live without her past. This is a story of disturbing intimacy and obsession, of exploitation and strength of will, by the celebrated author Yiyun Li.
short_summary: When news of her childhood best friend's death arrives, Agnès finally tells the story of their disturbing intimacy—and the plan that launched her toward fame and loss.
author_bios: Yiyun Li is the author of Wednesday's Child; The Book of Goose; Must I Go; Where Reasons End; Kinder Than Solitude; Gold Boy, Emerald Girl; The Vagrants; A Thousand Years of Good Prayers; and the memoir Dear Friend, from My Life I Write to You in Your Life. She has received a PEN/Faulkner Award, PEN/Malamud Award, PEN/Hemingway Award, PEN/Jean Stein Book Award, MacArthur Fellowship, and Windham-Campbell Prize, and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. She teaches at Princeton University.
quotes:
"A compulsively readable meditation on how our closest friendships harbor both love and hate—and how we can fail each other over and over again . . . Li's crystalline, insightful prose adds incredible depth to the drama, yet the dynamic between the girls remains the complex heart of The Book of Goose."

—Sarah Rose Etter, BOMB

"Li, of course, has never been the kind of writer who tells you what you want to hear, and this is surely part of why she has become, while still in her 40s, one of our finest living authors: Her elegant metaphysics never elide the blood and maggots."

—Megan O'Grady, The New York Times

"Exquisite . . . Knives, minerals, oranges, and the game of Rock Paper Scissors sneak into Agnès' narrative as she relates the trajectory of a once-unbreakable union. The relative hardness of those substances is a clue to understanding it all. Stunners: Li's memorable duo, their lives, their losses."

—Kirkus

title: These Summer Storms
long_summary:
Alice Storm hasn't set foot on her family's magnificent private island off the Rhode Island coast in five years—not since she was cast out and built a life beyond the Storm name, influence, and untold billions. But her larger-than-life father's shocking death changes everything.

Alice plans to keep her head down, pay her final respects, and leave the minute the funeral ends. Unfortunately, her father had other plans. The eccentric, manipulative patriarch left his family a final challenge—an inheritance game designed to upend their world. The rules are clear: spend one week on the island, complete their assigned tasks, and receive the inheritance.

But a whole week on Storm Island proves no easy task. Every corner of the sprawling old house bursts with chaos: her older sister's secret love affair, her brother's unyielding arrogance, her younger sister's constant vibe analysis, her mother's cold judgment. All under the stern, watchful gaze of Jack Dean, her father's intriguing and too-handsome second-in-command.

A smart and tender story about the transformative power of grief, love, and family, this luscious novel explores past secrets, present truths, and futures forged in the wake of wild summer storms.
short_summary: When Alice Storm returns to her wealthy family's private island for her father's funeral, she discovers he's left them an inheritance game that requires spending one torturous week together. Family secrets, forbidden romance, and old wounds collide in this addictive family drama.
author_bios: Sarah MacLean is the author of bestselling novels translated into more than twenty-five languages. Co-host of the weekly romance podcast Fated Mates, she is a leading voice in the romance genre. A product of Rhode Island summers and New England storms, Sarah now lives in New York City.
quotes:
"An addictive, engrossing story that combines generational drama, mystery, and the sizzling romance we've all come to expect from Sarah MacLean. It's perfect for fans of Succession and Knives Out."

—Ali Hazelwood, #1 New York Times bestselling author

"Poignant overtures of grief, deliciously complicated family dynamics, and forbidden love thread together in a perfect tapestry of mystery and romance."

—Ashley Poston, New York Times bestselling author of The Seven Year Slip

"From the first rumbles of thunder to the final torrential downpour, MacLean takes readers for a wild ride!"

—Abby Jimenez, New York Times bestselling author of Just for the Summer

title: The Mirror & the Light
long_summary:
England, May 1536. Anne Boleyn is dead, decapitated in the space of a heartbeat by a hired French executioner. As her remains are bundled into oblivion, Thomas Cromwell breakfasts with the victors. The blacksmith's son from Putney emerges from the spring's bloodbath to continue his climb to power and wealth, while his formidable master, Henry VIII, settles to short-lived happiness with his third queen.

Cromwell is a man with only his wits to rely on—no great family to back him, no private army. Despite rebellion at home, traitors plotting abroad, and threats of invasion testing Henry's regime to the breaking point, Cromwell's robust imagination sees a new country in the mirror of the future. But can a nation, or a person, shed the past like a skin? Do the dead continually unbury themselves?

With The Mirror & the Light, Hilary Mantel brings to a triumphant close the trilogy she began with Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies. She traces Cromwell's final years, offering a defining portrait of predator and prey, of a ferocious contest between royal will and a common man's vision of a modern nation making itself through conflict, passion, and courage.
short_summary: The final volume in Mantel's Cromwell trilogy traces his rise to unparalleled power and his brutal fall. Majestic and immersive, it completes one of the great achievements of modern historical fiction.
author_bios: Hilary Mantel was the author of Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies, both Booker Prize winners. The trilogy's final novel, The Mirror & the Light, debuted at #1 on the New York Times bestseller list. She wrote seventeen celebrated books, including the memoir Giving Up the Ghost, and won the National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction, Walter Scott Prize, Costa Book Award, and Hawthornden Prize. In 2014, she was appointed Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire. She died in 2022.
quotes:
"Two years ago something astonishingly fair happened in the world of prestigious prizes: the Man Booker Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction for 2009 both went to the right winner. The book was Hilary Mantel's Wolf Hall, and it would have dwarfed the competition any year…It was a hard act to follow. But the follow-up is equally sublime…That ironic ending will be no cliffhanger for anyone even remotely familiar with Henry VIII's trail of carnage. But in Bring Up the Bodies it works as one. The wonder of Ms. Mantel's retelling is that she makes these events fresh and terrifying all over again."

—The New York Times

"Bring Up the Bodies isn't just her boldest book; it's also her best -- and it reaffirms Mantel's reputation as one of England's greatest living novelists."

—NPR

"the finest works of historical fiction in contemporary literature."

—The Washington Post

title: The Hero of This Book
long_summary:
Ten months after her mother's death, a writer takes a trip to London—a city her mother adored. Wandering the familiar streets, she finds herself caught between memory and uncertainty: back in New England, the family home is for sale, its contents already sorted and winnowed.

As she walks, the narrator recalls everything that made her complicated mother extraordinary—her brilliant wit, fierce generosity, maddening obstinacy, and sheer determination to seize life despite physical limitations. But she also grapples with harder questions: How did her mother endure? And does chronicling this remarkable life constitute an act of love or betrayal?

What begins as a meditation on grief becomes something deeper—an exploration of the relationship between parent and child, and ultimately, a lesson in what it means to write. McCracken has crafted a novel that is both comic and heartbreaking, examining how we honor those we've lost while respecting their privacy. At once piercing and tender, this is a story about art as what remains when everything else falls away.
short_summary: A writer mourning her mother's death takes a trip to London and grapples with memory, grief, and the ethics of storytelling. McCracken's latest is both heartbreaking and luminous.
author_bios: Elizabeth McCracken is the author of eight books, including The Hero of This Book, The Souvenir Museum (long-listed for the National Book Award), Bowlaway, Thunderstruck & Other Stories (winner of the 2014 Story Prize), and The Giant's House (a National Book Award finalist). Her stories have appeared in The Best American Short Stories five times and won three Pushcart Prizes, two National Magazine Awards, and an O. Henry Prize. She holds the James A. Michener Chair in Fiction at the University of Texas at Austin.
quotes:
"The Hero of This Book defies description. Just read it. . . Page by page, it's the quiet story of an adult child mourning a parent. As a whole, it's a map of how to love someone… With admirable candor, pragmatism and humor, McCracken gives us a confessional gift as she walks through the experience of processing loss."

—The Washington Post

"[H]er words create an exquisite alchemy that makes a reader ready to follow her anywhere, believe every word she writes down. Is this book a novel or is it a memoir? It matters not at all. With every vital, potent sentence, McCracken conveys the electric and primal nature of that first fundamental love."

—Janice Y.K. Lee, The New York Times

"[A] beguiling meditation on family, grief, and caretaking that also addresses the burdens of storytelling: how much freedom you have — or don't — to write about family members after they're gone. With infinite freedom to invent, McCracken sparkles."

—The Boston Globe

title: One Last Stop
long_summary:
For cynical twenty-three-year-old August, moving to New York City is supposed to prove her right: that things like magic and cinematic love stories don't exist, and the only smart way to go through life is alone. She can't imagine how waiting tables at a 24-hour pancake diner and moving in with too many weird roommates could possibly change that. And there's certainly no chance of her subway commute being anything more than a daily trudge through boredom and electrical failures.

But then, there's this gorgeous girl on the train.

Jane. Dazzling, charming, mysterious, impossible Jane. Jane with her rough edges and swoopy hair and soft smile, showing up in a leather jacket to save August's day when she needed it most. August's subway crush becomes the best part of her day, but pretty soon, she discovers there's one big problem: Jane doesn't just look like an old school punk rocker. She's literally displaced in time from the 1970s, and August is going to have to use everything she tried to leave in her own past to help her.

Maybe it's time to start believing in some things, after all. McQuiston's One Last Stop is a magical, sexy, big-hearted romance where the impossible becomes possible.
short_summary: August's cynical worldview crumbles when she falls for Jane, a mysterious girl on the subway who turns out to be displaced from the 1970s. A magical romance about believing in the impossible.
author_bios: Casey McQuiston is a #1 New York Times bestselling author of romantic comedies, including One Last Stop, I Kissed Shara Wheeler, and Red, White & Royal Blue. Their writing has appeared in The New York Times, The Washington Post, and Bon Appetit. Born and raised in southern Louisiana, Casey now lives in New York City with a poodle mix named Pepper.
quotes:
"A breathtaking love story, filled with heart, yearning, coming of age, and the most wonderful found family. Honest, often humorous, always relevant, McQuiston's writing reads like poetry. One Last Stop is meant to be savored slowly."

—Helen Hoang, USA Today bestselling author of The Kiss Quotient and The Heart Principle

"Part romance, part fantasy, this gorgeous novel is about meeting someone on your daily commute — a girl, it turns out, who has been riding the train since the 1970s, thanks to a magical timeslip. But it's also about loneliness, and being unmoored from normal time, and missing people you've lost, and dealing with generational trauma and fearing an unknowable future."

—The New York Times

"McQuiston's joyful sophomore romp mixes all the elements that made Red, White & Royal Blue so outstanding—quirky characters, coming-of-age confusion, laugh-out-loud narration, and hilarious pop-cultural references—into something totally its own...With all the fun and camp of a drag show (of which this novel features more than one) but grounded in the tenderness of first love, this time-slip rom-com is an absolute delight."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Milk Blood Heat
long_summary:
A livewire debut from Dantiel W. Moniz, Milk Blood Heat depicts the sultry lives of Floridians in intergenerational tales that contemplate human connection, race, womanhood, inheritance, and the elemental darkness in us all.

Set among the cities and suburbs of Florida, each story delves into the ordinary worlds of young girls, women, and men who find themselves confronted by extraordinary moments of violent personal reckoning. These intimate portraits scour and soothe, blasting light on the nature of family, faith, forgiveness, and what we may—or may not—owe one another.

A thirteen-year-old meditates on her sadness when unexpected tragedy strikes. A woman recovering from miscarriage finds herself unable to let go of her daughter, whose body parts she sees throughout daily life. A teenager resists her family's church and is accused of courting the devil. Servers at a supper club cater to the insatiable cravings of wealthy clientele. Two estranged siblings take a road trip with their father's ashes, forced to face how he continues to shape them.

Wise and subversive, spiritual and seductive, Milk Blood Heat forms an ouroboros of stories that bewitch with their truth.
short_summary: Florida becomes the backdrop for intimate reckonings with family, faith, and loss. Moniz's debut collection captures the elemental darkness and surprising grace found in ordinary lives pushed to extraordinary moments.
author_bios: Dantiel W. Moniz is recipient of the Alice Hoffman Prize for Fiction, the Cecelia Joyce Johnson Emerging Writer Award, and a Tin House Scholarship. Her fiction has appeared in the Paris Review, Tin House, Ploughshares, the Yale Review, Joyland, McSweeney's Quarterly Concern, and elsewhere. Milk Blood Heat is her first book. She's Assistant Professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and lives in Northeast Florida.
quotes:
"Dantiel W. Moniz sings of Florida, girlhood, family, loss, and the glorious, ecstatic, devastating human body. A gorgeous debut from a wickedly talented new writer."

—Lauren Groff, author of Florida, Fates & Furies & Arcadia

"The stories in this book are rigorous and complex, lush and surprising. They are visceral, full of the intimate awe of existing in flesh. A wonder of a debut."

—Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah, author of Chain Gang All Stars & Friday Black

"These stories and the characters that drive them are like lightning—spectacular, beautiful, carrying a hint of danger. Dantiel Moniz is a brilliant new talent, her writing lush and sharp, her landscape so rich it feels we could step into it, her characters so alive and full of longing that they might step of the page and take the reader with them wherever they're headed next. Milk Blood Heat is a stunning and important debut."

—Danielle Evans, author of Before You Suffocate Your Own Fool Self

title: People Like Us
long_summary:
Jason Mott's electric new novel blurs the lines between reality and dream in ways that pull readers in and refuse to let go. While not memoir, the book carries deeply personal connections to Mott's own experiences, exploding with surreal moments—time travel, sea monster sightings, peacocks appearing without warning, and feelings of love and memory so vivid they ache.

Two Black writers navigate a world torn by gun violence, each seeking peace and belonging. One travels the globe on a book tour after winning a major literary prize; the other prepares to speak at a school recovering from a shooting. As their storylines converge, truth and absurdity dance together in equal measure.

Characters drink booze from award trophies while menaces lurk in shadows. Tiny French cars putter through countryside where handguns seem to hover in mid-air, and dreams persist against impossible odds. The result is wickedly funny and achingly sad simultaneously—a triumph bursting with larger-than-life characters who deliver startlingly real insights about our fractured world.

Mott has crafted something utterly new yet instantly recognizable, filled with characters experiencing profound loss alongside riotous humor and the deepest forms of love.
short_summary: Two Black writers seek peace in a world torn by gun violence—one on a global book tour, another speaking at a school after a shooting. Mott weaves reality and surreal dreams into something wickedly funny and achingly profound.
author_bios: Jason Mott has published four novels. His debut, The Returned, was a New York Times bestseller adapted into a two-season TV series. He holds a BFA in Fiction and MFA in Poetry from the University of North Carolina at Wilmington. His poetry and fiction have appeared in various literary journals, and his novel Hell of a Book won the National Book Award for Fiction in 2021.
quotes:
"The follow-up to Mott's National Book Award-winning Hell of a Book weaves the stories of two Black authors — one on an international book tour, the other confronting a deadly school shooting — into a comedic, surreal exploration of love and loss."

—The New York Times

"The novel's mischievous humor gradually gives way to a frightening fever dream. Mott's satire is thoroughly uncompromising, which makes it all the more refreshing."

—Publishers Weekly

"A meta-novel that stings and touches the reader.... The whole book seems the literary equivalent of a post-bop jazz performance, with oblique happenings that compel attention because of the book's antic energy and lyrical passages."

—Kirkus

title: If an Egyptian Cannot Speak English
long_summary:
In post-Arab Spring Cairo, an Egyptian American woman and a man from the village of Shobrakheit meet at a café. He's a former revolution photographer, now unemployed and cocaine-addicted, living in a rooftop shack. She's a nostalgic daughter of immigrants "returning" to a country she's never known, teaching English in a light-filled flat with balconies on all sides.

They fall in love and he moves in. But soon their desire—for one another, for the selves they want to become through the other—takes a violent turn neither expected.

Told in alternating perspectives, this experimental debut is both ravishing and wry, scathing and tender. Naga examines the ethics of fetishizing the homeland and punishing the beloved, exposing gaps in American identity politics when exported overseas. In our globalized world, what are the new faces of empire? When revolution fails, how long can someone survive the disappointment? Who suffers and who gets to tell about it?
short_summary: Post-revolution Cairo becomes the backdrop for a toxic romance between an Egyptian American woman and a local photographer. Experimental fiction that dissects desire, identity, and the new faces of empire.
author_bios: Noor Naga is an Alexandrian writer and author of the verse novel Washes, Prays. Winner of the Bronwen Wallace Award, RBC/PEN Canada Award, and Disquiet Fiction Prize, she teaches at the American University in Cairo.
quotes:
"Propulsive and philosophical. . . . The novel brims with sparkling prose. Naga's sentences are precise and rich with bold, complex observations. . . . [An] exhilarating debut."

—Nadia Owusu, The New York Times

"Naga impresses with her snappy prose . . . and has a gift for exploring varied perspectives. . . . This smart story is distinguished by its surprising empathy."

—Publishers Weekly

"A fascinating novel about class and abuse. . . . [Noor]Naga's writing in the book's first two parts is gripping, but the final section, metafictional and darkly funny, is an absolute master class. She deals with important issues with a gimlet eye and a rare sensitivity-it would be a massive understatement to call this novel a must-read. In a word: brilliant."

—Kirkus

title: Tom Lake
long_summary:
In the spring of 2020, Lara's three daughters return to the family's orchard in Northern Michigan. While picking cherries, they beg their mother to tell them the story of Peter Duke, a famous actor with whom she shared both a stage and a romance years before at a theater company called Tom Lake.

As Lara recalls the past, her daughters examine their own lives and relationship with their mother, and are forced to reconsider the world and everything they thought they knew. Tom Lake is a meditation on youthful love, married love, and the lives parents have led before their children were born.

Both hopeful and elegiac, it explores what it means to be happy even when the world is falling apart. Patchett combines compelling narrative artistry with piercing insights into family dynamics, creating a rich and luminous story told with profound intelligence and emotional subtlety.
short_summary: Three daughters beg their mother to share stories of her theatrical past while picking cherries during the 2020 lockdown. A luminous meditation on love, family secrets, and finding happiness amid uncertainty.
author_bios: Ann Patchett is the author of novels, most recently the #1 New York Times bestselling Tom Lake, works of nonfiction, and children's books. She has received numerous awards, including the PEN/Faulkner, the Women's Prize for Fiction, and the Book Sense Book of the Year. Her novel The Dutch House was a Pulitzer Prize finalist. Time magazine named her one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World. President Biden awarded her the National Humanities Medal. She owns Parnassus Books in Nashville, Tennessee.
quotes:
"Tom Lake is about romantic love, marital love and maternal love, but also the love of animals, the love of stories, love of the land and trees and the tiny, red, cordiform object that is a cherry. . . . This generous writer hits the mark again with her ninth novel."

—The Washington Post

"Wise. Beautiful. With an elegant soft touch….Brilliant, of course."

—Good Morning America

"A quiet and reassuring book . . . highly conscious of . . . [the] human failure to appreciate the little things."

—The New York Times

title: The Rich People Have Gone Away
long_summary:
Brooklyn, 2020. Theo Harper and his pregnant wife, Darla, escape to their upstate cottage to wait out the lockdown—a privilege not everyone in their Park Slope building shares. Xavier, the teenager in the Cardi B T-shirt, stays behind, as do Darla's best friend Ruby and her partner Katsumi, who are fighting to save their Michelin-starred restaurant.

During a hike on the aptly named Devil's Path, Theo reveals a long-buried secret. When Darla vanishes after their explosive argument, he becomes the prime suspect in her disappearance.

As families and friends mobilize to search for Darla, with Ruby and Katsumi working to broker peace, the investigation forces everyone to confront how past and present intertwine in startling ways. Set against the pulse of an ever-changing city, this is a story about ordinary New Yorkers navigating hope, love, and inequity—while discovering that no one leaves the past behind completely.
short_summary: When a pregnant woman disappears after her husband reveals a devastating secret, their diverse circle of New York friends and neighbors unite in the search. A gripping exploration of community, privilege, and connection during lockdown.
author_bios: Regina Porter is an award-winning playwright and author of The Travelers, a PEN/Hemingway Award finalist and Orwell Prize longlisted novel. A graduate of Iowa Writers' Workshop, her work has appeared in Harvard Review, Tin House, and Oxford American.
quotes:
"An immersive examination of the human condition in the face of tragedy and triumph."

—Zakiya Dalila Harris, author of The Other Black Girl

"Regina Porter weaves beauty and humor with pathos, in prose that is winding, prescient, and profound."

—Bryan Washington, author of Family Meal

"Striking . . . Porter keenly explores themes of generational and racial privilege and a community's fragile bonds. This one makes the lockdown worth revisiting."

—Publishers Weekly

title: Greta & Valdin
long_summary:
It's been a year since his ex-boyfriend dumped him and moved from Auckland to Buenos Aires, and Valdin is doing fine. He has a good flat with his sister Greta, a solid career where his colleagues only occasionally remind him that he's the sole Māori person in the office, and a good friend he only sleeps with when he's sad. But when work sends him to Argentina and throws him back into his former lover's orbit, Valdin is forced to confront the feelings he's been trying to ignore—and the future he wants.

Greta is not letting her painfully unrequited crush get her down (or her possibly pointless master's thesis, or her pathetic academic salary). She'd love to focus on the charming fellow grad student she meets at a party and her friendships with a circle of similarly floundering twenty-somethings, but her chaotic family life won't stop intruding: her mother is keeping secrets, her nephew is having a gay crisis, and her brother has suddenly flown to South America without a word.

Filled with kernels of humor and truth, Greta & Valdin careens through the siblings' misadventures and the messy dramas of their sprawling, eccentric Māori-Russian-Catalonian family. An acclaimed bestseller in New Zealand, this debut is fresh, joyful, and alive with the possibility of love in its many mystifying forms.
short_summary: Siblings navigate queerness, multiracial identity, and family chaos in this joyful New Zealand bestseller. When Valdin's work trip to Argentina reunites him with his ex, both he and sister Greta must confront what they really want from love.
author_bios: Rebecca K Reilly (Ngāti Hine, Ngāti Rehua Ngātiwai ki Aotea), born 1991, is a Māori novelist from Waitākere, New Zealand. She has a BA (hons) in German and European studies from the University of Auckland and an MA from the International Institute of Modern Letters at Victoria University of Wellington, where she won the Adam Foundation Prize in Creative Writing for 2019.
quotes:
"Generous [and] tender. . . Reilly's warm, overflowing novel defies categorization because its characters are too complex and multifaceted to be easily summed up. They're too alive in their messiness. If this novel shows us anything, it's that love—of family, of romantic partners, of community—is most joyful when it's without limits."

—The New York Times

"The loving family at the heart of this very funny and moving novel about a brother and sister is so complex . . .  every bond in the book is written to be precious and specific. Greta & Valdin is the rare story to live up to its fearless promotional copy, which calls it a cross between Schitt's Creek and Normal People. Perhaps that sounds impossible; that's what makes it so good."

—Linda Holmes, NPR

"Say hello to your new favorite fictional family. In the wrong hands [Greta & Valdin] could all be quirk for quirk's sake, or a half-baked hybrid of Schitt's Creek and The Royal Tenenbaums. But Reilly's humor is so riotously specific, and the many moments of true poignancy so gently infused with that same humor, that the Vladisavljevics seem like no one but themselves. [. . . ] If Reilly won't give us a sequel, then we can at least hope she won't make us wait too long for her next novel."

—Kirkus

title: Liberation Day
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
The "best short-story writer in English" (Time) returns with a masterful collection that cuts to the heart of what it means to live in community with our fellow humans. With his trademark prose—wickedly funny, unsentimental, and exquisitely tuned—Saunders delivers nine prismatic stories that encompass joy and despair, oppression and revolution, bizarre fantasy and brutal reality.

"Love Letter" offers a tender missive from grandfather to grandson amid a dystopian future, reminding us of our obligations to our ideals and one another. "Ghoul" follows a lonely, morally complex character in a Hell-themed underground amusement park who begins questioning everything about his reality. In "Mother's Day," two women who loved the same man reach an existential reckoning in the middle of a hailstorm.

"Elliott Spencer" presents an eighty-nine-year-old protagonist whose memory has been "scraped"—a victim of a scheme targeting vulnerable people for political manipulation. And "My House" confronts the haunting nature of unfulfilled dreams in just seven devastating pages.

Together, these subversive, profound stories make a case for viewing the world with the same generosity and clear-eyed attention Saunders brings to even the most absurd circumstances.
short_summary: Nine subversive stories that blend dystopian futures with tender humanity. Saunders explores power, ethics, and connection through his signature mix of dark comedy and devastating compassion.
author_bios: George Saunders is the author of thirteen books, including the novel Lincoln in the Bardo, which won the Man Booker Prize, and five story collections, including Tenth of December, a National Book Award finalist, and Liberation Day (selected by President Obama as one of his ten favorite books of 2022). Three of his books—Pastoralia, Tenth of December, and Lincoln in the Bardo—were chosen for The New York Times's 100 Best Books of the 21st Century. He hosts Story Club on Substack and teaches at Syracuse University.
quotes:
"It's that equilibrium of groundbreaking craft and bone-deep compassion—plus his rangy, tilt-a-whirl voice—that raises Saunders above other masters of the form."

—The Boston Globe

"Part of the Saunders elixir is that we feel more empathetic after reading his work."

—The San Francisco Chronicle

"Saunders has revealed himself to be nothing less than an American Gogol: funny, pointed, full of nuance, and always writing with a moral heart. This, his first book of short fiction in nearly a decade, only cements the validity of such a point of view. The nine pieces here are smart and funny, speculative yet at the same time written on a human scale, narratives full of love and loss and longing and the necessity of trying to connect."

—Kirkus

title: Our Country Friends
long_summary:
It's March 2020 and a calamity is unfolding. A group of friends and friends-of-friends gathers in a country house to wait out the pandemic. Over the next six months, new friendships and romances will take hold while old betrayals emerge, forcing each character to reevaluate whom they love and what matters most.

The unlikely cast includes a Russian-born novelist; his Russian-born psychiatrist wife; their precocious child obsessed with K-pop; a struggling Indian American writer; a wildly successful Korean American app developer; a global dandy with three passports; a young flame-thrower of an essayist from the Carolinas; and a movie star whose arrival upsets the equilibrium of this chosen family.

In a remarkable literary feat, Gary Shteyngart has documented through fiction the emotional toll of our recent times. Both elegiac and very funny, this story of love and friendship reads like a great Russian novel set in upstate New York.
short_summary: Eight friends weather the pandemic in a country house where new romances bloom and old betrayals surface. Shteyngart captures our recent chaos with the emotional depth of a Russian novel and his signature wit.
author_bios: Gary Shteyngart was born in Leningrad in 1972 and came to the United States seven years later. His debut novel, The Russian Debutante's Handbook, won the Stephen Crane Award for First Fiction and the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction. His second novel, Absurdistan, was named one of the 10 Best Books of the Year by The New York Times Book Review. His novel Super Sad True Love Story won the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize. His memoir, Little Failure, was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. His books have been published in thirty countries.
quotes:
"The novel's strengths abound. It upends clichés, pieties and commonplaces while also noticing salient details of the lockdown."

—The New York Times

"Our Country Friends has all [Shteyngart's] usual humor and absurdity, but it's deepened by a new empathy."

—Los Angeles Times

"Shteyngart knows how to make you belly laugh, and he's in his element here, poking fun at the claustrophobia of privilege. He perfectly captures the nature of adult friendships and the petty jealousies, disappointments, and dependencies that can define them."

—Vulture

title: Vera, or Faith
long_summary:
The Bradford-Shmulkin family is falling apart. A modern blend of Russian, Jewish, Korean, and New England WASP, they love one another deeply, but the pressures of life in an unstable America are fraying their bonds.

There's Daddy, a struggling, cash-thirsty editor whose Russian heritage gives him surprising new currency in the upside-down world of twenty-first-century geopolitics. His wife, Anne Mom, is a progressive, underfunded blue blood from Boston barely holding the household together. Their son Dylan's blond hair and Mayflower lineage provide him pride of place in the newly forming American political order. And above all, there's young Vera—half Jewish, half Korean, and wholly original.

Observant, sensitive, and always writing down new vocabulary words, Vera wants only three things: to make a friend at school, to keep Daddy and Anne Mom together, and to meet her birth mother, Mom Mom, who will finally tell Vera the secret of who she really is and how to ensure love's survival in this great, mad, imploding world.

Both biting and deeply moving, Vera, or Faith is a boldly imagined story of family and country told through the clear and tender eyes of a child.
short_summary: Ten-year-old Vera navigates her family's unraveling against the backdrop of America's own collapse. Shteyngart delivers a masterclass in voice—tender, funny, and devastatingly perceptive about love's fragility in chaotic times.
author_bios: Gary Shteyngart was born in Leningrad in 1972 and came to the United States seven years later. His debut novel, The Russian Debutante's Handbook, won the Stephen Crane Award for First Fiction and the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction. His second novel, Absurdistan, was named one of the 10 Best Books of the Year by The New York Times Book Review. His novel Super Sad True Love Story won the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize. His memoir, Little Failure, was a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist. His books have been published in thirty countries.
quotes:
"an unnerving—and very funny—portrait of America in the near future and an indelible portrait of its ten-year-old heroine, and attests to Shteyngart's magic ability to write in multiple emotional octaves and his gift for both sharp-edged humor and heartfelt tenderness."

—Michiko Kakutani, author of The Great Wave

"In its swirls of emotion, its humor, its pathos, and the unsparing humanity of its vision, Vera, or Faith is like some fabulous, hitherto-unknown creature that's been let out of its bottle and set free. It begins to seem that there's nothing Gary Shteyngart can't do."

—Michael Cunningham, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of Day and The Hours

"A novel that you can read in one sitting that will stay with you forever . . . Vera instantly became one of my favorite child narrators, and her lucid bewilderment is by turns poignant, funny, and wise."

—Karen Russell, Pulitzer Prize finalist for Swamplandia!

title: The Life of the Mind
long_summary:
As an adjunct professor of English in New York City with little hope of finding a permanent position, Dorothy feels "like a janitor in the temple who continued to sweep because she had nowhere else to be but who had lost her belief in the essential sanctity of the enterprise." No one but her boyfriend knows that she's just had a miscarriage—not her mother, her best friend, or her therapists (Dorothy has two of them). She wasn't even sure she wanted to be a mother. So why does Dorothy feel like a failure?

The Life of the Mind is a book about endings—of youth, of ambition, of possibility, but also of the meaning that an inquiring mind can find in the mess of daily experience. Mordant and remorselessly wise, this jewel of a debut cuts incisively into life as we live it, and how we think of it.
short_summary: Dorothy is an adjunct professor drifting through academic limbo and personal crisis. Smallwood's debut is wickedly funny and devastatingly precise about modern disappointment.
author_bios: Christine Smallwood's fiction has appeared in The Paris Review, n+1, and Vice. Her reviews, essays, and cultural reporting have been published in The New Yorker, Bookforum, T: The New York Times Style Magazine, and The New York Times Magazine, where she is a contributing writer. She has written the "New Books" column for Harper's Magazine, where she is a contributing editor, and been an editor at The Nation. She has a PhD in English from Columbia University and is a founding faculty member of the Brooklyn Institute for Social Research.
quotes:
"Hilarious, recognizable, and helplessly wise—a perfect foil for its namesake."

—Rivka Galchen, author of Everyone Knows Your Mother is a Witch & Little Labors

"Brilliant and pleasurable, funny and dark, cerebral and visceral—a must-read for the bleeding human survivors of the modern age."
