—Melissa Broder, author of The Pisces and Milk Fed

"One of the wittiest, most deliciously farcical novels I've read in a long time."

—Maureen Corrigan, NPR

title: Afterparties
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
Seamlessly transitioning between the absurd and the tenderhearted, Afterparties offers an expansive portrait of Cambodian-American lives in California. As the children of refugees carve out radical new paths for themselves, they shoulder the inherited weight of the Khmer Rouge genocide while grappling with the complexities of race, sexuality, friendship, and family.

A high school badminton coach and failing grocery store owner tries to relive his glory days by beating a rising star teenage player. Two drunken brothers attend a wedding afterparty and hatch a plan to expose their shady uncle's snubbing of the bride and groom. A queer love affair sparks between an older tech entrepreneur launching a "safe space" app and a disillusioned young teacher obsessed with Moby-Dick.

Balancing acerbic humor with sharp emotional depth, these stories illuminate a complicated, struggling, beloved American community with wry affection and unflinching honesty.
short_summary: Children of Cambodian refugees navigate identity, trauma, and belonging in California's Central Valley. So's debut collection balances razor-sharp humor with devastating tenderness, capturing the weight of inherited history.
author_bios: Anthony Veasna So (1992-2020) was a Stanford graduate who earned his MFA at Syracuse University. His New York Times-bestselling collection Afterparties was longlisted for the Andrew Carnegie Medal, winning both the Ferro Grumley Award for LGBTQ fiction and the NBCC John Leonard Prize. His work appeared in The New Yorker, The Paris Review, n+1, and Granta. A Stockton native, he taught at Colgate University, Syracuse University, and the Center for Empowering Refugees and Immigrants in Oakland.
quotes:
"Witty and soulful stories from a writer who was just getting started . . . . [So] was gregarious, tattooed, queer: a big personality. He radiates in much the same way on the page. . . . [His] stories reimagine and reanimate the Central Valley, in the way that the polyglot stories in Bryan Washington's collection Lot reimagined Houston and Ocean Vuong's novel On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous allowed us to see Hartford in a fresh light."

—Dwight Garner, The New York Times

"Afterparties weaves through a Cambodian-American community in the shadow of genocide, following the children of refugees as they grapple with the complexities of masculinity, class, and family. Anthony Veasna So explores the lives of these unforgettable characters with bracing humor and startling tenderness. A stunning collection from an exciting new voice."

—Brit Bennett, author of The Vanishing Half

"Afterparties, by the late Anthony Veasna So, was one of the big buzz books this year and it exceeded and upended my expectations. So, who died at the age of 28 before the book came out, was a queer first-generation Cambodian American who wrote smart, flip, rude, funny, sexually explicit and compassionate stories about the Cambodian refugee community in Stockton, Calif."

—Maureen Corrgian, NPR

title: Chronicles from the Land of the Happiest People on Earth
long_summary:
In an imaginary Nigeria, a cunning entrepreneur is selling body parts stolen from Dr. Menka's hospital for ritualistic practices. Dr. Menka shares this grisly discovery with his oldest college friend, Duyole Pitan-Payne—a bon viveur, star engineer, and Yoruba royal who's the life of every party.

Duyole is about to assume a prestigious post at the United Nations in New York, but someone seems determined to prevent his departure. Neither Dr. Menka nor Duyole knows why, or how close the enemy is, or how powerful.

Chronicles from the Land of the Happiest People on Earth is at once a literary romp, a crafty whodunit, and a scathing indictment of political and social corruption. It's a stirring call to arms against the abuse of power from one of our fiercest political activists, who also happens to be a global literary giant.
short_summary: Murder mystery meets political satire in this searing novel about corruption and power in contemporary Nigeria. Soyinka's first novel in decades showcases his brilliant wit and unflinching social commentary.
author_bios: Wole Soyinka was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1986. Born in Nigeria in 1934, he's an author, playwright, poet, and political activist whose prolific work includes The Interpreters and Death and the King's Horseman. Soyinka was twice jailed for criticizing the Nigerian government and destroyed his U.S. Green Card when Donald Trump was elected president.
quotes:
"Though his work has spanned multiple genres—poetry, plays, memoirs and essays—[Soyinka's] new novel manages to chart fresh territory. . . . Chronicles combines elements of a murder mystery, a searing political satire and an Alice in Wonderland-like modern allegory of power and deceit."

—Los Angeles Times

"It is Soyinka's greatest novel, his revenge against the insanities of the nation's ruling class and one of the most shocking chronicles of an African nation in the 21st century. It ought to be widely read."

—Ben Okri, The Guardian

"A biting satire that looks at corruption in an imaginary contemporary Nigeria, Chronicles is also an intriguing and droll whodunit. . . . A brilliant story that takes on politics, class, corruption, and religion from the very first chapters. It highlights Soyinka's lush, elegant language."

—Publishers Weekly

title: This Time Tomorrow
long_summary:
On the eve of her fortieth birthday, Alice's life isn't terrible. She likes her job, even if it isn't exactly what she expected. She's content with her apartment, her romantic status, her independence, and she adores her lifelong best friend. But her father is ailing, and something feels missing.

When she wakes up the next morning, she finds herself back in 1996, reliving her sixteenth birthday. It isn't just her adolescent body that shocks her, or seeing her high school crush—it's her dad, the vital, charming, forty-something version of her father with whom she is reunited.

Now armed with a new perspective on her own life and his, past events take on new meaning. Is there anything she would change if she could? With celebrated humor, insight, and heart, Straub offers her own twist on time travel tropes and delivers a different kind of love story entirely.
short_summary: When Alice wakes up on her fortieth birthday, she's somehow sixteen again—and reunited with her younger, healthier father. Straub's tender time travel novel explores second chances and the complicated love between parents and children.
author_bios: Emma Straub is the New York Times bestselling author of six books for adults: the novels This Time Tomorrow, All Adults Here, The Vacationers, Modern Lovers, Laura Lamont's Life in Pictures, and the short story collection Other People We Married. She is a Guggenheim Foundation Fellow and her work has been published in more than 20 languages. Emma and her husband own Books Are Magic, an independent bookstore in Brooklyn.
quotes:
"One of the most moving and intelligent time travel novels I have ever read. Nostalgic, wise, funny, and filled with love."

—Gabrielle Zevin, New York Times bestselling author of Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow

"If I could time travel, I'd go back just far enough to start Emma Straub's beautiful novel This Time Tomorrow again for the first time. The pages brim with tenderness and an appreciation for what we had and who we were. I could not have loved it more."

—Ann Patchett, New York Times bestselling author of Tom Lake, The Dutch House, Commonwealth & State of Wonder

"This Time Tomorrow is that rare one-in-a-million novel that not only pulls you wholly into itself, but leaves a lasting mark when it finally releases you. Never has Straub's writing been more incisive, clever, and emotionally generous— which is really saying something. The kind of book that will make you laugh, make you cry, and make you call the people you love. Exceptional."

—Emily Henry, New York Times bestselling author of Book People & People We Meet on Vacation

title: Shuggie Bain
long_summary:
Shuggie Bain tells the unforgettable story of young Hugh "Shuggie" Bain, a sweet and lonely boy navigating his 1980s childhood in run-down public housing in Glasgow. Thatcher's policies have devastated the working class, leaving fathers and sons unemployed while the city's drug epidemic looms.

Shuggie's mother Agnes is both his guiding light and greatest burden. She dreams of a house with its own front door, flicking through catalogs and ordering small happinesses on credit to brighten her grey existence. Married to a philandering taxi driver, Agnes maintains her pride through appearance—her beehive, makeup, and pearly-white false teeth creating a glamorous image of a Glaswegian Elizabeth Taylor.

But beneath the surface, Agnes finds solace in drink, draining the family's weekly benefits on cans of extra-strong lager hidden in handbags and poured into tea mugs. As her older children escape, Shuggie remains to care for her through alcoholic binges and brief periods of sobriety. Meanwhile, he struggles to become the "normal" boy he longs to be, though everyone realizes he is "no right"—harboring a secret that all but him can see.

A heartbreaking story of addiction, sexuality, and love, this debut offers an epic portrayal of working-class life rarely seen in fiction.
short_summary: Young Shuggie navigates 1980s Glasgow while caring for his glamorous, alcoholic mother Agnes. A devastating portrait of working-class life, addiction, and the complicated love between a boy and his deeply flawed parent.
author_bios: Douglas Stuart is a Scottish-American author whose debut novel Shuggie Bain won the 2020 Booker Prize and the Sue Kaufman Prize, and was a finalist for the National Book Award and PEN/Hemingway Award. His latest novel Young Mungo was a national bestseller and British Book Award finalist. His work appears in the New Yorker and Literary Hub.
quotes:
"We were bowled over by this first novel, which creates an amazingly intimate, compassionate, gripping portrait of addiction, courage and love. The book gives a vivid glimpse of a marginalized, impoverished community in a bygone era of British history. It's a desperately sad, almost-hopeful examination of family and the destructive powers of desire."

—Booker Prize Judges

"This year's breakout debut . . . It has drawn comparisons to D.H. Lawrence, James Joyce, and Frank McCourt."

—Alexandra Alter, The New York Times

"I'm really, really stunned by it. It's so good. I think it's the best first book I've read in many years . . . It's a heartbreaking story, and quite hard to read at times, but it's almost like it's uplifting on behalf of literature. And it's written with great warmth and compassion for the characters."

—Karl Ove Knausgaard, The Guardian

title: Night of the Living Rez
long_summary:
In twelve luminescent stories, Morgan Talty breathes life into a Penobscot community grappling with painful histories and uncertain futures. With searing humor and deep compassion, these tales follow families as they navigate the weight of inheritance—both cultural and personal.

A boy unearths a jar containing an old curse, setting his family's unraveling into motion. A man attempting to swindle pot from a dealer discovers a friend passed out in the woods, hair frozen into snow. A grandmother with Alzheimer's projects the past onto her grandson. Two friends, inspired by Antiques Roadshow, plot to rob the tribal museum for valuable root clubs.

Each story examines what it means to be Penobscot in the twenty-first century—what it means to live, survive, and persevere after tragedy. Night of the Living Rez offers an unforgettable portrayal of Indigenous life and announces the arrival of a major talent in contemporary fiction.
short_summary: Twelve stories set in a Penobscot community in Maine, where families navigate painful histories and uncertain futures. Talty writes with searing humor and compassion about inheritance, survival, and what it means to persevere.
author_bios: Morgan Talty is a citizen of the Penobscot Indian Nation and author of the nationally bestselling Night of the Living Rez. His writing appears in The Georgia Review, Granta, Shenandoah, TriQuarterly, Narrative, and Lit Hub. He's an assistant professor at the University of Maine, Orono, and faculty at Stonecoast MFA and the Institute of American Indian Arts.
quotes:
"These stories took me in the same way Denis Johnson's Jesus' Son did when I first read it. The comparison here is meant in every way to praise Talty as a writer, and I'm sure I won't be the only one who says so, partially because of his emotional precision, his stark, unflinching, droll, intoxicating style, and also because of a certain drug/addiction element at play here. But as I got deeper into the work, into the book, and came to understand these lives and this community, the further away it felt from my initial comparison with Johnson, and the more familiar it felt—our Native communities being bound by countless common threads, strengths and afflictions both—and only then did I understand the distinct brilliance of Talty's voice as its own, and ours. I knew and felt for these people. Wanted to and knew I couldn't help them, even as they did me. There is so much brutal, raw, and beautiful power in these stories. I kept wanting to read and know more about these peoples' lives, how they ended up where they ended up, how they would get out, how they wouldn't. It is difficult to be so honest, and funny, and sad, at once, in any kind of work. Reading this book, I literally laughed and cried."

—Tommy Orange, author of Wandering Stars & There There

"Morgan Talty's Night of the Living Rez is a beautifully crafted, raw and intimate book about youth, friendship, and family on the reservation. These stories are profoundly moving and essential, rendered with precision and intimacy. Talty is a powerful new voice in Native American fiction."

—Brandon Hobson, National Book Award finalist and author of The Removed

"Magnificent."

—Lily King, The New York Times

title: Scattered All Over the Earth
long_summary:
Welcome to the not-too-distant future: Japan has vanished from the face of the earth and is now remembered only as "the land of sushi." Hiruko, a former citizen turned climate refugee, teaches immigrant children in Denmark using her invented language Panska (Pan-Scandinavian): "homemade language. no country to stay in. three countries I experienced. insufficient space in brain. so made new language."

As she searches for anyone who can still speak her mother tongue, Hiruko gathers a troupe of unlikely companions. Their journey takes them across Europe—to France for an umami cooking competition, past a dead whale, encounters with an ultra-nationalist named Breivik, unrequited love, Kakuzo robots, red herrings, uranium, and an Andalusian matador.

Episodic and mesmerizing scenes flash vividly along as they make their way to Stockholm. With its intrepid band of companions, this first novel of a trilogy evokes Alice's Adventures in Wonderland or a surreal Wind in the Willows, but remains utterly sui generis—another Yoko Tawada masterwork.
short_summary: Japan has vanished, remembered only as the land of sushi. Climate refugee Hiruko searches Europe for anyone who speaks her mother tongue, inventing new languages along the way. Tawada's surreal odyssey is both deeply moving and magnificently strange.
author_bios: Yoko Tawada was born in Tokyo in 1960, moved to Hamburg at twenty-two, then to Berlin in 2006. She writes in both Japanese and German, publishing stories, novels, poems, plays, and essays in both languages. Her numerous awards include the Akutagawa Prize, Adelbert von Chamisso Prize, Tanizaki Prize, Kleist Prize, Goethe Medal, and National Book Award. New Directions publishes her collections Where Europe Begins and Facing the Bridge, plus novels including The Naked Eye, Memoirs of a Polar Bear, The Emissary, and the Scattered trilogy.
quotes:
"Magnificently strange. Tawada is reminiscent of Nikolai Gogol, for whom the natural situation for a ghost story was a minor government employee saving up to buy a fancy coat, the natural destiny of a nose to haunt its owner as an overbearing nobleman."

—Rivka Galchen, The New York Times

"This dystopian novel is riveting, bizarre as can be, and like nothing else I've ever read. I'm terrified not enough people will read it."

—Kamil Ahsan, NPR

"Tawada expands upon the themes of language, immigration, globalization, and authenticity which underpin this slyly humorous first installment of a planned trilogy."

—Kirkus

title: Pick a Color
long_summary:
Ning is a retired boxer, but to the customers who visit her nail salon, she is just another worker named Susan. On this summer's day, much like any other, the Susans buff and clip and polish and tweeze. They listen and smile and nod.

But beneath this superficial veneer, Ning is a woman of rigorous intellect and profound complexity. She's enthralled by the intricacy and rhythms of her work, yet haunted by memories of paths not taken. She navigates the complex power dynamics among her fellow Susans, whose greatest fears and desires lie just behind the gossip they exchange.

As the day's work grinds on, the friction between Ning's two identities—as anonymous manicurist and brilliant observer of her own circumstances—will gather electric force, demanding a reckoning with how the world of privilege sees a woman like her.

Told over a single day with razor-sharp precision and wit, Pick a Color confirms Thammavongsa's place as literature's premier chronicler of the immigrant experience in all its complex, subversive forms.
short_summary: Over one transformative day in her nail salon, retired boxer Ning navigates the invisible dynamics between worker and client, observer and observed. Thammavongsa delivers intimate, razor-sharp prose about dignity, labor, and what it means to be truly seen.
author_bios: Souvankham Thammavongsa was born in the Lao refugee camp in Nong Khai, Thailand, and was raised and educated in Toronto, where she now lives. She is the author of four poetry books and the short story collection How to Pronounce Knife, winner of the 2020 Scotiabank Giller Prize and 2021 Trillium Book Award. Her novel Pick a Color won the 2025 Scotiabank Giller Prize. Her stories have won an O. Henry Award and appeared in The New Yorker, Harper's Magazine, The Paris Review, The Atlantic, Granta, and NOON.
quotes:
"Pick a Color is one of the greatest novels I have ever read. In alchemical and captivating prose, this book orbits the steady flows of power and projection that exist between Ning, her employees and her clients. Love, death, joy, abandonment, deception and lust are all at stake in Susan's Nail Salon. The world of Pick a Color is shockingly intimate. Reading this book left me with an intense desire to touch a stranger's hands."

—Rita Bullwinkel, author of Pulitzer Prize finalist Headshot

"This debut novel is a must for fans (like me) of Thammavongsa's intimate, deliciously tricky short stories. With dry humor and a keen eye for class, she's given us a hauntingly good book about the dignity and despair of work: the secret life of nail salons…When Thammavongsa writes, I read!"

—Ed Park, author of Pulitzer Prize finalist Same Bed Different Dreams

"Only as masterful an ironist as Souvankham Thammavongsa could have pulled this off: a work of urgent and impassioned solidarity that is also a defiant, even pugnacious, assertion of narrative autonomy and technical control. Pick a Color is a knockout: every punch lands."

—Eleanor Catton, author of Birnam Wood

title: Margo's Got Money Troubles
long_summary:
As the child of a Hooters waitress and an ex-pro wrestler, Margo Millet has always known she'd have to make it on her own. So she enrolls at her local junior college, even though she can't imagine how she'll ever make a living. She's still figuring things out and never planned to have an affair with her English professor—and while the affair is brief, it isn't brief enough to keep her from getting pregnant. Despite everyone's advice, she decides to keep the baby, mostly out of naiveté and a yearning for something bigger.

Now, at twenty, Margo is alone with an infant, unemployed, and on the verge of eviction. She needs cash—fast. When her estranged father, Jinx, shows up on her doorstep asking to move in, she agrees in exchange for help with childcare. Then Margo begins to form a plan: she'll start an OnlyFans as an experiment, and soon finds herself adapting some of Jinx's advice from the world of wrestling. Like how to craft a compelling character and make your audience fall in love with you.

Before she knows it, she's turned it into a runaway success. Could this be the answer to all of Margo's problems, or does internet fame come with too high a price? Blisteringly funny and filled with sharp insight, this is a tender tale about wrestling money and power from a world that has little interest in giving it to her.
short_summary: Twenty-year-old Margo is broke, alone with a baby, and facing eviction when her ex-wrestler father shows up with advice about crafting personas and winning audiences. Her solution: OnlyFans meets professional wrestling wisdom.
author_bios: Rufi Thorpe is the author of The Knockout Queen, a finalist for the PEN/Faulkner award; Dear Fang, with Love; and The Girls from Corona del Mar, longlisted for the International Dylan Thomas Prize and the Flaherty-Dunnan First Novel Prize. A California native, she lives in Los Angeles with her husband and two sons.
quotes:
"It's been a long time since I was so swept up in a book that I read it all in one swoop. Margo's Got Money Troubles is totally delightful—a page-turning plot with flawed but loveable characters, big philosophical questions, and really top-notch writing. It's funny and touching. Highly recommend!"

—Celeste Ng, New York Times bestselling author of Our Missing Hearts & Little Fires Everywhere

"Margo's Got Money Troubles is an audacious, wildly funny, completely unpredictable novel by a writer so singular that it's hard to compare her to anyone else. Rufi Thorpe writes wildness so well, the messiness of the choices we make, the strange ways we bend and twist ourselves to accommodate those choices, and she does it with the rare qualities of tenderness and empathy. An absolutely brilliant book."

—Kevin Wilson, New York Times bestselling author of Now is Not the Time to Panic, Nothing to See Here & The Family Fang

"A hilarious novel about making the most of what you've got. Sharp and funny by turns, this is an exceptionally tender look at young motherhood and love that also involves professional wrestling, and yes, OnlyFans. I gobbled it up."

—Emma Straub, New York Times bestselling author of This Time Tomorrow

title: The Safekeep
long_summary:
A house is a precious thing...

It is 1961 and the rural Dutch province of Overijssel is quiet. Bomb craters have been filled, buildings reconstructed, and the war is truly over. Living alone in her late mother's country home, Isabel knows her life is as it should be—led by routine and discipline. But all is upended when her brother Louis brings his graceless new girlfriend Eva, leaving her at Isabel's doorstep as a guest for the season.

Eva is Isabel's antithesis: she sleeps late, walks loudly through the house, and touches things she shouldn't. In response, Isabel develops a fury-fueled obsession. When things start disappearing around the house—a spoon, a knife, a bowl—Isabel's suspicions begin to spiral.

In the sweltering peak of summer, Isabel's paranoia gives way to infatuation, leading to a discovery that unravels everything she has ever known. The war might not be well and truly over after all, and neither Eva—nor the house in which they live—are what they seem.

Mysterious, sophisticated, and infused with intrigue, atmosphere, and desire, The Safekeep is a thrilling debut about facing up to the truth of history and to one's own longings.
short_summary: Two women circle each other in a Dutch country house during the summer of 1961. What begins as suspicion and obsession transforms into something far more dangerous and revelatory.
author_bios: Yael van der Wouden is a writer and teacher. The Safekeep, her debut novel, was a finalist for the 2024 Booker Prize and longlisted for the 2025 Aspen Words Literary Prize. It was named a New York Times Notable Book of the Year and a best book of the year by The Washington Post, Time, The Economist, Kirkus Reviews, The Times (London), The Independent, BookPage, and others. She lives in Utrecht, Netherlands.
quotes:
"It is the only book I have read this year that has made me cry. . . . Van der Wouden has produced the rare novel about World War II, the Holocaust, and their aftermath that succeeds in feeling fully, intimately human. . . . [The plot] twist is not what makes The Safekeep remarkable; what does is the extraordinary, emotional story Van der Wouden crafts around it, and the pitch-perfect voice she brings to the characters who experience its consequences."

—Talya Zax, The Washington Post

"Quietly remarkable. . . . Van der Wouden's writing is fine and taut. She lasers in on details, and presents unsentimental and intrinsically powerful metaphors. . . . I would have liked this book in any case, just for the pleasure of reading it. But the story is resolved in such a bold and tender way that it becomes not merely clever, but indelible."

—Lori Soderlind, The New York Times

"A brave and thrilling debut about facing up to the truth of history, and to one's own desires. . . . The tightly controlled narrative breaks open into a tale of erotic awakening, followed by an almighty twist. Anticipating that twist will not lessen its impact—fittingly enough for a novel in which everyone knows more than they can bear to admit. van der Wouden brings stunning power and control to her page-turner about trauma and repression."

—The Guardian

title: Let Us Descend
long_summary:
Let Us Descend follows Annis on a harrowing journey from the rice fields of the Carolinas to the slave markets of New Orleans and into the brutal heart of a Louisiana sugar plantation. Sold south by the white enslaver who fathered her, Annis becomes our guide through this miles-long march of suffering.

As she struggles to survive, Annis turns inward, seeking comfort in memories of her mother and stories of her African warrior grandmother. She opens herself to a world beyond this world—one teeming with spirits of earth and water, myth and history. Some spirits nurture and give; others manipulate and take. Through this descent into darkness, Annis discovers her own power of rebirth and reclamation.

Ward inscribes Black American grief and joy into the very landscape—the rich but unforgiving forests, swamps, and rivers of the American South. This searing novel transforms historical trauma into transcendent art, revealing how the human spirit can ascend even from the deepest depths.
short_summary: Ward follows an enslaved girl's journey from Carolina rice fields to Louisiana sugar plantations, weaving African spirituality through American brutality. A devastating descent that becomes triumphant ascension.
author_bios: Jesmyn Ward received her MFA from the University of Michigan and has received the MacArthur Genius Grant, a Stegner Fellowship, the Strauss Living Prize, and the 2022 Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction. She won two National Book Awards for Fiction for Sing, Unburied, Sing and Salvage the Bones. She's also the author of Where the Line Bleeds and the memoir Men We Reaped, which won the Chicago Tribune Heartland Prize. She's a professor of creative writing at Tulane University and lives in Mississippi.
quotes:
"Jesmyn is, quite simply, the best of us."

—Ta-Nehisi Coates, author of Between the World and Me

"In Let Us Descend, Jesmyn Ward resurrects an enslaved girl out of the lost folds of the antebellum South, twists magic through every raindrop, mushroom, and stalk of sugar cane, and drops you into the middle of her harrowing, unendurable, magnificent song. This is a gripping, mythic, bone-pulverizing descent into the grim darkness of American slavery—and yet somehow this novel simultaneously leaves you in awe of the human capacity to not only endure, but to ascend back to the light. A spectacular achievement."

—Anthony Doerr, author of Cloud Cuckoo Land & All The Light We Cannot See

"Overwhelming . . . This is a novel of triumph. . . . Running up against the limits of faith in the face of calamity, Annis eventually hammers out a relationship to the spirit world, complete with a rough-hewn existential philosophy that is both revolutionary and entirely consistent with the tools at her disposal."

—The Washington Post

title: Palaver
long_summary:
In Tokyo, a son works as an English tutor, drinking his nights away with friends at a gay bar. He's entangled in a sexual relationship with a married man, and while he has built a chosen family in Japan, he remains estranged from his family in Houston—particularly his mother, whose preference for his oft-troubled, homophobic brother pushed him to leave home.

Then, in the weeks leading up to Christmas, ten years since they've last seen each other, his mother arrives uninvited on his doorstep.

Separated only by the son's cat, the two bristle against each other immediately. The mother wrestles with memories of her youth in Jamaica and her own complicated brother, working to reconcile good intentions with past missteps. The son struggles to forgive. But as life steers them in unexpected directions—the mother toward a tentative friendship with a local bistro owner, the son cautiously getting to know a new patron at the bar—they begin to see each other more clearly.

Sharing meals, conversations, and an eventful trip to Nara, mother and son try their best to define where "home" really is, and whether they can find it in each other. Moving through past and present across Houston, Jamaica, and Japan, Washington's Palaver is an intricate story of family, love, and the beauty of a life among others.
short_summary: Ten years of silence end when a mother shows up uninvited at her estranged son's Tokyo apartment. Washington crafts an intricate story of family wounds and tentative healing.
author_bios: Bryan Washington is the author of Lot, Memorial, and Family Meal. A National Book Award 5 Under 35 Honoree, he won the Dylan Thomas Prize, the NYPL Young Lions Fiction Award, the Ernest J. Gaines Award, two Lambda Literary Awards, and an O. Henry Prize. He is based in Tokyo.
quotes:
"Few writers write about tenderness as Bryan Washington does—unadorned tenderness that is full of heart and humor but steers clear from familiar sentimentalities and convenient solutions. With deep understanding of human relationships, Palaver is a rare novel that offers companionship to solitary readers and lonely souls."

—Yiyun Li, author of Things in Nature Merely Grow

"Palaver is the pinnacle of what has become Washington's classic approach to writing: care, humor, tenderness, and an embrace of human beings at their most vulnerable, lovely, and wounded. It's such a joy to see the summation of his generosity of thinking and living actualized in the sentence. Fiction—no—life is better because Washington is writing."

—Ocean Vuong, author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous and Emperor of Gladness

"Bryan Washington speaks for people who have too long been silenced, and the voice he has found for them is defiant, compassionate, decent and profoundly human."

—Damon Galgut, author of The Promise

title: Holler, Child
subtitle: Stories
long_summary:
In Holler, Child's eleven brilliant stories, LaToya Watkins presses at the bruises of guilt, love, and circumstance. Each story introduces us to a character irrevocably shaped by place and reaching toward something—hope, reconciliation, freedom.

In "Cutting Horse," the appearance of a horse in a man's suburban backyard places a former horse breeder in trouble with the police. In "Holler, Child," a mother is forced into an impossible position when her son gets in a kind of trouble she knows too well from the other side. And "Time After" shows us the unshakable bonds of family as a sister journeys to find her estranged brother—the one who saved her many times over.

Throughout this collection, we see love lost and gained, and grief turned to hope. Watkins peers deeply into the lives of women and men experiencing intimate and magnificent reckonings—exploring how race, power, and inequality map onto the individual, and demonstrating the mythic proportions of everyday life.
short_summary: Eleven searingly beautiful stories about Black lives in West Texas, where guilt and love tangle in impossible knots. Watkins transforms painful reckonings into transcendent art.
author_bios: LaToya Watkins's debut novel, Perish, was published to great acclaim in 2022. Her writing has appeared in A Public Space, The Sun, McSweeney's, and the Kenyon Review. She has received grants and fellowships from the Camargo Foundation, MacDowell, and Yaddo. She lives and teaches in a suburb of Dallas.
quotes:
"With her debut book Perish, LaToya Watkins proved herself to be a masterful novelist right out of the gate.  Now, with Holler, Child, Watkins shows herself to be a master of the short story as well. Each of these gorgeous, note-perfect stories packs the full-bodied punch of a novel, but with an economy and compression that are nothing short of miraculous.  How does she do it?  I don't know, but what I do know is that I very much want her to keep doing it."

—Ben Fountain, author of National Book Award-finalist Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk

"Above all, Holler, Child is an engrossing showcase of ordinary people struggling to get by, carefully and compactly drawn… Watkins's spare, evocative prose turns painful subject matter into thoughtful, transcendent art… an unforgettable collection."

—The Washington Post

"Eleven searingly alive stories about Black men and women from West Texas explore the ways remorse and resentment can coexist in secrecy…Granular yet transcendent storytelling."

—Kirkus

title: Harlem Shuffle
long_summary:
Ray Carney is a respectable furniture salesman on 125th Street, making a modest life with his wife and daughter in 1960s Harlem. But beneath the surface, he's the son of a Harlem crook—only "slightly bent" himself.

When his cousin Freddie ropes him into fencing goods from a botched heist at the Hotel Theresa, Ray is drawn deeper into a dangerous world of corrupt cops, gangsters, hustlers, and Harlem lowlifes. As he struggles to balance his double life—striver, husband, father, and reluctant crook—Ray learns who really holds power in the city.

At once a morality play, a page-turning caper, and a love letter to Harlem, this dazzling crime novel from the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Underground Railroad and The Nickel Boys is both brilliant social portrait and joyful entertainment.
short_summary: Ray Carney sells furniture and lives respectably in 1960s Harlem—until his cousin drags him into fencing stolen goods. Whitehead crafts a brilliant crime caper that doubles as both morality play and love letter to a neighborhood.
author_bios: Colson Whitehead is the #1 New York Times bestselling author of twelve works of fiction and nonfiction, and two-time Pulitzer Prize winner for The Nickel Boys and The Underground Railroad, which also won the National Book Award. A MacArthur and Guggenheim fellow, he lives in New York City.
quotes:
"A rich, wild book that could pass for genre fiction. It's much more, but the entertainment value alone should ensure it the same kind of popular success that greeted his last two novels, The Underground Railroad and The Nickel Boys."

—Janet Maslin, The New York Times

"One of the Ten Best Books of 2021"

—Laura Miller, Slate

"Colson Whitehead has a couple of Pulitzers under his belt, along with several other awards celebrating his outstanding novels. Harlem Shuffle is a suspenseful crime thriller that's sure to add to the tally — it's a fabulous novel you must read."

—NPR

title: Now Is Not the Time to Panic
long_summary:
Sixteen-year-old Frankie Budge—aspiring writer, indifferent student, offbeat loner—is determined to survive another dreary summer in Coalfield, Tennessee, when she meets Zeke, a talented artist who's just moved into his grandmother's house. Both lonely and awkward, they strike up an unexpected connection that sparks romance and creativity.

Together, they create an unsigned poster featuring an enigmatic phrase: "The edge is a shantytown filled with gold seekers. We are fugitives, and the law is skinny with hunger for us." The mysterious posters begin appearing everywhere, captivating anyone who sees them. But as rumors spread—Satanists, kidnappers—the town erupts into panic, and their art threatens to tear them apart.

Twenty years later, Frances Eleanor Budge is now a famous author with a loving family and carefully constructed life. Then journalist Mazzy Brower calls about the Coalfield Panic of 1996, threatening to unravel everything Frances has built.

Written with Wilson's trademark wit and blazing prose, this nuanced exploration of young love, identity, and art's power examines the secrets that haunt us and what truth ultimately sets free.
short_summary: Two misfit teenagers create mysterious art that sends their small Tennessee town into a panic. Twenty years later, one of them—now a successful novelist—must confront the past when a journalist comes calling.
author_bios: Kevin Wilson is the New York Times bestselling author of five novels, including Now Is Not the Time to Panic, Nothing to See Here, and The Family Fang, as well as two story collections. His work has received the Shirley Jackson Award and been selected as a Read with Jenna book club pick. He lives in Sewanee, Tennessee, with his wife and two sons.
quotes:
"This is a wildly funny, wonderfully sincere — and a little bit devastating — story of art, our limitless past, future nostalgia and all those perfectly imperfect ways we continually come of age. Kevin Wilson's books are so full of heart. They're utterly indelible."

—Courtney Summers, The Washington Post

"Wilson's fiction will have you laughing so much that you're not prepared for the gut punch that follows. . . . Now Is Not the Time to Panic is the heartfelt culmination of many years (and many pages) spent probing the tension between the urge to make a mark on the world and the costs of doing so—and the push-pull between art's disorienting and generative powers. . . . Go read Wilson's books. You'll discover one-of-a-kind worlds opening up."

—The Atlantic

"Now Is Not the Time to Panic is a quirky, complicated story about the power of words and art, and the importance of adolescent friendships."

—Time

title: The Family Fang
long_summary:
Mr. and Mrs. Fang called it art. Their children called it mischief.

Performance artists Caleb and Camille Fang dedicated themselves to making great art. But when an artist's work lies in subverting normality, it can be difficult to raise well-adjusted children. Just ask Buster and Annie Fang. For as long as they can remember, they starred unwillingly in their parents' madcap pieces, growing up in the fishbowl of their parents' strange world.

Now that they're adults, the chaos of their childhood has made it difficult to cope with life outside their family's bizarre universe. When the lives they've built come crashing down, brother and sister have nowhere to go but home, where they discover that Caleb and Camille are planning one last performance—their magnum opus—whether the kids agree to participate or not.

Soon, ambition breeds conflict, bringing the Fangs to face the difficult decision about what's ultimately more important: their family or their art. Filled with Wilson's endless creativity, vibrant prose, and sharp humor, The Family Fang is a masterfully executed tale that is as bizarre as it is touching.
short_summary: Two adult siblings return home to find their performance artist parents planning one final art piece. Wilson navigates this complex psychological terrain with humor and heart, examining what happens when family and art collide.
author_bios: Kevin Wilson is the New York Times bestselling author of five novels, including Now Is Not the Time to Panic, Nothing to See Here, and The Family Fang, as well as two story collections. His work has received the Shirley Jackson Award and been selected as a Read with Jenna book club pick. He lives in Sewanee, Tennessee, with his wife and two sons.
quotes:
"It's such a minty fresh delight to open up Kevin Wilson's debut novel, The Family Fang, and feel the revitalizing blast of original thought; robust invention; screwball giddiness. Every copy of The Family Fang sold in August should have a sticker on it imprinted with the life-giving invitation that used to be issued on movie marquees in summertime during the dawn of the air-conditioning age: "Come on in! It's cooool inside!" …a family story that's out-of-the-box, and funny, and, also, genuinely moving. Wilson's inventive genius never stops for a rest break. He spins out entertaining scenarios for the Fang performance pieces, as well as loony summaries for Buster's novels and Annie's movies, as well as what unfolds as the present-time suspense plot of the disappearance of Caleb and Camille. Is it genuine or is it yet another Fang performance piece? Early on in the novel, we're told that the strange art the Fangs create has been glowingly described by critics as "choreographed spontaneity." Wilson might as well have been writing a review for his own strange and wonderful novel, for The Family Fang indeed reads as a work of "choreographed spontaneity" that will linger in your mind long after the mall has closed and the mess in the restaurant has been cleaned up."

—NPR

"Inventive and hilarious. This is complex psychological ground, and the 32-year-old Mr. Wilson navigates it with a calm experience that his tender age shouldn't allow."

—The Wall Street Journal

"Wilson's creative and funny novel examines two young lives in the process of getting skewed, all in the pursuit of art with a capital A."

—Entertainment Weekly
